Project Name: Avalon Professional Web Trade Pte. Ltd.
Company Name: AVALON PROFESSIONAL WEB TRADE PTE. LTD.
Project Description: APW is a new trading company, based in Singapore, that sources purchase orders (POs) for home furnishings from US buyers, and subcontracts production on the POs to SME manufacturers, that form part of the APW network, in the Philippines. The APW network is comprised of SME furniture manufacturers that are prequalified by APW, based on their product quality, production reliability, environmental standards, size, export experience, proprietor quality and various other criteria. The SMEs, that are part of the APW network, benefit from APW''s marketing activities abroad as well as financing for pre-export activities such as raw material procurement and labor cost.  APW''s expansion plan includes extending the APW network to China, Indonesia and Thailand. This expansion strategy will enable APW to offer a product line to meet the full market demand ranging from high end, high craftsmanship, high margin products, to lower end, lower margin products, mass produced. Furthermore, the geographic expansion will allow APW to take advantage of raw materials indigenous to each region. This expansive product line supports APW''s strategy to offer international buyers quality products sourced from Asia for competitive prices.IFC''s investment in APW is a pioneering replicable model to promote SME development through broad investment.  APW will: (i) help SMEs obtain much needed working capital financing, presently unavailable due to the SMEs size and lack of collateral;  (ii) increase SME''s market reach; (iii) create a conduit through which SMEs can benefit from volume raw material discounts;  (iv) encourage international buyers to source production from the emerging markets in South East Asia. APW''s local production monitoring provides international buyers additional comfort to outsource such production to the Philippines. APW''s success will translate into growth in furniture exports from Cebu and as APW expands, throughout the region.  Being part of the APW manufacturing network will also promote greater transparency and an adequate level of environmental standards amongst the SMEs. The World Bank''s main focus in the Philippines is poverty reduction facilitated through enhanced economic growth. This project fits well with the World Bank strategy as SMEs are a major source of employment and wage income for a local labor force suffering from high unemployment. IFC''s investment in APW is also consistent with IFC''s strategy to finance SMEs through broad investment rather than directly in the SMEs.  Furthermore, the SME sector is one of the most dynamic sectors essential for the necessary economic growth in the Philippines. Therefore, APW contributes to improve the growth potential of SMEs by providing access to efficient financing and facilitating access to global markets.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project, and the following potential environmental, health and safety impacts of the project were analysed:  development and implementation of an Environmental Management System, implementation of a system for accrediting and monitoring environmental and social status of suppliers, air, water and solid waste emissions, fire safety and emergency response, general worker health and safety and sourcing of sustainable wood supplies.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityAPW will post environmental documents for public review at the Government Building, Governors Office in Cebu city.
Sponsor: The sponsors of APW are listed below.  They are also the major shareholders of the company.Gary Leonard Koh, Chairman of the Board (1.74%) -Mr. Koh  has over 20 years of experience in the areas of technology and software design.  He was one of the founders of Pacific Internet and an early stage investor and serves on the Board of Advisors of Interwoven, Inc.  Mr. Koh was formerly Director for e-commerce at Sun Microsystems in Asia-South. Mr. Koh spent 10 years at the Singapore National Computer Board where he was Head of Planning and Communications for the Singapore Government Computerisation.  Currently, Mr. Koh runs Fresh Chilli Pte Ltd, an e-commerce incubator in Singapore.Mariano V. Osmena, Chief Executive Officer/Member of the Board (24.87%) - Mr. Osmena has 19 years of work experience in the United States and in the Philippines in banking, technology, property, manufacturing and trading. Mr. Osmena was CEO for MRC Allied Industry from 1993 until early 1997. He also owns and runs the Philippine On-Line (POL) partner in Cebu and Works of Wonder.  POL is a traditional ISP, serving individual and small businesses in Cebu. Works of Wonder is a small chain of Internet cafes located in Manila and Cebu. The Osmena family is highly respected in the Philippines with several members of the family having held public offices (former President, Senators, and a former Governor of Cebu).Tze Guan Ong, Member of the Board/Chief Technical Officer (19.48%)- Mr. Ong has over 10 years experience in the field of engineering, management, and finance. Mr. Ong is currently Managing Director of Glowtec, a civil engineering firm based in Singapore. Mr. Ong''s father was President of Singapore and retired from politics in September of 1999.Richard S. Wright, Member of the Board/Managing Director  USA (25.3%) - Mr. Wright has founded five companies in the San Francisco bay area in the financial and technology fields. His core business is a California Certified Public Accounting firm, which has completed international transactions since 1980. His other active companies are in the computer systems and design area. He is also a cofounder of a business valuation firm, which values businesses throughout the United States for merger, acquisition, estate, and litigation purposes.
Cost Nature: The total company capitalization following IFC''s equity investment would be approximately US$2.25 million. It is anticipated that IFC would make an equity investment of up to US$1.0 million in this first round of financing. Project Description: Probusinessbank was founded in 1993 as a full service commercial bank by a group of graduates from the top Moscow universities. The initial capital came from companies in the chemical, construction, food production and machinery industries. At the end 1999 it had assets of $92 million and equity of $9 million equivalent. The bank''s business focus is on lending to mid-sized corporates and small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs).The investment will strengthen Probusinessbank capital base which was seriously eroded as a result of the 1998 crisis in the banking sector. It will also provide long-term funding to support the bank''s business development program, particularly the expansion of lending to mid-sized corporates and SMEs. On a selective basis the bank will also be able to start offering longer maturities to its strongest clients. The investment will be accompanied by a donor-funded program of technical assistance to upgrade the bank''s practices, systems and technologies. Currently there are virtually no commercial sources of long-term funding for Russian-owned banks, unless they belong to one of the big financial industrial groups. IFC''s financing will strengthen Probusinessbank''s balance sheet and provide resources to expand its lending activities without compromising its independence. The financing will be combined with a program of technical assistance to improve the bank''s operations. IFC''s presence as an investor in the bank may also help it attract foreign strategic investors, once the country conditions improve.The Russian financial sector is seriously undeveloped and does not function efficiently either in mobilizing or allocating resources. The resulting shortage of financing is a major constraint to the development of the productive sector of the economy. This project will contribute to rehabilitate and restore confidence in the Russian financial sector by helping a viable bank, that has the potential to become a leader in the commercial banking industry and provide credit to help the development of productive enterprises. It will also stand as a model for other similar institutions to follow its lead. The investment will also allow the bank to increase its lending, with longer maturities, to mid-sized Russian corporates and SMEs, thus supporting a sector of the economy which will be a key to achieving sustained economic growth and generating employment in the next few years.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category FI Type I project according to IFC''s environmental review procedure. PBB will be required to establish an environmental management system that will - ensure that investments are consistent with applicable host country environmental laws and regulations;- designate appropriate individuals who will have responsibility for environment; - submit an environmental management plan as a condition of disbursement; and- provide annual environmental performance reports.The Environment Division has already provided in-country environmental training to PBB.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community

They do not own a stake of more than 20% and are as follows: - Predpatie Torgovo-Machinostrotelnoi 20.0%- Probusiness Real Estate Agency 19.5%- NPC Khimplast 19.5%- Teploenergoviaz 19.5%- Rodina Insurance 8.9%- Prime Rate Investment Co. 8.8%The bank is independent from the large financial industrial groups which dominate large parts of the Russian economy.
Cost Nature: The proposed investment is a $5 million subordinated convertible loan for IFC''s own account.

Project Description: The CompanyPT. Indorama Synthetics Tbk is a successful, export-oriented, internationally competitive manufacturer of polyester filament and spun yarns, polyester fabric and bottle grade PET resin. IFC has made several loans to Indorama and is the second largest shareholder in the company.  Indorama has three main operating divisions:1. Spinning Division - It produces different types and blends of polyester yarns, as well as viscose and acrylic yarns;2. Polyester Division - It includes fibre, yarns (filament and draw-texturized yarns) and PET resin production operations; and3. Fabrics Division - It is a relatively small division that accounts for less than 10% of total revenues. The operations focus on value-added products, both grey fabrics (i.e. unprinted fabrics) and printed fabrics.In 1999, the company produced about 148,000 tons of polyester filament yarn and polyester staple fiber, 31,000 tons of spun yarn, 76,000 tons of PET resin and 22 million meters of grey fabrics. Production levels were consistently equal to, or above, rated capacity for all major production units.  The company is a proven exporter and, in 1999, generated over 60% of its revenues via exports principally to Europe, United States, Australia and the Middle East.  	Indorama has been able to consistently generate operating profits and robust cash flows even through the Asian economic crisis and the adverse economic conditions in Indonesia, which is reflective of its strong operating fundamentals. The company is also current on all its debt obligations. Based on its historical cash flows, liquidity position, and improving debt service coverage, the company appears to be strong from a credit quality perspective. However, with the bunching of debt repayments in the future, the company may face potential difficulties in servicing its debt obligations from internal cash flows. Recognizing this potential problem, Indorama proposes to issue a 5-year bond and refinance some of its existing debt. This would strengthen its future financial position as its future debt service obligations will better match its cash flows.		The ProjectIndorama plans to issue an IDR 1 trillion, 5-year bond in early 2001. The proceeds of the bond issue will be used to (i) prepay, in 2001, the net US$80 million bullet payment, due in March 2002, under the syndicated loan arranged by Deutsche Morgan Grenfell (DMG Loan), and (ii) strengthen the companys working capital needs. The proposed bond issue would strengthen the companys future financial position, as its future debt service obligations will be rescheduled to better match its cash flows. As an export-oriented company with more than 60% of its revenues in US$, Indorama received an approval from BAPEPAM (the Indonesian securities and exchange authority) to report its financial statement in US$.  Historically, Indorama has maintained its assets and liabilities in US$ to avoid any currency mismatches. Therefore, in line with its past practice, Indorama intends to swap the IDR bond proceeds into US$ at the prevailing exchange rate.  Based on Indoramas request, IFC is considering assisting the company in structuring and arranging the aforementioned swap.IFC Role Assist Indonesian Corporate: IFCs strategy in Indonesia focuses on assisting internationally competitive domestic companies to recover from the crisis. This involves assisting IFCs portfolio companies through financial restructuring and, where appropriate, providing additional working capital, long-term funding as well as other financial instruments to maintain necessary balance sheet flexibility and diversify available sources of funding. IFCs endorsement of both existing and new projects should signal to other investors IFCs continuing confidence in the long-term prospects of the Indonesian economy.  Promotion of Risk Management Product: Although clients usually swap IDR payments for US$ payments, this transaction provides the reverse -- it swaps US$ payments for IDR payments as the Company has dollarized accounts.  However, the broad implications of this transaction -- a first for IFC in Indonesia -- will serve as an example of how corporations can manage currency mismatches on their balance sheet and thereby reduce overall risks. Although the Indonesian corporates are seeking such risk management products, they are unable to obtain such products on a cost-effective basis.This ia due to the resistance from swap counterparties to enter into long-term contracts as a result of the high country risk associated with Indonesia. IFC''s intimate knowledge of Indorama''s performance allows us to be comfortable with the credit risk and intermediating swap, thereby allowing Indorama to manage its balance sheet risks in a cost-effective manner.   Development Impact:IFCs investment at this time will have two significant demonstration effects in the decimated Indonesian corporate scene: (i) IFC''s assistance in arranging the swap will send a positive signal to international investors and restore some of the confidence in the Indonesian private sector severely undermined by the Asian economic crisis; and (ii) IFC''s support to Indorama will demonstrate that, in an environment where a majority of companies are not current on their debt service and where implementation of debt restructuring is slow, borrowers who meet their obligations will gain support from the lending community. Furthermore, the introduction, through this project, of a risk management tool for use by Indonesian corporates would be an example of how companies could manage balance sheet exposures to currency mismatches and prevent adverse exposures to currency volatilities.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category C project, according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because it is likely to have minimal or no adverse environmental impacts.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The project sponsor is the Lohia Family, which is a well established Indonesian business group of Indian origin. Mr. S. P. Lohia is the Vice President Director of PT. Indorama Synthetics Tbk (Indorama or the company). He is involved in the day-to-day management of Indorama and is responsible for the growth of the company over the past twenty years.Indorama is an Indonesian company that is listed on the Jakarta and Surabaya Stock Exchanges of Indonesia. It is owned 51% by the Lohia Family, 7.3% by IFC and the rest is widely held by the public. As of December 31, 2000, Indorama''s shareholders are as follows:PT. Irama Unggul, Indonesia: 37.82%Indorama International Finance Plc., UK: 13.19%International Finance Corporation: 7.34%Public: 41.65% (Foreign: 41.09%,  Local: 0.56%)
Cost Nature: The project involves arranging a IDR - US$ swap for Indorama to swap the company''s proposed IDR 1 trillion bond issue. Swapping IDR 1 trillion (approximately US$108 million) of notional principal gives IFC a loan equivalent exposure of about US$20 million (about 18.5% of the notional amount). Although this is a contingent exposure for IFC under the swap, it will be booked as an  A Loan for IFC''s own account.

Project Description: The project South Pacific Project Facility (SPPF III), is a proposal for the second extension of the South Pacific Project Facility (the SPPF or the facility), for another five-year period: namely, from 2001 to 2005. SPPF is a technical assistance project established in 1990 by the IFC and with financial support from various donors. The mission of SPPF is to assist and accelerate the development of productive, self-sustaining small and medium-sized private sector enterprises (SMEs) in IFC''s Pacific Member Island Countries (PIMCs).  In recognition of the facility''s important contribution to business development in the region, the first SPPF extension was approved in 1995 for a five-year period up to December 31, 2000.Under SPPF III, the facility will pursue the two-fold strategy: (i) to continue to provide direct investment assistance to entrepreneurs; and (ii) to broaden support to SMEs directly and indirectly by introducing, with the SME Departments support, new products and services, utilizing e-business opportunities, thus creating a comprehensive system of small business promotion. To this end, the facility will deliver the following expanded program activities:A.  Enterprise Level Support - through (i) assistance to enterprises in project preparation, in project structuring, and in raising financing; and (ii) broader technical assistance programs to help individual enterprises overcome internal capacity constraints for their development. B. Capacity-building Work and Indirect Assistance by (i) creating sustainable local capacity to deliver SME support services through the strengthening and further development of local agents, consultants, and institutional strengthening targeted at business and industry associations; (ii) promoting financial sector development, focusing on institutional strengthening of funding source and capacity building of financial institutions, through transfer of modern lending techniques (such as cash-flow based loan screening and evaluation systems, risk management and client tracking systems), introduction of new information management systems, and new financial products and services tailored to the SME needs; (iii) expanding access to information technology by engaging the private sector, donors, and investors in determining the best way to facilitate the use of the Internet-based technologies in accessing market and business information, and in delivering Internet promotion training; and (iv) cooperation and contribution to policy dialogue with donors, World Bank and IFC.IFC has taken the lead in designing, funding and managing SPPF. The facility is headed by a Regional Manager, who is a senior staff member seconded from the IFC. IFC provides general administrative and operational guidance (through the SME Department), funding support (through both SME and IFC Trust Funds Departments), technical inputs (through the Industry and Specialists Departments), resource management support (through the Human Resource Department) and back-office accounting (through both the World Bank and IFC Controllers Departments). In addition, the SME Department provides the link between SPPF and IFC, and coordinates SPPF''s operations with other regional development initiatives in the Bank Group. This relationship gives SPPF access to IFC''s unique expertise in small business development and ensures cross-fertilization, through transfer of knowledge and best practices, among the existing facilities and other SME programs in the Bank Group. The IFCs ten Pacific Islands Member Countries (PIMCs) are relatively small, open economies with limited diversification and institutional capacity. They are vulnerable to external economic and environmental shocks, and have limited or non-existent access to global capital markets. Despite very high inflows of aid, economic performance in the PIMCs has been modest and varied considerably across the countries. The structure of PIMCs economies reflects domination of the public sector and the role of private sector has remained small. Apart from being crowded out by the government, the private sector has also been constrained by lack of human capacity, difficulties in obtaining secure access to land due to traditional land tenure practices, and difficulties in obtaining access to finance. In addition, the remoteness and isolation of the countries from major centers of trade and commerce makes it more difficult to compensate for the limited domestic markets. High transportation and infrastructure costs limit business opportunities. Through its activities for enterprise level support, capacity-building, and dissemination of best practices, SPPF will continue to work towards alleviating these constraints to private SMEs development. In addition, the facility will continue to build a sustainable local capacity to deliver the type of services SPPF would be providing.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category C project according to IFC''s Procedures for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because it is likely to have minimal or no adverse environmental impact. Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The project sponsors are IFC and other international donors. Major prospective donors include the Governments of Australia, Japan and New Zealand.
Cost Nature: Total funding requirements for SPPF III over a five-year period (2001 to 2005) are estimated at US$ 10.5 million, of which about US$ 1.2 million are expected to be generated from fees charged for SPPF''s services.  IFC would provide US$ 2.1 million, about 20% of the total funding requirements.Fundraising for SPPF III was discussed during the November 1999 donors meeting. All the donors present, including the representatives of Governments from the region, confirmed their interest and willingness to continue financial support for SPPF. Fundraising from all donors will be officially launched immediately after the Boards approval, to ensure that the funding is in place on time to continue the facility without any slowdown after December 31, 2000.  A SPPF donors meeting, chaired by IFC, will be held in February 2001 in Sydney. The donors will then be requested to make formal commitments towards the funding needed for SPPF III.
Location: SPPF headquarters are in Sydney, Australia. A satellite office is located in Port Moresby, Papua New Guinea.  In addition, SPPF has developed a network of agents in almost all countries where it operates: Papua New Guinea, Fiji, Federal States of Micronesia, Kiribati, Palau, Republic of Marshall Islands, Samoa, Solomon Islands, Tonga and Vanuatu.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category C project according to IFC''s Procedures for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because it is likely to have minimal or no adverse environmental impact. Location of environmental documents In locally affected community

Project Description: The company plans to create a franchisee network to use PV pumps in order to extract water which it will then purify, package, and retail as drinking water to domestic and commercial customers. The project aims to demonstrate the competitive use of PV-powered water pumping technology to produce products close to final point of consumption, especially when the grid is unavailable or unreliable.The project is financed by the IFC/GEF Photovoltaic Market Transformation Initiative (PVMTI). PVMTI aims to address market barriers by making available appropriate financing, stimulating business activity, and accelerating PV penetration to achieve reductions in greenhouse gases. By harnessing the innovation and discipline of the private sector in designing and implementing PV projects, IFC is helping to shift the design and financing of PV market activity to a more sustainable and replicable private sector context.By investing PVMTI funds in the project, IFC intends to support the demonstration of a successful and replicable business model for the Indian, as well as other developing country, PV markets.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: Aquasolar is a recently established, wholly-owned subsidiary of Total Solar Energie India Pvt. Ltd. (TSEI). TSEI is owned 51 percent by Total Energie S.A., a photovoltaic systems integration company incorporated in France, and 49 percent by New Millennium Energy Investments Pvt. Ltd., an investment company incorporated in India. The project encompasses the development of a network of PV-pumping, purification, and bottling stations for drinking water. It will also include the establishment of a franchising operation for the sales of drinking water in India. The company will partner with Bhartiya Samruddhi Finance Limited (BASIX), a micro-finance organisation based in Hyderabad, who will identify franchisees on behalf of the company.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is of $8,330,000, with an IFC/GEF PVMTI loan, equity, and grant investment of $3,000,000.
Location: Aquasolar is headquartered in Hyderabad, India. The project will take place in southern India, initially in Andhra Pradesh.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community

Project Description: OCPL is an existing company with a capacity to make around 665tpa cephalosporins and other pharmaceutical products at Alathur near Chennai. More than 80% of its production is currently exported to Asia, the Middle-East. Small quantities also go  to Latin America. The turnover for the current year, ending March 2001, is estimated at US$89 million. The company is expecting  to earn a net profit of US$8.5 million. The project envisages expansion and diversification of the company''s product mix and geographical reach so as to include developed countries and as to be able to sustain its business even after WTO regulations are in place.With its support to OCPL, IFC will assist a medium-sized company to grow and transform itself from a bulk drug company into a well-integrated pharmaceutical company with strong capabilities in research and formulations business. In this way, OCPL would be in a position to sustain its growth and profitabilty and expand its operations into the regulated markets.The project will significantly demonstrate how domestic companies can shift gears to meet emerging challenges (WTO induced regulatory reforms) and simultaneously use their strong comparative advantages, of low cost production and pool of trained scientists, to exploit the opportunities that are likely to be available in the domestic market.

Sponsor: The project sponsor is Orchid Chemicals and Pharmaceuticals Limited (OCPL)  a professionally managed company set up in 1992 by Mr. K. R. Rao, a first generation entrepreneur. Initially, OCPL had agreements with two Italian companies for providing technical know-how. Today OCPL continues to collaborate with them on ad hoc basis. The company has strong research and development capabilities that have been critical in providing improvements and new processes for its continued growth and competitiveness on the market. Of OCPL''s total equity, presently 27% is held by the sponsors and collaborators (comprising 16.5% held by Mr Rao and his management team, 3.87% held by collaborators and the balance held by associates), 38% is with Schroders ventures and the balance by the public and other financial institutions.

The three sites at Alathur, Irungatukottai and Aurangabad are located in special industrial areas, developed by the state industrial development corporations, and have adequate infrastructure by way of roads, telecommunications and power. Skilled manpower is easily available.

Project Description: In the late 80s, the sponsor created a dairy which produces pasteurised milk packs from cows, camels and goats. Tivisky is today the first camel dairy in Africa, its whole production (mainly from cows) amounts to about 15,000 l./day. This average level can noticeably vary, firmly depending on the season. As pasteurised milk can not be kept more than a few days, the promoter wants to build a sterilised cow milk production unit. The sterilisation process will use the UHT (Ultra High Temperature) technology and requires a specific investment. Target completion date is December 2001. The total production of the whole dairy will amount to about 40,000 l./day. Tivisky will benefit from the technical and commercial assistance provided by the French major milk company SODIAAL.The creation of a new production activity will have beneficial consequences for:-The producer: this new range of investment will contribute to strengthening a recent small-sized company, and thus will trigger the need of additional workforce.-The milk industry: although Mauritania is a milk consumer country, unlike other African countries, it has not developed a sufficient inner production, and has to import European sterilised milk. Sterilised milk is all the more important in Mauritania as it can be kept without cooling systems. The construction of a local dairy, which would meet hygiene and environmental standards, will support the development of this branch of the Mauritanian food-processing industry.-Agriculture: collecting milk from small and medium-sized producers at different places in Mauritania (up to 200km from Nouakchott) will contribute to providing those populations with a regular income. Consequently, they will be led to improve the quality and size of their production.-Gender promotion: TiviskiI S.A.R.L. is managed by a woman. Moreover, in some southern areas, the collecting system involves directly women, who own their cattle.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. As per the Agreement signed between IFC and Proparco, the disclosure rules call for release of the SPI 45 prior to commitment of the loan documents between the sponsor and the lenders. The Board date above is the expected date of commitment.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityTiviski S.A.R.L.BP 2069Nouakchott-Mauritanie
Sponsor: Tiviski S.A.R.L. is 100% owned and managed by Mrs. Nancy Abeiderrahmane, a Mauritanian citizen, and her children.
Cost Nature: The project cost amounts to EUR 2.4M, and it will finance new production assets. The financing plan includes a EUR 0.75M Proparco loan, a EUR 0.75M IFC loan, and a EUR 0.9M equity.

Project Description: The project consists of providing Sigma with up US$3 million in equity financing to help finance the expansion of its operations in the Indonesian market as well as in the U.S. and European markets. This would allow Sigma to continue to meet the growing demand for its services, particularly in the software development sector. The expansion would include: (i) funding Sigma''s market expansion through the establishment of U.S. and European based offices; and (ii) financing the purchase of computer hardware, software tools and infrastructure support such as communication links, call centers and other physical facilities in Indonesia. The project will have significant developmental impact by: (i) potentially creating several hundred, highly skilled software services jobs in Indonesia; and (ii) helping to train skilled workers in Indonesia by exposure to best practices from US and Europe.IFC''s participation would encourage other local and foreign institutions to invest in Sigma in future rounds as well as increase the group''s credibility with major global companies in securing additional contracts. IFC has also advised the company in its on-going restructuring efforts to streamline its corporate and shareholding structures under a single holding company. IFC could also introduce its existing portfolio clients (especially in the financial sector) to Sigma in order to IT-enable these clients with best-of-breed solutions that Sigma offers. IFC''s ICT department will bring its global knowledge to help Sigma fulfill its growth strategy.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.  Environmental, social and health and safety issues, which may be associated with this type of project, and that will be reviewed during project appraisal, include: land acquisition process and arrangements, land use planning and permitting, impacts to cultural heritage, direct and indirect impacts to natural habitats, water supply and liquid effluent treatment and disposal, solid waste disposal arrangements and adequacy, use of CFCs in air conditioning and refrigeration equipment, fire protection and life safety, including emergency response plans, general employee health and safety and training programs, and adherence to IFC Environmental and Social and Internet Projects exclusion lists in all Internet (e-Commerce) operations.   Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The Sigma Group consists of several companies that are employee/management-owned.  In order to streamline the organizational structure and rationalize the business segments, upon IFC''s advise, the various companies are being consolidated under a single holding company: PT Sigma Cipta Caraka (Sigma, or the company). Sigma has an experienced management team with deep domain expertise in the IT services industry. Cost Nature: The estimated project cost is approximately US$6.5 million over a 2 year period. The proposed IFC investment consists of an equity investment of up to US$3 million in the company. The remaining funding needs will be met via cash flow from operations.

Project Description: The project comprises the doubling of the capacity of the Mozal I aluminium smelter to produce an additional 250,000 tons per annum (tpa) of aluminium metal. Mozal I, to which IFC has existing loan commitments totalling US$120 million, has already produced first metal and is currently nearing completion, six months ahead of schedule and at about US$130 million below the budgeted project cost of US$1,340 million. Mozal I was designed with the Mozal II expansion in mind. In the existing site there is space for the installation of duplicate potline, anode baking, and casthouse facilities. Outside the main site, the only significant additional facilities required will be a second ship unloader and storage facilities at the port -all to be constructed within the existing boundaries of Mozal''s quay- to handle the extra raw materials, and an extra 132kV transmission line from the nearby substation. The project will have significant development impact. Mozambique''s net foreign exchange earnings will increase by over US$100 million, and GDP will increase by an estimated 3.5%. During construction, the project will employ an estimated 5,000 people, with 295 direct and 1,500 indirect jobs being created during operation. Opportunities for local small and medium sized enterprises (SMEs) are expected to be created through Mozal''s policy of out-sourcing all non-core activities to local companies. The import of project inputs from South Africa should further stimulate regional trade and integration. Lastly, with an expected annual spending of the order of US$2 million on social and community initiatives, the Mozal Trust will work to ensure the sustainability of the project''s impact on the local people. IFC''s role will be to: co-ordinate all the lenders for the approximately US$600 million debt package; ensure that the project meets IFC''s environmental and social policies and guidelines; encourage SME development around the project; and, through its continued investment in the country, provide reassurance to potential investors in other Mozambican projects.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an environmental and social review category A project.  Issues include air emissions (fluoride and SO2), wastewater and storm water management and discharge schemes, waste management including hazardous waste, and the incremental impacts of increased production on air quality and road traffic, including noise and safety. The sponsor is formulating appropriate management and mitigation actions based on the project''s Phase I experience, which included involuntary resettlement and management of induced impacts. The project provides opportunities for the expansion of existing sponsor-supported community development activities including agricultural improvement, SME promotion, malaria control and HIV-AIDS awareness for the population living in the project area.  No involuntary resettlement is associated with this expansion project.  Annual environmental monitoring reports (AMRs) will be required which detail project performance against the requirements of these documents, host country regulation and any other requirements incorporated into the investment agreement.  The AMR must be completed or verified for completeness and accuracy by an independent consultant acceptable to IFC.  A preliminary public consultation and disclosure plan (PCDP) was submitted to the Environment and Social Review Unit for review and approval.  The sponsor will give public notification and make the draft EIA report available at a public place readily accessible to project stakeholders as early as possible and no later than 60 days prior to the proposed Board date.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityEnvironmental documents will be available at the IFC/World Bank office, Avenue Kenneth Kaunda 1224, Maputo,  at the National Library in Maputo, the library at the National University, and the office of the district administrator of Beluluane (project location).
Sponsor: The primary sponsor of Mozal II is Billiton plc., with an equity stake of at least 47%. Billiton is a publicly traded international mining and metal group which specialises in the exploration, production, and marketing of alumina and aluminium products. Titanium minerals, steel, ferroalloys, nickel, coal and base metals are also produced. Other shareholders include Mitsubishi Corporation, a Japanese trading company, the Industrial Development Corporation (IDC), a South African developmental financial institution, and the Government of Mozambique.
Cost Nature: The estimated project cost is US$992 million, of which US$600 million will be loans. The proposed IFC investment will amount to a US$25 million loan for IFC''s own account.
Investment: 25.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan25.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative

Company Name: Ningxia Darong Chemicals And Metallurgy Co., Ltd.
Project Description: The project will finance:1) an expansion of the calcium cyanamide production from 50,000 tons per annum(tpa) to 150,000 tpa; and 2) the environmental upgrades of 3 existing calcium carbide furnaces, in oder to reduce air emissions and to recover waste heat to generate steam needed for the expansion.IFC''s investment will help Darong increase economies of scale and further strengthen its position as a low-cost producer of specialized calcium cyanamide, and its derivative products, in both domestic and International markets. IFC''s investment will: promote local private sector development; improve living strandards in Northwest China; and will help alleviate proverty in this remote and less developed region.  Through the increased production of the company, the project will provide employment opportunities at a time when local state-owned enterprises are laying off workers.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityEnvironment documents will be posted at the Gate of Darong Company, in addition, Darong will place an ad in Ningxia Daily Paper for three days, informing the public where the environmental documents are available for public viewing.
Sponsor: The project sponsor is Darong Chemicals and Metallurgy Company Ltd. (Darong or the company). Located in Shizuishan City, Ningxia Autonomous Region, P.R.C, the company was established in 1993. Privately-held, Darong is the largest producer of calcium cyanamide and the only exporter of granulated calcium cyanamide in China. The company is owned by Hong Kong Sheng Rong investment Company Ltd. (25.6%)and by Dawukou Ferroalloys Company (74.4%). Both companies are 100% family-owned.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is US$30 million. The proposed IFC investment will amount to US$18 million, consisting of a US$10 million A Loan for IFC''s own account, and a US$8 million B Loan for the account of participants.
Investment: 11.50 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan10.0Equity1.50* These investment figures are indicative

A major industrial center of Northwest China, Shizuishan city is located in the autonomous region of Ningxia, at about 70km north of Yinchuan city (the region''s capital). The project will be realized within the 112 acres of the company''s plant site.

Project Description: TV Africa is a content provider that offers its affiliates high quality programming in exchange for: a) airtime in which to place network and regional advertising that is sold directly by TV Africa; and b) a share of the local advertising revenue that is generated by the affiliates themselves. The company''s network currently provides advertisers and sponsors with a single point of access to a pan-African audience. It also offers access to audiences on a regional basis.IFC''s financing would assist TV Africa with its ongoing development program by providing capital with which the company can finance the strengthening of its affiliate network, purchase and produce content, secure programming rights, put in place infrastructure, and finance start up costs and working capital requirements. TV Africa estimates that it will require up to US$40 million of equity financing and IFC has been asked to provide up to US$10 million of this amount to complete the financing plan. The balance of the financing requirement will be provided by other institutional investors. Development Impact:TV Africa will assist in the development of local programming content.  One of the key success factors of TV Africa is its ability to deliver quality local programming content, which is desired by TV Africas viewers, potential advertisers and affiliates. TV Africa intends to develop further its local content through a combination of co-production, commissions and the acquisition of rights. This will lead to the strengthening of a number of firms involved in the writing, producing and processing of such content. These firms are often small and medium sized enterprises, which provide employment to a large proportion of the African creative talent not employed by governments.TV Africa will help to strengthen its affiliate partners. In Africas recently liberalised television market, private sector operators are generally undercapitalised and financially weak. Unable to acquire quality programming, these companies often lack the technical and managerial ability to operate as successful commercial TV stations. Affiliation with TV Africa enables these small operators to address their problems by obtaining: a) technical advice, in order to address their technical and managerial shortcomings; b) access to a broader audience, thus increasing the rates at which advertising can be sold; c) an increase in transmission hours, at little extra cost, augmenting their potential revenue.  Moreover, being part of the TV Africa network also encourages cooperation between affiliates (for example in sharing equipment).TV Africa will continue to provide educational programming and take part in HIV/AIDS and other health and social awareness campaigns. TV Africa currently provides up to 5 hours per day of educational programming. This programming, which has a strong following in a number of countries, covers a wide range of areas, including a high school equivalency program and subjects such as finance, accounting, and computing. In addition, TV Africa also airs programming aimed at increasing awareness about HIV/AIDS and other health and social issues. In connection with the last World AIDS Day, TV Africa  aired various documentaries about the disease and carried AIDS-related public service announcements prepared by the World Bank and UNAIDS. TV Africa is a platform for public service announcements.  TV Africa is currently used by various NGOs and various bi- and multi-lateral organizations as a vehicle for public service announcements on various issues.TV Africa will assist in the media liberalization process currently underway in a number of African countries.  By strengthening the competitive position of its affiliates, introducing economies of scale in the production and acquisition of programming, and creating regional markets for advertising, TV Africa will contribute to the development of sustainable competitors in the newly liberalized African media market.  This will in turn provide broader access to high quality programming in a continent where less than 0.5% of the owners of television sets have access to pay-TV options such as satellite and cable TV, to date the only conduits of such high quality programming. Such programming will provide viewers with a greater diversity of sources of information, while helping to break the monopolies of the state-owned broadcasting companies.IFC''s RoleIFC will provide the necessary funding. Given the perceived risks of investing in Africa and the scarcity of telecommunications and media investments on the world''s major markets, without IFCs assistance it would be difficult to raise the large scale funds necessary for an investment such as TV Africa.  If IFC does not participate in the proposed investment, it is likely that funding would be delayed, setting back the project.IFC will act as a catalyst. The other major potential investors in TV Africa have made it clear that they would take great comfort from IFC''s presence and the added value that the Corporation''s participation would provide. For these reasons, they will be much more likely to proceed with their investments in TV Africa if IFC decides to go ahead.IFC will ensure that some important development benefits are realized. TV Africa has indicated its willingness to work with IFC to optimize the company''s developmental benefits, should IFC go ahead with the proposed investment.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFC''s environmental review procedure because specific impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines, or design criteria.  The key environmental health and safety issues that were analyzed inlcude development of a corporate Environmental and Social Management Policies and Procedures to ensure compliance of existing and future facilities with relevant host country requirements and World Bank/IFC policies and guidelines; confirmation that local affiliates over which TV Africa exerts significant control will adhere to these policies and procedures; implementation of policies and practices for acquiring site(s) for facilities, transmitters, antennae, masts, satellite dishes and other structures, including site selection criteria, land acquisition procedures, right of way alignment, and access road construction, if applicable; employee health and safety and training programs; use of hazardous materials including liquid fuels, PCBs, halons and CFCs (e.g., in fire suppression or cooling systems); and fire prevention and emergency response procedures at studios and transmission sites.  IFC is reviewing environmental and health and safety information supplied by TV Africa, including a preliminary draft of its corporate Environmental and Social Management Policies and Procedures.  IFC also reviewed TV Africa''s plan for screening advertisements to ensure compliance with regulations prevailing in the country of transmission, as well as with local and international norms. Although not a requirement of IFCs environmental and social policies, the company has also provided an outline of its plans for providing and promoting educational programming, public service announcements, HIV/AIDS awareness information and other socially responsible program content.  Details of the proposed operating procedures and mitigation measures will be provided in the Environmental Review Summary (ERS) for the project, which is expected to be available from the InfoShop and locally (see below) on or about January 31, 2001.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityIFC Johannesburg Regional office1st floor Oxford GateHyde Park LaneHyde Park 2196Johannesburg, SOUTH AFRICAphone:	27-(0)11-341-9000fax:	27-(0)11-325-0582

Domiciled in Mauritius, its main operational centers are in South Africa, Kenya, Nigeria and Cote d''Ivoire. TV Africa was established in 1998 and is currently owned predominantly by institutional shareholders, the ZM African Investment Fund and the Southern African Enterprise Development Fund.

Company Name: ISTANBUL BILGI UNIVERSITESI GENCLIK CALISMALARI BIRIMI
Project Description: Bilgi, which graduated its first class in June 1998, is undertaking this project in response to its rapid growth and to the increasing demand for university education in Turkey.  Since it opened its doors in 1995, Bilgis student enrollment increased five-fold, from 914 to over 5,000 students.  At the same time, its faculty increased from 70 to 339.  It has achieved this growth by providing first-class social science instruction to a mostly urban population that thrives on the university which offers a variety of traditional core courses, as well as courses in communications, film and television and jazz.  The University serves its urban community by providing free instruction in English, accounting, and computer training.  It also has film festivals, produces shows for local TV stations, and promotes art exhibits. IFC Role: Turkeys financial sector has been unable to provide adequate local currency financing to support long-term investments, especially for not-for-profit institutions.  Financing for these institutions is limited to short-term loans at high spreads or leasing because they are considered frontier sectors and risk assessment is complicated by their not-for-profit status.  Yet they provide important social services that are directly linked to improving the social capital of the country.  Consequently, the role of IFC is especially important, as it is the only major source of long-term project financing for these clients.  With this first investment in a private university in Turkey, IFC would demonstrate the financial viability of these institutions, structuring innovate ways for securing its loans, while applying some governance measures commonly found in well-managed private companies.   Economic Benefits/Development Impacts: IFCs investment in education will help speed the diffusion of best practices to the public education system.  IFC is emphasizing investments that will deliver quality education in a cost-efficient manner.  The focus is on projects that will enhance competition and best practices, while increasing places for students across the system and relieving the pressures for additional places in the public university system. The Bilgi expansion is serving a growing demand for higher education in Turkey.  Growing numbers of secondary school graduates and a relatively strong private sector are creating ample numbers of applicants for Bilgis program. Bilgi University has so far contributed over US$5.0 million in kind to the three neighborhoods where its campuses are located.  These have taken the form of English language and computer training, training in accounting and teacher training.  In addition, Bilgi donated a primary school to the municipality.  Since 1998, over 1,500 participants have benefited from Bilgis community programs.  In addition, several small businesses, catering to students needs, have flourished in the neighborhoods where the campuses are located, and public services, such as transportation and housing, have improved.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category B project according to IFCs environmental review procedure because specific impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines, or design criteria.  IFCs Technical and Environmental Department staffs review of this project consisted of appraising technical and environmental information submitted by Bilgi.  The following potential environmental, safety and health and social impacts of the project were reviewed:·	Site selection and site environmental and social conditions;·	Water and power supply;·	Sewage treatment and disposal;·	Solid and hazardous waste management;·	Use of hazardous materials (e.g., CFCs and asbestos-containing materials); and·	Fire protection and life safety.The sponsor has presented plans to address these issues and to demonstrate that the proposed project will comply with applicable Turkish laws and regulations and World Bank requirements. Location of environmental documents In locally affected community The Environmental Review Summary is disclosed in Istanbul Bilgi University Libraries on three campuses: Kustepe, Taksim, and Dolapdere, as well as at Istanbul Bilgi University web site (http://www.bilgi.edu.tr/life/library.htm). The ERS was also disclosed in the local newspaper Radikal on February 2, 2001.
Sponsor: Istanbul Bilgi University was founded by the non-profit Bilgi Education and Cultural Foundation to contribute to the advancement and improvement of higher education in Turkey.  The founding members of the Bilgi Foundation are Turkish academics and businessmen, some of whom actively participate on the Board of Trustees of the University. Bilgi is dedicated to providing a high standard of education within an urban environment, utilizing the latest educational tools including interactive and on-line based programs.  It seeks to make utmost use of the resources available within a vibrant cultural city such as Istanbul.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at US$37.9 million. Bilgi will use IFC "A" loan of US$12.0 million and cash generation to finance the project.  Specifically, the project includes: (i) construction of an additional 12,500 square meters campus in Dolapdere, which will house first-year students, or probationary Foundation year. The number of students enrolled by academic year 2009-2010 is expected to reach 7,664 students from the present 5,335 students; (ii) modernization of the Taksim Campus, dedicated to the mandatory pre-university English language instruction which 80% of admitted undergraduate and diploma students as well as 15% of graduate students have to take; (iii) modernization of the Kustepe Campus, which houses the remaining 3-year university program; (iv) establishing on-line education programs, including an e-MBA which was already launched this academic year with an enrollment of 50 students going up to 186 students by Project Completion and 550 students by academic year 2003-2004; (v) improving library and laboratory facilities; and (vi) increasing the budget for research and publications.
Investment: 12.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan12.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The University is located on the European side of Istanbul: Dolapdere.  Dolapdere Campus is located in an old part of the city which has been used primarily as commercial and small business district in the last 30 years. The premises are leased from private individuals for 10 years on a renewable basis. Total area used is about 12,500 square meters.

Company Name: ALEXANDRIA AUTOMOTIVE CASTING FREE ZONE SAE
Project Description: The project is to establish Alexandria Automotive Casting Company, which will manufacture medium-technology automotive castings (brake calipers) to be sold under an off-take agreement to Continental Teves. Upon completion, AAC will have a capacity of 20,000 tons per annum.The proposed project will promote local enterprise in the autoparts sector, an industry in which Egypt has a strategic advantage due to its location close to Europe and comparatively lower production costs. The proposed project would create approximately 35 new jobs. As AACs production will be mostly for exports, the proposed project will contribute to foreign currency earnings.  It will stimulate transfer of the most advanced production technology, know-how and local staff training by Continental Teves to Egypt.IFCs role in the proposed project involves: (i) provision of long-term foreign currency financing which is currently not available from local banks; and (ii) encouraging the development of internationally competitive local manufacturers.  IFC''s participation in this project would create a demonstration effect for other foreign investors to invest in similar export oriented projects in Egypt.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityAmreya Metal Company Kilo 21, MerghemAlex-Cairo Desert Road, AmreyaAlexandria Central Train Station, Alexandria
Sponsor: The main project sponsor is the Mansour Group (the group), one of the leading diversified business conglomerates in Egypt. The group is active in the automotive, heavy equipment, and distribution sectors. Furthermore, it has established joint ventures with reputable foreign partners in the automotive assembly, fast food, and venture capital sectors. The group owns 21% of the Alexandria Automotive Casting  Company (AAC or the company) through Mansour Motor Company (fully owned by the group), the leading distributor of General Motors Vehicles in Egypt. Mansour Group also owns the additional 27.5% of AAC through El Mansour & El Maghraby Investment & Development Company (51% owned by the group). The remaining percentage of shareholding is owned by:-Sid Ahmed family (15.%), which has also equity stake in Amreya Metal Company, the major supplier of brake discs, drums and front suspensions to several local automotive assemblers as well as metal castings to cement manufactures;-Commercial International Investment Company (15.5%), one of the leading Egypts private equity companies;-Olympic Group (10.5%), the leader in white goods manufacturing and distribution in Egypt; and -Mr. Said Ahmed Mohsen (10.5%), a reputable Egyptian businessman.The company''s technical partner is Continental Teves, Germany, one of the worlds leading suppliers of quality automotive systems. Continental Teves manufactures components for global automakers while localizing vehicle application and development at its manufacturing plants around the world. It operates 25 facilities including 16 plants, high performance acoustic testing labs and 5 development/technical centers in 19 countries.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at US$14.5 million. The proposed IFC investment is an A Loan for IFC''s own account of up to US$5 million.
Investment: 4.74 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan4.74Equity* These investment figures are indicative

Project Name: Hipotecaria Su Casita, S.A. de C.V. - SOFOL
Company Name: Hipotecaria Su Casita, S.A. de C.V., SOFOM, E.N.R.
Project Description: The company''s primary business is the origination and servicing of mortgage and construction loans. Currently, even though homebuilders hold about 75% of the shareholding, less than 20% of Su Casitas business is originated with its shareholders. Since its founding, the company has obtained its financial support almost exclusively from a trust fund administered by the Central Bank of Mexico called FOVI, which has a particular focus on housing for low-income families.  FOVI current regulations limit the price of the homes sofoles can finance to a maximum of US$45,000.Over the past six years, Su Casita has experienced rapid expansion. It has grown the scope of its operations as measured by its physical presence and by its balance sheet. As of December 2000, it had 375 employees in 45 offices in 23 states, now covering most of Mexico.  It held approximately US$428 million of mortgage loans, up from US$34 million at year end 1996, representing an annual compounded rate of growth of 150%.  It is currently in the process of merging with Financiamiento Azteca (Finazte), another mortgage Sofol. The new entity will retain the name Hipotecaria Su Casita. The project consists of creating and issuing Mexicos first significant mortgage-backed securitization (MBS). It will be issued on behalf of Hipotecaria Su Casita which will use the proceeds of the bond offering to make mortgage loans to an under-served market segment of lower middle class families. IFC will invest in the mezzanine piece, or the B bonds.IFC will play a critical and unique role in support of this first significant MBS issue in Mexico. As a new class of security, investors will be wary of investment performance and untested legal structures. By taking a mezzanine bond, IFC will provide investment confidence to senior bond investors, and assure rating agencies of adequate credit support for the transaction. In addition, IFCs involvement will be part of a larger strategy to help develop the mortgage and capital markets in Mexico. The creation and issuance of this first deal is an important proof of concept step towards the overall goal of development of an active and liquid secondary mortgage market in the country. Finally, IFC will be playing an important role in supporting the growth of open-market institutions and in showing mortgage originators alternative funding avenues.  This securitization will generate funds for new open-market (non-FOVI funded) lending, expanding the reach of Su Casita in particular and of Sofoles in general.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category FI - Type 1.  SU CASITA will be required to develop an environmental management system. SU CASITA must require that investments under relevant operations (does not include household mortgage finance) meet host country environmental, health and safety requirements.  IFC will assess SU CASITAs capacity for environmental review and will provide training as necessary. SU CASITA must provide an annual environmental performance report.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The project sponsor is Hipotecaria Su Casita (Su Casita or the company), Mexicos second largest sofol (mortgage lender). It was established in 1994 by Jose Manuel Agudo, a former Banamex official, and Manuel Campos, a graduate of MITs Sloan School of Business who together own approximately 13% of the company. In 1995, Pulte Corp., the second-biggest U.S. homebuilder, invested US$0.9 million in the company, for a 23% stake of shareholding. This investment was part of Pultes strategy to enter the Mexican market.
Cost Nature: The total IFC investment cost is up to US$12.2 million and consists of two parts. The first part will be an investment in a mortgage-backed bond issued by Hipotecaria Su Casita. IFC will invest 6 million UDIs (inflation linked pesos) in a mezzanine tranche of the bond (approximately US$2.2 million). The second part will be a direct investment in the equity of Hipotecaria Su Casita.  IFC will invest up to $10.0 million to receive up to around 14% of the equity of the company.
Investment: 13.40 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan2.40Equity11.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Hipotecaria Su Casita is headquarted in Mexico City and has over 41 offices in 21 states throughout Mexico.

SU CASITA must require that investments under relevant operations (does not include household mortgage finance) meet host country environmental, health and safety requirements.  IFC will assess SU CASITAs capacity for environmental review and will provide training as necessary. SU CASITA must provide an annual environmental performance report.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community

Project Description: The project consists of establishing an infrastructure equipment services company, IIEL,  that would provide infrastructure equipment to contractors on a usage basis, thus allowing the contractor to focus on core competencies (construction and project management) while obtaining access to infrastructure equipment without investing capital. The company will be the first  nation-wide infrastructure equipment services company in India. The IIEL project is expected to further accelerate the process of mechanisation in the Indian infrastructure construction sector by providing contractors an alternative way of accessing high-quality and expensive equipment. Increased mechanisation will, in turn, have a strong bearing on improving the quality of infrastructure construction, better maintenance, and reduced delays in infrastructure project implementation. As an infrastructure-enabling service company, IIELs initial business focus will be on supplying specialised equipment for the road sector, multiple-use equipment for construction of roads, irrigation, dams, and pipelines, and high-value general-purpose equipment. Specialised equipment is expected to be rented by medium-sized and large contractors for short periods.  General-purpose equipment is expected to be rented by medium-sized and large contractors as back up during project peak loads or equipment breakdowns, and by small and medium-sized contractors who intend to bid for larger projects but are restricted because of capital constraints.The project is highly innovative and timely in the Indian market and is expected to pioneer the Indian infrastructure equipment rental sector.  Realising the importance of the infrastructure sector in fuelling future economic growth, over the last five years, the Indian government has increased its focus on modernising and upgrading the infrastructure sector (including urging the contractors to use more sophisticated and suitable infrastructure equipment by inserting minimum equipment specifications and requirements in documents inviting bids). Over the same period, several equipment manufacturers have either acquired or established manufacturing units in India. The availability of locally manufactured or assembled infrastructure construction equipment combined with an increasing investment volume in the infrastructure sector are key factors in making the project concept attractive in India. IFC has played a pivotal role in helping IIEL develop and structure a sound and comprehensive environmental management system (EMS). The EMS would comprise innovative features such as the establishment of an environmental advisory board (EAB) to ensure that IIEL equipment is not provided to projects which do not meet minimum environmental criteria. The EAB would comprise of independent environmental specialists who can inform IIEL management on controversial projects and give advise on how to handle potential environmental issues. IIELs adoption and use of the EMS is expected to have a strong demonstration effect in terms of encouraging Indian contractors and project promoters to focus on better environmental practices. Contractors and project promoters who are less stringent on environmental requirements, would have to rely on more expensive financing methods to get access to the equipment, which could result in higher project costs and/or non-competitive bids. IFC has also played a significant advisory role in helping the sponsors refine and elaborate the project concept, develop a robust financial structure, and identify and structure risk mitigation mechanisms. Moreover, IFC has actively assisted IIEL in its efforts to sell the project concept to other international financial institutions. IFCs presence as an investor will further help IIEL attract other investors and sources of funding.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognised performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community SREI Office"Vishwakarma 86 CTopsia Road (South)Calcutta 700 046.
Sponsor: The project sponsors and major shareholders of Indian Infrastructure Equipment Limited (IIEL or the company) are the Kanoria family and its associates (Kanoria family) and SREI International Finance Limited and its subsidiaries  (SREI). SREI, of which the Kanoria family is the main shareholder (53.9%), is one of the largest non-banking finance companies in India and is listed on the National, Bombay, Ahmedabad and Calcutta stock exchanges. Together with the Kanoria family, SREI would hold 51% of the total share capital of IIEL.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at US$46.5 millions, of which more than 80% will cover the cost of construction equipment. The proposed IFC investment amounts to  US$10.0 million, which includes an equity of US$2.1 million and a quasi-equity of US$7.9 million.

Project Description: Incorporated in November 2000,  AGC has been established as a holding company that focuses on infrastructure businesses. Existing projects include five Brazilian toll road concessions and a minority stake in the country''s first partially-privatized state water company. The focus of AGC''s investment strategy will be in the privatization of state-owned water companies, private toll roads and other concession based infrastructure businesses in Brazil. IFC''s strategy in infrastructure development has been to assist Brazil in modernising its infrastructure by encouraging the participation of the private sector in the provision of infrastructure services. The investment would also be strongly in line with IFCs strategy of supporting projects which demonstrate the viability of private investments in the newly opened and more difficult infrastructure sectors, such as water and sanitation, where local financial resources are limited and thus IFC can play an important role in structuring and mobilization. AGC, as other private water operators, is facing relatively short maturity in local financial markets and does not currently have reasonable access to long-term capital funds for its investments. IFC''s support could help develop local capacity to  participate in the privatization of a public utility sector.

Cost Nature: It is proposed that IFC will  make an equity investment of US$15 million and a convertible loan of US$15 million. The proceeds would be used to finance AGC''s equity investments in private infrastructure.

Project Description: Description of CompanyMahInfra is a new company that will be incorporated in India prior to the IFC investment. It would be an infrastructure holding company that will be formed as a result of a spin-off of MRIDL''s Infrastructure Privatization Group. Purpose of Project The project involves an IFC equity investment in a new company in India, which would develop, finance and operate infrastructure projects.  At the outset, the company will take over two infrastructure projects which are currently being undertaken by MRIDL. The projects are as follows:(i) SOFTOP: Mahindra Knowledge Park is a US$55.6 million greenfield industrial park development in the Mohali suburb of Chandigarh, the capital city of Punjab. It is in an area which houses other industrial parks, complexes and residential compounds. The project aims to develop a 15 acre site into a software technology park which will attract research and technology enterprises by offering modern facilities, well-developed data and communications links as well as financial / tax incentives. At present, the plot in Mohali has been allocated and an architectural firm has been selected for master planning. There is an accessible road to the park, where construction is expected to begin in June 2001, and another road which circumscribes the entire rectangular plot;(ii) Tirupur Water is a greenfield bulk water supply and distribution project in Tirupur, a mid-sized municipality in Tamil Nadu. Tirupur is an industrial town covering 27 square kilometers located 450 kilometers from the state capital, Chennai. The current population of the Tirupur municipality and the surrounding area covered by the project is estimated at 270,000 and 414,000 persons respectively. The US$287 million project involves the construction and operation of a potable water supply system that will abstract at least 185 million litres of water a day of water from the River Cauvery. The water will be treated and transmitted to (i) industrial and household consumers in the municipality of Tirupur; (ii) household consumers in 792 habitations spread over 4 Panchayat Unions, 4 Town Panchayats and 15 Village Panchayats; and (iii) industrial consumers (textiles) in the surrounding area. MahInfra will invest in India''s infrastructure industry, mainly but not exclusively in the following sectors: (1) water supply and wastewater management, (2) solid waste management, (3) transportation and logistics, (4) industrial parks and (5) power generation and distribution. It will play various roles in the projects it invests in, including the roles of developer, financier, operator and manager. Development ImpactThe company will have a significant development impact by bringing private sector investment to India''s poorly managed infrastructure sector.  This, in turn, should improve the quality of service and give access to the much needed infrastructure facilities to a larger percentage of the population. Better transportation facilities, water, wastewater services, and industrial parks will help reduce transportation costs, increase employment opportunities and strengthen local  social and environmental practices. The company''s investments will also develop the economies where projects are located and provide an infrastructure network that will make India a more attractive emerging market for foreign investment.  IFC RoleMahInfra will be IFC''s first investment in India''s water and transport infrastructure sectors. The development of local companies, where appropriate with international technical expertise, is the only real solution to sustained development of the infrastructure sector. The company wants to tap IFC''s experience in determining appropriate project structures, their financial viability and risk profiles. The proposed investment would give IFC the opportunity to get involved in infrastructure projects in India at the structuring stage. IFC''s presence in MahInfra would demonstrate the Corporation''s commitment to the infrastructure sector in India and enable IFC to have a stronger role in demonstrating the benefits of a more market-based concession criteria. Participation in the MahInfra investment would also allow IFC to reach and influence a number of smaller infrastructure projects, which IFC may not have been able to participate in directly. Lastly, IFCs investment in MahInfra would provide IFC with the ability to promote greater sustainability and social responsibility with respect to India''s infrastructure projects.
