Project Description: The project entails the installation of a furnace for glass production and three manufacturing lines to produce international-quality beverage bottles.  The project is expected to have a positive impact on Russia''s transition to a market economy.  Sisecam''s proposed investment is the first large-scale investment in and around Garokhovets since the Soviet era.  The venture will complete a plant site whose development was halted approximately ten years ago, when a local enterprise ran out of capital to complete its development.  The project is expected to provide over 200 direct jobs  to the local workforce and may have as large an impact in terms of indirect employment.  Once operational, the facility will add a domestic source of competitively priced, quality beverage containers in the Russian market, which is currently a net importer of glass bottles.  Sisecam is a world-class bottle manufacturer and the project''s local management cadre and workers can be expected to benefit from the transfer of best practice in cost and managerial accounting and financial controlling.The IFC investment would support the regional expansion of a project sponsor from one of IFC''s countries of operation into another IFC country of operation where the sponsor has comparative advantages based upon the industry know-how it has developed over the past decades.  Sisecam has been an IFC client in Turkey and hopes to benefit from IFC''s project finance experience in Russia.  Further, through its involvement in the project, IFC is also directly addressing its goal to mobilize relatively scarce foreign direct investment and know-how into the Russian Federation.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityA translation of the ERS is posted locally: Garokhovets Administration BuildingLenin Street No. 93601460 Vladimir OblastThe ERS is also available at the IFC Country Office in Moscow:7/5 Building 2 Bolshaia Dmitrovka103009 Moscow, Russian Federation
Sponsor: Anadolu Cam Sanayii, a subsidiary of Türkiye ie ve Cam Fabrikalar Group of Turkey (Sisecam), is the project''s sponsor and majority shareholder.  The  project will be undertaken through a joint venture company, ZAO Ruscam, with a group of regional and local investors.  Sisecam is the leading glass producer in Turkey, its home market.  It has been in business for more than 65 years and is listed on the stock exchange in Istanbul.  Sisecam will provide technical and marketing support to the project.
Cost Nature: Total project cost is estimated at roughly US$25 million equivalent.  IFC has been asked to provide a loan of approximately US$12.5 million for the project.
Investment: 13.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan13.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The project will be located 335 km east of Moscow, in the town of Garokhovets in the Vladimir region of Russia.  When completed, the plant is expected to operate a furnace with 275 tons/day capacity and three manufacturing lines to produce up to 250 million bottles per annum.

Project Description: NCCB was established in 1996 through a merger of 40 existing urban credit cooperatives in Nanjing which were owned primarily by private and collective enterprises and individual citizens.  It is a fully-licensed regional commercial bank providing a broad range of banking and related financial services.  The mandate of NCCB is to support the rapidly-growing small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Nanjing, most of which are privately and collectively owned.  Therefore, SMEs currently account for about 90% of NCCB''s total loan portfolio.The proposed project is intended to strengthen NCCB''s capital base and assist the bank in its efforts to improve corporate governance, adopt international banking best practices, and become one of the best-managed commercial banks in China for emulation by other Chinese banks.  IFC is already providing a technical assistance project to NCCB, which will be continued after IFC becomes a shareholder. The project would also help extend IFC''s reach to assist the rapidly-growing SMEs and private enterprises in China.At the moment, the Chinese domestic banks are still not open to foreign investment, so the proposed IFC investment in NCCB is subject to approval by the Chinese government.  In this context, the proposed project will enable IFC to play an important role to promote the liberalization and opening-up of China''s banking sector for foreign investment in the future.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category FI Type 1 project according to IFCs environmental review procedure.  NCCB has committed to establishing an environmental management system that will ensure that investments are consistent with applicable environmental, occupational health and safety regulations of the host country; designating appropriate individuals who will have responsibility for environment; attending IFCs environmental management workshops or approved equivalent; submitting an environmental management plan; and submitting an annual environmental performance report.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: Currently, 36% of Nanjing City Commercial Bank (NCCB or the bank) is owned by the Nanjing City government and several state-owned enterprises. The remaining 64% is held by private and non-state enterprises and individuals (including the 1,200 employees of NCCB).
Cost Nature: The proposed IFC investment is up to US$30 million for an equity stake of up to 15% in NCCB.

NCCB has committed to establishing an environmental management system that will ensure that investments are consistent with applicable environmental, occupational health and safety regulations of the host country; designating appropriate individuals who will have responsibility for environment; attending IFCs environmental management workshops or approved equivalent; submitting an environmental management plan; and submitting an annual environmental performance report.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community

Project Description: The project is to establish a new 100-ton per hour (about 640,000 tons p.a. of achievable output) grinding unit to produce ordinary Portland cement for the Ghanaian market.  Diamond plans to source clinker, the major input in cement manufacturing, from West African Cement S.A., (Wacem), a Togolese company, which has a production capacity of 200 tons of clinker per hour (1.2 million tons p.a.) and in which IFC invested US$6 million in loan and equity (investment #8962).There is a strong demand for cement and a need for additional production capacity in Ghana.  Over the past decade, cement consumption in Ghana has increased at an average rate of 11% p.a.  Demand is currently estimated at 2.1 million tons and is expected to reach 2.7 million tons by 2005.  Ghacem Ltd., Ghana''s only cement producer, with a total nominal capacity of 340 tons per hour (2.1 million tons p.a.), is already operating at high rates.Diamond is expected to have strong economic effects, including (i) a significant reduction in the price of cement due to competition and the contemplated lower price of its clinker, (ii) an improvement in the quality of the cement sold in Ghana, (iii) the creation of some 280 direct jobs and (iv) the development of regional integration and Ghana''s exports.IFC role includes providing project finance, comfort and technical advice.  IFCs investment is critical, as Ghanas financial sector is not in a position to provide either the long-term financing the project needs, due to the short-term nature of its resources and its very high rates, or the level of foreign currency it requires.  IFC will also provide comfort to the sponsors, a useful asset, given that the overall sub-region is still perceived as risky.  Finally, IFC has worked with the sponsors to improve the terms of equipment supply arrangements.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe environmental documents will be displayed at the project site, at Aflao council offices, and at Ketu district hall. Diamond will advertise the availability of these documents in the local press.
Sponsor: The project is sponsored by two strong and committed private investors, Messrs. Manubhai Jethabhai Patel and Motaparti Prasad, who own Diamond Cement Ghana Limited (Diamond or the company) on a 50%-50% basis.  As part of the contemplated project, they intend to associate a few minority investors to the company''s shareholding. Mr. Patel, a Kenyan of Indian origins, has been in business for more than 30 years.  He is a major shareholder of: (i) Eastern Rift Sawmills Ltd. (timber) and Pantel Industries Ltd. (chemicals) in Kenya, (ii) Tema Steel Co. Ltd. (TSC) (re-bars and castings) in Ghana and, (iii) Amexfield Togo Steel Sarl (ATS) (re-bars) and Wacem (clinker and cement production) in Togo.  Mr. Prasad, an Indian national, is a major shareholder of Martopearl Alloys Ltd. (alloy steel castings) in India.  He also has shares in TSC, ATS and Wacem.  In addition, Mr. Prasad oversees the management of ATS, TSC and Wacem.The final Diamond''s shareholding structure will include Messrs. Patel (38.57%) and Prasad (30.0%), Hazelbank Ltd. (17.14%) and IFC (14.29%). Hazelbank Ltd. is an investment vehicle belonging to a close business associate of Mr. Patel based in Kenya.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at US$15.3 million.  The proposed IFC investment includes an equity contribution of US$1.0 million and a loan of US$5.0 million.
Investment: 6.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan5.0Equity1.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The project will be located at Nkorgbuitame, near Aflao, some 6 km from the main border gate with Togo, in a rural area.  The two pieces of land Diamond acquired were not occupied at the time of their long-term leases and they did not support any construction or farming activities.  Vegetation mainly consisted of typical savanna grass with shrubs and few small trees here and there.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe environmental documents will be displayed at the project site, at Aflao council offices, and at Ketu district hall. Project Name: Niger Delta Contractor Revolving Credit Facility
Company Name: Niger Delta Contractor Revolving Credit Facility
Project Description: This project involves the establishment of a US$30 million revolving credit facility by IFC, Shell and a local bank. The facility, details of which are still under discussion, would focus on the oil services sector in Nigeria and would provide competitively priced term funding to small and medium-sized local contractors delivering services to the Shell Petroleum Development Company Joint Venture of Nigeria Limited (SPDC JV), primarily in the Niger Delta.  Currently, access to term funding is essentially nonexistent for these contractors.  Available credit to these companies is only short-term and very expensive.  Local banks lack adequate term finance resources in both Naira and US dollars, and tend to limit their exposure to Niger Delta contractors, because they portray high risks.  In addition, interest rates charged to these contractors are usually indexed to the Nigerian Inter-Bank Offered Rate (NIBOR), which is highly volatile.  Under these conditions, it is difficult for them to acquire and finance equipment, which in turn prohibits them from competing for larger, higher value-added contracts.  One of the major developmental benefits of the project would be its positive effect on the Niger Delta.  The facility would help support the growth of targeted local contractors, and, as a result, make a contribution to relieve unemployment and poverty.  Funding under the facility would also lead to technology transfer and more skilled training, which would provide longer term development gains and movement up the value chain.  This would also enable local contractors to compete more effectively with foreign companies on certain contracts, which are not currently accessible to them.  Ultimately the project would establish a strong base of local service companies, which would produce all around benefits, such as lowering the country''s production costs and increasing the benefits of oil production to the economy in general.The proposed facility would be the first of its kind for IFC.  IFC is actively involved with Shell in working out the structuring and funding arrangements.  The facility will also involve a local bank, which is yet to be identified.  By financing one third of the required funding for the facility, IFC will play a catalytic role in mobilizing additional term funding, which is not readily available to small oil services contractors operating in the Niger Delta.  The facility would also enable targeted contractors to access less expensive US dollar financing and strengthen their financial condition by reducing their borrowing costs.  In parallel, IFC''s SME department and APDF are actively working with SPDC JV to put together an estimated US$210,000 capacity building program to support contractors in developing their business.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Financial Intermediary (FI) Type 2 project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure.  The selected local bank would be expected to become familiar with IFCs requirements for financial intermediaries, including attending IFC sponsored or approved training, developing an environmental management system, and preparing an annual environmental performance report to IFC.  The local bank partner, as the administrator of the facility, will require that all contracts be carried out and operated in compliance with the applicable environmental, health and safety requirements.  Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The Niger Delta Contractor Revolving Credit facility (the facility) will be structured and funded by IFC together with Royal Dutch Shell (Shell) and a local bank to be identified.
Cost Nature: The maximum total lending for qualifying transactions would be US$30 million at a time.  The proposed IFC investment is a US$10 million revolving loan for IFC''s own account.
Investment: 15.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan15.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The target transactions would be in Nigeria.  The facility would offer financing to local contractors providing services primarily in the Niger Delta.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Financial Intermediary (FI) Type 2 project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure.  The selected local bank would be expected to become familiar with IFCs requirements for financial intermediaries, including attending IFC sponsored or approved training, developing an environmental management system, and preparing an annual environmental performance report to IFC.  The local bank partner, as the administrator of the facility, will require that all contracts be carried out and operated in compliance with the applicable environmental, health and safety requirements.  Location of environmental documents In locally affected community

Project Description: TelecomAsia was established by the Charoen Pokphand Group (CP Group) in November 1990 and is a strategic alliance between the CP Group and Verizon Communications (formed by the merger of Bell Atlantic and GTE).   In 1991, TA was granted a 25 year concession by the state-owned Telephone Organization of Thailand (TOT) to build and operate 2.6 million lines for the fixed line telecom network in Bangkok.As a result of the Asian crisis in 1997 and the resultant Thai economic downturn and currency devaluation, the company''s financial situation deteriorated.  A financial restructuring was completed early in 2000 which resulted in a more appropriate repayment schedule for outstanding debts.The proposed project would refinance foreign currency debt with long term local currency debt raised in Thailand.  IFC will partially guarantee the longest maturity tranches in order to promote and develop longer maturity corporate debt issuance in Thailand, provide quality long term investment opportunities for local investors and assist TelecomAsia in completing the post crisis rebalancing of its capital structure in a sound and sustainable fashion.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category C project, according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because it is likely to have minimal or no adverse environmental impacts.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The major shareholders of the project company are:  CP Group, a Thai holding company with interests in a number of sectors; Verizon, a major US-based telecommunications company, and Kreditanstalt FU Wiederaufbau (KfW), a German financial institution.  The shares of the company are publicly traded in Bangkok.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at US$500 million, but could exceed this amount.  The project remains subject to the approval of TelecomAsia''s board of directors and this document should not be construed as presuming the outcome of the board decision. The proposed IFC investment consists of a US$75 million, or Thai Baht equivalent thereof, partial risk guaranty of a debt issue for IFC''s own account and a US$25 million, or Thai Baht equivalent thereof, C Loan for IFC''s own account.

Company Name: TURKISH PRIVATE EQUITY FUND I L.P.
Project Description: The Fund, one of the first of its kind in Turkey, will invest in enterprises looking for expansion capital.  It will also seek acquisition opportunities for investment. The Fund is expected to create a diversified portfolio in industries driven by growth, exports, and deregulation.Investing in a private equity fund in Turkey has long been a part of IFC''s financial markets strategy in Turkey, as a necessary complement to the loan funding that IFC has made available through commercial banks. The development impact of this project is particularly pronounced in Turkey where the availability of private equity has historically been limited. Currently Turkey is in the middle of a financial crisis, which has greatly reduced the bank credits available to real sector companies in Turkey.  Such an environment increases the importance of private equity funds in the economy.IFC has been active in helping structure the Fund and in guiding the project sponsors.  In addition, IFC has introduced TVP to Advent.  IFC''s participation on the Advisory Board of the Fund will also provide significant comfort to potential investors, who value IFC''s experience in project finance, emerging market venture capital funds in Turkey, as well as its due diligence discipline.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category FI Type 2 project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure. TVP has committed to attend IFC''s environmental training course for financial intermediaries and will establish a formal management system for the environmental and social review and supervision of subprojects.  The Fund will require each portfolio company to comply with host country environmental standards and IFC''s Exclusion List and safeguard policies.  Category A projects will also be required to meet World Bank Group Environmental, Health and Safety (EHS) Guidelines, and must be subject to prior review and clearance by IFC.  TVP will provide IFC with annual environmental performance reports.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityN/A
Sponsor: The project sponsor is Turk Venture Partners LLC (TVP), which will be the General Partner as well as the Fund Manager for the Turkish Private Equity Fund (the Fund). TVP  is controlled by three Turkish entrepreneurs who are the founders of the Fund. The Fund will be affiliated with the global private equity firm Advent International (Advent), and they will jointly develop and invest in deals in Turkey.  Advent will actively participate in the management of the Fund and will exercise a veto right on the investment committee. Advent will also assist TVP with fundraising, structuring of the Fund, and training.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at US$ 40 million. The project consists of a proposed IFC equity investment of up to US$10 million in the Turkish Private Equity Fund for up to 20% of the Fund.

Project Description: Company description:The project aims to establish a dedicated Chinese mortgage processing company.  The services to be provided by the project company include: (1) offering advisory services to mortgage borrowers; (2) processing mortgage application documents; (3) performing due diligence and credit assessment; (4) obtaining legal opinions (through contracted law firms) and providing lending recommendations; etc. The project intends to provide China with international best practice standards for mortgage processing and underwriting, thereby contributing to the healthy development of the Chinese mortgage market.Development Impact:The proposed project will play an important institution-building role in developing the Chinese mortgage market. It will introduce the much-needed mortgage lending know-how to the market, help improve financial institutions'' risk management in mortgage lending and thereby support the healthy development of the Chinese housing market. The proposed project brings new technologies to the housing financing market in China.  The Sponsor will bring its proprietary software to China and will hence introduce up-to-date methods and technologies in the sector. This project is also expected to induce replication of the concept by other market players, thereby exercising a clear demonstration effect.IFC Role:IFC has helped KBH craft its expansion strategy in Asia.  IFC has advised the sponsor to first expand its activities in China mainly because of their established business relations in Hong Kong, the fact that their software is already in Chinese, their good knowledge of the market and the sizeable potential of the Chinese housing market. Furthermore, IFC helped structuring the transaction itself and IFC will bring added credibility to the Company which is important for KBH, a fairly young company.  This credibility will be key in the establishment of co-operations with Chinese banks who are very interested in the project and have warmly welcomed IFC''s participation in the Company.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category C project, according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because it is likely to have minimal or no adverse environmental impacts.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The project sponsor is Knowledge Based Holding Limited (KBH), a private company based in Hong Kong.  KBH was set up in November 1999 by a group of individual and institutional investors with the vision to become an efficient and up-to-date home mortgage financial service provider in Asia.   KBH started its operations in Hong Kong and pursues a strategy to build on its experience in Hong Kong and expand its operations through newly created joint ventures in selected Chinese cities.  KBH will invest in the project company through Advantage Services Holding Limited (ASHL), a wholly owned subsidiary that is being established in Hong Kong.
Cost Nature: The proposed project size is US$2.7 million to be financed by equity investments from the project company (75%; US$2.0 million) and local partners (25%, US$0.7 million). IFC would make an equity investment of up to US$500,000 for up to 25% of the project company''s total registered capital.
Investment: 0.25 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity0.25* These investment figures are indicative
Location: IFC is considering structuring this project through an investment in a Hong Kong holding company, which will establish joint ventures in mainland China with reputable local partners to focus on individual cities. The project company will start the first joint venture in Beijing, followed by Shanghai and Shenzhen.  Eventually, the Company will expand its activities into other cities in China.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category C project, according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because it is likely to have minimal or no adverse environmental impacts.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community

Project Description: The objective of the Fund is advancing and completing privatization of companies in Africa. IFC Role: IFC''s involvement in the Fund is expected to provide credibility given its successful privatization track record in the continent.  IFC''s involvement is expected to act as a catalyst in attracting potential investors and strategic partners (when needed) for the privatized entity.  As the main sponsor, IFC''s role in structuring and placing the Fund is also crucial.  IFC''s reputation and knowledge of the African markets is expected to play a significant role in giving joint investors the comfort to invest in the Fund. Development Impact: The project has a number of developmental impacts.  These include: improving management of privatized companies, promoting local ownership through public listing of shares, promoting capital markets'' development in the region and attracting foreign direct investment by improving investment climate in the region.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Financial Intermediary (FI) Type 2 project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  PFA must require all subprojects to be carried out and operated in compliance with the applicable environmental, health and safety (EH&S) requirements of the host country.   PFA must ensure that proper environmental due diligence procedures are executed prior to each fund acquisition.  In addition, subprojects whose total cost is less than US$500,000 must be consistent with IFC''s Microfinance Exclusion List.  Subprojects whose total cost is US$500,000 or greater must be carried out in accordance with IFC''s safeguard policies, be consistent with IFC''s Exclusion List, and meet the host country requirements.  PFA must obtain IFC clearance prior to making any loan or investment with IFC funds in any Category A subproject and such a subproject must meet the applicable EH&S guidelines and safeguard policies of the World Bank Group.  PFA must participate in environmental training, develop an environmental management system, and provide to IFC an annual environmental performance report. Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: IFC is the primary project sponsor.
Cost Nature: The Fund is expected to be capitalized up to US$400 million.  Proposed IFC investment is expected to be about 15% of the Fund or 25% (if the Fund closes at US$200 million).
Investment: 50.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity50.0* These investment figures are indicative

Company Name: CSRC China (Ma'anshan) Chemical Industry Co., Ltd.
Project Description: The Project Company is CSRC China Corporation, which acquired the carbon black assets from the Maanshan Golden Star Group (MGSG), a wholly owned state-owned enterprise (SOE) of the Maanshan city government.The proposed project is to: i) modernize the existing production lines; ii) expand the carbon black production capacity from 25,000 tpy to 60,000 tp; iii) expand the electrical co-generation capacity from 3.0 MW to 4.5 MW; and iv) improve environmental and safety conditions at the plant.The IFC investment will help transform an inefficient SOE into a sustainable, world-class business that will operate according to sound commercial principles, strong environmental performance and good corporate governance.  IFC''s investment will also promote the transfer of advanced technology and managerial know-how from the Sponsor to the local workforce.  The Project will demonstrate innovative ways in addressing the issue of redundant workers from MGSG.  By working closely with the Maanshan city government, and creating a new specialized service Small & Medium Enterprise (SME), redundant employees will be employed by providing catering, security, packaging and janitorial services to the Company.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityEnvironmental documents, including the ERS, will be posted at the notice board of the Maanshan City Library.  In addition, they will be posted via ads in the newspapers, the Maanshan Newspaper and People Newspaper.
Sponsor: The project sponsor is China Synthetic Rubber Corporation (CSRC), who wholly owns (100%) of the CSRC China Corporation (Project Company) indirectly through its wholly owned subsidiary, CSRC Singapore Limited.  Founded in 1973, CSRC is one of the worlds leading carbon black producers and technology providers.  CSRC became a listed company in 1986 and its shares are freely traded on the Taiwan, China Stock Exchange.
Cost Nature: The total Project cost is estimated at US$23.4 million.  IFCs proposed investment is US$ 10 million, consisting of an A loan of up to US$8.0 million and IFC equity of up to US$2.0 million.
Investment: 11.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan9.0Equity2.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The Project is located in the industrial area of Chihu, a major industrial complex in the northwest section of Maanshan city in the Chinese province of Anhui, about 300 km west of Shanghai.  At present, the area of the Project site is approximately 91,090 m2 covering the carbon black production lines, power generation facility, feedstock storage, warehouse and administration buildings  As an expansion program, the Project Company will purchase the land use rights for an additional three adjacent lands to the current Project site totaling 44,090 m2 which will cover the two new production lines.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityEnvironmental documents, including the ERS, will be posted at the notice board of the Maanshan City Library.  In addition, they will be posted via ads in the newspapers, the Maanshan Newspaper and People Newspaper.

Project Description: More specifically, the Project consists of the following investments: Alfa Retail Park  a US$44.6 million redevelopment of a former semiconductor factory into a big-box shopping mall, mainly for home appliances and home improvements retailers.  The site is located 8 km from Riga centre on a heavily trafficked Brivibas street.  It will comprise about 60,000 m2 of retail space through refurbishment of existing buildings and construction of new premises.Riga Central Railway Station  this US$50.1 million project consists of three parts: renovation of the existing station, development of a new shopping mall/department store building, and a new retail building on the station square.  The potential for a parking garage underneath the Railway Station square is also being considered.  In addition to having commercial merits, the project is expected to strengthen the public transport infrastructure in Riga by making the railway a more attractive means of transportation and helping to relieve traffic congestion.  It is estimated that around 170,000 people pass through the Riga Railway Station every day.Mols Shopping Mall - a US$27.4 million extension of the first modern car-based shopping center in the Baltics.  This regional shopping center will improve its competitive position through an addition of 10,000 m2 retail space as well as expansion of parking facilities.IFCs involvement in the Project is central to the Companys ability to raise the financing necessary for its expansion as there is limited availability of long-term commercial bank financing in Latvia today.  In addition to its own funds, IFC would provide a syndicated B loan and work with local financial institutions to raise financing for expansion of the Companys traditional retail mall.  Before IFC''s involvement, a major Scandinavian commercial bank failed to raise financing for the Company on a project finance basis.This Project fits well with IFCs strategy as it would contribute to the modernization and restructuring of the retail sector in Latvia, including a large number of local SMEs.  With IFCs support, the Project will demonstrate that longer-term financing is available in Latvia on a project finance basis for non-export oriented projects and, perhaps more importantly, that transparent FDI can be successful despite a difficult business environment.The Project will have strong direct and indirect development impact.  It will act as a catalyst for private sector development by:establishing Retail Parks where local and international retailers are brought together in a symbiotic environment, which promote exchange of information and know-how, thereby contributing to the growth and efficiency of the private sector;providing much needed retail floor space, which currently is in short supply in Riga;delivering consumer benefits by providing wider choice of higher quality merchandise and service at lower prices to a broad cross-section of the Latvian population;improving transparency and good corporate governance, which contribute to the reduction of the size of the informal, unreported sector of the Latvian economy (currently estimated to represent 30-40% of the overall economy) and improve tax collection;restoring and rehabilitating landmark buildings in downtown Riga, cleaning up the environment around the buildings, creating additional parking space and resolving traffic congestion and public safety issues; andhiring and training of Latvian nationals, and job creation in the SME sector.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category B project according to IFCs environmental review procedure because specific impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines, or design criteria.  IFCs Technical and Environmental Department staffs review of this project consisted of appraising technical, environmental, and social information submitted by Linstow Varner.  The following potential environmental, safety and health impacts of the project were reviewed: Alfa Center and Riga Railway Station site contamination due to past practices; noise, dust, and traffic disturbance during construction; sewage and solid waste handling and disposal; hazardous materials management; and fire protection and life safety.The Sponsor has presented plans to address these issues and to demonstrate that the proposed project will comply with applicable Latvian laws and regulations and IFC/World Bank requirements.  Accordingly, IFC concludes that the proposed project will meet the applicable World Bank/IFC environmental and social policies and the environmental, health and safety guidelines.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityAll the environmental documents are located at the Company''s administrative HQ in Riga (see contact address below).  In addition, the ERS (translated to Latvian) will be posted at the gates of the three project sites as well as on the bulletin board of the central library in Riga.
Sponsor: Linstow Varner SIA (the "Company") is a wholly owned subsidiary of Linstow Varner AS (Norway), which is in turn owned 50% by Linstow International AS (Norwegian real estate company), 25% by Varner-Gruppen AS (the largest textile retailer in Norway), and 25% by Hakon Gruppen AS (grocery chain owned by ICA/Royal Ahold).  Linstow International in turn is owned by the Anders Wilhelmsen Group which, among others, is one of the largest shareholders in Royal Caribbean Cruise Lines.Linstow Varner SIA owns and operates retail centers in Latvia, including "Mols", "Dole", "Minsk", and "Centrs".  As part of the Project, the Company is developing the Riga Central Railway Station as well as an abandoned industrial site in Riga ("Alfa") into modern efficient retail parks.  Linstow Varner SIA also holds a 10% ownership stake in Narvesen Baltija SIA that operates kiosks, perfumeries and restaurants in the centers as well as other locations in Latvia.  Finally, the Company holds 40% of Securitas Latvia SIA that handles security operations in the malls.Varner Gruppen (through through their retail outlets Derssmann, Cubus and Bik Bok) and Hakon Gruppen (through RIMI) occupy close to 25% of the retail space in the existing centers in addition to outlets outside the Linstow Varner centres.  A shareholder agreement between the three Sponsors (Varner, Hakon and Linstow), give Varner and Hakon first right of refusal on competitive terms for retail space in new centers.  Conversely, Linstow International AS has a first right of refusal on Hakon and Varners 25% stakes in Linstow Varner AS. The paid in share capital of Linstow Varner SIA is LVL13 million (US$ 21.6 million).  In addition, the Sponsors have provided subordinated loans for a total of about US$35 million as of year-end 2000.The management team of Linstow Varner SIA is composed of Latvian and Norwegian executives.  The aim is to maintain a strong management team in Riga, and to support it by the development and operational experience of Linstow Varner AS in Norway.  Furthermore, the Board members have a varied and highly valuable experience within the real estate and retailing sectors.  They also have extensive knowledge of the Baltic region, especially Latvia and Riga, gained through their long experience in the region.  Mr. Petter Salmonsen is the General Director of the Company.  Previously, he was a director in Linstow ASA, responsible for shopping mall development and operations in Norway.
Cost Nature: The total Project cost is estimated at about US$148 million, including contingencies, as well as an estimated US$15 million and US$11 million of interest during construction on the external debt and subordinated shareholder loans, respectively.  IFC has been invited by the Sponsors to be the lead financer.  On a preliminary basis, it is proposed that IFC provide a US$12 million A Loan and a US$8 million C Loan for its own account.  An additional US$70 million would be raised in the form of a B Loan (US$20 million) and parallel loans for the account of commercial banks and NIB.   The remaining would be financed through a combination of cash flow from operations and equity/subordinated loans from the Sponsors.
Investment: 25.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan25.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: During the period 1997-2000, Linstow Varner SIA purchased, renovated and started operation of four modern shopping centres in Riga.  The total retail area for these centres is about 29,000 m2.  As of year end 2000, the total investment was about US$80 million, nearly all (about US$75 million) of which was financed through equity and subordinated loans from the Sponsors.The Company now plans to expand their retail operations in Riga with an additional 100,000 m2 of retail space.  Two new sites have been purchased and one of the existing centers will be expanded.  The Project involves the redevelopment of an old and abandoned industrial site ("Alfa Retail Park"), promotion of public/private partnership in renovating and improving the old Riga Central Railway Station, and solving traffic problems that congest the Railway station square, as well as developing further successful western retail concepts (Mols), promoting competition and setting industry standards for retailing in the Baltics.

The following potential environmental, safety and health impacts of the project were reviewed: Alfa Center and Riga Railway Station site contamination due to past practices; noise, dust, and traffic disturbance during construction; sewage and solid waste handling and disposal; hazardous materials management; and fire protection and life safety.The Sponsor has presented plans to address these issues and to demonstrate that the proposed project will comply with applicable Latvian laws and regulations and IFC/World Bank requirements.  Accordingly, IFC concludes that the proposed project will meet the applicable World Bank/IFC environmental and social policies and the environmental, health and safety guidelines.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityAll the environmental documents are located at the Company''s administrative HQ in Riga (see contact address below). Company Name: GUNKOL GUNES ENERJISI VE KLIMA SANAYI A S
Project Description: Project :  Gunkol Gunes Enerjisi ve Klima Sanayi A.S. (Gunkol, or the Company), the white goods company of the Teba Group, is Turkeys leading profitable exporter of cooking ranges and ovens with 2000 revenues of US$60 million equivalent.  The project is a US$20 million modernization investment to (i) support the Company''s growth to satisfy the increasing international demand for quality low-cost cooking ovens, and (ii) further increase Gunkols export competitiveness through technology improvements and manufacturing cost reduction. The project will raise the Companys cooking range manufacturing capacity from 360,000 units at present to about 700,000 units, mostly for exports primarily through the rationalization of production processes and equipment modernization.  The investment will also support new product development with new designs and features in response to export market demands and specifications.  The project is expected to be completed by end-2002.Development Impact:  The proposed project will have a significant direct and indirect development impact on the local economy, especially since Gunkol sources products from over 300 local suppliers, mostly in the Izmir area.  While direct additional employment at Gunkol will be limited to about 40 people, the project will generate significant indirect employment for about 200 people at local suppliers who are expected to provide higher local value-added and technical inputs to Gunkol.  The gradual transformation of Gunkol into a leading global supplier through newer production and design technologies will help the Company and the local suppliers to become globally competitive through increased quality and efficiency demands of export markets.  Gunkol could also serve as a model for other Turkish manufacturing enterprises aiming to become competitive exporters to help the economy.  IFC Role:  The project gives IFC an opportunity to support a new client in Turkey, which is a growing medium-size, second-tier, export-oriented, family-owned company not associated with any of the large industrial groups in Turkey.  Access to long-term financing in Turkey is limited, especially for second-tier companies such as Gunkol.  IFC will provide a stable longer-term funding base to the Company so that it can instead focus strategically on enhancing production efficiency and exports.  This will directly support the Turkish economy, especially in the current economic climate.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe Company will disclose the documents locally as appropriate in accordance with IFC''s public disclosure guidelines, including at the following address:Gunes Enerjisi ve Klima Sanayi A.S.Fevzi Cakmak MahBekir Saydam cd. No. 70Pancar TorbaliIzmir, TURKEYTel: 90-232-864-1729
Sponsor: The project sponsor is the Teba Group (Tebaor the Sponsor), a second-tier, family-owned business group based in Izmir largely owned by Mr. Teoman Baygan, the founder and his family members.  Gunkol is a profitable white goods manufacturing company of the Teba Group.  Gunkol has exported cooking ranges and ovens to over 80 countries since the 1980s and is Turkeys leading cooking appliances exporter with 85-90% of its revenues in hard currency.  Gunkol is owned 44.2% by Mr. Baygan, 29% by Tema A.S., a distribution and marketing company of the Teba Group, 26.5% by Ente A.S., an air-conditioner manufacturing company of the Teba Group and 0.5% by other individuals.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at US$20 million.  IFC has been requested to provide a financing package of US$10 million for its own account comprising an A Loan of US$5.0 million and a C Loan component of US$5.0 million, which will be convertible into equity in Gunkol prior to its planned IPO in a few years.
Investment: 10.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan10.0Equity0.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The project is located in Izmir, Turkey''s third largest city.  Izmir is also the second largest port in Turkey with a free trade area for exports. The city has a developed infrastructure in terms of roads, electricity, water and telecommunications. There is an abundant supply of well-educated manpower, including engineers.  Gunkol has two separate plant locations in Izmir.  The investment will involve the relocation of the old Menderes plant near Izmir airport to the new facility in Pancar nearby covering an area of 110,000 sq.m. within the premises of an organized industrial zone.  Gunkol plans to close the Menderes plant because of its older layout and fully transfer the production to the Pancar plant.

Project Description: China suffers from severe air pollution problems caused by huge numbers of small, inefficient, coal-fired heating boilers that supply steam to residential, commercial and industrial customers.  Central CHP plants, such as those operated by PPIC, are more efficient and thus generate steam using much less fuel.  This enables the shutdown of many of these small boilers, thus reducing regional air emissions (including greenhouse gases) as well as generating substantial cost savings.  Unfortunately, Government of PRC environmental regulations are inadequately enforced, and even relatively new CHP plants are non-compliant and sub-optimally managed.  The project will have a strong development impact by demonstrating that environmentally compliant, well-managed CHP plants can be financially viable in the PRC market, thus setting a benchmark for other operators.  IFCs involvement will ensure that existing plants are environmentally upgraded to the extent practical and that new units meet international emissions levels.The World Bank Group Country Assistance Strategy for China calls on IFC to assist China in establishing a more private sector-oriented framework for infrastructure development.  Another major objective of the WBGs work in China is to assist State-Owned Enterprises (SOEs) in becoming more competitive.  In an indirect way, this project does that by providing lower priced steam inputs to industrial SOEs.  In addition, the WBGs strategy for China specifically cites the need to assist the country in reducing the level of air pollution.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityPeak Pacific Investment CompanyBeijing Reperesentative Office9th Floor Sunjoy Mansion6 Ritan RoadChaoyang DistrictBejing, China  100020
Sponsor: Peak Pacific Investment Corporation Ltd (PPIC)The management of PPIC is focused on the power market, and specifically within that broad market, the market for combined heat and power plants (CHP) in China.  This has allowed PPIC to develop standard processes in appraising, investing in and operating CHP plants.  Standardization has facilitated the comparison of the risk-return profile among PPICs projects.  PPIC management concentrates also on lowering overhead costs by hiring locally and extensively training staff so that, over time, decisions can be pushed down to the local level.  Management believes that it has developed among its staff some of the most knowledgeable experts in the CHP business in China.PPICs majority owner is Alliant Energy International, a wholly-owned subsidiary of Alliant Energy Corporation, an electric utility based in the Midwestern U.S. within excess of US$6 billion in assets (as of 12/31/00) and net income in 2000 of just under US$400 million.  Alliant is expanding its activities in distribution and CHP, where it has extensive US experience.  PPIC strongly benefits from the active participation of Alliant.  Alliant provides support during due diligence and actively monitors the Companys activities at the Board level.  Alliant has indicated that PPIC will be its primary vehicle for investing in CHP projects in China.  It is also active in two other international markets  Australia/New Zealand and Brazil.  Other key investors in the Company are the John Hancock Insurance Company and the Energy Investors Fund Group. The existing owners of PPIC, with their respective ownership percentages, are Alliant Energy International (82.3%), John Hancock Life Insurance Co. (9.0%), Peak Pacific Holdings Limited, a vehicle controlled by PPIC founders (3.3%), the Project Finance Fund III LP, a fund managed by the Energy Investors Fund Group (4.5%) and JP Sijoitus Oy (0.9%).
Cost Nature: As an investment company, there is no total project cost because the Company has four different existing projects and a number of others in its pipeline.  The Company funds its acquisition of existing projects or construction of new projects with a combination of internal as well as external financing.  IFC is proposing a US$25 million senior loan to the Company to assist it with its financing of additional CHP projects (either acquisition or construction).
Investment: 25.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan25.0Equity0.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The project consists of an investment in Peak Pacific Investment Company Ltd.  PPIC was established in 1996 to own and manage the operation of electric and steam generating facilities in the Peoples Republic of China (PRC). These facilities are primarily combined heat and power plants (CHP) that provide electricity to a local grid and steam to industry and heat to residential customers. The company has also begun to look at investing in plants that sell electricity (as well as in some situations, steam) to a single customer (captive").  PPIC is registered and has its headquarters in Singapore, with technical and administrative staff based in Beijing.  Alliant Energy International, a wholly owned subsidiary of Alliant Energy Corporation (a Midwest US power utility), is the majority shareholder in PPIC.The PRC continues to be forecasted as the largest growth market for electric power generation in the world over the next 10 years.  The CHP market in China continues to be favored by all PRC policymakers.  CHP plants will continue to be needed, as they are the only method of providing small towns and cities in China with central heating/process steam for factories in a clean and efficient manner. More recently, captive plants have begun to be offered for sale to investors by a number of Chinese companies as the need to become cost competitive and focus on core business interests has been heightened with the advent of Chinas entry into the WTO.The Company has focused its development efforts in areas where there is a need for locally produced power, and in economically advanced cities and towns where process steam can be used by financially viable industries.  A typical investment profile of a PPIC project is a combined heat and power/cogeneration plant or a captive power facility that sells power and/or steam to one/two customers.  Electrical capacity is typically 25 to 100 MW.  PPIC will consider investing either via acquisition or expansion of an existing plant or construction of a new facility.  Funds are invested through a 60 to 80 percent ownership of a joint venture using a Cooperative Joint Venture (CJV) structure with the local municipal government or large end user as the normal joint venture partner.  PPIC controls the CJV''s in which they have invested to date and has stated clearly that such control is a key requirement for future PPIC investments.  Project prerequisites are that the local community and government should fully support the project, there should be a strong and expanding market for heat/steam, and power and steam tariffs should be competitive with the market. PPIC works actively with Chinese banks to raise local RMB financing for its projects whenever possible.  The Company has been able to hedge its foreign currency exposures in projects that have foreign currency debt.PPIC started construction on its first plant, a 24 MW CHP plant in Hebei Province, in October 1998 and it commenced operation in October 2000.  The Company''s second project, acquired in April 1999, was a 6 MW CHP plant in Shandong Province.  The acquisition of a 2 x 50 MW power plant in Henan Province followed in October 1999.  An additional 24 MW CHP plant was acquired in Hebei in 2000.  All plants use local coal as fuel.  The Company plans to have one additional project in place by the end of June 2001, and to develop two to three projects per year thereafter.  PPIC has been able to develop projects with competitive power and steam tariffs (e.g. power tariffs in PPIC projects range from 3.7 UScents/kwh to 4.5 UScents/kwh).  PPIC''s projects have long-term power and steam offtake contracts with cost pass-through provisions.Alliant Energy has already funded/committed to provide USD 85 million in equity investment.  IFC has been invited to consider an equity investment in and a convertible loan to the Company. PPIC views IFCs support at this juncture in its development as important in realizing its strategic objectives.

Project Description: ABCH was formed in May 2000 following a merger between First Merchant Bank Holdings and udc Holdings. The merger put in motion the transformation of ABCH, whose major operations are in Zimbabwe into a diversified financial services group with an increased geographical reach in Southern and Eastern Africa. The project is intended to decrease ABCHs exposure to the harsh economic conditions prevailing in Zimbabwe by widening its revenue base in neighboring African countries with more stable economic fundamentals and attractive market potential. This diversification and expansion will be accomplished through its established regional financial leasing subsidiaries, and a widening of its product line to include full wholesale banking services in the region. IFCs lead role in this project will help to build confidence among investors and attract funding from both private investors and bi-lateral agencies to ensure the long-term growth prospects of ABCH. The project will help fill a critical market gap by expanding and strengthening a locally-managed financial institution that will provide specialized financial services such as investment banking, asset financing and management, all critical areas for building a robust financial infrastructure and providing sustainable term funding for private sector activity. Moreover, this project will have a positive impact on the integration of financial systems in the Southern Africa region, which will in turn support increased cross-border trade and investment.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Financial Intermediary (FI) Type 2 project according to IFC''s environmental review procedure.  ABCH will be required to undertake an environmental review of each subproject to ensure compliance with host country requirements, IFC environmental and social safeguard policies, and, if applicable, World Bank Group environmental, health and safety guidelines. IFC will assess ABCHs capability to carry out environmental reviews.  ABCH must obtain IFC clearance prior to making any investment with IFC funds in any Category A project. Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The Project sponsor is African Banking Corporation Holdings, Ltd., incorporated in Botswana.  The main shareholders are Anglo American Corporation of Zimbabwe, the Heritage Group, Old Mutual Company of Zimbabwe, EDESA and Zephyr Management.
Cost Nature: Project Cost: US$ 100 millionIFC investment: US$ 20 million, of which $5 million in quasi-equity, and a $15 million term loan.

Project Description: Rubico Holding (Pty) Ltd. (Rubico) has developed component based software that is used as building blocks in the design of large corporate systems including HR, payroll, general ledger accounting, e-commerce, inventory management, etc.  Rubicos technology targets primarily the financial services industry, which, because of its dynamics, mission critical data and diversity of products and methods, is best served by a component-based approach.  The component based technology that Rubico has developed allows customization of software to business needs to be quick and economical and further enhancements effortless.  The company has two streams of revenues: product sales and consulting revenues.  The IFC investment will help Rubico (a) obtain other financing from local and foreign investors, (b) assist the company in accessing the US and West European market, (c) provide assurances to VAR partners and clients that the company will survive and continue to provide products and support in the future, (d) will allow Rubico to develop its international sales channels.It is anticipated that a successful investment in Rubico will: (i) prove that South Africa can develop world-class technologies, (ii) help in increasing VC interest in South African IT market, (iii) help increase employment opportunities in South Africa.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category C project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityN/A
Sponsor: Rubico Holding (Pty) Ltd. has been in operation for 5 years.  The current shareholders of the company are the following:(1)	Rubico Management Systems is owned by Rubicos top management.  RMS is the companys sponsor and owns about 37% of the company.  (2)	Braitec is the tech VC of Brait Funds.  Braitec is a $36 million fund which has invested in Rubico, through loans to management, equity investment and bridge loanst. Brait is also the largest shareholder with 40% of the shares.(3)	Group 5 is a large South African construction company.  Rubico was founded by its IT managers and was spun off as a separate entity in 1996.  Group 5 owns about 8% of the company.(4)	Women Investment Portfolio Holding is a large black and women empowerment investment group.  WIP owns about 16% of the company.
Cost Nature: Total investment in this round is expected to be $10 million.  The proposed IFC investment is $5 million in exchange for Series C Preferred Shares.  Other investors expected to participate are International Development Corporation (IDC) of South Africa, DEG of Germany and Copia Capital Partners of UK.
Investment: 5.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity5.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The company is located in Johannesurg, South Africa.  A smaller sales office in Cape Town is under consideration.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category C project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityN/A
Sector: BA - Computer Systems Design and Related Services (System Integration, Custom Computer Programming, IT Services etc.)

Project Description: Telecom Technology Limited (the Company)  is an exisisting company involved in the business of providing internet services in the city of Dushanbe, Tajikistan. The Company, now wants to expand its activities to other cities of Tajikistan nemely Khujand, Kurgan Tube and Chakalovsk and the Project involves the installation of 4-satellite VSAT stations to establish a network connecting these four cities of Tajikistan.  As a result of the Project, a wide range of reliable Internet, Email and private data communications services (currently unavailable or under-served in Tajikistan) will be made available in Dushanbe and three cities of Northern Tajikistan. The Project is a business expansion, sponsored by Telecom Technology  Limited.  The estimated US$0.7 million cost of the Project includes cost of purchase of new equipment, installation and training and working capital.  The Project is expected to be implemented within a period of 6 months after disbursement by IFC. The Project will have the following developmental impacts: (1) expansion of an information service increasingly vital to the development of competitive industry and services; (2) increased competition in a small market; (3) introduction of up-to-date technology in a sector where this is crucial; (4) supporting the emerging Tajik business community; and (5) creation of 30 jobs. The Project is in line with the World Bank Group Country Assistance Strategy, which highlights IFCs key focus in Tajikistan on promoting investment in small and medium size businesses to foster broad based industrial development and help alleviate poverty.  More specifically, the Project complements IFCs strategy to encourage and support commercially viable Projects in Tajikistans emerging SMEs in the private sector by: (a) helping develop new and efficient private sector companies; (b) assisting employment generation; and (c) promoting development of communications. The proposed Project builds directly on these strategies and supports the CAS in private sector development, particularly in the area of SMEs.
Environmental Social Issues: This project is a category C project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedures.  There are minimal environmental or social impacts associated with this project.  Therefore, no further environmental or social analysis is required. Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityN/A
Sponsor: The Project will be owned and operated by Telecom Technology Ltd (the Company). The Company was established in 1994. At start-up, it specialized in development of banking software as well as designing and installation of customized networks for leading Tajik banks and providing networking facility to local businesses.  In 1996, the Company became a member and VSAT-operator of INTELSAT, an international satellite communication company and represented Tajik Ministry of Communications in international forums on electronic communications. In 1998, Telecom Technology became the first ISP (Internet Service Provider)  and VSAT operator in Tajikistan and today it is the market leader in providing Internet and Email services. In 2000, it opened the first Internet-Café in the country. The Company presently employs some 35 people and is headed by Mr. Shavkat Khalilov (one of its founders). The Company is established as a Tajik limited liability entity and its present shareholding structure is as follows:Private Company Kon				11%Mr. Shavkat Khalilov				65%Mr. Bakhtier Khudainazarov				24%
Cost Nature: Total project cost is estimated at US$710,000.00.  The proposed IFC investment comprises an A-Loan of  US$315,000 for its own account and represents about 44% of the project cost. This exposure for IFC is within SEF norms for a business expansion.  Also,  a participating element, which is 2% of Gross Sales, has been included.  (This may lead to its re-categorization as Venture Loan, or C Loan, after further negotiation and appraisal).
Investment: 0.35 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan0.35Equity* These investment figures are indicative

There are minimal environmental or social impacts associated with this project.  Therefore, no further environmental or social analysis is required. Project Description: Gapco Kenya is an oil company that imports, bulk stores and distributes oil products in the East African countries of Kenya, Tanzania, Uganda and Rwanda. The Company began operation in June 1999 with a focus on penetrating the Kenyan wholesale market. The project is to build a fuel oil terminal and blending unit at the port of Mombasa. The project will enable Gapco Kenya to import larger parcels, store in-house, lower costs, provide tailored products, improve reliability of supply and grow its fuel distribution business.    The  project will have a strong developmental impact as it supports the expansion of the oil distribution sector and improves the availability of fuel oil in East Africa. All oil is imported in East Africa and the project increases and improves the infrastructure for handling oil products, the lifeblood for any developing economy.  The project is a natural backward linkage to the IPPs supported by the World Bank Group in Kenya. Kenya over the past three years faced an acute power deficit due to a lack of investment in power generation and a drought that reduced hydro supply. The WB group has encouraged the Kenyan government to allow independent suppliers to generate power to reduce the deficit. These IPPs all use fuel oil to generate electricity. With the revival of the East African Community and the goal of creating a regional market and trading block,  there will be a demonstration effect as Gapco is one of the first local companies that is adopting a regional rather than national strategy. The project will provide Gapco Kenya the infrastructure facilities to compete more effectively with the multinationals, leading to better service and lower fuel costs for consumers.  IFC will provide long-term debt financing.  Availability of long-term financing denominated in foreign currencies is limited in East Africa. Local banks have limited access to long-term funding and focus on short-term trade finance. IFCs investment will complete the financial plan. To date capital expenditure has been funded from shareholder funds and internally generated cashflow. IFC''s financing will allow the project to be completed in a timely manner and free up the Company''s working capital to grow the business.  IFC has assisted greatly in project structuring and implementation.  This is Gapcos first time to construct a greenfield terminal.  IFCs petrochemical engineer has provided considerable input to the sponsors to the requirements necessary to build the terminal to international safety and environmental standards.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. The sponsor will implement the necessary measures to ensure compliance with World Bank guidelines and policiesLocation of environmental documents In locally affected communityKenya Ports Authority Headquarters on  Moi Avenue, Mombasa
Sponsor: Gapco Kenya''s entire shareholding is held by a holding company, Gulf Africa Petroleum Corporation (Gapco) of Mauritius. The shareholders of Gapco Mauritius are two brothers, Messrs. Yogesh (44%) and Dhiran(44%) Kotak  and Africa Growth Fund (12%).  The Kotaks, Tanzanian nationals, are well-established, reputable businessmen. Their main business is importation and marketing of petroleum products in East Africa through local Gapco subsidiaries in Tanzania, Uganda, Rwanda and Sudan. Gapco Mauritius also own Tranenergy Kenya Ltd., an oil products road haulage company which is an existing IFC client.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at US$44 million. The proposed IFC investment is a a US$ 15 million A loan for IFC''s own account.
Investment: 15.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan15.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The Company is headquartered in Nairobi, Kenya. The project site is in Mombasa port on the Kenyan coast. The site is on a 3ha leased greenfield site from the Kenya Ports Authority. The site required some filling and leveling. The site is accessed by both both road and rail. Oil pipelines connect the site to the two oil jetties at Mombasa harbour.

Project Description: The proposed Project will help the Bosnian government privatise its share in three still majority state owned banks (PBS, Central Profit Banka, Travnicka Banka) group by June 30, 2001, the deadline agreed with IMF and the World Bank.  The Project will also help to restructure guarantees issued by PBS and this will release all PBS group banks from their joint and several liability, which currently threatens the very existence of all PBS spin offs.
Environmental Social Issues: The project has been classified as Category FI Type 1 according to IFC''s environmental review procedure.  Each PBS bank owned by the special purpose vehicle will be required and assisted to begin developing appropriate environmental programs ahead of their eventual sale to strategic investors.  Such programs will focus on the appraisal of corporate borrowers'' environmental performance, including compliance with Bosnian environmental and health & safety standards.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityNot applicable.
Sponsor: The Privredna Banka Sarajevo ("PBS") group consists of seven banks in Bosnia, which are all spin-offs of PBS, which dominated Bosnian banking in Yugoslav times.  These banks have a joint and several liability for all guarantees extended by PBS before they were spun off.  The project would focus on up to three banks (PBS, Central Profit Banka, Travnicka Banka), which have not yet been privatised.Before the war in Bosnia, PBS extended several guarantees to various foreign entities on which it defaulted and for which all PBS group banks are now jointly and severally liable. In spite of some previous debt restructurings, these old guarantees could still wipe out all the PBS group banks.A special purpose vehicle owned by IFC, the creditors of PBS and the Bosnian government would become majority owner of up to three currently state owned PBS banks and would then restructure PBS'' pre war debt.  As a part of this restructuring, IFC would extend a loan to the special purpose vehicle to pay off the creditors at a substantial discount. As soons as practical, the special purpose vehicle would then sell off these banks to strategic investors.  IFC''s A-loan would be repaid from proceeds, which the special purpose vehicle receives by selling off these banks.
Cost Nature: The proposed IFC A-loan will be up to DEM 20 million. In addition, IFC may extend C-loans of in total up to DEM 10 million to individual PBS Group banks.
Investment: 9.27 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan9.26Equity0.01* These investment figures are indicative
Location: PBS and Central Profit Banka are headquartered in Sarajevo and have branches across the Bosnian Federation. Travnicka Banka is a regional bank and has branches in the Travnik region.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The project has been classified as Category FI Type 1 according to IFC''s environmental review procedure.  Each PBS bank owned by the special purpose vehicle will be required and assisted to begin developing appropriate environmental programs ahead of their eventual sale to strategic investors.  Such programs will focus on the appraisal of corporate borrowers'' environmental performance, including compliance with Bosnian environmental and health & safety standards.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityNot applicable.

Project Description: The project is a greenfield project which will construct a confectionery factory.   As well as providing high-quality confectionary to Tanzania, a significant proportion of output  is expected to be exported to neighboring countries.    The project has a strong development impact:  (a)  While Kenya''s competitiveness as the industrial center for East Africa has declined markedly in recent years, that of Tanzania has instead improved significantly.  Despite this, inward investment in industrial projects has been limited.  The proposed project should help demonstrate the attractiveness of Dar es Salaam as an industrial location;  (b)  The project is forecast to create 150 jobs;  and (c)  Generate foreign currency earnings of over $ 2 million per annum within five years, as well as saving forex currently spent on confectionery imports. IFC''s  Role is :  (a) Long-term lending: in Tanzania there is a dearth of term finance;  (b) Catalyst:  IFCs participation  in the project is expected to be instrumental in bringing in a domestic financial institution;  and (c)  Marketing and business development assistance:  in particular, the IFC consultant has helped the management of 2000 Industries map out an export strategy and refine their business strategy.  Also, the IFC project team has been exploring ways in which the distribution and marketing methods used can have a positive social impact.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe ERS will be made available at the Dar es Salaam Municipal Council notice board and at the project site.  Availability of the ERS at these locations will be advertised in a major local newspaper.
Sponsor: The project sponsors are comprised of two groups: the first one comprising the Shah and Patel families who are already involved in confectionery production in the region, and the second the Vora family who have been distributors of fast moving consumer goods in the region for more than 30 years.  The two groups will be equal shareholders and know each other well.
Cost Nature: Total project cost is estimated at US$ 4,750,000.  The proposed IFC investment is a US$ 1,600,000 A loan for IFC''s own account.
Investment: 1.60 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan1.60Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: A greenfield site of 1.8 hectares in an industrial area in the northern part of Dar es Salaam, Tanzania.   It is about 2 km from the main Bagamoyo road.
