Project Description: Project description.  Webdunia is the leading provider of web-enabling technologies and content/media services in Indian languages.  Since inception in April 1999, the company has built a strong position in both the enabling technology and the media services components of the business and employs 125 people.  Webdunia offers a variety of Internet-based software applications for corporate partners and individuals, including webmail (590,000 users as of May 31, 2001), a transliteration engine (transferring Western characters into Indian languages via standard keyboard), search engines, e-greetings, discussion boards, and chat, in a total of 11 Indian languages.  The company operates portals in four languages (Hindi, Tamil, Telugu, and Malayalam).  In addition, it provides customized language-enabling services and content to corporate clients and government.Developmental impact.  Webdunia plays a unique role as an enabler of growth for the Internet in India.  With only 6 percent of the Indian population (approximately 60 million people) conversant in English, increased availability of content and applications in local languages will be necessary for broader adoption of IT and the Internet.  This will have a positive impact on delivery of social services and e-government, corporate productivity, and strengthening of local cultures.  Through the project, IFC has the opportunity to support this critical component of the IT infrastructure in India  and play a catalytic role in increasing Internet access to the large majority of Indians who do not speak English.IFC Role.  The proposed IFC participation in the project would help bring strategic and venture investors to the company during a period of severe pullback in investment activity in early-stage companies in India.  The impact on technology firms with an India-centric revenue model has been particularly harsh.  Potential strategic investors have indicated that IFCs participation in the round will enable them to invest.  In addition, IFCs participation would raise the profile of the company and assist in customer acquisition on both the corporate and government markets.  Finally, the project will provide an important precedent for local language-based business models which can address the need faced by many IFC client countries for local language software applications and content.  The companys platform is highly adaptable and could be taken into other markets with phonetic-based writing systems.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category C project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure. The company leases space, and the project will not cause the company to buy or build a new structure. There are minimal environmental or social impacts associated with this project.  Therefore, no further environmental or social analysis is required. If the construction of physical assets becomes necessary during the life of the IFC investment, the sponsor will notify IFC of such plans and obtain IFC''s consent prior to commencing construction.  In addition, the sponsor will develop procedures to appraise these projects and demonstrate compliance with all applicable environmental, occupational health, fire and life safety legislation and standards of the host country, as well as relevant World Bank Group environmental and social policies and guidelines.The sponsor will develop a Corporate Environment and Social Policy Statement demonstrating their commitment to comply with all applicable environmental, occupational health, fire and life safety legislation and standards of the host country in which business is conducted, as well as relevant World Bank Group environmental and social policies, guidelines and industry best practice.  The policy will indicate that the sponsors will not knowingly engage in any of the activities on the Exclusion List Annex or on the Exclusion List for Internet Projects. The sponsor will also develop a Code of Conduct to be posted on their web site to address the issues raised in the Exclusion Lists.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The founder of Webdunia (the company), Mr. Vinay Chhajlani, holds a majority shareholding in the company of 58 percent. The balance is held by a leading US-Asian venture capital firm, Walden International Investment Group (20%), Silicon Valley entrepreneur and investor Prakash Bhalerao (6%), an Indian venture capital fund, Passion Fund (2%), employees and other individuals.Mr. Chhajlani has over 15 years of experience in the information technologies (IT) and media industries both in India and the United States.  He earned a B.S. at BITS Pilani and has also served as General Secretary of the university. In addition, he earned an M.S. in systems and printing technology at Rochester Institute of Technology.  Mr. Chhajlani founded the company in January 2000 as a spinoff from his previous firm, Suvi Information Systems Private Limited (Suvi).  Suvi is a software company with a wholly-owned US subsidiary, Diaspark.  Prior to founding Suvi, Mr. Chhajlani played a management role in Naidunia, the leading Hindi newspaper in the state of Madhya Pradesh, India.

Project Description: Salutia is implementing a proprietary, multichannel, Internet-centric transaction platform, Health24TM, to efficiently and securely process transactions and exchange information among healthcare payers and providers, and eventually, also patients and suppliers. Salutia''s core clients are healthcare payers who determine the initial care eligibility and authorization, therefore experiencing the greatest cost savings from adopting Salutia''s technology platform. E-health connectivity companies hold tremendous promise both globally and in Latin America. Through connectivity, administrative inefficiencies are reduced and clinical information is improved. The potential of Salutia therefore is not only to reduce healthcare administrative waste, but also to improve the quality of care by giving healthcare professionals more complete, accurate data at the point of care. Given recent level of skepticism among investors in the area of healthcare information technology and e-health, IFC has an important catalytic role in the project. Also, IFC''s involvement lends additional credibility to Salutia, especially in its dealings with healthcare payers and policy-makers.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category C project, according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because it is likely to have minimal or no adverse environmental impacts.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: Established in late 1999, Salutia.com, Inc. (Salutia or the company) is a privately held healthcare connectivity company focused primarily on payer/provider transactions in Argentina and Brazil. Salutia is owned by approximately 30 shareholders, the largest being Merrill Lynch Global Emerging Markets Partners, UBS Capital, and NAP Acquisition/Newbridge Latin America.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at US$12.5 million. IFC is considering an equity investment of up to US$2.5 million.

Project Name: Interseguro Compania de Seguros de Vida S.A.
Company Name: Interseguro Compania de Seguros de Vida S.A.
Project Description: The project is to invest up to US$4 million in equity for up to 15% of Interseguro.  Interseguro was founded in 1998 as an initiative of Interbank Group to take advantage of the high growth expected in the life insurance business in Peru. As with all relatively new and growing life companies, Interseguro is posting net losses as it builds technical reserves against its portfolio of policy liabilities.  IFC''s investment will provide additional capital to support Interseguro through this critical growth stage.  It is an opportunity for IFC to provide continued support to private pension reform and contractual savings as Interseguro provides the "next step" (through its annuity product) for members of the private pension plans as they retire.  It will also be an opportunity for IFC to support greater corporate governance through its possible participation on Interseguro''s Board.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category C project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects.  No further review is therefore reqiured.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: Initially, Interseguro was formed as a joint venture with the Interbank Group (through its holding company IFH Peru Ltd.) and Bankers Trust Co., which had controlling interest of Consorcio Nacional de Seguros de Chile, the largest life insurance company in Chile. As a result of the sale of Bankers Trust to Deutsche Bank in 1999, Bankers´ holdings in the company that held the shares of Interseguro were sold to Chilean investors. In mid-2000, the IFH Peru Ltd. bought that holding company from the Chilean investors, obtaining 100% control of Interseguro. IFH Peru Ltd. is publicly traded (including ADRs).
Cost Nature: The proposed IFC investment is a US$4.0 million equity investment for IFC''s own account.  This equity will support Interseguro''s continued growth in its life insurance business (specifically its annuity business).
Investment: 4.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity4.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Interseguro is headquartered in Lima and has eight branches nationwide (in the South: Arequipa, Ilo, Ica; North: Trujillo, Piura, Chiclayo, Chimbote; North-eastern: Iquitos), and a commercial branch in Lima (Av. Dos de Mayo 1798, San Isidro, Lima).

Company Name: Ipek Kagit Sanayii ve Ticaret A.S.
Project Description: Ipek Kagit is Turkey''s leading producer of tissue paper with about 60% market share. Ipek Kagit was established by the Eczacibasi Group in 1970 as Turkey''s first large scale and modern tissue paper operation.  In 1998, Ipek Kagit undertook a US$86 million expansion and modernization project, which increased Ipek Kagits total tissue paper capacity by 50,000 tons per year (tpy) to 87,000 tpy and its converting capacity by 28,000 tpy to 53,000 tpy. As a response to the economic crisis in Turkey which has caused a contraction in the domestic market, Ipek Kagit intends to increase its tissue paper exports substantially. Consequently, Ipek Kagit has requested IFC to provide a medium-term financing of up to US$12 million to fund its increasing export operations. After the recent political and macro economical turmoil, interest rates in Turkey have skyrocketed and credits have become very scarce.  More importantly, local financial institutions do not provide the financial depth required for the long-term, outward looking strategic development of major corporations in Turkey.  Loan maturities exceeding even a one year range are currently not available to the Turkish market.  Without IFCs investment, Ipek Kagit would be forced to rely on extremely limited, short-term and more expensive financing which would adversely affect liquidity.  In the context of the uncertain economic environment and competitive pressures in the global industrial tissue paper sector, the project critically supports the sustained and competitive evolution of a vital Turkish corporation.  The proposed project will have a significant development impact. IFCs support of the project is critical at a time when higher inflation, shrinking domestic demand and price increases have stagnated the economy, especially manufacturing sector, which has brought about massive layoffs, causing severe economic and social instability in the country. Ipek Kagit is internationally competitive and export about 36,000 tons of its production, resulting in over US$36 million equivalent of foreign exchange earnings per year. Through the proposed investment, IFC will support a Turkish company ride out the financial difficulties to emerge as a stronger and more competitive company in the global setting.  IFCs participation of the project would provide comfort to other foreign investors who are wary of Turkeys perceived macro-economic and political risks, and encourage additional foreign direct financing and investment in Turkey. The devaluation of the currency has made Turkeys exports more attractive.  By providing the timely export financing, IFC will help Ipek Kagit seize the market opportunity, boost export sales and most importantly equip it with the financial resources needed to explore new export avenues, thereby increasing the countrys foreign exchange earnings.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category C project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  The existing investment in Ipek Paper is in material compliance with the specified World Bank Group policies and guidelines.  No additional environmental and social review is required for this additional financing.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: Ipek Kagit Sanayi ve Ticaret A.S. (Ipek Kagit)  is owned on a 50:50 basis by the Eczacibasi Holding, the holding company of a large Turkish industrial group, and by Georgia Pacific Europe N.V., owned by Georgia Pacific U.S. (formerly Fort James), one of the leading global competitors in the tissue paper business.  Eczacibasi Group:  The Eczacibasi Group is a large and respectable industrial group in Turkey with 38 companies operating in three core business divisions: pharmaceuticals, building materials and consumer products.  In 2000, the Eczacibasi Holding is expected to realize a total turnover of US$ 24 million. Georgia-Pacific Europe: Georgia-Pacific (GP) is a leading manufacturer and distributor of tissue, pulp, paper, packaging, building products and related chemicals with operating facilities in more than 600 locations in the United States, Canada and 11 other countries.  In pursuit of its corporate strategy of moving up the value chain to higher margin businesses, on November 27, 2000, GP acquired Fort James Corporation (the former 50% shareholder of Ipek Kagit) and GP Europe is now the 50% sponsor of this project.  GP Europe had a turnover of approximately US$119 million in 2000.
Cost Nature: This is a working capital loan.  The proposed IFC investment would consist of a medium-term loan of up to US$12 million (in Euro equivalent).
Investment: 12.27 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan12.27Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Ipek Kagit is located in Istanbul with manufacturing facilities in Karamursel, about 100 kilometers to the southeast of Istanbul.  The project site is close to main highways, railway and a main sea port.

The existing investment in Ipek Paper is in material compliance with the specified World Bank Group policies and guidelines. Project Description: The project consists of  the establishment of an emerging market, private sector focused, collateralized bond obligation (CBO) vehicle. The venture will securitize Asian emerging markets bonds, through the issuance of  various classes of  securities to institutional investors backed primarily by a portfolio of bonds issued by corporates in Asia. The project will be the first structured financing transaction of this type in Asia since the crisis, and the first ever focusing on Asian corporates. IFC''s role:IFC would play a critical role in structuring the project to achieve a more viable financial structure and will, through its investment, fill the gaps in the financial plan which cannot be filled by the market at this time.  Development Impact- Mobilization - through this investment, IFC will help demonstrate the feasibility and effectiveness of securitization of financial assets as a source of funds mobilization for emerging markets;- Development of Asian bond markets - as purchasers of Asian corporate bonds this and similar CBO vehicles will encourage the re-entry of Asian companies into the corporate bond markets.  Furthermore, the active management of bond portfolios held by these vehicles will help improve market liquidity;- Market signal - whilst the economic fundamentals in many of  the Asian economies have improved over the last few years after the Asian crisis, investor perception about these markets remains negative.  This has made recovery more difficult. Even some of  the best companies have not been able to access badly needed financing. The transaction will help improve the overall market attitude towards Asia and in that process contribute to the recovery process.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category C project, according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because it is likely to have minimal or no adverse environmental impacts.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The project sponsors are Overseas Union Bank Ltd. (OUB) and its wholly owned subsidiary, OUB Asset Management Ltd.  OUB first started business in Singapore in 1949. It is one of the big four local banks in Singapore and has an extensive network of 71 offices worldwide.  OUB Asset Management Ltd., which is a wholly-owned subsidiary of OUB, will act as investment manager in the project. OUB Asset Management Ltd. was incorporated on 12 February 1980 in the Republic of Singapore.  Its principal activities are the provision of financial services and advice, and the management of unit trusts and other trusts and investments.

Project Description: The project encompasses the development and marketing of a network of PV-powered front- and back-lit lighting systems (Adlites) for the provision of advertising services in major cities in India. The network of Adlites will be sited on privately held land such as college campuses, petrol stations and parking lots.  Adlites can offer low-cost lighting for outdoor spaces, making them safer at night and expanding the range of possible uses.  The project aims to demonstrate that this value-added application of PV technology can become commercially sustainable at a large scale.This is a project financed by the IFC/GEF Photovoltaic Market Transformation Initiative (PVMTI). The Global Environment Facility (GEF) has provided US$30 million in concessional funds to IFC to support investments in private sector projects to encourage market development for photovoltaics.  PVMTI aims to address market barriers by making available appropriate financing and stimulating business activity, accelerating PV penetration to achieve reductions in greenhouse gases. By harnessing the innovation and discipline of the private sector in designing and implementing PV projects, IFC is helping to shift the design and financing of PV market activity to a more sustainable and replicable private sector context.By investing PVMTI funds in the project, IFC intends to support the demonstration of a successful and replicable business model for the Indian, as well as other developing country PV markets.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category C project, according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because it is likely to have minimal or no adverse environmental impacts.  Because of the targeted nature of the advertising, the sponsor has committed not to sell advertising space to the alcohol, tobacco, gaming, or munitions industries.  In addition, the sponsor will be responsible for ensuring proper recycling or disposal of batteries.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: Sunlit Media is a recently established company owned 49% by Sunwatt Energy (P) Ltd. and 51% by Microsol Power (P) Ltd.   Both Sunwatt Energy (P) Ltd. and Microsol Power (P) Ltd. are incorporated in India.
Cost Nature: Total project cost of US$6,640,000, with IFC/GEF PVMTI loan, equity, and grant investment of US$2,300,000.
Location: The company is headquartered in Hyderabad, India.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category C project, according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because it is likely to have minimal or no adverse environmental impacts. In addition, the sponsor will be responsible for ensuring proper recycling or disposal of batteries.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community

Project Description: The project involves the expansion of the production capacity of the company, which produces and distributes industrial gases (mainly oxygen and acetylene). The company was created in 1993  through the acquisition of the repackaging equipment for cooling gases of the local subsidiary of the German firm HOECHST.  In 1993 HOECHST closed its activities in Cameroon and signed an exclusive representation contract for cooling gases with FME-GAZ. In 1995, the company diversified into the production of industrial gases in response to the increasing demand which CAMOA (Société Camerounaise d''Oxygène et d''Acétylène), a local subsidiary of the French AIR LIQUIDE Group, could not satisfy. The expansion entails the purchase and installation of the following equipment: (i) a second air separation plant for oxygen with a capacity of 30 m3/hour, bringing the total capacity to 45 m3/hour; (ii) the acquisition of some essential utilities (gas cylinders and trucks); and (iii) the expansion of the production facility to house the new oxygen unit and the construction of a loading plate-form.  IFC''s objective is to help provide financial resources channeled towards long term financing. Local banks dispose mainly of short term resources, and their ability for long term funding of investments is now severely constrained by implementation of tighter prudential regulations by COBAC. Investors are now turning to international financial institutions such as PROPARCO, FMO, DEG, IFC, etc. The developmental impact resulting from the project includes: (i) contributing in improving competition in the local liquid gas industry, which has been dominated for many years by a single multinational firm: CAMOA of the French AIR LIQUIDE group . This company is present in most French speaking African countries as a monopoly. Cameroon is one of the rare countries where an indigenous firm has successfully established a business in the sector, and captured a share of the market; (ii) enabling IFC to implement its objective under the Chad-Cameroon SME initiative, to promote and increase an indigenous participation in sub-contracting activities in the Chad-Cameroon pipeline project; and (iii) creating 16 additional permanent jobs and save the existing ones, bringing the total up to 50.

Sponsor: The main sponsor is Mr. André Fotso with 67% of the FME-GAZ Sarl (the company) shares. The rest of the shares (33%) belong to five Cameroonian business associates, who have consistently supported the company since creation. Mr. André Fotso (42) holds a masters degree in business administration completed in 1982 at the University of Lyon (France).  From 1985 to 1992 Mr. Fotso was financial controller at the Douala based "Compagnie Batoula", in the chemical industry sector. Between 1985 and 1992 he was administrative and finance director of the local subsidiary of the French Rhone-Poulenc company. Since 1992  Mr. Fotso has operated as an independent businessman by first creating 3T CAMEROUN (transit service company), then FME-AGROCHIMIE (distribution of chemical and phytosanitary products, closed in 1999 due to inability to compete after sector liberalization), and lastly FME-GAZ in 1993. Mr. Fotso is highly regarded and respected in Cameroon business circles.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated art US$ 621,000. The proposed IFC investment is an A venture loan for IFC''s own account for the amount of US$ 310,500 (US$1 = CFA750).
Investment: 0.31 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan0.31Equity* These investment figures are indicative

The land belongs to the state-owned industrial land authority "MAGZI" (Mission d''Amenagement et de Gestion des Zones Industrielles), and the company has a 25-year renewable long-term lease (valid through June 20, 2020) over the site. The site has easy access to major transport networks (road, rail and sea).

Project Description: The project consists of the construction and operation of a greenfield, vertically integrated furniture component operation with an annual capacity for wood harvesting of up to 250,000 m3, sawmilling of up to 150,000 m3, and furniture component production of up to 24,000 m3. The plant''s production, to be made of both birch and pine, and eventually also spruce, will be designed specifically to fit into IKEA''s global supply structure, and to complement IKEA''s existing network of Russian suppliers.  In addition, IFC and Swedwood are considering the implementation of a technical assistance (TA) program to improve the sustainability of the company''s operations, including training of local forest operators that would eventually supply the plant.  The project represents the initial step in Swedwood''s long-term strategy to create its first integrated production base for furniture manufacturing in Russia. The project is expected to have a significant development impact by increasing the economic value of the forest resources of the Leningrad region, which are currently under-utilized, and by conducting sustainable forestry practices in the project area.  It will also provide direct employment to approximately 425 people in a remote area, to be considerably expanded in the long term.  The sponsor will allocate substantial resources to training, similar to its other production facilities in Eastern Europe.  Indirectly, the local business community will benefit from the project as a nucleus for regional development.  Further, the implementation of the proposed TA program is expected to result in long-term contracts for local companies to supply Swedwood, which will create stable revenues and employment opportunities.IFC''s role in this project is to provide comfort to the sponsor in its first investment in the Russian forestry sector.  IFC will also have a strong role in mobilizing financial and technical resources to build up the capabilities of local forest operators and contribute to improving the business climate in the forestry sector.

Swedwood is a fully-owned subsidiary of Stiching Ingka Foundation, a privately held entity that owns IKEA, the home furnishings retailer.  Headquartered in Sweden, Swedwood was founded in 1991 with the goal of securing furniture production capacity for IKEA, mainly in Eastern Europe.

Project Description: Teteks operations are currently organized into four divisions:  (i) spinning; (ii) weaving; (iii) knitting; and (iv) ready-made-garments.  The production process starts with producing yarn from wool tops, and continues into the production of fabrics, blankets, knit products and garments.  The company employed 3,864 workers as of 2000 year-end. Teteks has a few non-textile subsidiaries in Macedonia including Teteks Banka.  Business activities of the non-banking subsidiaries include trading, recycling of waste materials from the textile operations, production of packaging materials mainly for the textile products, a gas station, transportation, and a travel agency.  Teteks also has representative offices in the U.S., Bulgaria, Germany, Croatia, Albania, Bosnia and FR Yugoslavia,  which serve to support the company''s export activities.  The proposed investment should assist Teteks in achieving its two core strategic objectives: (i) to increase exports by improving the quality and range of its products, and (ii) to reduce costs, both in an environmentally sound and socially responsible way.  The proposed project program encompasses the following main components.Textile operations modernization program:  Teteks plans to further modernize its spinning, weaving, knitting, and ready-made-garments facilities.  This investment should enhance Teteks'' export opportunities by both improving the quality of its products and its product development capacity and reducing its costs.   Energy efficiency and environment component:  A portion of the textile project, financed by a grant from the government of Netherlands, is investment in Teteks'' energy plant to reduce air and soil pollution and energy costs.  Teteks Corporate Citizenship Initiative (Teteks CCI):  A portion of the project is to establish the Teteks CCI with objective to provide financing to Teteks'' laid-off workers to help them start their own small businesses.  Through this initiative, Teteks would help the community by providing commercially sustainable market opportunities to small and medium enterprises (SMEs), creating new job opportunities, and fostering entrepreneurship.  Teteks Banka will be the manager of the Teteks CCI.  On a best efforts and as needed basis, IFC would raise trust funds to finance the technical assistance development programs for the company''s laid-off workers and/or for the institutional development of Teteks Banka.  Short-term debt repayment and refinancing will also be part of the project.  This will improve company''s debt service capacity and reduce overall interest expense.  Waste water treatment plant:  A portion of the project would finance a waste water treatment plant.  If by January 2003 the government has not initiated building a municipal treatment plant, Teteks has agreed to build a system to ensure its waste water is treated prior being released by the end of 2003. This is second IFC''s project with Teteks.  IFC has already provided a US$1.5 million equivalent loan financing to Teteks in 1997, supporting a modernization program which has successfully been implemented.  The second project with Teteks is consistent with the initially proposed phased approach in implementing the company''s modernization program.  Given the visibility of Teteks and this project in the region, the project will serve to encourage additional foreign direct investment in Macedonia at a time when foreign investors are wary because of regional instability in south-east Europe.

In the common services department office at the Teteks plant, Tetevo, Macedonia.
Sponsor: The project sponsor is Teteks, A.D. (the company or Teteks), a joint stock company established in 1951.  Teteks is 100% privatized with a diverse shareholding structure.  The company is the largest wool textile mill in Macedonia and the only vertically integrated textile operation in Europe.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at US$10.4 million equivalent.  IFC has been requested to provide up to US$5.3 million equivalent in a form of a senior loan to Teteks of which US$5.0 million would be to help finance the company''s textile operations'' investment program, and US$0.3 million would be to finance a newly formed Teteks Corporate Citizenship Initiative (Teteks CCI), a program that would help create job opportunities.

Project Description: The project is to expand hotel operations by adding 56 rooms to the existing 25 rooms; in addition a garden and recreation/sports facilities will be added with the overall concept being a garden resort.  The project''s concept responds directly to increasing demand for better quality rooms and tourist facilities in Luang Prabang. IFC''s involvement in this project enables long term loan financing for the project, both in terms of the IFC loan as well as a parallel loan from a local bank.  The local bank has approved their loan because of the IFC managed Mekong Project Development Facility (MPDF)  assistance to the project and IFC''s proposed financing.  Without IFC, significant long term funds would not have been available, and thus, the project would not have been able to go forward at this time.  The project has been developed with the assistance of MPDF, who has worked with the company for over a year to strengthen the project plan and, in particular, improve the hotel''s management capabilities and increase training of staff.Funds are sought under the IFC''s Extending the Reach Program. With its 100% Lao ownership, the project fits both MPDF''s and the IFC Extending the Reach Program''s shared objective to promote development of local small and medium scale enterprises.  The venture is also in line with IFC''s overall strategy to support Lao PDR''s transition to a market economy while helping to meet the country''s need to earn and save foreign exchange.  The project will have a demonstration effect for local banks by encouraging them to develop stronger capacities to evaluate risk, and consider other projects, in the Lao PDR tourism sector.The project is in line with the Wold Bank Group long term strategy to reduce poverty, promote infrastructure, and promote human resource development, as well as fitting the World Bank Group strategy to promote macroeconomic stability and further enable the environment for private sector development.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe project description and Environmental Review Summary (ERS) was publically disclosed in English and local language newspapers in Lao PDR twice,  first for a two week period starting October 10, 2000 and then for another two week period starting February 15, 2001. In addition, the project description and ERS summary were posted in English and Lao language in the village next to the project site, at the gate of the project site itself, and at the offices of the Chamber of Commerce of Luang Prabang during those periods.  Currently, the project description and ERS are publically available for review at the Chamber of Commerce of Luang Prabang and at the offices of the Hotel Villa Santi.
Sponsor: The project sponsor is the single proprietorship Hotel Villa Santi Hotel company (Villa Santi or the company) and its owner, Mr. Santi Inthavong.  Mr. Inthavong is 40 years old and was born in Lao PDR. He spent many years overseas and was educated in France, Thailand, and Lao PDR. In 1992, he and his wife started the Villa Santi  as one of the first 100% privately owned hotels in Luang Prabang, Lao PDR. In 1994, Villa Santi registered as a hotel business at the Provincial Commerce department. In a short period of time  the hotel successfully developed a strong reputation for service and best occupancy rates in Luang Prabang.
Cost Nature: Total project cost is estimated at US$ 2.76m and the proposed IFC investment consists of a  loan of US$ 1.15m.
Investment: 1.15 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan1.15Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The project is located on Nadeui Road, in Nadeui Village, a rural area on the outskirts of the small city of Luang Prabang.  Luang Prabang is the old royal capital of Lao PDR and is home to numerous temples and buildings of religious and historical significance.  The site is six kilometers from the city center and located outside the UNESCO World Heritage restricted zone; nevertheless, the project''s architectural plans have been reviewed and approved by the World Heritage architect.  The project is a resort concept using traditional building designs on ten hectares of land; electricity and water treatment facilities are also being installed.  Access to the site is on paved and grated roads maintained by the local government.

In addition, the project description and ERS summary were posted in English and Lao language in the village next to the project site, at the gate of the project site itself, and at the offices of the Chamber of Commerce of Luang Prabang during those periods.  Currently, the project description and ERS are publically available for review at the Chamber of Commerce of Luang Prabang and at the offices of the Hotel Villa Santi.

Project Description: Sonic Duo was established to offer GSM mobile cellular services in the Moscow license area, covering the city of Moscow and the Moscow Oblast.  In May 2000, Sonic Duo received the third cellular license in Moscow to offer GSM cellular services in the 900/1800 MHz frequency range.  This project would help the company build out its network and provide GSM cellular service to the area.This project will help increase the country''s wireless penetration directly by spurring competition in the Moscow license area, and also indirectly, by promoting additional investment and growth to other areas of Russia through the demonstration effect, attracting other telecommunications operators as the market and industry mature.   IFC would provide long-term financing for its own account and for the account of participant banks, which is not otherwise available.  At present, long-term commercial financing is not available in Russia, particularly on the tenor and conditions necessary to finance a major infrastructure project.  The project would therefore mobilize foreign direct investment in Russia, providing a demonstrative effect by showing that longer-term financing is available in the country on a project finance basis for non-export driven projects.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFC''s Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result, which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityInformation-Consultancy Center of the Public Libraries Bolshoy Kiselny Lane 16, Moscow, RussiaTel.: 095 925-95-49, Fax: 095 925-60-18
Sponsor: The project sponsors of Sonic Duo (the company) are Sonera and LV Finance, owning 35% and 65%, respectively, of the company through wholly-owned subsidiaries.  Sonera, the technical and marketing partner of Sonic Duo, is a publicly listed international telecommunications operator based in Finland, where it has over 2 million customers.  It has extensive experience in operating telecommunications networks in emerging markets including the Baltics, Turkey, and Russia.  LV Finance provides investment advisory to Russian and international companies on M&A and corporate finance transactions in the Russian telecommunications, Internet, and media sectors, and invests actively for its own account in the telecommunications and technology sectors.  LV Finance is a privately held company which was founded by its largest shareholder, Mr. Leonid Rozhetskin, the former co-founder and head of investment banking at Renaissance Capital.
Cost Nature: The estimated project cost is US$210 million, to fund network construction as well as operating losses in the first two years of operations.  IFC''s proposed investment comprises an equity or quasi-equity investment of approximately US$6 million and an A Loan of approximately US$24 million, both for IFC''s account, as well as a B Loan of US$10 million for the account of participant banks.  The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) is considering to provide parallel financing on similar terms.

Company Name: TURKIYE SISE VE CAM FABRIKALARI ANONIM SIRKETI
Project Description: The project is a proposed corporate loan to the Sisecam  Group, with Sise ve Cam Fabrikalari (the holding company of the Group) as the borrower, and Trakya Cam, Pasabahce Cam, Anadolu Cam and Cam Elyaf as co-borrowers; all are long standing clients of IFC.  The co-borrowers have been identified as principal users of the loan, with indicative amounts as incremental working capital requirements allotted to each of them.  However, on disbursement of the loan, the borrower will decide on the actual amount of distribution depending on the immediate and current working capital needs of the co-borrowers.The recent crisis in Turkey has severely curtailed domestic market demand in the manufacturing sector, presenting challenges for the corporate sector at large.  The Sisecam Group, which is dominant in the domestic glass market (67% of total sales), is attempting to mitigate the impact of falling sales by increasing exports. With an existing export base of about $330 million, which is expected to grow, the Group is faced with the challenge of finding dependable source of funding to finance its exports. Exports typically require higher working capital due to the longer receivables period and additional inventory carrying costs. The Group is funding its existing working capital requirements through short term debt financing, payable in one year, subject to rollover at renewal. In the past, such rollovers were routinely granted but, given the present state of the Turkish economy, Sisecam is finding it increasingly difficult to extend its short term debts from local or foreign banks.  Local Turkish Lira loans from Turkish Eximbank are harder to obtain, while foreign banks have reached their Turkish exposure limits and are unwilling to extend existing or new loans.  As a result, the Group is looking to IFC to provide a dependable and stable source of future financing for working capital needs with a $35 million loan.  This loan would mitigate some of Sisecam''s liquidity constraints and increase its export marketing capacity. After the recent political and macro economical turmoil, interest rates in Turkey have increased sharply and credits have become very scarce.  More importantly, local financial institutions do not provide the financial depth required for the long-term, outward looking strategic development of major corporations in Turkey.  Loan maturities exceeding even a one year range are currently not available to the Turkish market.  In addition, Turkish Eximbank does not have sufficient resources to provide Sisecam''s export credit requirements and to process the applications in a timely manner.  Without IFCs investment, the Group would be forced to rely on extremely limited, short-term and more expensive financing which would adversely affect liquidity.  In the context of the uncertain economic environment and competitive pressures in the regional glass sector, the project critically supports the sustained and competitive evolution of a vital Turkish corporation.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category C project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  The existing investment in Sisecam is in material compliance with the specified World Bank Group policies and guidelines.  No additional environmental and social review is required for this additional financing.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The project sponsor is the Sisecam Group.  Turkiye Sise ve Cam Fabrikalari Group (Sisecam, or the Group) is comprised of Turkiye Sise ve Cam Fabrikalari A.S. (TSCFAS, or the Holding Company) and 28 affiliates/subsidiaries companies, in which TSCFAS owns a majority shareholding and/or effectively controls their management.  TSCFAS was established 65 years ago in Turkey by Turkiye Is Bankasi A.S. (Is Bank), one of the largest private commercial banks in Turkey.  Currently Is Bank has a controlling interest in the Sisecam Group and owns 69% of its capital.  The principal companies consolidated into the Group are:Trakya Cam Sanayii A.S. : float glassPasabahce Cam Sanayii ve Ticaret A.S. : glass tablewareAnadolu Cam Sanayii A.S. : glass packaging Cam Elyaf Sanayii A.S. : fiber glassSisecam is one of the largest glass producers in Europe and the industry leader in Turkey.  Group companies are engaged in the production and sales of a variety of glass products (from hand-made crystal to container, pharmaceutical glass, mechanical glassware and float glass), and glass related chemicals.  The Group employs cutting edge technology in its production facilities and uses sophisticated systems and up-to-date marketing methods to sell its products, and employs a workforce of over 12,500 people.  Total production capacity is approximately 1.5 million tons per year and the Group''s production accounted for approximately 1.5% of total global glass output and 4% of European glass production.
Cost Nature: The total working capital requirement for the four co-borrowers within the Sisecam Group is estimated to be $400 million in 2001 and 2002.  IFC''s proposed working capital facility investment is a $35 million A loan in Euro equivalent for IFC''s own account.
Investment: 35.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan35.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Group plants are strategically located all over Turkey with convenient access to raw materials, power and energy sources, tranportation facilities, and customers.  Specifically, plants of the four co-borrowers are located in Luleburgaz in the Thrace region of Turkey, and in Mersin.  The Group is headquartered in Istanbul, Turkey.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category C project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure. Project Description: On May 29, 1998, IFC approved a US$10 million convertible pre-privatization loan to Banc Post.  The loan is fully disbursed and was originally intended to be converted, in whole or part, before June 30, 2000.  However, owing to delays caused by post-privatization uncertainty over the shareholding structure of BP, IFC was not willing to convert last year.  At the time of the privatization, GE Capital (GE) was to be the strategic technical partner, taking 35% of BP, with Banco Portugues de Investimento (BPI) taking 10%.  The remainder was to remain with local shareholders, and both IFC and EBRD provided US$10 million pre-privatization loans with options to convert into equity at the average price paid by GE and BPI.  Payment for the shares was to have been made in 12 installments.  However, after three installments, GE decided to withdraw from the transaction, and the success of the privatization looked to be in jeopardy.  Largely due to the support of IFC and the efforts of BPI,  the Greek Eurobank (EFG) was brought in to replace GE.  At the insistence of the Romanian authorities, GE remains with the shares that it had already paid for.  With all these changes, it is now apparent that our existing loan does not match the current or future needs of BP or its shareholders.  To meet EFG''s growth targets, BP needs equity or tier 2 capital, but our existing facility is a senior loan which has already started amortizing.  IFC''s convertible pre-privatization loan to BP supported the bank''s privatization and facilitated the entry of a strategic technical partner.  The positive effects usually associated with privatization are beginning to show also in the BP case: strengthening of management, introduction of new products, efficiency gains and greater competitive.  The new investment would further strengthen BP by providing the bank with additional funding necessary to enter new businesses.  As a result, Romania should see a deepening and broadening of the financial sector.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category FI Type 1 project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure.  BP will establish and implement an environmental management system for its corporate lending and leasing operations to ensure that the activities and enterprises it finances comply with Romanian environmental and occupational health & safety requirements.  The management system will include training of BP staff and the provision of an annual environmental report to IFC.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: EFG Eurobank (EFG) is the strategic technical partner with about 19.25% share ownership.  EFG is the sixth largest Greek corporate (in market capitalization) and had about US$1.0 billion in gross revenue in 1999.   EFG employs about 3700 in 175 branches throughout Greece.  EFG provides retail, corporate, investment and merchant banking services to Greek enterprises, private banking to high net worth individuals, as well as mutual fund management, treasury, advisory and custodian services.Shareholding structure is as follows: EFG Eurobank:  19.25%; BPI:  17%; SOF (State Ownership Fund, now called APAPs):  17%; GE Capital:  8.75%; Banc Post (BP) employees and management:  8%; and local private investment funds (SIFs):  30%
Cost Nature: IFC''s investment will be in the form of a convertible subordinated loan of up to $10,000,000, which would replace the existing US$10,000,000 currently outstanding.  The new facility will conform with all National Bank of Romania''s definition of tier 2 capital.
Investment: 10.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan10.0Equity0.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Banc Post S.A. (BP or the bank) is headquarted in Bucharest and has over 125 branches across Romania.  Loans and investments can be made throughout the country.

BP will establish and implement an environmental management system for its corporate lending and leasing operations to ensure that the activities and enterprises it finances comply with Romanian environmental and occupational health & safety requirements.  The management system will include training of BP staff and the provision of an annual environmental report to IFC.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community

Project Description: The purpose of the project is to support the expansion of a fast-growing, well capitalized housing finance company focused on Southern India.  The Indian mortgage market has witnessed growth of 20% in the past five years and is expected to continue to grow at double digit rates into the near future. This growth reflects the huge demand of India''s population and the fact that the country suffers from a housing shortage estimated at 19 million units in 2001. Sundaram Home Finance will provide mortgages to underserved markets both outside and within the major metropolitan areas in the south.IFC''s role is to provide long-term fixed rate debt so the company can fund its mortgages loans with limited interest rate and maturity mismatches, and no currency risk. IFC has also been providing the company with ongoing advice in the areas of market strategy, asset and liability management, and product development. The main development impact comes at two levels. First, IFC''s funds will enable Sundaram Home to make loans to Indian households, which will directly improve their living conditions and quality of life.  Second, the provision of housing finance helps improve the housing stock, stimulating the construction sector and other industrial activities.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category C project according to IFCs environmental review procedure.  No further environmental review is required.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: Sundaram Home Finance (SHF or the company) is a Chennai-based, new private sector mortgage company sponsored by India''s leading multi-finance firm, Sundaram Finance (SF), which holds a 65% equity stake in the company.  IFC has an equity stake of 20% in the company along with the Dutch development bank, FMO accounting for 15%. Sundaram Finance, the promoter, was established in 1954.  Over the last forty-six years, SF has expanded operations and built up a network of 100 branches across India, with a focus on the southern states. It is viewed as one the strongest finance firms in terms of its distribution.
Cost Nature: The project is to provide a local currency denominated eight year credit line of up to Rs500 million (US$10.6 million equivalent) to Sundaram Home Finance to fund the expansion of its mortgage loan portfolio.
Investment: 10.42 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan10.42Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Sundaram Home Finance is based in Chennai, India and has several branches throughout the state of Tamil Nadu and a branch in Hyderabad. The IFC loan will be available to grant mortgage loans to individuals in any of SHF''s locations.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category C project according to IFCs environmental review procedure.  No further environmental review is required.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community

Project Description: Project DescriptionThe project involves establishment of Africap a private equity fund which will make investments in MFIs across the African continent. The fund will be closed-end with a ten year life, and will make investments in the form of equity and quasi-equity in about 10 well-performing MFIs in Africa. Africaps fund manager will be Africap MicroVentures Ltd., a wholly owned subsidiary of Calmeadow.  In addition to capital, the fund manager will provide advisory services and coordinate technical assistance funding for a full range of strategic and operational improvements to the selected microfinance institutions.  These initiatives, as well as more general industry promotion activities, will be supported by a parallel grant-funded technical services facility, which will be closely coordinated with the fund.Development ImpactDemonstration Effect.  The primary objective of the fund will be to promote the commercial viability of African MFIs by investing and providing technical assistance in order to build them into successful models of commercial micro-finance. This demonstration impact will be reached as the investee companies develop into profitable and growing operations, on the model of similar institutions in Latin America, in which ProFund has invested. The fund will seek to act as a catalyst early on by having private co-investors in its ventures. Private Sector Development , Economic and Living Standards Contribution.  The entry of micro-finance institutions in the formal financial system, or the provision of micro-finance services by traditional financial institutions represents a significant step in integrating the formal and informal sectors, thereby helping the informal sector live up to its economic development potential.More generally, the involvement of sustainable MFIs in the formal financial sector can have a powerful legitimizing impact on an emerging sector, bringing forth several benefits including: an expansion in scale and outreach of MFIs to serve an increasing number of clients among a base of poor people without any access to basic financial services; the recognition of previously marginalized people and their treatment as clients; the development of new products and services for such clients; and the improvement of efficiency and resource allocation within the financial markets.IFC RoleIFCs solid track record as a risk-taking investor, strategic advisor, and technical assistance provider to the financial services industry places it in a unique position to provide comfort to other investors acting as anchor investor and participating in the growth and development of the industry at this critical stage of its evolution.IFC also has an important role in the structuring of the fund.  IFC has stressed the lessons learned in its private equity investments, and the sponsor has incorporated such best practices in the structuring of this project to align the interests of the sponsors and the various investors.  IFC will also play an important governance role through its participation in the board and investment committee of the fund.  Finally, IFC will contribute its regional and micro-finance expertise.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Financial Intermediary (FI) Type 1 category project according to IFCs environmental review procedure.  The fund will be required to develop an environmental management system that will require that investee companies investment operations meet host country environmental, health and safety requirements and be consistent with IFCs Microfinance Exclusion List.  IFC will work with the fund to develop an environmental review capacity. Depending upon IFCs assessment, environmental training will be required.  The fund will be required to provide an annual environmental performance report to IFC.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The sponsors of the project, Calmeadow and Accion International, are two institutions with considerable experience in micro-finance and with strong international reputation.  Calmeadow, a Canadian non-profit organization, is a global micro-finance pioneer, with investments and advisory work internationally and experience operating two loan funds in Canada.  The goal of Calmeadows international work is to support the development of a thriving global micro-finance industry that will eventually attract commercial capital to fund its growth.  Calmeadows roots are in the Latin American micro-finance community where it helped create, along with Accion, BancoSol (1992), Latin Americas first regulated private commercial micro-finance bank.  Cameldow was also a sponsor of Profund (1995), Latin Americas first specialized private equity fund for micro-finance institutions (MFIs) in which IFC is an investor. Calmeadow has since initiated a strategic expansion into Africa (1996). Calmeadow has been coordinating the preparation of AfriCap Microfinance Fund (Africap or the fund). It will invest in the fund and participate in the funds board and investment committee.Accion International is a USA-based non-profit organization dedicated to micro-finance with: 26 affiliates in Latin America; an active research, policy and communications program; investment capacity through in-house funds; and a team of 30 investment professionals that provide technical and management support to organizations in the field.  Its strategy of providing a combination of long-term technical support together with an equity presence in those institutions permits it to enhance its investees'' value through an equity/governance role.  In 2000, Accion made a strategic commitment to expand into Africa. Accion will also invest in the fund and participate in the funds board and investment committee.Other institutions considering investment in the fund, either directly or indirectly, include: Argidius Foundation, Calvert, Cordaid, DFID, DOEN Foundation, the European Investment Bank, FMO, IFC, Swedish AfriCap Consortium, USAID, and Triodos.
Cost Nature: The funds targeted size is US$15 million, with a minimum first closing of US$10 million. The proposed IFC investment is of up to US$2 million (for capital contributions as well as management fees).
Investment: 2.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity2.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Africap  is to be incorporated as a for-profit investment fund company in Mauritius.  The fund management company, AfriCap MicroVentures, Ltd, will start operations with an office in Dakar, Senegal and subsequently open an office in East or South Africa.  The geographical focus of the fund is the whole African continent and neighboring islands, with an emphasis on Sub-Saharan Africa excluding South Africa.

IFC will work with the fund to develop an environmental review capacity. Depending upon IFCs assessment, environmental training will be required.  The fund will be required to provide an annual environmental performance report to IFC.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community

Project Description: The  tourism resort that will be constructed and operated will consist of 24 villas and a central complex which will group  the reception area, offices and lounges, a restaurant building, a spa and a swimming pool.  At the entrance of the property, a service building containing storage rooms, a laundry facility and locker rooms for staff will be built. Bel Air Plantation Ltd. was specifically established to own and operate the proposed tourism resort.The project is expected to create employment for 66 persons at full operation.  It will provide training to workers who will be recruited mainly from the St. David''s area.  In addition, it will, as far as possible, purchase food and supplies produced locally.  Guests at the resort will require sightseeing and touring services and are expected to purchase artwork, crafts and souvenirs from the local community, further contributing to the local economy.In addition to providing long-term financing which is not available in the country for long maturities, IFC will assist the sponsor with environmental management improvements and will provide technical assistance and advice on project structuring and operation.  It will also assist the company to secure additional financing.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityEnvironmental documents related to the project are available in Grenada at the company''s offices located at St. David''s Point in St. David''s Parish, at the St. George''s Public Library in Carenage, St. George''s, and at the World Bank Infoshop in Washington, DC, USA
Sponsor: The project is sponsors are Dr. Michael Fisher and Miss Susan Fisher who equally own Bel Air Plantation Ltd. Dr. Fisher is an internationally famous scientist who won the 1989 Edison Award for the most significant discovery of the year.  Miss Fisher has held senior management positions in the retail industry.
Cost Nature: The total project cost, including working capital, is estimated at US$6.3 million (EC$16.8 million equivalent).  IFC proposes to contribute a senior loan the amount of US$1.5 million and an income participating loan of US$0.5 million in support of the project.
Investment: 2.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan2.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The project site is located at St. David''s Parish, a rural area at 20 km from St. George''s, Grenada''s capital city.  The site is bordered by sand and pebble beach on one side, and by a cliff on the other side.  It was previously uninhabited and used occasionally for pasture of cattle.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityEnvironmental documents related to the project are available in Grenada at the company''s offices located at St. David''s Point in St. David''s Parish, at the St. George''s Public Library in Carenage, St. George''s, and at the World Bank Infoshop in Washington, DC, USA

Project Description: Operating since January 2000, MEB Kosovo is a specialized provider of credit and financial services to private micro and small enterprises in Kosovo.  As of the end of May 2001, total credit provided was US$15.9 million equivalent, including a loan portfolio of over 1,200 accounts totalling US$5.7 million equivalent, with an average loan size of about US$4,700 and average maturity of ten months.  Portfolio quality is high, with the end-May arrears rate reported at 0.5%; the sectoral distribution of the portfolio was 65% to trading enterprises, 20% to the light manufacturing sector, and 15% to the service sector.  The bank reported net income of US$3.7 million in 2000.  MEB Kosovo has experienced an exceptionally high rate of deposit mobilization.  Customer deposits were US$110.0 million as of end-May, representing 36,563 depositors.Although initially developed to provide microcredit, MEB Kosovo quickly has become a key part of the payments infrastructure of Kosovo -- an infrastructure which was wiped out by the conflict in the former Yugoslav province.  The bank has, in addition, developed a considerable international transfer business and has attracted a large deposit base of over US$100.0 million.  This is a major achievement, considering the widespread losses depositors suffered due to wartime confiscation of savings accounts, and the collapse of pyramid savings schemes during the early 1990s.  It is estimated that about 90% of Kosovo''s money supply is still held outside the banking system.  In common with the other parts of the former Yugoslavia, therefore, there is a need to support new, professionally-managed and credible financial institutions in Kosovo which can be trusted as both deposit-taking and lending institutions.  Following its very successful launch, MEB Kosovo strategy in 2001/02 is to build on its province-wide presence by establishing itself as the main lender to the MSE sector.Microfinance schemes have shown a major positive impact in reducing poverty and unemployment in emerging markets worldwide, and -- in recognition of this strong developmental impact -- almost all multilateral and bilateral institutions and donor agencies are actively promoting microfinance schemes.  The developmental impact of commercially-run microcredit programs in particular, on post-confict transition economy populations with little or no access to formal credit institutions has been well-demonstrated by IFC''s microcredit investments in Bosnia-Herzegovina and Albania.  IFC''s developmental strategy in the field is to attract serious private sector investment in microfinance by demonstrating that microfinance can be a viable commercial proposition.The proposed investment in MEB Kosovo is expected to be strongly developmental -- in terms of its economic impacts, stimulus for business reconstruction, employment generation, confidence-building in the banking sector, and introduction of commercially-oriented microfinance techniques to Kosovo.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category FI Type 1 project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure. IPC/IMI has in place an environmental management framework to ensure that each financial institution in which IMI invests will have an environmental management system (EMS).  Under that framework, IMI will cause MEB Kosovo to develop and implement an EMS requiring activities financed to comply with the applicable environmental, health and safety legislation and standards of Yugoslavia and to be consistent with IFCs Microfinance Exclusion List.  MEB Kosovo will be required to provide an annual environmental performance report to IPC.  In turn, IPC will provide IFC a consolidated annual environmental performance report on IMI investments and environmental management. IMIs report for CY2000 was satisfactory.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: Micro Enterprise Bank of Kosovo (MEB Kosovo, or the bank) is jointly sponsored by IFC, EBRD, Kreditanstalt fur Wiederaufbau (KfW), Nederlandse Financierungs Maatschappij Voor Ontwikkelingslanden (FMO) and Commerzbank.  Current bank shareholders are: FMO (21.7%), Commerzbank AG (21.7%),  KfW (via FEFAD Foundation of Albania) (21.7%), Internationale Micro Investitionen AG (IMI) (17.4%), and Micro Enterprise Bank Bosnia (MEB Bosnia) (17.4%). IPC, the project technical partner, was established in 1980 in Germany, and is a leading international consulting and financial services company specializing in development and management of microfinance institutions.  IFC has a global relationship with IPC, and is currently working with IPC in Bosnia, Georgia, Haiti, Moldova and Ukraine, among other countries.  IMI was established by IPC in 1998, to provide an investment vehicle for IPC-managed microfinance ventures in developing and transition economies.  IFC subscribed to a 16% stake in IMI in November 2000 for US$2.0 million equivalent.  Micro Enterprise Bank Bosnia, established in 1997, is owned by IFC, EBRD, FMO, KfW and IMI/IPC.   The bank has six branches in Sarajevo, Ilidza, Bihac, Tuzla, Mostar and Banja Luka.  It reported total assets of US$14.3 million, including a loan portfolio of US$9.5 million, and total equity of US$4.1 million, as of Q1 2001.  EBRD has successfully collaborated with IFC on microfinance projects in Albania, Bosnia, Moldova, Ukraine and Georgia.  KfW is the German Government''s bilateral lending agency, and is a shareholder in IFC investee microfinance institutions FEFAD Bank (Albania), MEB (Bosnia), MFB (Ukraine) and MBG (Georgia).  FMO, a Dutch development bank jointly owned by the Dutch government and the country''s leading private banks and trade unions, is an investor with IFC in MEB (Bosnia), MEB (Kosovo) and MBG (Georgia).  Commerzbank is Germany''s third-largest bank group, with a network of over 900 domestic branches and significant international operations in asset management, investment banking and insurance.  As of Q1 2001, Commerzbank Group reported total assets of Euro 492.9 billion and equity of Euro 12.7 billion.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at US$8.8 million equivalent.  The IFC investment is an option to purchase 16.7% of MEB Kosovo''s share capital, for up to EURO 1.25 million (US$1.1 million equivalent).

Project Description: The company is involved in the purchase and distribution of fuel and is divided into three different divisions which carry out complementary activities: (i) Sanke Station: owns the stations and manages the purchase and distribution of fuel; (ii) Sanke Transport: brings to their final destination the products ordered by the company or its customers; and (iii) Sanke Transit: manages the company''s administration with the custom''s office when importing goods.  The project consists in the purchase of 27 tank trucks to renew the existing fleet (89 trucks) and allow the company to gain new contracts and ensure the functioning of its new depot under construction. The development impacts of the project are expected to be:Supply of Fuel: The truck acquisition would help diversify and thus strengthen Malis supply of fuel.Employment Creation: 54 jobs would be created: 27 drivers and 27 apprentices would be hired.Revenues for the State: The company would be one of the largest tax and customs duty contributors to the State.IFC''s role in this project will be as:Lender of Last Resort: The project would support a local entrepreneur who up to now did not have access to long term financing.Support to Local Entrepreneur: Proparco, as the agent, has provided advice on the financial and managerial aspects of the company. It  has also strengthened the companys financial reporting by putting the sponsor in contact with an auditor. Lastly, Proparco has sensitized the sponsor to the importance of respecting the local regulations and in ensuring an on time supply of fuel to the final destinations.

Project Description: The project involves the launch of South Africa''s first local currency residential mortgage securitization.  SAHL''s business model is largely based on its ability to offer mortgage rates below current market levels, based largely on low-cost, securitization based funding from institutional investors.  SAHL''s mortgage portfolio has now reached sufficient size to launch its first placement of mortgage backed securities in the institutional markets. IFCs participation in SAHL''s "maiden" securitization will significantly increase the probability of a successful placement, which is a fundamental requirement for the success of SAHL''s business model.  IFC will also be able to add a lot of value in the structuring period, based on its experience with similar initiatives in other emerging markets.  The project is also in line with IFC''s strategy to develop and modernize the housing finance sector in emerging markets through investments in model transactions that other investors may wish to follow. The proposed project will be an efficient way of channeling long-term financing from institutional investors in MBS to retail home mortgage borrowers. The project is expected to have a significant developmental impact in a number of areas:  (i) it will improve the feasibility of the securitization of domestic assets in South Africa by allowing the accumulation of an economically efficient sized pool of assets, (ii) it will introduce the concept of  securitization warehouse lending in the local banking market and (iii) by helping a pioneering initiative like SA Home Loans succeed the project will improve competition in the domestic market for housing finance.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category C project, according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because it is likely to have minimal or no adverse environmental impacts.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The project sponsor is SA Home Loans (Pty) Limited (SA Home Loans or SAHL), South Africa''s first specialized residential mortgage origination, servicing and securitization company.  SAHL started operations in early 1999 and, since then, it has proven itself as a successful originator and servicer of residential mortgages.  IFC holds a 10% equity stake in SA Home Loans.  Other major shareholders include Peregrine Holdings, Standard Bank, JP Morgan and Management.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at R1 billion consisting of three tranches of securities: senior AAA rated notes, mezzanine BBB rated notes, and a junior equity piece.   IFC''s proposed investment is in up to R40 million of BBB rated mezzanine notes for its own account.
Investment: 6.06 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan6.06Equity* These investment figures are indicative

Project Name: Astana Tower Business and Shopping Center
Project Description: The project involves the development of a greenfield business and shopping center in view of the anticipated demand for quality office and shopping space in Astana. In 1998, Astana became Kazakhstan''s new capital and most of the national government administration has since been moved from Almaty to Astana.  Businesses and foreign investors have also started to establish their presence in the capital city.  However, the lack of quality business infrastructure has been an impediment to more rapid movement of businesses to Astana, and has hindered Astana''s emergence as a fully developed new capital.  Astana Business and Shopping Center (ABS, or the company) responds to this growing need for modern business and office space in the emerging capital city of Kazakhstan.  In Astana, ABS is the first business and shopping center built to international standards. ABS is located in a busy area of Astana at the intersection of one of the citys busiest avenues leading to  government, city administration, and diplomatic quarters.  The project was designed by Turkish architects and has been developed by Ahsel Group, which has been active and known in Kazakhstan, most notably through its Regent Ankara Hotel in Almaty.  ABS consists of a 20-floor office/ residential tower and a 3-floor shopping area, which is connected to the tower at the ground floor.  The building is suitable for international companies and is equipped with modern facilities, including a fitness center, central heating and air-conditioning, security systems, information technology network, communications systems, fire/ smoke detectors and sprinklers.  Development Impact:  The projects developmental impact is expected to be significant since the project will help upgrade the local business environment, introduce modern business practices, and provide shopping facilities in the local community.  The project will help attract private businesses and foreign capital to Astana and help develop the new capital of Kazakhstan.  IFC Role:  The project is in line with the Kazakh government''s priority to rapidly establish the city as the nation''s capital by encouraging influx of private businesses in Astana as well.  Astana is likely to attract more businesses to relocate from Almaty if the currently available business and office infrastructure is upgraded to meet required international standards. IFC''s investment would signal confidence in the development of private sector activity in Astana and private investment in Kazakhstan.  IFC will provide the company with long-term financing, which is not available in the local market.  Furthermore, IFC has introduced Ahsel Group to the World Trade Center organization, which is seeking to extend its network into Kazakhstan and is considering locating their operation in Astana Tower.  This is likely to significantly benefit Kazakhstan''s integration with overseas markets.  Finally, IFC will work with the sponsors to increase their awareness of international safety and construction standards, which is expected to result in consistent application of these standards in other Ahsel tourism and residential development projects.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe environmental documents will be publicly available in Astana local newspaper, and at the project site on the ABS premises.
Sponsor: The project is sponsored by companies of the Ahsel Group of Turkey and by Mr. Ayan, who is the founder of Ahsel Group and major shareholder in its member companies.  The project company is 100% owned by Ahsel Construction Undertaking and Trade.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is about US$22 million.  The proposed IFC investment is a loan of up to US$5 million.
