Company Name: Pasabahce-Schott Cam Sanayi ve Ticaret A.S.
Project Description: Pasabahce-Eskisehir was originally incorporated in 1998 as Pasabahce-Schott, a joint venture between Pasabahce Cam of Turkey and Schott-Zwiesel of Germany. Sisecam  and Carl Zeiss Stiftung (CZS) were the two sponsors and equal shareholders.  Sisecam/Pasabahce was to provide technical and production expertise and Schott was responsible for marketing and sales.  A greenfield plant was commissioned in Eskisehir, Turkey at a cost of approximately DM114 million (US$60 million), partly financed by an IFC A loan of DM29 million and two B loans aggregating DM29 million (Dresdner: DM19 million; Landesbank Rheinland-Pfalz: DM10 million).  However, in June 1999, Schott expressed its intention to terminate the joint venture for commercial reasons and the plant was shut down in July 1999.  As a result, both B Lenders, which had initially participated in the project financing due to their existing relationship with Schott, indicated that they would make a formal request for a prepayment, as Schott''s imminent departure amounted to a material adverse change in the project.  After lengthy negotiations, a solution was reached which was satisfactory to all parties concerned.  An amendatory project funds agreement was signed on March 2000, where Schott''s support was provided until November 30, 2001 and the B lenders agreed to remain in the project till July 31, 2001, after which they were granted the right to demand repayment for the full outstanding loan amount.  The project plant resumed operations in March 2000.  Schott sold its shares in the company to Sisecam and remained in the project solely to provide project funds support.  Satisfactory progress was made since operations were resumed, the project is performing, and the loans are being serviced on time.  However, after July 31, 2001, and in line with the Amendatory PFA, the two B lenders have asked for repayment for the full amount of their outstanding loans, despite all efforts undertaken by the B Loan Management Division to try to convince the B lenders to remain in the project. The  B lenders did so because they considered the country risk shifting to Turkey as the Schott guarantee will soon be extinguished on November 30, 2001, and the B Lenders do not want to assume further Turkey risk given the deteriorating macro-economic situation beginning from November 2000.The recent economic crisis in Turkey has resulted in a severe debt scarcity, particularly for the manufacturing sector.  Commercial banks and financial institutions operating in the country are not willing or able to extend long-term credit to Turkish companies.  Foreign banks in particular have reached their Turkish exposure limits, or have revised their country strategy, and are reluctant to extend existing or new loans, and local TL loans from Turkish Eximbank are almost nonexistent.  Long-term hard currency loans are impossible to obtain, whereas short-term debt is priced expensively and is not guaranteed to be rolled over automatically, as was done routinely in the past.    Pasabahce-Eskisehir, already faced with the prospect of reduced revenue and cash flow due to the contraction in the domestic market, would find it very difficult to raise the additional financing required to make the full repayment as requested by the B lenders, and the Company''s liquidity would be severely curtailed.  As a result, the company has requested IFC to provide a dependable and stable source of long-term financing, to provide the liquidity required to replace the existing B lenders in full.  This loan would allow Pasabahce-Eskisehir to continue to focus on its core competences and concentrate on increasing its export revenue to compensate for the shortfall in the domestic revenues.The proposed investment will have a significant development impact. IFCs support is critical at a time when high inflation, shrinking domestic demand and price increases have stagnated the economy, especially the manufacturing sector, and have brought about severe economic problems in the country.  Pasabahce-Eskisehir is a competitive glass tableware manufacturer that exports about 70% of its aggregate glass production, with a projected foreign exchange revenue of approximately US$25 million in 2001.  The company also employs a workforce of 250 people, and is a conscientious corporate citizen.  Through the proposed investment, IFC will support a Turkish company as it rides out current financial difficulties to emerge as a stronger and more competitive entity.  IFCs participation in the project would also provide comfort to other foreign investors who are wary of Turkey''s perceived macro-economic and political risks, and encourage additional foreign direct financing and investment in Turkey.  The devaluation of the currency has made Turkey''s exports more attractive.  By providing the timely replacement loan, IFC will allow Pasabahce-Eskisehir to seize this opportunity and focus on increasing its exports and improving its international competitiveness instead of having to divert resources to raise additional financing to pay off the two B lenders.  The proposed investment will also allow the company to continue normal operations and therefore keep its workforce intact, which is very important especially in a time when economic contraction is resulting in increased unemployment.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category C project, according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because it is likely to have minimal or no adverse environmental impacts.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The project sponsor is Turkiye Sise ve Cam Fabrikalari A.S. (TSCFAS), which is the holding company of the Sisecam Group.  The project company is Pasabahce Eskisehir Cam Sanayii ve Ticaret A.S. (Pasabahce-Eskisehir or the company), and is owned 100% by TSCFAS.  The Sisecam Group is comprised of TSCFAS and 28 affiliate/subsidiary companies (including the project company), in which TSCFAS owns a majority shareholding and/or effectively controls their management.  The Sisecam Group, through TSCFAS, was established 65 years ago in Turkey by Turkiye Is Bankasi A.S. (Is Bank), one of the largest private commercial banks in Turkey.  Currently, Is Bank has a controlling interest in the Sisecam Group and owns 69% of its capital.The principal companies consolidated into the Sisecam Group are:Trakya Cam Sanayii A.S. : float glassPasabahce Cam Sanayii ve Ticaret A.S. : glass tableware or glasswareAnadolu Cam Sanayii A.S. : glass packaging Cam Elyaf Sanayii A.S. : reinforced glass, fiber glass (part of the chemical sub-group)Sisecam is the industry leader in Turkey and one of the largest glass producers in Europe.  The group companies are engaged in the production and sales of a variety of glass products (from hand-made crystal to glass containers, pharmaceutical glass, mechanical glassware and float glass), and glass related chemicals.  The group employs cutting edge technology in its production facilities, and uses sophisticated systems and up-to-date marketing methods to sell its products.  It employs a workforce of over 12,500 people.  Total production capacity is approximately 1.5 million tons per year and the group''s production accounts for approximately 1.5% of total global glass output and 4% of European glass production.
Cost Nature: The proposed IFC investment is up to US$8 million A loan for IFC''s own account to Pasabahce-Eskisehir, which would be used to replace the existing B loans of the company

Project Description: SVTI has been established exclusively to operate, maintain and expand the Port of San Vicente under a 15-year concession granted by Empresa Portuaria Talcahuano-San Vicente (EMPORT), the port authority of San Vicente and the neighboring port of Talcahuano.  The purpose of the project is to transform the Port of San Vicente into the most efficient port in region VIII.  The project is expected to benefit from its important geographical location due to the presence of major Chilean export industries such as forestry and fishing.  The project will also serve to increase growing regional trade with other Latin American countries by providing importers and exporters with better access to foreign markets at reduced costs.  IFC ''s investment will contribute to strengthening the port sector by providing a well-managed and efficient container and general cargo facility.    In addition, IFC''s support of the project, with the targeted participation of local and foreign financial institutions as co-financiers is expected to encourage and support Chile''s privatization efforts in this important sector.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.    Location of environmental documents In locally affected community(i) Offices of the Port of San Vicente - Av. Latorre 1590, Talcahuano, Chile.(ii) Offices of Empresa Portuaria Talcahuano-San Vicente - Av. Blanco Encalada 547, Talcahuano, Chile.
Sponsor: The project sponsors of San Vicente Terminal Internacional S.A. (SVTI) are Sudamericana, Agencias Aéreas y Marítimas S.A. (SAAM), a Chilean stevedoring and transport cargo service company, owned by Compañia Sud Americana de Vapores S.A., a Chilean shipping company; and SSA Holdings International Chile Limitada (SSAHI), a majority owned subsidiary of FRS Service Companies, Inc. of the United States.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at US$ 71.8 million, including concession fees to EMPORT (see below), expenditures on equipment and civil works for the improvement and expansion of the existing facility.  IFCs proposed investment would include an up to US$1.3 million equity investment, an up to US$15.0 million loan for IFC''s own account, and an up to US$17.0 million loan for the account of participants.  Additionally, the project considers the participation of local financial institutions as co-financiers for at least US$4 million.
Investment: 17.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan15.0Equity2.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The Port of San Vicente is located 520 km to the south of Santiago and 18 km from Concepcion, the capital of region VIII.  The area under the concession comprises three berths (603 meter total length) which are designed for all vessel types, with a maximum draft of 12.2 meters.  The port covers a total area of 40 hectares of which 14 hectares are hilly or unsurfaced.  This includes 2,000 ground slots for container stacking and 3.5 hectares of covered storage space in large high-sided warehouses.

Company Name: Al-Amir for Sanitary Ware Production, S.A.E.
Project Description: The proposed investment involves the construction of a modern green-field turn-key facility for the production of vitreous china ceramic sanitaryware. The annual capacity is 350,000 pieces. The proposed project would meet the needs of a big market growing at a rate of more than 15% annually, and would capitalize on: (i) the sponsors'' established distribution network through which it is already selling 200,000 pieces of sanitaryware annually (60% of Gava''s proposed capacity), and (ii) internationally competitive production costs due to cheap labor, raw materials and energy. Moreover, Gava would be able to share overhead costs with Al-Amir, thus providing the company with additional competitive advantage.Development Impact: The project will result in roughly 220 new jobs along with training in new skills and technologies.IFC Role: Local term loans being scarce, IFC will provide much needed long-term financing to this company for the proposed project. Moreover, IFC''s input will substantially assist the company in negotiating with equipment suppliers; in addition, IFC''s review of technical agreements will ensure that the company obtains appropriate technical support after plant commissioning. IFC''s participation will also ensure adherence to strict environmental, social and corporate governance standards.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe ERS is disclosed in the 10th of Ramadan Industrial City at: (i) the main police station, (ii) the main post-office, and (iii) the main public telephone offices. The ERS has been made available to the general public at all three locations since September 9, 2001 and will remain there for thirty days. Notice of the disclosure was published in the Al-Akhbar newspaper on September 9th, 11th and 13th, 2001.
Sponsor: The project is sponsored by Ceramica Al-Amir (50%), along with the individual shareholders of Al-Amir (consisting of three Egyptian families: Hakim, Gabra, and Mikhael - each with 16.67% of ownership-). The project company, Gava Sanitary Ware will be sponsored and owned jointly by Al-Amir and the shareholders of Al-Amir. Ceramica Al-Amir, ranks third amongst ceramic tile producers in Egypt (and fourth in the MENA region) in terms of capacity and sales revenues. The company started in the early 1980''s by establishing a distribution network for Egyptian and imported ceramic tile and sanitary ware in and around Cairo and Alexandria; by 2001 this network grew to 28 showrooms and sales distribution centers throughout Egypt. In 1996, the partners established a facility to produce ceramic wall and floor tile with an capacity of 2 million square meters; it will reach a capacity of 28,000 square meters daily by the end of 2001 (a 5 fold growth over 6 years). Its tile production is sold predominantly in the local Egyptian market, with 7% of total sales revenues derived from exports to neighboring countries (United Arab Emirates, Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, Yemen, Jordan, Bahrain, West Bank and Gaza and Sudan) during the first nine months of 2000. In addition to production and sale of ceramic tiles, the Sponsors currently market sanitaryware, produced by two Egyptian producers (Lecico-Egypt and Ideal Standard), through their existing distribution network of more than 28 sales and distribution centers. Such an extensive distribution network in the industry is unique in Egypt as well as the MENA region.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at US$ 12.0 million; the proposed IFC investment is a US$ 6 million A loan for IFC''s own account.
Investment: 6.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan6.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative

The 10th of Ramadan Industrial City has been developed to alleviate population congestion and pollution in the capital Cairo. It is in the desert, between Cairo and Ismailia; the development is well served in terms of access routes and infrastructure to accommodate medium and light industry.

Project Description: The funds of the project will be used for sub-loans to micro and small enterprises (SMEs) in Georgia. IFC Role:  By providing the proposed loan to MBG, IFC is clearly demonstrating its commitment to support the bank.  IFC is also supporting MBG''s lending to small and medium enterprises (SMEs) that otherwise would not have access to the financial sector in Georgia.  In addition, by placing a representative on MBGs Board, IFC is able to (i) assist in the banks strategic development; (ii) gain insights into the Georgian banking sector; and (iii) develop and leverage its experience with microfinance institutions.Development Impact:  Benefits to small and micro-enterprises:  The project will help improve SMEs access to credit, enabling them to raise their productivity and employment. The inability to obtain financing for expansion, modernization, or any other business objective, is one of the most serious constraints to private sector development in Georgia. Another serious constraint to private sector development is the lack of business know-how among current or potential entrepreneurs, particularly in assessing their own financial situation and needs, and in their general knowledge of and trust in transacting with a formal financial institution. MBG is trying to address this issues and help to build a culture of responsible lending and borrowing. Benefits to the banking sector:  The trust and experience that MBG builds with borrowers will not only benefit the bank, but spillover into the financial sector overall. In addition, MBG is starting to expand regionally, moving into areas where there is only nominal banking activity. In doing so, the bank will contribute to the regional development of Georgia.  The bank would also serve as a role model to other Georgian banks by: (i) showing that the SME market can be profitable if it is targeted efficiently, and (ii) highlighting the significance of operating policies, transparent reporting, environmental screening procedures, and a clear governance structure.
Environmental Social Issues: MBG has established an environmental policy and procedure to verify that its clients comply with Georgian environmental, health and safety requirements and the IFC Microfinance Exclusion List.  MBG provides IFC and other shareholders with an annual environmental report and its environmental performance is considered to be satisfactory.  These requirements will also be applied to the proposed IFC loan.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: Microfinance Bank of Georgia (MBG or the bank) was established in Tbilisi, Georgia as a closed joint stock company under the laws of Georgia in October 1998.  Its shareholders include:- German-Georgian Foundation for the Promotion of Private Sector Development (GGF); - International Finance Corporation (IFC); - Commerzbank; - Nederlandse Financierungs Maatschappij Voor Ontwikkelingslanden (FMO); - Internationale Micro Investitionen (IMI); - European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD); - TBC Bank of Georgia; and - Intellectbank of Georgia.
Cost Nature: IFC will provide an A loan of US$6 million in two equal tranches to MBG for onlending to micro and small enterprises in Georgia.
Investment: 6.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan6.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative

These requirements will also be applied to the proposed IFC loan.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community

Project Description: The bank offers an array of financial services, including retail, commercial, corporate, and private banking. The credit line to be established would be used to finance companies that have viable projects but limited access to term financing.  Onlending will be carried out for investments in the areas of sanitation, development of water and sewage services, small power plants including biomass-based energy plants, industrial expansion and environment support. The proposed project is a response to the following:a) Strong demand for, and inadequate availability of, long-term financing for private infrastructure projects.b) Inadequate financial resources for the private sector and exports.Even for the more efficient firms, capital scarcity has been a major constraint to modernize plant and equipment, to expand in order to meet external competition, or take advantage of new opportunities opened by changes in relative prices.  Under todays market conditions - with access alternately closed (when bad news occurs) or open only for top-quality credits- the ability of Brazils private sector to borrow externally remains minimal and limited to a few blue chip companies and banks for short maturities at high rates.  IFC''s credit line will help provide much-needed long-term financing to Brazilian companies.  Furthermore, it will enable IFC to help a relatively large number of Brazilian corporates more efficiently than through direct IFC lending. This project has important benefits for Brazils financial and infrastructure sectors--both key in promoting growth. Increased productivity in a globalizing environment is today''s challenge for Brazilian firms, which, historically, have mainly competed against other domestic producers.  In this connection, improving the countrys infrastructure is a priority of the government of Brazil, since major bottlenecks are emerging in power, ports, railways, gas, roads, urban transport, and water, due to low investment over many years.   Given the weak investor confidence in emerging markets, there is a major capital and financing constraint, and several initiatives have been delayed or put on hold.  The proposed credit line will be critical to the countrys rehabilitation and expansion efforts as it continues to recover from the recent difficult environment and as the Brazilian companies brace for competition in globalized markets.

Project Name: Uniao de Bancos Brasileiros S.A. Credit Line
Project Description: Unibanco provides banking, insurance, leasing, brokerage and asset management products through relatively independent subsidiaries.  Under the proposed credit line, on-lending will be made for projects in the areas of  sanitation, development of water and sewage services, small power plants including biomass-based energy plants, industrial expansion, and environment support. The credit line would be used to finance companies that have viable projects, but have limited access to term financing.  The project is a response to:	a) Strong demand for and inadequate availability of long-term financing for private infrastructure projects.	b) Inadequate financial resources for the private sector and exports.Even for the more efficient firms, capital scarcity has been a major constraint  to modernize plant and equipment, expand to meet external competition, or take advantage of new opportunities opened by changes in relative prices.  Under todays market conditions, with access alternately closed (when bad news occurs) or open only for top-quality credits, the ability of Brazils private sector to borrow externally remains minimal, and limited to a few blue chip companies and banks for short maturities at high rates.  IFC''s credit line will help provide much-needed long-term financing to Brazilian companies.  Furthermore, it will enable IFC to help a relatively large number of Brazilian corporates more efficiently than through direct IFC lending. This project has important benefits for Brazils financial and infrastructure sectors--both key in promoting growth. Increased productivity in a globalizing environment is today''s challenge for Brazilian firms, which, historically, have mainly competed against other domestic producers.  In this connection, improving the countrys infrastructure is a priority of the government of Brazil, since major bottlenecks are emerging in power, ports, railways, gas, roads, urban transport, and water, due to low investment over many years.   Given the weak investor confidence in emerging markets, there is a major capital and financing constraint, and several initiatives have been delayed or put on hold.  The proposed credit line will be critical to the countrys rehabilitation and expansion efforts, as it continues to recover from the recent difficult environment and as the Brazilian companies brace for competition in globalized markets.

Project Name: Eesti Raudtee and Baltic Railway Services
Project Description: In 1999, the government of Estonia decided to privatize the state railway company AS Eestii Raudtee through the sale of 66% of the shares through public auction. Within three years of the share sale, all the land occupied by the company will be re-registered to grant 50-year leases of the land to EVR. Baltic Railway Services won the bid and purchased 66% of EVRs shares on August 31, 2001. EVR is a vertically integrated railway which includes the management of fixed infrastructure (track, bridges, stations, signaling and communications, etc.) and operation of freight transport services. EVR is the dominant freight operator in Estonia and operates a 693 km long railway network in Estonia. The principal route consists of the main 210 km west-east axis from Tallinn to the Russian border at Narva. The first 77.5 km are double track as far as Tapa where a second route branches off towards Tartu in the south. At Tartu, the line further divides into a route into Russia via Petseri and also to Latvia via Valga. According to EU rules, Estonia has separated the operation of trains and ownership of rail infrastructure. As the owner of the railway network EVR is required to maintain the network and provide network access to the various licensed passenger operators and freight operators in return for a track access charge. The IFC project comprises: (i) the companys investment plan over the next five years including the replacement of EVRs locomotive fleet, track replacement and renovation, improvement of signaling and communications, station renewals and investments in environmental protection; and (ii) the acquisition of 66% of EVRs shares by BRS. Total IFC project cost is estimated at US$226.8 million. The railway sector plays an important economic role in Estonia by transporting large amounts of oil products, oil shale, and other bulk commodities that constitute a substantial part of transit traffic through Estonia. This role is enhanced by helping in the strategic regional development of the port of Tallinn.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe environmental documents will be available at EVRs offices in TallinnThe address is:AS Eesti Raudtee, 36 Pikk Street, 15073 Tallinn, Estonia
Sponsor: AS Eesti Raudtee (EVR, the company)  is owned by Baltic Railway Services OU (66%) and the government of Estonia (34%). Baltic Railway Services OU in turn is a company jointly owned by Rail World Estonia, LLC, a subsidiary of Rail World Inc. of the USA (25.5%), Jarvis International plc of the UK (25.5%), Railworld Development Corporation of the USA (5%) and Ganiger Invest OU of Estonia (44%).
Cost Nature: Total project cost is estimated at US$226.8 million. The proposed IFC investment would consist of a US$50 million loan to EVR for IFC''s own account.

Project Description: The project provides an IFC credit line to DeltaLeasing.  The purpose of the investment is to fund DL''s leasing operations, which provide equipment financing to small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in several regions of the Russian Federation.   The proposed credit line would help the company: (i) expand its existing portfolio and client base; and (ii) provide a new source of funding, independent from the company''s main shareholder (TUSRIF).  One of DL''s main business objectives is to move towards private funding sources in order to ensure the company''s growth and future sustainability.  This project serves as an example of how IFC uses its technical assistance efforts to promote investment opportunities, especially in the leasing sector.  Over the past two years, DL has been a recipient of technical assistance from IFC''s Leasing Development Group, IFC''s technical assistance unit, whose aim is to promote the development of the leasing sector in Russia.   The project would have the following developmental impacts: 1) IFC''s financing will be used by Russian SMEs to upgrade capital assets and thereby improve their competitiveness -- currently Russian SMEs have virtually no other sources of funding;2) DL will channel lease finance to support viable enterprises in economically important, but undercapitalized regions in the Russian Federation.3) IFC is playing its role of catalyst in providing DL with a chance to establish an excellent borrowing record for the company''s future access to private lenders.
Environmental Social Issues: DL will establish an environmental management system designed to ensure that leased assets comply with Russian environmental, health and safety standards and applicable IFC policies and guidelines.  DL will participate in IFC-approved environmental training and provide IFC with an annual environmental report.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityN/A
Sponsor: DeltaLeasing''s (DL, or the company) sole shareholder is the U.S. Russia Investment Fund (TUSRIF), a private investment fund established in 1995 through the merger of the Fund for Large Enterprises in Russia and the Russian American Enterprise Fund.  TUSRIF has been funded by the US Congress via grants administered by USAID totalling US$234 million, with a total commitment of US$440 million.  To date, TUSRIF''s investment activities have focused on two main areas: (i) direct equity investments, and (ii) credit programs.  With regard to direct equity investments, TUSRIF has invested in over 34 projects in Russia in various sectors, including telecommunications, consumer goods, and retail networks.  The credit programs are divided into 3 categories: (a) small business lending; (b) mortgage finance; and (c) leasing.  TUSRIF conducts its leasing operations through DeltaLeasing.
Cost Nature: The project involves an IFC A loan of US$10 million for IFC''s own account.

Project Name: Puertas Finas de Madera Montealban, S.A. de C.V.
Company Name: PUERTAS FINAS DE MADERA MONTEALBAN, S.A. DE C.V.
Project Description: With the objective of increasing the company''s production capacity and further improving its efficiency, the project comprises:(i) increasing the production capacity at the company''s existing door plants;(ii) constructing a new plant in Guerrero for plywood and veneer production;(iii) constructing a new facility in the State of Mexico for the productions of wooden reels and truck platforms, etc;(v) opening 4 new retail stores in various cities;(vi) upgrading the environmental aspects of the company''s production facilities; and (vii) restructuring bridge loans incurred for the project.Development ImpactsThe proposed project is expected to bring about the following development impacts: (i) The company''s production facilities would serve as important direct employment pools, economic stimulators, and promoters of sustainable forestry operations in various parts of Mexico, particularly in the states of Oaxaca and Guerrero - the second and third poorest states of the country; (ii) With its long-term supplier relationships with numerous communities in Oaxaca and Guerrero, the company will continue helping the communities'' development by: (a) constructing and maintaining the roads leading into the forests; (b) providing technical assistance on various aspects of forestry operations; (c) providing the communities with a legally constituted enterprise which buys their products at market prices; and (d) providing a stable source of timber demand, which translates into a stable source of income for the communities;  (iii) The project will enable the company to increase its exports, and substitute imported raw materials with in-house manufactured goods, thereby reducing its production costs and increasing its international competitiveness; and (iv) the project will indirectly positively impact the communities as, at IFC''s request, the company will formalize a corporate policy that seeks to assist communities in reaching Forest Stewardship Council (FSC) certification and attain better forest management practices.IFC RolesIFC can play a significant role in this project: (i) IFC''s investment will provide the necessary long-term financing for a medium-sized Mexican company.  Even though the credit rating of Mexico has been upgraded, long-term financing is still very limited to the top-tier companies and is practically unavailable for middle market companies and small and medium enterprises (SMEs).  IFC''s investment in the project would provide the company with the lacking long-term financing to meet its expansion plans and asset/liability matching requirements; (ii) IFC can help the company in its process of obtaining the FSC certification, with which Puertas Finas will be able to gain access to the European market and continue supplying to the US and Canada; and (iii) IFC''s involvement will result in substantial improvements to the health and safety conditions at the company''s plants by subjecting the Puerta Finas to the World Bank Group social and environmental guidelines.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. Municipal offices close to the communities who are suppliers to the Company.

The company is involved in wooden products manufacturing, ranging from veneer and plywood to wooden doors and reels.

Project Description: Coppel is a retail chain based in Culiacan, in the Mexican state of Sinaloa.  The Company has a strong presence in Mexico, as it currently operates 132 stores, located in 22 Mexican states.  Coppel currently offers a wide variety of products including electrical equipment, electronics, furniture, and apparel.  Its target customers are the low to middle income segment of the population.  As a second-tier retail chain, Coppel needs to formalize its business and improve its corporate governance in order to foster the credibility needed to become a successful national chain.  IFC can provide added value to the Company by:  (i) providing advice on how to formalize and enhance its existing credit program; (ii) introducing international industry best practices to further improve its operations; (iii) providing the necessary long-term financing for its investment program; and by (iv) helping to set up social and environmental policies that comply with World Bank Group standards.The project is expected to:  (i) improve the living standards of the lower social segments of Mexico by extending the Company''s credit program to cover other parts of the country; (ii) create new job opportunities; and (iii) bring about training opportunities in retailing to new employees, particularly those in less developed states.
Environmental Social Issues: Environmental, social and health and safety issues associated with this project include: site acquisition and possible economic and/or physical displacement (resettlement); liquid waste treatment and disposal;  potable water supplies; fire safety; and issues in the supply chain. Project Description: The project involves the expansion of a nation-wide digital GSM cellular network in Jamaica offering a wide range of standard and value-added mobile services in the country.  The Company was awarded a 15-year license in February 2000 for this purpose, with an open tender bid price of US$47.5 million.  The project would help meet the need for better telecommunications services in Jamaica through the promotion of competition in the domestic market.  Currently, the market is serviced by two operators, Cable and Wireless Jamaica (CWJ) and the Company.  Since CWJ entered the market in 1986 with the privatization of the state-controlled telephone company, it had enjoyed exclusive operating rights in both fixed and mobile services until April 2001.  The introduction of competition has lowered tariffs, improved the quality of service and customer responsiveness, and expanded access to telecommunication services to a broader segment of the Jamaican population.  IFC''s direct investment and the resultant competition have thereby helped raise the country''s mobile penetration rate from 6.5% in June 2000 to over 15% by October 2001.  IFCs direct investment in the expansion of this network would help the emerging competitive market to develop further by (1) increasing telecommunications usage nation-wide, (2) improving the efficiency of the business sector, and (3) increasing the connections between Jamaica and the global community.  Finally, the investment would also provide a demonstration effect by showing other governments in the region that the liberalization of their telecommunications sectors will benefit their populations, and could be followed by international capital inflows.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category C project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.    Mossel''s Environmental and Social Management Policies and Procedures for its operations were reviewed and found acceptable in late 2000 as part of the initial IFC investment.  There have been no significant changes in the project concept and the expansion will occur within the existing service area.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The project''s main sponsor is Mr. Denis OBrien, who holds a majority stake in Mossel (or, the Company).  He has had a variety of experiences with telecommunications projects worldwide.  Most notable of these was his highly successful competitive mobile business in Ireland called Esat, which was ultimately taken over by British Telecom for US$2.5 billion.  Esat was the first private company to compete with the state-owned Irish telephone company in 1991.  Much like the situation in Jamaica, Esat entered the market with only one license.  However, it eventually procured licenses for all sectors of the telecommunications market, including mobile cellular services.  The minority shareholders in Mossel are Mr. Osmond Kilkenny and Mr. Leslie Buckley.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at US$60 million.  The proposed IFC investment is US$20 million, comprised of a US$12 million A Loan for IFCs account and a US$8 million equity investment for IFC''s account.
Investment: 20.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan12.0Equity8.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The project is located in Jamaica, with Company headquarters in Kingston.  The Company will expand its network throughout the island, in both urban and rural areas.  Upon completion of the expansion, the Company expects to reach approximately 85% of the countrys population.

Project Description: The project consists of construction and operation of a new container terminal, with two berths totaling 600 meters and five gantry cranes.  The project company, CII, is a new company created by the sponsors to carry out the venture.  The existing main port of the Dominican Republic, Rio Haina, is severely congested.  Additionally, shipping companies are precluded from serving the country with larger vessels due to limited water depth and the channels narrow turning basin.  The new Caucedo terminal will have a deep-water (15 m) harbor, enabling shipping companies to serve DR with Panamax size vessels and thereby gain economies of scale. The terminal will also provide easy access to the Caucedo free trade zone and support its development. IFC will play a key role in creating an appropriate financial structure.  It will also provide comfort to other lenders of the project given the political risks associated with this concession-based project.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category A project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because it may result in significant adverse environmental and/or social impacts that are sensitive, diverse or unprecedented.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityAvenida Abraham Lincoln No. 504, Décimo Piso, Santo Domingo, D.N.
Sponsor: CSX World Terminals (CSXWT), the former Sea-Land Service Inc., is the project sponsor and technical sponsor and has over 40 years of terminal operation experience.  The local sponsors are Samuel A. Conde, Manuel E. Tavares, and the B&R Group, who are in the business of construction, free trade zone operation, shipping and terminal services.  The project company, Caucedo Investments Inc. (CII), is 50% owned by CSXWT and 50% by Caucedo Development Corporation (which is held by the three local sponsors).
Cost Nature: Total project cost is estimated at $277 million.  The proposed IFC investment is an A loan of $50 million for IFC''s own account.

Project Description: Global CyberSoft is a Vietnamese software company established in July 2000.   During Sep-Dec 2000, GCS generated US$332,000 in revenues and has approximately US$1.1 million of software outsourcing contracts in hand for FY2001.  The company intends to capitalize on the worldwide software-outsourcing trend by uniquely positioning itself to be a low cost, high quality, supplier of factory automation software for the global semiconductor industry. The company is also developing proprietary enterprise-based factory automation software products.  GCS can be found on the web at: http://www.globalcybersoft.comIt is expected the recent trade deal with the United States - which is pending ratification by the United States Senate - will help to open a previously closed economy, and Vietnam is developing the skills base to be able to compete in high-technology exports.  Nonetheless, Vietnam is a country only part way through a transition from command economy towards the market, and remains one of the poorest economies in Asia.  This project will support efforts to catalyze growth and development through high-end services exports, creating quality jobs and also acting as an important symbol of the benefits of continued reform, opening up, and support for education.  The project will have significant developmental impact by: (i) potentially creating hundreds of highly skilled software development jobs in Vietnam over the next two to three years; and (ii) helping to train workers in Vietnam by exposing them to international best practices. This venture would contribute to bring higher standards of software development to companies in Vietnam.  In addition, while salaries for IT workers in Vietnam are extremely low by international standards, GCS is one of the best paying employers in the local market.  The companys business plan calls for the employment of approximately 800 software engineers in Vietnam by the end of 2004.While IFC has made twelve investments to date in Vietnam, GCS would is the first ever investment in the ICT sector and only the third IFC equity investment in the country.  An investment in GCS would represent an opportunity for IFC to support the emerging Vietnamese software industry, which is still at a nascent stage.  The project would support a group of local entrepreneurs that are providing software outsourcing services to the semiconductor industry in the developed world from a production base centered in Vietnam.   IFC''s participation would also be critical to terms of bringing another institutional investor into the Series A round.  There is little active venture capital in the ICT sector at the present time, and IFC will have to use its own contacts in the venture capital community and technology sector to help the Company close the Series A round.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category C project, according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because it is likely to have minimal or no adverse environmental impacts.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: Global Cybersoft (GCS, or the company) has a committed management team with extensive expertise in the semiconductor industry as well as business contacts in the USA, Japan, Taiwan, and Korea.  Most of them have worked with major US technology companies and/or investment banks covering the semiconductor sector.  The management team also possesses deep roots in Vietnam.  The two founders of the company are: Kevin Nguyen - Vice-Chairman & President/CEO.  Kevin has more than 20 years of experience in a broad range of system integration and internet activities, catering to the semiconductor IC design, manufacturing layout, and capital equipment sectors.  He founded and served as chief technology officer of FabLink.com (previously known as Mitta Technology Group, Inc.), an Internet B2B company. Prior to being an entrepreneur, Kevin worked as a senior technical professional for various major US high-tech companies including IBM, Honeywell, and Boeing Computer Services.   Kevin earned an BSIE from the University of Illinois and an MSIE from the University of Cincinnati. He is a frequent lecturer on the global semiconductor industry and has published numerous technical papers in the fields of computer integrated manufacturing and object-oriented technology.   Kevin is Vietnamese-American.           Hunt Macnguyen - Chairman & CFO.  Hunt has more than 12 years of professional experience at leading international investment banks, including Merrill Lynch, Nomura Securities, and W.I. Carr.  Prior to founding CyberSoft, Hunt was based in Hong Kong and Vietnam, and worked as a senior investment banker covering the Asia Pacific region.  Hunt also has more than 5 years of working experience as the semiconductor equity research analyst for the Nomura Research Institute of America (in New York City, USA) and W.I. Carr (in Tokyo, Japan).  Prior to this, he worked as a semiconductor IC design & test engineer for AT&T for  more than 3 years.  Hunt earned a BSEE  from the University of Pennsylvania, an MSEE  from Lehigh University, and an MBA from the Wharton Business School.  He has published numerous equity research reports relating to the global semiconductor industry and marketed his investment analysis extensively throughout the USA, Europe, and Asia.   Hunt is Vietnamese-American.The company''s two founders, Kevin Nguyen and Hunt MacNguyen, together own a stake of approximately 40% in GCS.  The balance of the equity is held by GCS''s Japanese angel investors, as well as members of the company''s senior management team.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at US$4.5 million.  It is envisioned that IFC would make an equity investment of up to US$1.5 million in a Series A round of venture capital financing.  The investment would be in the form of redeemable preferred shares convertible into common shares.

Project Name: Latin American Agribusiness Development Corporation S.A.
Company Name: LATIN AMERICAN AGRIBUSINESS DEVELOPMENT CORP SA
Project Description: Incorporated in Panama in 1970 with US$2.4 million in equity,  LAAD started lending in Central America.  Subsequently, it expanded also  to South America and the Caribbean, disbursing in excess of US$375 million to over 750 agribusiness projects in 16 countries.  LAAD is one of the very few, or possibly the only, financial institution targeting exclusively the agricultural sector and doing it on a profitable basis for almost thirty years.  According to company estimates, the projects it financed during these three decades created 65,000 jobs and generated US$450 million in foreign exchange earnings annually.  The 8-year credit line will provide financing to private Latin American and Caribbean companies engaged in agriculture, livestock, fishing and forestry.  In light of the lack of long term financing available to this sector, the project will have the following development impact:Provide long-term, possibly fixed rate financing to this sector;Reduction of rural poverty through job creation in rural and semi-rural areas;Increase and higher quality of agricultural output through the ability to purchase, on credit, the required quality inputs;Demonstration effect of the viability of an institution such as LAAD, that can possibly be replicated in other regions.IFCs proposed financing will enable LAAD to offer long-term funds to selected clients who need it for the success of their enterprises, but can not obtain it due to the current five-year maximum tenor of LAAD''s commercial funding.  The on-lending will be made to small and medium size export agribusiness firms operating out of South and Central America and the Caribbean.  The loans will average US$400,000. This project will enable IFC to make one of its first experience in the difficult field of rural finance and possibly replicate the model, or apply the lessons learnt to future projects in this and other regions.  Finally, IFC is expected to make a positive contribution to environmental practices in the agribusiness field.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category FI Type 2 project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure. LAAD has committed to undertaking an environmental and social review of each subproject financed with IFC funds. LAAD must require all subprojects to be carried out and operated in compliance with the applicable environmental, health and safety (EH&S) requirement of the host country and also IFCs EH&S Guideline for Pesticide Handling and Application.  In addition, LAAD must require subprojects whose total cost is less than US$500,000 must be consistent with IFC''s Microfinance Exclusion List.  Further, subprojects whose total cost is US$500,000 or greater must be carried out in accordance with IFC''s safeguard policies, be consistent with IFC''s Exclusion List, and meet the host country requirements and IFCs pesticide guideline.  In addition, LAAD must require any Category A subproject to meet the World Bank Groups applicable environmental, health and safety guidelines and will not make a loan to any such subproject prior to receipt of IFC''s clearance.  LAAD must participate in environmental training as may be required by IFC, develop an environmental management system, and provide an annual environmental performance report.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The shareholders of Latin American Agribusiness Development Corporation (LAAD, or the company) are twelve multinational finance and agribusiness corporations, featuring some of the first tier names in banking and industry, namely:  Bank of America, Borden, Cargill, Dole, Rabobank, J.P. Morgan, Unilever Bestfoods, Deere, Novartis (previously Gerber), Monsanto, Agribands and Goodyear Tire.  They have each an equal stake in the LAAD. To protect the company''s mission and maintain certain continuity, the sponsors established strict rules for the transfer of shares, creating a very stable institution.  In addition, they established the governance rules, the  reporting and disclosure policies, the accounting standards and the ethical underpinning that constitute LAAD''s hallmark.
Cost Nature: The project consists of a proposed US$20 million credit line to LAAD.

Project Description: The project supports the growth and strategic development of Tigar, a leading tire and rubber goods producer in Yugoslavia and the Balkans.   With the return of Yugoslavia to the international community, Tigar is planning to undertake a comprehensive corporate restructuring and investment program (the project) and has approached IFC for financial support.  The project involves; (i) debottlenecking and expanding its tire production capacity, which currently operates at 100% capacity, and moving into production of premium high speed tires; (ii) restructuring of non-core assets and businesses, and (iii) balance sheet restructuring to better match assets and liabilities.  Given that the project had been postponed due to circumstances outside its control, Tigar now wants to move quickly and IFC''s proposed project is structured to be responsive to this need.   The proposed project has a strong development impact.  Through this investment, IFC would be supporting the continuation of the transfer of technology to Yugoslavia.  The company is expected to be internationally competitive and export most of its production, resulting in over EUR30 million equivalent of foreign exchange revenues per year.  Moreover, this restructuring project will help employees of Tigar, especially among the tire producing units, secure their jobs in an environment where tens of thousands of employees are being laid off in various sectors in Yugoslavia. After a decade of war, international isolation and poor economic management, there is low degree of financial intermediation in FRY and the mobilization of resources for new investment is negligible.  The banking system has a very low level of capitalization and extremely low intermediation capacity.  The financial difficulties of the major state owned banks preclude them from servicing the growing demands of the private sector.  Private banks are mostly small, thinly capitalized, and only offer short-term (1-3 month) working capital.  Private companies have little or no access to external finance.  As a result, interest rates are prohibitively high and local financial institutions do not have the financial depth required for the long-term, outward looking strategic development of major corporations in the country.  Loan maturities exceeding even a one-year range are not currently available in the  market.  In the context of an uncertain economic environment and competitive pressures in the global tire sector, IFC''s proposed long term financing of the project will provide critical support for the sustained and competitive evolution of a vital corporate sector enterprise in FRY.  Without IFCs investment, the company would be forced to rely on short term, extremely limited and very expensive financing.  While Michelin has had and will continue to have direct corporate exposure to Yugoslavia, its appetite for such exposure will in fact be enhanced by IFC''s participation in the venture.  IFC is working with the sponsors to structure a bankable investment program and ensure fair burden sharing amongst the parties.  IFC is also planning to provide technical assistance to Tigar with a view to eventually restructuring its non tire businesses  to preserve jobs and develop value-added business opportunities.Tigar is keen to have an environmental audit of operations and assistance to correct any deficiencies. IFC will also provide funding needed for environmental enhancement.The proposed project will have a strong demonstration impact by supporting the investment of a leading tire manufacturer (Michelin) in FRY.  IFC financing is likely to encourage additional foreign direct financing and investment in Yugoslavia,  at a time when foreign investors are wary of Yugoslavias perceived macro-economic and political risks.  In the event that syndication is possible, it would be an enhancement of local companies'' credit worthiness in Yugoslavia.   In line with IFC''s view of developing Yugoslavia''s industry base, the project  supports research and development (in cooperation with Yugoslav technical institutions), new product development initiatives, and manufacturing technologies, which promote global competitiveness on the technology front.  In addition, by supporting a leading outward looking, regional company, IFC fosters the transfer of first-class production methods, strong environmental, health, and management systems in a country that has urgent needs to renovate its industrial base.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe translated environmental documents will be disclosed at the following locations:1. The local weakly newspaper "Sloboda" (four times)  (address: IJP "Sloboda", Pirot, Trg pirotskih oslobodioca 30)2. The local TV station "p canal" (address: "p canal", Pirot, Trg pirotskih oslobodioca b.b)3. The municipal and local government offices in Piro4. The Tigar montly newspaper
Sponsor: The project sponsors are Michelin, of France, and Tigar of Yugoslavia.Michelin Group:Michelin, established in 1889,  is one of the world''s leading tire producers with consolidated net sales of EUR15.4 billion in 2000.  The Michelin group of companies make tires for all types of vehicles: bicycles, cars, trucks, motorcycles, earthmover equipment, buses, subway trains, and aircrafts. Michelin is also involved in the production of rubber and elastomers, reinforcement materials,  and suspension systems (wheels, antivibration equipment, assemblages).  In addition, the group provides tourism services, and produces weather maps, guides, atlases and computerized products.  Michelin has more than 130,000 employees and has a business presence in 170 countries. Tigar:Tigar Rubber Products Company (Tigar or the company), one of the most respected tire/rubber goods producers in Central and Eastern Europe, was founded in 1935. Tire manufacturing began in 1959.  In 1974, Tigar signed a business and technical cooperation and license agreement with BF Goodrich.  This agreement was enhanced in 1978 when both companies signed a joint venture (JV) agreement.  From 1977 to 1985 Tigar gradually expanded its production program to include inner-tubes and chemical products. It also established a network of international outlets and a wholly owned distribution network in Yugoslavia.  In 1997, the BF Goodrich JV agreement was assumed by Michelin (North America) when the assets of the US company were acquired by the French tire manufacturer.  In 2000 the unincorporated JV agreement was renewed with Michelin (France) with the following shareholding structure;  Tigar  75.86% and Michelin (France)  24.14%.Tigar''s Current Shareholding StructureTigar, a former state owned company, has been largely privatized in two rounds, with employees acquiring 12% in the early 1990s and then a further 53% under the provisions of the 1997 privatization law.  In both rounds, ownership was very widely dispersed among former and current employees. The current share ownership is as follows: private shareholders (65.3%), state (23.6%), socially owned (2.4%), Pensin funds (8.7%).
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at Euro 45 million.  The proposed IFC investment is an aggregate of up to Euro 20 million,  for IFC''s own account, which includes a convertible loan of up to Euro 5 million.
Investment: 17.24 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan13.79Equity3.45* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The project and the production site are located at the city of Pirot and Babusnica (20 km north of Pirot) - Yugoslavia.  Tigar''s tire operations began in 1950''s in the same area.  The plant has access to international transportation routes both motorway and railway.  The project company is headquartered in Pirot.  Tigar has two main sales offices in UK and Greece for exports, and a large distribution network in Yugoslavia.

Company Name: SOKTAS TEKSTIL SANAYI VE TICARET ANONIM SIRKETI
Project Description: The project is a proposed working capital loan to Skotas, Turkeys leading producer of  fabric for color woven shirting, and one of the leading manufacturers in Europe in this sector.  Soktas has three principal products: (i) fine count, yarn-dyed fabric (shirting); (ii) piece-dyed  fabric (sportswear); and (iii) grey, unfinished fabrics.  The recent crisis in Turkey has severely curtailed domestic market demand in the manufacturing sector, presenting challenges for the corporate sector at large.  Soktas is attempting to mitigate the impact of falling domestic sales by increasing its exports.  With an existing export base of about US$21 million as of end 2000 (representing 40% of total sales), which is expected to grow to reach about US$34.0 million (70% of sales) as of end 2001, the company is faced with the challenge of finding dependable sources of funding to finance its increasing exports.   Exports typically require higher working capital, due to the longer receivables period, and additional inventory carrying costs. The company is funding its existing working capital requirements through short term debt financing, payable in one year, subject to rollover at renewal.  In the past, such rollovers were routinely granted but, given the present state of the Turkish economy, Soktas is finding it increasingly difficult to extend its short term debts from local or foreign banks.  Local TL loans are harder to obtain, while foreign banks have reached their Turkish exposure limits and are unwilling to extend existing or new loans.  As a result, Skotas is looking to IFC to provide a dependable and stable source of future financing for its working capital needs.  This loan would mitigate some of Soktas''s liquidity constraints and increase its export marketing capacity. The proposed project gives IFC an opportunity to support an existing client at a critical time, when higher inflation, shrinking domestic demand and price increases have stagnated the economy, and especially the manufacturing sector. By financing Soktas''s working capital needs on a long-term basis, IFC will allow the company to focus on building its export base, while also helping it to weather out the difficulties in the domestic market. Through the proposed investment, IFC will thus support a Turkish company to emerge as a stronger and more competitive company in the global setting. IFC''s participation in the project will also provide comfort to other foreign investors who are wary of Turkey''s perceived macro economic and political risks, and will thus encourage foreign direct financing and investments in Turkey. Furthermore, the devaluation of the currency has made Turkey''s exports more attractive. By providing the timely export financing, IFC will aid the company in seizing the market opportunity, boosting its export sales, and will most importantly equip the company with the financial resources it needs to explore new avenues, thereby increasing the country''s foreign exchange earnings
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category C project according to IFCs environmental and social procedure and as such the project has been cleared by the Environmental and Social Development Department.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityCategory C projects have minimal or no adverse environmental impacts. Therefore, no environmental documents are required.
Sponsor: The project sponsor is Soktas Pamuk Ve Tarim Urunlerini Degerlendirme Ticaret Ve Sanayi A.S. (Soktas, or the company).  Soktas is owned by the Kayhan family, which has an excellent reputation and track record in Turkey.  Mr. Muzaffer Kayhan is the founder of the company and, to this day, is involved in Soktas'' corporate policy and practices regarding cotton purchasing.  He still holds the title of chairman of the board.  The Kayhan family owns about 71% of Soktas, the other board members hold about 0.5%. Relatives of the board member hold about 4% of the company, while and the remaining 24.5% is traded on the Istanbul stock exchange.
Cost Nature: The total working capital requirement of Soktas will be around US$14 million in 2001-02.  IFC''s proposed working capital facility investment is a $4.0 million A loan for IFC''s own account.  The balance of the working capital requirement will be financed by internal cash generation and short term debt.

Project Description: The project consists of structuring and establishing the first private sector banking institution in Syria:  the Syrian Commercial Bank (SCBank or, the bank), since the nationalization of the sector in 1961.  The bank would be capitalized at $30 million, with Blom Bank of Lebanon as the technical partner, exercising managerial control with 39% equity, a group of reputable Syrian businessmen with 51%, and IFC with 10%.  The project will help meet the needs of private enterprises and increase the level and efficiency of financial intermediation in Syria.  It is envisaged that this new joint venture bank will be a "best practices" model that will disseminate modern banking techniques, upgrade standards, promote competition, and increase the efficiency of the domestic banking system.  SCBank would provide modern commercial banking products which are currently unavailable to domestic retail and corporate customers.  Particular emphasis would be placed on providing services to SMEs, which constitute the majority of economic activity in the country.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Financial Intermediary Type 1 project.  SCBank will be required to develop an environmental management system to cover relevant operations (e.g., project finance, corporate finance).  SCBank must require that activities financed through lending and investments under relevant operations to comply with the environmental, health and safety requirements of Syria.  With respect to the trade enhancement facility, SCBank will be required to screen the goods and related projects for consistency with IFCs Exclusion List.  SCBank must participate in environmental training and must provide to IFC an annual environmental performance report.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The project sponsor, Blom Bank (Blom, or the bank), was founded in 1951 as Banque du Liban et d''Outre Mer.  Today, Blom is the largest bank in Lebanon, accounting for one tenth of both total banking assets and deposits.  In addition to its Lebanese investment banking arm (Banque d''Affaires du Liban et d''Outre Mer sal), Blom has two wholly owned subsidiaries:  Banque Banorabe (France) S.A. and Banque Banorient (Switzerland), which provide a full range of commercial, investment, corporate, and private banking activities.  Blom has a capital adequacy ratio of 24.45% and an A- rating from Capital Intelligence. The bank, which has about 270 shareholders, is headed by Dr. Naaman Azhari, a well-regarded banker who owns 8.75% of the bank''s shares.  Other shareholders include: (i) Bank of New York with 23.73% (as a GDR deposit holder); (ii) Banorabe Holding with 13.24%; and (iii) the Shaker, Oueini and Jaroudy families with a total of 22.75%.  The local shareholders comprise prominent Syrian businessmen headed by Dr. Rateb Shallah.  Together, the group would own 51% of the bank''s shareholding.  Dr. Shallah is  the current president of the Federation of Syrian Chambers of Commerce and Industry.  A U.S. educated economist, Dr. Shallah is one of the most respected businessmen in Syria.The trade enhancement facility would be provided by BNP Paribas (BNPP).  BNPP is the leading listed banking group in France, the third largest banking group in market capitalization (Euro 41.2 billion) in the Euro zone, and the fourth largest banking group in Europe in terms of net worth (Euro 20 billion).  BNPP provides private banking and asset management in over 20 countries.  The international trade sector of BNPP combines all of the services (i.e. consulting, technical support, international corporate bonding) and financing linked to international trade, particularly with regard to exports.  The bank also holds dominant positions in the aviation and shipping sectors.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at US$50 million.  IFC''s proposed investment consists of an equity subscription of 10% of the bank''s total shareholding of $30 million.  In addition, IFC would provide SCBank with a trade enhancement facility of up to $10 million.

Project Name: VAALCO Offshore Gabon Oilfield Development Project
Project Description: The project will involve the completion of the four existing wells, the drilling and testing of approximately two additional wells and the installation of subsea equipment.  VAALCO will also lease a floating production, storage and off-loading vessel (FPSO) with a capacity of 30,000 barrels per day.  IFCs participation in this project will fulfill a number of important objectives:  (i) IFC would encourage investment by smaller, independent producers in the hydrocarbon sector which has experienced a significant decline in output in recent years, (ii) through the B-Loan program,  IFC would provide the sponsor with an opportunity to tap into international capital markets for the first time, and (iii) IFC is providing important capacity building opportunities for VAALCO by improving its environmental planning and mitigation standards and helping conform its existing corporate Environmental Management and Emergency Response Plans to its operations in Gabon.The project has a number of developmental objectives.  Project revenues, in the form of royalties and production sharing, will help ease the governments current budgetary constraints by providing over US$20 million annually on average in the early years of operation.  The government is estimated to accrue up to 25% of the total revenues or US$200 million in the proved reserves case over a ten -year production life.  In addition, the government receives bonuses totaling US$900,000 when certain production milestones are met.  Other positive impacts on the economy include: (i) a required contribution of US$0.05 per barrel to a Hydrocarbon Support Fund created for the purpose of developing petroleum research in Gabon, (ii) annual contribution for the training of Gabonese nationals in the oil and gas sector, and (iii) a 25% discount on oil supplied for domestic consumption.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe Environmental Documents have been disclosed for review at the Oloumi Clinic - B.P. 12061, in the Zone Industrielle d''Oloumi, in Libreville.  Summary information will be posted on the bulletin board.  Supporting information will also be available for reveiw.
Sponsor: VAALCO Energy, Inc, the project sponsor, is a small, publicly traded, independent exploration and development energy company based in Houston, Texas.  Its wholly owned subsidiary, VAALCO Gabon (Etame), owns 28.1% of the production license for the Etame Marine permit area and will act as operator of the project.  The other shareholders of the production license are: PanAfrican Energy Corp., Sasol Petroleum, PetroEnergy Resources Corp.,  Nissho Iwai Corp., and Energy Africa/Gabon government (to be carried by other shareholders until the production phase).
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at US$98 million, including US$33 million of prior capital investment.  VAALCO''s share of the total costs is US$28 million.  The proposed IFC investment is US$18 million, comprising an A and B Loan of US$9 million each, to fund VAALCOs contribution to future costs.
Investment: 10.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan10.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The project is located in the Etame Marin permit area, which covers a 3,073 km2 area in the pre salt reservoirs in the most northern portion of the Congo Basin.  The Etame oilfield exists in two sandstone formations at a water depth of approximately 75 meters, 45 kilometers off the southern coast of Gabon.

Company Name: GRUPO DE INVERSIONES SURAMERICANA S A
Project Description: The project consists of a corporate investment package that is designed to support various organizational and financial measures that are being undertaken by the Suramericana Group.SIGhas an impressive track record of investment and growth.  During the 1990s, the group established companies that moved to leadership positions in various sectors, including insurance, pension fund management, health care, banking and various retail and service sectors.  Due to the peculiarities of the Colombian market, most investments were funded from within the group (by the holding companies together with other group companies that had excess cash balances).  While this approach has served SIG well over time it has created a complex web of cross-shareholdings among group companies, thereby making them less transparent to external investors.As part of the project, IFC will (i) assist SIG in the elimination of some of these cross-shareholdings; (ii) advise it on measures to improve corporate governance and transparency; and (iii) help it to significantly reduce the debt that has accumulated at the holding companies level as a result of the current structure. The attractiveness of this Project for IFC stems not only from the direct benefits which would accrue to some of Colombias key companies (which are part of the Suramericana Group) but also from the benchmarks it will set for other Colombian companies in areas such as corporate governance and transparency that are key to the efficient functioning of domestic capital markets.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects. Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityBiblioteca Publica Piloto,  Carrera 64 # 50 -32, Medellín, Colombia
Sponsor: The Suramericana Group (SIG, or the group) is a diversified group of companies with total assets, revenues and equity of approximately US$8 billion, US$1.7 billion, and US$1.3 billion respectively.  The group has investments in over 100 companies across nine economic sectors.  About 31% of the groups resources are invested in banking and finance, 17% each in insurance and cement, 11% in food,  7% in retail, 6% in textiles and 3% in pension fund management and social security.  The major group companies include Argos (a holding company for various cement firms), Compañia Nacional de Chocolates (CNCH, a large food company), Bancolombia (a premier commercial bank), Inversura (a grouping of insurance and health care companies), Exito (a chain of supermarkets), Proteccion (a pension fund management company), and Corfinsura (a premier merchant bank where IFC has an existing investment), among others.  Apart from the cross-shareholdings between group companies, Suramericana does not have any major shareholders.  Shares in Suramericanas listed companies are widely held by Colombian individuals and institutional investors and there is also some participation by foreign institutional investors.  The group is managed by a cadre of professional managers.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at US$350 million.  The proposed IFC investment is a US$50 million A loan for IFC''s own account, US$35 exchangeable loan for IFC''s own account and a US$15 million equity investment

Project Description: TEB had unconsolidated total assets of US$1.7 billion equivalent and US$110 million in shareholders equity as of end-March 2001. The main focus of the bank is to provide short-term trade finance to a select client base, which include multinationals and leading Turkish conglomerates. The bank also has a strong private banking business, treasury operations, asset management, and is developing its retail operations.The project would be structured in two tranches.  The first tranche, of up to US$15 million would be a subordinated convertible loan to further strengthen the balance sheet of TEB. The second tranche would be a syndicated three-year facility of up to US$20 million for IFC''s own account and up to US$80 million for the account of participant banks, depending on demand.Through the project IFC intends to provide capital to the Turkish banking sector and provide finance to Turkish corporates for the purpose of working capital, investment and trade. By investing in TEB, IFC would send an important signal of support to the Turkish banking system at a time when confidence is low and banking activity is severely constrained. Secondly, Turkish private corporates are constrained by lack of adequately priced finance, a sector which is critical to the recovery of Turkey from the current crisis.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category FI Type 1 project according to IFC''s environmental review procedure.  As a result of earlier IFC investments, TEB has developed an acceptable environmental review procedure for its operations.  This environmental management system (EMS) will be reviewed by IFC to ensure it complies with current requirements.  TEB will be required to update the EMS to meet current requirements should this be necessary.  The EMS must include verification of borrowers'' compliance with Turkish environmental, health and safety standards. TEBs environment staff  may also need to attend additional IFC environmental training course for FIs.  TEB will be required to submit annual environmental reports to IFC.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The project sponsor is Turk Ekonomi Bankasi A.S. (TEB or the bank), a mid-sized Turkish wholesale commercial bank. The bank is considered one of Turkeys most prestigious banks, with a reputation for prudence and conservative management. TEB is owned 79% by the Colakoglu group, and 21% is held by the public. The shares of the bank are listed on Istanbul Stock Exchange and the London Stock Exchange. With the exception of TEB, all other businesses of the group remain wholly owned.  The Colakoglu group is highly regarded in Turkey and engages in a diverse range of businesses including financial services, steel production, shipping container production, power generation and shipping.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at US$115 million. The proposed IFC investment is an A loan of up to US$20 million for IFC''s own account, and a syndicated B loan of up to US$80 million B loan for the account of participants and a US$15 million subordinated convertible C loan for IFC''s own account.

TEB will be required to update the EMS to meet current requirements should this be necessary.  The EMS must include verification of borrowers'' compliance with Turkish environmental, health and safety standards.
