Project Description: The project company, ISA Peru, was incorporated in May 2001.  ISA Colombia, both directly and through its majority ownership of Transelca, S.A. ESP, owns the majority of the shares of ISA Peru.  ETECEN, one of Peru''s national transmission companies, is a minority shareholder.The project consists of the engineering, construction, ownership and operation of two high-voltage transmission lines in central Peru under a concession awarded through an international tender in February 2001. The venture is part of the government of Peru''s broader program to expand electricity transmission access, improve the national grid''s stability and overall reliability, and to evacuate power from a new generation facility. Specifically, the project will:link Pucallpa, Peru''s most important town in the Amazon region with a population of about 240,000 people, to the national power grid, thus displacing currently utilized more expensive thermal generation,complete an alternative route for transmitting electricity to Lima and its surrounding areas, reducing technical losses and improving the overall reliability of the national grid system,reinforce power supply to mining centers in central Peru, where demand for power is growing as a result of new mining projects being developed,evacuate power from the Yuncan hydroelectic power plant, a 160 MW generation facility expected to commence operations in late 2002; andprovide the base for the planned expansion of the national interconnected system to the north, thus allowing the grid to reach a larger proportion of Peru''s population and eventual interconnection with Ecuador.The government of Peru has only recently begun to privatize transmission assets.  IFC''s support is particularly important to demonstrate that these types of projects can be financed on a project finance basis, a development which has yet to be realized in Peru.  Additionally, infrastructure projects require long-term financing.  IFC''s presence in this financing will provide comfort to other investors and potential lenders, facilitating the provision of long-term financing at a time when such financing is not easily accessible.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe environmental documents will be disclosed locally. Copies and comments please contact: Ing. Gabriel CanaveralISA PeruJr. Salaverry No. 243Pucallpa, UcayaliPeruTelefax: 064-574959Ing. Ricardo GuzmanISA PeruJiron Union No. 186Barrio Buenos AiresCarhuamayo, JuninPeruTel: 064-345028Additionally, ISA Peru will make radio announcements in the areas of Cerro de Pasco and Carhuamayo.
Sponsor: The project sponsor is Interconexion Electrica, S.A. E.S.P. (ISA Colombia).  ISA Colombia owns and operates 80% of Colombia''s transmission assets, and participates in the Colombian telecommunications sector through subsidiaries.  As of April 2001, ISA Colombia''s ownership was the following:	Government of Colombia			66%	Individual Shareholders (publicly traded)	13%	Empresa de Medellin			12%	EPSA (a private corporation)			 5%	Others					 4%ISA Colombia''s classification is that of a mixed public service company, a status that provides some limited benefits (most of which are set to expire in 2003).  Although the government of Colombia is the majority shareholder, ISA Colombia has all the features of a commercial entity and is currently managed as a private company.  ISA Colombia is a proven company whose technical operations are comparable to international transmission companies worldwide and possesses the financial means to support its investment obligations.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at US$67.4 million, of which US$40.5 million will be funded with senior debt.  The proposed IFC investment is a US$18.0 million A Loan for IFC''s own account and syndication of US$11.25 million B Loan for the account of participant banks.  Additional senior debt is expected to be provided by a bilateral agency for the remaining US$11.25 million of senior debt.
Investment: 18.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan18.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The proposed investment will be located in central Peru. The first power line (242 km in length) will be located in the high sierra Andes mountains and runs through areas of mostly idle land and pastures.  The second power line of 131 km will be located in the lowlands of the Amazon basin east of the city of Antamina and will pass through primarily pastures, orchards and croplands.

Project Description: Egar is a financial technology company founded in March 2000.  The company develops highly specialized capital markets and risk management information systems, including off-the-shelf software products and customized solutions and consulting services.  Egar targets trading and risk management departments of large banks, corporate treasuries, and specialized smaller and middle market financial institutions.  The company blends Russian software development and mathematical talent, and US business development and managerial know-how.  The Russian base of the project gives Egar a competitive cost structure and access to professionals with highly developed quantitative skills which are critical to the development of risk management tools. The purpose of the proposed project is to improve product development and R&D, expand its Russian development centers, build up sales and marketing infrastructure, and its working capital needs.Russia is in the midst of developing the skills base necessary to compete in high-technology exports.  This project will support efforts to catalyze growth and development through high-end services exports, creating quality jobs, and acting as a symbol of the benefits of continued reform, opening up support for education and partnering with western organizations and professionals.  The project will have significant developmental impact by potentially creating hundreds of IT related jobs in Russia.  The company currently employs about 100 people in Moscow and has recently opened a second development center in Nishny Novgorod.  In 2004 Egar expects to employ about 350 people in Russia.  Egar will also contribute to train skilled technology workers in Russia by exposing them to best practices from U.S. based technology firms.  There is, at present, a shortage of qualified managers in the IT sector in Russia.  This is a significant bottleneck to further the technological development across the country, since most companies , particularly small and medium enterprises, do not have access to U.S. and western European technology expertise.  Finally, Russia and Eastern Europe will also be important target markets for Egar, contributing to the improvement in the efficiency of financial institutions in this region through providing state-of-the-art technology and services.IFCs investment would support a company that creates intellectual property and provides highly specialized software services to companies globally, from a production base centered in a developing country with highly qualified human resources.  IFC would play a critical role in bringing in other investors, for the current as well as potential future rounds because of concerns regarding country risk.  The scarcity of capital available for projects such as this, from private U.S. sources, is demonstrated by the fact that the company has only been able to raise financing from a Russia based institution funded by USAID.  Finally, IFC would bring its global knowledge of financial institutions as well as software services industry.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category C project, according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because it is likely to have minimal or no adverse environmental impacts.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The project company is Egar Technology (Egar, or the company). Egar''s current shareholding structure is as follows:Shareholders:%Ravi K. Jain32.7%Gena Ioffe32.7%Michael Aiken10.1%Midland Trading10.1%Randolph Street Partners0.7%Simon Vine2.0%ESOP (Russian Employees)11.7%TOTAL100.0%Ravi Jain, President & Co-founder.  Prior to joining FNX and founding EGAR, Ravi was a Managing Director and Global Head of Foreign Exchange and Precious Metal Options Trading & Risk Management for the Republic National Bank of New York.  Ravi has a B.Tech. in Electrical Engineering from the Indian Institute of Technology and an M.S. in Operations Research from Baruch College. Gena Ioffe, CTO & Co-founder.  Gena Ioffe immigrated to the United States from Russia in 1989 and started working as a programmer.  In 1991 he founded a financial software company called Delta Analytics, which was later acquired by FNX.  He has an MS in Applied Mathematics from Moscow University.Midland Trading (Midland) invested US$500,000 in September 2000.  Midland is an equity options market maker on the Chicago Board Options Exchange and the American Stock Exchange.  Midland partnered with Egar in order to utilize the companys expertise to modernize their proprietary market making system and add advanced features using Egars technology.  Midland has recently been acquired by TFM, a large derivatives market maker based in Philadelphia.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at US$2.5 million.  The Company has requested that IFC invest US$1.5 million in equity.
Investment: 1.50 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity1.50* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The company has headquarters in New York, United Sates (where it employs 10 people). The company is also present in Russia with two offices: in Moscow and Nizhny Novgorod (where it employs about 100 people).
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category C project, according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because it is likely to have minimal or no adverse environmental impacts.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community

Company Name: MODERN KARTON SANAYI VE TICARET ANONIM SIRKETI
Project Description: Modern Karton is  the largest private sector producer of corrugating packaging materials in Turkey, with the third largest capacity in Europe. MK is targeting sales of US$52 million this year, with exports of about US$16 million. The proposed project will be the IFC''s second project with the company, the first being for MK''s US$110 million capacity expansion program for 1998-2000, which increased the company''s production capacity from 90,000 tons p.a. to 290,000 tons p.a. Full capacity utilization by MK is expected to be reached by 2004, which, along with the increase in exports, will create additional working capital needs. The proposed investment will be used to finance the incremental working capital needs of the company until full capacity utilization is reached.The recent crisis in Turkey has severely curtailed domestic market demand in the manufacturing sector, presenting challenges for the corporate sector at large. MK is finding that it has to increasingly rely on exports to make up for the loss in the domestic market. With an existing export base of US$4 million in 2000, which is expected to grow to US$30 million by 2004, the company is faced with the challenge of finding dependable sources of funding to finance its exports. However, the financial crisis has made access to bank financing very difficult for Turkish corporates such as MK, since interest rates have increased sharply and credits have become very scarce. Loan maturities exceeding even a one year range, are currently not available to the Turkish market and financing from the Turkish Eximbank is inadequate.  As a result, MK is requesting a medium-term working capital loan of US$10 million from the IFC to finance an increased volume of sales and inventory over the next few years. Under the circumstances, without the IFC''s investment, MK would be forced to rely on extremely limited, short-term and more expensive financing which would adversely affect its liquidity. Therefore, in the context of the uncertain economic environment and the competitive pressures in the sector, the project critically supports the sustained and competitive evolution of a vital Turkish company.  The project is expected to have the following developmental impacts, which are in line with the IFC''s mission to reduce poverty and improve people''s lives: - support the industrial packaging sector through paper production and further investments in corrugated box manufacturing; - increase exports for both MK and the country;- create employment in the paper plant and related fields, such as waste paper collection and shipping; - increase waste paper recycling and use of non-wood fibers (such as straw);- improve energy efficiency through cogeneration, which will also benefit surrounding enterprises (that buy the excess energy produced by Modern Enerji); and - disseminate modern technologies and advanced know-how in paper-making.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category C project according to the IFC''s environmental and social review procedure. The existing investment in Modern Karton is in material compliance with the specified World Bank Group policies and guidelines. No additional environmental and social review is required for this additional financing.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The project sponsor is the Eren Group (the group), which is a diversified, family-owned, second-tier Turkish company with consolidated sales of over US$265 million in 2000. The Eren Group has a 75% shareholding in Modern Karton (the company or MK), along with Dentas, another Turkish paper producer (20%), and others (5%). The Eren Group has eleven companies in the textiles, cement and paper sectors; a joint venture in Germany for facilitating import/export activities; a cogeneration plant (Modern Enerji); and is the distributor of Swatch watches in Turkey.
Cost Nature: The proposed IFC investment is a US$10 million A Loan for IFC''s own account.
Investment: 10.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan10.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Modern Karton''s plant is conveniently located in Corlu, in the Thrace region of Turkey, approximately 180 km west of Istanbul. The plant has easy access to raw materials, power and energy resources (the group''s cogeneration plant, Modern Enerji, is located adjacent to MK), transportation facilities and customers. The Eren Group has its administrative headquarters in Istanbul, Turkey.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category C project according to the IFC''s environmental and social review procedure. The existing investment in Modern Karton is in material compliance with the specified World Bank Group policies and guidelines. No additional environmental and social review is required for this additional financing.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sector: AG - Paper Packaging Products (Including Boxes, Cartons, etc.)

Project Description: Ru-Net owns controlling stakes in a number of Russian information technology (IT) and Internet businesses.  The company has a two-pronged strategy which consists of: (i) developing a portfolio of majority owned Internet companies with extremely high growth potential; and (ii) creating a leading systems integration company to serve the Russian domestic market.  Consolidated revenues for 2000 were approximately US$1 million.  On a pro-forma basis (following three recently closed acquisitions) the Ru-Net group is projecting revenues of approximately US$25 million for 2001.   The combination of a strong management team, controlling stakes in a number of Russia''s leading IT companies, and the support provided by the company''s existing international institutional investors, positions Ru-Net as one of the most promising firms in the Russian information economy.  Ru-Net''s website is located at www.ru-net.ru.   This IFC project would support a group of local entrepreneurs that is building an internationally competitive IT services company offering value added to domestic firms.  It would also represent an excellent opportunity to finance a company providing value added software services to companies in the developed world from a production base centered in Moscow.  The company currently employs approximately 250 employees, all of whom are located in Russia.  IFC''s participation would be critical to bringing in other investors in the proposed round that have concerns regarding country risk.  In addition, by learning from its other IT service company investments across the world, IFC will be able to bring its global knowledge to help Ru-Net in its growth strategy.    Russia is in the midst of developing the skills base necessary to be able to compete in high-technology exports.  This investment will support efforts to catalyze growth and development through high-end services exports, creating quality jobs but also acting as an important symbol of the benefits of continued reform, opening up, and support for education.  The project will have significant developmental impact by: (i) potentially creating hundreds of IT related jobs in Russia; and (ii) helping to train skilled technology workers in Russia by exposing them to best practices from U.S. based technology firms.  There is, at present, a shortage of qualified managers in the IT sector in Russia.  This is a significant bottleneck to further development of the Internet and Internet applications across the Russian region, since most companies (particularly SME''s) do not have access to U.S. and European technology expertise at the present time.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category C project, according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because it is likely to have minimal or no adverse environmental impacts.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: Ru-Net Holdings Limited (Ru-Net or the company) has a committed management team, with extensive domain expertise in the Internet and technology sectors.  The management team also possesses deep roots in Russia. Its key members include:Leonid Boguslavsky, Executive Chairman Leonid Boguslavsky is a founding investor who officially took over the executive management duties of Ru-Net in April 2001. Mr. Boguslavsky has spent twenty years in the information technology industry, and thirteen years as an entrepreneur.  Prior to joining Ru-Net, he was the Managing Partner for Management Consulting Services at Price Waterhouse Coopers (PWC) in Russia, where he focused on developing their technology consulting practice in Eastern Europe.  In 1990, Mr Boguslavsky founded LVS (Logovaz Systems), and over the next seven years built it into one of Russias largest systems integrators, which he sold to PWC in 1997.  Jason Downes, General DirectorJason has been employed by Ru-Net since January 2000 and is responsible for day to day management of Ozon, Yandex, and the group''s other venture capital investments.  Prior to that he was a Vice-President at UFG where he focused on developing technology investment projects.  Baring Vostok Capital PartnersBaring Vostok is a well-known private equity firm in Russia, sponsored by Barings Private Equity of the UK.  The firm currently has a 38.5% stake in the Ru-Net group and has a seat both on the Board of Directors as well as on the Investment Advisory Board.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at US$12 million.  It is envisioned that IFC would make an equity investment of up to US$5 million in a series B round of venture capital financing.  The investment would be in the form of redeemable preferred shares convertible into common shares.
Investment: 6.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan3.0Equity3.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Ru-Net is incorporated in Bermuda while the operating subsidiaries are incorporated in Russia.  Ru-Net was established in January 2000, and all of its staff and management team (about 250 including all of Ru-Net''s subsidiaries) are located in Moscow, where the company is able to benefit from access to a large pool of well educated and highly trained computer programmers and software engineers.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category C project, according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because it is likely to have minimal or no adverse environmental impacts.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community

Company Name: Global Materials Services Venezuela, C.A. / ACBL Riverside Terminals C.A.
Project Description: The Riverside Terminal project comprises the development of two floating dock facilities (a ship dock and a barge dock) for public use in order to serve the industrial zone of Ciudad Guayana. The floating barge terminal of the Riverside project started operations in late 1999 and is currently being operated by ACBLV. Once completed, the terminal will provide dependable ship and barge loading/unloading facility with warehousing and logistics for the industrial zone located around the facility.  The terminal will handle bulk, break bulk and containerized cargo. The Riverside project includes: (i) purchase of 24.9 hectares of land, (ii) purchase of barges to serve as dock, (iii) purchase of handling equipment, and (iv) development of related infrastructure.The GMSV project involves a floating barge unloading terminal for unloading of bauxite transported by barges from CVGBs mine in El Jobal to its alumina production plant in Ciudad Guayana. GMSV will sign a five-year take-or-pay contract  with CVGB for unloading a minimum of 4.6 million tons of bauxite annually.  The GMSV project includes: (i) purchase of barges needed for the floating dock, (ii) purchase and installation of two equilibrium cranes (E-Cranes) and (iii) purchase and installation of a conveyer system to connect to the existing conveyer system of CVGB. The proposed projects would help to relieve the port congestion problems in the area by providing efficient cargo handling services.  Consequently, the proposed IFC investment would help to: (i) reduce the cost of transportation and thereby benefit shippers, shipping lines and consumers alike; (ii) encourage competing facilities in the region to increase their efficiency and, therefore, serve as a catalyst for increased trading activity in the region as a result of reduced costs; and, (iii) create additional employment for the region and bring about upgrading of workers'' skills.  IFC will bring to this project financing at a tenor and interest rate which is essential for this project but not available from other sources.  IFC will play a key role in creating an appropriate financial structure for the project.   Given IFC''s experience of financing port projects around the world, IFC involvement in this venture would also encourage another multilateral institution to participate in the financing.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The two river port terminals, to be constructed in Ciudad Guayana, Venezuela, on the Orinoco River, will be developed and operated by two different companies with some common shareholders.   The first project (the GMSV project) is a bauxite unloading facility.  This facility is being developed by, and will be operated by, GMS de Venezuela, C.A. (GMSV), a joint venture between subsidiaries of Global Materials Services LLC and selected Venezuelan and  American investors.   Global Material Services LLC is a U.S. based materials handling and warehousing company, operating a total of 26 terminal and warehouse locations, both domestically and internationally.  The second project (the Riverside project) is a riverside general cargo terminal, which is being developed by ACBL de Venezuela, C.A. (ACBLV).   ACBLV is owned by American Commercial Lines International LLC and selected Venezuelan and American Investors.
Cost Nature: The total project is estimated to cost US$27.325 million (US$17.2 million for Riverside and US$10.125  million for GMSV). The proposed IFC investment would include a loan of up to US$8,653,000 (US$5,447,000 for Riverside and US$3,206,000 for GMSV) for IFCs own account and an equity investment of US$911,000 (US$573,000 for Riverside and US$338,000 for GMSV). The Riverside project is expected to be completed by December 2002 and the GMSV project is expected to be operational by May 2002.
Investment: 9.80 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan8.80Equity1.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The Riverside terminal site is located on the right descending bank of the Orinoco River, 194.5 miles away from Orinoco Delta, in Ciudad Guayana, Venezuela, between Venalum and Sidor terminals and in close proximity of Matanzas industrial zone. Access to the Orinoco River from the Atlantic Ocean is made through the Boca Grande channel and is navigable during day or night throughout 12 months with the help of buoys. The GMSV terminal will be an extension of a dock owned by CVG Bauxilum at its alumina production plant in Ciudad Guayana, Venezuela, located on mile 193 (from the Orinoco River delta) on the right descending bank of the Orinoco River. GMSV will unload bauxite transported by barges from CVGBs mine in El Jobal (located about 600 km upstream the Orinoco river) to Ciudad Guayana during the navigation season of that section of the Orinoco river (from May through December). The two ports will be located in close proximity to an industrial zone with the concentration of mining and mineral industries.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community

Project Description: PriceSmart is constantly seeking new emerging markets where it can develop, own and operate new retail warehouse membership-shopping businesses that leverage existing and local capabilities. In line with this strategy, PSMT has formed a joint-venture to expand its operations by constructing and operating 2 deep-discount, "no-frills" membership shopping warehouses in Kingston and Montego Bay, Jamaica.  The 50,000 sq. ft warehouses will follow the successful concept adopted by PSMT in its expansion in Central America, other Caribbean islands, and more recently the Philippines. They will sell a variety of food and consumer goods with an emphasis on quality, low prices, and efficient operations. The warehouses will typically carry a much smaller product range compared to supermarkets (2,500 stock-keeping units ("sku") vs. 25,000-30,000 sku for supermarkets) including apparel, food services, bakery, photo centers, tire centers, etc.. The target customers will be consumers and small businesses. About 50% of sales will be derived from products sourced from the local market. The shopping format will include an annual membership fee of approximately US$25 with expected annual purchases averaging US$1,250 per member.IFC Role:IFC role is to provide long-term financing not readily available for retail companies in the Caribbean. The project''s requirement for long-term debt with long maturities precludes it from obtaining satisfactory financing from local sources. PSMT''s experiences in the Caribbean and Central America show that the company has not been able to access loans with adequate maturities in these markets. The financial package will meet the project''s needs and strengthen its financial structure.  IFC will also provide environmental oversight to ensure that the project meets World Bank Group guidelines, along with its financing. Development Impact:The project will have a strong development impact by expanding and strengthening the retail industry in Jamaica.  It will provide consumers with lower prices on a wide variety of food and quality consumer goods through increased efficiencies of purchasing, logistics, technology, and distribution. Therefore, the project will, to a great extent, contribute to raising the standard of living for a large portion of the local population. Lower prices to consumers:   PSMTs strategy is to be the high-volume low-cost operation to provide lower prices in the marketplace.  Its goal is to be the "low-price leader" for the markets served.  This is achieved by offering a limited range of products in a low-cost, no-frills warehouse type environment.Product Quality Enhancement:  PSMT will source 50% of its products from local sources. To maintain the same high product standards it gets from imported products, the company requires that all its local suppliers meet the same quality standard. This will help uplift quality standards of local suppliers and encourage competitiveness.  The project will also introduce international best practices and bring modern technology by inducing suppliers to adopt bar coding and other sophisticated MIS systemsHigh Quality Job Creation:  PSMT employees will receive higher than average pay and will be trained in product display, modern selling and marketing techniques, inventory control and working in a computerized environment. The project will create nearly 300 direct jobs. A number of indirect jobs will also be created. In addition, significant opportunities exist for training, acquiring merchandising skills, and promotion within the group as PSMT advertises job opportunities for domestic, regional, and international jobs internally and on its website.Ethical Business Practices:  Operating in the formal sector, PSMT employs ethical business practices, pays import taxes and duties, V.A.T, and local and income and taxes. This provides dependable revenue source for the governments.Regional Market Development:  PSMTs operations in the region will link markets in Central America and the Caribbean by providing access to local manufacturers and suppliers in each others markets through the companys buying and retailing network.  In addition, the project has mobilized capital from the region, bringing in Latin American investors.Efficiency of Supply Chain:  A significant number of customers of PSMT warehouses are small retailers who buy in bulk and then resell in their own stores in more remote locations of each country. Developing and increasing this line of business allows PSMT to improve the efficiency of the entire supply chain of a particular country. The benefits of variety, quality, and low cost of products are extended to those who do not live close to the warehouses.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community Kingston Chamber of Commerce7-8 East ParadeKingston, JamaicaMontego Bay Chamber of Commerce4-7 Overton PlazaMontego Bay, Jamaica
Sponsor: PriceSmart Inc. (PriceSmart, PSMT, or the company) was founded in 1997 to operate membership shopping stores in emerging markets. PriceSmart currently owns majority interest in 24 warehouse clubs in 11 countries in Central America, the Caribbean, and Asia (four in Panama; three each in Costa Rica, Dominican Republic, and Guatemala; two each in El Salvador, Honduras, Trinidad & Tobago, and the Philippines; and one each in Aruba, Barbados, and the United States Virgin Islands). The company also licenses seven warehouses in China and one in Saipan, Micronesia. It does not operate stores in the US, choosing instead to concentrate in emerging markets with rapid growth potential. PSMT is a publicly held corporation listed on NASDAQ. It is 38% owned by Sol Price and his son Robert Price, about 20% by institutional investors, around 15% by insiders (management, staff, and JV partners). The 27% balance is held by the public.PSMT has recently entered into a joint-venture agreement with local investors in Jamaica to form a new company in which it will have a 67.5% shareholding. The joint-venture structure is consistent with PriceSmart''s philosophy of entering into agreements with prominent local partners to leverage their knowledge of local political, economic, and consumer patterns. The lead local investor in this venture is the Myers family, who is the sole owner of Restaurants of Jamaica Limited (RJL). RJL is the authorized franchisee in Jamaica for Kentucky Fried Chicken and Pizza Hut fast-food chains. The franchise, which began operation in 1975, has expanded to 24 restaurants employing approximately 1,100 persons island-wide. Through the company, the Myers family also provides major support for programs in education, sports, and other projects that help ensure development of the country''s human resources. In addition to the Myers family, several investors in other PriceSmart ventures are also investing in the Project.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at US$20 million. The proposed IFC investment consists of a US$10 million C Loan for IFC''s own account.

Project Description: The project is to provide Rs.840 million (US$17 million equivalent) in long term local currency funding to MMFSL to: expand its product lines to include new businesses designed to capitalize on the companys extensive rural branch network; take up insurance products distribution (both life & genera) either through itself or through its subsidiary/associate companies; better match its assets and liabilities;  strengthen its capital base to position itself for future growth; and diversify its funding sources by assisting the company to go public at an appropriate time and eventually to raise funds in capital markets.  IFC will have a strong role in the project as it will: (i)  help MMFSL leverage off its extensive rural network to provide new products to rural customers and to help bring rural money into general circulation;(ii)  help to diversify the companys funding sources both in terms of debt and equity financing; (iii) provide long-term local currency debt financing to the company which will help it better manage its asset-liability mismatch;(iv) the project will send an important and positive signal to Indian financial markets and will help improve the image of non-bank financial companies (NBFCs) in India.The project is expected to have a strong development impact. It will: (i)  contribute to improve access to financial products and services for both rural and semi-urban populations; (ii)  help to deepen rural financial systems by offering a wider range of financial products and services; (iii) have a demonstration effect for other rural finance institutions and NBFCs, in expanding the range of financial services in rural areas.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an Financial Intermediary Type 1 project according to IFC''s environmental review procedure. The company will be required to develop and implement procedures to screen loan applications for compliance with host country environment, health and safety requirements and for consistency with IFC''s Exclusion List.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: Mahindra and Mahindra Financial Services Limited (MMFSL or the company) is the finance subsidiary of Mahindra & Mahindra (M&M), the flagship company of the Mahindra Group in India.  MMFSL provides lease/hire purchase financing mainly for the acquisition of utility vehicles, tractors, light commercial vehicles and cars by M&M customers. The company also provides assistance to M&M dealers through bill discounting and hire-purchase/lease finance.  The company was established in 1991 and is currently 96% owned by M&M.  M&M Ltd. is an IFC investee company with revenues in FY2001 of Rs.43.53 billion (approx. US$1 billion equivalent).  It is one of the largest private sector companies in India and is primarily involved in the manufacture and marketing of utility vehicles, light commercial vehicles and tractors and is the market leader in terms of sales of utility vehicles and tractors.  Since beginning its operations in 1945, the Mahindra Group has diversified its operations to include investments in auto components, information technology, financial services,  trading, hospitality,  and infrastructure development.
Cost Nature: The IFC financing will include a local currency senior loan of US$10 million equivalent and a local currency instrument of US$7 million equivalent which will qualify as Tier II Capital.
Investment: 17.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan17.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: MMFSL is headquartered in Mumbai (Bombay) and has one of the largest semi-urban and rural networks in India after public sector banks.  Its 151 branches cover 323 of 394 districts in India and service over 118 automotive dealers and 350 tractor dealers.

The company will be required to develop and implement procedures to screen loan applications for compliance with host country environment, health and safety requirements and for consistency with IFC''s Exclusion List.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community

Project Description: Financiera Calpiá S.A., which opened for business in July 1995, is the result of a successful transformation of an NGO (non-governmental organization) into a regulated finance company. Financiera Calpiá operates 15 branches and manages an outstanding loan portfolio consisting of approximately 38,000 loans with a total balance of over $31.3 million (as of December 2001). As a finance company subject to banking supervision, Calpiá started offering savings products to its target group of small and micro entrepreneurs in 1996. Its transformation into a commercial bank will allow it to further expand into the business of current accounts, receiving of remittances, SME-lending, etc..Calpiá offers the following products, with an average loan size of $808:Standard microenterprise creditsCredit lines to preferred customersSeasonal short term loans to the microenterprise sectorProducts targeted to agro-fishing sectorHousing improvement Special line for financing reconstruction and housing funded with special linesSmall business lendingShort term credits, guaranteed with fixed term depositsIFC would contribute to the conversion of Calpiá into a commercial bank by taking financial services from low income clients to the next level of commercialization. Latin America, with its large and developed microfinance sector, offers a unique environment for commercial bank transformations. IFC can contribute its experience with MFIs worldwide and Calpiá could benefit from IFCs burgeoning knowledge in this field. Microfinance schemes have been shown to have a major positive impact in reducing poverty and unemployment in developing countries. In general, the disadvantaged economic sectors in developing countries have limited access, if any, to financing through the traditional financial institutions. This IFC equity investment would allow Calpiá to transform itself from a finance company to a commercial bank. In addition, Calpiá could, with this new capital, leverage its loan portfolio by roughly $20 million.The project''s objective-- to give small farmers and proprietors of small businesses long-term access to loans from the banking syistem-- would lower current capital costs for any loan obtained outside the formal financial sector, where interest rates can be as high as 1000% per annum. Calpiá offers services, first and foremost, to customers in which existing local banks have no interest, providing a possibility for sustainable social and economic development.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a FI Type 1 microfinance project.  IMI has established an environmental management framework to ensure that each institution in which IMI invests has an environmental management system (EMS).  The EMS requires the screening of borrowers for consistency with IFCs Microfinance Exclusion List and requires activities financed by Calpiá to be conducted in material compliance with applicable environmental, health and safety requirements of the host country.  Each microbank must have an in-house Environmental Coordinator and is required to provide an annual environmental performance report to IMI.  IMI in turn provides IFC an annual environmental performance report on IMI investments (which will include Calpiá).  The proposed investment in Calpiá will be captured under the IMI environmental framework.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityFinanciera Calpiá, S.A.Paseo General Escalón No. 5430, San Salvador, El SalvadorTel: (503)-264 1647, Fax: (503)-264 1194
Sponsor: The core share holders are: Fundación Calpiá, Internationale Micro Investitionen Aktiengesellschaft (IMI), Internationale Projekt Consult GmbH (IPC) and Fundación Salvadoreña de Desarrollo y Vivienda Mínima del Salvador (Fundasal). Fundacion Calpiá is a non-profit organization that supports micro and small enterprises in all sectors of the economy, in their efforts to gain access to financial services. IPC is a leading microfinance consultancy and management services company with tested experience in managing microfinance institutions (MFIs) and by investing in the equity of the companies it manages. IMI is an investment company dedicated to acquiring equity participation in emerging markets MFIs. FUNDASAL is dedicated to create and promote social development and transformation for the poor and offers programs for socio-economic development including low-cost housing schemes.Calpiás shareholding structure recently underwent a significant change. Between November 2000 and June 2001, IDB (MIF) and Central American Bank for Economic Integration (CABEI) each sold their 25% shareholding. This allowed for IMI AG and IPC to become shareholders and for Fundasal, a low income housing provider, to take a more significant stake.
Cost Nature: The estimated total project financing required is US$4.0 million, comprising an IFC equity investment of up to $2 million and a parallel equity investment by Nederlandse Financierings-Maatschappij voor Ontwikkelingslanden (FMO) of $ 2 million. IFC''s shareholding would represent approximately 17.3% of Calpiás share capital. The funding will be used to meet minimum capital requirements for Calpiá as it transforms into a commercial bank in 2002.
Investment: 2.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity2.0* These investment figures are indicative

The company has a presence in 9 of El Salvadors 14 provinces. It operates primarily in the western and central part of the country with 12 branches; 38% of the lending business is concentrated in San Salvador and in the neighboring province of La Libertad.

Project Description: Description of Company: In 1999, the group established Metro Markets, the first Egyptian-owned chain of retail stores. During 1999 and 2000, Metro Markets expanded at a realistic pace, opening 17 operating outlets in Cairo and Alexandria.  All stores are designed following a corporate identity that encompasses fixtures, fittings, signage, layout and shelf stickers.  Individual product prices are identified by bar codes. Each store is pleasantly finished with false ceilings, tiled floors and wide aisles. It has a dedicated security staff (both uniformed and non-uniformed) that routinely keeps a close watch, and it is equipped with fire extinguishers.  The current strategy calls for further expansion in order to capture a larger share of the market, develop synergies with existing stores and achieve economies of scale, and contribute to the development of a formal retail sector in the country. Purpose of Project:   The proposed IFC financing will be in the form of a corporate loan to Metro Markets to finance an investment program in the areas of supermarket retailing (ongoing expansion of Metro Market stores) and dairy foods and juice drinks (modernization of the Siclam plant and efficiency improvements).Development Impact: The proposed investment program is expected to have the following development impacts:Supermarket retailing operations:  (i) impact on the retail sector of the economy : the projects investment in to the expansion of the first Egyptian owned supermarket chain will be an added support to the rapidly growing retail sector and services as a whole.  The project will also help strengthen the retail distribution network in Egypt; (ii) impact on consumers: consumers will benefit from access to an organized retail supermarket with quality products at competitive prices; and (iii) impact on suppliers: the project will have several backward linkages within the economy-- as the supermarket chain develops, more goods will be sourced locally, which will help develop a local supply chain, especially within the agriculture and manufacturing industries.  Manufacturers will be encouraged to produce goods locally which will lead to improvements in the quality of products, as competition increases domestically and with foreign products.Dairy and juice drinks operations:  (i) Impacts on customers:  consumers of dairy and juice products will benefit from the availability of well packaged, nutritious fresh milk produced, at a reasonable price, under strict guidelines of hygiene and food safety; (ii) impacts on suppliers: it is expected that with the establishment of a new plant, Siclams factory will be modernized to world standards. Hence, the availability of such modern, environmentally/hygienically friendly technology in Siclams dairy production will have a spillover effect on competitors and other suppliers of dairy and juice products in Egypt - i.e., environmental standards within the entire dairy industry can be expected to increase as Siclams competitors strive to produce outputs that comply with similar hygiene and food safety standards; (iii) Impacts on farmers:  fresh milk, used in the dairy production process of Siclam, will be collected from 4 centers to which smaller dairy farmers will bring their milk.  This will increase the access of small dairy farmers to an improved and more organized market for their milk, thereby raising overall family incomes.  Another benefit of the projects backward linkages to the micro-dairy farm sector will be the improvement of the quality and hygiene standards of milk produced by dairy farmers in Egypt.IFC has a strong role to play in this project.  First, the provision of long-term financing, which is scarce in Egypt, to allow the company to finance its expansion and modernization programs.  Second, the project would support Egypts only formally-organized local chain of retail outlets (grocery stores) and would create the first private sector integrated dairy plant in the country, thereby contributing to the development of the local private sector. Third, the project would introduce higher environmental and hygiene standards including: appropriate food handling and packaging, suitable transport, storage and display facilities, and training of staff in hygiene and food safety.  It would also ensure a regular supply of consistent products hygienically produced and packaged.  Finally, the project will improve the welfare of remote rural areas by providing small farmers with a constant demand for raw milk and thus a stable source of income. The implementation of four new milk collection centers equipped with milk testing facilities will integrate the small farmers to urban areas and improve the quality of the milk collected.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category B project according to IFCs environmental review procedure because specific impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines, or design criteria. Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityIn Cairo: At Metro Market Maadi Branch - Misr Helwan Agriculture Road.In Alexandria: Inside the Siclam plant located at the following address: 1, Elbert Street - Semouha, Alexandria.
Sponsor: The project sponsor is the Mansour Group (the group), a leading diversified private sector conglomerate, rapidly expanding in the production and supply of consumer goods and services in Egypt. The group owns nine companies in the manufacturing and retail distribution sectors. They are collectively named Mansour Manufacturing and Distribution Group of Companies (MMD) and are mainly active in five business segments: (i) supermarket retailing, (ii) dairy food and juice drinks production and distribution, (iii) production and distribution of tobacco products, (iv) courier services, and (v) bottling of natural water. Metro markets, as well as the nine companies forming MMD, are fully owned by the three brothers of the Mansour family: Youssef Mansour, Mohamed Younes Mansour, and Yassin Ibrahim Mansour. Each holds one third of the shares in each company. In 1998, the group acquired the Siclam plant, an existing dairy product and juice drink production facility located in Alexandria. Shortly after acquiring the plant, a refurbishment and upgrade program was implemented and new branded milk and juice products were designed, manufactured, and launched in April and June of 2001. The newly launched products have been well received in the market and the group is now implementing a major modernization and upgrading program to bring the plant up to international standards.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at US$48 million and comprises: (1) Metro Markets'' expansion program (US$27 million); and (2) Siclam''s modernization (US$21 million). The proposed IFC''s investment is a US$15 million A loan for IFC''s own account.
Investment: 15.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan15.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Metro Markets: The new stores would be mainly located in the greater Cairo area, Alexandria, the Delta Region, Hurgada, Sharm El Sheikh, and other large cities where demand for such facilities exists.  As location of stores affect distribution costs, accessibility is a critical factor, especially in Cairos densely populated area.  For Metro Markets stores, site selection is based on predetermined criteria such as neighborhood population, accessibility, income levels, likely customer profile, serviceability, competition, and availability of utilities and good infrastructure around the new stores. The sites contemplated for the proposed expansion have all been evaluated so as to meet the above criteria. Typically, Metro Markets stores are in urban locations.  Store sizes and layouts vary depending on the characteristics of the building.  Siclam:  The Siclam plant is located in Alexandria, Egypts second largest city, on the Mediterranean coast at almost 200 km north of Cairo. The site is on a 5-hectare plot with adequate space for future expansion.  In the immediate vicinity there is a mixture of housing, light industry and commercial buildings.  Alexandria is strategically positioned in the delta region of Egypt, which includes greater Cairo (the main market) and allows for easier collection of milk from the farms which are predominantly located in this area. The road and rail link with Cairo and the other big towns like Port Said are very good.  There is a reliable supply of utilities and the plants wastewater outlet is connected to the municipal wastewater network.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category B project according to IFCs environmental review procedure because specific impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines, or design criteria. Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityIn Cairo: At Metro Market Maadi Branch - Misr Helwan Agriculture Road.In Alexandria: Inside the Siclam plant located at the following address: 1, Elbert Street - Semouha, Alexandria.
Sector: AA - Wholesale (Including Grocery and Farm Products)

Project Description: As of March 2001, BBA-CA ranked 11th in size among all private banks operating in Brazil, and 5th among privately owned domestic banks, with total assets of approximately US$6.3 billion and net worth of approximately US$486 million.  Unlike the big three private sector banks in Brazil  Bradesco, Itau, and Unibanco  BBA-CA does not view itself as a universal or multiple financial institution, as its operations are principally focused on wholesale banking and because it does not have a large retail client base with a significant retail banking franchise.  The bank provides its corporate customers with credit facilities, trade finance, foreign exchange, derivative products, underwriting facilities, and advisory services on mergers, acquisitions and privatizations.   In addition to its core wholesale banking business, BBA-CA also has an active proprietary trading book and offers its clients asset management services, private banking services and consumer finance products.   In light of deteriorating world-wide economic conditions and possible contagion from the Argentine crisis, IFC considers it important to support the Brazilian banking sector, particularly the wholesale banking sector.  Therefore, IFC''s further investment in BBA will give an important signal to the market of its support of this sector, particularly given the current crisis in Argentina .
Environmental Social Issues: The proposed transaction is a Category C project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  Therefore, no further environmental review is required.  BBA has established an environmental management system covering the IFC credit line and has also extended its environmental review practice across banking operations.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: Banco BBA Creditanstalt S.A. (BBA-CA or the bank) is a private financial institution established in 1988 as a joint venture between Creditanstalt-Bankverein Vienna/Austria and two Brazilian shareholders: Fernao Bracher (a former Chairman of the Brazilian Central Bank) and Antonio Beltran.  Since its establishment, the ownership structure of BBA-CA has changed as a result of several transactions, including the acquisition of 70% of the voting shares of Creditanstalt-Bankverein by Bank Austria in March 1997, and the integration of Bank Austria into Bayerische Hypo-und Vereinsbank (HVB) in September 2000.  The current ownership structure of BBA-CA is as follows:  48% is owned by BBA Participações S.A. (a holding company for Fernao Bracher and Antonio Beltran);  another 48% pertains to HVB;  and the remaining 4% is held by BBA-CA HE Participações S.A (a company owned by twenty-one senior executives of BBA-CA).  HVB is entitled to appoint up to one third of the statutory directors of BBA-CA, other than the Chairman and the Vice-Chairman, and one half of the banks Advisory Council.  BBA Participações is entitled to appoint two thirds of the banks statutory directors and one half of its Advisory Council.
Cost Nature: BBA-CA has an existing credit line with IFC of up to US$40 million for on-lending to Brazilian exporters, of which US$20 million has been utilized to-date.  The credit line is being used mainly for project finance for companies that have viable projects to increase export volume but have limited access to term financing and was a response to the sluggish performance of Brazilian exporters following the currency float in January 1999.  BBA-CA is currently under discussions with IFC for a transaction that would provide the bank with funding.  IFCs exposure for the transaction would be capped at US$ 50 million.
Investment: 50.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuarantee50.0LoanEquity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: BBA operates four branches in Brazil in addition to its head office in Sao Paulo, one branch abroad in Nassau, Bahamas (BBA Nassau) and representative offices in New York, USA and Buenos Aires, Argentina.

Therefore, no further environmental review is required. Project Description: EKS is one of Turkeys leading tile manufacturers and exporters with revenues of about US$70 million in 2001.  The proposed project includes financial restructuring by providing long-term working capital financing, and investments in capacity and efficiency which will enable EKS to further enhance its overall export competitiveness by increasing high value-added production and reducing costs.IFC Role and Developmental Impact:  IFCs role as a provider of finance for the Turkish corporate sector has increased significantly after the recent economic crisis and financial turmoil.  IFC will be providing the necessary long-term finance to enable strong exporters such as EKS to continue to maintain their position in the global market. With IFCs assistance, EKS will be able to: (i) improve its balance sheet by replacing expensive and uncertain short-term debt with long-term financing; (ii) undertake export-oriented investments in specialty tiles; and (iii) enhance the overall efficiency of its operations by removing bottlenecks in production. IFC''s investment will thus restore the companys liquidity and enable it to increase exports in direct support of the Turkish economy. Moreover, the project gives IFC an opportunity to support a company belonging to an existing client (Eczacibasi Group) in one of its major business segments at a critical time for the Turkish economy.World Bank Group Strategy:  The World Bank Group and IMF have focused recent efforts on helping Turkey cope with its financial crisis through continuing adjustment lending, support of structural reforms and fiscal stabilization.  This project is consistent with both World Bank strategy and with IFC''s country strategy for Turkey, which seeks to: restore stable growth, improve living standards, reduce economic vulnerability and poverty, and aid the private sector to take advantage of the opportunities offered by the reform.  By reinforcing the financial structure of an export-oriented company, IFC supports an inflow of foreign currency earnings for Turkey while providing a positive image for quality-based Turkish exports.  Such a role figures prominently during recessionary periods such as 1999, when the overall value of Turkish exports declined.  In addition, by supporting a leading outward looking, regionally-oriented company, IFC fosters the transfer of first-class production methods, strong environmental, health and management systems.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe environmental documentation (ERS) will be posted on the notice board at the entrances of the two plants in Bozoyuk and in Tuzla.
Sponsor: Eczacibasi Karo Seramik A.S. (EKS, or the company) is owned by Eczacibasi Holding, the project sponsor and major shareholder with 98% shareholding.  The  Eczacibasi Holding belongs to the Eczacibasi Group, one of the leading business groups in Turkey with 39 companies, consolidated sales of about US$1.4 billion (in year 2000), and more than 7,000 employees. The group has three main lines of business (i) pharmaceuticals, (ii) consumer products, and (iii) building materials. Eczacibasi has a long history of cooperation with international firms and a number of joint ventures in pharmaceuticals and consumer products. Minority shareholders in EKS are: Marazzi Gruppo Ceramiche Spa, a prominent Italian producer of quality ceramic tiles, with 1.5% stake in EKS, and other Eczacibasi family members with 0.5% shareholding.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at US$25.0 million.  IFC will provide an A Loan of up to US$10.0 million.

Project Description: The project involves the setting up of seven warehouse stores, in different parts of Metro Manila by PS Phils. The warehouse stores are being located within Metro Manila to take advantage of dense populations and relatively high levels of consumer demand.  They sell a variety of food and consumer goods with emphasis on quality, low prices, and efficient operations.  The warehouses typically carry a much smaller product range compared to supermarkets - 2,500 stock-keeping (sku) units (vs. 25,000-30,000 sku units for supermarkets) including apparel, food services, bakery, photo centers, and tire centers.  About 50% of sales are derived from products sourced from the local market.  The target customers are consumers and small businesses.  IFC''s Role:- Provide long-term financing which is otherwise not available.- IFC presence will help mobilize other medium to long-term sources of funding.Development Impact:- Introduction of a relatively new retailing concept which through increased efficiencies of purchasing, logistics, technology and distribution will provide consumers with lower prices on and wider access to, quality food and consumer goods.- Better value for the mom&pop "sari-sari" stores (largely small and medium enterprises and micro enterprises).- New markets for local suppliers that produce world class products.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityS&R Price, 32nd Street, 5th Avenue, Fort Bonifacio Global City, Taguig, Metro Manila
Sponsor: The project sponsor is PriceSmart (PSMT), based in San Diego, USA, which owns 52% of PriceSmart Philippines (PS Phils or the company) which operates under the brand name of S&R Price.  Modeled after the first membership warehouse shopping chain in the US, the Price Club, PSMT is engaged in merchandising in Central America, the Caribbean, and East Asia.  In the US, PSMT operates two buying offices, two distribution centers and a corporate headquarters.  As of August 31, 2001, PSMT owned majority interest in 22 warehouse stores with 7 other warehouse stores under licensed agreements in China and Saipan.  Other shareholders include the E Class Corporation, which owns 38% of the company and is owned by William S. Go and Robert C. See.   Mr. Go is mainly engaged in the import and export business between the Philippines and the US.  Both Mr. Go and Mr. See are owners of Century Seafood Restaurant, a high end Chinese restaurant.  The remaining 10% of PS Phils is owned by First Metro Investment Corporation, the investment arm of Metro Bank, the largest commercial bank in the Philippines.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is US$68.7 million.  IFC proposed investment totals US$17.2 million with US$12.2 million in the form of an A loan to PS Phils/PSMT and US$5 million in the form of quasi-equity in PSMT.

Aseana business Park, Roxas Boulevard, Paranaque5.  Filinvest Corporate City, Muntinlupa6.  Quirino Highway, Novaliches7. The locations are situated on main arterial roads with direct access and good visibility.  The sites are close to densely populated neighborhoods or commercial centers.

Project Description: The project involves extending a secured line of credit to DC to provide housing finance to Russian retail clients.   Specifically, IFC would provide a 10 year, fixed rate loan to fund the origination of mortgage loans denominated in US dollars or in rubles, with payments linked to US$.  DC, which is  the leading company for mortgage lending in Russia, would use the loan proceeds to on-lend to Russian families via its own origination network, or via Russian banks which: (i)  pass DC''s comprehensive audit review, and (ii) are trained in DC''s credit underwriting process (Qualified Banks).  With long term funding from DC, the Qualified Banks would originate long term fixed rate US dollar denominated/linked mortgage loans, secured by properties in Russia to borrowers who meet DC''s underwriting criteria .  The Qualified Banks and the properties securing the mortgage loans, are currently based in the Greater Moscow and St. Petersburg areas.  The proposed investment would represent IFC''s entry into the Russian housing finance market, a crucial building block of the Russian financial sector.  The project will have a significant developmental impact for several reasons:  first, since housing finance provides a substantial benefit to social sector development, the project will contribute to the growth of Russias nascent mortgage finance market.  It will also help increase the mobility of the labor force by alleviating the difficulties faced in finding suitable and affordable housing.  The project will also result in the creation of jobs in construction and its downstream economies.  Lastly, IFCs credit line will stimulate the ability for the company to obtain funding from external sources in the future.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category C project, according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because it is likely to have minimal or no adverse environmental impacts.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: DeltaCredit Bank''s (DC, or the company) sole shareholder is the U.S. Russia Investment Fund (TUSRIF), a private investment fund established in 1995 through the merger of the Fund for Large Enterprises in Russia and the Russian American Enterprise Fund.  TUSRIF has been funded by the US Congress via grants administered by USAID totalling US$234 million, with a total commitment of US$440 million.  To date, TUSRIF''s investment activities have focused on two main areas: (i) direct equity investments, and (ii) credit programs.  With regard to direct equity investments, TUSRIF has invested in over 34 projects in Russia in various sectors, including telecommunications, consumer goods, and retail networks.  The credit programs are divided into 3 categories: (a) small business lending; (b) leasing; and (c) mortgage finance.  TUSRIF conducts its housing finance operations through its newly licensed bank, DeltaCredit.
Cost Nature: The project involves an IFC A loan of US$20 million for IFC''s own account.

Project Description: Established in late 1999, Eastwood is an urban economic zone for information technology (IT)-driven companies and represents the Philippines'' first initiative to create a special economic zone for export-oriented IT companies, along lines similar to the software technology parks in India.  The project is envisaged to be a mixed use facility incorporating office and commercial developments and an IT school building.   It aims to provide an environment in which the technology infrastructure is state-of-the-art and companies have the facilities to conduct business efficiently.  The funds will be used to finance the construction of the IT school, the IT infrastructure and 3 IT buildings.IFC Role:Improving Governance. It is likely that IFCs support for this project will result in an improvement in the sponsors corporate governance practices through covenants in the IFC loan.Providing long-term financing.  Under the present circumstances, Philippine corporations find it extremely difficult to secure long-term financing, as local banks are unable and foreign banks are reluctant to provide it. Though Megaworld would probably be able to proceed with the project in the absence of IFC financing, it would have to do so by obtaining much shorter term financing locally. Critical mass. The rationale for supporting a second technology park in the country lies in the competitive advantage of the Philippines in the IT services area. Building up a critical mass is crucial for the realization of this potential.Development Impact:Export Potential. The project is likely to play an important role in strengthening the Philippines capacity to export IT-enabled services thus diversifying the countrys export base. Over-dependence on assembly type electronics exports has resulted in high macroeconomic vulnerability to shocks in external demand.  Gender Equality: Many of the projects tenants would be IT enabled services such as call centers which employ primarily women, thus contributing to greater gender equality.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityERS will be posted in the web site of Eastwood CyberPark, in Eastwood Locators Assistance Center and in the local government office.
Sponsor: The sponsor is Megaworld  Corporation, (Megaworld or the sponsor) which was established in 1989 and is a publicly listed company on the Philippine Stock Exchange.  Megaworld is one of the leading, medium-sized property developers in the country.   Mr. Andrew Tan is the president of Megaworld and owns, directly and indirectly, 50.62% of the company.  Other major shareholders include: Colony Capital (14.67%) and other institutional investors (34.71%).
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at US$52.9 million.  IFC proposes to finance up to US$25 million or 45% of the total project.  IFC''s financing would be in the form of an A Loan - of up to US$25 million.

Project Description: This is an innovative pilot attempt by IFC to alleviate the acute poverty of cotton farmers in Tajikistan by enabling them to take control of their own commercial activities.  FOM, which will be owned by the farmers, will use the IFC Loan and the SECO grant to: (i) purchase and deliver to the farmers a complete input bundle (including seeds, fertilizers, agrochemicals, tools, implements, grain bags, crop storage, equipment rental, picking charges and transport); (ii) arrange for processing the farmers crop; (iii) sell through its marketing service the farmers crops directly on the market; and (iv) identify and develop market opportunities and enterprises to assist with improving farmer viability and enterprise diversification. The proposed project will bring management skills and financial support to the agricultural sector and demonstrate the economic benefits to be gained by upgrading the quality and quantity of the cotton crop.  The technical assistance will be managed by Private Enterprise Partnership (PEP), who will train the farmers in proper production, irrigation, fertilization and financial management, in addition to appointing the manager.  The technical assistance is part of the overall Swiss-IFC Central Asia technical assistance Partnership for Central Asia that has been recently approved by SECO and that will be implemented by PEP.  The project is expected to increase cotton yield and revenues for farmers currently living in abject poverty. The venture will also bring an increase of foreign exchange in the country, as over 80% of Tajikistan''s cotton is exported.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe documents will be located at The World Bank country office, 105 Rudaki Street, Dushanbe, Republic of Tajikistan.
Sponsor: The project company is Farmers Ownership Model (FOM). FOM will be financed on a commercial basis by IFC, and on a grant basis by the Swiss State Secretariat for Economic Affairs (SECO). The Zafarabad Mcht Association of Farmers (in Zafarabad province) and the Andarasoy Association of Nov Farmers (in the adjacent Nov province) are the most likely candidates to become farm shareholders in the joint stock company.  Together, the two associations account for approximately 1,940 hectares.  IFC selected farmers who are least indebted and will eventually expand membership to adjacent farmers, and to others in Southern Tajikistan should the pilot program prove to be successful.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at US$502,000.  The proposed IFC investment is a US$250,000 A loan for IFC''s own account.  The balance is capital reserve made available through Swiss grant funds and share capital paid in by farmers.
Investment: 0.25 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan0.25Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The project will be located in the Nov and Zafarabad regions of Northern Tajikistan and expand thereafter to other regions.

Project Description: The project is to modernize and upgrade the existing facilities of a AWMC, a mineral water bottling plant, by installing a PET bottling line including a PET and polyethylene (PE) bag packing facilities. The existing plant (including its underground aquifer sourced water) was in test trial operations for four months since its purchase in 1998, but was shut down because it used PVC technology. The new project will replace it with PET. The venture aim is to achieve a 20-25% share of Yemen''s 100 million liters market by providing a full product size. Distribution will cover the capital of Sana''a, the cities of Aden, Hodeidah, Ibb, Taiz and their surrounding areas. The plant will produce naturally sourced water in 750 ml. and 1.5L. PET bottles including 500 ml. size PE bags. The proposed water bottling project will promote local enterprise in the bottled water sector and increase the supply of safe drinking water. The project would create approximately 100 new jobs, stimulate competition, and introduce healthier PET bottles. IFC''s role in the proposed project involves: (i) providing long-term foreign currency financing which is currently not available from local banks; and (ii) encouraging the development of competitive local manufacturers. IFC''s participation in this investment would create a demonstration effect as an international standard venture that would produce mineral water of high quality and promote sound and modern business practices.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityAl-Ahlia Mineral Water CompanyP.O. Box 3625Zaid Ben Sultan St.Hodeidah, Republic of Yemen
Sponsor: The main project sponsor is the Salahaddin Industrial & Commercial Group (the group), one of the leading business groups in Yemen, and its chairman, Mr. Yousuf Abdul Wadood Saeed. The groups activities cover trade, manufacturing of plastic products and household metal appliances, and insurance. The Saeed family owns 33.1% of Al-Ahila Mineral Water Company (AMWC). The group instead owns 11.3% and 6% through Salahaddin Plastic Industries & Marketing Co. Ltd. and Salahaddin Metals Household Appliances Factory (fully owned by the Saeed family). It also owns an additional 2.7% of AMWC through Al-Watania Insurance Company.  The remaining 46.9% shareholding is owned by minority shareholders.

Project Description: The IFC credit line would be used for on-lending to micro and small enterprises in Bosnia.  At December 31, 2001, about 94% of MEB''s disbursed loans were between $1,500 and $15,000, and the average loan continues to be about Euro 4,300 (about $3,800).  In addition, about 25% of loans were for women.  The Euro 3.0 million IFC loan will allow MEB to continue growing its operation and its loan portfolio while continuing to extend credit to the poor and under-served of BiH.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category FI Type 1 project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure.  Under MEBs existing environmental procedures, all sub-loans will comply with IFCs Microfinance Exclusion List and host country environmental standards, and MEB will provide IFC with an annual environmental report.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community

The original sponsors of the project were BH Banka, IPC, FMO, IFC and EBRD.  In July 1999, KfW acquired BH Banka''s shares in MEB, strengthening MEBs position as a financial institution with broad international support.
