Project Description: Sekem, a privately owned holding company, was established in June 2001 to rationalize the activity and organization of six existing companies of the group which are now wholly owned subsidiaries. The companies are:Company		Products	- Atos 		Phyto-pharmaceuticals and health 					products production and marketing.			- Libra Organic	Organic fresh fruit, vegetables and herbs processing.		- Hator		Packaging and marketing 		Libra Organic products.				- Conytex		Manufacture of organic textiles.        			- Sekem		Organic herbs and spices processing.			- Isis		Organic foodstuff and herbal teas.				The group has approached IFC for a corporate loan to implement an expansion, re-organization and financial restructuring plan encompassing four of the above-mentioned companies.  This project would be IFCs first investment in the phyto-pharmaceutical sector.  The entire cultivation is achieved using  bio-dynamic methods.  Based on the premise that organic cultivation does not produce any unusable waste, all products of the system can be either sold or re-used in cultivation, thereby creating a sustainable process.  The group also exemplifies the view that profit making can go hand-in-hand with an integrated socioeconomic business model, providing employees and suppliers with assistance in developing the educational, social, and health aspects of their lives.Impact on labor:  Although the project has limited direct impact on job creation (possibly up to 200 additional jobs), it is expected to have a considerable indirect impact on employment generation in the agriculture sector.  Seven hundred and fifty farm holdings are expected be members of the Egyptian Bio-dynamic Association (EBDA), of which almost 400 will be supplying products to Sekem.  Assuming around a 30% increase in the number of farms joining the EBDA in the future, with Sekems expansion, an additional 120 farms will become direct suppliers to Sekem.  This will result in significant employment creation in the agriculture sector, especially for women, as well as in other sectors in the supply chain (e.g., processing, packaging, transportation, storage etc.).  In addition, the direct employees of Sekem, especially women and working mothers, will benefit from very favorable labor conditions and non-wage benefits (e.g., paid maternity leave, non-exposure to hazardous work,  flexible work hours for mothers with young children, schooling benefits/vocational training for children of employees and households in the neighboring rural areas, medical benefits etc.).Impact on suppliers: The project will result in a transfer of technology and bio-dynamic farming methods across different levels: (i) from Sekem to supplying farm holdings; (ii) from international Demeter certification, to Sekem; and (iii) from Sekem to farm holdings in other parts of the world.Impact on customers: Egyptian consumers will benefit from the project as they will have greater access to (i) phyto-pharmaceutical products derived from organically grown components, (ii) organic fruits and vegetables and organic herbs and spices.  In addition, part of Sekems marketing strategy is an effort to enhance awareness amongst consumers on the benefits of organically grown food products and phyto-pharmaceuticals.Impact on the overall economy: Pharmaceutical products and cotton textiles are import export commodities in Egypt, and Sekems expansion will contribute to improving Egypts export performance and foreign exchange earnings. IFC Role: The group has already approached local banks unsuccessfully for long-term financing of its expansion and restructuring.  IFC can therefore provide much-needed term funds.  IFC''s advice on corporate governance will assist the group in improving the effectiveness of its organizational and management structure, and in formulating an investment policy that will enable it to achieve both its profitability and its social objectives.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community- Sekem head office in Heliopolis, Cairo (at the address below); - Entrance to the Sekem farm and processing facilities in Belbeis, a small town 60 km north-east of Cairo; andBelbeis Public Library.
Sponsor: The project is sponsored by the family of the founder of Sekem Holding (Sekem or the group), Dr. Ibrahim Abouleish, which, after financial restructuring, will own 95% of the outstanding shares, with small proportions of shares being held by its associates and employees.  The Abouleish family is well-known in Egypt for brand names in its Sekem Group of companies.  Mr. Helmy Abouleish, Dr. Ibrahims son,  is responsible for day-to-day operations.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at USD 13.3 million.  IFC has been requested to consider an A loan of up to USD 5 million for IFC''s own account.

Project Description: The project consists of a credit line of up to US$40 million to Republic to provide medium to long-term financing to productive projects operating in a variety of sectors in T&T and other IFC member countries of the Caribbean.  Currently, Republics long term funding is scarce, forcing the bank to rely on its capital, or take the maturity risk or raise investment funds from third party private sources in order to finance longer-term projects.  This results in maturity mismatch or lost opportunities for Republic in face of growing demands to finance projects in industry, private infrastructure and tourism.  By way of this investment, IFC would finance Republic''s current project pipeline, reducing the bank''s maturity mismatch and enhancing environmental as well as financial management, i.e. better asset/liability management at the bank.  The credit line would provide much-needed long-term financing for projects in T&T and throughout the Eastern Caribbean region and would accrue the following benefits: longer loan tenor, broader clientele, expansion of SME lending and portfolio diversification.  Moreover, IFC would demonstrate its confidence in the T&T financial system,  raising the environmental awareness and leveling the playing field within the banking sector.  Strengthening the financial sector in the country is one of the World Bank Group''s priorities and IFC''s collaboration with a major local bank would be important in this effort, as the project would establish a foundation for other IFC financial markets development work in the country and region.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Financial Intermediary (FI) Type 2 project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure. Republic must require all subprojects to be carried out and operated in compliance with the applicable environmental, health and safety (EH&S) requirements of the country where the subproject is situated.  In addition, subprojects whose total cost is less than US$500,000 must be consistent with IFC''s Microfinance Exclusion List.  Subprojects whose total cost is US$500,000 or greater must be carried out in accordance with IFC''s safeguard policies, be consistent with IFC''s Exclusion List, and meet the host country requirements.  Republic has agreed to obtain IFC clearance prior to making any investment with IFC funds in any Category A subproject, and such a subproject must meet the applicable EH&S guidelines and safeguard policies of the World Bank Group.  Republic has agreed to participate in environmental training as required by IFC, develop an environmental management system, and provide an annual environmental performance report.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community

Trintrust and Roytrin Securities are trust companies owned respectively by Republic Bank Limited and Royal Bank of T&T Financial Holdings Limited.  CIBC West Indies Holdings Limited is a wholly owned subsidiary of a Canadian Bank.

Although Republic invests principally in T&T, the bank has moderate exposures in the Eastern Caribbean islands and the Spanish speaking Caribbean as well.

Project Description: Middle East Regional Development Enterprises (MEREN)  was established in 1996 as a private shareholding company to develop investment projects in Jordan and the MENA region. The proposed project is to establish MEREN silica sand plant (MEREN) which will manufacture high quality silica sand to be exported mainly to European glass manufacturers. With an installed annual capacity of 530,000 tons, MEREN is designed to manufacture a number of different quality products, including dried and milled silica for glass, ceramics, sodium silicate, glass fiber, oil and gas fracturing and other industries that use high quality silica sand. The proposed project will promote healthy local enterprise in the silica sand sector, an industry in which Jordan has a natural advantage. It will directly create approximately 30 jobs in the silica sand factory, and indirectly up to an estimated 350 jobs in the transport, storage and handling, and mining sectors.  Since all MERENs production will initially be for exports, the proposed project will increase Jordans export performance and foreign currency earnings. In the longer-term, it may also stimulate establishment of new downstream industries in Jordan such as glass or ceramics manufacturing that use high quality silica sand.  The project will involve transfer of the most advanced production technology, know-how and local staff training by Outocumpu to Jordan and it will promote creation of an internationally competitive local enterprise.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community- Middle East Regional Development EnterprisesP.O. box 941394 Amman, 11194 JordanPhone:: (962-6) 567 9679Fax: (962-6) 569 7545- New Quwayra Municipality Office, Quwayra- Branch Municipality Office, Humaimeh
Sponsor: The company''s four shareholders are well established businessmen from Jordan and the Gulf.  Mr. Riad Sadik (with 40.4% of MEREN),  manages the Al Habtoor Group Engineering Enterprise based in Dubai, with operations in several Arab and European countries and an annual turnover of US$250 million.  Mr. Hamid Jafar (with 40.4% of MEREN) is the owner and chairman of Crescent Petroleum Company International, Sharjah. He is a managing director of Intoil Bahrain and the Chairman of Gultainer Co. Ltd. (Sharjah) established in 1976 which manages and operates two container terminals on behalf of the Sharjah Port Authority in the United Arab Emirates. Mr. Hassan Mango (with 14.2% of MEREN) is a prominent Jordanian businessman; he is the Managing Director of Al Emranya Company, active in construction material trading with offices in Dubai and Amman. Mr. Talal Al Hassan (with 5% of MEREN) has served as Jordanian ambassador to several European countries and was Minister of State for Foreign Affairs from 1993 to 1995. The company''s technical partner is Outokumpu, Finland, one of the worlds leading producers of stainless steel and ferro-chrome products, operating in 32 countries worldwide.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at US$14.6 million. The proposed IFC investment is a loan for IFC''s own account of up to US$5 million.

The proposed plant will be located in this area, close to the sand mines and the main road to Aqaba.

Project Description: Atilim  University, founded in July 1997, has about 1,186 students in its three faculties (arts and sciences, management, and engineering). It also provides graduate degrees to 74 students in engineering and management. Atilim wants to become a top-ranked research institution helping students develop market-needed competencies in engineering and business.  Upon completion of its long-term investment program by the year 2010, the university expects to have three additional faculties: law, fine arts, and communications, a broader science faculty with five additional departments in the faculty of arts and sciences, and two new engineering departments. The engineering faculty will be the largest, followed by the faculty of management. Eventually, about 10% of the total 10,500 students will be enrolled in graduate programs. The project will increase enrollment in Atilim by about 1,300 students. It will add 15,000 m2 of indoor space dedicated to classrooms and laboratories for the faculties of management and engineering. In addition, this phase will include the construction of a waste water treatment facility and a power generation and distribution facility.  Development impact: The project will help augment the delivery of quality tertiary education in Turkey and alleviate the shortage of slots in Turkish universities. With the expansion, Atilim University will begin to achieve sufficient scale to increase its research activities. The successful implementation of the project will encourage other private initiatives in tertiary education and diffuse best management and academic practices to the public and private education system.  IFC''s role: Turkeys financial sector has been unable to provide adequate local currency financing to support long-term investments, especially for not-for-profit institutions such as Atilim.  Financing for these institutions is limited to short-term loans at high spreads or leasing, because they are considered frontier sectors and risk assessment is complicated by their not-for-profit status.  Yet they provide important social services that are directly linked to improving the social capital of the country.  Consequently, the role of IFC is especially important, as it is the only major source of long-term project financing for these clients.  With this investment in a young private university in Turkey, IFC would demonstrate the financial viability of these institutions, structuring innovate ways for securing its loan, while applying some governance measures commonly found in well-managed private institutions.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project, according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The review of this project consisted of appraising technical and environmental information submitted by the project sponsor.  The following potential environmental, health and safety impacts of the project were analyzed:·	water and power supply and sewage treatment and disposal;·	solid waste management and disposal including any hazardous wastes from laboratories;·	building design for earthquake protection and to avoid the use of asbestos-containing materials and CFCs; and·	fire protection and life safety including emergency response plans.The sponsor has presented plans to address these impacts to ensure that the proposed project will, upon implementation of the specific measures agreed, comply with applicable host country laws and regulations and IFC requirements.  Location of environmental documents In locally affected community The Environmental Review Summary is disclosed on the bulletin board of the Rector office of Atilim University as well as at Atilim university web site (http://www.atilim.edu.tr/cevre_durum_rapor.htm in Turkish, and http://www.atilim.edu.tr/envi_assess_report.htm in English. The ERS was also announced in the local newspaper Anadolu Newspaper on February 1, 2002.
Sponsor: The project sponsors are Atilim Foundation and Atilim Construction Company. Atilim Foundation is a non-profit organization established in 1995 to create Atilim University (Atilim or the university). The foundation''s mandate is to enhance education in Turkey and to ensure that Atilim University complies with its education mission. Atilim University, as all private universities in Turkey, is a not-for-profit institution. Atilim Construction is a construction management company, 70% owned by Mr. Zaim. Mr. Zaim founded the Atilim Group and chairs the Board of Trustees of the Atilim University. Most ongoing projects of Atilim Construction are with the Turkish State. Atilim Construction also manages the construction of Atilim University. In addition, the company built and operates a hotel in Bursa (Hotel Edessa).
Cost Nature: Total project cost is estimated at about US$13.5 million. The proposed IFC investment is a US$6.5 million A loan.
Investment: 6.50 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan6.50Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The project is located in the outskirts of the city of Ankara, Golbasi location, at Kisilcasar Village and is close to the Ankara-Konya highway. Out of 24 ha, 10 ha are already in use by a private school (kindergarten to college) and by Atilim University. The remaining 14 ha still remain to be built. The project will add two buildings and 15,000 m2 of indoor space.

The following potential environmental, health and safety impacts of the project were analyzed:·	water and power supply and sewage treatment and disposal;·	solid waste management and disposal including any hazardous wastes from laboratories;·	building design for earthquake protection and to avoid the use of asbestos-containing materials and CFCs; and·	fire protection and life safety including emergency response plans.The sponsor has presented plans to address these impacts to ensure that the proposed project will, upon implementation of the specific measures agreed, comply with applicable host country laws and regulations and IFC requirements. The ERS was also announced in the local newspaper Anadolu Newspaper on February 1, 2002.

Project Name: Erste & Steiemarkische Bank d.d. Zagreb II
Project Description: ESB was established in September, 2000 as the successor bank to Bjelovarska Banka d.d., Trgovacka Banka d.d., and Cakovecka Banka d.d.   Before the merger, all three banks were under common control of EB and SB.   The acquisition and subsequent merger of the three institutions is consistent with the shareholders'' strategy of creating a nationwide universal commercial bank, with a focus on SMEs and retail.  Recently, the bank has increased its emphasis on residential housing mortgages.  The housing sector is a key government priority due to the housing shortage and associated social and labor mobility issues, the poor condition of existing housing stock, and the economic stimulus possible from housing construction.  The proceeds of the project would be used for on-lending to private individuals for residential mortgages.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category C project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure as this is a loan for on-lending to private individuals for residential mortgages.  As a result of an earlier IFC investment ESB has an IFC approved Environmental Management Plan (dated January 14, 2000).  The EMP details ESB''s environmental policy, project review procedures, annual reporting requirements and environment staffing as well as their roles and responsibilities.  Based on 2 years of operational experience ESB has agreed that the EMP needs some minor revision.  The revised EMP will be reviewed and approved by IFC.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: Erste & Steiermarkische Bank d.d. (ESB or the bank) is majority-owned by two Austrian banks: Erste Bank (EB) and Steiermarkische Bank (SB).  Other than EB and SB, no single entity owns more than 5%.  Both foreign shareholders play an active role in the ESB.  As of June 30, 2001, EB had total assets of USD71 billion equivalent and a net worth of USD1.6 billion equivalent.  At year-end 2000, SB reported total assets of USD6.6 billion equivalent and equity USD398 million equivalent.
Cost Nature: The proposed project consists of a long-term (up to 10 years) credit line of up to EUR30 million to ESB.
Investment: 26.91 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan26.91Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: ESB is based in Zagreb and has a network of 34 retail branches concentrated in the Zagreb, Bjelovar, and Northern Croatia regions.

The EMP details ESB''s environmental policy, project review procedures, annual reporting requirements and environment staffing as well as their roles and responsibilities. Project Description: Banco Caja Social is a $510 million bank focusing on lower income clients.  It is the 10th largest bank in the Colombian system in terms of total assets.  Despite a strong capital adequacy ratio and the second best quality portfolio in the system, BCS has historically been among the most profitable banks in the Colombian banking system.  As of August 2001, its profitability ratios of 25.6% ROE and 4% ROA were the highest in the system.  BCS has developed a hybrid business model of good consumer banking practices and innovative microfinance underwriting.95% of BCS clients are individuals, either salaried or self-employed.  78% of clients make less than $5,000 per year and 70% have only a basic education.  Households and businesses represent the largest use of loans, followed by vehicle loans, then unrestricted loans, and finally, working capital loans.The project will have a positive development impact, including: 1) increasing the availability and safety of savings products for the poor; 2) increasing the availability of formal productive credit and lowering the cost of this credit to low income borrowers; 3) increasing the geographic reach of BCS and 4) allowing BCS to move into markets that have been underserved following the collapse of many of Colombia''s cooperatives.  The availability of credits will allow small entrepreneurs to expand their operations, in turn generating employment.  The home improvement loans and business loans allow clients to begin to accumulate assets, in turn allowing them to better withstand economic downturns.The client is also eager to benefit from IFC''s growing expertise in low-income banking.  IFC could play an important role in trying to get BCS''s low- income banking methodology implemented in other countries.  BCS and IFC have discussed the implementation of sound environmental and social policies and BCS will be receiving additional training in this subject in February.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an FI Type 1 microfinance project.  BCS must screen borrowers for consistency with IFCs Microfinance Exclusion List and require activities financed to be in material compliance with the environmental, health and safety requirements of Colombia.  BCS has committed to develop an environmental management system and provide an annual environmental performance report.  BCS''s designated environmental manager is registered to participate in an IFC-sponsored environmental workshop from February 20 - 22, 2002.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The project sponsor is Fundación Social, Colombia, a not-for-profit entity with a mission to develop the economic well being of the poor in Colombia.   Its mission is to provide profitable financial services to the poor and use the proceeds for charitable work. This work was initiated by the Círculo de Obreros in 1911 in conjunction with the Caja de Ahorros del Círculo de Obreros, a savings institution that was ultimately transformed into Banco Caja Social.  BCS''s main tasks are to provide savings and limited lending services to the urban working classes.  Fundación Social took over the labor developed by the Círculo de Obreros and is the holding company in terms of ownership interest of Banco Caja Social and other companies.  By retaining earnings the foundation has developed two banks, Banco Caja Social, which targets low income clients, and Banco Colmena, which targets middle income clients.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at US$27 million in additional capital.  The proposed IFC investment will support the expansion of BCS into new geographic areas throughout Colombia, and the implementation of new products.  IFC will be investing $7 million.
Investment: 7.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity7.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Banco Caja Social is headquartered in Colombia and has 122 branches in 40 cities through out Colombia.  The project will allow the bank to expand into urban and rural markets that are presently have little or no banking access.  In addition, the project will allow BCS to develop new electronic banking, ATM and call center services for its low income clients, thereby lowering the cost of services and saving clients time.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is an FI Type 1 microfinance project.  BCS must screen borrowers for consistency with IFCs Microfinance Exclusion List and require activities financed to be in material compliance with the environmental, health and safety requirements of Colombia.  BCS has committed to develop an environmental management system and provide an annual environmental performance report.  BCS''s designated environmental manager is registered to participate in an IFC-sponsored environmental workshop from February 20 - 22, 2002.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sector: AC - Commercial Banking - Microfinance and Small Business

Project Description: The project will establish a specialized financial institution providing credit and other financial services on commercial terms to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Azerbaijan.  The Micro Finance Bank of Azerbaijan (MFBA) will have initial equity capital of US$5.0 million equivalent. IFC''s investment in MFBA is expected to yield a strong developmental impact -- in terms of business growth, employment generation, confidence-building in the banking sector, and the introduction of commercially-oriented microfinance techniques to Azerbaijan.  The establishment of a professionally-managed, reputable bank in Azerbaijan is particularly important in light of the weakness of Azerbaijan''s private banks and public lack of confidence in the banking system.  In addition to poverty reduction and related impact within the MSE target group, IFC''s involvement in MFBA is also expected to:Encourage replication of commercially-oriented IFIs in the market and downscaling by existing commercial banks to serve SMEs;Generate spill-over benefits in the form of trained managers and employees available to other local FIs; and,Mobilize SME savings, although this will not be the bank''s initial focus.IFC initiated this project in 1999 as the result of a promotion mission to Azerbaijan and has been the lead institution in developing this transaction, including fostering dialogue with the Government of Azerbaijan and the Azeri Association of Private Banks, securing approval in principle for MFBA with the National (Central) Bank of Azerbaijan (NBA), identifying financial investors, and managing preliminary legal due diligence.  IFC is also providing advice to NBA to strengthen the legal and regulatory environment for SME and microfinance lending.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category FI Type 1 project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure.  MBFA must require and use best efforts to ensure that its micro and small enterprise clients comply with applicable local and national environmental, health and safety requirements and IFC''s Microfinance Exclusion List.  The Environment Department will provide advice to the technical partner on developing a suitable environmental review procedure and appraisal checklist.  MBFA must provide IFC with a brief annual environmental report.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThis is a category FI Type 1 project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure.  MBFA must require and ensure that its SME clients comply with applicable local and national environmental, health and safety requirements and IFC''s Microfinance Exclusion List.  The Environment Department will provide advice to the technical partner on developing a suitable environmental review procedure and appraisal checklist.  MBFA must provide IFC with a brief annual environmental report.
Sponsor: The project sponsors and proposed shareholding group for Microfinance Bank Azerbaijan (MFBA) are IFC (25.0%), EBRD (25.0%), DEG/KfW (25.0%), the Black Sea Trade and Development Bank (BSTDB) (20.0%) and LFS (5.0%), the technical partner.EBRD and KfW have successfully collaborated with IFC on microfinance projects in Eastern Europe and are shareholders in IFC investee microfinance institutions FEFAD Bank (Albania), MEB (Bosnia), MFB (Ukraine) and MBG (Georgia).  DEG recently merged with KfW, and is now the lead institution for equity investments.  BSTD, a regional multilateral, was established by the member states of the Organization for Black Sea Economic Cooperation.  The three largest shareholders are Greece, the Russian Federation and Turkey.  GFA Luso Group (LFS) is a German consulting company specializing in management services for financial institutions primarily dedicated to SMEs.  LFS has managed SME credit lines in Azerbaijan (KfW Germany-Azerbaijan Fund), loan programs in Bosnia (EU housing refurbishment loans) and Uzbekistan (EBRD-Japan Small Business Fund) and a microbank in Mozambique (GTZ Sociedade de Credito).
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at US$7.7 million.  The proposed IFC investment is $1.25 million in equity.

Project Description: GBAO is one of the most isolated and impoverished areas of the world.  It experiences long cold harsh winters.  During the Soviet period, diesel power plants with subsidized fuel provided electricity to the majority of the population.  With the collapse of the Soviet Union, and the subsequent civil war and sharp economic decline, fuel deliveries ceased and the plants have deteriorated beyond repair.  As a result, the population has come to depend on fuel wood for cooking and heating.  An estimated 70% of the regions tree cover has been cut down over the decade, schools and other public institutions must be closed during the coldest periods, indoor pollution is acute, and economic activity is stifled.  The household income survey undertaken for the project estimated average monthly income for a household of six at $27.The project will generate and supply electricity under a 25-year concession.  It will (i) take control of the assets of the state utility (around 40 MWs generation capacity in total) serving 200,000 people, (ii) expand the main Soviet era hydro-plant from 14 MWs to 28 MWs, and construct a river regulating structure at an upstream lake (to provide better winter flows), and (iii) rehabilitate other generation, transmission and distribution assets.  In addition, the project will provide tariff subsidy mechanisms to ensure a minimum level of electricity for the poorest.  In order to lower the project tariff and provide tariff subsidy mechanisms, IDA is expected to fund the project together with a grant from the Government of Switzerland.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityInfo Shop at the World Bank Group, World Bank Group Dushanbe Office in Tajikistan, Pamir Energy Company office in Dushanbe, Tajikistan, the Ministry of Energy in Dushanbe, Tajikistan, and the Hukamats of Khorog, Ishkashim, and Vanj in Tajikistan.
Sponsor: The Aga Khan Fund for Economic Development (AKFED) is one of the agencies of the Aga Khan Development Network (AKDN).  It is a for-profit institution that promotes sustainable economic development particularly in Asia and Africa by investing in projects in industry, tourism, and financial services, often acting as a catalyst for mobilization of other foreign institutional investors into the projects.  Its approach is to help build economically viable enterprises through a long-term equity participation combined with competent professional management, technical expertise and support.AKDN, including AKFED, has been very active in Tajikistan, providing a wide range of development programs focusing on support for reconstruction of the country after the collapse of the Soviet Union and the subsequent civil war.  Its programs include rural development, health and education, microfinance, and the development of the University of Central Asia, and it has a comprehensive organizational network throughout the region.     AKFED is the sole sponsor of the project, and will be a 70% equity holder in the project company.  IFC will hold the remaining 30%.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at US$25.0 million.  In addition, the project includes additional funding of $8.8 million for a tariff subsidy.  IFC is expected to invest up to $4.3 million in the form of an A loan for IFC''s own account, and up to $3.2 million in the form of an equity stake of 30% of the project company.
Investment: 8.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan4.50Equity3.50* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The project will be located in the Gorno-Badakhshan Autonomous Oblast (GBAO), in the eastern part of Tajikistan.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityInfo Shop at the World Bank Group, World Bank Group Dushanbe Office in Tajikistan, Pamir Energy Company office in Dushanbe, Tajikistan, the Ministry of Energy in Dushanbe, Tajikistan, and the Hukamats of Khorog, Ishkashim, and Vanj in Tajikistan.
Sector: BA - Large Hydro - Renewable Energy Generation

Project Description: SVI is a leading IT services company in the Philippines.  The company''s core business has historically been offshore systems development and maintenance targeting US companies, following the successful model of Indian IT services companies such as Infosys, Satyam and Wipro.  Recently the company has expanded into offshore IT-enabled services such as call center services (through the acquisition of a US based company, TCI, in October 2000) and Business Processes Outsourcing (or, BPO), which include activities such as document management, billing, transcription, etc.  Though most of SVI''s revenue comes from exports to the US market, in the late 1990s SVI helped develop the systems and software for the billing and collection services of the National Home Mortgage Finance Corporation (NHMFC) and developed software to help the Philippine Department of Budget and Management to track government expenditures.  The purpose of the project is to  (i) restructure expensive short-term debt; and (ii) expand the company''s operations and finance general working capital needs.  By helping to finance this project, IFC would help to provide long-term financing and equity capital to a leading local IT company.   Long term capital is not easily available from local financial institutions, especially for companies in the IT services business.  IFC''s presence would also attract other investors in current and future rounds.  IFC''s participation is also seen as lending the company very high credibility in the local market, particularly with public sector clients.In addition, the project would help increase the export of IT services which would help the country to build on its strengths and diversify the country''s export base.  It would also help enhance gender equality as the call centers employ a high number of women.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category C project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure. There are minimal environmental or social impacts associated with this project.  Therefore, no further environmental or social analysis is required.The sponsor will develop a Corporate Environment and Social Policy Statement demonstrating its commitment to comply with all applicable Philippine environmental, occupational health, fire and life safety legislation and standards, as well as relevant World Bank Group environmental and social policies, guidelines and industry best practice.  The policy will indicate that the sponsor will not knowingly engage in any of the activities listed in the Exclusion List Annex A or Elements of a Code of Conduct for Internet/eCommerce  Projects. The sponsor will also develop a Code of Conduct to be posted on its web site to address the issues raised in the Exclusion List and Elements of a Code of Conduct for Internet/eCommerce Projects.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: Software Ventures International, Inc. (or, SVI or the company) was formed in 1986 by a group from the technology subsidiary of the largest power distribution utility in the Philippines, Meralco.  Gil Guanio, the former CTO of Meralco, is the president of the company.  Mario Camacho, a former president of Meralco, is the chairman.  The shareholding structure of SVI is as follows:Employees 		56% (incl. President: 18% & Chairman: 12%).Walden		24% (incl. investment through Walden Ventures, an IFC Fund)Citibank		10%GE		10%

Project Description: The company is a fully owned subsidiary of Allianz AG and its affiliate AGF S.A.  In November 1999, the company obtained the license to sell non-life insurance policies to foreign-funded companies in Vietnam.  Presently, the company has obtained government approval to expand its business to domestic companies.  This project will help the only existing non-state owned, non-life insurance company in Vietnam to grow and emerge as a significant player.Development ImpactDevelopment impact will be measured by the following factors:growth rates (of premium, assets, profits and other financial indicators) relative to large state-owned insurance companies;profitability compared with industry average and industry leaders;share of premium to non-state companies in total premium relative to industry averages and market leaders; andimpact on markets, i.e. increasing market share; mergers with or acquisitions of other small state-dominated insurance companies; pressure on other insurance companies to attract outside investors and adopt similar business practices.IFCs RoleAlthough there are a number of foreign insurers that have invested in insurance companies in Vietnam, the company is the only non-life insurance company without state-ownership, as compared to others which have state ownership of at least 50%. IFC will give critical support to the company to grow into a significant player in the local market;IFCs participation will enhance the credentials of the company by adding diversity to its business expertise through the infusion of an independent investor to its shareholding; andIFCs participation adds to the companys effort in setting benchmarks for the industry for corporate governance, transparency, and business and accounting practices.
Environmental Social Issues: Environmental and social language for category FI projects is to be provided by the Environmental/Social Specialist.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The project sponsor is Allianz AG of Germany, one of the world''s leading insurance and financial services companies.  In Asia alone, Allianz operates over 22 joint ventures and subsidiaries across 17 markets.  Allianz has four core businesses: general, life and health insurance, and asset management.
Cost Nature: The proposed project entails an equity investment of approximately US$1.5 million in Allianz /AGF (Vietnam) Insurance Co., Ltd. (or, the company). The company is a fully owned subsidiary of Allianz Group.

Project Description: On initiative of the EBRD, KMB Bank started operations in 1992 as the Russian Project Finance Bank, focusing on project finance.  The bank was subsequently converted into an institution specializing in financing small businesses, and started operations with this new focus in late 1998. KMB makes loans to privately-owned micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), and provides a range of other financial service.  Its lending activity has a regional focus, and future plans include expansion in the Urals, Siberia, and the European part of Russia. Development impactGiven the focus of KMB''s business plan on regional expansion and the SME sector, by helping the bank maintain its rapid growth trend, IFC will be supporting the development of the key business sector in Russia, especially in areas that are away from the better-banked Moscow region.  The development impact of the project is expected to be threefold: (i) supporting expansion of the SME sector which in Russia is still underdeveloped compared with other countries in Central and Eastern Europe; (ii) regional development, as KMB will emphasize expansion outside the better-banked Moscow and St. Petersburg regions; and (iii) financial sector development, by contributing to the growth of banking services aimed at SMEs, and hopefully serving as a demonstration model to other banks that are considering moving into the sector. IFCs RoleCurrently, there are virtually no commercial sources of long-term funding for banks in Russia unless they belong to one of the big financial/industrial groups.  KMB''s access to funding from existing sources (primarily EBRD) has been exhausted and its deposit base is still small, short term, and it will take considerable time and effort to develop into a reliable source of funding.  At the same time, funding on the inter-bank market is very short-term and expensive. IFC financing will provide resources which are essential for KMB to expand its lending activities and to broaden the range of its services by making larger loans to serve its best SME customers, in addition to micro-enterprises and to increase profitability.  Finally, by taking a Board seat, IFC will be able to provide input into the bank''s operations and further development.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category FI Type 1 project according to IFCs environmental and social procedure. KMB will establish an environmental management system designed to ensure that its borrowers comply with Russian environmental, health and safety standards. Bank officers will complete an IFC-approved environmental training course and KMB will provide IFC with an annual environmental report.  Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityn/a
Sponsor: KMB Bank (KMB or the bank) is owned by: European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (35%); Soros Economic Development Fund (35%); Deutsche Investitions  Und Entwicklungsgesellschaft Mbh (22%), and Stichting Triodos-Doen, a Dutch publicly-owned development institution (8%).   EBRDs financial support as the shareholder and lender has been a key factor to the development of the bank.
Cost Nature: The project involves a US$3 million equity investment and a US$7 million senior loan in KMB Bank for IFCs own account.

Project Description: African Bank was established in 1975, to serve the "unbanked" sectors of the community. It has now grown to be a dominant player in the payroll based lending market, which accounts for about 1.5% of the total assets in the South African banking sector.The proposed project will assist African Bank to: expand its operations to small contractors and taxi financing; provide micro-loans to previously disadvantaged groups for low-cost housing and education.IFC will provide long-term finance to a second-tier bank, thus promoting confidence in the sector.  The increase of the number of small businesses, low-cost housing availability, and the number of educated people, are high priorities for the South African government. Small contractors and taxi operations provide a means of livelihood in a country with high unemployment; housing is a necessity; and education is essential for economic growth.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Financial Intermediary (FI) Type 1 microfinance project according to IFC''s environmental review procedure.  For the microfinance operations funded under this project, the Bank will be required to establish an environmental management system to require that all microfinance loans comply with the environmental requirements of South Africa and are not on IFC''s microfinance exclusion list.  In addition, the Bank will be required to report annually to IFC on the environmental aspects of its microfinance operations.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityIFC Office, Hyde Park Lane, Johannesburg
Sponsor: The project sponsor is African Bank, a wholly-owned subsidiary of African Bank Investments Limited  (ABIL), a South African holding company. ABIL is listed on the JSE Securities Exchange and has a diverse shareholding mainly consisting of institutional investors with Coronation (13%) and Shroeder (8%) being the largest. Other local and international shareholders with less than 5% shareholding comprise the balance.
Cost Nature: IFC is asked to make a loan facility of US$40 million.

Project Description: With assets and capital of about USD56 million equivalent and USD20 million equivalent respectively, BACB focuses on small and medium enterprises (SME) and mortgage lending.  The bank''s loan portfolio of about USD52 million equivalent consists of 75% SME loans and 25% mortgage loans.  BACB has been a leader in mortgage finance in Bulgaria.  The bank successfully spearheaded the effort to draft and enact the Mortgage Bond Law, and, in July, 2001, was the first bank to issue a mortgage bond, which has since been listed locally.    BACB has now asked for IFC''s financing for the proposed facility so as to support the growth of its mortgage finance business. The first part of the facility (Part A) would be a revolving line of credit to fund BACBs portfolio of mortgage loans until they are refinanced through the issuances of mortgage bonds. The second part (Part B) would be for IFCs participation in the banks mortgage bond issuances, in the form of either a subscription in or credit enhancement of a BACB mortgage bond.  The facility should enable BACB to expand the reach of its mortgage origination.  It is also envisioned that IFC participation in future BACB mortgage bonds would enable the bank to catalyze increased investor interest.  The venture should also enhance the availability and affordability of residential mortgages in Bulgaria, and have a positive financial markets impact, as the volume of mortgage bonds and OTC market trading grows.  Further, it would enable small entrepreneurs to use their home equity to secure small business (microfinance) loans, which are otherwise difficult to obtain.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category C project, according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects. Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityn/a

Project Description: VSTC was incorporated in April 1986 by Mr. Qasim Ibrahim to represent his interests in trading and shipping.  In 1988 the company diversified into tourist resorts, which now dominate VSTC''s operations.  The company, with US$ 108.4 million in total assets and a net worth of US$ 60.9 million as of June 30, 2001, is one of the larger private companies in the Maldives.Having received land for storage purposes from the government of Maldives, VSTC is now expanding its trading operations by implementing storage facilities at Thilafushi island. VSTC also intends to make its resorts world class by improving environment compliance and safety facilities. VSTC corporate investment program consisting of :i) Infrastructure for Trading Operations (US$23.2 million) including installing storage tanks for diesel, kerosene and petrol (38,000 cubic meters), LPG storage and filling plant (2,538 MT), and cement storage silos and packaging plant (8,000 MT).ii) Energy Saving Equipment (US$4.3 million)  including solar water heating systems, heat recovery systems and rationalisation of the installed power generating capacity. These systems would reduce energy consumption by 10-20%, resulting in savings of about US$0.65 million per annum.iii) Environment and Safety Infrastructure (US$3.8 million)  including fire detection and safety systems, exhaust chimney systems, and waste water treatment plants. iv) Debt Restructuring of up to US$ 9.5 million of short-term debt.IFC RoleIFC would provide long term funding for the proposed project which is not available in the Maldives.  The banks operating in the Maldives restrict funding to 3-4 years and offer small amounts at high fixed interest rates of 12% - 14% p.a. in US$ terms.  Resort owners have to rely mainly on financing arrangements with tour operators, which have high hidden interest costs of 20% - 30% p.a.  IFC would help the company to demonstrate its commitment to protecting the local environment and improving its own environment and safety infrastructure.  The Sun Island, partly funded by an IFC loan, has demonstrated good environmental performance (being the first winner of the "Presidential Green Globe Award" in the Maldives) and the current investment is expected to bring the other resorts to similar standards of compliance. IFC would also encourage VSTC to improve its corporate governance and management structure.Development ImpactThe proposed project benefits tourism, the most important and fastest growing sector in the Maldives with considerable spillover effects on the national economy.  The proposed upgrade of VSTC''s environmental and safety facilities and implementation of energy saving measures, will further yield quantifiable and non-quantifiable economic benefits.The expansion of VSTC''s trading activities increases the choices available to the Maldivian consumer and leads to more efficient delivery and market linked prices of essentials goods such as diesel, LPG and cement. The project will extend the fuel distribution network to the more remote islands, which are at present not fully served. World Bank Group StrategyThe project is consistent with the IFC strategy for the Maldives which includes encouraging private sector participation in promoting key sectors such as tourism, and related infrastructure, and the World Bank strategy of assisting development in an environment friendly way.

He is currently the Vice Chairman of Maldives Association of Tourism Industries, and has been a past President of the SAARC Chamber of Commerce and Industries.

Project Description: The project company, Tecon Suape S.A., is a special purpose Brazilian company, which was established to build, develop and operate the container terminal at Suape port under a 30-year lease from the Suape Port Authority. The projects objective is to build, develop and operate berths 2 and 3 at the port.  The project cost covers the first phase of investments, which includes acquisition and installation of container handling equipment, development of the container yard, construction of office buildings, and installation of computer systems.The project is expected to have a positive developmental impact, as it will help reduce overall transport costs and increase competitiveness of exports from the north-east of Brazil by improving operational efficiency and lowering rates at Suape and neighboring ports. IFC''s role in the project is to provide the necessary financing to Tecon Suape at a time when international and local long term financing for infrastructure projects is scarce.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityEnvironmental documents in the local affected community will be available at the administrative offices of Tecon Suape.
Sponsor: The project sponsor is ICTSI, a private Philippine company incorporated in 1987 and involved in the management, operation and development of container ports and terminals in the Philippines and Brazil.  ICTSI manages and operates the Manila International Container Terminal at the Manila Port that handles about 900,000 TEUs per year, representing 65% of the international container trade in the Philippines.  ICTSI owns 100% of the project company, Tecon Suape S.A.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at US$19.5 million. The proposed IFC investment consists of a US$6 million A loan for IFC''s own account.
Investment: 6.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan6.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The Port of Suape is located in the State of Pernambuco in the northeastern tip of Brazil.  It is approximately 40 km south of Recife, the capital of Pernambuco.  It is located in a 13,500-hectare industrial development zone, which currently accommodates 34 industrial and commercial enterprises.  The industrial zone has road and rail access, power and water supply, a waste treatment facility and access to a modern communications network.

Project Description: TELCO is among the top ten commercial vehicle (CV) manufacturers in the world and the market leader in the Indian automobile sector.  The project consists of a $397.8 million capital expenditure and debt restructuring program, which is an integral part of the operating and financial restructuring of TELCO. This restructuring program intends to make TELCO a globally competitive automobile manufacturer. The project is divided into a $256.3 million program for product development and modernization, and a $141.5 million debt retirement/refinancing program. The main objective of the product development program is to introduce new products and variants of existing products to the commercial vehicle and passenger car segments. IFC has an important role to play in this project. Through its investment, IFC will assist TELCO in moving toward a regional and/or global presence, and will help the company to restructure and modernize in order to become internationally competitive. By providing a partial guarantee, IFC will enhance the credit rating of TELCO''s proposed bond issue and enable the company to access the capital market for long-term funding and obtain more appropriate pricing for long-term risk.  By facilitating the development of a market for structured instruments, IFC will also play a key role in promoting the growth and liquidity of the domestic debt market.  The development impact of the project is expected to be significant. If TELCO is able to successfully restructure its operations and become globally competitive, it will generate significant economic benefits. The main quantifiable, economic gains will derive from increased production volumes and quality, with lower costs of production at or close to international levels, for passenger vehicles. In addition, as TELCO expands its subcontracting capacity, SME suppliers and other vehicle manufacturers will gain value from improved competitiveness and economies of scale in the domestic auto component industry. TELCOs global restructuring will also have a significant demonstration effect on other vehicle manufacturers operating in India, as well as on the auto-component industry.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe ERS will be disclosed at the company''s main manufacturing facilities in Jamshedpur, Lucknow and Pune (Pimpri & Chinchwad).
Sponsor: Tata Engineering & Locomtive Company Limted (TELCO, or the company) is promoted by the Tata Group, India''s premier business house.  Tata Sons Limited (TSL), the principal investment and holding company of the Tata Group is the largest shareholder of TELCO with a 14.33% stake.  Other Tata companies own 11.32% of the company, bringing the total Tata Group shareholding to 25.65%.  Other major shareholders include DaimlerChrysler AG (10.00%), Indian financial institutions & banks (21.14%) and the public (22.90%)
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $397.8 million. TELCO has just completed a rights issue, which will help the company raise $201.9 million over a period of three years to partially finance the project. The proposed IFC investment consists of a partial credit guarantee for a $103 million local currency bond issue to partially finance the project. The IFC guarantee amount will depend on market considerations, but in any event will not exceed $65.0 million.

Project Description: Founded in 1997, Ramenka has established itself as one of Moscow''s largest retailers.  Operating under the name Ramstore, the company currently owns and operates three hypermarkets/mini-malls and six supermarkets. Together the hypermarkets and supermarkets have approximately 27,410 square meters of retail selling space, and 25,850 square meters of leasable retail space.The purpose of the project is to bring Ramenka''s value proposition, which consists of affordable pricing, convenient location, pleasant shopping environment and wide assortment of goods, to a larger number of Moscow consumers.  In addition, the project will increase the amount of available retail space in Moscow, which has had the least amount of per capita retail space among all European capitals.The implementation of the project will result in a significant developmental effect. This will include: considerable managerial expertise transfer in the areas of inventory management, marketing, and sales techniques; a switch to more efficient retail formats; a further strengthening of the local distributors, wholesalers and primary food processors (at present Ramenka is sourcing approximately 60% of its product from the local market, working closely with domestic suppliers to ensure a consistent supply of high quality products); an important demonstration effect for retailers in Moscow and Russia more generally; the creation of approximately 900 new jobs for Russian nationals and the doubling of many new jobs in up and down stream activities; and availability of lower-cost, high quality foodstuffs and other consumer goods.IFCs role in the project will be to provide long-term debt financing in a difficult business environment, and to assist Ramenka in mobilizing a US$30 million B loan, one of very few such transaction to be undertaken in Russia since the 1998 crisis, and among the first syndicated loans in Russia under the guarantee of Turkish sponsors.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe ERS is disclosed at Ramenka''s administrative offices.  Address: 121552, Moscow, Yartsevskaya Street, 19
Sponsor: The sponsors of the project are Migros Turk Ticaret Anonim Sirketi (Migros), Enka Holding (Enka) and Entrade GmbH (Entrade).  Migros, the largest and the oldest supermarket chain in Turkey, is a part of the Koc Group, one of Turkey''s most important financial and industrial conglomerates.  Enka Holding is one of Turkey''s leading industrial group focusing on construction, contracting, property development and retail.  Both Migros and Enka are listed on the Istanbul Stock Exchange.  Entrade is Enka Holding''s wholesale business subsidiary incorporated in Germany.The project company, Ramenka, is a limited liability company incorporated in the Russian Federation. Migros, Enka and Entrade currently own 50%, 38% and 12% of Ramenka respectively.
Cost Nature: The total cost of the project is estimated at US$100 million.  The proposed IFC investment  consists of an A loan of up to US$30 million for IFC''s own account and a syndicated B loan of up to US$30 million.  Initially the loans will be secured by a guarantee from the sponsors.

A second hypermarket and mall of a similar size is to be located in southern Moscow.  Sites for the four new supermarkets will be chosen close to Moscow''s major transportation routes.

Project Description: The proposed project consists mainly of refinancing CNO''s existing debt.  In order to finance its activities and continued growth, CNO borrowed US$280 million, through a financial structure maturing in June and July 2002 . Due to the political uncertainty in Brazil, the recent crisis in Argentina, and the terrorist attacks to the USA, the international financial market has been adversely affected. It is in this context the company has requested IFCs assistance in mobilizing US$280 million for the financing of its future operations (the project).IFC Role	IFC''s role in this project includes: (i) providing financing that is otherwise currently not available; (ii) "bailing-in" other private sector financing sources through its B-loan mobilization program; (iii) advising the company on a more rational and sustainable financing structure and financial management through appraisal; and (iv) contributing in the improvement of corporate governance practices.Development ImpactThe Brazilian private sector at present is faced with multiple threats to its stability and prospects of future growth: the depreciation of the Real; the current political and economical uncertainty in Argentina; the political anxiety prior to the 2002 presidential election; the world economic slowdown; and the flight to quality since the September 11 event.  These factors are seriously affecting Brazilian firms ability to raise financing necessary to maintain the normal course of business, let alone to invest for future growth.  Even large companies that previously had access to market financing have lost access.  Under the circumstances, demand for financing support from institutions like IFC is mounting and pressing.  This requires IFC in the short-run to narrow its focus towards responding to such urgent demand, while remaining within the framework for its medium-term objectives. In relation to this project, the borrower has agreed to earmark US$1 million to finance a social project, acceptable to IFC.

Sponsor: Odebrecht S.A (ODB) is one of the ten largest Brazilian private-sector conglomerates in terms of revenues, and Brazils leading service exporter. It employs almost 30,000 workers in Africa, Europe and the Americas. Construtura Norberto Odebrecht S.A (CNO) is a subsidiary of ODB (99.85% of the voting capital, and 99.82% of the total capital), which in turn is 81% controlled by Odebrecht Investimentos S.A., a Brazilian corporation wholly owned by the Odebrecht family. CNO is the largest Brazilian engineering and construction company as measured by 2000 revenues. CNO provides a variety of engineering, procurement and construction services for infrastructure projects, manufacturing and processing plants and heavy and industrial construction (which includes oil and gas-related construction activities). Together with its wholly-owned construction companies, CNO engages in the construction of large scale infrastructure and other projects, including highways, railways, power plants, bridges, tunnels, subways, buildings, port facilities, dams, manufacturing and processing plants, as well as mining facilities, steel mills, paper and pulp mills, cement plants, and chemical and petrochemical plants. Geographically, CNO undertakes projects in all regions of Brazil, as well as in most South American countries, Central America, Portugal, United States and Angola. CNO was ranked the world''s largest constructor of hydroelectric plants (by revenues) according to ENR- Engineering News Records (in the December 2000 edition) as well as one of the world''s top 20 service exporter in that sector.
Cost Nature: The total investment cost for the proposed project is estimated at US$280 million to refinance existing debt and support the company''s future operations. IFC will assist CNO by providing a financial package consisting of an up to US$20 million A loan,  an up to US$60 million C loan and an up to US$200 million syndicated B loan.

Project Description: Osprey Oil & Gas Limited (Osprey) is a newly established Exploration and Production (E&P) company with a focus on oil and gas prospects in Africa. IFC will provide "seed" capital to cover the establishment and operational costs for one year. Osprey is willing to work with local partners thereby enabling local companies to benefit from the liberalization of the oil and gas sector. IFC''s early participation will also (i) assist the company in mobilizing much needed expansion capital, (ii) enhance the credibility of Osprey by helping it attract investors with high integrity, and (iii) add value in terms of best practices in the areas of environmental and social policy and corporate governance. The proposed IFC financing secures the right to 13.3% of the company''s equity with the option to participate in future transactions. The next stage of financing, in which IFC may or may not be involved, will include the acquisition and development of oil and gas assets.

They both have over 20 years experience in the oil and gas industry and have held a number of senior management positions in oil & gas related organizations. They became Managing Director and Finance Director respectively of Energy Africa Ltd. at the time of its flotation on the Johanesburg Stock Exchange remaining in those positions until April 2001.

Project Description: The proposed project consists of the refurbishment and repositioning of Hotel Lietuva.  The hotel, which targets the conference market currently underdeveloped and underserved in Vilnius, will be operated by Reval Hotel Group, a leading mid-market hotel operator in the Baltics.  Opened in 1982, Hotel Lietuva was originally designed as a landmark hotel with 324 rooms on 18 floors, but has suffered from insufficient  maintenance and a lack of upgrading.  The refurbished hotel will have approximately 275 rooms, as well as restaurant, bar, conference and banquet facilities.  The sponsor plans to renew all of the internal infrastructure and upgrade all common areas and the façade.  The renovation is expected to start in the second quarter of 2002 and to be completed within 12 months.The renovation of Hotel Lietuva will create high quality mid-market accommodation for business and tourism development in Lithuania, fostering a conference market that will support related industries such as restaurants, retail, and transport, as well as suppliers to the hotel.  The project is also expected to bring social and economic benefits in the surrounding area, which the city of Vilnius has targeted for extensive commercial development.IFC''s role in the proposed project is to provide long-term financing which is not currently available in Lithuania at a reasonable cost, and to mobilize additional capital, fostering foreign direct investment flows into the country.  IFCs presence will help ensure that the environmental and fire and life safety standards of the refurbished hotel conform to World Bank Group guidelines.

Sponsor: Viebutis Lietuva, the company that owns Hotel Lietuva (the hotel), is 89% owned by Linstow International AS, a Norwegian property company.

A major four lane road (Ukmergës) runs on the north side of the hotel, with a parallel secondary road (Upës) on the south side.  The area surrounding the hotel is a mix of shops, offices, public buildings, and parks.

Project Description: FTD is one of four cellular operators in the Dominican Republic.  The company launched commercial operations on 17 November 2000 eight months after France Telecom purchased a 86% stake in Transmisiones y Proyecciones S.A. (TyP), a local company which was originally granted a telecommunications license in 1996.  Following the renaming of TyP to France Telecom Dominicana, France Telecom transferred its entire stake in TyP to Orange S.A.  As of November 2001, FTD had over 220,000 customers and a network that covers approximately 95% of the country''s population.The Dominican Republic telecommunications market is currently characterized by low national penetration rates and long wait lists for fixed lines.  Fixed line penetration in the Dominican Republic, at 10.5%, is below the 14.7% average for the Latin America and Caribbean region.  Although cellular service was introduced in 1987 and the country''s market is currently served by 4 mobile operators, the Dominican Republic''s 13.9 % mobile penetration rate is still low compared to that of other countries in the region.  The project will help increase wireless penetration by serving new subscribers and spurring increased competition.   Furthermore, the project will introduce new value added services for mobile telephony as well as offer new wireless hi-speed data services to local companies and SMEs and the Dominican population at large.  By increasing access to reliable and affordable telecommunications in the Dominican Republic, the project will benefit the development of almost every sector of the economy and contribute to sustaining the countrys economic growth.  Furthermore, the introduction of new customized services and technologies, that specifically target local companies and SMEs, will contribute to the development of private sector enterprises.  In addition, the project will create direct and indirect jobs in the Dominican Republic.  Many of the position created, especially within FTD, will involve technical or managerial training.  The project will therefore support the building of Information and Communications Technologies human capacity through the creation of high-tech jobs.On a broad scale, IFCs presence will help demonstrate to other potential investors that longer-term financing is available in Dominican Republic on a project finance basis for non-export driven projects.  On a project-specific scale, IFCs credibility and umbrella will enable the Company to secure the funding necessary for it to complete the project

Sponsor: Orange S.A. (86%)  The project''s main technical sponsor, Orange S.A., is Europe''s second largest wireless operator as well as a leading global mobile telecommunications company with interests in operations in 20 countries and a brand presence in a further three.  Orange S.A. is 85% owned by France Telecom, one of the largest integrated telecommunications companies in the world and a familiar client to IFC.  Orange S.A. maintains full operational and management control over the project company, France Telecom Dominicana (FTD or the company)Carn Vale International Limited (14%) - is FTD''s local sponsor and is owned by a group of Dominican investors.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at US$290 million equivalent. The total proposed US$130 million IFC investment is comprised of a senior A loan of up to US$35 million for IFC''s own account, a syndicated senior B loan of up to US$80 million for the account of the participant banks and a subordinated C Loan of up to US$15 million for IFC''s own account.  In addition, the company plans to raise up to US$40 million equivalent in senior parallel local financing.

Project Name: Daaboul Company for Chemicals & Petrochemicals Industres
Company Name: UNITED JOINT STOCK CO FOR PETROCHEMICAL INDUSTRIES
Project Description: The project consists of the construction and operation of a 40,000 mt/year linear alkyl benzene (LAB) plant and the necessary infrastructure outside of Damascus, Syria.  Construction of the project has started in June 2001 and is progressing well. LAB is the major feedstock required to produce all kinds of detergents, from liquid soap to dishwasher powder. The venture is an intermediate step towards backward integration of Mr. Daaboul''s detergent operations and will allow Daaboul Detergents to rely on in-house produced LAB instead of depending on supplies from abroad. It will be implemented as a greenfield project and will be incorporated as ''Daaboul Company for Chemicals & Petrochemicals Industries''. The venture will have a number of positive development impacts. The project is competitive locally and within the region, and will generate jobs and increase revenue through taxes.  It will aslo support an entrepreneurial and competitive local private sector group of the sort that will be vital if Syrias more liberal approach to private sector led economic development is to succeed.  In addition, as one of IFCs first financings in the Syrian market, the project will have a positive demonstration impact for local and foreign investors.IFC''s environmental and technical input will be crucial to smoothen the project''s implementation and make the daily operations safe. With this investment, IFC demonstrates its commitment to support local entrepreneurs and to help improve the long-term competitiveness of a family-owned business.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category A project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because it may result in significant adverse environmental and/or social impacts that are sensitive, diverse or unprecedented.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe environmental documents (ERS) are also available locally (in Arabic) at the following locations : - Deir Ali Municipality office- The Ministry of Environment, Damascus
Sponsor: The project sponsor is Ahmad Daaboul & Sons Company for Detergents (Daaboul Detergents). Like his other companies, Daaboul Detergents is managed and wholly-owned by Mr. Daaboul and his family. Since its modest beginning in 1974, Daaboul Detergents has developed into the leading producer of detergents in Syria, offering laundry powders, dishwashing paste, and cleaning and disinfecting liquids under established brand names. Production capacities are 35,000 mt/year of powder, 15,000 mt/year of paste, and 15,000 mt/year of liquid cleaners. Roughly, one third of the detergent production is exported to other Arabian countries including Saudi Arabia and Morocco, but also to Gabon and some Eastern European countries.
Cost Nature: The estimated project cost is US$38.0 million. An A-loan of US$13.0 million is the contemplated IFC investment.
Investment: 13.20 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan13.20Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The project is located 25km south of Damascus in Deir Ali, next the the principal highway connecting Damascus with Amman.
