Project Description: Glaverbel is strongly committed to making Borsteklo a successful turnaround story and to consolidate its operations within its network of float glass and automotive glass production subsidiaries.  This is already evidenced by Glaverbel''s significant progress in undertaking environmental clean up efforts, strengthening management, reduction in barter, the introduction of computerized reporting systems, IAS accounting, and improvements in the Company''s distribution network.The benefits of the modernization plan to the company include extended furnace life, improved glass yield, a 14% expansion in capacity, and lower energy costs derived from improved technology.  Following the cold repair of furnace #1, Borsteklos capacity will reach 1,200 tons per day.  The company will also be capable of supplying new products, including large glass panels used in the construction of modern commercial buildings and improved and higher quality automotive products for Russian JVs with Western Manufacturers, and other possible new entrants.IFCs role in the project is twofold. First, by providing long-term finance, IFC will assist a project with long-term foreign currency needs which are currently unavailable in Russia today. Given the sponsors desire to share Russia risk and the reluctance on the part of commercial banks to provide long-term debt to Russian projects, the lack of IFCs involvement would constrain the companys ability to finance its activities.  Second, IFCs involvement will allow the Corporation to continue to leverage its strong client relationship to undertake a project in a difficult and uncertain environment.  The project will enhance the positive demonstration effect for local businesses Borsteklo has had through their best practice production and environmental standards. The company will also continue to provide sustainable employment to the people of Bor located outside of Nizhny Novgorod where few other viable employment opportunities exist.  Indirectly, Borsteklo will also continue to help create jobs and improve infrastructure in many key upstream and downstream businesses.  Upstream, Borsteklo''s steady, 256,000 tpa demand for sand, soda ash, dolomite and other glass inputs allows suppliers the ability to grow and encourages competition.  Downstream, Borsteklo''s high quality product helps dealers build their client base of consumers.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFC''s Environmental and Social Review Procedure. Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityAt entrance gates of company site: Steklozavodskoe Shosse, Bor-3, Nizhegorodskaya Oblast, 606443.
Sponsor: AOOT Borsky Stekolny Zavod (Borsteklo) is owned by a consortium of shareholders led by Glaverbel SA (the sponsor) of Belgium, Borsteklo''s largest shareholder.  IFC owns 19% of Borsteklo.  The sponsor is a leading float glass producer, serving the automotive, construction and furniture markets, with major manufacturing facilities in Belgium, the Netherlands, Italy, Spain, France and the Czech Republic. Following a recent public offer by Asahi Glass of Japan to purchase shares in Glaverbel, Glaverbel is now owned 91% by Asahi and will be fully integrated into the Asahi group.  Glaverbel''s investment in Borsteklo is in line with its diversification strategy in Central and Eastern Europe which is aimed at building a strategic long-term position through early market entrance.
Cost Nature: This is an expansion project with an estimated cost of US$79 million equivalent. IFC has an existing equity investment of US$15 million in the company. The new project involves IFC providing an additional US$25 million A loan  for a total of US $40 million in IFC exposure. The remaining cost will be covered by the company and a similar loan from EBRD.
Investment: 25.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan25.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Borsteklo is located in the town of Bor, Nizhny Novgorod Region, about 450km east of Moscow.  The plant operates on a 71 hectare site on the banks of the Volga River.  Its two float glass furnaces were built in 1970 and 1986 with a design capacity of 1,060 tons per day.  The company is the only Russian float glass producer equipped with advanced technology float lines. In addition to its two float lines, Borsteklo has substantial downstream processing operations, including laminated and tempered glass lines.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFC''s Environmental and Social Review Procedure. Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityAt entrance gates of company site: Steklozavodskoe Shosse, Bor-3, Nizhegorodskaya Oblast, 606443.
Sector: CA - Glass and Glass Products (Including Glass and Mineral Wool)

Project Description: Swazi Paper Mills was established in 1986 to produce and supply 1-ply tissue paper to the South Africa market. The company''s two initial tissue paper machines were later increased to four.  In 1990 Swazi Paper Mills installed a kraft paper machine to produce fluting and test liner paper for the South Africa corrugated box converting industry. A second kraft paper machine (KPM2), which produced only test liner paper, was installed in 1995 with financial assistance from IFC. The tissue paper machines were sold in 1998 following the Sharma family''s decision to withdraw from the tissue paper business in South Africa and to concentrate instead on producing fluting and test liner paper. Nampak, a large South African paper producer, bought the tissue paper machines and entered into an operating agreement with Swazi Paper Mills. The Sharma family subsequently established Unicell Paper Mills to expand its kraft paper business.  The project is part of the Sharma family''s strategy to create critical mass and to optimize production and supply of fluting and liner paper to the South African market. The project involves the upgrading of KPM2 to increase production capacity and to equip the machine to produce fluting paper, and will enable the sponsor to produce all fluting paper at Swazi Paper Mills and all test liner paper at Unicell Paper Mills, with resultant economies of scale. The project will generate foreign currency and secure about 500 jobs in a country with high unemployment. IFC will provide long-term financing which is not otherwise available. Local commercial banks are constrained by their capitalization levels, whilst South African banks are reluctant to engage in cross-border long-term financing.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityAt the offices of the Swaziland Environmental Authority in Mbabane, Swaziland.
Sponsor: The project sponsor is Cosco Limited, a company registered in Jersey. The Sharma family, which owns Cosco, has been in the paper business for over 40 years and has built a multinational business with operations in South Africa, Swaziland, Botswana, Zambia, Dubai, and the USA. Swazi Paper Mills is wholly owned by Cosco Limited, whose other main subsidiary is Unicell Paper Mills Limited, a modern kraft paper mill currently being commissioned in Johannesburg, South Africa.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at US$8.5 million. The proposed IFC investment is a R38 million (South African Rands) loan - about US$3.3 million equivalent.
Investment: 3.87 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan3.87Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Swazi Paper Mills is located in Mastapa in Swaziland. The project site has good road access to South Africa, the company''s principal market.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityAt the offices of the Swaziland Environmental Authority in Mbabane, Swaziland.

Project Description: The EOF will provide catalytic project development funding and flexible investment financing for innovative projects that address primarily local environmental issues.  Target sectors include:  (i) environmental infrastructure services (e.g., clean water supply and wastewater treatment), (ii) pollution abatement services (e.g., for outdoor and indoor air pollution), (iii) sustainable technologies and business models (e.g., renewable energy, low-impact agriculture, eco-tourism), and (iv) eco-efficiency improvements that reduce material and energy inputs.Investments in these types of projects clearly contribute to IFCs mission of supporting sustainable development.  However, a number of promising projects do not yet meet IFCs mainstream investment criteria because they involve higher-than-acceptable costs and/or risks.  The ventures hold out the prospect for increased environmental sustainability but must overcome the uncertainty associated with new markets, new technologies and new ways of doing business.The EOF will allow IFC to support these more challenging ventures with grants for project preparation and/or flexible investment financing.  EOF projects will be pursued in a manner that clearly acknowledges the higher risks and designs appropriate interventions.  In this way, the EOF will give IFC the ability to push the market towards adopting new business models and technologies that protect the environment and address problems of critical concern to people living in developing countries, especially the poor.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.  Each investment made by the EOF will be reviewed, categorized and required to meet IFCs Environmental, Health and Safety Guidelines and IFCs Environmental and Social Safeguard Policies.  Each EOF investment will also be subject to IFCs disclosure policy.  The EOFs non-investment activity, including project development activities, will not be subject to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.  All of the EOFs activities are expected to generate positive environmental benefits.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityWhile disclosure through the World Bank InfoShop has been undertaken, the Facility itself has no environmental impacts or locally affected stakeholders. However, each EOF investment will be subject to IFC''s Disclosure Policy and will prepare and disclose project-specific Environmental Review Summaries'' locally and via the World Bank InfoShop.
Sponsor: IFC will manage the Environmental Opportunities Facility (EOF, or the facility), which in turn will support a number of different private-sector projects with various sponsors.
Cost Nature: The facility''s costs over a five-year period are estimated at US$25 million.  IFC would contribute a grant of up to US$5.0 million (US$1.0 million per year for five years), with the balance of US$20.0 million coming from external donors.
Location: The facility will support projects in a number of different IFC developing member countries.  The facility itself will be based in IFCs Environment and Social Development Department at IFC headquarters in Washington, D.C. and will utilize IFC''s field offices as needed to help implement its activities.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.  Each investment made by the EOF will be reviewed, categorized and required to meet IFCs Environmental, Health and Safety Guidelines and IFCs Environmental and Social Safeguard Policies.  Each EOF investment will also be subject to IFCs disclosure policy.  The EOFs non-investment activity, including project development activities, will not be subject to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.  All of the EOFs activities are expected to generate positive environmental benefits.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityWhile disclosure through the World Bank InfoShop has been undertaken, the Facility itself has no environmental impacts or locally affected stakeholders. However, each EOF investment will be subject to IFC''s Disclosure Policy and will prepare and disclose project-specific Environmental Review Summaries'' locally and via the World Bank InfoShop.

Project Description: IFCs approach to sustainable development is to recognize its potential to bring financial value to businesses in emerging economies.  By making more visible the business case for more advanced approaches to Corporate Citizenship and Sustainability, IFC believes that broader benefits in the provision of public goods, social equity in local economic development, and environmental conditions will accrue.  Research by IFC (and others) has demonstrated that these links exist.  The Corporation has developed a substantial data base of IFC experiences to help inform and guide future efforts in these areas, and is planning to jointly publish key findings and conclusions later this year.  However, recognition and understanding of these opportunities among businesses in emerging economies are highly variable.  They therefore face risks in new potential barriers to trade and investment in relation to social and environmental performance.The Corporate Citizenship Facility is designed to support best practices in emerging markets businesses, disseminate them through business to business interactions, and leverage benefits at the sector level.  The CCF will implement its objectives through three programs:  (i) the Environmental Stewardship Program, (ii) the Communities, Stakeholders and Engagement Program, and (iii) the Employment and Employees Program.  The issues to be addressed through these programs are coalescing as core developmental challenges and critical business issues developing countries.IFC''s role:  The design of the CCF draws heavily on IFCs extensive experience in working on environmental and social issues with project sponsors.  It responds to a growing demand from clients for assistance to address changing business expectations in relation to environmental and social performance, that are being driven by external pressures (such as concerns about the impact of globalization, consumer and shareholder action, access to markets and capital); internal responses (such as brand and reputational risk assurance strategies, and increasing cost efficiencies through more resource efficient production); and the availability and use of information about company activities.   The CCF will enhance the commitment that IFC has made to expand the range of non-financial value-added support to clients, and will support the global leadership role in support of sustainability that IFC is seeking to develop.  Efforts in the area of corporate citizenship to date have been largely supported by individual and ad-hoc trust fund financing.  To achieve the required scale and impact of change in our client base and wider private sector goes beyond the level of support that IFC can currently provide.  If IFC is to achieve significant change, it needs to be able to deliver a more proactive, focused, and structured program of project support, through a dedicated project facility.Developmental impact:  CCF will have  potentially significant development impact through the provision of guidance and support to the private sector in the areas of corporate social responsibility and environmental stewardship.   It is clear that environmental and social performance is becoming an increasingly important issue for many businesses  in emerging economies and that enhanced performance in these areas can deliver business benefits through reducing operational and reputational risk, increasing access to capital, securing price premiums and market access opportunities, and increasing employee fidelity and retention.  By strengthening the environmental and social capacity of companies, CCF will help private sector companies to:  (i) identify, define, and promote better practices;  (ii) help realize opportunities;  and (iii) disseminate and replicate successful findings more widely through the private sector in emerging economies.  As such, the objectives of CCF are closely aligned with emerging commitments and strategy in relation to IFCs Sustainability Initiative.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category C project, according to IFC''s Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because it is likely to have minimal or no adverse environmental impacts.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityn/a
Sponsor: IFC will manage the Corporate Citizenship Facility (CCF, or the facility/), which in turn will support a number of projects working with private sector sponsors, industry associations, and civil society groups.
Cost Nature: The facility''s total net costs over a five-year period are estimated at US$15.0 million.  IFC would contribute a grant of up to US$2.5 million, with the balance of US$12.5 million coming from external donors.  Where appropriate, the CCF will charge fees for services provided and recover costs.
Location: The facility will support projects in a number of different IFC developing member countries.  The facility itself will be based in IFCs Environment and Social Development Department at IFC headquarters in Washington, D.C. and will utilize IFC''s field offices as needed to help implement its activities.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category C project, according to IFC''s Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because it is likely to have minimal or no adverse environmental impacts.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityn/a

Project Description: Founded in 1889, GEB is the leading beverage producer and distributor in Colombia, Ecuador, and Panama.   It produces beer and non-alcoholic beverages (water, fruit juices, milk and malt-drinks) at twelve manufacturing plants.  In addition to its core business, the company actively promotes community and social programs, such as developing grain farmers and fruit growers throughout the country,  sponsoring sporting events, and endorsing cultural and educational programs.  The project is designed to allow the company to increase the efficiency of its production and distribution facilities; further develop its non-alcoholic beverage products, including fruit juices and water; and expand outside Colombia within the beverage sector. Development Impact· Regional Focus:  GEB is embarking on a program that will result in investments in a number of Andean and Central American countries.  These countries by-and-large lack domestic capital markets and also find it difficult to attract foreign investors.· Investment and Growth:  The investment program, which is significant both in terms of its size and its timing (given the situation in Colombia) will result in growth of output, increased productivity, and an associated rise in income in the targeted countries.· Benefits to Consumers:  The venture will introduce a wider choice of beverages and higher standards for processing and packaging.· Fiscal Benefits:  Beverage companies such as GEB are an important source of tax revenues for governments (including sales and income taxes).  GEB is the single largest tax paying entity in Colombia and it is also expected to be an important tax generator in the other countries in which it operates.· Supply Linkages, from the investment program, should flow to farmers engaged in supply of grains and other raw materials and to manufacturers of glass bottles, crowns, cases, and other packaging supplies.· Corporate Governance:  As the leading Colombian blue chip, the implementation of a new corporate governance program at GEB will set an important example for other companies in Colombia and increase the attractiveness of the market for investors.· Demonstration Effect:  IFCs support and its success in syndicating a B loan could have an important demonstration impact at a particularly difficult time for Colombia.IFC RoleUntil 1999, the Groups complicated organizational configuration hampered its ability to tap local and external financing sources.  IFC is assisting the company in concluding its organizational and financial restructuring, thereby helping the company to position itself for growth and further investment in the region.  Given Colombias current situation, GEB is seeking IFCs assistance in order to tap international capital markets, which are currently not accessible for term financing even to Colombian blue-chips.  The IFC financing package (including the B loan) would be critical for completing GEBs financial plan.  IFC would also assist the company in a number of other areas, including: (a) Corporate Governance:  GEB is in the process of upgrading its corporate governance practices and IFC is supporting the companys efforts in this area; (b) Environment:  With IFCs assistance, the company would further improve its environment, health, and safety standards by bringing them into compliance with World Bank guidelines; and (c) External Linkages:  the IFC financing package would enable the company to expand initiatives with suppliers, including: (i) an outsourcing program that GEB has developed for former employees which includes training and support for undertaking warehousing and distribution activities; and (ii) technical and financial support that the company provides to fruit growers and other suppliers of agricultural inputs.

Sponsor: The Project Sponsor is Grupo Empresarial Bavaria (GEB, or the company), the premier beverage manufacturer in Colombia.    The Santo Domingo family of Colombia owns 80% of GEBs principal company: Bavaria, S.A. (Bavaria). The remaining 20% is held by minority shareholders and traded on the Colombian stock exchange.  Bavaria in turn directly or indirectly owns controlling stakes in the other group companies.  The Santo Domingo family  has wide-ranging business interests (including airlines, automotive, telecommunications, media and retail).  In addition, the family is active in philanthropic and charitable causes through the Santo Domingo Foundation, a 42-year old not-for-profit entity that develops social, cultural, health, educational, and scientific programs for low-income groups throughout Colombia.

Project Description: The project''s prime objective is to foster the development of Central America''s nascent credit information system, thus facilitating the extension of credit to previously underserved client segments.   Empirical evidence has shown that credit bureaus are critical to the expansion of credit, that the availability and use of credit bureau reports in credit decisions increase the quality of the credit decisions, and that credit bureaus provide a significant protection for financial institutions against fraud.IFC has been working closely with the World Bank over the past two years to build capacity and promote better credit information infrastructure in our member countries.  The first phase of our efforts focused primarily on promotional undertakings, including an international conference on credit information and credit scoring in 2001, roundtables and video-conferences hosted in or for a number of countries including Central America.  The proposed investment in TUCA would be IFCs first investment in a consumer and commercial credit bureau.The investment would support and finance TUCAs expansion in Central America through the establishment of new subsidiaries, as well as outsourcing arrangements for and investments in existing credit bureaus.   TUCA, through its subsidiaries and affiliates, will be providing both consumer and commercial credit information primarily to financial institutions.  The project is expected to significantly improve the current credit information infrastructure in the region, and allow financial institutions to make better credit decisions and pro-actively manage and monitor their existing portfolios while at the same time lower operating expenses.  This in turn will lead to greater access to financing for the underserved as improved credit information allows lenders to extend more credit while maintaining or reducing their loan losses.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category C project, according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because it is likely to have minimal or no adverse environmental impacts.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityn/a
Sponsor: Trans Union Central America (TUCA) is a credit bureau company operating in the Central American region. Its major shareholders are SFI Corporation, a  Costa Rican credit bureau and factoring company (51%), and T U, LLC,  one of the three key credit bureau operators in North America (49%).
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimatred at US$800,000. IFC will be making an equity investment of US$400,000, for no more than 25% of TUCA.
Investment: 0.40 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity0.40* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Incorporated in Panama, TUCA is designed to provide the region''s lenders with credit information pertaining to both individuals and businesses.  TUCA is currently operating in Costa Rica, Guatemala, El Salvador and Honduras and intends to begin operations in Nicaragua and Panama.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category C project, according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because it is likely to have minimal or no adverse environmental impacts.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityn/a

Project Description: The project consists of financing the 2002-2005 investment program of MWCI, the concessionaire for Metro Manila East.  In 1997, MWCI won a competitive tender to operate the Metro Manila East service zone (1997 population: 4.5 million) under a 25-year concession agreement. It inherited facilities that require significant rehabilitation and to date MWCI has spent approximately US$20 million for its own capital expenditures and close to US$60 million in projects funded through multilateral loans to MWSS. Upon commencement of operations, MWCI delivered an average of 440 millions of liters per day (MLD) to 325,000 households.  Billed volume in the last 4 years has increased 70% to 750 MLD in December 2001. During the same period the number of households served has gone up to 428,000 and the population served has increased from 3.0 million to 4.05 million (from 70 percent to 89 percent). Water availability has also gone up during the last 4 years.  The percentage of areas that have 24-hour access to water has increased from 26 percent in 1997 to 55 percent in 2001.MWCIs Operating Improvements since 1997 TakeoverExpanded Coverage67% to 89% of populationImproved 24 hour supply26% to 83%Reduced NRW63% to 51%Built New Distribution Lines170 kmsThe improvements in coverage and billed volume during the last 4 years were also accompanied by a reduction in NRW, which fell by close to 12 percentage points from 63% of treated water in 1997 to 52% in 2001.  MWCI has pushed up the quality standard from 91% compliant in 1997 to 99.5% in 2001, exceeding the 95% required by the National Standards for Drinking Water.MWCI inherited 2,165 employees at the turnover date and has reduced this figure to 1,530 without mandatory redundancies, largely through a voluntary early retirement scheme. The vast majority of MWCIs staff are ex-MWSS employees. There have been no reductions in pay.MWCI Efficiency Indicators 1997-200119971998199920002001No. of Household Connections (000s)325340390409428  Population Served (millions)3.03.13.63.764.05  Staff per 1000 connections6.35.14.83.83.6Total Operating Cost per cubic meter of billed water5.955.475.214.774.73The Project as defined includes (i) new water sources development; (ii) service expansion to East and Southeast areas; (iii) network distribution improvement; (iv) other pipe extension and improvement projects; (v) water supply facilities; (vi) non-revenue water (NRW) reduction programs; (vii) sewerage & sanitation services; and (viii) payment of concession fees to Metropolitan Waterworks and Sewerage System(MWSS), the conceding authority. The concession fees finance the portion of MWSSs debt to multilaterals which has been incurred for capital works programs benefiting MWCIs service area, as well as MWSSs counterpart funding toward those programs and its administrative costs. The impact of inadequate water and sanitation services falls primarily on the poor. Badly served by the formal sector, the poor make their own, often inadequate, arrangements to meet basic survival needs. Many fetch water from long distances or end up paying high prices to water vendors for very small quantities of water or enduring significant coping costs in terms of investments in backup tanks and pumps. The clear need for basic water and sanitation services for the poor assume even greater significance when the linkages with other dimensions of poverty are considered.   Water and sanitation related sicknesses put severe burdens on health services and keep children out of school. Human waste poses a tremendous social cost through pollution of rivers and groundwater.  Thus, improved water and sanitation services contribute to poverty reduction and growth through their impact on, inter alia, health, private sector development, urban development, environment and water resource management. MWCIs investment program, through expansion of coverage in water, sanitation and sewerage, thus makes a significant contribution to the economic development of the Philippines. This positive contribution is amplified by the focus the project has on expansion of coverage to lower income residents through innovative arrangements for connection and payment. There have been a limited number of successful privatizations in the water and sanitation sector in emerging markets.  IFC''s assistance to MWCI would build upon the earlier IFC privatization advisory work by supporting a concessionaire who has begun to demonstrate the efficiencies and client responsiveness that a private sector provider can introduce to the provision of public services.  By supporting this successful private water concessionaire IFC will send a positive signal to the market and to other governments considering water privatizations. One of the reasons MWCI has approached IFC is because local banks are not offering financing of the appropriate maturity. The sponsors further believe that completing a financing with IFC would be a signal of quality that would help it in later rounds of financing, including a planned IPO. In addition to these practical points, Ayala Corporation, which cultivates a corporate image as a socially responsible company, has expressed interest in IFC for broader developmental reasons. Ayala Corporation perceives that the presence of a prestigious institution such as IFC in MWCI would be good for the Philippines by demonstrating that privatization can work despite the challenges posed by poverty in the Philippines, and that a well-run company can attract financing in an emerging market context.

Sponsor: The project sponsors are Ayala Corporation (Ayala), United Utilities, Bechtel Corporation and Mitsubishi Corporation. The project company, Manila Water Company Inc. (MWCI), is owned by Ayala Corporation (35.25% direct share and 7.05% indirect share through MWC Holdings, an investment vehicle), United Utilities B.V. (18.8%), International Water (MWC) S.a.r.l. (9.4% direct and 4.7% indirect through MWC Holdings), BPI Capital Corporation (9.4%), Mitsubishi Corporation (9.4%), and employees (6%). Ayala is the oldest business conglomerate in the Philippines with interests in real estate, banking, telecommunications, utilities, electronics and information technology, automotive, and international operations. United Utilities B.V. is a subsidiary of United Utilities PLC, a listed company that provides water, sewer, energy and electricity services to over 28 million people worldwide. International Water (MWC) S.a.r.l. (Luxembourg) is a joint investment vehicle of Bechtel (US) and Edison S.p.A (Italy). Bechtel Corporation is a world leader in civil construction and engineering of major infrastructure projects. BPI Capital Corporation is a wholly owned subsidiary of Bank of the Philippine Islands, the country''s second-largest financial institution. Mitsubishi Corporation is a trading company and investor in more than 600 companies dealing in chemicals, information systems, metals, fuels, machinery, foods, textiles and general merchandise.

Project Description: The borrower will be Petreco S.a.r.l., a Luxembourg private limited company. Its assets and activity are solely in Bulgaria, namely the development of the Galata Field and a 100% interest in the exploration permit for the rest of Block-III and the adjoining Block Kaliakra, 99, in offshore Bulgaria. As stated earlier, part of its interest is held through its Bulgarian subsidiary, Petreco Bulgaria, which will execute the project.  The proposed project involves the development of the Galata gas field.  An independent reserve engineer has certified proved reserves of 49 bcf of dry gas. The development of the field will involve the drilling of two wells, the installation of a production platform, the construction of an 83 km pipeline and related processing and metering facilities. Melrose expects to achieve first gas by the second half of 2003.Bulgaria has very limited indigenous gas production and its domestic market for natural gas is still in an early stage of development. The sector does, however,  play a key role as a gas transit country for deliveries of Russian gas to Turkey, Greece, and Macedonia. This role is poised to become more important with increasing deliveries. As a result of it being a gas transit country, Bulgaria has access to imported gas as well as a well developed gas transmission system which provides a solid base to support gas distribution in the country. Development of a competitive gas market is an objective of the government of Bulgaria and towards this goal concessions are on offer for local distribution by private companies. The development of the Galata Field will help introduce competition in gas supply, albeit in a limited way (around 15% of total annual supply). More importantly, the successful development of the Galata Field will have a significant impact on the perceptions of other potential upstream investors and on Bulgaria''s standing as a responsible gas transit country.  Secondly, it is expected that the Galata Field, upon depletion will be used as a gas storage facility, thus strengthening Bulgaria''s role as a gas transit country with its attendant revenue generating benefits. Third, royalty and other taxes from the project, including production bonus, will accrue to the government. Fourth, the sponsors have committed , under the terms of the concession agreement, to actively support local companies in project execution and to train Bulgarian employees. Finally, the employment during construction phase will total several hundred people and the core operating and management staff in production will be approximately 30 people.At a proven reserve of 49 Bcf, Galata is a relatively small gas field and it is believed that this is the reason that Texaco, which discovered the field more than a decade ago did not pursue the development of the field. From the country''s point of view, commercial production from  the Galata Field is important for development of a competitive  domestic gas market. The project has not been able to attract private financing, even for the relatively shorter terms needed, and IFC''s participation is critical for the financing of the project. Secondly, the gas sector in Bulgaria and in particular Bulgargaz, the national gas company, is in a process of change. IFC''s participation gives comfort to the sponsors that these changes would be undertaken in a manner which does not jeopardize the commercial viability of the project.

Sponsor: The project is sponsored by Melrose Resources plc,  a UK oil and gas company established in May 1997 and listed on the London Stock Exchange in 1999. The largest shareholders (65%) are the Adair Shareholders which include Mr. Robert Adair, certain trusts for the benefit of Mr. Adair and his immediate family, and Skye Investments Limited, a company controlled by those same trusts. Mr. Robert Adair, the Executive Chairman of Melrose, is a chartered accountant by training and in the past he headed the oil and gas practice of Arthur Anderson, UK., and, since 1992, he has held senior positions in the Melrose Petroleum Group until its demerger and management buy-out in 1997. Other shareholders include senior management of Melrose and the publicMelrose Resources plc holds 100% interest in the Galata Field through its wholly owned subsidiary Petreco Sarl (the borrower), a Luxembourg registered company.  Petreco Sarl, in turn, has a fully owned Bulgarian subsidiary, Petreco EOOD (Petreco Bulgaria) and the concession interest is held 48.33% directly by Petreco Sarl and the balance 51.67% through the Bulgarian subsidiary.The principal activity of Melrose is oil and gas exploration, development, production and sales. It  currently has oil and gas interests in the US, Egypt and in Bulgaria . The principal subsidiaries are Melrose Energy Company (US), Petreco S.a.r.l. and Petreco EOOD, Bulgaria, and Odyssey (Egypt).

Project Description: FCL and ALAS Bosna, a special purpose company for modernizing the cement plant for FCL, would be the co-borrowers for the project.  FCL was established in 1974 as a state owned company, and uses the dry process technology of the 1970s. It has a kiln capacity of 800 tons per day, translating to around 340,000 tons of cement a year. The project would involve the post privatization rehabilitation and modernization of  the company. The project would consist of (i) optimization of production capacity of the existing facility of the borrowers located at Lukavac, Macan Marije bb, Bosnia and Herzegovina from its current cement output level of about 260,000 tons per year (tpy) to a full capacity level of 340,000 tpy (stage 1); (ii) expansion of the existing cement grinding capacity to 800,000 tpy (stage 2); and (iii) expansion of clinker production capacity by installing a new kiln line of 2,000 tons per day (tpd) capacity to match the cement production level of 800,000 tpy (stage 3). The first two stages will be implemented together as Phase I, while the kiln will be constructed as Phase II of the project.The project is underpinned by strong local demand driven by the need to complete repairs to buildings, bridges and other infrastructure damaged during the war. Demand is also growing from new construction of industrial and commercial facilities, fueled by a high post war GDP growth rate and is currently being met through heavy cement imports (estimated at 900,000 tpy in 2001). The modernization will also bring down production costs and enable the company to compete with imports, thus contributing to foreign exchange savings.   The project provides an opportunity for IFC to support privatization and one of the largest and highly visible FDI in BiH.  Moreover, the underdeveloped financial system in BiH is not able to provide the sponsors with access to adequate long-term limited recourse financing.  In addition, IFCs review and approval of the project will provide confidence to other potential lenders and signal an improving investment climate in BiH, as the current perception of BiH, and its associated macroeconomic risk, by many international banks is somewhat negative.  IFCs investment, including long term funding for its own account and mobilizing commercial resources, would also play an important role in assisting a company whose modernization would have a substantial positive impact on the economic development in the area.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityERS is displayed at the Culture Hall in Lukavac.
Sponsor: The project sponsors are the Asamer & Hufnagl Group (Asamer), a large Austrian private company in the aggregates and construction business; and Alpine Mayreder bau GmbH (Alpine), another leading Austrian private construction company (together the sponsors). The majority shareholder of the project company is ALAS International (51%), which is a special purpose holding company established as a joint venture between Asamer (71.5%) and Alpine (28.5%) to hold their investments in frontier countries.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at EUR102 million equivalent. IFC''s proposed investment consists of an A Loan of EUR20 million for IFC''s own account, and a syndicated B Loan of up to EUR5 million for the participants account, for an aggregate investment not to exceed EUR25 million.
Investment: 24.10 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan24.10Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The existing facilities of Fabrika Cementa Lukavac (FCL, or the company) are located close to the town of Lukavac, Macan Marije bb, 18 km from the city of Tuzla in the northern part of BiH at a flat land between wooded hills. The location offers good infrastructure such as access at just 200 meters to the main road Doboj-Tuzla-Orasje connected to the Sarajevo transversal, railway branch to the plant, power transmission from the public grid, modern communication systems, and human resources at an urban area. The site provides good possibilities for further expansions.

Project Description: Company Description:  Amaggi, a major soybean merchandiser, crusher, and exporter was established in 1950 in the state of Parana by the André Maggi family of Italian origin.  In 1979, Amaggi moved to the state of Mato Grosso to take advantage of the enormous agricultural potential of the Center-West region of Brazil.  At that time, total soybean production accounted for less than 1% of Brazils total production.  In 1983, the company started pre-financing farmers.  In 2001, the company entered the crushing business to take advantage of the added value of soybean by-products, such as soyoil and soymeal.  The companys sales volume was 1.8 million metric tons in 2001, mostly for the export market (88%) and with total sales of US$342 million equivalent. The companys working capital cycle starts with the advances to farmers at the beginning of the cropping season (June-July), and ends with the building up of soybean inventories when the company purchases and stores the soybeans at harvest time (January  April).  The companys peak sales occur following the harvest, in May  June.  Project Description:  The project consists of financing the growing working capital requirements of Amaggi.  Amaggis working capital consists mainly of (i) farmers advances, such as inputs and cash for soybean production, and (ii) inventory of soybean and its by-products.  It is proposed that IFC finances up to US$30 million of the projected permanent working capital increase, which would have otherwise been financed by short-term funding.IFC Role:  The proposed project will back a company that has demonstrated its capability to respond to challenging infrastructure issues and created an efficient export channel for its soybeans. Also in line with the World Bank''s Country Assistance Strategy (CAS), the IFC loan will stabilize the balance sheet structure of a midsize company in one of the countrys most important export commodities.  Because of the financial intermediation role played by Amaggi in its farmers financing program, the IFC project will be indirectly reaching almost 900 farmers which benefit from companys advances in a cost effective approach.Developmental Impact:  Section A:  The project will provide the company with a more stable source of financing for a portion of its permanent current assets, namely advances to farmers and a minimum inventory of beans, particularly for its crushing operations, given the deterioration in the regional economy and the possible contagion of the Argentine crisis to its Mercosur neighbors. This long-term financing will substitute short term debt to mitigate the possible risk of refinancing which could follow from a financial crisis in the country. As such, a financial and economic rate of return cannot be meaningfully calculated. Section B: The experience of other countries (Asia, Argentina) indicates that, in times of crisis, agribusiness companies dependent on short-term debt are forced to restrict their operations. In the case of Amaggi, advances to farmers would most likely be curtailed, with consequences on farmers ability to purchase inputs and reach current production levels. Also, the company would be hard pressed to purchase and store soybeans from the farmers, thus limiting its processing season. More soybeans would be directed to exports rather than storage, which would result in lowered prices at harvest time because of bottlenecks in logistics. A more stable source of funding for working capital will therefore provide partial insurance against the refinancing risk, with widespread benefits to farmers and the companys operation.Section C: Supervision of the development impact will focus on the companys ability to sustain the pre-and post-harvest financing of the soybean supply chain: (i) advances to farmers; (ii) purchases of soybeans; and (iii) crushing of soybeans.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe Environmental documents will be located in the following locally affected communities:  Itacoatiara, Porto Velho, Rondonopolis, Sapezal.
Sponsor: Amaggi (the company) is 100% owned by the André Maggi family and is one of the three other main operating companies belonging to the family. The other two are Hermasa Navegaçao da Amazonia (Hermasa), the transport arm, and Agropecuaria Maggi Limitada (Agropecuaria), the familys own farm and also a supplier of soybeans to Amaggi.  The establishment of Hermasa was a response for overcoming the poor infrastructure that prevented in the past, the flourishing of soybeans in Mato Grosso. Today, Hermasa, with its barge terminal at Porto Velho in the state of Rondonia and its deepwater port in the Amazon river system at Itacoatiaria, in the state of Amazonas, is a highly efficient export channel for Amaggi soybeans.  In June 1991, the Maggi family decided to bring the activities of the three operating companies under one umbrella and created a holding, Grupo André Maggi Participaçoes Limitada (GAM or the group).  The Chairman of the group and the company is Mr. Blairo Maggi, the son of  the founder of Amaggi and the person who conceived the highly successful infrastructure initiative which has given Amaggi an edge over competition.  The management of both the GAM and Amaggi is mainly professional, with Mr. Pedro Jacyr Bongiolo as the Chief Executive Officer who has been with the company for 23 years and has extensive knowledge of the soybean industry.
Cost Nature: This is a US$30 million financing for working capital purposes.  IFC proposes to finance a portion of the permanent working capital of the company with a loan of up to US$30 milion.
Investment: 30.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan30.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The company is located in the state of Mato Grosso, Brazil''s Center West.  It originates its soybeans mostly from 3rd party farmers located in this state with some origination coming from its affiliate, Agropecuaria Maggi, also located in Mato Grosso, in the town of Sapezal.  Transport services and shipment of soybeans and fertilizers is undertaken by Hermasa, the transport arm of the group, with a barge terminal located in Porto Velho, in the state of Rondonia, and a port facility located in Itacoatiara, in the state of Amazonas.  Amaggi has also two crushing plants, one located in Cuiaba, state of Mato Grosso, and the other in Itacoatiara, in the state of Amazonas.

Project Description: The proposed project comprises the operation and expansion of SIA under a 30-year BOT concession granted by the government of Jamaica (GOJ) to the project company, MBJ Airports Limited (MBJA), a special purpose company to be formed by the sponsors.  The proposed project includes the expansion and improvement of the existing terminal and the construction of a new concourse to handle approximately 5 million passengers annually.  Construction will include the supply/installation of all equipment normally associated with a modern terminal building.  Equipment to be supplied will be of proven technology.  Revenue will accrue from all normal airport sources, both aeronautical and non-aeronautical.  A new Airport Improvement Fee, per departing international passenger, will be put in place to pay for part of the capital expenditures.  SIA is of significant importance as an integral part of Jamaica''s tourism infrastructure.  Therefore, expansion and modernization of the SIA facility have been recognized as a high priority by the GOJ to cater for the increasing levels of passenger throughput.  In this context, the proposed project will relieve the current capacity constraints at SIA and improve its operating efficiency using international best practices in the airport and construction industries.  This would significantly benefit the tourism industry and help the country to further develop this important sector of the economy.  YVRAS will provide Technical Services on airport operations transfering their know-how to Jamaica, resulting in upgrading of skills of the local workforce. The shareholders will also provide their experience and skills in management and financing. Furthermore, the success of this high profile project will also encourage foreign investments and further private sector participation in other airports and other sectors such as roads and ports.IFC''s investment in the proposed project will provide long-term financing necessary for a concession-based project at a reasonable cost.  Long-term financing is practically non-existent in Jamaica from either domestic or foreign sources.  IFC''s involvement in the project will act in as a catalyst for additional financing through the B loan syndication.  IFC also participated in the negotiations of the concession.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  Environmental and social issues associated with this project include: - Subsurface contamination; - Stormwater drainage, including impacts on marine ecosystems; - Solid waste management; - Liquid effluents and sewage discharge; - Fuel/Hazardous materials storage and handling, including emergency response; - Bird hazards to aircraft; - Aircraft noise; - Employee health and safety; - Environmental, health and safety management systems; and - Employment and community relations.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityAdministration Office of the Airports Authority of Jamaica at Sangster International Airport and Post Office in Montego Bay.
Sponsor: The proposed shareholding structure of project company is as follows: Agencias Universales S.A. (AGUNSA)35.0% Dragados Concesiones de Infraestructuras,  S.A. (Dragados Concesiones)35.0% YVR Airport Services Limited (YVRAS)15.0% Ashtrom Group Limited (Ashtrom)15.0% Total100.0%AGUNSA is a leading Chilean company in ship agency and integral cargo services.  Its businesses include: (i) tug services in Chile, Peru, Argentina and Ecuador; (ii) logistics and cargo distribution (including stevedoring) and operating one of the most important warehouses and distribution centers in Santiago; (iii) bunkering business in Chile and Argentina; and (iv) acting as general sales agent for United Airlines, Taca Group, and Varig in several cities of Chile and Peru.  In addition, AGUNSA is a controlling partner of SCL Terminal Aéreo Santiago S.A., current concessionaire for a l5-year period of Arturo Merino Benítez International Airport in Santiago. Dragados Concesiones is a subsidiary of Grupo Dragados S.A. (Dragados). Dragados, established in 1941, is a diversified Spanish construction, engineering and services conglomerate.  It builds and manages large-scale projects such as civil engineering projects (roads, dams,  irrigations, ports, etc.), buildings (both residential and non-residential), industrial projects, oil pipelines and power facilities. It provides port and harbor services and logistics, management and operation of transport infrastructure concessions,  and it manages renewable energy and waste collection and treatment facilities.  Dragados is part of 35 infrastructure concessions in 12 countries, and many others in urban services area.  Infrastructure concession projects include airport terminals, car parks, toll (including shadow toll) roads and railways. Currently, Dragados has concessions of 15 airports in 3 countries, with some of 32 million passangers, aproximatelly 900,000 tons of cargo and around 700,000 aircraft movements.YVRAS, established in 1994, manages airports and provides specialized consulting services to clients worldwide. YVRAS is a majority-owned (90%) subsidiary of the Vancouver International Airport Authority, which operates Vancouver International Airport - Canada''s second busiest airport (after Toronto) and a major West Coast gateway, with some 16 million passengers, approximately 252,000 tons of cargo and 295,000 take-offs and landings in 2000.  A minority position in YVRAS is held by UK''s CDC Capital Partners.  YVRAS currently manages/provides consulting services to 13 airports in 4 countries.  YVRAS will provide technical assistance to the project company.Ashtrom is Israel''s leading private development and manufacturing concern.  The company is involved in a wide range of construction and related activities locally and abroad, including residential, commercial, industrial, and institutional projects.  Ashtrom is also one of the leading construction companies in Jamaica, involved in complex civil engineering works including road bridges, major residential and commercial projects, office buildings and hotels since 1970.  Ashtrom also provides residential and commercial construction in the US, Poland, Bulgaria, Romania and Nigeria.  Ashtrom will be the EPC contractor for the proposed project.
Cost Nature: The venture is a 2-phase project whose total cost amounts to US$135 million. IFC is only financing the first phase of the project which amounts to US$80 million.   IFC proposed investment is a US$20 million A loan for IFC''s own account and a US$25 million B loan for the account of participants.

The aerodrome reference point is located at N18 30 13.2085 W 077 55 27.33520 (WGS84 Format) at an altitude of 4 feet above sea level.  Located on approximately 231.6 hectares of land, SIA is the gateway to the island''s major resort facilities in Montego Bay, Negril and Ocho Rios.  SIA is the third largest airport in the Caribbean, after Puerto Rico and Cancun.  The airport served more than 3 million passengers in 2001.

Project Description: Omimex, an independent energy company engaged in the exploration and production of crude oil and natural gas, has requested financing from IFC to fund the further development of its various Colombian heavy oil fields as well as the expansion of the companys 100%-owned Colombian pipeline.  Having been in the country since 1994, Omimex has gained significant experience in the Middle Magdalena Basin, an increasingly active area for oil development located 125 miles northwest of Bogota.  The company currently produces from three existing fields (Velasquez, Teca, Nare) in the basin, but plans to increase production through a multi-year, staged development program.IFC''s proposed loan will help finance a project which has four key development impacts.  First, the project represents a significant investment in a poor and underdeveloped region of the country.  Construction and operation will create many primary and secondary local employment opportunities in the area.  Second, further investment in the companys oil fields will allow them to be exploited to their full potential and help boost the countrys declining production.  Third, the project will supply oil to a local refinery which will, in turn, free up higher-quality crude for export.  Fourth, the project will provide a valuable source of revenue to Colombia through royalties and taxes.IFC has several important roles to play in this project.  First, the weak Colombian economy and negative perceptions of physical security have made it difficult for companies to secure long-term financing at reasonable costs from commercial sources.  IFC will therefore play an essential role by providing economic funding with reasonable maturities.  Second, IFC involvement will support the governments attempts to promote and attract new private sector investment in the oil and gas sector.  Third, IFC will contribute to the projects sustainability by working closely with the company to build and enhance its institutional capacity regarding project and financial management as well as developing an Environmental and Social Management System at the corporate level that can be applied to all future projects.

Mr. Vashisht has thirty-five years of oil field experience in the United States, the Middle East, India and South America.  Omimex is a US-registered company.

Project Description: Generadora de Occidente Ltda. of Guatemala was formed in 1999 to undertake the project and is 100% owned by EGI, through subsidiary companies.  The purpose of the venture is to expand Guatemala''s base of hydroelectricity and support Guatemala''s merchant power industry. Developmental impacts are expected to include: (i) support of an innovative financing structure that will reinforce a competitive market and attract long-term investment; (ii) improvement in sector efficiency through enhanced price stability; and (iii) demonstration, both nationally and regionally, that renewable energy can attract competitive financing.   IFC''s role in the project is the support of Guatemala''s power sector reform and the investment of long-term debt in an innovative power project.

Sponsor: The sponsor is Energía Global International, Ltd. of Bermuda (EGI), a renewable power development company.  EGI is indirectly owned by Enel Green Power S.p.A. of Italy, a wholly owned subsidiary of Enel S.p.A. of Italy.  The project company is Generadora de Occidente Ltda. of Guatemala, which is indirectly owned by EGI.
Cost Nature: The construction of El Canadá, a 43 MW hydroelectric station in Guatemala (the project), is estimated to cost US$57.1 million.  The financial plan consists of US$37 million in debt and US$20.1 million in shareholder equity.  IFC is considering a US$15 million loan for its own account. The balance of the debt will be provided through an IFC B loan or parallel loan.
Investment: 15.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan15.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The project is located 12 km south of Quetzaltenango Municipality and approximately 200 km west of Guatemala City.  El Canadá will be constructed immediately down-stream of the existing Santa María hydroelectric plant on the Samalá River.   Diverted tailrace from the Santa María station will flow through a 1.2 km tunnel to a 184,000 m3 five-hour peaking reservoir.  Water stored in the reservoir will flow to a powerhouse situated on the Samalá River.  The 43 MW of gross capacity will be produced by two Pelton turbines.

Company Name: Asian Strategic Investments Corp. Beijing Representative Office
Project Description: The Group operates as an integrated entity supplying a wide range of automotive components (including foundry products, brake systems, diesel fuel injection systems, electrical products, and engine parts and accessories) to the Chinese and the international markets.    In 2001, it had revenues of about US$160 million, EBITDA of US$25 million, and a net income of US$1.8 million.  Total assets at the end of 2001 were US$400 million and shareholder funds were US$235 million (including equity and interest free shareholder loans). 	The project is to establish a new company (Newco) which will acquire the Funds'' ownership of the Group, thereby converting the Group ownership to a corporate structure.  The current fund ownership structure restricts the Group from upgrading existing operations, taking advantage of many new investment opportunities, and financing itself in an optimal manner.  Through this ownership restructuring the Group will be able to effectively increase its value added, by allowing it to develop its franchise as a reliable and comprehensive supplier of quality auto components, and to leverage its management and manufacturing infrastructure.  The acquisition of the Funds'' ownership of the Group will be effected by the Limited Partners converting about 30% of their ownership interest into shares in Newco, and Newco purchasing the remaining 70%.  The management of ASIMCO will become the management of Newco, and the ASIMCO staff that currently manage the operating units will be retained to manage the operations.  DEVELOPMENT IMPACTThe proposed project is expected to contribute to the transformation and rationalization of the industry, which has traditionally been dominated by inefficient state-owned enterprises. This is all the more important as China''s entry into the WTO is likely to have a significant impact on the automotive component industry in China, both in terms of challenges and opportunities. Through the project, IFC will support a group of restructured SOEs, who can become successful examples of China''s restructuring and privatization process.The Group has been a pioneer in introducing modern management techniques, while relying on local managerial talent for plant operations. This has resulted in significant welfare benefits for local staff and the strengthening of local managerial skills and capacity. The Group was named one of the "Ten Best Employers in China" as part of the "Best Employers in Asia" study conducted by the Asian Wall Street Journal, The Far East Economic Review and Hewitt Associates. The Group possesses the management ability to provide leadership in the Chinese automotive components sector with regard to EHSS performance - and can drive these issues down to the next level of the supply chain pyramid, thus enhancing the development impact of the project.IFC ROLEIFC''s assistance is targeted at supporting privatization and restructuring of the automotive component industry to better prepare it to meet the challenges of a more competitive market environment following WTO entry.  In the absence of IFC support, the restructuring of the Group is unlikely to move ahead, as the current diffused ownership structure and the diverse interests and objectives of the many parties involved make it difficult to agree and implement an appropriate strategy. Moreover, IFC''s presence in the transaction is likely to be a source of comfort for co-investors which include development agencies and private investors.By assisting the Group in formalizing a performance based environmental management system, IFC is likely to play a vital role in improving its operating efficiency and in enhancing their ability to attract "global customers" that typically have environmental performance requirements for their suppliers. IFC will also continue to assist the Group with the identification of potential environmental technology products, for which there is strong demand in China. Finally, IFC will assist Newco in adopting best corporate governance policies and practices.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe environmental documents will be available at the Group''s headquarters at 4th Floor, Parkview Centre , 2 Jiangtai Road , South Side Chaoyang District, Beijing
Sponsor: Asian Strategic Investments Corporation (ASIMCO or the manager) is a Cayman Islands investment management company, headquartered in Beijing, that directly manages and operates an automotive components group (the Group) on behalf of two Limited Partnerships (the Funds).  The Funds are incorporated in the Cayman Islands and have 71 and 72 investors respectively, including US pension funds, insurance companies, endowment funds, international government investment agencies, and high net worth individual investors.   The funds have majority ownership/control of the Group companies which include ten automotive manufacturing companies in China, one USA trading company and the operating assets of the Manager/ASIMCO.  ASIMCO is owned (i) 34.5% by TCW/CIC; (ii) 34.5% by PRC Cayman Holding Ltd., a company incorporated in the Cayman Islands and owned by General Electric Investment Corporation; and (iii) 31.0% in the aggregate by certain key members of ASIMCO''s management which includes:    Mr. Perkowski (CEO/Chairman/Founder) joined Paine Webber in 1973. He was the director of investment banking when he left in 1988 to become the managing director of a leveraged buy-out firm.  In 1990, Mr. Perkowski began to research the concept of investing in Asia, leading to the formation of ASIMCO.  He developed the Funds'' investment strategy and is responsible for ASIMCO taking an active role in management of the Group companies.  Michael A. Cronin (EVP/CFO) worked in the Audit and Accounting division of Arthur Andersen specializing in manufacturing clients.  He gained extensive financial due diligence experience in connection with acquisitions as an audit manager.  For the five years prior to joining ASIMCO in 1994, Mr. Cronin worked for 3i plc, Europe''s leading direct investment company, where he was responsible for making and monitoring a wide variety of direct investments. At each of the operating units, ASIMCO has put in place a core management team, comprising a general manager, a CFO and 1 to 4 deputy general managers.  These managers are almost all Chinese, with a strong background in the automotive/manufacturing sector obtained through their previous employment with international companies like General Motors, Caterpillar, Daimler Chrysler, Delphi, etc.
Cost Nature: The project cost is estimated at US$70 million. The proposed IFC investment is US$15 million to be structured as approximately 10% in terms of value in common shares, and the balance as a dollar denominated shareholder loan that would carry a coupon of about 5% and be repaid in 9 equal, semi-annual amounts starting in year 2008.
Investment: 15.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan5.0Equity10.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The 10 operating companies are located in 8 provinces across China, including Beijing, Guangdong, Hebei, Anhui, Hunan, Hubei, Shanxi and Jiangsu.  Each of these sites is well connected by road to the company''s customers.  The US based trading unit of the Group has an office in Beijing, and a sales/technical support office in the US located in Twinsburgh, Ohio.

Project Description: GIT has two business lines, GIT Technology, which provides systems integration services and value added solutions, and GIT Software, which produces proprietary software for customers in the banking and insurance industries.  GIT was founded in July 1997 by Mr. Yu.  GIT is seeking to raise up to US$14 million to finance i) the expansion and development of GITs software product offerings, ii) select acquisitions, iii) construct a software development center and iv) working capital for market expansion of its hardware and software businesses (the project).  The project would have significant development impact by supporting a group of local entrepreneurs who have built a successful IT services firm through organic growth and who are now attempting to take the company to the next level by bringing in institutional investors to supply growth capital, market credibility, and better corporate governance.  In addition, as GIT grows, it will continue to train skilled technology workers in China and expose them to international best practices.  IFC is expected to play a significant role in structuring the deal so as to enable international investors to invest in a medium sized Chinese technology company.  The GIT management team is focused on an eventual international listing for the company''s shares given the greater transparency, liquidity and credibility that an international listing affords.  In addition to developing the investment structure, IFC''s presence will provide comfort to foreign investors in this newly evolving sector in China.  Investors are wary not only of country risk but also of intellectual property rights in China.  Despite the exceptional promise of the company, GIT has found it difficult to raise such a large round of capital in the current investment environment.  An IFC decision to invest in the company would help GIT mobilize the addition funds needed to complete the financing plan.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category C project, according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because it is likely to have minimal or no adverse environmental impacts.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: Mr. Yu Wei, Chairman and CEO, is the founder and majority owner of the Great Infotech Group (GIT or the company). He  controls GIT through a holding company: Shenzhen GIT Investment Co. Ltd.  Mr. Yu has over 12 years of IT sector experience in China.  He previously spent five years as General Manager for ASCII Software (China) Co. Ltd., the first Sino-foreign software company in the Peoples Republic of China (China or PRC).  ASCII, established in the 1970s, was later acquired by Seacom, a Tokyo stock exchange listed systems intergration company with revenues of over US$1 billion.  Mr. Yu leads the GIT senior management team, most of whom have been with him since his time at ASCII.  Mr. Yu graduated from the International Relations University in China.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at US$14 million.  The proposed IFC investment is a US$5 million equity investment for IFC''s own account.  The balance is expected to be provided by Hong Kong based private equity firms.

Project Name: Central Asia Micro and Small Business Capacity Building Facility
Project Description: The project is to establish a financial facility for (i) Kazakhstan; (ii) The Kyrgyz Republic; (iii) Uzbekistan; and later (iv) Tajikistan.  The facility will comprise individual credit lines to selected partner banks (PBs) which will then be on-lent to micro and small enterprises (SMEs) through specialized micro and small business finance windows that will be created at the PB level for this purpose.The objective of the facility is to expand the frontier of finance by extending downward the range of market segments served by commercial financial institutions.  Thus, the facility will increase the availability of sustained credit to creditworthy SMEs, while at the same time building up the lending capacity and skill base of selected PBs.  To help achieve this objective, the project will be supported by a donor-funded Technical Assistance (TA) program.  The main objectives of this program are to (i) create and strengthen the SME departments at PBs; (ii) train all levels of SME lending personnel; (iii) develop new loan products; (iv) develop internal audit and management information systems; and (v) establish and evaluate SME departments as profit centers.This project capitalizes on the experience of a similar and successful EBRD program in Kazakhstan.  This existing program has shown strong financial and developmental results -- US$72.5 million has been disbursed under the program and the portfolio at risk is only 0.58%.  The new program will both increase the activity in Kazakhstan, and introduce it to additional Central Asian countries.The proposed facility will have a strong development impact, as it will introduce a micro and small business finance program to a wider market in Central Asia, building from the experience of an existing successful EBRD program in Kazakhstan.  It aims to improve the standard of living of the poorest segments of the populations in the countries to be covered by the facility  some of which are among the poorest in the world.  Micro finance is a key sector where IFC can focus its efforts to support economic development.  The proposed project is part of a concerted WBG effort to develop partnerships with international micro finance support organizations and technical partners that stand as leaders in the field.The facility will assist in the development of the emerging micro and small business sector in Central Asia by augmenting financing to existing SMEs.  It will also have a strong institution-building role.  By providing selected PBs with training and technical assistance, the project will seek to address the shortage of banking skills that are necessary to establish a market-based banking environment, especially with respect to SMEs.  It will also fuel the expansion of SME operations into previously under-served regions of Central Asia.  An additional key objective of the facility is to generate a significant international demonstration effect, which can catalyze replication of model micro finance programs in developing countries, and in Central Asia in particular.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Financial Intermediary (FI) Type 1 project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  The facility will be required to ensure that each Partner Bank (PB) develops and implements an Environmental Management System (EMS) to screen loan applications for compliance with host country environment, health and safety requirements and consistency with IFCs Microfinance Exclusion List.  Each PB must identify two individuals to have responsibility for environmental matters and provide the appropriate training.  Each PB will be required to provide an Annual Report on its EMS.  Funding for environmental capacity building should be an integral part of the TA effort.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The Central Asia Micro and Small Enterprise facility (the facility) will be established together with the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) and the Swiss State Secretariat for Economic Affairs (SECO).  IFC, EBRD, and SECO are the sponsors of this project.
Cost Nature: The total resources of the facility are up to US$118 million.  IFC''s portion of the investment is for up to US$45 million, representing approximately 38% of the total financing.  EBRD and SECO will co-finance the facility for a combined amount of up to US$73 million (EBRD-US$70 million and SECO-US$3 million).
Investment: 45.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan45.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The facility will cover the following countries: Kazakhstan; The Kyrgyz Republic; Uzbekistan; and Tajikistan.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Financial Intermediary (FI) Type 1 project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  The facility will be required to ensure that each Partner Bank (PB) develops and implements an Environmental Management System (EMS) to screen loan applications for compliance with host country environment, health and safety requirements and consistency with IFCs Microfinance Exclusion List.  Each PB must identify two individuals to have responsibility for environmental matters and provide the appropriate training.  Each PB will be required to provide an Annual Report on its EMS.  Funding for environmental capacity building should be an integral part of the TA effort.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
