Project Description:
In April 1998 through an international bid, the Instituto de Acueductos y Alcantarillados Nacionales (IDAAN), the national water company of Panama, awarded the lake Gatun potable water supply concession to APSA., a special purpose company created by British water company Biwater Supply Limited.  Under the concession contract, APSA will abstract water from Lake Gatun, treat it and deliver an agreed daily volume of potable water (varying between 15 and 20 million gallons per day MGD) into the existing distribution system at Nuevo Chorrillo.  The delivery point is located on the west bank of the Panama Canal approximately 20 kilometers from Panama City.  The construction of the water treatment plant was completed in June 2002 and a partial acceptance certificate was issued by IDAAN at that time.  The plant was fully completed in September 2002, with a total project cost of $25 million.  

The contract, which provides APSA with a 30 year concession period, specifies that the company will deliver to IDAAN a minimum daily bulk volume of potable water into Nuevo Chorrillo, which serves the west bank of the Panama Canal including the urban areas of Arraijan, Chorrera and Capira.  In consideration of its service, APSA will receive a monthly payment calculated on the basis of the agreed volumes of water delivered and a base unit price of $0.8942/1000 US gallons, adjustable at regular intervals by an agreed price escalation factor.  The towns of Arraijan, Chorrera and Capira served by the Nuevo Chorrillo water supply system are facing an acute water shortage due to the inability of the offtaker IDAAN to produce sufficient water to supply the population in these areas, which totals 270,000 people.  The APSA project will provide potable water into the distribution system increasing supply to these areas, which at present have no viable alternative. Thus the project will have a high development impact by improving the living conditions of the population in these towns.

IFC financing package to APSA will enable the company to retire bridge shareholder debt from Biwater Supply Limited initially used to finance this project.  IFC will provide long-term funding, otherwise unavailable to the project company, which would support private sector participation in Panama's water and sanitation sector.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a Category B project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure. Environmental, safety and health and social impacts of the project include potable water quality and sustainability of raw water resources; water treatment sludge management; effect of past construction impacts (erosion and sediment control) of potable water plant construction; evaluation of site selection, land acquisition, R-O-W access, and related compensation of affected people; fuels/hazardous materials storage and handling; emergency response planning and preparedness; and employee health and safety (including training). Company Name: SHANGHAI INTERNATIONAL BANKING AND FINANCE INSTITUTE
Project Description: SIBFI will be set up as a joint venture international banking and finance institute in Shanghai to provide world-class training to Chinese financial institutions, primarily commercial banks.  The objective of establishing SIBFI is to help meet the strong and rapidly growing needs in China for acquiring international best practices in banking and finance.  This investment will demonstrate IFCs continued support of the development of Chinas banking industry.  To date the Corporation has invested in two Chinese banks, with two more investments near completion.  In addition, IFC has been providing a variety of technical assistance (TA) and training activities to selected Chinese banks.  The proposed project will institutionalize banking training on a sustainable and commercially viable basis.  The establishment of SIBFI is very timely, as Chinas WTO membership and the expected increase in banking competition have brought about a surge in the demand for training among Chinese banks.  There are currently various training activities and initiatives taking place in China, but SIBFI will be the most reputable and professional international training institution.  Therefore, this project is expected to have a very strong demonstration and developmental impact.IFC is playing a critical role in this project.  It was IFC which brought together two separate initiatives undertaken by Bankakademie on the one hand, and PCBS and SUFE on the other, and combined the two initiatives to work towards a common goal.  Through our experience in investing in and providing TA to Chinese banks, IFC has established a good reputation and expertise which are viewed as very important by all other partners of this project.  IFC will not only play an important role in setting up SIBFI, but will also play an active role in the strategic development of SIBFI through our director on the board of SIBFI.  The establishment of SIBFI will also leverage and enhance the ongoing TA and training activities of IFC and the World Bank in China.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category C project under IFC''s environmental and social review procedure. Thus, no further environmental or social review is required and the project is cleared by CESPS for Board review.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The main sponsor of the project is Bankakademie, which will take a 40% equity stake in Shanghai International Banking & Finance Institute (SIBFI), and will play the key role in setting up and managing SIBFI.  Other partners will also play important and complementary roles. One of the most successful bank training institutes in the world, Bankakademie was incorporated in 1957 in Frankfurt, Germany, as a nonprofit association, and has been supported and managed by German banking associations since 1966.  Its strong interest in this project is based on its belief that the current stage of development of the Chinese banking industry offers an enormous market, as well as an excellent opportunity, for banking training services.Other partners of the project include the Shanghai University of Finance and Economics (SUFE), and the Pacific Coast Banking School (PCBS) of the US.  SUFE was established in 1917 and is a reputable multi-disciplinary institution of higher learning under the leadership of Chinese Ministry of Education.  It is among the first group of Chinese higher education institutions authorized to award masters and doctoral degrees in economics and management science and MBA degrees.  SUFE has about ten schools and six departments, a staff of 1,180, and 17,000 students.  It has already established various programs of cooperation with reputable universities in different countries and international organizations, including the World Bank Institute and IMF.  PCBS was founded in 1938 as a nonprofit organization.  It is located in Seattle and has operated in cooperation with the University of Washington Graduate School of Business.  PCBS offers a three-year program to primarily US bankers, and a 2-3 week program to commercial bankers from the Pacific Rim countries.Based on preliminary discussions among the partners, it is envisaged that SIBFIs shareholding structure will be as follows:- 40% Bankakademie- 25% SUFE- 20% IFC- 10% PCBS- 5% a private company in Hong Kong.The proposed structure is still on a preliminary basis and may be slightly changed as the project moves forward.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $2.1 million, and the proposed IFC equity investment is up to $425,000.
Investment: 0.34 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuarantee0.26LoanEquity0.08* These investment figures are indicative
Location: SIBFI will be located in Shanghai, China, and the training courses will take place in existing building facilities of SUFE.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category C project under IFC''s environmental and social review procedure. Thus, no further environmental or social review is required and the project is cleared by CESPS for Board review.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community

Project Description:
The fund's objective is to create value for investors by identifying, investing in and supporting medium-sized private companies located primarily in the St Petersburg and Nizhny Novgorod regions.  

Developmental Impact
It is expected that the fund will generally provide capital to established and profitable companies in order to expand capacity and develop as a potential market leader.  Aside from providing scarce equity capital, QCR will add value to the investees by helping the companies to professionalize their corporate structures, implement appropriate management and financial accounting systems, and also create strategic linkages with Western European and other Russian companies.

IFC Role:
IFC has three important roles to play in the fund:

As an anchor investor, IFC will play a catalytic role in attracting other investors to the fund.  Institutional investors are typically wary of investments outside the Moscow area, particularly for smaller and medium sized local companies.  QCR believes that IFC's participation as an anchor investor and as a member of the Advisory Board and observer on the Investment Committee would be crucial in order to encourage commercial investors to broaden their investment horizons into Russia's regions.

IFC's involvement in reviewing transaction opportunities from an early stage will be crucial in assessing the availability of loan finance for potential investees.  In this capacity, IFC will play a key role in mobilizing longer-term loan finance for mid-sector Russian companies, which is scarce in Russia, particularly for companies outside the Moscow region.

IFC's work on corporate governance issues in Russia has provided the corporation with specific insights into some of the more widespread governance problems in Russia.  As improving the governance standards of investee companies will be one of the Fund's objectives, the fund manager will be able to draw on IFC's expertise through interaction with IFC on the Advisory Board and at the Investment Committee.
Environmental Social Issues: Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: The Private Equity/Venture Cap Fund (the fund) will be managed by Quadriga Capital Russia (QCR), a subsidiary of Quadriga Capital, a Frankfurt-based private equity fund manager.  In 1995, QCR secured the mandate to manage, in 1998, the St Petersburg Regional Venture Fund and the Central Russia Regional Venture Fund under the EBRD Regional Venture Fund program.  QCR maintains offices in St Petersburg and Nizhny Novgorod and plans to open an office in Moscow.
Cost Nature: The target size of the fund will be $140 million, however a first closing may be established with $70 million in commitments.  It is proposed that IFC invest the lesser of $20 million and 25% of total commitments.
Investment: 20.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity20.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The fund will be established as a limited partnership domiciled in a suitable jurisdiction and will invest in companies located principally in Russia.  The fund manager will manage the investments from its offices in St. Petersburg, Nizhny Novgorod and Moscow.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sector: BA - Private Equity/Venture Cap Fund - Country

Project Description: Hana Bank and Seoul Bank provide a full range of banking services and products for both individuals and corporations such as retail banking, commercial banking, corporate finance, credit card services and asset management. The project will enhance the scale and scope of Hana Bank''s operations while at the same time assisting the Republic of Korea in meeting its desired goals in privatization as well as achieving consolidation in the banking industry. The merger between Seoul Bank and Hana Bank is expected to be completed by December 1, 2002, and KDIC has committed to sell to Hana Bank 60% of its Hana Bank holdings , or 36,600,000 shares, within twelve months, with the remaining 40% to be sold within 18 months.IFC has been by Hana Bank to participate in the merger and privatization of Seoul Bank, which is 100% government owned by the Korea Deposit Insurance Corporation. In addition to enhancing the scale and scope of Hana Bank''s operations which will lead to a strengthened financial position, this privatization will also assist the government of South Korea in meeting its stated goals of privatizing, consolidating and reforming the financial sector. These goals are entirely consistent with those of the IMF and the World Bank as this project seeks to privatize one of the largest Korean banks, thus marking an important milestone of the restructuring process in Korea.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a  Financial Intermediary Type1 project.  The bank will be required to develop an environmental management system to require that investments conducted under relevant operations (e.g., project finance, corporate finance) meet host country environmental, health and safety requirements.  IFC will work with the bank to develop an environmental review capacity.  Depending upon IFC''s assessment, environmental training will be required.  The bank will be required to provide an annual environmental performance report to IFC.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The project sponsor, Hana Bank, has agreed to merge with another local bank, Seoul Bank, which is 100% government owned (Korea Deposit Insurance Corporation, or KDIC).  Hana Bank, originally Korea Investment Finance Corporation (KIFC), changed to its current name when it was transformed into a commercial bank in 1991. KIFC was incorporated in May 1971 with IFC assistance, and was the first short-term finance company to be established in Korea. Hana Bank''s major shareholders include Allianz AG with 11.8%, Kolon (Korea) with 5.5%, and Dongwon (Korea) with 4.8% and IFC with 4%. Upon merging with Seoul Bank, the new entity will be 30.9% owned by KDIC, 8.1% by Allianz, 3.8% by Kolon, and 3.3% by Dongwon, and will be the third largest bank in Korea.
Cost Nature: The project calls for a proposed IFC equity investment of approximately $50 million to support the privatization of Seoul Bank and its merger with Hana Bank. Hana Bank has signed a definitive agreement with KDIC to pay a guaranteed price of 1.15 trillion Korean Won ($954 million) for Seoul Bank. After the all share deal is completed, KDIC will hold 61 million shares of Hana Bank, which equates to a 30.1% shareholding of the combined banks.
Investment: 50.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity50.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Hana operates a network of 301 branches in Korea, which are supervised from its head office in Seoul, Republic of Korea.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a  Financial Intermediary Type1 project.  The bank will be required to develop an environmental management system to require that investments conducted under relevant operations (e.g., project finance, corporate finance) meet host country environmental, health and safety requirements.  IFC will work with the bank to develop an environmental review capacity.  Depending upon IFC''s assessment, environmental training will be required.  The bank will be required to provide an annual environmental performance report to IFC.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community

Project Description: Prodem is a well managed fondo financiero privado (FFP), the legal vehicle under which microfinance entities are regulated as NBFIs in Bolivia.  Prodem is dedicated to micro-lending to small entrepreneurs and indigenous populations and has developed  rural finance activities as well.  The proposed project will allow Prodem to increase the outreach of its lending operations.  The developmental impact of Prodem is expected to be far reaching in terms of economic support for productive micro businesses, stimulus for growth and employment generation, and confidence building for the microfinance sector.  In addition, the bond issue would have a significant developmental impact in educating institutional investors as to the unique role of micro-financiers and on diversifying their holdings into this segment of the financial markets.
Environmental Social Issues: Prodem must require that investments under relevant operations meet host country environmental, health and safety requirements and be consistent with IFCs microfinance exclusion list.  Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor:
The key sponsor of Prodem Fondo Financiero Privado S.A. (Prodem) is Fundacion Prodem (80% shareholding), a non governmental organization.   The remaining 20% is held by about 12 individuals. 

Fundacion Prodem has been focusing primarily on facilitating micro-enterprises and underprivileged individuals to access loans, through viable and continuous lending operations in urban and rural areas of the country.
Cost Nature: IFC will be investing: $1.0 million as part of a $3.0 million denominated bond issue to be placed on the Bolivian capital markets; and $2.0 million credit line, for on-lending by Prodem.

Project Description:
, P.T. Astra International is one of the largest automotive business in Indonesia.  The company also has interests in financial services, agribusiness and heavy equipment.  The $150 million rights issue will complement Astra's recently scheduled comprehensive debt restructuring plan which will be approved on November 26, 2002. The plan aims to: establish an achievable debt amortization schedule, and an appropriate and sustainable capital structure; and  provide funding flexibility to support Astra's operations and business development.

Development Impact
Indonesia is lagging other Asian crisis countries in its corporate restructuring efforts. The project is part of the financial restructuring of one of the leading Indonesian private sector corporates and as such is expected to have a strong demonstration effect on the restructuring of the corporate sector in the country.  The venture will help Astra, which employs over 56,000 people, to be more competitive by enabling it to: strengthen its balance sheet; undertake needed investments in modernizing and expanding its automotive distribution/dealership business to further enhance customer service and productivity in a competitive and increasingly liberalized industry.  The proposed rights issue would be marketed extensively to institutional investors in the US and in Europe and would help to re-introduce Indonesia and Astra to these markets.

IFC Role
because of its strong, long-standing relationship with Astra and its reputation as an independent investor, IFC has been invited by C&C/Jardines to be a stand-by investor for unsubscribed rights. IFC involvement should help ensure success of the rights issue in the current uncertain economic and political climate and send a strong signal to the investment community that IFC is supportive of first-class companies in Indonesia with good corporate governance and environmental performance.  This is the first non-distressed rights issue in Indonesia since the Asian crisis and its success would provide a much-needed vote of confidence in Indonesia's manufacturing sector.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category C project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  Astra International has developed and implemented a comprehensive Environmental Management System to provide assurance that environmental and social issues are handled appropriately across its range of operations.  IFC will continue with its annual environmental and social supervision of Astra.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor:
The project sponsor is P.T. Astra International Tbk. (Astra or the company).  Astra was established in 1957 as an agricultural trading company and subsequently diversified into manufacturing and distribution of automobiles, heavy equipment, and related components.  Today, Astra is a vertically integrated automotive business with operations ranging from the manufacture of components, passenger cars, light trucks, motorcycles, to automotive distribution and after-sales services, car rentals, and consumer finance and insurance for automotives.  The company, through its subsidiaries and affiliates, has interests also in agribusiness, heavy equipment and infrastructure. Astra is one of the few professionally, non-owner managed companies in Indonesia, and prides itself on its good corporate governance and transparency.
 
Astra has been listed on the Jakarta and Surabaya Stock Exchanges since 1990. The company has a diversified shareholder base of above 4,000 shareholders.  Cycle & Carriage (C&C) is the largest with 31.2% stake, followed by Toyota Motor Corporation with 7.4% stake.  IFC's shareholding in Astra is 2.3%.

C&C is a listed Singaporean company whose core businesses are motor vehicle distribution and retail, and property investment and development. It is controlled by Jardine Matheson Holdings Ltd (Jardines), a Hong Kong listed company.  Jardines is a large conglomerate with operations in distribution, sales and service of motor vehicles and related activities (including financing, insurance and contract hire), shipping and logistics, engineering and construction, retail, insurance services, real estate, and hotel investment and management.
Cost Nature:
The project cost is estimated at about $150 million. Approximately $60 million of the net proceeds will be used to repay part of the company's debt and approximately $90 million of the net proceeds will be used for working capital financing and for capital expenditures.

IFC's proposed investment comprises: an equity investment of about $3.5 million equivalent for IFC's proportionate (2.3%) rights; and a stand-by equity investment for up to $16.5 million of un-subscribed rights.
Investment: 20.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity20.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The project is located in Jakarta, Indonesia.

Astra International has developed and implemented a comprehensive Environmental Management System to provide assurance that environmental and social issues are handled appropriately across its range of operations.  IFC will continue with its annual environmental and social supervision of Astra.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Name: Banca pentru Mica Industrie si Libera Initiativa:  Mindbank, S.A.
Project Description: Mindbank was incorporated in Romania in 1990 as the "Bank for Small Industry and Free Enterprise".  Mindbank is licensed by the National Bank of Romania to conduct all commercial banking activities and is principally engaged in carrying out banking services for small enterprises.  The purpose of the credit line would be to extend the tenor of small business loans and, with the support of external technical assistance, develop a project finance capability geared to small enterprises, local cooperatives and microentrepreneurs.  IFC's convertible credit line will facilitate the entry of a strategic technical partner, which is expected to lead to an improvement in Mindbank's lending technology and enhance its long term perspective as a sustainable niche player in the Romanian banking sector.
Environmental Social Issues: Mindbank will be required to develop and implement procedures to screen loan applications for compliance with host country environment, health and safety requirements and consistency with IFC''s Microfinance Exclusion List. Mindbank''s environment staff will need to attend the IFC environmental training course for financial institutions. Mindbank will also be required to submit annual environmental reports to IFC.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Mindbank's three largest shareholders as of December 31, 2001 were: 
UCECOM, the Romanian National Association of Handicraft and Production Cooperatives (24%); 
Mr. A.H. Bahman, a Kuwaiti citizen with strategic investments in 30 companies internationally (15.4%); and 
MISR Romanian Bank with a (9%).  

MISR Romanian Bank is a joint-venture institution between Egypt's Banque MISR and Romania's Banca Comerciala Romana.
Cost Nature: The project involves an IFC investment of $5 million in the form of a convertible senior credit line for up to eight years.

Project Description: RAEF is in the process of establishing Ro-Fin Mortgage Loan Company (Ro-Fin, or the company), a green-field entity, as a specialized housing finance company to originate and service primary mortgages to Romanian households. Ro-Fin will be capitalized with equity and long-term debt at $36 million (ROL 1,200 billion equivalent) making it the first significant private mortgage company in Romania. The strong capitalization would enable the company to mobilize ample funds internally and externally at attractive rates and offer affordable residential mortgages in Romania. The proceeds from IFC's long-term loan will be on-lent as long-term residential mortgages and home refurbishing sub-loans that are very scarce products in the Romanian market. The company will be chaired by an experienced, senior mortgage banker.Development Impact:Mortgages are virtually nonexistent in Romania.  An important developmental impact of this project is to provide critically needed long-term funding to families that wish to own their home. The tenor of IFC's loan would enable Ro-Fin to provide long-term, and thus, more affordable mortgage credits. With the increased affordability, more individuals could access funding to purchase new or renovate existing homes, thus addressing the poor condition housing in Romania. Further, through extensive linkage effects, the housing industry will contribute to the development of SMEs that supply labor and materials for the construction and improvement of homes; a major contributor to economic growth in Romania. It is further envisaged that the project would have a powerful demonstration effect in stimulating other market players to augment their underwriting standards, laying the foundation for a sound and thriving secondary market for issuing mortgage-backed securities.IFC Role:IFC will play a major role in ensuring that the underlying mortgages are structured using best practice underwriting and mortgage servicing standards.  Documentation and mortgage requirements for sub-loans will be based on standardized underwriting criteria to facilitate securitization. The objective of this project will be to spur the growth of the primary residential mortgage market, with a view to developing the secondary market through securitization and the creation of an active refinancing entity. IFC will be tapping know-how from its Housing Finance Unit in the Global Financial Markets Group to provide value added, "informal technical assistance" to this project. The client is welcoming IFC's housing finance expertise in the framework of project structuring.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category C project, according to IFC''s Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because it is likely to have minimal or no adverse environmental impacts.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: The project sponsor is Romanian American Enterprise Fund (RAEF), a private US corporation whose mission is to promote free enterprise and entrepreneurship in Romania through investments in and loans to small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). Established by the President and the US Congress in 1994, RAEF is capitalized by a $61 million committed grant from the USAID. RAEF focuses on the banking, telecommunication and energy sectors of Romania. Since the start of its activities in 1995, RAEF has participated in more than $130 million in equity investments and has provided loans totaling more than $25 million to 1,650 enterprises in targeted sectors.The technical partner is Shorebank Advisory Services, Inc. (SAS), a wholly owned subsidiary of Shorebank Corporation, America's oldest and largest community development bank, recognized nationally and globally for its expertise in SME finance, emerging market investment tools, and mission-driven financial institutions. After the technical assistance phase of the project, SAS will turn Ro-Fin's operations completely to local managers trained in the techniques of mortgage underwriting and securitization by senior management.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is $36 million.  The proposed IFC investment is a $5 million long-term loan for IFC's own account and a $1 million equity subscription in the project company, for a total commitment to the project of $6 million.  A co-financing of $15 million is also being considered.
Investment: 6.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan5.0Equity1.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Ro-Fin is headquartered in Bucharest and it plans to open branches in other parts of Romania, as business develops. Investments can be made throughout the country.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category C project, according to IFC''s Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because it is likely to have minimal or no adverse environmental impacts.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Company Name: Banco Pyme Los Andes ProCredit S.A.
Project Description: Caja's core objective, once it becomes a fully licensed bank, is to promote efficient financial intermediation by facilitating the integration of economically underprivileged social sectors to the formal financial system of Bolivia.  The bank will achieve this goal through enhanced funding and a wider product range.  The developmental impact of IFC's investment in Banco Los Andes is expected to be far reaching in terms of its economic support for productive businesses, stimulus for growth, employment generation and confidence-building in the banking sector. IFC's investment is in line with World Bank strategy as demonstrated by the expected developmental impact described above. Furthermore, IFC support, both financial and knowledge sharing, is key to Caja's successful conversion.
Environmental Social Issues: Banco Los Andes must require that all activities that it finances comply with Bolivian environmental, social and health and safety regulations and with IFC''s Microfinance Exclusion List. Banco Los Andes must attend environmental training as may be required, operate an environmental management system, and provide an annual environmental performance report.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: The project involves converting Caja Los Andes (Caja) into a fully licensed and regulated bank (Banco Los Andes, or the bank).  As part of a requisite capital increase, DEG/KfW, IFC, and the non governmental organization (NGO) Asociación ProCredito will subscribe to new shares to be issued by Caja.  The main sponsor and shareholder of Caja will continue to be Pro-Crédito, an NGO.  Caja began operations in 1992 as Pro-Credito, and began providing financial services to microenterprises.  In 1995, Pro-Credito changed its name to Caja Los Andes and became the first of the Fondos Financieros Privados, i.e, the regulatory form under which microfinanciers operate as non-bank financial institutions in Bolivia.
Cost Nature: The project involves IFC investing $4 million in the form of a credit line and $1.0 million in the form of equity as part of a capital increase.

Project Name: Asociacion Dominicana para el Desarollo de la Mujer
Company Name: Banco de Ahorro y Credito ADOPEM
Project Description: ADOPEM is the second largest MFI in the Dominican Republic.  ADOPEM, a true micro lender, is known for its market savvy and keen application of its credit methodology.  While still a non governamental organization (NGO), ADOPEM is undergoing a formalization process to obtain access to cheaper and more diversified funding.  ADOPEM has completed many of the necessary legal and regulatory requirements and will be ready to formalize its conversion  into a regulated commercial microfinance bank by mid-2003.  This would allow the institution to amplify its product line, mobilize deposits and open its capital participation to new investors.  IFC's investment is structured in this perspective and should facilitate the entry of a strategic technical shareholder.
Environmental Social Issues: ADOPEM must require that investments under relevant operations meet host country environmental, health and safety requirements and be consistent with IFCs microfinance exclusion list.  IFC will assess ADOPEMs capacity for environmental review.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Cost Nature: The project involves IFC investing up to $2.0 million in the form of a credit line and $2.0 million in equity.

Project Description: Founded in 1987, Banco Sol is the first commercial bank in Latin America to focus on microcredit activities.  The purpose of the credit line would be to increase Banco Sol's on-lending activities while extending the tenor of its small business and micro loan portfolio.  This project will also allow Banco Sol to increase the outreach of its lending operations.  There are 600,000 small and microentrepreneurs in Bolivia and the sector represents 20-25% of Bolivian GDP.   This project is expected to reach 30,000 new clients during the tenor of the credit line.
Environmental Social Issues: Banco Sol will be required to establish and environmental management system to ensure that relevant lending activities are consistent with IFCs Microfinance Exclusion List and in compliance with applicable host country laws.  IFC will assess Banco Sols environmental and social capacity.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: The key sponsors of Banco Sol are Fundacion Prodem, Profund International S.A. (ProFund), and Accion International (Accion). Since its founding, Fundacion Prodem has been focusing primarily on facilitating access to loans, by microentrepreneurs,  through viable and continuous lending operations in urban and rural sectors of the country.  ProFund was incorporated in 1995 as a for-profit investment fund in the city of Panama, while ACCION has been a leader in the commercialization of the microfinance industry.  Accion has also developed significant experience in providing debt and equity financing to microfinance institutions (MFIs) and in developing their corporate governance.  Another significant shareholder is the Commonwealth Development Corporation, which has a stake of about 22.5%.
Cost Nature: The project involves IFC investing up to $6.0 million in the form of a credit line of seven years to Banco Sol.
Investment: 6.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan6.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Banco Sol is headquartered in La Paz, with 35 branch offices located throughout Bolivia.

IFC will assess Banco Sols environmental and social capacity.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Description: Through its equity investment IFC will buy a large block of shares from a government owned institution which will reduce government shareholding in CBC.  By providing funding for a portion of the shares of CBC for its employees, IFC will help to align employee and shareholder interests, by making the former part owners of the bank.  The provision of longer term financing to a strong financial institution which operates in a difficult macro-economic environment will allow CBC to extend the maturities of its loans to sub-borrowers and lengthen the maturity of the Bank's liabilities.  In addition, the project would facilitate the privatization of Sri Lanka's largest insurance company and also provide a demonstration effect to strengthen the government's privatization program.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Financial Intermediary (FI) Type 1/Type 2 project according to IFC''s environmental review procedure.   CBC must establish an environmental management system to require relevant operations to comply with the environmental laws of Sri Lanka, and for projects funded by the loan or guarantee facility, applicable World Bank Group environmental, health and safety guidelines and IFC safeguard policiesLocation of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: The project sponsor is the Commercial Bank of Ceylon (CBC), which in its over 30 years of existence became one of Sri Lanka's leading banks measured in terms of profitability, capital, and management quality.  CBC has a history that goes back to 1920, when Eastern Bank, one of the predecessors to CBC, was founded.  CBC was established as a separate entity in 1969 with Chartered Bank holding 40% of its equity.  Currently, CBC's main shareholders include the Sri Lanka Insurance Corporation (SLIC) with almost 30% and DFCC, with approximately an additional 30%.  The remainder of the bank is owned widely by individual and institutional investors.
Cost Nature:
IFC's proposed investment into CBC will be a package of up to $25 million comprised of three elements:
- up to $10.5 million for the acquisition of 15% of CBC's common shares from the Sri Lanka Insurance Corporation (SLIC), Sri Lanka's largest life insurance corporation and a government owned institution which is being privatized;
- up to $4 million of short term funding for the purchase of 5% of CBC's common shares for CBC's employee stock ownership plan.; and 
- a long term loan of up to $10 million.
Investment: 25.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan14.0Equity11.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: CBC is headquartered in Colombo, Sri Lanka and has over 100 branches throughout the country.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Financial Intermediary (FI) Type 1/Type 2 project according to IFC''s environmental review procedure.   CBC must establish an environmental management system to require relevant operations to comply with the environmental laws of Sri Lanka, and for projects funded by the loan or guarantee facility, applicable World Bank Group environmental, health and safety guidelines and IFC safeguard policiesLocation of environmental documents in locally affected community

Company Name: MOLINOS RIO DE LA PLATA S.A.
Project Description:
The 2001 recession and following early 2002 financial, political, and economic crisis in Argentina led to a significant cut in Molinos' credit lines.  In order to counteract the local prevailing environment, Molinos changed its sales mix and increased its exports from 25% of sales in FY2001 to 47% in 1H02 and expects to close FY2002 with over 50% exports.  To assist Molinos overcome short-term capital constraints and increase exports to the envisaged levels, IFC intends to structure a short-term, pre-export finance, export receivables-backed facility. The facility will be renewable annually for a maximum of three years.

Developmental Impact:
The project is designed to alleviate the immediate constraints faced by the oilseeds sector in Argentina and to help maintain its competitiveness in the face of a remunerative world market but a very volatile political, social, and economic environment.  The following benefits are expected from the project:
Financing the marketing of the 2003 crop (soybean, sunflower, and wheat aimed at the export market.)  The proposed project will enable Molinos to leverage its export receivables and extend financing to farmers.  
Preserving the supply chain  Molinos's strategy has been to position itself as one of the primary originators of oilseeds and grains in Argentina to compete with global traders who are able to leverage their considerable network of export destinations worldwide.  The venture will enable Molinos to secure its grains and oilseed procurement to satisfy both the internal and export markets.  
Demonstration impact  IFC's support to the Argentine grain/oilseed supply chain is expected to send a signal to foreign financial institutions to focus their attention on the true nature of the credit risk in these operations.  This may lead to an increased appetite by foreign banks to increase their exposure to the better corporates -- something essential for Argentina to move towards an export-led recovery.

IFC Role:
IFC's participation in the proposed project will: 
provide capital not accessible today from the markets and enhance the operational and financial sustainability of a major domestic agro-exporter; 
ensure the participation of foreign banks through a B-Loan under a challenging country scenario; and 
protect an existing IFC investment.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category C project, according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because it is likely to have minimal or no adverse environmental impacts.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor:
Borrower:
Molinos Río de la Plata S. A. (Molinos or the company) is one of the largest buyers from Argentina agricultural sector, specially of oilseeds, cereals, meat, yerba mate tea, rice, and vegetables.  Molinos' activities have therefore a wide impact on Argentina's agricultural sector and a large number of farmers across the country.  Molinos is a market leader in Argentina in a number of product lines, including oils (49% market share), flours (53%), breadings (54%), and dry pasta (29%) among other.

Sponsor:
In 1999 the Perez Companc family acquired a controlling block of shares (64%) of Molinos.  The family heads one of the most important groups in Argentina with interest in mining, energy, refinery, petrochemical, electric generation transmission and distribution, and mass consumption food processing, as well as extensive farmlands and cattle holdings.  In July 2002, the family announced its decision to divest from the energy sector to concentrate in the food mass consumption sector.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $60 million.  The proposed IFC investment is a $30 million A Loan for its own account and up to $30 million-syndicated B Loan.
Investment: 30.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan30.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Project funding will be directed to continue soybean and sunflower seed purchases in the Santa Fé, Córdoba, and Buenos Aires provinces on Argentina.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category C project, according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because it is likely to have minimal or no adverse environmental impacts.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Description: The project seeks to facilitate the expansion of the companys business via the provision of funding for infrastructure expansion, working capital and the extension of consumer finance to support the sale of solar home systems (SHS).  In implementing its business plan, Selco India will partner with numerous regional rural banks to provide consumer finance under the project.This is a project financed by the IFC/GEF Photovoltaic Market Transformation Initiative (PVMTI). The Global Environment Facility (GEF) has provided $30 million in concessional funds to IFC to support investments in private sector projects to encourage market development for photovoltaics.  PVMTI aims to address market barriers by making available appropriate financing and stimulating business activity, accelerating PV penetration to achieve reductions in greenhouse gases. By harnessing the innovation and discipline of the private sector in designing and implementing PV projects, IFC is helping to shift the design and financing of PV market activity to a more sustainable and replicable private sector context.By investing PVMTI funds in the project, IFC intends to support the demonstration of a successful and replicable business model for the Indian, as well as other developing country PV markets.
Environmental Social Issues: Based on the available information, this is a category C project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure.  No further environmental and social review is therefore required.  Selco India will be responsible for ensuring proper recycling or disposal of batteries.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: Selco India is a 100% owned subsidiary of Solar Electric Light Company Inc, a US based solar photovoltaics company specializing in rural PV for developing countries.  Selco India is headquartered in Bangalore, India.
Cost Nature: Total project cost of $2,300,000, with IFC/GEF PVMTI loan and grant investment of $1,100,000.
Location: The project encompasses the expansion of Selco Indias business in the Southern states of India.  The company will manage the venture from its headquarters in Bangalore.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: Based on the available information, this is a category C project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure.  No further environmental and social review is therefore required.  Selco India will be responsible for ensuring proper recycling or disposal of batteries.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sector: IA - Electric Power Other (Including Holding Companies)

Company Name: PUBLIC JOINT STOCK COMPANY NBD BANK
Project Description: NBD is a regional private commercial bank, specialized in financing small and medium businesses. It was established in 1992 and it is currently the fourth largest bank in the Nizhniy region by assets, with a net worth of $9.1 million and assets of $42 million equivalent as of June 30, 2002. NBD has continuously benefited from cooperating extensively with international financial institutions such as IBRD (housing program, ESP and FIDP), the US Russia Investment Fund, USAID etc. Despite its small size, it has become the 3rd largest user of the EBRDs Russian SME lending program. The main strategic goal of NBD is to remain a leading regional financial institution with a solid and dominant position in the Nizhny Novgorod region, providing a wide range of high quality financial services to small-and medium enterprises. The bank would use IFC funding to finance medium-sized enterprises in productive sectors of the economy and to strengthen its balance sheet.  Development ImpactIFC funding will support the expansion of the bank''s lending capacity to SME sector, thus supporting a sector of the Russian economy that will play a key role in achieving a sustained economic growth. At the same time, NBDs activity will help address the limitations of the Russian banking sector in providing term-financing to SMEs and growing Russian businesses, particularly in areas outside the better-served Moscow region both through its activity and via the demonstration effect for other banks. While providing the bank with longer term funding, the project would support the development of a leading regional bank. IFC RoleWhile the IFC investment would provide NBD with access to long-term funding not available in the market, particularly IFC''s quasi-equity investment component would primarily (i) provide institutional support; (ii) strengthen the operational capacity of one of the leading regional banks in Russia; (iii) strengthen NBDs balance sheet, both in size and structure; and (iv) help the bank strengthen its market position in the region. In addition, IFC''s quasi-equity investment, could potentially affect shareholding in NBD, and hence it could send a signal to the market and enhance the bank''s attractiveness to potential strategic investors.
Environmental Social Issues: This a Category FI Type 1 project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure. NDB has already developed and implemented an environmental management system for its corporate and SME lending operations, requiring borrowers'' compliance with local and national environmental, health and safety standards and Bank officers have also received appropriate environmental training. NDB will continue to provide IFC with an annual environmental report on the ongoing implementation of its environmental management system.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: NBD Bank (NBD or the bank) is a small regional bank in the Nizhniy Novgorod region of Russia. The main shareholders and their percentage of voting stock they hold are: Nizegorod Promstroiproect (36.9%), EBRD  (25.0%), Nizhegorodsky Dokhodny Dom (7.4%), Region (7.1%). The bank is independent from large financial industrial groups which dominate large parts of the Russian economy.
Cost Nature: The proposed IFC''s investment consists of a senior loan of up to $5.0 million and a subordinated convertible loan of up to $2.0 million in NBD Bank. The project would be the second IFC investment in NBD.
Investment: 7.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan7.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: NBD is headquartered in Nizhniy Novgorod and has six branches and four agencies in the Nizhniy Novgorod region.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This a Category FI Type 1 project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure. NDB has already developed and implemented an environmental management system for its corporate and SME lending operations, requiring borrowers'' compliance with local and national environmental, health and safety standards and Bank officers have also received appropriate environmental training. NDB will continue to provide IFC with an annual environmental report on the ongoing implementation of its environmental management system.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community

Company Name: Banco para el Fomento a Iniciativas Economicas SA
Project Description:
FIE is a Fondo Financiero Privado (FFP, the legal entity under which micro-financiers operate and are regulated as non-bank financial institutions in Bolivia).  The purpose of the credit line would be to allow FIE to increase its lending activity, i.e., upgrading and diversifying from its expertise in microfinance.  FIE lends to both micro and small businesses, but would like to increase its lending to small businesses.  

The developmental impact of FIE is expected to be far reaching in terms of its economic support for productive small businesses, stimulus for growth and employment generation and confidence building for the banking sector.  There are about 600,000 small and micro entrepreneurs in Bolivia and the sector represents 20-25% of Bolivian GDP.   This project is expected to reach an estimated 700 new small businesses and micro entrepreneurs during the tenor of the credit line.  

IFC's involvement would provide financial resources to micro and small entrepreneurs and support the strengthening of the Bolivian financial sector.
Environmental Social Issues: FIE must require that investments under relevant operations meet host country environmental, health and safety requirements and be consistent with IFCs microfinance exclusion list.  IFC will assess FIEs capacity for environmental review.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: Centro de Fomento a Iniciativas Economicas (Promotion Center of Economic Initiatives), a non-governmental organization (NGO) owns 69% of Fondo Financiero Privado F.I.E. (FIE).  Its mission, from its inception in 1995, has been to support the sustainable development of low income clients, typically those that had no previous access to formal sources of credit.
Cost Nature: The FIE project involves IFC investing a $2.5 million direct credit line of five years to FIE Fondo Financiero Privado.
Investment: 2.50 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan2.50Equity* These investment figures are indicative
