The Botswana Government views the Game Reserves as areas in which mine exploration and development is allowable alongside conservation initiatives under strict conditions.   For any prospecting in these areas, KDL will implement Government of Botswana guidelines associated with  Prospecting in the Central Kalahari and Khutse Game Reserves as well as applicable World Bank Policies and Guidelines.  Any future mine development resulting from KDLs activities would be evaluated as a new project with a new environmental classification appropriate to its impacts. Project Description: The project involves a major renovation of Grand Hotel (GH), a successful 3-star, 91-room business hotel in Bamako, Mali, owned and operated by SMPH. The hotel was established with IFC''s financial support through a loan granted in 1994 to help renovate the then newly privatized 74-room facility. The proposed renovation of GH is critical in maintaining and increasing its competitiveness. The colonial-style low rise facility (three floors) built in 1953, has not been refurbished since 1994. It now needs a profound renovation and uplifting into a modern and international standard business hotel.IFC''s objectives are two-fold. The proposed investment would:confirm IFC''s support to local businesses in the development of tourism infrastructure in Mali, thereby improving the country image among potential investors; and supplement a regional "Banque Ouest Africaine de Développement" (BOAD) financing, thereby providing scarce long-term resources devoted to development. The developmental impact  includes: - consolidating and maintaining quality standard business accommodation facilities, thereby improving the overall attractiveness of the Bamako destination; - revitalizing the urban architecture and cultural heritage of the town, through the renovation of the GH building which dates back to the colonial days and which was recently classified as an ancient monument; - saving and maintaining about 74 jobs, in a country with high unemployment; and - enabling the state to continue collection of fiscal revenues to the tune of CFAF250 million ($0.35 million) per year.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe environmental documents will be located on the bill board of both SMPH hotels (Grand Hotel and Hotel Salam), as well as at the entrance of same hotels in Bamako, Mali.
Sponsor: The main sponsor is Société Malienne de Promotion Hôtelière (SMPH), a Malian public limited company with stated capital of CFAF2.8 billion ($4 million), 92.8% owned by Mr. Mossadeck Bally (42), a Malian seasoned businessman who graduated from the San Francisco University and has investments in the tourism, banking and trading sectors. Mr. Bally took over the family business from his father in 1989 (predominantly trading) and developed it into a modern company, that diversified mainly into tourism. SMPH is a strong and profitable company. Its main assets include two hotels (Grand Hotel and Hotel Salam). Both hotels are doing fine and achieved a cumulative occupancy rate of 74% in 2001.  Revenues increased by an average 31% over the past three years (from $2.9 million in 1999 to $4.7 million in 2001) and cash-flows by 20% (from $1.5 million to $2.1 million), whereas lowest net profit/sales ratio for same period was 21%.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at Euro 3.8 million. The proposed IFC investment is an A loan for IFC''s own account for the amount of Euro 1.5 million.
Investment: 1.68 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan1.68Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The project is located on a 7,357 square meter surface area at the Avenue Van Vollenhoven, in down town Bamako, capital of Mali. The site is prime location at the business and administrative neighborhood, about 25 minutes from the international airport Bamako - Senou.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe environmental documents will be located on the bill board of both SMPH hotels (Grand Hotel and Hotel Salam), as well as at the entrance of same hotels in Bamako, Mali.

Project Description: The project is aimed at spinning off four Occindental''s hotels in Mexico in one company (the company) that will become the main vehicle for Occidental''s future developments in Mexico and in the region. Occidental will contribute four hotels and IFC will help raise the necessary debt financing and invest a further $10 million in quasi-equity. Once the company has been properly financed, FONATUR, Mexicos tourism development agency, will consider becoming a minority shareholder in the company through the contribution of hotel assets or plot of land suitable for hotel development.Through the proposed investment IFC will support the establishment of what is likely to become an important regional hotel company in Mexico and Central and South America, following a market downturn. IFC will provide a financing package with long maturities which the market cannot provide and will help put the company on a sound long term footing.  Also, IFCs proposed participation is key to help structure the project and raise complementary financing.  In addition, IFC has played an important role by encouraging Occidental to review its fire & safety standards for its whole hotel portfolio, and has led Occidental to a new program of developing a comprehensive and high impact corporate risk management system aimed at identifying and mitigating environmental, fire & safety and sustainability risks related to the management and development of hotel operations.In the long term, IFCs involvement will support the efforts of the Mexican government to leverage the assets of FONATUR by entering into joint ventures with the private sector. In this context, IFC will play a honest broker role between Occidental, a foreign company, and FONATUR, a government agency.  IFCs participation will also help ensure that all properties owned by the Company will comply with IFC and WBG environmental, social and life and fire and safety policies and guidelines.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category B project, according to IFC''s Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of projects.  The environmental, health, safety, and social issues associated with this project are described in the Environmental Review Summary (ERS).Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityDireccion Contraloria  Area CozumelOccidental Grand CozumelKm 17.5, carretera Sur, San Francisco Palancar77600 Cozumel, Quinatana Roo, MéxicoContralor: Rafael AzuetaDirección Contraloría Area PlayacarOccidental Royal HidewayKm 16.5, carretera Sur, San Francisco Palancar77600 Cozumel, Quintana Roo  MéxicoContralor: Gilberto Lopez
Sponsor: The sponsor and main shareholder of the project is Occidental Hotels Management BV (Occidental). Occidental is the third largest Spanish hotel chain worldwide, operating 85 hotels with an aggregate of 20,400 rooms in Europe, Latin America, the U.S., and Africa.  It is a privately held company and the three main shareholders in Occidental are Mercapital, La Caixa and other Spanish individuals and institutional investors. Mercapital is a leading Spanish venture capital group dedicated to the industrial and service sectors. La Caixa of Spain is one of the principal saving banks in Europe with interests in several Spanish sectors including infrastructure, utilities and telecommunications. The project company is a subsidiary Mexican company of Occidental and is 100% owned by Occidental.
Cost Nature: Project cost is $150 million consisting of four existing hotels located in Playa del Carmen and Cozumel. The proposed IFC investment is a  $30 million A loan for IFCs own account, a $40 million B loan and a $10 million convertible C-loan.

Project Description: EBA will be a new, target group oriented bank with the objective of providing, on a country-wide, financial services basis that are specifically tailored to the needs of client groups at the lower end of the market. In its business operations, the bank will focus on credit extension to private micro and small enterprises and on savings mobilisation from these enterprises, salaried workers, private individuals and the general public.  EBA will have two main groups of products: instalment loans and other banking services, including current and savings accounts (in Kwanzas and in USD) and national and international payment services. EBA will provide loans of between $100 and $50,000, to finance fixed assets and working capital of micro enterprises and small businesses.IFC is a leader in Microfinance: IFC''s experience over a range of microfinance projects has shown that establishment of a specialized financial institution dedicated to microfinance provides a focused and efficient means of reaching the SME target group.  Due to the small size of typical microfinance banks, streamlined credit evaluation procedures and appropriately tailored MIS and micro-loan monitoring technologies can be put in place quickly.  High efficiency levels for SME lending are therefore achieved in a relatively short timeframe.   EBA will draw on these and other lessons from IFCs experience with building financial institutions and emerging best practice in microfinance institutions.The proposed investment in EBA is expected to be strongly developmental -- in terms of its economic impacts, stimulus for business reconstruction, employment generation, confidence-building in the banking sector, and introduction of commercially-oriented microfinance techniques to Angola.In addition to poverty alleviation and related impacts within the SME target group, IFC''s involvement in EBA is expected to yield a number of important demonstration effects.  First, establishment of EBA will provide for a best-practice financial institution with sound operating policies, transparent financial reporting, environmental screening procedures and a clear governance structure.  Over time, IFCs involvement in EBA is expected, to lead to the replication of commercially-oriented MFIs in the market and downscaling by Angolas existing commercial bank operations to serve SMEs.  Third,  technical assistance provided to EBA is expected to generate spill-over benefits in the form of trained managers and employees available to other Angolan financial institutions.  Lastly, EBA will contribute to mobilizing SME savings in due course, although this will not be its initial focus.
Role: Development Impact:Microfinance schemes have shown a major positive impact in alleviating poverty and unemployment in emerging markets worldwide, and -- in recognition of this strong developmental impact -- almost all multilateral and bilateral institutions and donor agencies are actively promoting microfinance schemes.  The developmental impact of commercially-run microcredit programs in particular, on post-confict transition economy populations with little or no access to formal credit institutions has been well-demonstrated by IFC''s microcredit investments in Bosnia-Herzegovina and Albania.  IFC''s developmental strategy in the field is to attract serious private sector investment in microfinance by demonstrating that microfinance can be a viable commercial proposition.IFC Role:The project will support IFCs Africa strategy of establishing and supporting new financial institutions.  The strategy pays special attention to establishing links between the financial system and the informal sector of the economy, through the establishment of savings banks, credit cooperatives, microfinance institutions and business incubators.
Environmental Social Issues: EBA is a category FI Type 1 project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure.  IMI and project technical partner IPC have developed an environmental management framework to ensure that financial institutions in which IMI invests and IPC manage have appropriate Environmental Management Systems (EMS).  IFC''s  Environment Division has approved this environmental framework.  Under the framework, IMI/IPC will: (i) develop and implement an EMS at EBA; (ii) build EBA''s microfinance portfolio in accordance with applicable environmental, health and safety legislation and standards of Angola and IFC guidelines for microfinance banks (IFC Microfinance Exclusion List); and (iii) report annually on environmental performance at EBA.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The project sponsor is International Micro Investitionen (IMI). IMI is an established private investment vehicle based in Germany, with holdings in IPC-managed microfinance ventures in developing and transition economies, in which IFC holds a 16.7% stake.  IFC, DOEN Foundation, BIO and FMO will be the other shareholders.  Enterprise Bank of Angola (EBA or the bank) professional management will be provided under contract by Internationale Projekt Consult (IPC), the technical partner, who will second a general manager and other senior staff to the bank.  EBAs initial shareholder capital will be $4,200,000.  IMI will own 33.3% and the rest of the shareholders will own 16.7% each.
Cost Nature: The project cost is $44,200,000 consisting of initial shareholder capital in EBA.  IFC will take up $700,000 of the shares for a 16.7% ownership in the bank.
Investment: 0.70 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity0.70* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The bank will be established as a commercial bank in Angola specializing in banking services for micro- and small-size enterprises and individuals, with headquarters in Luanda.  Over time the Bank will open branches in different parts of the country as conditions permit.

Project Description:
BBI is one of the most conservative commercial banks in Indonesia, with particular strength in serving small and medium-sized (SMEs) businesses.  The bank intends to increase its capital by issuing new shares via rights issue. Therefore BBI has invited IFC to become a shareholder and offered IFC the right to board representation.  

Development Impact
Efficient intermediation of capital into productive investments is vital to the restructuring and the future growth of Indonesia.  With a limited number of alternative intermediaries, the banking sector has a significant role to play.  By investing in the capital of BBI, IFC will be supporting the modernization and growth of an intermediary that has the opportunity to become a more significant player in the Indonesia banking sector.  While BBI is going through the transition from a privately owned company to a publicly listed company with a broader number of shareholders, IFC is in a position to facilitate such transition through strengthening corporate governance and transparency.  At the same time, IFC's investment would help BBI to become a model institution on the Jakarata Stock Exchange. 

Indirectly, IFC's investment would benefit the SME sector as BBI's focus is on the SME segment representing 40% of Indonesia's GDP and 50% of total employment.

Fit With World Bank Group Strategy and IFC Role
The World Bank Group's current strategy in Indonesia, as outlined in the FY01-03 Country Assistance Strategy, focuses on three broad areas closely related to the Government's priorities in its economic recovery program and its medium-term development plan: sustaining economic recovery and promoting broad-based growth, building national institutions for accountable government, and delivering better public services for the poor.

After placing its program (in March 2001) of new investments in Indonesia under review until the legal and law enforcement climate in the country improved, IFC cautiously restarted its program in February 2002. In terms of development priorities, IFC's strategy for Indonesia focuses on: 
assisting the recovery of the financial and corporate sectors - through provision of liquidity facilities, support of financial intermediaries, and assistance for corporate restructuring;
overcoming structural weaknesses in the economy  through  help in building up the institutional and regulatory framework, and 
promoting long-term sustainable development - by supporting environmentally sound practices in natural resource use, and the integration of the economy into a globalized marketplace. 
The proposed project is consistent with this strategy.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category FI type 1 project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  BBI will be required to develop an environmental management system to ensure that relevant operations comply with the environmental requirements of Indonesia.  IFC will assess BBI''s capacity to conduct environmental and social reviews.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Description:
DeltaCredit provides mortgage loans in Moscow and St. Petersburg directly to individuals and indirectly through funding mortgages via fourteen foreign and local Russian banks, all using stringent underwriting and servicing standards specifically designed for the Russian market.  The underwriting criteria were designed with FannieMae experts and Russian lawyers.  At year-end 2002, the outstanding mortgage portfolio reached over $53 million, and asset base of $63 million.

By providing a warehouse line to an existing Russian client, IFC's financing would help DeltaCredit build the volume of mortgage loans needed to eventually securitize its loan portfolio on the domestic or international capital markets or sell it to an unrelated third party on commercial basis.  Through a properly structured deal to be entered by DeltaCredit with foreign or domestic financial institutions, IFC would introduce DeltaCredit to a professional way of collateralizing its mortgages on behalf of DeltaCredit's lenders and be the leader of 'best practice' in this industry in Russia.  Also, the proposed financing would cement further a strong partnership between DeltaCredit and IFC for years to come.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category C project according to IFC''s procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because it is likely to have minimal or no adverse environmental impacts.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: DeltaCredit Bank (the bank or DeltaCredit) is the first mortgage bank in Russia specializing in the origination and servicing of mortgage loans.  DeltaCredit began its activities in 1999 with the establishment of DeltaCredit Mortgage Finance Netherlands B.V., which is wholly owned by the U.S. Russia Investment Fund (the fund).  The fund is funded through grants from the USAID with a total commitment of $440 million and is managed on commercial basis by Delta Capital Management Company.  In 2001 the bank obtained its own banking license through the acquisition of ZAO 'JP Morgan Bank'(Russia) and set up its own retail banking operations.
Cost Nature:
The proposed IFC investment to DeltaCredit Bank consists of: 
- a five-year, up to $54 million revolving warehouse line of credit, collateralized by a pool of mortgages, and comprised of two tranches for the expansion of the bank's mortgage finance activities in Russia, and  
- up to $6 million subordinated convertible loan structured to meet Russian requirements for tier-II capital.
Investment: 66.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan60.0Equity6.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: DeltaCredit is headquartered in Moscow and has one representative office in St. Petersburg, Russia.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category C project according to IFC''s procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because it is likely to have minimal or no adverse environmental impacts.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Description: Founded in 1998, Novica is an Internet-based artisan marketplace which enables a network of over 10,000 artisans located in emerging markets to sell their products to international retail and wholesale buyers.  The company has created a global infrastructure that includes on-line retail, wholesale and catalog distribution channels, served by a network of sourcing hubs in seven developing countries.  The companys goal from its inception was to create a destination on the Internet for sales of locally produced arts and handicrafts.  This has been accomplished by providing professional and strategic resources to its artists, all of whom are located in the emerging markets, as well as by providing a scaleable technology platform that enables online sales to customers in the developed world.  The company is allowing artists to increase their standard of living and hire additional workers and is also helping to spread the use of technology among a group of people that were not previously part of the global marketplace.  Novica has had, and will continue to have, a significant impact on the earning potential of numerous low-income artisans, due to higher volume sales and better prices for their goods.  As part of its stated Novica Law of Pricing, the company pays the artisans more for their product than alternative purchasers, yet keeps end prices relatively low, contributing to higher volumes.  Novica''s focus on quality and authenticity also enables the artisans to preserve their cultural heritage and prevents the loss of high quality skills that occurs when artisans are forced to focus on low cost buyers.  For smaller artisans, the rolling purchases facilitated by Internet sales help them avoid "boom and bust" cycles that characterize contracts with traditional exporters, allowing them to build up working and human capital in a sustainable manner.  A strengthened relationship with IFC would benefit Novica in many ways.  The company is already working with artisan groups and with IFCs Small and Medium Enterprise (SME) department to build supplier capacity, which allows the groups to access more profitable markets and hire additional employees.  There is also potential for IFCs Microfinance and Small Business Group (part of Global Financial Markets) to facilitate discussions between Novicas artists and IFCs micro finance portfolio companies.  This could enable Novicas artisans to secure small loans from these credit providers.  Novica believes these loans could enable its artisans to take increased inventory risk, and allow smaller artisans to increase their scale.  It is expected that many Novica artisans who currently have little or no access to formal credit institutions in their own countries will benefit from introduction and access to financial services from IFCs portfolio of dedicated micro finance institutions, enhanced access to working capital and other services that micro finance banks typically provide to self-employed artisans and other micro entrepreneurs.  IFCs experience has shown that this can have a major positive impact in reducing poverty and unemployment in emerging markets worldwide.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category C project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  The company is an Internet based firm operating from leased office space both in Los Angeles and in all of its international locations.  Thus, no further environmental or social review is required and the project is cleared by CESIG for Board review.  The sponsor will develop a corporate environment and social policy statement demonstrating their commitment to comply with all applicable environmental, occupational health, fire and life safety legislation and standards of the host country in which business is conducted, as well as relevant World Bank Group environmental and social policies, guidelines and industry best practice.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: Novica United (Novica or the company) has three institutional investors and a number of individual investors.  In addition, the management owns a large percentage of the company.  Novicas institutional investors are:Scripps Ventures  Scripps is a $50 million corporate venture fund created by the E.W. Scripps Company, a NYSE listed firm with a market capitalization of approximately $6 billion.  E.W Scripps operates 20 daily newspapers and 10 broadcast television stations.  Scripps Ventures finances early stage companies in the retail and business to business sectors.  Doug Stern, the CEO of United Media and a partner at Scripps Ventures, is a Novica Board member.Foursome Investments  A European based venture fund investing in socially responsible businesses, Foursome invests in four broad areas: the environment, education, technology and culture.  Susan Marks, a member of Foursomes board as well as the Chairman of New York based City Harvest, the worlds largest food rescue program, is a Novica board member. Foursome is actively involved with the World Economic Forum.National Geographic Ventures  NG Ventures was formed by the National Geographic Society in 1995 and manages NGs television, film, interactive, online, merchandising, travel and related businesses.  Fran Marshall, the COO of National Geographic Ventures, is a Novica board member.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $3 million to fund Novica operations until the company reaches profitability.  The proposed IFC investment is the purchase of $1.5 million in Novica Preferred Stock.

Project Description: Groupo Mexmal provides components for computer systems, systems design services, and technical assistance and training to value added resellers (VARs) and systems integrators in Mexico, and works with them on the joint development of higher value added solutions. Mexmal also offers connectivity solutions, including Internet access. The company is planning to expand its operations into Mexico City, which would constitute the primary use of funds for this project. The expansion comprises leasing additional space, and increasing working capital requirements (inventory and accounts receivable). Mexmals working capital needs for its existing businesses would also increase as the business expands and the company moves into higher value added components. Development ImpactThe project would have significant developmental impact by creating IT related jobs in Mexico, and providing low-cost computer solutions to schools, small and mediume enterprises and less wealthy sections of the population.  In addition, Mexmals support to local VARs would increase the technical know-how available throughout the country.  IFCs RoleThe economic turndown and the decline of appetite for technology investments by private equity investors has made it extremely difficult for mid-sized companies such as Mexmal to raise long-term capital.  The IFC funding is, therefore, critical to the companys expansion plans.IFCs presence would provide Mexmal with the credibility it needs to attract investors in future rounds of funding.  IFC would also assist the company in obtaining needed credit facilities.  Moreover, IFC would play a major role in enhancing the Mexmals corporate governance practices and assisting in its transformation from an entrepreneur-owned company to a professionally managed company with international best practice.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category C project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  There are minimal environmental and social impacts associated with this project.  If physical assets, for example warehouses, are constructed during the life of the project loan, the Company will notify IFC, develop procedures to appraise the construction project(s), and demonstrate compliance with all relevant environment and social policies, guidelines and procedures.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The project sponsor is Patrick Wong and Alfredo Flores, who own Grupo Mexmal (Mexmal or the company). Patrick Wong, President, CEO -  Before co-founding the company in 1990, Patrick was an adjunct professor at Laredo State University where he taught computer programming, statistics, and information systems.  Patrick received an MBA in Management Information Systems from University of Texas at Arlington and a B.S. in Computer Science from the University of Oklahoma.Alfredo Flores, Executive Vice President  Alfredo co-founded the company in 1990.  Alfredo received an engineering degree in computer engineering with a minor in computers and communications from Universidad Autonoma de Nuevo Leon, Mexico.
Cost Nature: The total projected cost is estimated at $20 million.  The proposed IFC investment would be a loan of up to $7 to 10 million.

Project Description: The project concept is to develop a self-sustaining , commercially viable micro credit enhancement facility to support MFIs throughout the world.  The facility will provide credit enhancement products at commercial terms to MFIs working through local commercial banks.  These enhancements will enable and encourage the local banks to provide loans or to substantially increase the modest support that may be provided to MFIs, where such banks would otherwise not be prepared to make such loans and would do so with primarily local currency.  Credit enhancement products will include standby facilities, such as letters of credit, letters of guarantee and direct funded loans or deposits products with local commercial banks.  The facility will also provide credits directly or through local commercial banks.  Presently many MFIs fund growth of their local currency loan portfolios through hard currency loans.  This subjects them to foreign currency risk, which is the greatest risk affecting the microfinance industry globally.  The facility directly addresses this issue by filling the local commercial funding gap which strongly limits the growth of MFIs and should result in a stronger and more effective commercial microfinance industry, leading to economic development and increased opportunities for the MFIs and their borrowers.  IFC's participation would help facilitate the entry of other investors.
Environmental Social Issues: As part of the credit framework (to be defined), the Facility will adopt an environmental screening policy.  Ongoing monitoring will confirm compliance by the local lending banks with such policy.  The environmental screening policy should insure that no loans will finance activities that are included in IFCs exclusion list.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: The IFC Micro-Finance Facility, formerly the Deutsche Bank / IFC Microcredit Facility, (the Facility) will be Sponsored by IFC and managed by Cyrano Management (Cyrano), a Lima, Peru based investment management firm specialized in managing debt funds that on-lend to microfinance institutions in Central and South America will be hired as the management company.  The Managing Director of Cyrano, Mr. Fernando Lucano, is an experienced investor in microfinance institutions having worked in Africa, Eastern Europe, in addition to Central and South America.  The Facility will be capitalized with US$2.0 million grant funding from the Dutch Government and US$470,000 from IFC.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is US$30 million. The facility will raise tiered resources structured in two ranked lending tranches by seniority (A snd B).  IFC's investment, in the B tranche (second ranked), would be up to $4 million.
Investment: 4.05 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan4.0Equity0.05* These investment figures are indicative

Ongoing monitoring will confirm compliance by the local lending banks with such policy.  The environmental screening policy should insure that no loans will finance activities that are included in IFCs exclusion list.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Description:
The company's investment objective is capital appreciation achieved through dividends and premium returns based on the value realized through bank restructuring activities.  IFC will invest in a fund that will look to obtain controlling positions (at least 50.1%) in banks located in Sub-Saharan Africa and place them under the management of commercial bankers with experience in meeting the return requirements of sophisticated investors.  Once acquired on realistic investment terms and conditions, that correctly value the franchise, relatively straightforward turnaround techniques will be applied.  After the franchises' potential for profitable growth as a full service commercial bank, including retail banking, has been demonstrated, the banks will be sold or refinanced through a private placement or public sale either singly or in combination.  
The company will seek to achieve a development impact by improving access to financial services.  IFC's participation as a core investor supports the project's development goals.   
Commitment to Branch Networks and Retail Banking
The company is based on the central premise that large commercial bank franchises with extensive branch networks in sub-Saharan Africa can be profitably managed to provide retail financial services.  In other words, banks can go 'down-market' and still be profitable.  In addition, this provision of services will have positive macro-economic consequences by contributing to economic growth and social welfare, enhancing the company's appeal to government sellers.
Commitment to Microfinance and Small Scale Lending
The company is committed to developing a retail loan product by leveraging lessons learned in microfinance and generate substantial expected impact on economic development.  ABH will partner with CGAP, recognized experts in designing and managing retail consumer loan programs in developing countries.  CGAP will be closely involved in the design of the retail loan product and the management of the portfolio banks.  

IFC is planning to hold a seat on the Investment Committee and will provide ongoing support in the areas of market and bank analysis and environmental issues.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category FI-2 project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure.  The fund manager must require that each bank in which the fund invests establish an environmental management system (EMS) as part of the restructuring, and ensure that that appropriate staff are trained to implement it.  In the restructuring process, the fund manager should establish a procedure to identify existing environmental liabilities in each investee banks portfolio.  The fund manager will be required to provide to IFC an annual report on the status of environmental and social issues in its investee banks.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor:
The project sponsor is WPA, a private advisory firm based in Cambridge, Massachusetts, USA.  WPA and its principal, Wendy Peter Abt, have been instrumental in restructuring, privatizating, and re-capitalizing of several government-controlled banks in Sub-Saharan Africa.  

subject to completion of due diligence and satisfactory legal documentation, potential major investors in ABH (the company) are the HSBC Group, IFC, and other multilateral and bilateral development finance institutions.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at: $150 million. The proposed IFC investment is an equity investment up to $ 30 million.
Investment: 20.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity20.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The project will be located in Sub-Saharan Africa.  Investments will be made in commercial banking institutions in multiple regional countries. ABH is expected to be legally domiciled in the Cayman Islands.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category FI-2 project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure. The fund manager will be required to provide to IFC an annual report on the status of environmental and social issues in its investee banks.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Description: The project is to establish an investment company, ACCION Investments in Microfinance. The primary objective of the company is to capitalize profitable MFIs so that they can scale up, reaching more people who currently do not have access to traditional formal financial services. Through its role on investee boards, AIM will provide governance support.  ACCION''s parallel  technical assistance facility will provide a range of strategic and operational assistance in areas such as new product development and MIS development. Development ImpactDemonstration Effect.  The entry of MFIs into the formal financial system, or the provision of microfinance services by traditional financial institutions, represents a significant step in integrating the formal and informal sectors. This demonstration impact, particularly in Africa''s young commercial microfinance industry, will be achieved as investee companies develop into sustainable formal financial intermediaries.Private Sector Development , Economic and Living Standards Contribution.   Micro enterprises and small businesses account for the major share of the private sector and employment in many developing countries. Yet, despite their size and importance, these businesses rarely have access to the savings, credit, and payment services provided by formal institutions. By expanding the scale and outreach of financial services to these businesses, the project will make a significant contribution to economic and living standards of low-income populations in developing countries. IFC RoleIFCs solid track record as a risk-taking investor, strategic advisor, and technical assistance provider to the financial services industry places it in a unique position to provide comfort to other investors, acting as anchor investor and participating in the growth and development of the industry at this critical stage of its evolution.IFC also has an important role in the structuring of the company, drawing on lessons learned in its other wholesale microfinance investment vehicles. The sponsor has incorporated such ''best practices'' in the structuring of this project, to align its interest with those of other investors.  IFC will also play an important governance role through its participation in the company''s board of directors.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Financial Intermediary (FI) Type 1 category project according to IFCs environmental review procedure.  The company manager (AIM) will be  required to develop an environmental management system that will require that investee companies investment operations meet host country environmental, health and safety requirements and be consistent with IFCs Microfinance Exclusion List.  IFC will work with AIM to develop an environmental review capacity. Depending upon IFCs assessment, environmental training will be required.  AIM will  provide an annual environmental performance report to IFC.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The project sponsor is ACCION International, a USA-based non-profit organization dedicated to poverty reduction through sustainable microfinance. ACCION has been engaged in the microfinance industry for 30 years, was one of the earliest advocates for the commercialization of microfinance, and leads a highly regarded microfinance network.ACCION has 26 affiliates in Latin America and Africa, an active research, policy and communications program, investment capacity through in-house funds, and a team of investment professionals who provide technical and management support to microfinance institutions (MFIs). Its strategy of providing a combination of long-term technical support together with an equity presence in its affiliates permits it to enhance its investees'' value through an equity/governance role. ACCION plays an important role in several equity investment vehicles. It has sponsored and invested in ProFund, a $23 million private equity fund investing in Latin America & Caribbean MFIs, and AfriCap, a $15 million fund investing in African MFIs. ACCIONs wholly-owned, for-profit subsidiary, Gateway ACCION International Manager, Inc. (GAIM), manages the ACCION Gateway Fund LLC and IADB/MIF funds.
Cost Nature: ACCION Investments in Microfinance (AIM or the company) targeted size is $20 million, with a minimum first closing of $10 million and an expected actual first closing of $15 million. ACCION International plans to raise up to $4 million to establish a parallel technical assistance facility to support investee companies. IFC is considering matching ACCION International''s equity investment of $3 million and its contribution to the technical assistance facility of $500,000.
Investment: 3.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity3.0* These investment figures are indicative

The company manager will be located in ACCION''s headquarters in Boston, MA. Investments will be made in Latin American, Caribbean and African countries initially and ultimately in any World Bank member country with developing markets.

Project Description:
The proposed investment consists of a risk-sharing facility under which IFC would share with a member insurer of Zurich, a portion of the emerging market financial institution risk associated with medium-term trade transactions.  Eligible transactions will be backed by bankers' acceptances, letters of credit (L/C's) and other standard trade facilitation instruments issued by the covered emerging market financial institution's on behalf of importers in emerging markets.  Under this facility, Zurich would issue a credit risk insurance policy covering the risk of an emerging market financial institution and IFC would cover a portion of this risk through a risk-sharing agreement with Zurich.

The project's developmental impact lies primarily in supporting the recovery of emerging markets by providing additional access to term finance necessary to fund the import of capital goods and services.  The limited access to this finance in emerging market economies is a key constraint to the ability of these countries to import the capital goods that they need to develop.  IFC's participation in the project will help enable Zurich offer a new, much needed product that provides medium term risk coverage on emerging market financial institutions.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category C project, according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because it is likely to have minimal or no adverse environmental impacts.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor:
The main project sponsor is Zurich Emerging Market Solutions (ZEMS) which is the emerging markets political risk and credit insurance unit of Zurich North America, a business unit of Zurich Financial Services Group.  ZEMS is a leading underwriter in providing innovative political risk and credit insurance solutions in emerging markets where it has underwritten policies covering risks in 93 countries. 

Zurich North America is a leading commercial property and casualty insurance company serving the multinational, middle market, and small business sectors in the U.S.  Zurich North America is a member of the Zurich Financial Services Group, a global leader in the financial services industry.  Headquartered in Zurich, Switzerland, the Group's worldwide presence builds on strong positions in its key markets of North America, the United Kingdom and Continental Europe.  It has offices in more than 60 countries reaching over 33 million customers and employing 70,000 staff members.
Cost Nature: The expected size of the facility would be $125 million for the account of IFC and would result in supporting up to $370 million of medium-term trade transactions assuming no rollovers and full commitment.
Investment: 125.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuarantee125.0LoanEquity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Investment will be made in emerging markets with an initial focus in the Asian, African and the Middle Eastern regions.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category C project, according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because it is likely to have minimal or no adverse environmental impacts.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Description: This PVMTI subproject will facilitate the introduction of a microfinance credit scheme to accelerate the uptake of solar home systems (SHS) in rural areas of Morocco.  Zakoura, a leading  microfinance institution, will provide a range of credit packages to buyers of SHS in partnership with multiple PV suppliers selected by Zakoura, which are able to comply with the PVMTI technical guidelines.  IFC will provide a partial credit guarantee for Zakoura, so that it can access debt financing for the project locally from Société Générale Marocaine de Banques (Soc Gen).The project is financed by the IFC/GEF Photovoltaic Market Transformation Initiative (PVMTI). The Global Environment Facility (GEF) has provided $30 million in concessional funds to IFC to support investments in private sector projects to encourage market development for photovoltaics.  PVMTI aims to address market barriers by making available appropriate financing and stimulating business activity, accelerating PV penetration to achieve reductions in greenhouse gases. By harnessing the innovation and discipline of the private sector in designing and implementing PV projects, IFC is helping to shift the design and financing of PV market activity to a more sustainable and replicable private sector context. By investing PVMTI funds in the project, IFC intends to support the demonstration of a successful and replicable business model for the Moroccan, as well as other developing country PV markets.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category C project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure.  No further environmental review is therefore required. Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: Zakoura is an independent, autonomous not-for profit microfinance institution.  Zakoura is headquartered in Casablanca, Morocco.
Cost Nature: Total project cost is estimated at $3,368,000, with proposed IFC/GEF PVMTI credit guarantees and grant investment of $915,000.
Location: The project encompasses the introduction of a micro-credit scheme by Zakoura to support the purchase of PV systems by private households throughout Morocco.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category C project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure.  No further environmental review is therefore required. Location of environmental documents In locally affected community

Project Description:
Vodafone Albania is the second national mobile telephone operator in Albania.  The company was established in 2001 after winning a license as part of a fair and transparent bidding process.  The company is rapidly expanding its subscriber base and coverage area.  The greenfield project represents the full 5 year investment program (2001-2005) for the establishment and operation of the second nationwide mobile telephone network offering various services, including but not limited to GSM cellular services and leased fixed lines to enterprises.

IFC's role in the project includes:
supporting the liberalization and private sector development of the telecom sector.
encouraging healthy competition in the cellular market in Albania.  This will result in:  lower tariffs; improved quality of service and customer responsiveness; expanded access to telecommunication services, and introduction of new services. 

Development Impact:
Given Albania's low telecom penetration rates (6.8% for fixed line), the venture would fulfill substantial unmet demand for reliable telecommunications services and thereby support economic growth.  It would also support competition in a previously monopolized mobile market which would result in lower tariffs and the introduction of new value added services for consumers.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityVodafone Albania

The company's direct owners are Vodafone International Holdings (wholly owned by Vodafone Group), which holds 51% of the company, while 49% is directly held by Vodafone Panafon International Holdings (100% owned by Vodafone Panafon of Greece, itself 63% held by the Vodafone Group).

Company Name: ALD AUTOMOTIVE UKRAINE LIMITED LIABILITY COMPANY
Project Description:
Established in late 1999, FL is one of the earliest entrants into the Ukrainian leasing sector.  FL's primary product is vehicle leasing/financing for enterprises operating in Ukraine.  The company primarily leases cars, light vans, and trucks which are used for monitoring and managing inventory; deliveries; and promotion.  The IFC credit line will be used to finance FL's operating lease activities which provide vehicle leasing to commercial enterprises in Ukraine.  

FL has also received the approval of a comprehensive technical assistance program (TA) with funding of $130,000 from the government of Holland.  As FL is still a young enterprise, the technical assistance project will focus on improving/developing several operational areas to help the company sustain its growth.  The TA project will involve the following, among other, components: 
integration of FL's back office and IT systems; 
assistance in new product development; and
implementation of a leasing oriented IAS accounting system.    

The benefits of leasing to private enterprises, particularly small and medium enterprises (SMEs), are well documented.  In Ukraine's credit-constrained environment, leasing will provide one of the few viable means of financing investments in assets.  This is particularly important in the SME sector where the lack effective financial intermediation is acute.  Ultimately, a well-functioning leasing sector would play an important role in supporting the capital investment needs of local enterprises.  

IFC's support of FL will help the company expand its leasing activities as well as develop further its internal management and technical systems.  IFC's credit line will provide needed financing to FL in an environment where access to term financing is extremely limited.  At the same time, the demand for leasing far outweighs the supply provided by existing leasing companies.  In addition, the technical assistance activities associated with the loan will help strengthen various business/operating aspects of the company as noted above.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an FI Type 1 project.  First Lease will be required to apply environmental review procedures to relevant operations.  IFC will assess First Leases capability to carry out environmental reviews.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor:
The project sponsor is Eastern Prospect bv (EPB).  The First Lease (FL or the company) is wholly owned by EPB, a Netherlands based entity founded in 1998 to act as a holding company of FL.  EPB's main shareholders are as follows:  

Eastern Future BV, ultimate beneficiary Robert Speelman, formerly of Mees Pierson. Mr. Speelman is FL's co-founder and Managing Director of Eastern Prospekt.  He is also a member of FL's Board of Directors and Credit Committee (27.5%). 
Martin Elling, formerly of the EBRD, is the co-founder of Eastern Prospekt and member of FL's Board of Directors and Credit Committee.  During his tenure at EBRD, Mr. Elling was responsible for agribusiness and energy projects in Ukraine (22.5%).  
Ildom ltd, managed by Theodore Margellos, and investor who has several other business interests Ukraine (22.5%). 
Fimbank, a bank incorporated in Malta (15%).
Ducrein BV, ultimate beneficiary René Hooft Graafland (12.5%)
Cost Nature: The total project cost is $2 million.  The proposed IFC investment is an IFC A loan of up to $2 million for its own account.

IFC will assess First Leases capability to carry out environmental reviews.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Description:
SAHL is an existing company with both retail and wholesale mortgage banking lines of business.  It operates on the retail level by originating mortgages through a new and non-bank distribution channel.  SAHL offers existing mortgage holders the option to lower their mortgage rates, because the company has lower operating expenses than traditional banking firms.  This is called the 'switching business'.  SAHL has made significant inroads in this market.  In addition, the company operates in the wholesale market by securitizing it mortgage portfolio.  In this sense it provides a bridge between the primary mortgage market and the capital markets of South Africa.

This particular investment involves a buyout of Peregrine, one of the original investors in SAHL.  Peregrine today has about a 10 percent shareholding, but doesn't desire a longer term outlook in their investment.  IFC's buyout of this shareholder would restructure and rationalize the company's shareholding as it enters a new phase of corporate development
Role:
There is a significant role for IFC to play going forward based on the following considerations:  
Demonstration effect on other countries of the region, particularly those with a high likelihood of developing housing finance systems in the near future.  IFC's continuing support for the best example of housing finance development in the region's most closely watched financial market will set a standard and send a signal for up to seven other countries in the Sub-Saharan Region.  The signal will be that IFC has the expertise, institutional binding power and vision to lead markets in terms of housing finance development.  The standard and the signal will make it easier for IFC to make progress in our high priority countries.  If we fail to take this opportunity, a contrary signal will be sent, with deleterious effects in other high priority countries.
Making housing finance more affordable:  The impact has been partially realized by opening a new distribution channel outside the dominant banking firms.  In addition, SAHL has succeeded in raising awareness of the significant over-pricing by the banks.  But the job is only partially complete.  Market share of originations is only about three percent.  On a book basis, market share is only slightly over one percent.  There is building political pressure on the big banks to serve their communities by offering mortgage loans to qualifying lower income households.  So, in addition to the upside in making further inroads in market share, SAHL is the  viable and proven conduit to handle lower income mortgage loans and increase funding to this segment.  IFC's increased investment in SAHL will bolster this line of business.
Developing a new asset class of MBS:  This has only partially been accomplished.  Two completed deals, although quite successful, are nonetheless limited, unless mortgage product can be sourced from other originators.  IFC's unique honest broker reputation gives us the best opportunity to achieve this.  Having a larger shareholding adds to our credibility in this endeavor.  It has become increasingly obvious that demand for MBS is growing, even beyond the normal long-term institutional investor base, as two banks have recently established commercial paper conduits that will invest in SAHL MBS.
Future market development: Ability to use SAHL as a possible vehicle for the development of a secondary mortgage market for residential loans.

As a result, IFC can leverage its investment in SAHL to have a greater impact in the development of the South African financial market.  This places an additional dimension to the value of SAHL from IFC's perspective.

Peregrine is one of the founding shareholders of SAHL.  Peregrine is an investment company.  Its principals have no expertise or special interest in the mortgage business.  Their initial shareholding could be construed as a pure venture capital investment.  They have not participated in rights issues, and are now interested in selling.  Of the major shareholders, IFC, by virtue of its relatively small shareholding, honest broker reputation and recognized expertise in housing finance, is uniquely positioned to buy the shares and instill a clearer sense of mission to the Company.  The two largest shareholders, Standard Bank and JP Morgan have very good working relationships with IFC.  Together, we would form a cohesive and effective management team.  This mission is every bit as important as infusing new capital.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category C project according to IFCs environment and social review procedure.  It is expected to have minimal or no environmental impact.  No further environmental review or action is required.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: The major shareholders are Standard Bank with a 49 percent shareholding, JP Morgan with a 29 percent shareholding and Peregrine with a 10.1 percent shareholding.  IFC is currently owner of 8.6 percent of shares.  The remainder is held by employees.  Standard Bank and JP Morgan can be considered the key project sponsors.  The CEO of the company is Simon Stockley.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at up to $2.5 million.  This is for the proposed buyout of shares, and would constitute an additional investment by IFC in the equity of the company.
Investment: 2.51 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity2.51* These investment figures are indicative
Location: SAHL is headquartered in Durban, South Africa.  It operates in all major cities throughout the country.  SAHL has  developed a novel distribution system.  As such, it does not have a traditional branch network.  It employs about 60 sales agents who travel around in marked cars displaying the SAHL logo and take mortgage applications at clients homes and places of business.  In addition, a certain portion of originations are sourced via the call center and over the internet.

No further environmental review or action is required.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Description: Like all Russian banks, MNB currently has limited access to the international debt markets, in particular to medium and long-term funding.  This is a major impediment to growth.  Likewise, and partly as a consequence, Russian corporates have only limited access to long-term capital, which many of these companies need for making much needed capital investments to upgrade machinery and production facilities, or to invest in new projects and facilities. MNB has a strong track record including weathering the 1998 Russian crisis and has been able to return to operating profitability.  It has refocused its activities on the area of structured trade finance, and implemented new risk guidelines and controls.  MNB has been able to attract only limited term funding to finance its current level of business.  The provision by IFC of a five-year loan will significantly enhance MNBs capital structure, and will increase MNBs chances of re-gaining its pre-crisis investment-grade rating.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an FI Type 1 project.  MNB will be required to develop an environmental management system to ensure that investments under relevant operations meet host country environmental, health and safety requirements.  IFC will assess MNBs capacity for environmental review.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The project sponsor is Moscow Narodny Bank, Limited, a U.K. licensed and regulated bank, which is 89% owned by the Central Bank of Russia.  With a fully-owned subsidiary in Moscow, a branch office in Singapore, and headquarters in London,  MNB operates as a commercial bank, and is primarily active in providing trade finance and related lending to Russian exporters.  In this area, MNB has established lending relationships with leading Russian corporates and has developed skills to structure and syndicate trade finance facilities.   As of December 31, 2001 MNBs total assets amount to $1.5 billion; with equity of $ 440 million, the bank posted a profit of $ 49.3 million and paid dividends of  $17.7 million.
Cost Nature: The proposed IFC investment is a Loan for IFC''s own account of up to $100 million for the purpose of on-lending to select Russian exporters.  The loan will have a maturity of up to five years.
Investment: 100.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan100.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: MNBs headquarters are in London.  The proceeds of IFCs loan will be used to extend medium-term, trade related credit facilities to privately-owned and creditworthy Russian exporters.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is an FI Type 1 project.  MNB will be required to develop an environmental management system to ensure that investments under relevant operations meet host country environmental, health and safety requirements.  IFC will assess MNBs capacity for environmental review.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community

Project Description:
Housing Development Finance Corporation Limited (HDFC or the company) is one of India's premier financial institutions. The company was incorporated in 1977 with a share capital of Rs.100 million ($11 million) and has since grown to become the largest residential mortgage finance institution in the country, with over 50% of the total market share and a market capitalization of $1.9 billion equivalent.

The purpose of the project is to provide HDFC long-term funding not available in the local market and to assist the company in extending the maturity of syndicated funding accessible internationally.  Funds from the investment would be used by HDFC to extend its reach to the underserved middle and lower income segments of the population in India.
Role: HDFC provides mortgages all over India. The company is among the best institutions in the country to address the needs of the middle and lower income segment of the market. Its extensive network, financial strength, and operational efficiency will allow it to structure and price its products so that they are affordable, and without subsidy, to prospective middle and lower income house-owners. Moreover, the strong brand recognition of HDFC will generate confidence in prospective borrowers who have never borrowed from formal housing finance institutions before, thereby enabling rapid penetration. Analyst reports suggest that the demand for housing will outpace the growth and funding capacity of existing financial institutions, even if they target only the predominantly urban top 30% income tier of the population. Without increased longer term funding available, the middle and lower income segment of the market will continue to be under-served for the foreseeable future. IFC's goal in this project is to encourage and support HDFC in its drive to extend its lending to the middle and lower income segment of the housing finance market in India. The IFC loan will be help the company expand a lending program focused on the middle income segment of the population, which is substantial and underserved.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category C project, according to IFC''s Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because it is likely to have minimal or no adverse environmental impacts.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: HDFC's enjoys broad institutional ownership. Its equity shares are listed on the Mumbai Stock Exchange and the National Stock Exchange and are permitted for trading on all the recognized stock exchanges in India. The shareholding pattern, as of December 31, 2002, was as follows :- Foreign Institutional Investors 50%- Individuals 16%- Foreign Direct Investment 23%- Local Financial Institutions 6%- Mutual Funds 3%- Local companies 2%
Cost Nature: IFC will provide HDFC with an A Loan of $100 million to $150 million for a tenure of up to 8 years, and a B Loan of $50 million to $100 million for a tenure of 6 years.  The total investment of the A Loan and B Loan combined would amount to up to $200 million
Investment: 150.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan150.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: HDFC is headquartered in Mumbai (Bombay) and has an extensive network of 142 offices around India which enables it to access customers that smaller institutions cannot reach. The company's extensive network allows it to offer a rapid response to loan applications and the lowest cost structure in the industry.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category C project, according to IFC''s Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because it is likely to have minimal or no adverse environmental impacts.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Role:
The project will have a widespread developmental impact. It will have a broad impact on the Russian poultry industry by demonstrating the benefits of a vertically integrated system with application of modern management and technology. It will increase demand for the region's large grain crops. The project will create/save 1,300 jobs, most of them in the newly acquired broiler farms which are currently idle, in rural areas where there is little employment alternatives except for the subsistence activities. The investment will improve product quality, hygiene and bio-security. The venture's broiler farms will serve as demonstration units to train local farmers in modern broiler outgrow techniques.

IFC has played an important role in developing and structuring the project. Using the IFC-British Trust Fund, IFC commissioned consultants to prepare the project's feasibility study and subsequently advised the company on structuring the project. Drawing on its extensive sector experience, IFC provided in-house advise on livestock operations, which have already helped the company achieve performance improvements. The IFC loan provides extended grace and repayment periods, not available locally.  Going forward, IFC's vital role in the project will be reinforced by extensive supervision required during the implementation phase.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a category B project according to IFCs environmental review procedure because specific impacts may result that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. Project Description:
Description of Company
The AnJia Group (AnJia or the group) was established in January, 2000 and currently comprises of three operating entities namely, AnGage Real Estate Service Company, which is engaged in residential mortgage origination and servicing, AnJia Info Tech Limited which produces real estate related software and AnLian Info which is a portal and internet services company.  AnGage has become the core operating entity within the AnJia Group. 

Purpose of Project:
With the recent privatization of the housing sector in Shanghai, the home resale market has grown rapidly. Banks engaged in housing finance do not have the retail network capability to process the large volumes of mortgages in demand. In addition, the lengthy administrative procedures involved in deed transfer and collateral registration delay the release of funding and stifle the market growth.  AnJia's participation in the market as an independent and neutral brokerage intermediary would allow the banks to focus on what they do best - make credit decisions - and outsource the laborious administrative aspects of origination, underwriting and servicing to a focused, specialized, and therefore more efficient brokerage entity - AnJia - thus enabling continued rapid growth in the industry.  However, for AnJia to succeed and thrive in its role, it needs to expand its operations and develop its staff and systems. Therefore the group has approached IFC for an equity investment to achieve this aim.

More specifically, the AnJia Group would use the funds from the proposed IFC investment to: 
strengthen its mortgage origination and servicing capability by acquisition and by expanding its physical retail outlets network; 
attract the qualified high calibre staff needed to support the rapid growth of the business, specifically to train and develop individual qualified mortgage brokers who will form the backbone of its retail mortgage servicing network;
overhaul its processing systems to increase capacity and improve information access and reliability; and
develop the AnJia brand and position the company as the leading mortgage originator and servicer in Shanghai.
Role:
Development Impact
The proposed project will promote efficiency in the housing finance market by backing the development of an intermediary specializing in mortgage origination and servicing.  Focus and specialization on origination and servicing will shorten mortgage processing times, reduce costs, and hence improve efficiency. The venture will also facilitate faster growth in the home resale market and help promote private home ownership, thereby encouraging transfer of housing assets to the private sector.  These assets can be used as collateral in the future, therefore the project will help in broadening access to private sector led financial services.   The investment is also expected to have a demonstration effect on other similar players improving mortgage asset quality and introducing discipline in the housing finance market as a whole.  Also, by standardizing the origination and mortgage servicing processes, the project will facilitate new entry by banks to the housing finance market, enable existing banks to expand mortgage lending, and also set the stage for secondary mortgage market development.  Finally, the creation of an efficient large scale mortgage origination and servicing industry will facilitate the eventual entry of non-banking financial institutions in the housing market.

IFC Role
IFC backing will substantially enhance AnJia's financial standing,  its credibility in the financial sector and among customers and regulators.  IFC backing will also assist the company in attracting the high calibre professionals it needs to drive its expected rapid growth and development.  IFC's support is especially important during the company's early stages of development, where it will need assistance in building the necessary institutional and corporate governance structures to establish a solid foundation for future growth and business sustainability.  Over the longer term, IFC's participation in AnJia's growth and development positions IFC to assist, by way of technical assistance, in the development of uniform standards in mortgage origination and servicing, setting the stage for secondary market development.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category C project, according to IFC''s Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because it is likely to have minimal or no adverse environmental impacts.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor:
The key sponsor of the project is Mr. Alan (Xu Dong) Zhang, the founder, Chairman and CEO of the AnJia Group. Mr. Zhang, a dynamic and enterprising former investment banker, is the majority shareholder of the the group. Other shareholders of AnJia include management, Technology Development Fund of Singapore (TDF), and Shanghai Venture Capital Corporation (SVCC).

Mr. Zhang has extensive experience in business development, investment banking and finance.  Prior to founding the AnJia Group, Mr. Zhang was the Managing Director of International Capital Services and subsequently the Managing Director for Greater China and CFO of the Asia-Pacific Region for Koch Industries, Inc.  Before that, he was Vice President of Corporate Finance with the First National Bank of Boston.  He also worked as Senior Investment Analyst in the Private Placement Department of New England Mutual Life Insurance Company of Boston.  Mr. Zhang has a master's degree in economic development and is well respected in the Shanghai business circles and is backed by a strong management team.
Cost Nature: The project cost of $10 million will be funded by the proposed equity investment of up to $10 million by IFC for its own account.  AnJia may seek additional investment over the medium term to further expand its operations as necessary.
Investment: 10.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity10.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: IFC's investment will be made at the offshore holding company level.  The operating companies funded by the proceeds of the investment will be based in the People's Republic of China.  AnJia's operating companies are headquartered in Shanghai.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category C project, according to IFC''s Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because it is likely to have minimal or no adverse environmental impacts.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Description: Raiffeisenbank Austria was established in 1996 and has become one of the leading retail banks in the country with a solid reputation and a strong retail franchise.  As of December 2002, the bank ranked among the top 20 Russian banks in terms of assets (approximately $1.6 billion).  Raiffeisenbank Austrias equity amounted to approximately $133 million on December 18, 2002.  The banks main areas of activity are corporate, retail, and investment banking.  Raiffeisenbank Austria views mortgage finance as one of its strategic priorities and has been marketing this product actively on the market.By providing the credit line to the bank, IFC will help Raiffeisenbank Austria expand its funding base, match its maturity needs, and enable it to provide long-term funds for mortgage finance, a sector that has an acute need for term financing.  In addition, the credit line would have a strong developmental impact on the still nascent Russian housing finance industry.  The proposed financing would cement IFCs strong global partnership with RZB in Central and Eastern Europe, and further extend this cooperation to Russia. This project is also a part of IFCs overall strategy to promote the development of the housing finance sector in Russia.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category C project, according to IFC''s Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because it is likely to have minimal or no adverse environmental impacts.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: ZAO Raiffeisenbank Austria (Raiffeisenbank Austria or the bank) in Russia is 100% owned by Raiffeisen Zentralbank Österreich AG (RZB), one of Austria''s major financial institutions.  As of June 30, 2002, the RZB group''s total assets amounted to EUR43.9 billion, its equity base reached approximately EUR2 billion, and its 1H2002 pre-tax profit was EUR118.4 million.  RZB has an A1 rating (LT) from Moody''s and an A+ rating from Standard and Poor''s.  RZBs commitment to Russia and its significant regional expansion have been recognized by a number of international finance magazines, including the Euromoney award as  Best Bank in Russia in 2001.
Cost Nature: The project involves providing a $40 credit line to Raiffeisenbank Austria for residential mortgage on-lending in Moscow, St. Petersburg, and other regions of Russia.
Investment: 80.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan80.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Raiffeisenbank Austria has five branches in Moscow (including its head office), and one branch in St. Petersburg.
