Project Description: CSMC Tech, the project company, manufactures semiconductor wafers using 6-inch technology.  CSMC Techs current capacity is 20,000 wafers per month (wpm).  The proposed project consists of: -  capacity expansion of (Fab1), from 20,000 wpm to 35,000 wpm; and -  construction of a greenfield semiconductor wafer manufacturing facility (Fab 2) with capacity of 25,000 wpm. The project will be implemented by CSMC, backed by China Resources Logic Limited (CRL), the industrial and technology arm of China Resources Holdings.   The project will contribute to the government''s effort in building the IC industry in China. The project production will be used as import substitute, and thus help reduce China''s dependence on imports. Furthermore, end-user markets will benefit from the project''s cost savings and quality management. The project will promote the open foundry model in China, and will make foundry services more available for IC design houses, and IDMs in China, which in turn will enhance integration along the value chain of the IC industry. In addition, the project will transfer CSMCs know-how in technology and management to the local market. The project will benefit from the management expertise of a strong team, which has significant know-how in foundry services. The project will provide employment opportunities, both directly and indirectly. Current operation has about 670 employees, including highly qualified workers and engineers. This number is expected to increase to around 1000] at project completion. In addition, the project will provide training to local workers and engineers. Through its participation in this project, IFC will support Chinese government''s efforts to strengthen the country''s IC production capability. Although China''s electronics industry has achieved annual growth of about 25% in the last five years, the IC sector as a key building block of the industry, has been lagging behind. IFC''s participation in the project will provide comfort to other investors. Through its equity participation in the project, IFC will help the company move to international standards of corporate governance.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category B project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure. Environmental and social issues which may be associated with this type of project, and which will be assessed during project appraisal, include: site selection and land acquisition process including any associated resettlement or economic displacement; management of possible redundancies at Huajing; development of corporate environmental, health and safety management programs, including training; air emissions; waste water treatment; energy efficiency and use of non-ozone depleting refrigerants in clean room air conditioning systems; delivery, storage, handling and disposal of hazardous materials; solvent use; disposal of possibly hazardous solid waste. Health and safety issues may include fire safety and emergency response and labor and workplace conditions.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe environmental documents will be posted on the factory gate at 14 Liang Xi Road, Wuxi City, Jiangsu Province, PRC.
Sponsor: The project sponsor is CSMC, which holds 51% in CSMC Technologies Corporation (CSMC Tech), the project company. Founded in 1997 by Dr. Peter Chen, CSMC, the first open foundry in China, was backed by international investors including China Walden Venture Investment Ltd. (17% shareholding),  and the Pacific Venture Group, Taiwan, China, (16% shareholding).  The other major shareholder, with 49% shareholding in CSMC Tech, is China Resources Logic (CRL), the technology arm of China Resources (Holdings) Co., a large Chinese state-owned trading and investment conglomerate.  CRL is listed on the Hong Kong Stock exchange.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at  about $200 million. The proposed IFC investment is a $10 million in preferred equity.
Investment: 12.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity12.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The project is located in an urban area in Wuxi, Jiangsu Province PRC. The existing  fab* (Fab 1) occupies an area of  3,520 sq. m.  The second fab (Fab 2) will be built close to Fab1, on a greenfield site in the center of Wuxi New Area, and will occupy an area of about 300,000sq.m.   * fab  manufacturing facility for producing semiconductor wafers
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category B project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure. Environmental and social issues which may be associated with this type of project, and which will be assessed during project appraisal, include: site selection and land acquisition process including any associated resettlement or economic displacement; management of possible redundancies at Huajing; development of corporate environmental, health and safety management programs, including training; air emissions; waste water treatment; energy efficiency and use of non-ozone depleting refrigerants in clean room air conditioning systems; delivery, storage, handling and disposal of hazardous materials; solvent use; disposal of possibly hazardous solid waste. Health and safety issues may include fire safety and emergency response and labor and workplace conditions.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe environmental documents will be posted on the factory gate at 14 Liang Xi Road, Wuxi City, Jiangsu Province, PRC.
Sector: BB - Computer & Electronic Products(Computers & Peripherals, Communications Equip., Elec. Watches & Similar Elec. Products.  Integrated Circuits & the application of Miniturization Technologies characterize this sector.)

Project Description: Zhejiang Babei Necktie & Weaving Co. Ltd.(Babei, or the company) is a leading silk necktie and necktie fabric producer in China. It is the largest and most influential company in Shengzhou , which is the necktie production base in China with around 1000 companies engaged in the business. It has existing production facilities with a total capacity of around 2 million square meters of necktie fabric by 2002. The project will increase the companys market presence in both the export and domestic markets. The project mainly involves:- expanding the weaving facilities from 60 to 168 looms, - building a new dyeing plant, and - relocating the main facilities to a new site.
Role: Following the best corporate practice in accounting, corporate governance, and environment, Babei will have a significant demonstration effect in the local business community. Approximately 400 new jobs would be created by the project when it reaches its production capacity in the next 2-3 years.Babei is a family-owned business. It has expressed a strong willingness to improve the corporate governance and to follow the best corporate governance. IFC will play a role in upgrading the company to the international standard by sharing our experiences and resources in this field.  IFC will also play an advisory role in providing technical and financial expertise. Besides IFCs long-term financing, IFCs extensive experience and network in textile industry will add value to Babeis development. In addition, by partnering with local bank in parallel financing, IFC will provide valuable experience to local banks in project financing.The project reflects IFCs strategic support for demonstration projects that will help Chinese companies adopt international standards for corporate governance, accounting and environmental management. Babei has successfully been exporting quality products and has become highly visible in the local business community; therefore this project fits well with the World Bank Group strategy.
Environmental Social Issues: Environmental and social review of the proposed project will include assessment of capacity to manage environmental and social issues. If applicable, the review will examine, land acquisition for the new site, (possible resettlement and cultural property issues); labor issues, including workplace health and safety, assurance of compliance with IFC child and forced labor policy; energy management / efficiency; utilization of chemicals, including dyes and moth-proofing compounds; discharges to the environment (air, water); and solid waste management.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityCity Government Promulgation Corner,Guan He Rd., Shengzhou City,Zhejiang Province, P.R. China
Sponsor: The sponsor is Babei Hong Kong International Co., Ltd. (Babei Hong Kong), which is a holding company registered in 1999 in Hong Kong, China, and 100% owned by Mr. Jin Yao and his family.  The company is currently 76% owned by Babei Hong Kong, and 24% owned by Zhejiang Shengzhou Babei Necktie Co., Ltd. (Babei Shengzhou), which is a holding company registered in Shengzhou, China, and also 100% owned by Mr. Jin and his family.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $24 million. The proposed IFC investment is a $5.0 million A loan and $2.0 million C Loan for IFCs own account.
Investment: 16.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan11.0Equity5.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The company is located in Shengzhou, China and currently has three locations; an existing downtown facility, a new weaving plant across the river to the south of the city, and a yarn dyeing facility to the north east of the city. The sites are well accessed to transportation routes. The new weaving plant has 3.3 hectare area, which was formerly low grade agriculture land and had no settlement.

Project Description:
Arctic S.A. ('Arctic' the "company") is Romania's only producer of refrigerators, with revenues of approximately $53 million in 2002. The $50 million project consists of :
acquisition of Arctic by Arcelik, a Turkey-based home appliance leader, with a turnover of approximately $1.5 billion in 2002;
Arctic's conversion into an efficient production base for Arcelik's refrigerator sales in Europe.  
Arcelik will improve Arctic's performance through:
implementing a modernization, quality improvement and capacity expansion program and 
restructuring Arctic's existing financial liabilities.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityA translation of the ERS will be available at the local Municipal Office (down the street from the plant) and the plant gate where the workers access the facility.
Address: 210, 13 Decembrie st. 0150 Gaesti- Romania
Sponsor:
Founded in 1955, Arcelik, the project's sponsor, is now an established leader in Turkey's home appliance sector and is one of the Koc Group's flagship companies.  In 2002, Arcelik's consolidated sales amounted to about $1.5 billion.  International revenues account for approximately 50% of this amount.  The sponsor's asset base at the end of 2002 was $1.2 billion.

Arcelik's is 57% owned by the Koc Group companies, and 20% of the project sponsor belongs to the Burla Group.  The remaining 23% of Arcelik's stock are public.  Public shares are traded at the Istanbul Stock Exchange.

Arcelik currently owns approximately 91% of Arctic's stock. The remaining project company's shares are widely dispersed among a large number of minority shareholders.

The project investments involving the purchase and installation of tangible assets will be made at this site.

Project Description:
SIDER, a state-owned enterprise and Algeria's sole integrated steel producer, has been privatized in October 2001. In this context, LNM Holdings N.V. has bought a 70% stake in Ispat Annaba (the company), the main steel producing plant and a 70% stake in Ispat Tebessa, its associated mines.  LNM/Ispat group is contemplating a project in Ispat Annaba to: 
rehabilitate and de-bottleneck the existing plant; and 
upgrade the plant to meet international environmental norms. 
The investment program is to be phased over a 10-year period, with about $123 million to be invested between 2003 and 2005.

23000 Annaba, Algeria

The project is sponsored by LNM Holdings NV which is part of the LNM Group (the Group).  
In addition to LNM Holdings NV, the Group includes Ispat International N.V. , a company quoted on the New York Stock Exchange and the Amsterdam Stock Exchange.  The Group is the world's 2nd largest and most global steel producer, with annual sales of over $9 billion and a steel making capacity of 35 million tonnes spread over 12 countries.

LNM Holdings is the largest shareholder in Ispat Annaba, with a 70% stake in the company.  The remaining 30% are held by SIDER, a state-owned enterprise.

Project Description:
The objective of the project is to establish one of the first specialized housing finance companies in Egypt (the company). The project will address the scarcity of long term financing for potential homeowners, and help develop a more efficient and innovative housing finance industry. In the long term, it will further contribute to the deepening of Egypt's financial market, by  enabling a vast number of Egyptians presently experiencing facility housing shortages to gain access to safe/improved housing and to obtain a higher standard of living. The development of a housing finance industry will also help boost housing investments and promote the growth of overall savings in the economy. 

The IFC's role in the project is two fold:

IFC would assist in the development of a business strategy and operations of the company based on its experience in financing housing finance companies, i.e. where applicable, institutional building, and,

IFC would seek to provide assistance to the company to raise long-term loans during its initial phase of operations, i.e. long-term funding and resource mobilization.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an environmental and social category C project. No further environmental or social analysis is required.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityNot applicable.
Sponsor:
The main sponsor and major shareholder of the project company is Egyptian American Bank ('EAB') (www.eab-online.com). EAB is a joint venture between American Express Holdings, Inc, and the state-owned Bank of Alexandria, and was established in 1976. It is licensed to conduct a full range of commercial banking services through its head office in Cairo and has 30 branches, and has a total of 825 permanent employees. As of December 31, 2002, American Express holds 40.83% of EAB's capital and the Bank of Alexandria holds 33.81%. The remaining shares are held by the EAB's employees, companies and private individuals. At year-end 2002, EAB has total assets of EGP8.2 billion ($1.8 billion equivalent) and net income of EGP50.0 million ($10.8 million equivalent). 

The other two proposed shareholders are: 

DEG, an enterprise of the KfW Group, is one of the largest European institutions for long-term project and company financing. Its aim is to establish and expand private enterprise structures in developing and transition countries, and thus create the basis for sustainable economic growth and a lasting improvement in the living conditions of the local population, and ,

Housing Development Finance Corporation Limited (HDFC) (www.hdfc.com), incorporated in 1977, is one of India's premier financial institutions with a 55% share of the entire Indian mortgage market. While its main line of  business continues to be residential mortgage loans, HDFC has extended and diversified its reach by developing other financial businesses through subsidiary and associate companies. As of  March 31, 2002 HDFC has a net income of  Rs. 5,800 million  ($121 million)  and total assets of Rs. 214,585 million ($4,380 million). HDFC would also provide technical assistance to the company.
Cost Nature: The project company will be capitalized at EGP50 million ($10.9 million equivalent). The proposed IFC investment would include an equity investment of up to EGP10 million (approximately $2.5 million) for up to a 20% equity stake in the project company, and a loan of up to $5 million equivalent.
Investment: 1.60 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity1.60* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The project company will be established in Cairo, Egypt.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is an environmental and social category C project. No further environmental or social analysis is required.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityNot applicable.

Project Description:
Rabitabank (RB) or (the Bank) was established in 1993 by public-sector companies of the Ministry of Communications.  Since then, the Bank has been privatized, and currently is 95% privately owned.   Following privatization, RB retained its communications sector niche and continues to serve and finance local and joint-venture companies in the cellular, long-distance, and telecom installation fields.  However, learning from the experience of peer banks' failures from sector concentrations as well as understanding the importance of SMEs in the country's economic development, RB is placing importance on increasing work with SMEs.  The Bank is headquartered in Baku and has 4 branches in and outside of Baku. 

IFC has been approached by Rabitabank for loan funds to on-lend to small businesses in Azerbaijan.  The Bank wishes to increase the provision of financing to small businesses to strengthen the linkages between large oil and gas sector firms and the small business market.  There is currently a major shortage of funds targeted at this segment of the economy.
Environmental Social Issues: Environmental considerations.  Rabitabank is a category FI Type 1 project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure.  The Bank must require and use its best efforts to ensure that its small enterprise clients comply with the environmental, health and safety, and IFCs Microfinance Exclusion List requirements on both a national and local level.  The Bank will also provide IFC with an annual environmental performance report and ensure that adequate number of staff members have been through IFCs environmental training course.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityRabitabank's headquarters are located in Baku, Azerbaijan
Sponsor: At its establishment, RB was 100% owned by public-sector enterprises controlled by the Ministry of Communications.   Successive share capital increases have diluted the public sector interest in RB to less than 2%.  Management and employees of RB hold about 70% of equity, and Azinvestbank, a medium-sized local joint-stock bank, holds a 9% stake. Azerigazbank holds a 4% stake.  With capital increases in 2002, the Bank's paid in capital is now US$2.5 million.
Cost Nature: The total project cost of the IFC Senior Loan is estimated at $1,200 thousands to be disbursed in two tranches of $600 thousands each. The duration of this loan is 6 years (including 2 year grace).
Investment: 1.20 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan1.20Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Rabitabank's branches are in Baku as well as other cities in Azerbaijan..
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: Environmental considerations.  Rabitabank is a category FI Type 1 project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure.  The Bank must require and use its best efforts to ensure that its small enterprise clients comply with the environmental, health and safety, and IFCs Microfinance Exclusion List requirements on both a national and local level.  The Bank will also provide IFC with an annual environmental performance report and ensure that adequate number of staff members have been through IFCs environmental training course.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityRabitabank's headquarters are located in Baku, Azerbaijan

Project Description: Azerigazbank (AGB, or the bank) was established in 1992 by the companies of Azerigaz State Concern as a joint-stock investment bank.  While AGB was established primarily to provide banking services to the various companies of the state-owned gas sector, it has since diversified its shareholder and customer base.  AGB no longer lends to Azerigaz and its affiliated public-sector companies, and is shifting its focus toward retail banking.  In addition to the head office in Baku, Azerigazbank has 103 employees, 25 currency exchange offices, and 5 branches throughout Azerbaijan.IFC has been approached by Azerigazbank for loan funds to on-lend  to small businesses in Azerbaijan.  The Bank wishes to increase the provision of financing to small businesses to strengthen the linkages between large oil and gas sector firms, the tourism industry and the small business market.  There is currently a major shortage of funds targeted at this segment of the economy.
Role: IFCs experience over a range of micro and small business finance projects has shown that a financial institution whose main focus is small business finance provides an efficient means of reaching the small business target group with initial technical assistance support. Due to the small size of the Bank, streamlined credit evaluation procedures and appropriately tailed MIS and small loan monitoring technologies, can be put in place quickly with the help of on-site technical advisors. High efficiency levels for small business lending are therefore achieved in a relatively short timeframe.The project is expected to strengthen the financial sector in Azerbaijan, which has an economy of significant gaps in funding for economic activity. In addition, there is potential for the development of small businesses which are directly linked with, and supply to, large companies within Azerbaijans oil and gas sectors.The proposed TA support will make four major contributions to the Bank:Create systems and procedures for prudent assessment of small business loan applications;Create a small business development function within the bank to enable ongoing generation of new lending opportunities;Create and implement a system within the institution to ensure that loans are properly monitored and portfolio risk is adequately controlled;Implement a training program for branch managers, loan officers and credit analysts to strengthen the credit and risk management capacities of the bank.
Environmental Social Issues: Environmental considerations.  Azerigazbank is a category FI Type 1 project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure.  The Banks must require and use its best efforts to ensure that its small enterprise clients comply with environmental, health and safety, and IFCs Microfinance Exclusion List requirements on a national and local level.  The Bank will also provide IFC with an annual environmental performance report and ensure that adequate number of staff members have been through IFCs environmental training course.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe Banks headquarters are located in Baku.
Sponsor: AGB was established with 49% share capital from Azerigaz, and 51% private ownership.  Successive share capital increases have diluted the public sector interest in AGB to less than 2%.  Private individuals owning less than 1% collectively own 40% of the Bank.  AGB Chairman Chingiz Asadullayev and his immediate family directly control about 25% of the Banks shares; while management and families own about 12%; and its employees about 15%.  Other shareholders include the Improtex Trading Group (4%), and Rabitabank (4%).
Cost Nature: The total project cost of the IFC Senior Loan is estimated at $1,200 thousands to be disbursed in two tranches of $600 thousands each. The duration of the loan is 6 years (including 2 year grace).
Investment: 1.20 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan1.20Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The Banks branch operations are concentrated in Baku, Azerbaijan.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: Environmental considerations.  Azerigazbank is a category FI Type 1 project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure.  The Banks must require and use its best efforts to ensure that its small enterprise clients comply with environmental, health and safety, and IFCs Microfinance Exclusion List requirements on a national and local level.  The Bank will also provide IFC with an annual environmental performance report and ensure that adequate number of staff members have been through IFCs environmental training course.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe Banks headquarters are located in Baku.

Project Description: IFC proposes to provide to Microfinance Bank (MFB, Bank, Borrower), a commercial bank established as a closed joint stock company in Belgrade, Serbia and Montenegro, a Loan for IFC's own account of up to eight million euro (EUR 8,000,000) for on-lending by the Borrower to micro and small enterprises in Serbia.  The funds would be for the exclusive use of MFB to on-lend to Eligible Sub-Borrowers.
Role: Since its inception in 2001, MFB has had strong developmental impact by rapidly expanding its services to micro and small  entrepreneurs in Serbia and Montenegro.  The developmental impact of commercially-run micro and small business credit programs on post-conflict transition economy populations with little or no access to formal credit institutions has been well-demonstrated by IFC's more mature microfinance investments in several countries.
Environmental Social Issues: MFB is a category FI Type 1 project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure.  IMI and project technical partner IPC have developed an environmental management framework to ensure that financial institutions in which IMI invests and IPC manage have appropriate Environmental Management Systems (EMS).  IFC''s  Environment Division has approved this environmental framework.  Under the framework, IPC, IMI and MFBY has developed an EMS, requiring activities financed to comply with the applicable environmental, health and safety legislation and standards of Serbia & Montenegro and IFCs Microfinance Exclusion List.  Implementation of the EMS may involve an orientation in cleaner production and a focus on clients presenting the greatest environmental risk and opportunities.  MFB provides an annual environmental performance report to IMI/IPC.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityBank's headquarters in Belgrade.
Sponsor: The Microfinance Bank is owned by IFC, Commerzbank AG (Germany), EBRD, FMO (Netherlands), IMI (Germany) and KfW (Germany) each in the amount of $2,000,000 for a 16.67% share in the common equity of the bank.  IMI, in which IFC has a 13.64% share, is a Frankfurt-based investment company specializing in microfinance.
Cost Nature:
The total project cost is up to EUR 8,000,000 (but not to exceed the equivalent of $8,000,000 at commitment) consisting of two tranches:
Tranche A (a regular tranche) in the amount of up to EUR 4,000,000; 
Tranche B (a stand-by tranche) in the amount of  up to EUR 4,000,000.   
The use of proceeds is to provide sub-loans to eligible sub-borrowers.  Sub-loans repaid and/or prepaid to be used solely for sub-loans to eligible sub-borrowers in accordance with the terms of the loan.
Investment: 8.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan8.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative

Project Description: In June 2000, Austindo Nusantara Jaya (ANJ), Olympus Capital Holdings Asia managing and JP Morgan Partners Asia managing committed $100 million equity capital and created Verdaine Investment Limited (Verdaine, the company), a dedicated vehicle incorporated in Mauritius, to acquire and manage oil palm plantations in Indonesia.  Stakes of the partners are around 31.4%, 35% and 33.6%, respectively.  The companys primary acquisition targets are cash flow positive plantations in Indonesia with growth potential derived primarily from the rehabilitation of ill-maintained areas.  Verdaine plans to acquire, rehabilitate and manage 40,000 to 50,000 hectares of palm oil plantation.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Verdaines plantation and crude palm oil (CPO) mill acquisition procedure includes environmental and social due diligence and the identification of issues that require correction subsequent to purchase of the acquisition target.  Rectification of identified issues for existing and future acquisitions is required to bring environmental and social performance into compliance with Indonesian regulatory requirements and IFC policies and guidelines.  Several aspects of the due diligence model, which will be carried out as part of this investment, need to be strengthened to ensure adequate coverage of the issues typically associated with this industry.    Verdaine has made progress to correct the environmental and social issues identified in external consultants reports for the first acquisition in Northern Sumatra.  Selected issues such as terminating empty fruit branches (EFB) incineration and reuse of whole EFBs as fertilizer in the plantations will be resolved in accordance with a corrective action plan.  Similarly, occupational health and safety, employee retrenchment compensation, and hazardous waste management issues that were identified during due diligence and at the time of IFCs appraisal have not been fully resolved in the plantations and in the CPO mill.  The sponsor will be tasked with resolution of these as well as an overall improvement in occupational health and safety practices and achievement of internationally recognized certification of the occupational health and safety system.  A number of environmental and social issues were identified during due diligence of Verdaines second acquisition target on Belitung Island.  Requirements to rectify the shortcomings for the plantations and CPO mill are captured in the corrective action plan for the project.  IFC will collaborate with the sponsor to ensure that appropriate compliance shortcomings identification and amelioration steps are taken for acquisitions in the offing to ensure compliance with Indonesian regulatory and IFC policy and guideline requirements.   Verdaines annual environmental and social monitoring reports will provide IFC with updates on completion of required ameliorative measures for each specific purchase as well on achievement of global requirements such as institutionalization of occupational health and safety programs within each plantation and CPO mill and with certification of the system for the company as a whole.  Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityLocation of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe environmental documents are available in the following locations: - P.T. Eka Pendawa Sakti, Wisma Bil, 7th Floor, JL. Diponegoro No. 18, MEDAN 20152, - on the company bulletin board of P.T. Eka Pendawa Sakti, located in Kabupaten Tapanuli Selatan, North Sumatra Province and;- on the company bulletin board of PT Sahabat Mewah Dan Makmur located in Kecamatan Dendang and Gantung, Kabupaten Belitung, after the acquisition by Verdaine.
Sponsor: PT Austindo Nusantara Jaya (Austindo, sponsor) is a conglomerate with interests in agribusiness, electric power generation, mining and financial services. Austindo is a 13.11% shareholder of PT Agro Muko a palm oil plantation, where IFC made $2.2 million equity investment for a 7% stake.  Austindo is a solid group with virtually no debt ($128 million equity for $145 million assets in 2002). Olympus Capital Holdings Asia (OCHA) is a direct investment firm dedicated to making long-term equity investments in Asia. Armed with some $600 million in committed capital under management, Olympus Capital targets investments in public and private companies operating in the region and has invested in the financial services, communications, and natural resources sectors.  Ziff Brothers Investments, L.L.C. (ZBI) is the lead investor in the funds managed by Olympus Capital. ZBI, headquartered in New York, is the primary investment vehicle of the Ziff family and related entities, and has several billion dollars under management across a wide range of industries. In addition to funds from ZBI, its affiliates and other private investors, Olympus Capital Holdings Asia also manages Asia Development Partners, LP, a private equity fund supported by financing guaranteed by the Overseas Private Investment Corporation (OPIC).JPMPA manages the $1.1 billion Asia Opportunity Fund L.P. (AOF), the largest pan-Asia direct equity investment fund.  JPMPA has invested in the palm oil, semiconductor, auto parts, mobile telecom, food, internet and technology sectors.  In 1999, IFC made a $100 million equity investment in AOF. AOF plays an active role in recapitalizing and restructuring Asian companies affected by the Asian crisis. The fund, which has a 10 year life, invests principally in Korea, Thailand, Philippines, Indonesia and Malaysia.
Cost Nature: Total project cost is estimated at $200 million.  The proposed  IFC investment is a $40 million loan to Verdaine and/or its operating subsidiaries.

The second investment to be acquired in March 2003 is PT Sahabat Mewah Dan Makmur (SMM), located in Kecamatan Dendang and Gantung, Kabupaten Belitung, in the Province of Bangka  Belitung.  SMM has a 15,000 hectare concession with 8,800 hectare mature area out of 12,000 hectare planted.

Company Name: Inversiones y Valores Milenium, S.A. de C.V.
Project Description:
Copamex S.A de C.V. (Copamex, or the company) is a leading Mexican producer of paper products for the consumer goods, industrial packaging and printing, and writing (P&W) markets.  Located in Monterrey, Copamex is a holding company with 39 subsidiaries (35 in Mexico, 2 in the United States, 1 in Costa Rica and 1 in Nicaragua) of which 36 are wholly-owned and 3 are majority-owned joint ventures. 

The company is embarking on a debt reduction and refinancing strategy which will enhance its financial flexibility and its ability to compete effectively.  As part of this strategy, Copamex has requested IFC's assistance to refinance part of its long term debt and to fund capital expenditure aimed at rationalizing existing facilities.  IFC will help Copamex improve its financial profile in order for the company to become a stronger regional player, better able to compete with multi-nationals.  The principal components of the project are as follows: 
financial restructuring and other measures designed to improve the ability of the company to access national and international sources of finance on competitive terms;
rationalization of existing facilities; and 
measures to improve corporate governance and environmental management and enhance the social impact of the company.
Role:
As the company shifts its production focus toward areas in which it has stronger competitive advantages, Copamex's profitability will increase. Specifically, consumer and packaging products will be emphasized taking full advantage of the Company's proximity to the market and its brands.  By refinancing US dollar debt with new peso financing with longer maturity, the company's foreign exchange risks will be reduced and longer maturities will free up resources.  Consequently, the enhancement of  Copamex's liquidity will allow its management to better focus on production and market issues and have the resources to invest in improvements.  The Project is also expected to support the viability of an important source of employment for 6,878 people in the company.  

Copamex contributes to the hygienic living standards of the people in the country through the production and distribution of affordable consumer products to all segments of the society.  The company significantly contributes to recycling wastepaper and cardboard generated in Mexico and abroad, since around two thirds of its raw material fiber is recycled.  By adopting IFC's environmental, health and safety policies and guidelines, the company will improve to stricter international practices and reduce risk to the public, while renewed emphasis on safety will provide its employees with safer working conditions.

IFC Role:
Provide long-term financing better suited to the Copamex's business dynamics.  While Mexico has enjoyed better access to capital following its investment grade rating, the current market volatility and the recessive environment will make it difficult for the company to raise long-term refinancing without IFC's involvement;
IFC expects also to provide some advisory services to improve corporate governance, environmental and social matters.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an environmental review category B project.  Environmental, social, occupational health and safety issues include: air emissions from boilers, generators and other sources; process water use and process and sanitary wastewater treatment and disposal; energy efficiency; hazardous and solid waste management; hazardous materials storage and handling; fire protection and emergency response; general workplace health and safety including exposure to noise and chemicals; and management of staff reduction program.  Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe environmental document Environmental Review Summary (ERS) will be available at Copamex's headquarters (see below for address) and on the company's website: www.copamex.com.
Sponsor:
The Maldonado Quiroga family of Monterrey (Mexico) founded the Copamex in 1928 and still maintains approximately 100% ownership.  The Maldonado family has two branches, namely the well known and reputable Maldonado Elizondo and Maldonado Gonzalez families.  The members of the Maldonado Elizondo family own in aggregate 92% of the company and play a bigger role in the management of the Copamex than the Maldonado Gonzalez family with 8%.

The Maldonado family is active in philanthropic and charitable causes through the Fundación de Beneficiencia Maldonado Quiroga, a 14-year old not-for-profit entity that gives donations to low-income groups in Monterrey.
Cost Nature:
The estimated Project Cost of $262 million is to refinance part of the company's debt and to fund capital expenditure for modernizing and rationalizing some of the Copamex's existing facilities.  The capital expenditure component of the project is not part of an expansion program, it consists instead of various investments necessary to keep the facilities competitive.  

The IFC's proposed investment would consist of a up to $50 million A loan for IFC's own account, a up to $107 million B loan for the account of participants banks, and a up to S$25 million quasi-equity C loan for IFC's account.  The company has expressed interest in obtaining Mexican peso financing in order to minimize its foreign exchange exposure and as such IFC is considering providing its A loan in pesos, arranging local currency parallel loans (the 'Parallel Loan', for the account of local lenders) to replace the IFC B loan.  In the event that the Parallel Loan is insufficient, IFC will consider swapping any IFC B loan then required to complete the financing plan in pesos.
Investment: 25.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk Management0.0GuaranteeLoan25.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The company headquarters are located in Monterrey, in the State of Nuevo Leon, which borders with the United States (Texas). The Copamex's main facilities are located in the states of Nuevo Leon, Chihuahua, Mexico State, Michoacán and Jalisco. The company also has other facilities in the United States and Central America.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is an environmental review category B project.  Environmental, social, occupational health and safety issues include: air emissions from boilers, generators and other sources; process water use and process and sanitary wastewater treatment and disposal; energy efficiency; hazardous and solid waste management; hazardous materials storage and handling; fire protection and emergency response; general workplace health and safety including exposure to noise and chemicals; and management of staff reduction program.  Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe environmental document Environmental Review Summary (ERS) will be available at Copamex's headquarters (see below for address) and on the company's website: www.copamex.com.

Project Name: GEF Mongolia Egin-Uur Watershed Conservation Initiative
Project Description: The American flyfishing company, Sweetwater Travel and its Mongolian parner, Hovsgol Travel, have been operating a successful flyfishing ecotourism business on the Eg and Uur rivers since 1995.  The two companies established an NGO, the Taimen Conservation Fund (TCF), to assist the local communities manage the EUWA natural resources.The project aims to establish a partnership between the local communities, government institutions and bodies, and tourist companies to collaboratively and proactively establish a natural resource management regime for the Eg-Uur Watershed Area (EUWA) in the north-western region of Mongolia.  The underlying rationale of the project is to treat wildlife as a locally managed concessionable natural resource, rather than a simple public good, thereby enabling the local communities to maximize the economic returns from its use.  The financial sustainability and biodiversity conservation vehicle for the project is high-end, low impact catch and release flyfishing ecotourism.  The project promotes poverty reduction by supporting community based initiatives in sustainable land and resource use.  The GEF intervention provides the conditions to initiate a natural resource user fee system, which will tap into these returns to fund biodiversity conservation and community development  on a financially sustainable basis.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project, according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The review of this project consisted of appraising technical and environmental /social information submitted by the project sponsors and field visits by IFC Environment and Social Development Department staff.  The following potential environmental, social, health and safety impacts of the project were analyzed:·	Potential for economic and physical displacement as a result of conservation measures·	Identification of local populations as indigenous peoples·	Collaborative management structure and local consultation·	Resource conservation measures and law enforcement activities·	Regional and cumulative impacts·	Environmental monitoring and evaluation programLocation of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe ERS was posted according to the IFC public disclosure guidelines in the Bulgan & Hovsgol provincial center post offices, and the seven districts in the EUWA majors offices.  An announcement was posted in the Bulgan & Hovsgol provincial newspapers.
Sponsor: The project will be implemented by the Taimen Conservation Fund (TCF), a Mongolian NGO established by  Sweetwater Travel, and Hovsgol Travel.  The project will be carried out with significant support from Sweetwater Travel, an American fly fishing company, Hovsgol Travel, its Mongolian partner, World Wildlife Fund, and the Mongolian Business Development Agency (MBDA), a Mongolian NGO with ten years of operating experience in Mongolia.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is $1,906,000.  Of this amount, $975,000 is being sought from the Global Environment Facility(GEF). The GEF funds will be channeled through IFC in its capacity as GEF Executing Agency.
Location: The Eg-Uur watershed area (EUWA) is located in a remote region of Norther Mongolia where the Eg and Uur rivers meet.  The high priority biodiversity conservation zone that is the focus of this project consists of approximately 15,000 Ha within the EUWA.  The Eg river is 474 km in length with 40,454 km2 of catchment area, originates from Lake Hovsgol and flows south where it meets with the Uur river.  The Uur river is 331 km in length with 12,300 km2 of catchment area, originates from the Kheven-Saluu mountains in NE Hovsgol Province and flows south until it meets the Eg river.  The combined Eg-Uur, recognized from this point on as the Eg river, flows for another 200 km until it reaches the Selenge river.  The triangular shape watershed area, consisting of the Eg and Uur rivers until the point of confluence with the Selenge river is recognized as the Eg-Uur Watershead Area, a total area of aproximately3.48 million Ha.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project, according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The review of this project consisted of appraising technical and environmental /social information submitted by the project sponsors and field visits by IFC Environment and Social Development Department staff.  The following potential environmental, social, health and safety impacts of the project were analyzed:·	Potential for economic and physical displacement as a result of conservation measures·	Identification of local populations as indigenous peoples·	Collaborative management structure and local consultation·	Resource conservation measures and law enforcement activities·	Regional and cumulative impacts·	Environmental monitoring and evaluation programLocation of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe ERS was posted according to the IFC public disclosure guidelines in the Bulgan & Hovsgol provincial center post offices, and the seven districts in the EUWA majors offices.  An announcement was posted in the Bulgan & Hovsgol provincial newspapers.

Project Description:
Taj Maldives Private Limited (TMPL, or the company) is a subsidiary of Taj Asia Limited affiliated with the Taj Group, one of the leading hotel chains in India and part of the Tata Group. TMPL owns and operates two resorts in the Maldives.  The company is proposing to refinance its existing debt of $17 million, on a limited-recourse basis (the project).  IFC will consider a long-term loan of up to $8.5 million to TMPL and further assist through a B-Loan syndication of an additional $8.5 million.

Due to limited appetite of banks for long-term financing in Maldives, companies operating in the Maldives have found it difficult to raise long-term debt on a limited-recourse basis. In the past, TMPL financed capital expenditure in its two properties with a combination of short term debt, cash generation, inter-company loans and small equity investments. TMPL would now like to refinance these loans totaling $17 million with longer-term loans, on a limited or non-recourse basis.
Role:
Tourism is one of two mainstays of the Maldives economy (the other is fishing) but it relies on expensive and scarce stopgap financing that threatens the long term financial health of firms in the sector.  Until now, TMPL has relied on parent support to find reasonably priced mid-term finance.  The proposed refinancing will put the company on a sustainable financial structure and the involvement of other financiers will introduce the company to international markets on a stand-alone basis.  In addition, linkages with the rest of the economy will also be created in fishing, and food and beverage supplies.  Taj Group brings extensive training and international best practices in operating resorts which will increase the skill levels of local employees.  

IFC has a strong role in supporting the project as it provides:

- Access to long-term capital. IFC would provide limited-recourse, long-term debt (ten or nine years) to TMPL, as financing on these terms is generally not available in the Maldives. Such support for TMPL will be a signal to the international commercial finance community of the improved investment climate in the country, as well as of the commercial viability of investment in the key tourism sector.  IFC may also help mobilize additional long term financing by way of B-Loan syndication. IFC involvement will help implement an appropriate financial structure in the company.
- Attract international financial institutions to participate in investments in Maldives.  IFC may also help the company mobilize additional long term financing by way of B-Loan syndication.
- Technical assistance in environmental and social best practices.  While TMPL has been environmentally responsible in most aspects of operations, IFC has leveraged its ability to mobilize scarce long-term financing by convincing the company to implement a fire, life safety and water treatment improvements.  In addition, TMPL will participant in a coral reef restoration program initiated by the IFC.
- Encouragement of 'south to south' Foreign Direct Investment.  Taj Group is a leading Indian company with investments in Sri Lanka, Maldives, Nepal, Goa, and Zambia.  The company's expansion strategy includes investment in other developing countries such as Mauritius and Seychelles that demonstrate an increase in demand in global tourism.  IFC's investment will support foreign direct investment from India to other Part II countries.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.  Environmental, social, health and safety issues associated with this project include: management of resort operation waste streams and emissions; management of resort operation impacts on the marine environment, including coral reefs and marine fauna; life and fire safety of resort guests and employees; and employee occupational health and safety.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: TMPL is a 100% subsidiary of Taj Asia (TA), which is a 50:50 joint venture between Taj Group and Cigen Corporation.  The Taj Group is the hospitality business arm of the Tata Group and operator of the two properties of TMPL.  Taj Group will leverage its hotels and resorts management experience to run the TMPL properties.  The flagship company of Taj Group is Indian Hotels Company Limited (IHCL) which has 50 properties in India and 10 properties overseas.  Other companies in Taj Group include Oriental Hotels Ltd, Taj International Hotel Ltd, Taj Asia, and PIEM Hotels Ltd.   Cigen Corporation is controlled by Chaudhary Group of Nepal. Chaudhary Group owns 5% of Cigen directly and the balance through associates. Chaudhary Group is engaged in banking, insurance and consumer goods sectors in Nepal.
Cost Nature: Total project cost is estimated at $17 million.  The proposed IFC investment is a $8.5 million A loan and a $8.5 million syndicated B Loan.
Investment: 8.50 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan8.50Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: TMPL is located in the Republic of Maldives and operates Taj Exotica and Taj Coral Reef resorts on the islands of Emboodhu Finolhu and Hembadhoo in the Male Atolls.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.  Environmental, social, health and safety issues associated with this project include: management of resort operation waste streams and emissions; management of resort operation impacts on the marine environment, including coral reefs and marine fauna; life and fire safety of resort guests and employees; and employee occupational health and safety.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Description: The weakness of Russia's financial sector and its inability to mobilize and allocate resources efficiently are major constraints on Russia's ability to sustain macro-economic growth over the long term. This, combined with the lack of access to international debt markets and the limited availability of long term funding, are major impediments to its overall economic growth.  As a result, Russian private sector companies and exporters are prevented from making much needed capital investments as well as obtaining import and export financing for their products. Following the recent upturn in Russia's economy, Russian companies are seeing emerging opportunities recorded in the increased level of trade between Western countries and Russia. The proposed project will help BCEN-EuroBank (or the bank) to provide critically lacking term resources and trade lines to private Russian corporations. In addition, by providing term resources at time when the bank is going through a transition from state to private ownership, IFC will lend credibility to BCEN-EuroBank and enhance its privatization prospects. It is expected that ultimately, the success of the privatization will free up resources from the public sector and lay the groundwork for creating a sustainable private sector bank.
Role: The proposed project will help BCEN-EuroBank to provide critically lacking term resources and trade lines to private Russian corporations. In addition, by providing term resources at time when the bank is going through a transition from state to private ownership, IFC will lend credibility to BCEN-EuroBank and enhance its privatization prospects. It is expected that the success of the privatization will ultimately free up resources from the public sector and lay the groundwork for creating a sustainable private sector bank.
Environmental Social Issues:
BCEN-EuroBank will be required to develop an environmental management system to ensure that investments under relevant operations meet host country environmental, health and safety requirements.  IFC will assess BCEN-EuroBanks capacity for environmental review.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Sponsor:
The sponsor of the project is Banque Commerciale pour l'Europe du Nord  Eurobank (BCEN-EuroBank). Incorporated in 1921 in France, it is 87% majority owned by the Central Bank of the Russian (CBR).  BCEN-EuroBank was established primarily to facilitate trade between France and ex-USSR and later between the Russian Federation (RF) and the rest of the world.  Following the break up of the Soviet Union in 1991, the bank was part of a network of Soviet banking subsidiaries abroad (Sovzagranbanks) that the CBR inherited from the former Vnesheconombank, This network comprised of other banks such as Moscow Narodny Bank (IFC is currently considering a loan to this bank), Donau Bank A.G, Russian Commercial Bank, Ost-West Handelsbank A.G. and East-West United bank S.A. 

These banking affiliates form a banking network encompassing all the major European financial centers namely, Paris, London, Vienna, Frankfurt, Zurich and Luxembourg. On the basis of financial statements for the year 2002 statutory auditors certify that BCEN-EuroBank's total assets amounted to Euro 1,3 billion, with capital stock of Euro 94 million; the bank posted a profit of Euro 35 million after taxes.
Cost Nature: The project consists of medium term loan of up to $100 million to BCEN-EuroBank.  The loan is intended to fund the growth of BCEN-EuroBank loan portfolio and trade finance related activities with Russian companies.
Investment: 100.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan100.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: BCEN -EuroBank headquarters are in Paris.  The proceeds of IFC's facility will be used to extend medium term credit facilities to privately owned and creditworthy Russian companies.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati:
BCEN-EuroBank will be required to develop an environmental management system to ensure that investments under relevant operations meet host country environmental, health and safety requirements.  IFC will assess BCEN-EuroBanks capacity for environmental review.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
