Project Description:
Merec Industries Lda (or the company) was founded in 1998 and began producing maize meal and coconut oil in its new factory erected in the Maputo suburb of Machava in January and September 1999 respectively.  In December 2000, IFC approved and signed a guarantee to help finance the construction of the wheat mill in Machava-Maputo (Project Number: 10185). The project is successful and achieved 100% of its production capacity two years ahead of appraisal projections.

Merec II is a project for the expansion of Merec Industries Lda's wheat mill processing activities in Mozambique. Merec intends to build a new wheat mill including grain storage silos in Beira, the capital of Sofala Province and the second largest city in Mozambique.  A new 140tonne/24h Buhler mill and silos with storage capacity of 12,500 tonnes will be installed in new buildings, with production scheduled to begin in 2005. 

Following Merec's success with the first project in Maputo, the company management decided to test the market for Merec's products in the Beira region to the north of Maputo using a portion of its output from the Maputo wheat mill plant.  The good quality of the product and the reliable distribution of Africom (a distribution company owned the sponsors of Merec Industries Lda) have contributed towards the success of this experiment in Beira.  Merec is now selling 12,000 tonnes of flour per year in this area but is experiencing demand for this in the South so that once the Beira project is complete there will be no problem switching back.  The opportunity in Central Mozambique will be fully exploited through this expansion project.
Role:
The project development impact can be summarized in the following categories:

-  Enterprise Development: Merec is interested in participating in supply chain and distributor chain linkages, which with the assistance of IFC can help the growth of small and micro enterprises (MSME's).  This will involve the provision of technical assistance for the local micro and small bakeries, which will use their products. . Merec's new project will create opportunities for many small businesses to supply goods and services to the plant.  A growth in the supply chain will also come about as Merec will be distributing its increased volume through a network of small scale distributors and in some cases directly to new small bakeries.  Merec has also requested the support of IFC in the development of the company's HIV/Aids awareness and treatment programs. 

-  Economic Growth: The World Bank Group's objectives in Mozambique include supporting the Government's program for poverty reduction by investing in sustainable industrial projects.  The Merec expansion project will add economic value and create 48 new, direct jobs.  Merec will provide the necessary on-the-job training for supervision and technical staff in order to improve skills and strengthen the industrial base.  Merec will source its packaging locally and will also promote local transport companies which will be subcontracted to carry grain and finished product.

-  Provision of Finance: IFC is providing financial backing through the guarantee facility thereby enhancing the ability of a local bank in Mozambique to make a long-term loan available to the project.  There is a shortage of long term project finance available in Mozambique because of the need for bank liquidity and perceptions of risk.
Sponsor: The main sponsors of the project are Mr. Mhamud Charania and his mother Mrs Gulsham Ramji.  Mr. Mhamud Charania is a 37-year-old British citizen and holds a mechanical engineering degree from the University of Toronto. He is dynamic, enthusiastic and is well respected by his staff.  He is an influential member of the Ismaili community in Maputo.  Mrs Ramji is 69 years old and is essentially retired.  The sponsors came to Mozambique in 1994.  They established Africom Lda which has been successfully trading in and distributing basic commodities such as sugar, rice, oil, soap, biscuits, and maize and wheat flour, sourced locally and abroad.  They founded Merec Industries Lda in 1998.  Part of the Merec complex is rented to Africom.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $4,950,000.  The proposed IFC investment is a Guarantee Facility of $ 2.5 million to guarantee the loan that will be provided to Merec by Banco Standard Totta de Mozambique (BSTM).
Investment: 2.39 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuarantee2.39LoanEquity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The Merec II project will be located in Beira.  The location in Beira, the biggest market in Mozambique, is one of the major strengths of this project in addition to the close proximity to the port.  The Beira region is one of the most populated parts of the country with an abundant labor force.  The site consists of two hectares of unoccupied land within the Beira industrial area.  Power, water and other utilities are nearby and available.
Sector: AA - Grain Processing (Milling, Starch, Flour, Malt)

Company Name: GEM VII Targeted Value Income Fund
Project Description:
Quasi-Equity investment of up to $30 million in GEM VII Targeted Value Debt Fund (the fund or the company). The proposed fund is a closed-end special purpose vehicle, structured as a Collateralized Bond Obligation (CBO), which will invest in emerging market debt issues. The fund is structured to offer investment opportunities both to existing emerging markets investors and to credit-quality sensitive institutional investors who can only invest in investment-grade instruments. The fund is expected to be at least 70% invested in 30 countries at closing in June 2003, in a globally diversified portfolio of US dollar denominated debt issues from emerging markets. Against the assets of the fund, three classes of obligations:
-  Senior Notes, 
-  Second Priority Notes, and 
-  Preference Shares - are expected to be issued in an amount of $400 million. 
The Senior and Second Priority Notes will be over-collateralized and credit-enhanced by the Preference Shares and are targeted to receive a higher investment grade rating of Aa2 and Baa2 from Moody's, and AA and BBB- from S&P, respectively. The Senior Notes will be wrapped by a monoline insurer guarantee to achieve a rating of Aaa/AAA. 
The fund will invest in emerging market corporate, quasi-sovereign, and sovereign debt securities and is a vehicle designed to support the World Bank Group strategy of promoting the development of corporate debt markets in the member developing countries.
Role:
The fund is to play an important role in enhancing the status of emerging markets corporate debt as a distinct asset class for international institutional investors.  Consequent to the global economic downturn, retrenchment of banks and hedge funds from emerging market debt has seriously affected domestic companies' accessibility to foreign funding. New issuance of corporate paper has declined to $19 billion in 2002 from a high of $41 billion in 1997. Through investment in this fund, IFC will encourage dedicated fixed income fund managers in this asset class to successfully create new products in the form of structured debt funds that are designed to modify the return/risk profile of emerging market assets to tap those investors who are limited to investment grade securities and increase the overall demand for emerging market corporate debt, thereby facilitating emerging markets companies to access the international capital markets either to lower their funding costs or extend their debt maturities or both. 

Traditionally, the emerging markets investment pool has largely been limited to investors in high-yield bonds, a relatively specialized investor group with limited resources for high-risk classes of assets. By structuring a specialized investment vehicle for large credit-rating-sensitive institutional investors to access emerging market debt securities, IFC would send a strong signal that IFC is committed to develop innovative financial instruments for these investors. 

According to the fund manager's initial market soundings, investors are hesitant about investing in emerging market debt issues.  In order to move the fund forward, TCW must structure the subordinate tranche of the CBO, which is always the most challenging component in such transactions. This problem has been further compounded as institutional investors are trying to reduce risk on their balance sheets and have limited appetite for emerging market exposure. Participation by a strong investor like IFC in the subordinate tranche at the early stage is likely to have a significant catalytic effect and be critical to the distribution and placement of the fund.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is an environmental review category FI-1 project. All potential corporates considered for inclusion in the underlying asset pool will require that the issuer''s business does not involve activities on IFC''s exclusion list. Corporates from companies with known poor environmental and/or social practices will also be excluded. The fund Manager will insure the screening procedure is applied to determine the suitability of the corporates for inclusion in the asset pool.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Sponsor: TCW Asset Management Company will be the fund Manager. TCW Asset Management Company is a wholly owned subsidiary of the TCW Group, Inc. (collectively TCW), which is an indirect subsidiary of Société Générale, S.A.  As of December 31, 2002, TCW had approximately $80 billion assets under management, including over $3.7 billion in emerging market debt. TCW has 14 debt funds under its management, of which eight are emerging market debt funds with CBO structures.
Cost Nature: The expected size of the fund is $400 million. IFC proposes to invest $20 million in the Preference Shares and $10 million in the Second Priority Notes.
Investment: 30.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity30.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The location of the project is Los Angeles, USA

Project Description:
Citibank Kazakhstan (CK, or the bank) is a fully licensed commercial bank.  It offers to its resident and non-resident clients a complete range of banking products for domestic and cross-border operations in both Kazakh tenge and foreign currencies.  CK has been based in Kazakhstan since 1994 and was fully incorporated in on May 12, 1998.  As of December 31, 2002, the bank's total assets stood at $349.8 million equivalent and the total capital equaled $54.8 million equivalent including the subordinated debt.

The project involves the provision of long-term funding of up to $20 million to the Bank to support the expansion of its mid-term lending operations. Through this loan IFC will enhance the supply of much-needed finance to the local private sector. With the increased economic activity in Kazakhstan over the last two years, due to favorable oil prices and a stable economy, there is undoubtedly a substantially increased demand from companies for longer term financing.  The proposed investment is therefore intended, although in a small way, to address this demand.  A secondary benefit is that it will increase competitiveness in the country's banking system
Role:
The project will have a major impact on two areas that are critical for development in Kazakhstan:  

-  Availability of term financing for long-term projects. The project's principal development impact is its direct contribution in addressing Kazakhstan's critical  constraint to future sustainable economic growth. Furthermore, the proceeds of the loan will be on-lent to private sector companies which will contribute to the potential job creation.

-  The development of competition in the banking sector. 

IFC's loan would help extend the maturity of CK's funding base, enabling the bank to provide longer-term and affordable funds for corporate borrowers.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is an environmental and social review category FI type 2 project.  The bank will be required to demonstrate that its environmental management system is adequate to address the projects finance under the loan.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Description: HVB Ukraine, ( the bank or the company) formerly known as Bank Austria Creditanstalt Ukraine (BACAU), was set up in 1997 by Creditanstalt (67.5%) a local Ukrainian bank Aval (12.5%), and IFC (20%).  Following mergers between Creditanstalt and Bank Austria and then between Bank Austria and Hypovereinsbank Group, the HVB Ukraine became part of the Hypovereinsbank Group in late 2001.The project is to provide HVB Ukraine with an up to $15 million Guarantee Facility to enable the bank to solidify and expand its client base and reach more medium-sized Ukrainian corporates.  The Guarantee Facility will be provided through HVB Ukraines parent, HVB Munich (HVB AG) for the portions of loans to HVB Ukraine clients which exceed HVB Ukraines single exposure limit. IFC will assume 95% risk of the HVB, AG share of the syndicated loan.  Maximum loan sizes covered by the IFC guarantee will hence be twice HVB Ukraines limit (i.e. $ 6 million).  Thus, IFCs maximum exposure would be 47.5% - with HVB Ukraine taking 50% of the loan and IFC guaranteeing 95% of the balance.  IFC would retain the right of refusal over each transaction. HVB has provided a pipeline of projects as potential loans under this facility.
Role: The developmental impact of this project is high as it achieves the following objectives in a frontier country:-  Provide larger amounts of financing to Ukrainian companies, in need of longer and larger financial resources that are scarce in Ukraine due to underdeveloped banking sector.-  Allow a well-managed bank increase its loan portfolio, reach more Ukrainian clients and better manage its assets and liabilities position.IFCs support to HVB Ukraine will help the company reach more clients in need of financing. IFCs Guarantee Facility will provide the bank with needed financing in an environment where long-term financial resources are still scarce.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an FI Type 2 project.  HVB Ukraine will be required to demonstrate that its existing environmental management system and environmental performance standards for investments are adequate to address the projects anticipated to be guaranteed through the project.  IFC will assess HVB Ukraines EMS.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: HVB Ukraine is owned by HVB Group (91.3%) and IFC (8.7%).  HypoVereinsbank ranks third among Europes banking groups.  In 2002 the Groups total assets and equity stood at approximately EURO 715 billion and EURO 17.3 billion respectively.  Following the above mentioned mergers, HVB inherited a loss-making bank, with deteriorated capital.  Both IFC and Aval decided not to participate in the supplement capital increase while HVB injected $5 million to ensure that the bank complied with prudential requirements.  As a result, IFCs shareholding was diluted from 20% to 8.7% and Aval bank sold its stake to HVB.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is $15 million dollars and it consists of an IFC Guarantee Facility to be provided to HVB Ukraine.

Project Description: The project will be a two-stage effort to support expansion of an Export Securitization Program (the program) organized by a consortium of Argentine banks. The banks are led by HSBC Bank Argentina S.A. (HSBC), BBVA Banco Frances S.A. (BBVA) and Banco Rio de La Plata S.A. (BRLP and together they are called the Arrangers). The program provides pre-shipment export financing to Argentine corporates.The two stages of the program will be structured through Financial Trusts incorporated in Argentina under Law 24.441 (the Trust), to be created by HSBC, BBVA and BRLP as Arrangers and Trustors. The Trusts will acquire predetermined USD-denominated, pre-shipment export loans originated by the Arrangers, and will fund this origination activity by issuing USD-denominated short-term debt notes (the Notes or the Securities). The Notes will be issued under the Argentine public offering regime and will be registered with the Comision Nacional de Valores (CNV).  Preliminarily, domestic pension funds (AFJPs) will be targeted as investors for the Notes.  In the short-term, the project is expected to support further expansion of the program, in order to make it more widely available for Argentine exporters.  This may catalyze a significant mobilization of funding from pension funds, which are currently quite liquid, to the cash-strapped export sector. Given the current state of the Argentine banking sector  which has traditionally funded trade finance activity in the country  such a mobilization is essential in order to provide needed funding to Argentine exporters.  A medium-term objective of the project (and the program) is to attract international investors to an asset class with a relatively attractive commercial structure, but where perceived Argentine country risk is mitigated.The project will have two stages.  In a first stage, IFC would support the execution of an up to $40 million financing under the program (EXPO II), by providing a stand-by purchase commitment to the Arrangers for up to $10 million.  This purchase commitment can be accessed -- at the Arrangers'' sole discretion -- in order to cover an under-subscription or achieve an over-subscription of Notes to be issued.  IFCs participation in the first stage of the program would be instrumental to replicate the success of the initial EXPO transaction, given that:-  EXPO II is larger than EXPO I, -  domestic pension funds are still not well acquainted with the program, and -  EXPO II will securitize assets from a larger group of exporters.In a second stage, a larger transaction (EXPO III) including around 30 smaller exporters is planned. As a result of the more diverse credit profile of this second group of exporters and nature of assets underlying a proposed securitization undertaken on their behalf, it is expected that credit rating agencies will require a junior/subordinated tranche in Notes issued by the Trust for EXPO III, and that a two-tier funding structure is therefore necessary in order for the Notes to achieve a credit rating compatible with pension funds investment guidelines.  In this second stage of the project, IFCs investment participation in EXPO III would entail subscription of up to a $5 million portion of a junior Notes tranche to be issued by the Trust, as well as a stand-by purchase commitment to the transactions Trust for up to $5 million.
Role: As a result of cutbacks in conventional trade finance from international and domestic banks due to Argentinas debt servicing difficulties, its bank crisis, as well as global risk aversion, Argentine exporters  even top-notch domestic names  face difficulties in obtaining pre- and post-shipment trade funding.The project is primarily meant to help address this situation by :-  Providing new sources of funding to exporters, thereby allowing them to capitalize on their improved underlying international competitiveness as a result of currency depreciation.  -  Promoting development of Argentinas capital markets by increasing the supply of a new asset class (i.e., securitized trade finance receivables) that may prove to be an attractive investment opportunity for domestic institutional investors (principally pension funds), who have ample and growing liquidity; and-  Encouraging further development of a relatively low credit risk asset class (i.e., trade finance receivables securitized via a well-designed transactional structure and incorporating offshore payment mechanisms), which may be attractive to international investors, thereby enticing them to gradually return to Argentina in the medium term.     IFCs role in this transaction is four-fold: -  Supporting an initiative to bring much needed new trade finance funding to Argentine exporters; -  Collaborating with a major domestic financial intermediary to mobilize funding from pension funds system for the countrys export sector;  -  Helping to expand use of a new financing structure to smaller and less sophisticated exporters; and -  Demonstrating that an innovative structure which mitigates cross-border risk is viable.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category C project according to IFCs environmental review procedure.  No further environmental review is required.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The major sponsors are the following banks:-  HSBC Bank Argentina S.A.HSBC Bank Argentina S.A. (HSBC or the bank) is a fully owned subsidiary of HSBC Holdings plc. Headquartered in London, HSBC Holdings is one of the largest banking and financial services organizations in the world. The HSBC Group comprises over 9500 offices in 80 countries and territories around the world.  HSBC Bank Argentinas interest in general banking include: investment banking, corporate banking, cash management, leasing, personal banking and asset management.-  BBVA Banco Frances. BBVA Banco Frances S.A., ( BBVA or the bank) formerly known as Banco Frances S.A., a subsidiary of Spain''s Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria S.A., operates a banking network of 303 branches throughout Argentina, excluding those of its subsidiaries. The bank provides a full range of financial services to large corporations, middle-market businesses and individual consumers. The Corporate Banking Division specializes in business with large international and domestic companies or companies that belong to an international group. This division has three branches dedicated to serve groups of companies from Europe, the United States and the rest of the world and companies in Argentina. The Middle Market Division handles the relationship with small and medium-sized companies, and has a network in Argentina specialized in serving the small and medium-sized company segment. The Retail Banking Division is in charge of commercial relations with individuals, shops and small companies.-  Banco Rio de la Plata. Banco Rio de la Plata, (BRLP or the bank) is the second largest private bank in Argentina and member of Banco Santander Central Hispano (BSCH) Group, operates through a network of 250 branches offering commercial and investment banking services to nearly one million customers. Its services include saving and checking accounts, certificates of deposit, insurance, asset management, and credit card services. The bank also provides auto, agricultural, and mortgage loans.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $50 million. The proposed IFC investment is a $20 million stand-by purchase commitment for IFCs own account.
Investment: 10.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan10.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The program will provide support to Argentine exporters through pre-shipment export financing to be granted to companies in diverse sectors, including but not limited to: food, oil &gas, petrochemicals, steel, agribusiness, etc.

Project Description: The core objective of the LAC SME Program will be to promote private sector development through support to SMEs with the aim of fostering job creation and reducing poverty in the host countries.  The program will develop projects that can lead to the creation of replicable models with the establishment of strong partnerships between donors, the government, the local private sector, and other relevant actors, with IFC as the catalyst.The program will focus its efforts on implementation activties in the following core areas:-  Supporting the development of clusters in specific sectors	- in Bolivia - wood, tourism, llama, wool, quinoa, textiles	- in Peru - tourism, textiles, white maize	- in Honduras - wood, tourism, and ornamental plants	- in Nicaragua - tourism and wood-Improving the business enabling environment by supporting selected government red tape reduction initiatives (e.g. registration and licensing simplification);-  Improving the capacity of financial institutions to better serve the SME market;-  -  Linkage programs to be developed around IFC investments, where the SME Department''s linkages team would work to build the capacity of small and medium business to provide inputs and services to larges companies;-  Special Programs  - depending on donor support, a number of additional activities with innovative foundations, NGOs, universities etc. are envisaged.  This will include support to microfinance institutions for capacity building, training, roll-out of new technologies, i.e. mobile ATM machines with thumb print identification, and SME development programs to link micro rural producers into urban and export marketsThe program will be executed with the benefit of the best practices available from other project development facilities and the Private Enterprise Partnership (PEP) model that implements technical assistance to SMEs in the former Soviet Union countries.IFC''s Role:  IFC has taken the lead in designing and fund-raising for the program, and once established, the World Bank Group SME Department in close collaboration with the IFC LAC regional Department will manage the program on behalf of IFC and other donors.  IFC''s role will be to transfer best practice in the thematic areas envisaged for support and to use the experience accummulated in SME development through other PDFs and the PEP to support SMEs development in program countries.  IFC can also draw upon its strategic partnership with best practice partners ( for eg, FUNDES, ACCION, SEAF)  in areas ranging from business development services, SME finance to the enabling environment to develop cutting edge programs using these "best practice partners" experience worldwide.  Additionally, as part of the WBG, IFC is uniquely placed to create synergies between ongoing policy reform aimed at private sector development work supported by Bank PSD projects and  activities aimed at supporting SMEs. Development Impact:  The majority of the private sector firms in the region are SMEs and many operate in the informal sectors, largely due to the numerous constraints they face that are common across countries.  The program will help to address these constraints, promote robust SME sectors in these countries and foster much-needed job creation, which are essential requirements for poverty reduction in the region. Where applicable, prior to  each project''s commencement, IFC will take a baseline measure which will be used to assess the development impact throughout the life of the project as measured by its contribution to inter alia: market development, demand driven business development services, improvements in the business environment, increase in value added exports and local sales, and economic and social welfare (increased employment, poverty reduction). IFC currently operations eight PDFs worldwide, which have provided high impact, targeted assistance to thousands of SMEs in diverse regions.  The program will build upon the experience and knowledge-base that has been accummulated in these operations.  It will benefit from the facilities-wide strengthening program now underway, which places more focus on cost recovery, domestic capacity building, sustainability, a broader range of service offerings, partnership, donor exit arrangements and metrics.The program will also draw on the PEP model that IFC has established in former Soviet Union countries.  The Partnership has demonstrated that its technical assistance programs have shown positive results in creating job and in increasing local income, building financial market, improving corporate governance and environmental practices, and shaping legislation aimed at improving the investment climate.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category C project, according to IFC''s Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because it is likely to have minimal or no adverse environmental impacts.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The project sponsors are IFC, bilateral donors and multilateral institutions.  IFC staff has held several discussions with potential partners, and a number of bilateral donors and multilateral institutions have indicated in principle support for the proposed operations.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at up to $30 million over a 5-year period (2003-2008).  IFC would be requested to provide a $2.0 million grant per year over the 5-year operational period, for a total of $10 million, representing up to 33% of the total funding requirements.  The remaining financing will be sought from bilateral donors and multilateral institutions.
Location: The proposed LAC SME Program will be managed by the WBG SME Department in close collaboration with the IFC LAC Regional Department and would cover Bolivia, Honduras, Nicaragua, and Peru with activities to be undertaken based on clearly identified demands and opportunities in each country.  These four countries have been chosen for a variety of reasons: -  they are all macroeconomically stable and have implemented structural reforms, yet incomes remain low (Honduras and Nicaragua are the poorest countries in Central America and Bolivia is the poorest in South America); -  they share a similar profile of the enterprise sector with few large enterprises, a huge number of informal microenterprises, and a missing middle of vibrant SMEs; -  all four governments assign priority to strengthening the SME sector and have official initiatives either underway or in the pipeline, to enhance productivity and competitiveness, which constitute a basis for the proposed Program; -  the program also builds upon existing IFC linkage work and upon the SME Department''s existing activities, especially in Bolivia and Peru.The program will consider expansion in other countries in the region, subject to additional donor funding and feasibility work.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category C project, according to IFC''s Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because it is likely to have minimal or no adverse environmental impacts.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community

Project Description: Celtel Congo (RDC) S.p.r.l. (Celtel DRC or the company) operates a GSM (Global System for Mobiles) mobile telephone network in the Democratic Republic of Congo covering the major cities of Kinshasa and Lubumbashi, as well as surrounding areas and other regions including, Mbuyi-Mayi, Kananga, and Kolwesi.  The company was granted its nation-wide mobile cellular license in December 1999, and launched its operations in Kinshasa in December 2000.  The purpose of the project is to improve Celtel DRC's existing operations by building a long distance backbone from Kinshasa to Matadi and to Congo Brazzaville and expand its network to other towns and cities, including both formerly occupied and newly liberated areas.
Environmental Social Issues:
As a condition of the equity investment made by IFC in MSICIH in November 1999, MSICIH agreed to and has developed an Environmental and Social Management Plan (ESMP), which it is implementing throughout its operations.  MSICIH also agreed to complete a Fire and Life Safety Review, as well as design, build and operate future operations in compliance with -  mitigation programs and monitoring plans contained in environmental and social documents; -  all pertinent national legislation and local standards; and -  World Bank Group policies and guidelines.  Celtel DRCs Board of Directors has adopted the corporate ESMP, and the status of implementation of this and other issues was reviewed on appraisal.  Presently, IFC Against Aids is working with MSICIH to implement a corporate approach to HIV/AIDs, which is being developed in selected country operations as a pilot and will be adopted over time throughout all the MSICIH operations. Project Description: The Hernic company was established in 1994 and has grown to become one of the world's leading ferrochrome producers. The purpose of the project is to increase total ferrochrome production capacity from 260,000 to 420,000 tonnes per annum by expanding the existing operations of Hernic Ferrochrome (Pty) Ltd. (Hernic or the company).
Role: IFC has already assisted Hernic in its environmental and social audit and will continue to help strengthen Hernic's environmental and social action plan and implementation. IFC will also assist Hernic's management to improve social management capacity including addressing issues related to Black Economic Empowerment and community development.  In particular, IFC has been asked to assist the company in establishing a social plan that would meet the requirements of the new South African Mining Charter. Other potential focus areas include establishing a HIV/AIDS strategy and implementation plan, developing SME linkage programs and promoting mining related education programs.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedures.  There are limited environmental, health and safety risks associated with this expansion project as mining and processing chromite does not require the use of chemicals and involves a process flow which generates a limited amount of emissions, effluents and waste.  The project will not involve any significant social, resettlement and cultural property impacts, as it is an existing site located in an agricultural area at the fringe of an industrial zone. To review the current situation, Hernic has carried out a detailed environmental, social, health and safety audit of their facilities (mainly the beneficiation plant, pelletizing plant, and three furnaces) and associated opencast and underground mines.  An environmental and social action plan to correct areas of non compliance has been discussed with the company and a number of detailed programs are being implemented to address air emissions, water management, soil and groundwater contamination, public participation, community development and black economic empowerment. A new environmental and social management structure will be put in place, as well as detailed monitoring and reporting protocols. Hernic is aiming at getting accreditated for a  full ISO14001 Environmental Management System (EMS). It is proposed that IFC will invest approximately $26 million in equity/shareholder's loan and A loan.

Project Description: The Cartones América Group (CAME, the Group or the company) is a leading, privately-owned, Andean Region manufacturer of containerboard, corrugated boxes, clay-coated paperboard, spiral tube board and specialty board packaging products.. The Group traces its roots back to the 1950s in Cali, Colombia. In recent years the company has grown steadily, investing in operations in Venezuela (1993), Ecuador (1998), and Peru (2000).  CAME is in an important phase of its development and the project is aimed at helping CAME consolidate recent investments and realize the synergies to be achieved in its operations across the Andean Region..
Role:
IFC's support for CAME will support the Company's drive to become more efficient and competitive.  Impacts on economic development in Colombia are given below.

-  Strengthening a non-traditional industrial activity to enhance the country's economic diversification.     

-  Employment Impact-  CAME employs nearly 600 people directly.  Further, indirectly its operations support the activities of 40 recycled paper collection companies in the Andean Region which employ 800 people directly and an estimated 8,000 indirectly.  In Bogotá, CAME is participating in a program with the municipality to build recycled waste collection centers which are operated by street collectors.

-  Community Development:-  CAME actively supports its workers in home purchase.  More than 90% of its workers in Cali are homeowners, and it has been implementing the same program for employees at its companies in Ecuador and Peru.  CAME has also supported the formation of SMEs in service areas including transportation, maintenance and production of labor intensive items such as dividers.  Finally, CAME invests in training at all levels.  Its policy is to cover 50% of the cost of educational programs attended by its employees, and many of its employees have acquired technical, university and masters degrees. 

-  Environmentally Friendly.-  CAME's mills use recycled waste as it main raw material.  The Group has invested in technology to permit the utilization of lower grades of recycled fibers.  They have also made investments to substitute boiler fuel from diesel to natural gas and to increase water consumption efficiency.  

IFC's role in the project has the three aspects outlined below.

-  Access to Long-term Financing.-  Recession, liquidity constraints in the domestic banking sector, struggles with narco-terrorist activity, and Colombia's loss of its investment grade rating have severely constrained access to long-term credit, even for strong credits such as CAME.  Many foreign commercial banks have left the Colombian market or conduct short-term trade financing only and IFC remains one of few long-term sources of financing for independent companies.  

-  Catalytic Role.-  Given the situation described above, CAME's current lenders would not be able to extend the maturities of their current loan exposures in individually.  However, with IFC taking a lead by extending a loan of up to 9 years maturity, some of these banks have indicated that on the basis of an improved debt maturity profile, they will be able to increase the final maturity of some of their current loans to CAME from about 2-3 years to about 7 years.  

-  Value-Added for next Stage of Corporate Development.  Historically a family-owned company, CAME is rising through the ranks of middle market companies to become a more significant regional player.  Its next stage of development may include geographic diversification into Central America and the Caribbean and a potential linking with an industrial partner.  The company may be able to leverage IFC's ties in the industry and its experience in neighboring markets to support the pursuit of these objectives.

-  Support for Cross-Border Operation.  IFC's support for CAME is consistent with the objectives of the governments of the Andean Region to promote cross-border business and financial synergies.  In particular, IFC's engagement is important in backing the Group's operations in Venezuela, where CAME has extremely limited financing options due to the recent crises.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a Category B project according to IFC''s Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe environmental documents and ERS will be made available in the following locations:

COLOMBIA - Mosquera - Iglesia de Mosquera
PERU - Chincha - Cartelera Municipalidad Chincha Baja
PERU - Lurin - Cartelera Centro Industrial
VENEZUELA - Guaccara - Cartelera Zona Industrial El Nepe
Sponsor: Cartones América S.A. (incorporated in Cali, Colombia) directly and indirectly wholly-owns all the companies of the Group.  Cartones América is a privately held company which is majority owned (69.8%) by a Colombian family which has been dedicated to the packaging industry for more than 40 years.  Citicorp International Finance Corporation is the most important minority shareholder (29.5%) with the balance held by former and current employees (0.7%).
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at up to $44 million.  IFC is considering extending an A loan for its own account of up to $22 million to CAME, of which up to $5 million could be a quasi-equity instrument.  About one-half of the project cost would be allocated to debt refinancing which will extend CAME's debt maturities, improving its credit profile and strengthening its balance sheet. The balance of the project cost is comprised of investments in operational improvements, environmental upgrades and working capital that is aimed at enhancing CAME's competitiveness and further reducing its impact on the environment.  The most significant of these investments is for a cogeneration plant in Cali, estimated to cost up to $6 million.  Other investments include a new printing machine in Ecuador and upgrades in environmental controls at plants in each of the countries CAME operates in
Investment: 22.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan22.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: CAME operates paper mills in Cali (Colombia) and Chincha (Peru).  In addition, it operates corrugating and box making operations in Cali and  Mosquera (Colombia), Lurin (Peru), as well as near Valencia (Venezuela), and Quito (Ecuador).  The two plants in Cali are separate sites within the urban area of the city.  The other sites are all located in industrial parks situated on the edge of cities.  Some portion of the capital investment comprising the project is allocated for each of these sites.  The most significant investment, a cogeneration plant, would be installed at the paper mill site in Cali.

Project Description:
Founded in 1986, Grupo M is the largest private sector employer in the Dominican Republic with 12,000 employees working in 22 production facilities and is the largest apparel producer in the Caribbean/Central American region supplying to major US brand name companies including Liz Claiborne, Polo, Levis, Hanes and Tommy Hilfiger.  

The Haiti Project is a phased development of a 500,000 m2 site on the border of Haiti and DR.  Phase 1 of the investment program will develop an area of 150,000 m2  for a total investment of $11 million. Upon completion, Phase 1 is expected to generate 1,500 direct jobs and up to 3,000 indirect jobs for Haitian workers in the adjacent area.  Subsequent development is expected to include outside customers producing apparel, footwear and other  products who would lease or purchase facilities built to order by the zone development company, which will be 100% owned by Grupo M. The total site area would allow up to 40 factory units providing as many as 20,000 direct jobs and 40,000 indirect jobs at full capacity. The project is to provide 
-  a corporate financing to Grupo M (the Group or the company), a vertically integrated apparel manufacturer in the Dominican Republic producing knits and woven products for the US market, to finance ongoing capital expenditures, long term working capital needs and to refinance existing obligations, and 
-  a loan to finance an export zone promoted by Grupo M focusing on garment production in the Republic of Haiti (the Haiti Project).
Role:
Grupo M is the largest private sector employer in the DR.  The company has been an innovator in adopting sustainable business practices since its founding.  The Group has ISO9002 certification and has won awards for labor practice and corporate citizenship.  Financing of Grupo M is an opportunity for IFC to secure the long term growth of the Group.

The Haiti Project will have a very significant development impact. This project is the key private sector development in the Republic of Haiti creating an opportunity to rejuvenate the garment sector in the country, which once employed more than 60,000 people but has reduced substantially in the past 10 years. If successful, the development of the zone and the direct investments by Grupo M can be expected to mobilize significant other private sector investments creating as many as 60,000 direct and indirect jobs and thus a dramatic impact to alleviate poverty. IFC is working closely with the Group on additional initiatives in support of sustainability and linkages to the wider community in Haiti.

IFC will play a key role in this investment, firstly through its support of a major private investor making a first investment in the Republic of Haiti. IFC's presence as a long term investor will significantly enhance the attractiveness of the Haiti Project for Grupo M and for other private sector investors who can be expected to follow their lead.  The proposed IFC corporate financing  of Grupo M will provide otherwise unavailable long term funding to significantly bolster the long term competitiveness and sustainability of Grupo M, the largest employer in the DR and the flagship of the Dominican garment sector.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. The review of this project consisted of appraising technical and environmental/social information submitted by the project sponsor as well as a site visit by an environmental and social specialist in April 2003. The following potential environment, health and safety and social impacts of the projects were analyzed.-  Corporate Environmental and Social Management Systems and capacity;-  Land acquisition and economic displacement;-  Air emissions and noise;-  Water supply and discharge;-  Solid and liquid waste disposal;-  Use of CFCs;-  Occupational health and safety including employee exposure to noise and dust;-  Fire protection and emergency response;-  Trans-boundary and influx migration issues.The sponsor has presented plans to address these impacts to ensure that the proposed project will, upon implementation of the specific agreed measures, comply with the environmental and social requirements - the host country laws and regulations and the World Bank/IFC environment and social policies and the environmental, health and safety guidelines.  The information about how these potential impacts will be addressed by the sponsor/project is summarized in the Environmental Review Summary which has been released for public consultation in parallel with this document. Sponsor: The founding companies for Grupo M were established in 1986 by Fernando Capellan, a Dominican Republic (DR) entrepreneur. Grupo M, the holding company, was established in 1993.  Fernando Capellan and family members are the controlling shareholders who, together with senior management and company staff hold 82% of the outstanding share capital.  Banco Popular, the largest financial group in the Dominican Republic holds 10% of the outstanding shares, while the remainder is held by other local shareholders.
Cost Nature: The total cost of the project is estimated at $43 million of which $11 million is the projected cost for the first phase of the Haiti Project. The proposed IFC financing consists of a $20 million loan for IFC's account  to Grupo M to fund ongoing capital expenditures and debt restructuring and a second $3 million loan for IFC's account to the Haiti Project development company.
Investment: 20.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan20.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location:
Grupo M's main production facilities are located in two industrial zones developed by the group in Santiago,  Dominican Republic.  The Haiti Project is located on the northern border of  the Dominican Republic and the Republic of Haiti on the outskirts of the towns of Ouanaminthe  (Republic of  Haiti, population  56,000 ) and   Dajabon   (Dominican Republic, population   65,000).  

The development plan for phase 1 of the Haiti Project will include 
-  site clearing and access roads and utilities, 
-  training center, staff facilities (medical services and cafeteria) and customs clearing offices, and 
-  3 factory buildings owned by Grupo M.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati:
This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. The review of this project consisted of appraising technical and environmental/social information submitted by the project sponsor as well as a site visit by an environmental and social specialist in April 2003. The following potential environment, health and safety and social impacts of the projects were analyzed.-  Corporate Environmental and Social Management Systems and capacity;-  Land acquisition and economic displacement;-  Air emissions and noise;-  Water supply and discharge;-  Solid and liquid waste disposal;-  Use of CFCs;-  Occupational health and safety including employee exposure to noise and dust;-  Fire protection and emergency response;-  Trans-boundary and influx migration issues.The sponsor has presented plans to address these impacts to ensure that the proposed project will, upon implementation of the specific agreed measures, comply with the environmental and social requirements - the host country laws and regulations and the World Bank/IFC environment and social policies and the environmental, health and safety guidelines.  The information about how these potential impacts will be addressed by the sponsor/project is summarized in the Environmental Review Summary which has been released for public consultation in parallel with this document. Project Description: Tourism Promotion Services (Afghanistan) Limited -TPS(A)- was established by the Aga Khan Fund for Economic Development (AKFED) for the purpose of investing in the Kabul Serena Hotel.  TPS(A) will completely renovate and expand the old Kabul Hotel (the project) at an estimated cost of $27.8 million.  The hotel development will be phased with 160 rooms total and will be operated by AKFED's hotel management subsidiary, Serena Tourism Promotion Services (STPS), which trades as Serena Hotels.  Originally built in the 1930s, the Kabul Hotel is in a major state of disrepair as a result of war damage and overall neglect over the years but was once an attractive hotel and an important meeting place in Kabul
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of projects.  The environmental, health, safety and social issues associated with this project are described in the Environmental Review Summary.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe completed ERS in English and Farsi will be made available at the TPS(A) office in Kabul.
Sponsor: The sponsor is AKFED and its subsidiary, STPS, now operates 20 hotels in Kenya, Tanzania, Mozambique and Pakistan under the Serena brand.  As in other hotel projects, STPS has established a separate company in Afghanistan, TPS(A) for the purpose of implementing this project.  AKFED is an economic development agency headquartered in Geneva, Switzerland that helps develop economically viable enterprises through equity participation combined with management and technical expertise and support.  AKFED is part of the larger Aga Khan Development Network (AKDN), a group of development agencies working in health, education, culture and rural and economic development.  AKDN has been active in Afghanistan for a number of years and has a strong local presence.
Cost Nature: Total project cost is estimated at $27.8 million.  IFC's proposed investment is a loan of  up to $ 7 million.
Investment: 7.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan7.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The project is located in downtown Kabul on Bank Street, across from the Central Bank, and adjacent to Zanegar Park, which will be maintained as a green area.  The existing Kabul Hotel currently occupies this site and a new building will be added within the hotel grounds as part of the expansion.   To further enhance the quality of the neighborhood in the vicinity of the  hotel and facilitate a higher level of security around the hotel , the whole of Bank Street along the boundary of the hotel will be dedicated as a pedestrian zone.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of projects.  The environmental, health, safety and social issues associated with this project are described in the Environmental Review Summary.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe completed ERS in English and Farsi will be made available at the TPS(A) office in Kabul.

The company was incorporated in July 2001 and currently utilizes 300 sewing machines.  IFC's investment will be used for financing the additional capital investment needed to complete the Project and for funding a part of  the working capital requirement of the project.

Company Name: CGTF Central Geradora Termelétrica Fortaleza S/A.
Project Description:
The project consists of the development, construction and operation of a 310.7 MW (net) thermal power plant located in the industrial complex near the Port of Pecém, in the municipality of Caucaia, state of Ceará, in the poorest northeastern region of Brazil that was most severely affected by the recent power rationing program.

The Government of Brazil (GOB) established the Programa Prioritário de Termeletricidade (PPT Program) in order to incentivize the development of licensed thermal power plants so as to more optimally balance the country's power generation capacity base.  The project is designed to complement the Northeast region's hydropower-based electricity production by providing natural gas-fired generation capacity.  The project is included in the PPT program.

The plant will sell its entire output, under a 20-year Power Purchase Agreement (PPA), to Companhia Energética do Ceará (Colece), the sole electricity distribution company for the state of Ceará.  Cegás, the gas distribution company for the state of Ceará, and Petrobrás, the national oil and gas company, will supply natural gas to the project under 20-year Gas Supply Agreements (GSAs).  Mitsui is the selected EPC Contractor.  The total project cost is estimated at about $250 million.  The plant is currently under construction, and is expected to achieve commercial operation by December 2003.
Role:
The project is expected to have significant developmental impacts in that it will help to address a key developmental and strategic priority of both the GOB and the World Bank.  The project will provide reliable and environmentally sound additional thermal power generation capacity to the poor northeast region of Brazil, the region that is heavily dependent on one river  São Francisco river  and was the worst affected by the 2001 energy crisis.  Thereby, it will provide important system complementarities to the hydro-based system of the Northeast, and will help to reduce the risk of shortages, that have high economic costs.  Moreover, the project will contribute to the economic growth in the Northeast in several ways: by bringing in and supporting foreign private investments; by creating about 1,200 jobs during construction; and by providing industrial and commercial customers with reliable capacity in a region that is extremely vulnerable to hydrological conditions.  Finally, the project will be the first efficient combined-cycle thermal power plant in the state of Ceará (which currently imports electricity over a distance of at least 700 km, resulting in high transmission loss), and will cater to about 30 percent of the state's current power demand.

IFC will be playing a critical investment mobilization role in this project through the raising of an IFC 'B' Loan from commercial banks of up to $112.5 million.  In light of the extreme cautiousness among commercial lenders in Latin America, this is a significant amount of commercial financing for a project in Brazil (particularly in the Northeast) at this time, given the evolving regulatory structure in Brazil's power sector, the continuing crisis in Argentina, and the continuing downturn of the power industry worldwide.  

By financing the TermoFortaleza project, IFC will be providing strong support to the Brazilian power sector following the recent energy crisis.  In this regard, the GOB has been working to attract investments from major international power developers because it realizes that it needs the support of large, well-capitalized companies to ensure the success of this effort.  In the context of the retreat from emerging markets of various power companies over the past 1 to 2 years, it is critical that debt financing be available to support those strategic sponsors still willing to invest in the sector in developing countries.  IFC's support of the Project will send a strong signal to the market that IFC will continue to support those international power companies that remain committed to investing in emerging markets.
Environmental Social Issues:
Environmental, social and health and safety issues reviewed include:      -   Endesas corporate capacity to review and manage the project in accordance with IFCs environmental and social safeguard policies,     -  natural environment (air quality, water supply and liquid effluents, noise, land use, soil and biological resources, visual resources, traffic and transportation),     -  health and safety (public health, worker safety and fire protection),     -  socio-economic (public consultation, cultural resources, community development, local employment),    -   global environment (generating efficiency, greenhouse gas emissions),   -  alternative analysis (site, fuel, generation technology, air emission control technology, cooling system technology), and -   impacts of associated facilities (the transmission line and gas pipeline connections including possible land acquisition or economic displacement).Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe environmental documents will be made available at the following location:

Endesa Fortaleza
Rua Adolfo Pinheiro 176
Bairro Dionisio Torres
CEP 60120-040
Fortaleza, Ceara
Brazil
Sponsor:
The project sponsors are Endesa Internacional (EI), a wholly owned subsidiary of Endesa, S.A. of Spain, and Enersis, S.A., a Chilean electricity company that is 65% owned by EI.  EI holds one of the largest market shares among private companies in five major Latin American countries, controlling 12.4 GW of installed capacity and serving over 10 million customers.  To date, EI has invested in over 950 MW of generation capacity (including CGTF) in Brazil.  Additionally, EI controls CIEN (transmission line company interconnecting Brazil and Argentina) and owns two distribution companies  Cerj (servicing Rio de Janeiro) and Coelce (off-taker of CGTF).

The sponsors established a special purpose project company, Central Geradora Termeléctrica Fortaleza, S.A. (CGTF), to finance, own and operate the Project.  EI holds 51% and Enersis 49% of CGTF, which is incorporated under Brazilian law.  Expatriates from Spain and Chile manage CGTF.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at about $250 million.  The proposed IFC investment is an A Loan of up to $62.5 million for IFC's own account, and syndication of up to a $112.5 million B Loan for the account of the participants.
Investment: 62.50 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan62.50Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The project is located in the industrial park adjacent to the Port of Pecém, in the municipality of Caucaia, state of Ceará, Brazil.  The state of Ceará is promoting the industrial park in Pecém which is expected to include various projects, such as a steel plant, a petrochemical plant, a regasification plant, power plants, and warehouses.  Existing industries in the industrial park include a 200 MW simple-cycle gas-based power plant, which is presently completed.  The project is strategically located at the load center, represented by the industrial park and by the metropolitan region of Fortaleza, one of the fastest growing cities in the northeast Brazil.  It is in close proximity to the Guamaré-Pecém gas pipeline, and about 2 kms away from the grid at 230 kV Cauipe substation of CHESF.

Project Description: Olam International Limited (Olam or the company) is an international integrated supplier of both raw and processed agricultural commodities headquartered in Singapore with over 2,300 employees worldwide.  Olam operates in 35 countries (primarily in sub-Saharan Africa and Asia) and in nine major agricultural products: cocoa, rice, cashew, cotton, coffee, timber, sugar, sesame and shea nut.  The company is involved in varying degrees across the total product supply chain, which can include procurement as close to farmgate as possible, primary processing, inland transport, warehousing, marine transport, and distribution -- using a network of local buying agents, primary processing facilities and logistics. The proposed IFC investment will help strengthen Olam's balance sheet and support its operations.  IFC's financing is therefore expected to help enhance and expand Olam's activities in frontier countries including Ghana, Cameroon, Gabon, Nigeria, Indonesia, Viet Nam and Uzbekistan.
Environmental Social Issues: Refer to the Environmental Review Summary also being made available at the World Bank InfoShop and locally affected communities (see below).Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityOlam will publicize the availability of the ERS in Singapore (the company headquarters) and the following country origins: Nigeria, Ghana, India, Vietnam and Cote d'Ivoire. These origins have been chosen on the basis of their representative geographic and sectoral spread. Olam will use both media outlets and its extensive network of buying agents to ensure widespread distribution of the ERS.
Sponsor: Olam is part of the Kewalram Chanrai Group which is held privately by overseas Indian family trusts. From the Chanrai family's beginnings in trading in Nigeria and India in 1860, the group has grown into a conglomerate with diversified operations and interests in textile manufacturing, agri-commodities sourcing, processing and trading, international trade, and property development employing more than 12,000 people in over 45 countries. Olam's other shareholders are its management group and the Asia Infrastructure Fund, an IFC investee.
Cost Nature: The proposed IFC equity investment of US$15 million is part of a project aimed at helping Olam expand its equity base by approximately US$50 million in order to strengthen its balance sheet and support its operations worldwide, mainly in sub-Saharan Africa and Asia.
Investment: 7.50 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity7.50* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The project will support Olam's activities mainly in over 20 existing origin countries in sub-Saharan Africa and Asia where the company sources, processes and/or markets its nine major agricultural products.

Role: The projects development impact include continued direct benefits to rural populations and a demonstration impact on sustainability. Olam''s operations provide substantial benefits to rural areas of many developing countries given the company''s ability to -  enhance the efficiency and transparency of agribusiness logistics and -  provide knowledge transfer in the primary processing of products which set high standards needed to meet the requirements of international buyers, thereby providing best practices for local companies to emulate. With Sub-Saharan Africa and Asia accounting each for about half of Olam''s production volume, IFC''s investment in Olam complements the World Bank''s efforts in liberalizing the commodity export markets in many developing countries. It also provides support for IFCs efforts to promote private sector development and the export sectors (including the diversification of export products) in these countries.

Project Description:
Incorporated in Trinidad and Tobago (T&T), Republic Bank Limited (Republic or the bank) has a long and profitable history of banking in the Caribbean.  Created in 1837, under the then name of Colonial Bank, the bank has gone through a number of stages of development before reaching its current incarnation.   In the 1920's the bank came under the ownership of Barclay's Bank but returned to local ownership in 1977 and took the current name of Republic Bank Limited.  Republic has ten operating subsidiaries and three associated companies. 

Republic has a strong and experienced management team with a proven track record.  Highly profitable, the bank has on average doubled profits every 4 years in the period since 1971 leading to an average ROI (return on investment) during the period of approximately 40%.  The bank's market capitalization is $1.0 billion or approximately two times book value.  As at fiscal year end September 30, 2002, the group had $3.1 billion equivalent in total assets and $496 million in total equity.  As at the same period, Republic's return on average assets and return on average equity were 2.43% and 17.3% respectively.  The bank's risk weighted capital adequacy ratio was 18.02%.

The project is to provide up to $50 million to Republic to help finance the privatization of Barbados National Bank (BNB).  Republic has received the approval of the Government of Barbados to purchase a minimum 57% shareholding in BNB.  Currently, BNB is 77% owned by the Government of Barbados, 10% owned by the National Insurance Board (another public sector agency), and 13% publicly held.  The public sector will maintain a shareholding of approximately 30% following the privatization of BNB.
Role:
Development Impact:  
-  The acquisition of BNB by Republic will facilitate regional integration of the financial services industry by enabling the largest bank in T&T to enter the lucrative Eastern Caribbean markets (Barbados and St. Lucia); and 
-  Republic's strong management, information systems and expertise will allow BNB to achieve greater diversification of products and services and ensure that it keeps up with competition in the wake of industry wide mergers and acquisitions. The BNB acquisition will further enable a strong bank from T & T to diversify its activities and to provide high quality services to customers in a wider geographic area.

IFC Role:
IFC has been requested to invest in the company for the following reasons:  
-  to support Republic's regional expansion strategy; and 
-  to provide long-term financing for the proposed acquisition.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an F1 Type 1 project.  The bank will be required to maintain an environmental management system.  The bank must require that investments under relevant operations meet host country environmental, health and safety requirements.  IFC will assess the banks current capacity for environmental review and will provide additional training as necessary.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor:
Republic's five largest shareholders are:
Trintrust Limited (17%), 
Colonial Life Insurance Company Limited, known as CLICO (22%), 
CLICO Investment Bank Limited (12%), 
Roytrin Securities Ltd. (10%), and 
CIBC West Indies Holdings Limited (9%).  

The remaining shares are held by over 10,000 small shareholders.
Cost Nature: The proposed IFC investment is a $50 million loan to Republic.
Investment: 50.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan50.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative

The bank must require that investments under relevant operations meet host country environmental, health and safety requirements. Project Description:
The project is to design, construct and operate a greenfield, integrated, dry process cement plant of 800,000 tons per year (tpy) clinker capacity and 900,000 tpy cement capacity at an estimated cost of $84 million in the Dominican Republic.  The Domicem plant is expected to be commissioned by May 2005 and to sell 90% of its production in the domestic market and 10% as exports.

As of March 16, 2005, there has been a modification to this project, which is covered under a new project, Domicem II  Project No.24209.  Total Project Cost has also been revised to US$113.5 million.
Role:
The IFC Role will provide the following:

-  Access to Long-term Financing.  

IFC's involvement will enable the project to obtain long-term financing with maturities otherwise unavailable in the local DR market.  As a greenfield project, Domicem requires adequate grace periods on principal repayments to ensure proper capitalization and breathing room' during construction and start-up.  IFC will also play a catalytic role by attempting to mobilize up to $21 million from foreign commercial banks who may be unfamiliar with the local DR market and political environment.  In this regard, IFC's own investment in the project is expected to provide comfort to banks.  

-  Support to Colacem.  

Colacem seeks to diversify geographically and find growth opportunities in emerging markets.  While it has formed a joint venture with strong local partners in the DR, Colacem can benefit from IFC's involvement in Domicem given that this is its first investment in Latin America.  IFC contributes, beyond its umbrella', regional knowledge and investment experience in the cement industry in the Latin America. IFC has also provided the Sponsors with input such as suggesting improvements in limestone quarry investigation, bulk sampling of raw materials for the turnkey contractor, and guarantee for Nitrogen Oxides (NOx).

-  Endorsement of CBMI as Turnkey Contractor.  

IFC has first-hand knowledge of CBMI, the Chinese turnkey contractor, which Colacem will use for the Domicem project after its successful prior collaboration with CBMI.  IFC's endorsement of CBMI would help introduce a new, low cost, competitive supplier to the Latin American market. 

Development Impact:  

The Domicem project, a joint venture between Colacem, an industry player with a solid track record and a strong group of local DR investors, is expected to improve the productivity and competitiveness of the DR cement sector.  By supplying its own clinker needs through an integrated cement operation in a country where 60% of cement is produced on the basis of imported clinker, Domicem is expected to have a competitive cost structure.  The additional production of quality cement is expected to reduce cement prices in the DR, which are among the highest in the world, to more competitive levels.    

Other development benefits of the project include best practice' technology transfer, job creation and foreign exchange generation when the project exports a portion of its production.  The project will also support infrastructure development and construction efforts, which are critical in a country prone to frequent devastation from hurricanes and in constant need of quality cement and building materials. Colacem has a track record of implementing community development programs in the communities where it operates in Italy and is committed to support similar efforts in the DR.  Domicem is expected to operate in line with superior environmental management and safeguard systems, including best practice' standards for energy efficiency.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  This categorization is based on the location of the cement plant in an unpopulated area, the limestone quarry is a short distance from the plant in an area previously used for grazing cattle with no apparent land acquisition issues, and the sponsor is committed and capable to run the operation in an environmentally and socially responsible manner.  The limestone and clay quarry has all the necessary licenses and permits from the government.  Environmental, health, safety and social issues associated with this project include: -  management of air emissions including potential cumulative impacts;-  management of wastewater and solid waste;-  impacts of transportation;  -  quarry reclamation plan;-  occupational health and safety; -  hazardous materials management;-  life and fire safety;-  emergency response;-  land acquisition procedures;-  community relations and development.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe environmental documents will be made available at the following locations:
Domicem's offices in Santo Domingo 
Municipality of Ciénega de Palenque
Cost Nature:
The total project cost is estimated at $84 million.  The proposed IFC investment amounts to $42 million and comprises a $21 million A Loan for IFC's own account and a $21 million B Loan for the account of participants.

As of March 16, 2005, total project cost has been revised to US$113. 5 million.  The proposed IFC investment will increase to US$55.5 million (see project Domicem II  No. 24209).
Investment: 24.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan24.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The Domicem project will be located on a 500 ha site located 40 km from the capital Santo Domingo, 26 km from the international Port of de Haina and 2 km from the village of Sabana Grande de Palanque, where the project's limestone quarries are located.  The site is easily accessible, located 2,000 meters away from the Haina Palanque highway.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati:
This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  This categorization is based on the location of the cement plant in an unpopulated area, the limestone quarry is a short distance from the plant in an area previously used for grazing cattle with no apparent land acquisition issues, and the sponsor is committed and capable to run the operation in an environmentally and socially responsible manner.  The limestone and clay quarry has all the necessary licenses and permits from the government.
