Project Description: The Project entails the construction and operation of the 124-room Marriott Courtyard Hotel in Port of Spain (POS), the capital of Trinidad & Tobago (T&T), by Caribe Hospitality of T&T (CHTT).  Demand for business lodging has grown in recent years as a result of significant investment in Trinidad and should continue to increase with new developments in the natural gas sector  and other positive economic indicators.  Marriott International will operate the hotel under a Management Agreement and will  provide technical assistance in the design and implementation phases.
Role: The Caribe Hospitality concept has an important development impact in demonstrating that regional investment schemes with cross border capital can be successfully implemented in Central America and the Caribbean.  Through CH, local and regional investors are able to expand and diversify their business interests.  Ultimately the establishment of a chain of business hotels in this area will support regional trade and business development with a network linked by common management and onward reservations, and providing services of known quality and range.More specifically the POS Courtyard will:- provide additional hotel rooms which are clearly needed as part of the countrys basic business infrastructure;- introduce high standards in life and fire safety, energy and water conservation, etc., which should encourage similar upgrading by other hotels;- support a near downtown urban hub that is becoming an important location for modern retailing and social activities; - have strong linkages with T&Ts construction and building supply sectors during construction.  Once operational, the project will stimulate local supplies of goods and services used by the hotel and its guests;- provide direct employment for some 60 workers once the hotel is operational and many more jobs will be created indirectly.  Hotel employees will benefit from Marriotts training programs, promotion practices  and overall high service standards.IFCs most important role is the provision of A and C loans with long tenors and grace periods to match market and project risks.  IFC has also provided valuable input regarding the Management Agreement and the land lease agreement.  In the future IFC may pursue additional CH hotel investments and we can continue to valuable input to improve the viability of CH by ensuring that future hotel projects undertaken are justified on a market basis, that management agreements with Marriott are equitable, that project costs are reasonable and that the financial structures for individual projects are sound.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of projects.   The environmental, health, safety and social issues associated with this project are described in the Environmental Review Summary.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityAn advertisement will be placed in Express newspaper in Trinidad.  Documents will be posted at NLBA Architects Ltd., 36 Carlos Street, Port of Spain.
Sponsor: Caribe Hospitality of Trinidad & Tobago Ltd. (CHTT), the project company, was incorporated in 2002 as a joint venture between Caribe Hospitality S.A (CH) (60%), Mouttet Capital Ltd (30%) and Poui Holdings Ltd (10%).  The purpose of the company is to develop the POS Courtyard hotel.Caribe Hospitality S.A. was incorporated in Panama for the sole purpose of developing and operating small business hotels in Central America and the Caribbean to be managed by Marriott under its Courtyard brand.  The intent is to partner with local sponsors for individual hotels on a joint venture basis.  Shareholders in Caribe Hospitality are Ramiro Ortiz, Edgar Zurcher and John Keith.Local sponsors in this project are Mouttet Capital Ltd, a wholly owned subsidiary of Victor E Mouttet Limited (VEML) established in Trinidad in 1958, and Poui Holdings Ltd., a shell company that is owned by Joseph Esau, a Trinidadian national.
Cost Nature: Total project cost is estimated at $11 million.  IFCs proposed investment comprises an A loan of $1.6 million and a C loan of $2.0 million with an income participation feature.
Investment: 3.80 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan3.80Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The POS Courtyard will be located in Invaders Bay, about a mile from the downtown area of the city and across from Hasley Crawford Stadium.  Invaders Bay is a former swampland which was filled several years ago by the government to address the need for additional land in Port of Spain.  Completed developments in Invaders Bay thus far include a port, PriceSmart and the MovieTowne complex which includes restaurants and shops.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of projects.   The environmental, health, safety and social issues associated with this project are described in the Environmental Review Summary.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityAn advertisement will be placed in Express newspaper in Trinidad.  Documents will be posted at NLBA Architects Ltd., 36 Carlos Street, Port of Spain.

Project Description:
Hikma Investment (the company, or Hikma) is a privately held multinational generic pharmaceuticals holding company headquartered in Amman, Jordan.  Manufacturing operations started in 1978 in Jordan, and the company was established in 1991 to consolidate the ownership of all Hikma group's manufacturing subsidiary companies throughout the Middle East, United States, Europe, and North Africa.  Hikma has been an existing client of IFC since 1987. 

The project involves expanding the company's operations in the Middle East and North Africa region (MENA), Portugal, and Asia. This program is being planned in connection with preparing the company for a future U.S. initial public offering. It will include an IFC corporate governance component to help the company satisfy the recent corporate governance and securities law reform in the U.S. (the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002), which institutes new rules regarding the corporate governance of publicly held corporations listed in the U.S., including American Depositary Receipts (ADRs).
Role:
The project will have a significant developmental impact for several reasons:  
- IFC's technical assistance will introduce high levels of corporate governance to a Jordanian company with a multinational presence.  This will also carry a strong demonstration effect for other Jordanian companies.  
- IFC's investment will contribute to the growth of the Jordanian pharmaceutical sector, a major contributor to the country's exports.
- The project will also send a strong signal to the market, and therefore support a Jordanian multinational in a U.S. IPO.  
- IFC's investment in the form of a corporate loan will stimulate the ability for the company to obtain such funding from external sources in the future.  

IFC Role:
Throughout this project, IFC will support the continued development of a leading Jordanian pharmaceutical company into a global company.  IFC's long-term loan would allow Hikma to implement a change in business strategy, further expanding in the MENA region, U.S., and Europe, and better targeting more profitable drugs coming off patent.  Moreover, IFC's technical assistance in the form of corporate governance advice and training will help the company in satisfying the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002, a prerequisite for issuing ADRs, thus ensuring future access to capital.  Also, IFC's technical and financial assessment of the company will provide Hikma's management with a fresh external view of the operations, which will be taken into account in the finalization of the business plan.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a category B project according to IFCs environmental review procedure. Potential environmental, social, health and safety issues associated with this project include air emissions, liquid effluents, solid and hazardous wastes handling and disposal, raw materials and chemicals handling and storage, water supply, employee health and safety training, including hygiene, fire safety and emergency response, environmental management capacity, social development activities in corporate operations. Project Description: Established in 1969, MESA Housing Industries (MESA HI) is a construction and real estate development company with operations in Turkey and abroad.  The main company of the MESA Group (MESA),  MESA HI is carrying out an estimated  $45 million project to build and commission a 115-bed general tertiary level greenfield hospital in central Ankara, addressing the demand for high quality healthcare in the city.

The group is also active in tourism (resort facilities and a travel agency) and co-owns several shopping centers.  MESA is controlled by close to 40 individual shareholders.

The total built-in area will be approximately 24,000 square meters.

Project Description:
Borusan Group is a major Turkish company involved in steel and pipe production, distribution of automobiles and heavy construction equipment, a logistics company and in new technologies. The proposed project consists of:
-  restructuring the balance sheet; 
      -  implementing a number of corporate initiatives to improve productivity; and 
      -  strengthening corporate governance.  

The objective is to improve the company's overall operational and financial performance. Borusan Group is organized into five divisions: 
-  Steel Pipe Division:
 comprising three companies which together represent one of the top five pipe manufacturers in Europe; 

-  Distribution Division:
 comprising the sales and support for Caterpillar construction and earth moving equipment and power systems and also BMW and Land Rover passenger vehicles; 

-  Flat Steel Division:
 which includes Borçelik, an IFC client, with cold-rolling steel operations; 

-Logistics Division:
which provides logistics, domestic and international transport, port, warehousing and other services to third parties; and,

-  Technology Division:
 offering LAN, alternative telecom and other IT services and taking partnerships in high growth IT and telecom companies.
Role:
-  Borusan Holding is one of the second tier corporations in Turkey. However, IFC's track record with its most prominent and profitable operations has been excellent: Borusan's pipe division  since 1976 and Borçelik since 1994. As the Group prepares for the next stage in its evolution against the backdrop of economic and political uncertainty in Turkey, it need access to stable long-term financing. Long-term financing in Turkey is virtually nonexistent, limited to only supplier financing, a problem which is exacerbated in the current crisis environment.  

-  The project includes the implementation of important corporate initiatives as described above, which will build on an established base of achievements in these areas: Group companies already hold various quality certifications, such as ISO 9001, ISO 9002, ISO 14001, OHSAS 18001, QS 9000; in addition, Borçelik has won the European Foundation for Quality Management (EFQM) excellence model award.

-  The project will strengthen a group employing 3,400 people, most of which are based outside of Istanbul.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityEnvironmental Review Summary has been announced on May 9 , 2003 in local papers in Istanbul Ticaret Gazetesi, Bursa Hakimiyet Gazetesi and Özgür Kocaeli Gazetesi and made available at the premises of Borusan Holding at the following address:

Borusan Holding A.S.Meclisi Mebusan Caddesi 103Salipazari 80040 Istanbul TurkeyPhone: (90 212) 251 34 10 / 506Fax:     (90 212) 249 32 05
Sponsor: Borusan Group is organized under a Holding structure, which acts as a parent for its operating subsidiaries. The Borusan Holding is owned by members of Kocabiyik family and is privately held. Borusan history began in 1944 with Istikbal Ticaret, a trading company. By 1972, after integrating steel pipe operations, all Borusan companies were brought together under Borusan Holding. In the 80's Borusan entered a new sector, distributorship, by becoming the Turkish representative for BMW passenger vehicles, as well as for Caterpillar professional earth moving equipment and power systems as the brand's sole representative in Turkey, Azerbaijan, Georgia and Kazakhstan. The 90's also marked the founding of Borçelik, Turkey's first private sector manufacturer of cold rolled flat steel. The partnership with Mannesmann in 1998 placed Borusan among the top five steel pipe producers in Europe.

Company Name: CAIXA ECONOMICA DE CABO VERDE, S.A.
Project Description:
Caixa Económica de Cabo Verde (CECV or the company) was established in 1928 as a postal savings bank. In August 1993 it changed to a universal bank and, in December 1998 changed the name to the current denomination. CECV was privatized in December 1999 through an international biding process. The Montepio Geral Group from Portugal has a total of 27.4% of the share capital of CECV and is the provider of know-how and experienced management.

The project consists of a credit line of up to EUR5 million to be extended to CECV, the second largest bank in Cape Verde. The credit line will have a tenor of 5-7 years and will provide much needed foreign exchange denominated term finance to CECV and the private sector. This project is the first IFC investment in Cape Verde's financial markets.
With total assets of $122.3 million at the end of FY02, CECV increased its balance sheet by 13.9% when compared with the previous year, thereby consolidating its expansion strategy constructed on three different pillars: the expansion of the branch network, the diversification of distribution channels and a more personalized approach to its client base.

As of December 31st, 2002, CECV had a CAR of 16.0%. Despite a lower return on equity in 2002, CECV remains a profitable institution and should be able to maintain at least the FY02 profitability level. Its cash flows can sustain without any difficulty a $5 million loan from the IFC, especially as the loan will allow the bank to leverage its strong capital base to increase business.
Role:
Development Impact

The proposed project will have a significant development impact in Cape Verde. In particular, it will:
-  improve CECV corporate governance practices. IFC's name is perceived a good practitioner in this area and the bank requested IFC's assistance to develop a sound corporate governance system;
-  Channel much needed foreign exchange term-finance to Cape Verde's private sector; and,
- Encourage further investment from Portuguese companies to the archipelago, given CECV's strong Portuguese links.

IFC's Role:

This is potentially the first investment by IFC in a financial institution in Cape Verde. IFC's knowledge and experience in banking in the region is well recognized by the sponsor, and they look forward to IFC's assistance. IFC will be providing long-term funding, which is in short supply in the region. Even major banks in countries with well developed capital markets and access to foreign sources of funding have difficulty in obtaining long-term (3 years and longer) hard currency funding.  The proposed 5-7 year term facility, will allow CECV to expand its long-term activities and enhance its ability to match its foreign exchange assets and liabilities.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an FI Type 2 project. The bank will be required to undertake an environmental review of each subproject. IFC will assess the banks capability to carry out environmental reviews.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor:
Montepio Geral (MG) is the sponsor of this project. The MG Group was established in 1840 and is today the most important mutual institution in Portugal, with close to 200 thousand associates. The Group fully owns Caixa Económica Montepio Geral, the oldest Portuguese credit institution, that was created in 1844. Recent changes to the Portuguese banking legislation recognized MG as a full fledged commercial bank, allowing them to boost their activities, sustained by the expansion of the branch network, restructuring of services and technological modernization. 

The new status of MG also allowed the company to start working towards the completion of one of its visions: to expand its international activities through representative offices in markets with a strong Portuguese emigrant community and with joint-venture operations to all five Portuguese speaking countries in the African continent. Presently, and always in partnership with local partners, MG is established in Cape Verde with Caixa Económica de Cabo Verde, Guinea-Bissau with Banco da Àfrica Ocidental (in partnership with Banco Efisa and IFC) and in Mozambique with Banco de Desenvolvimento e Comércio (in partnership with Banco Efisa and possibly with IFC).

MG also considered taking an equity stake in the privatization of Banco Comercial Angola, in Angola, but the requirements of the Angolan authorities were not considered acceptable. Lastly, MG is considering setting up a new financial institution in Sao Tome and Principe.

The MG Group holds 27.4% of the share capital of CECV and all the remaining shareholders are all from Cape Verde.
Cost Nature: The project consists of a credit line of up to EUR5 million to be extended to CECV, with a tenor of 5-7 years. This project is the first IFC investment in Cape Verde's financial markets.
Investment: 6.08 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan6.08Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: CECV is headquartered in Praia, Cape Verde. The bank has a large geographical coverage and is present in most of the islands of the archipelago.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is an FI Type 2 project. The bank will be required to undertake an environmental review of each subproject. IFC will assess the banks capability to carry out environmental reviews.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Description:
The proposed Euros 73.8 million project represents a post privatization restructuring of a Bulgarian steel mini-mill, Stomana Industry A.D. (Stomana, or the company). Headquartered in the Pernik industrial area, Stomana is the largest employer in a depressed region, notorious with the unsuccessful privatizations of a number of big state-owned companies.  Moreover, with production of about 600,000 tpy of long and flat steel products and more than 1,300 employees, Stomana is the second largest steel producer in Bulgaria and one of the most important enterprises in the country.  

The project will be implemented by Sidenor Steel Products Manufacturing Company S.A. (Sidenor or the Sponsor).  As part of the project, Sidenor will refurbish the plant, improve production methods and environmental performance, and facilitate transition to higher value-added products.  After the completion of the overall investment program, Stomana's production is not expected to divert significantly from current levels as planned investment is in cost reduction and quality improvements, and not in capacity increases.
Role:
The project is expected to reduce costs and improve quality and competitiveness.  It should result in more efficient use of raw material inputs and labor, and a better overall productivity, due to implementation of new, better technology, and improved management practices. Moreover, the project is expected to have a significant environmental impact as the sponsor is planning to invest about Euros 13 million in environmental improvements.  
The project will benefit from the management expertise of a strong sponsor, who has significant technological know-how for both investment and production.  In addition, the sponsor will bring into the project advanced marketing and sales techniques and a proven quality control system.  An important part of sponsor's support will be on-the job training provided by Sidenor, including employee training in Sidenor's plants in Greece.  Last but not least, as Stomana is one of  the largest employers in the town of Pernik, the successful turnaround of the mini mill is critical for Pernik's community and its surroundings.    

IFC has a major role to play in this project by providing long term financing which is scarce in Bulgaria.  IFC will play a critical developmental role by ensuring that the project meets World Bank environmental and safety guidelines and hence serve as a model in pollution and dust emission control in Bulgaria.  IFC is also playing an important role in structuring the financial plan and bringing other lenders into the transaction while also helping sustain major productive asset and a key employer in the region.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of projects.  This project involves several environmental upgrades and approximately  13 million of the projects total cost is related to environmental upgrades: -  slag cooling and crystallization; -  revamping the EAF off gas system; - EAF energy reduction program; -  plate mill reheat furnace energy reduction; -  long products mill reheat furnace energy reduction; -  additional water treatment; -  further site cleanup of waste debris and slag and demolition of old buildings; and -  other environmentally related expenditures.  Since the 24 months that Sidenor has been operating the plant, the sponsor has made huge strides in their modernization and revamping of the entire operation.  Employee morale is high, progress has been dramatic, and future plans are very ambitious.  Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe ERS will be disclosed on Stomana's factory gate in Pernik.
Sponsor: The project sponsor, Sidenor (with 75% shareholding in Stomana), is based in Greece and is the largest long steel products manufacturer in the country.  It operates two steel mini-mills in Greece and has holdings in several companies which manufacture and market a wide variety of steel products.  Established in 1962, Sidenor has been continuously profitable without a single year of financial loss.  Sidenor is listed on the Athens Stock Exchange.
Cost Nature:
The total project cost is estimated at about Euros 73.8 million.  IFC is considering a financial package of approximately Euros 30 million comprised of: 
-  an A Loan for IFC's own account of about Euros 20 million, and,
-  an equity or quasi-equity investment of about Euros 10 million.
Investment: 21.79 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan21.79Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The project will be implemented in Stomana's existing production facilities, located in the industrial zone of the town of Pernik, Bulgaria.  Pernik is situated about 30 kilometers southwest of Bulgaria's capital, Sofia.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of projects.  This project involves several environmental upgrades and approximately  13 million of the projects total cost is related to environmental upgrades: -  slag cooling and crystallization; -  revamping the EAF off gas system; - EAF energy reduction program; -  plate mill reheat furnace energy reduction; -  long products mill reheat furnace energy reduction; -  additional water treatment; -  further site cleanup of waste debris and slag and demolition of old buildings; and -  other environmentally related expenditures.  Since the 24 months that Sidenor has been operating the plant, the sponsor has made huge strides in their modernization and revamping of the entire operation.  Employee morale is high, progress has been dramatic, and future plans are very ambitious. Role:
The project will have significant development impact, including benefits for consumers and businesses in Sri Lanka.  The Sri Lankan market for telecommunications is currently characterized by low national penetration, unreliable service with high fault rates, and long waiting lists for connection.  At end-2001, fixed line penetration was estimated at only 4.3%, while wireless penetration stood at only 3.8%.  In particular, it will: 

-  provide access and lower the entry barrier to affordable, high quality communications services; 
-  spur further competition; and 
-  foster economic growth.    

IFC has a strong demonstration and catalytic role in this Project.  On a broad scale, IFC's involvement will show support for private sector participation in the Sri Lankan telecommunications sector and demonstrate to other potential investors that longer-term financing is available in Sri Lanka for such projects.  Further and more generally, given the depressed state of the global telecommunications sector, support to and financing for emerging markets telecommunications projects is extremely important.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a category B project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  Potential environmental and social issues include corporate environmental and social management systems to ensure compliance of project facilities with local requirements and World Bank policies and guidelines; tower site development, including site selection criteria, land acquisition procedures, access road construction, control of hazardous materials including liquid fuels, and development of previously undisturbed land; use of PCBs and CFCs; solid and liquid waste treatment and disposal; fire prevention and emergency response; and workplace health and safety and training programs.  Dialog has prepared Environmental and Social Management Policies and Procedures for its operations to address the above issues and ensure compliance of Project facilities with local requirements and World Bank policies and guidelines.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community-  Head Office:  475, Union Place Colombo 02

Sponsor: The project sponsor is Telekom Malaysia, which is the leading telecommunications company in Malaysia and the 100% owner of Dialog.  TM provides voice and data services through its fixed-line, mobile, and Internet subsidiaries.  For the fiscal year ending 2002, TM posted net income of $278 million equivalent from revenues of $2.6 billion equivalent.  TM is listed on the Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange with a market capitalization of approximately $6.4 billion equivalent, with a majority being owned by the government.  TM recently established TMI as an investment holding company for its international assets which include operations in South Africa, Malawi, Guinea, Ghana, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, Thailand and Cambodia.  TM provides financial, strategic management, and technical support to its portfolio companies through TMI.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $110 million equivalent, covering capital expenditures and other investments.  The proposed IFC investment is up to $50 million, comprised of a $40 million senior A Loan and a $10 million subordinated C Loan, both for IFC's own account.

Project Description: Tala-Delhi Transmission Limited (TDTL, or the company) is a proposed joint venture between the private utility Tata Power Company Limited (Tata Power, which will own 51% of TDTL), and the Government of India (GoI) owned Power Grid Corporation of India Limited (PGCIL, which will own 49% of TDTL) to establish the Tala Transmission project (the project). PGCIL is also the sole off-taker of the project.  The project is to build, own, operate and maintain, on a BOOT basis and for 30 years, five 400kV and one 220 kV double circuit transmission lines of about 1,200 kilometers, with a capacity of about 3,000 MW.  The purpose of the transmission system is to: -  expand capacity of the grid connecting the power surplus region of East and Northeast India with the power deficit region of North India, and -  facilitate the evacuation of power from the 1,020 MW Tala Hydroelectric Project (Tala HEP) in Bhutan which is being executed by Tala Hydro Power Development Authority (THPA).
Role: Through this project, IFC is demonstrating its continued support for the development of Indias power sector, promoting sustainable development through growth of private power projects, with synergies in the rest of the economy.  This project supports the expansion and upgrade of transmission links between power surplus East and Northeast India and the power deficit North India, and meets a long overdue need for a high capacity transmission link between the two regions.  The project also facilitates evacuation of hydropower from Bhutan and contributes not only to reducing power shortages in India, but also to the economy of Bhutan.  Improved transmission capacity between the two regions will facilitate trading of power and enhance competition in the generation sector, which could lead to potentially lower energy costs for the end consumers.  Improved electricity transmission and greater availability of power are also likely to support investments in other sectors, thereby promoting economic growth.  The successful implementation of this first, private sector transmission project may act as a model for the much-needed private investment in the countrys transmission sector.IFC would be providing TDTL with access to long-term finance in local currency, which will strengthen the financial viability of the company and the stability of the transmission tariff over the life of the project.  Additionally, the private sectors participation of transmission services is a pioneering activity in emerging markets with few sponsors pursuing investment opportunities, and with few financial institutions having the experience and ability to structure these transactions.  This is IFCs investment in the first private sector transmission project in India.  By supporting the project, IFC expects to share its global experience in this sector with the sponsors and other Indian financial institutions, and encourage greater involvement and investment in the Indian transmission sector.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The following potential environment and social impacts of the project have been considered: -  Acquisition and maintenance of transmission line right-of-way and its impact on human livelihoods including physical resettlement, sites of cultural significance, and forests or other natural habitats and wildlife; -  Siting and construction of towers including the reclamation of construction sites, lay-down areas and access roads; -  Public disclosure and consultation; -  Worker health and safety; -  The use of PCB-containing materials in the electrical transmission network; and -  Monitoring and management of both contractor and operator environmental health and safety performance.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe environmental documents will be made available at the following locations:1) Power Grid Corporation of India Ltd,Siliguri Division, Vidyut Nagar,Post: Satellite Towenship,Dist. Ghaziabad (UP) 210 1026) Power Grid Corporation of India Ltd,Siliguri Division, Vidyut Nagar,Post: Satellite Towenship,Dist. Jalpaiguri, West Bengal  734 218
Sponsor: Tata Power, incorporated in 1919, is principally engaged in the business of generation, transmission and distribution of electricity.  Tata Power is the largest private company in the Indian power sector, with an asset base of about US$1.5 billion and revenues of around $800 million, as of March 31, 2002.  Tata Power has a license to generate, transmit and distribute thermal and hydroelectric power to bulk and retail consumers in its Mumbai (the capital city of the state of Maharashtra and a major business/ industrial hub in India) service area.PGCIL, the Central Transmission Utility, is the sole investment vehicle and operating agency of the GoI in the inter-state electricity transmission sector.  PGCIL is involved in the planning, construction and maintenance of high voltage inter-state electricity networks connecting large generating stations and main load centers.  With a vast network of over 40,000 circuit-kms spanning the entire country, PGCIL wheels over 40% of the entire power generated in India.  As of March 31, 2002, PGCIL had an asset base of approximately $3.5 billion and revenues of around $500 million.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at about $254 million.  The proposed IFC investment is a $62 million A Loan for IFCs own account.

Project Description: IFC plans to create a Central Asia Leasing Facility (the facility or the company) to expand financing options for small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and help them expand their operations, as well as to introduce competition in the financial sector.  The facility will on-lend to selected local financial institutions  banks, leasing companies and NGOs  to write leases in Kazakhstan, Kyrgyz Republic, Uzbekistan and later, Tajikistan.  Selection of participating financial institutions will be based on criteria such as:  track record of financial soundness, clear corporate governance and transparency standards, and demonstrated commitment to leasing and to the SME sector.  The facility will be supported by a donor-funded technical assistance program to address capacity and operational needs of local financial institutions.
Role: The facility would have a significant development impact for the Central Asia region,  i.e. it would:-  address the critical shortage of term funding for SMEs;-  help develop a robust leasing sector in the regions through the technical assistance components capacity building program;-  help deepen the financial markets and stimulate competition in the financial sector;-  assist SMEs in acquiring assets to expand existing operations, and eventually in accessing credit through banks; and-  generate employment (estimated ~7,000 jobs) through resultant growth of SMEs.By making available the facility and the technical assistance program, IFC will play a catalytic role in furthering the development of a robust leasing sector in the region, thus in helping deepen and diversify financial markets in these countries.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Financial Intermediary (FI) type project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure.  Each participating financial institution will be required to:	-  establish an environmental and social management system (policy, procedure, resources) for relevant operations and require that activities conducted under those operations comply with host country environmental, health and safety requirements;	-  appoint a senior officer with overall responsibility for environmental and social issues and identify an individual who will manage and/or conduct reviews.  Both must attend IFC sponsored or approved training in environmental and social management for financial institutions; and	-  submit an annual environmental performance report, which focuses on its environmental and social management system.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: IFC is taking the lead role in creating the facility; however, it is expected that other international financial institutions and donors would also invest in the facility.  Working with local leasing experts, technical assistance will be provided jointly by IFCs Private Enterprise Partnership and a leading, private international leasing company.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $40-50 million, of which IFC would invest $40 million.
Investment: 30.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan30.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The  facility will on-lend to participating financial institutions in Kazakhstan, Kyrgyz Republic, Tajikistan and Uzbekistan.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Financial Intermediary (FI) type project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure.  Each participating financial institution will be required to:	-  establish an environmental and social management system (policy, procedure, resources) for relevant operations and require that activities conducted under those operations comply with host country environmental, health and safety requirements;	-  appoint a senior officer with overall responsibility for environmental and social issues and identify an individual who will manage and/or conduct reviews.  Both must attend IFC sponsored or approved training in environmental and social management for financial institutions; and	-  submit an annual environmental performance report, which focuses on its environmental and social management system.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community

Project Description:
Banco Interfin S.A. (Interfin) is the second largest privately-owned bank in Costa Rica with $508 million in total assets and $43 million in equity as of December 31, 2002.  Interfin is 100%-owned by Corporación Interfin S.A. (the group or the company), incorporated in Costa Rica, which serves as a holding company for Interfin and its affiliates.  As of December 31, 2002, the group had $930 million in total assets and $82 million in shareholders' equity.

As with IFC's two previous projects with Interfin, the primary purpose of the project is allow Interfin to provide small and medium-size enterprises (SMEs) the much-needed access to long-term credit and to help finance equipment purchases for lease contracts under the group's leasing affiliate, Arrendadora Interfin (Arrendadora).  Additionally, this project will provide subordinated debt financing that will enable the group to grow and strengthen its competitive position as a regional bank.
Role:
-  Project Development:
In a region where SMEs still suffer from sufficient access to long-term credit, the project will enable a strong banking group to continue to efficiently and effectively provide financing to Costa Rican SMEs, which is essential to foster entrepreneurship, increase employment and contribute to higher standards of living.  Facilitating the group's growth strategy in the region will enable Corporación Interfin to provide more affordable and comprehensive banking solutions.  

-  IFC Role:
IFC's role in this project goes beyond its traditional role in supporting local financial institutions that provide SMEs access to credit, in that it seeks to have stimulative effect on the integration of the Central American financial sector, which is key to improving the efficient provision of financial services to local clients.  Financial sector integration is crucial to sustaining economic integration within Central America particularly in light of the accelerating globalization process and intensifying negotiations between Central America and the US on the free trade agreement.  The small economies of the Central American region would benefit from economies of scale by integrating themselves, in particular, in physical and financial infrastructure.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an FI Type 2 project.  Interfin will need to demonstrate that its existing environmental management system is adequate to address the environmental and social issues of the projects to be financed under this new financing.  Interfin must require all subprojects to be carried out and operated in compliance with the applicable environmental, health and safety (EH&S) requirements of the country where the subproject is situated. In addition, subprojects whose total cost is less than $500,000 must be consistent with IFC''s Microfinance Exclusion List. Subprojects whose total cost is $500,000 or greater must be carried out in accordance with IFC''s safeguard policies, be consistent with IFC''s Exclusion List, and meet the host country requirements. Interfin must obtain IFC clearance prior to making any loan or investment with IFC funds in any Category A subproject, and such a subproject must meet the applicable EH&S guidelines and safeguard policies of the World bank Group.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: As a wholly-owned subsidiary of Corporación Interfin, Banco Interfin's primary businesses are corporate and retail banking.  The group is well-diversified and provides a broad array of financial services including leasing, offshore banking, brokerage services, pension fund management, investment and merchant banking and asset management.  Corporación Interfin is owned by the original group of 12 local Costa Rican entrepreneurs (who individually own between 3.0% and 15.0%, for a total of 83.7%); FMO (the Dutch development finance company) and CABEI (the Central American Bank for Economic Integration) together own 4.7% and the remaining 11.6% is owned by individual investors.
Cost Nature:
The proposed IFC financings are comprised of a 
-  $15 million term loan to Banco Interfin to be used for on-lending and the discounting of lease receivables and 
-  $5 million subordinated loan  -to be counted as Tier II capital- to Corporación Interfin.
Investment: 20.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan20.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location:
Corporación Interfin's primary subsidiaries are Banco Interfin (retail and corporate banking), Arrendadora Interfin (leasing), Interfin Valores (brokerage services and investment and merchant banking), Créditos Bisa Interfin (credit cards), Interfin OPC (pension fund management), Corporación Privada de Inversiones de Centroamérica (trade financing) and Transamerica Bank and Trust, Ltd. (off-shore commercial banking).  All of the businesses are currently domiciled and operate in Costa Rica with the exception of the leasing business, which operates in each of the Central American countries, and the offshore business, which is located in Nassau, Bahamas.  

Banco Interfin, which represents 55% of the total assets of Corporación, acts as the primary provider for the broad array of financial services offered by the Group.  As of December 31, 2002 Interfin had 780 employees and 16 branches.  Customers have access to a network of 525 Automated Teller Machines (ATMs), including 22 that are owned by Interfin.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is an FI Type 2 project.  Interfin will need to demonstrate that its existing environmental management system is adequate to address the environmental and social issues of the projects to be financed under this new financing.  Interfin must require all subprojects to be carried out and operated in compliance with the applicable environmental, health and safety (EH&S) requirements of the country where the subproject is situated. In addition, subprojects whose total cost is less than $500,000 must be consistent with IFC''s Microfinance Exclusion List. Subprojects whose total cost is $500,000 or greater must be carried out in accordance with IFC''s safeguard policies, be consistent with IFC''s Exclusion List, and meet the host country requirements. Interfin must obtain IFC clearance prior to making any loan or investment with IFC funds in any Category A subproject, and such a subproject must meet the applicable EH&S guidelines and safeguard policies of the World bank Group.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Description: Continental is the third largest private bank in Panama with assets of $1.8 billion and equity of $191 million as of December 2002 with return on average equity of 13.7% and return on average assets of 1.4%.  Traditionally characterized as the premier corporate bank in Panama, Continental has evolved into a fully integrated universal bank offering comprehensive products through its four business lines: corporate banking, consumer banking, private and investment banking and treasury and correspondent banking.  With the recent acquisition of BIPAN Holdings, the fifth largest Panamanian commercial bank, Continental will also service small and medium clients, which comprise BIPAN's loyal customer base.  In addition, with the acquisition of Banco Aleman Platina, another Panamanian commercial bank specialized in trade financing with representative offices in Guatemala, El Salvador, Costa Rica, Mexico and Colombia, Continental hopes to embark on a regional strategy of providing traditional banking products and services through an existing and recognized network.  The project is to provide a financing package of $40 million to Banco Continental de Panamá S.A. (Continental, bank or the company) to address the bank's maturity mismatch resulting from long term lending for housing and project finance and short term liabilities that fund such loans, and to provide long-term funding to productive enterprises.
Role:
IFC has been requested to provide financing to Continental for the following reasons: 
-  to help Continental reduce its asset and liability mismatch; and 
-  to assist Continental in establishing an environmental management system.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a  Financial Intermediary Type1 project.  Continental will be required to develop an environmental management system to cover relevant operations (e.g., project finance, corporate finance).  The bank must require that investments under relevant operations meet host country environmental, health and safety requirements.  IFC will work with the bank to develop an environmental review capacity.  Depending upon IFC''s assessment, environmental training will be required.  Banco Continental will be required to provide an annual environmental performance report to IFCLocation of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: Grupo Financiero Continental (GFC) owns 100% of Continental, and the bank represents approximately 97% of GFC's assets.   GFC is majority owned by the Motta (32%) and Pascual families (14%), two of Panama's leading trade, financial and industrial conglomerates.  The other shareholders of GFC are Assa Compania de Seguros (13%), the Jacobs Group (8%), the Hebron Group (5%), all of which are Panamanian companies; the remaining 28% is owned by 400 small shareholders.
Cost Nature: IFC will provide $40 million to Continental to better match the assets and liabilities of the bank.
Investment: 40.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan40.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Continental is located in Panama City, Panama, and has representative offices in Mexico, Colombia, Guatemala, El Salvador and Costa Rica, through its subsidiary Banco Aleman Platina.  It also has an off-shore office in the Cayman Islands.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a  Financial Intermediary Type1 project.  Continental will be required to develop an environmental management system to cover relevant operations (e.g., project finance, corporate finance).  The bank must require that investments under relevant operations meet host country environmental, health and safety requirements.  IFC will work with the bank to develop an environmental review capacity.  Depending upon IFC''s assessment, environmental training will be required.  Banco Continental will be required to provide an annual environmental performance report to IFCLocation of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Description: The Lecico Group (Lecico or the Group), a leading manufacturer of sanitary ware and ceramic tiles in the Middle East, headquartered in Alexandria, Egypt, has requested IFC to provide a corporate loan of up to $20 million.  The Group's holding and main operating company Lecico Egypt S.A.E (Lecico Egypt or the company) is planning to make various investments to expand the Group's production capacity in Egypt and to refinance the debt of its majority-owned subsidiary the Lebanese Ceramic Industries Co. S.A.L. (Lecico Lebanon) in Lebanon.  The proposed investment will help Lecico address sanitary ware export growth opportunities in the region and Europe as well as reduce production costs further in order to make it more competitive.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category B project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedures.  Please refer to the Environmental Review Summary.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe environmental documents will be available at the Lecico Group's headquarters in Khorsid, Alexandria, Egypt and its plants in Egypt and Lebanon. Project Description:
This project - Joint Stock Commercial Bank Kyrgyzstan (AKB, company or the bank) is part of IFC's Central Asia Micro and Small Enterprise Facility (the facility), comprising individual credit lines to selected partner banks that will then be on-lent to micro and small enterprises (MSEs) through specialized micro and small business finance windows that will be created at the partner banks' level for this purpose.  Within the framework of the facility, IFC will, in close collaboration with EBRD, make available up to $45 million for lending (in the form of credit lines) to selected local banks for onlending to micro and small enterprises (MSEs) in Kazakhstan, The Kyrgyz Republic, Uzbekistan, and later Tajikistan.

AKB, the second largest bank in the Kyrgyz Republic, has been selected as a partner bank for the facility.  It was established in 1991, and was one of the first commercial banks in the country.  The objective of this project is to expand the frontier of finance by extending downward the range of market segments served by AKB.  Thus, the IFC credit line will increase the availability of sustained credit to creditworthy MSEs, while at the same time building up the lending capacity and skill base of AKB.
Role:
IFC's investment in AKB will have a strong development impact, as it will augment the availability of micro and small business finance in the Kyrgyz Republic that aims to improve the standard of living of the poorest segments of the population.

Microfinance is a key sector where IFC can focus its efforts to support economic development.  The IFC investment will assist in the development of the emerging micro and small business enterprise sector in the Kyrgyz Republic by augmenting financing to existing MSEs.  It will also have a strong institution-building role.  By providing AKB with training and technical assistance, the project will seek to address the shortage of banking skills that are necessary to establish a market-based banking environment, especially with respect to MSEs.  An additional key objective of this project is to generate a significant international demonstration effect, which can catalyze replication of model microfinance programs in developing countries, and in Central Asia in particular.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Financial Intermediary (FI) Type 1 project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  EBRD and IFC have consistent environmental requirements and EBRD have trained, and plan to continue training, all of the participating Partner Banks of which AKB is included.  The bank will be required to develop and implement an Environmental Management System (EMS) to screen loan applications for compliance with host country environment, health and safety requirements and consistency with a Microfinance Exclusion List developed jointly by EBRD and IFC.  AKB must identify two individuals to have responsibility for environmental matters and provide the appropriate training and will be required to provide an Annual Report on its EMS.  Funding for environmental capacity building should be an integral part of the TA effort.  AKB Kyrgystan will commit to meet the above requirements.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: The bank's ownership is well diversified, with its shares spread out among approximately 5,000 shareholders. Management and employees own approximately 34.5% of the bank's share capital, while the remaining 65.5% are owned by a number of Kyrgyz companies.
Cost Nature: The project involves an IFC investment of up to $1.5 million in the form of a credit line to AKB.
Investment: 45.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan45.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: AKB is based in Bishkek, with a country-wide branch network of 28 branches and 2 cash settlement offices.

AKB must identify two individuals to have responsibility for environmental matters and provide the appropriate training and will be required to provide an Annual Report on its EMS.  Funding for environmental capacity building should be an integral part of the TA effort.  AKB Kyrgystan will commit to meet the above requirements.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Description: The proposed project includes the construction and operation of two new commercial third party warehousing, logistical and office centers in the Moscow metropolitan area, totaling over 30,000 square meters of space.  The first complex, Southern, is projected to cost $7.4 million; the second, Baltia, is projected to cost $14.1 million, for a total of $21.5 million. Prospective tenants include reputable international and local firms involved in the wholesaling, retailing, and business services sectors. Southern and Baltia will be owned and developed by two Russian-based project companies, Kulon Development and Kulon-Estate respectively.
Role: IFC's investment will help to implement the project by providing long-term financing of structure and tenor currently unavailable in the local financial market.  IFC's support will help alleviate a shortage of logistical infrastructure in Moscow, contributing to an improvement in the business environment in Russia.  Development impacts associated with the project will be derived from the wider and more efficient availability of consumer goods at competitive prices throughout Russia.  The project may also lower costs and improve the ability of foreign manufacturers to export their products to the Russian market as well as the ability of Russian manufacturers to sell their products in Russia and abroad.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. The review of this project consisted of appraising technical and environmental  information submitted by the sponsors. Sponsor: The project companies will be majority owned by Cyprus-based Aldama Limited, which is privately held by Russian and Portuguese individuals who are experienced warehouse operators.  They are co-owners and managers of Joint Stock Company PTF Kulon, a major warehousing company that currently owns and operates a warehouse and office complex in Moscow providing storage services to several foreign and local companies located in Moscow.
Cost Nature: The total cost of the project is estimated at $21.5 million. IFC is considering a financing package of up to $15 million consisting of a $2.5 million A loan for IFC's own account, a syndicated B loan or parallel financing of up to $7.5 million for the account of participant banks and an income participating $5 million C loan for IFC's own account.

Location of the sites is advantageous for warehousing, logistical and office operations serving the Moscow metropolitan area. Both Southern and Baltia have good access to utilities and major transportation routes.

Project Description:
Oyak Bank (Oyak, the bank or the company) was formerly the Turk Boston Bank, which was established in 1984 as a branch of the First National Bank of Boston, then converted to a wholly-owned subsidiary in 1990, and subsequently sold to a group of local investors, including Ordu Yardimlasma Kurumu (OYAK). OYAK acquired majority ownership of the bank at the end of 1993 (it now owns 100%), and changed bank's name to Oyak Bank in mid-1996.  With a strong owner and conservative management, the bank has survived nearly three years of recession in Turkey as well as a devastating financial crisis in 2001/2002 which led to nearly a dozen banks being taken over by the State Deposit Insurance Fund (SDIF). Oyak Bank's merger with Sumerbank on January 11 2002, one of the banks auctioned by SDIF, is a clear sign how the Bank is committed in its growth strategy. With this merger the Bank's total assets reached around $2.1 billion (pre merger total assets were around $300 million) and total shareholder's equity amounted to roughly $228 million (as opposed to pro merger figure of $90 milion).
The project would consist of a flexible, multi-purpose facility, which would allow Oyak Bank to 

-  lengthen the average maturity of its liabilities, both strengthening its balance sheet and enabling it to fund longer term assets; 
-  build up its consumer finance activities; and 
-  make opportunistic acquisitions as the Turkish banking sector undergoes further consolidation.  

This would be IFC's second loan to OB; the first, a $40m syndicated facility is almost fully repaid.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an environmental and social FI type 1 project.  The bank must demonstrate that its current environmental management system (EMS) remains in place and is adequate to address the new IFC loan.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: Oyak Bank is 100% owned by OYAK. Oyak was established in 1961 as a foundation under the Special Act of Parliament as a supplementary social security institution for the military and civilian employees of the Turkish Armed Forces. The Oyak Group has grown to be one of the largest institutional investors in Turkey with 27 subsidiaries and 12 affiliated companies concentrated in the automotive, cement, financial, food/ chemicals  and services centers.
Cost Nature: The proposed IFC investment is a $50 million A Loan for IFC's own account.
Investment: 50.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan50.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Oyak Bank is headquartered in Maslak, Istanbul. The bank has 220 branches, 62 of them situated in Istanbul. However, the bank has presence in almost all provinces of the country which enables investments to be made throughout Turkey. Oyak Bank employs 3,590 personnel.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is an environmental and social FI type 1 project.  The bank must demonstrate that its current environmental management system (EMS) remains in place and is adequate to address the new IFC loan.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Description: It is proposed that IFC provide a credit line of up to $1.5 million to Finance and Trade Bank (Banca de Finante si Commert or Fincombank) for the purpose of on-lending to finance eligible sub-projects by way of sub-loans to eligible sub-borrowers.  Fincombank, previously state-owned, was privatized in 1993 and became one of Moldova's first private commercial banks.  Today, Fincombank provides a range of banking services to Moldovan businesses, primarily small and medium-sized businesses, through its 20 branch offices (six in Chisinau).  Fincombank has 166 employees and over 9,600 clients.
Role: The developmental impact of IFC's loan to FCB is expected to be far reaching in terms of its economic support for productive small businesses and its stimulus for growth and employment generation.  The organization's strong performance, as demonstrated by its portfolio growth and profitability, its methodology and its control mechanisms will serve as "best practice" examples for other institutions throughout Moldova.  IFC's investment will support the further growth and strengthening of the seventh largest bank in Moldova and one of the only banks that focuses primarily on small businesses.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an FI Type 1 project.  FCB must require that investments under relevant operations meet Moldovan environmental, health and safety requirements and be consistent with IFCs microfinance exclusion list.  Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Cost Nature: Total project cost is $1.5 million, funded through an IFC credit line of $1.5 million.
Investment: 1.50 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan1.50Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Fincombank's headquarters are located in Chisinau, Moldova.

FCB must require that investments under relevant operations meet Moldovan environmental, health and safety requirements and be consistent with IFCs microfinance exclusion list. Project Description:
Sundaram Finance Limited (SFL or the company) is the flagship company of a Chennai-based diversified financial services conglomerate.  Sundaram Finance Group is engaged in vehicle finance, mortgage finance, general insurance, asset management and manufacturing of auto components through various group companies.  The promoters, belonging to the larger TVS Group, hold a 37% stake in the company with the other 63% widely held by  Indian and foreign institutional investors and by retail Indian shareholders.  SFL has a fifty year track record in financing the development of the road transport industry in India especially in the four southern states.  The company continues to build its auto and truck finance business with a solid reputation.  SFL is now one of the 5 largest Non-Bank Financial Companys (NBFCs) in India and is rated AAA for its medium term obligations by ICRA and AA+ by CRISIL for its fixed deposit obligations.  SFL's shares are listed on the national stock exchange of India.

This project is to assist Sundaram Finance Limited (SFL or the company), a leading Indian non-bank financial company, to lengthen the maturity of its liability profile and broaden its funding base.  IFC intends to grant a long-term loan of up to $45 million to SFL, to be used by the company to support its growing operations primarily for increasing trucking and automobile financing needs in rural and semi-rural areas -- a segment constituting an important part of the broader SME market and a critical part of the cargo transportation infrastructure in India.
Role:
Development Impact:

This project's main development impact is to support a strong well-managed Indian financial services group and assist it to grow across its businesses.  The project will enable the company to 

-  expand lending to the truck transport segment which is an important constituent of the SME market and is gaining increasing significance with the recent improvements in road infrastructure, 

-  contribute to improving access to financial products and services in semi-rural areas of India.  

The truck financing market comprises about $1.5 billion per year in annual disbursements and encouraging greater flow of this credit to truckers in the smaller towns and semi-rural areas will assist in the sustainable growth of those economies.  

Fit With World Bank Group Strategy:

As part of IFC's regional business development strategy, we want to increase our presence in Southern India, and strengthen our relationship with leading financial institutions which can innovate and introduce new products or develop new markets.  This second investment with the Sundaram group, with its focus on southern India and range of financial services, supports the overall World Bank Group strategy.  In addition, the Sundaram group has interests in auto components, which is another priority area for business development.

IFC's Role:
IFC's role in this project is to 
-  encourage SFL to expand lending to truckers in semi-rural areas, and 
-  extend SFL's liability profile with 6 year money as against the 2-3 years funds that are easily available locally.  

SFL is a premier client and this loan will be a quality asset for IFC.  This transaction is also a potential door-opener for deals with other companies in the TVS Group, especially in the auto ancillary industry in which we see a significant role for IFC.  Finally, SFL is a key player in southern India which is a region that IFC is now looking to make a strong impact.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an FI Type 1 project. SFL will be required to develop an environmental management system.  SFL must require that investments under relevant operations meet host country environmental, health and safety requirements.  IFC will assess SFLs capacity for environmental review and will provide training as necessary.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor:
-  TVS Group:

The TVS Group has been the largest automotive component group in India since 1911.  With total annual sales of about $1.7 billion, it is also a major player in other sectors such as two-wheelers, electronic equipment and auto ancillaries.  The Group comprises about 29 different companies, several of them joint ventures and most of them highly profitable.  The major companies in the TVS group, apart from the companies under Sundaram Finance Group, are TVS & Sons, Lucas TVS, TVS Motors, Sundaram Clayton, Sundaram Industries, Southern Roadways and Sundaram Fasteners.  The Group has, over the decades, built a strong franchise and a reputation for conservatism, integrity and creditworthiness.
Cost Nature: The proposed investment is an up to $45 million A loan for IFC's own account.
Investment: 43.61 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan43.61Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The company is headquartered in Chennai, the capital of Tamil Nadu in India with 122 branches located nationwide.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is an FI Type 1 project. SFL will be required to develop an environmental management system.  SFL must require that investments under relevant operations meet host country environmental, health and safety requirements.  IFC will assess SFLs capacity for environmental review and will provide training as necessary.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Description: The project consists of a $5.0 million credit line to Corporación Nicaragüense Financiera (Confia, or the company) S.A.  Confia is a financial institution supervised by the Superintendency of Banks of Nicaragua and is specialized in lending to micro-entrepreneurs. Confia began operating in 2000, and since then has become the leading Nicaraguan microfinance institution.
Role: The developmental impact of Confia is expected to be far reaching in terms of its economic support for productive small businesses, stimulus for employment generation and confidence building for the banking sector.  Microfinance in Nicaragua is in its infancy and there is ample opportunity for portfolio growth.  There are about 200,000 small and micro-entrepreneurs in Nicaragua and the sector represents a significant percentage of  the GDP.   This project is expected to reach at least 200 new small businesses and micro-entrepreneurs during the tenor of the credit line.
Environmental Social Issues: Confia must require that investments under relevant operations meet host country environmental, health and safety requirements and be consistent with IFCs microfinance exclusion list.  IFC will assess Confias capacity for environmental review.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: IPC, the sponsor, is a German based microfinance consulting firm, widely regarded as one of the leaders in the microfinance industry. IPC has a track-record of creating greenfield financial institutions, providing these institutions with senior managers that implement tight and efficient operations.  In 1998, IPC created an investment company, Internationale Micro Investitionen Aktiengesellschaft (IMI), to act as a vehicle for investment in microfinance institutions that IPC created or helped manage.  IMI has 73% equity ownership.
Cost Nature: The project consists of a $5.0 million credit line.

Project Description:
This transaction consists of a subordinated credit line of up to $5.0 million and a senior loan of up to $5.0 million to Financiera Calpiá S.A. (Calpiá or the company) of El Salvador.  Calpiá is an IFC investee.  Calpiá requires Tier II capital for two reasons:
-  to support its  portfolio growth (the net loan portfolio increased 45% from the prior year to $43.3 million equivalent and is expected to grow at 30-40% for the next five years ); and,
-  to support the extension of its operations to other countries in Central America, with an initial direct investment of $2.5 million in Financiera Confia, Nicaragua.  

Calpiá will, however, be expanding its business in neighboring countries through planned capital increases and not an increase in debt.
Environmental Social Issues: Calpiá must establish and maintain an environmental management system to ensure that investments under relevant operations meet host country environmental, health and safety requirements and are consistent with IFCs microfinance exclusion list. In 1998, IPC created an investment company, Internationale Micro Investitionen Aktiengesellschaft (IMI), to act as a vehicle for investment in microfinance institutions that IPC created or helped manage.  IMI owns 25% of Calpiá's equity.
