Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is an FI Type 2 project and will be required to undertake an environmental review of each subproject.  IFC already has an investment in this bank.  Based on a review by IFC, the bank should improve it''s EHS performance by having new staff attend the CEA Workshop which will improve their project review process, and allow them to update their EMS.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community

Project Description: The project entails an IFC equity investment of up to Rmb130 mn ($16 million approx.) for up to 7.5% of equity in a greenfiled joint stock life reinsurance company, China Life Reinsurance Company Limited (CLRC or the company).  The company will be founded by China Reinsurance (Group) Corporation (China Re) and a number of domestic and foreign investors. The project represents a first major step on the part of China Re, which is 100% government owned, to attract private sector investors into its shareholding.
Role:
The project will inject much needed capital into an industry that is quickly growing at a time when the interest from international trade buyers is low. The successful development of a professional life insurance industry is a vital element in the development of an economy.??Reinsurance is a key ingredient in the successful development of a professional insurance industry.

IFC would assist the Chinese government in privatization of its state-own life reinsurance company and in institutional strengthening of this newly privatized company.  CLRC looks to IFC as a desirable partner who would help attract other private investors as well as contributing to the professional expertise and corporate governance of the company.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category C project according to IFC''s project review procedure because no environmental and social impacts are expected to result from a power trading operation. No further environmental or social review is required.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: China Re, previously known as PICC RE, was the result of a spin-off from the People's Insurance Company of China (PICC) in 1996, when the Chinese government decided to separate life, non-life and reinsurance operations into separate legal entities. As a 100% state-owned company (its initial capital was funded directly by the Ministry of Finance), China Re was the sole authorized onshore reinsurer in China accepting compulsory and voluntary businesses for both life and non-life reinsurances. China Re has about 250 employees, 204 of whom are based at the head office in Beijing, 40 in the domestic branches and six in the representative offices.
Cost Nature: IFC's equity investment entails an amount of up to Rmb130 mn (USD16 million approx.) for up to 7.5% of the common shares to be issued by CLRC.
Investment: 15.34 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity15.34* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Beijing, Capital of China.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category C project according to IFC''s project review procedure because no environmental and social impacts are expected to result from a power trading operation. No further environmental or social review is required.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Description: Digicel is a provider of mobile telephone services which entered the Jamaican market in early 2001.  Since then, the Company has succeeded in attracting in excess of 700,000 subscribers, distinguishing itself from the incumbent provider through rates as well as superior quality, functionality, and service.  The currently proposed Project aims to finance Digicels expansion into five islands in the Eastern Caribbean:  St. Lucia, St. Vincent, Grenada, Aruba and Barbados.  The introduction of Digicel to these markets is expected to have the same positive effects to mobile phone coverage, quality and rates as in Jamaica.  IFC will not finance Digicels operations in Aruba since this island is territory of the Netherlands, an IFC Donor.  In addition, IFC will not finance Digicels operations in St. Vincent unless it becomes an IFC member.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category C project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  For IFC''s previous investments with the Digicel group -- for Mossel, a mobile GSM telephone subsidiary in Jamaica -- Mossel developed an environmental management system that provides for the identification and mitigation of environmental and social impacts associated with Mossel''s wireless telecommunications operations.  Digicel has agreed to apply Mossel''s environmental management system to Digicel Eastern Caribbean Limited''s operations.  In addition, Digicel''s environmental annual monitoring report to IFC for Mossel will be expanded to cover Digicel Eastern Caribbean Limited''s operations.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The Projects main sponsor is Mr. Denis OBrien, with a majority stake in the Company. He has had a variety of experiences with telecommunications projects worldwide. Most notable of these was his highly competitive mobile business in Ireland called Esat, which was ultimately taken over by British Telecom for US$2.5 billion.  Esat was the first competitor to the state-owned Irish telephone company in 1991.  Much like the situation in Jamaica, Esat entered the market with only one license. However, it eventually procured licenses for all sectors of the telecommunications market, including mobile cellular services.  The minority shareholders in Mossel are Mr. Osmond Kilkenney and Mr. Leslie Buckley.
Cost Nature: The total project costs are estimated at US$120 million.  The proposed IFC investment is up to US$14.55 million, comprising a US$10 million Senior Loan for IFCs account and up to a US$4.55 million equity investment for IFCs account.
Investment: 14.60 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan13.68Equity0.92* These investment figures are indicative
Location: DECL is headquartered in St. Lucia, and the Project sites are five islands in the Eastern Caribbean:  St. Lucia, St. Vincent, Grenada, Barbados and Aruba.  Both rural and urban areas will be covered by the new network, and the Company expects to reach approximately 75% of the individual countrys populations.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category C project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  For IFC''s previous investments with the Digicel group -- for Mossel, a mobile GSM telephone subsidiary in Jamaica -- Mossel developed an environmental management system that provides for the identification and mitigation of environmental and social impacts associated with Mossel''s wireless telecommunications operations.  Digicel has agreed to apply Mossel''s environmental management system to Digicel Eastern Caribbean Limited''s operations.  In addition, Digicel''s environmental annual monitoring report to IFC for Mossel will be expanded to cover Digicel Eastern Caribbean Limited''s operations.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community

Project Description: The project is a financial transaction whereby a consortium led by Mvelaphanda Resources Limited (Mvela or the company), through a wholly owned special purpose subsidiary Mvelaphanda Gold Limited (Mvela Gold), will purchase, for ZAR4.1 billion, a 15% stake in Gold Fields Limiteds (GFL) South African assets. Mvela has requested IFC to subscribe to ZAR200 million (approximately $27 million) worth of preference shares to Mvela Gold to support the financing of this transaction.  This transaction would enable GFL to satisfy the requirement under the new South African Mining Charter that all mining companies achieve, within 5 years, at least 15% ownership transfer to historically disadvantaged South Africans (HDSAs). All mining companies will be required to meet the provisions of the Mining Charter before government will convert their existing old order mining rights into new order mining rights. The assets underlying the transaction comprise all of GFLs South African operations, namely the Driefontein, Kloof and Beatrix mines, which have been estimated by GFL and Mvela to comprise 70% of GFLs total value. The acquisition price was based on this percentage and the value of GFL at the time the transaction was first announced.   Mvela has implemented two significant Black Economic Empowerment (BEE) transactions in the mining sector, whereby it acquired minority stakes in Northam Platinum Limited, a platinum mining operation, and Trans Hex Group Limited, a diamond mining operation. This transaction is consistent with Mvelas strategy of acquiring stakes in a diversified range of mining companies, in the context of the Mining Charter and the SA governments push towards BEE.  It will be of an order of magnitude greater than the previous two transactions and is Mvelas next step in fulfilling its ultimate ambition to become an operator in its own right.
Environmental Social Issues: The transactions purpose is to facilitate a transfer of minority ownership and as such it will have no adverse environmental impacts. It has accordingly been classified as Category C according to IFC''s Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects. Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The project sponsor is Mvela, which is 57% owned and controlled by Mvelaphanda Holdings Limited (MHL).  MHL is a private company headquartered in Johannesburg which was formed in 1998 by Mr Tokyo Sexwale. MHL has since become one of South Africa''s leading BEE players, with minority investments in over twenty companies across a diverse range of sectors, including property, oil and gas, and financial services. Several broad based empowerment entities, such as groups representing former political prisoners and rural women, are stakeholders of MHL.GFL is the worlds fourth largest gold company, with annual attributable gold production of over 4.4 million ounces and attributable mineral resources of 187 million ounces and mineral reserves of 79 million ounces. It has operations in South Africa, Australia and Ghana and gold and platinum group metals exploration projects throughout the world.
Cost Nature: The total transaction size is estimated at ZAR4.1 billion (approximately $560 million). IFCs proposed investment comprises a quasi-equity investment for IFCs own account in the form of a subscription for ZAR200 million (approximately $27 million) of preference shares in Mvela Gold. The balance of the funding will consist of debt and additional preference shares to be raised by Mvela (complemented by ZAR300 million of financing from GFL), and a significant equity capital raising by Mvela. A significant component of the structure will be in the form of preference shares to be provided by IFC and a group of South African lenders.
Investment: 28.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan28.0Equity0.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Mvelas office is located in Dunkeld West, Johannesburg, South Africa.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The transactions purpose is to facilitate a transfer of minority ownership and as such it will have no adverse environmental impacts. It has accordingly been classified as Category C according to IFC''s Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects. Location of environmental documents In locally affected community

Project Description: The proposed project involves the construction of a 240,000 tons annual capacity greenfield float glass plant in the Russian Federation to meet its growing domestic demand.  The project will be located in the Moscow region close to its target markets.  Initially sales will focus on the construction industry but later may expand to the automotive sector.
Role:
The project would have a substantial impact on the development of the industry and the local economy.  Pilkington would bring state-of-the art float glass expertise and the best technological and managerial practices to Russia.  The project will increase the competitive structure of the glass industry in the country and consumers will benefit from competitively priced, better quality float glass.  It would create jobs and would also positively affect the country's balance of payment account as it results in import substitution.  As a large industrial complex, the project would also generate linkages with other industries.

IFC Role consists of: 
-  providing long-term funding which otherwise is not available in the country,
-  ensuring that the project is implemented in an environmentally sound way,
-  the project could encourage other lenders and investors to consider investments in the Russian Federation.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects.  The most important environmental, health and safety and social impacts are related to:-  site location and suitability; -  sustainable raw material supply;  -  air emissions; and  -  occupational health and safety.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe company will display the environmental documents at the following location:

Pilkington Glass LLC
Troilinskiy Pereulok, 3, 2nd floor
119002 MoscowRussian Federation
Sponsor:
The project is sponsored by Pilkington plc (Pilkington or the company), and AIG Emerging Europe Infrastructure Fund L.P. (AIG EEIF).  Pilkington and AIG EEIF will each hold 50% of the share capital of the project company.

Employing approximately 25,600 people globally, Pilkington is a leading worldwide producer of float glass products, automotive glass products and specialty glass.  Established in 1826, it is a publicly traded company on the London Stock Exchange since 1970.

AIG EEIF is a private equity fund with $550 million capital to invest in selected greenfield projects, companies undergoing post-privatization restructuring and privatization in Eastern and Southern European countries including the Russian Federation.
Cost Nature: Total project cost is estimated at EUR190 million of which capital cost is EUR165 million.  The proposed IFC investment is a EUR42.5 million A loan for IFC's own account.  Co-financing by EBRD for the project is planned.
Investment: 53.58 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan53.58Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The project site is greenfield in the Ramenskii District, 35 kilometers south east of Moscow.  The site is located in rural area along the rail line.  A new access to the main road to Moscow will be constructed as part of the project.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati:
This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects.  The most important environmental, health and safety and social impacts are related to:-  site location and suitability; -  sustainable raw material supply;  -  air emissions; and  -  occupational health and safety.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe company will display the environmental documents at the following location:

Pilkington Glass LLC
Troilinskiy Pereulok, 3, 2nd floor

Sector: CA - Glass and Glass Products (Including Glass and Mineral Wool)

Company Name: METEKSAN SISTEM VE BILGISAYAR TEKNOLOJILERI AS USKUDAR ISTANBUL SUBESI
Project Description:
Meteksan Sistem Ve Bilgisayar Teknolojileri AS (Meteksan, or the company) is one of Turkey's leading information technology (IT) companies.  The company's primary focus is to provide turnkey IT solutions for government agencies, state-owned enterprises, and large and medium-sized private sector corporations. The company is headquartered in Ankara, Turkey and employs approximately 400 full-time staff.

The project consists of: 
-  refinancing short-term debt and current maturities of long-term debt; 
-  financing capital expenditures; and 
-  funding working capital needs to position the company for growth.  

The proposed IFC loan would extend the average maturity of the company's debt beyond what is currently available in the market for Turkish companies.
Role:
The project is expected to have a significant development impact in the following areas: 

-  Jobs/Training.  
The company currently employs over 400 people.  The project will have a significant development impact by potentially creating a number of additional IT-related jobs in Turkey and by providing state-of-the-art training and skills development to recent university graduates, building a knowledge industry while improving public efficiency and governance.  

-  Healthcare.  
Overall healthcare expenditures in Turkey have historically been quite low, which has resulted in a health care system that provides poor quality and inefficient services to the Turkish population.  Meteksan will help to address this issue by providing medical institutions with modern clinical information systems, including hospital information systems, laboratory information systems, and radiology information systems.  

-  Education.  
The Turkish Ministry of National Education (MoNE) is currently sponsoring several educational programs targeted at providing basic and higher-level education to the Turkish population.  Though its Mobilsoft subsidiary, Meteksan has written numerous self-learning programs for children and adults.

IFC Role:

-  Corporate Governance.   
IFC's investment will be conditioned on increased independence of Meteksan from other group companies.  This will allow the company to optimize its capital structure and more aggressively pursue growth.

-  Demonstration Effect.  
The project would be IFC's first investment in a Turkish technology firm.  An IFC investment at this time would support a later-stage technology company that has successfully grown to become one of the leading IT companies in Turkey.  It would also provide the company with capital in a difficult financing environment.  Following the 2001 financial crisis, it has been extremely difficult for Turkish companies to obtain hard currency credit, and it is still difficult for companies to raise financing from sources outside of Turkey. The project, thus presents an excellent opportunity to serve as a catalyst to bring other international investors into the market.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category C project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure. There are minimal environmental or social impacts associated with this project.  Therefore, no further environmental or social analysis is required.If the construction of physical assets becomes necessary during the life of the IFC investment, the sponsor will notify IFC of such plans and obtain IFC''s consent prior to commencing construction.  In addition, the sponsor will develop procedures to appraise these projects and demonstrate compliance with all applicable environmental, occupational health, fire and life safety legislation and standards of the host country, as well as relevant World Bank Group environmental and social policies and guidelines.The sponsor will develop a Corporate Environment and Social Policy Statement demonstrating their commitment to comply with all applicable environmental, occupational health, fire and life safety legislation and standards of the host country in which business is conducted, as well as relevant World Bank Group environmental and social policies, guidelines and industry best practice.  The policy will indicate that the sponsors will not knowingly engage in any of the activities listed in the Exclusion List Annex A or Elements of a Code of Conduct for Internet/e-Commerce Projects.The sponsor will also develop a Code of Conduct to be posted on their web site to address the issues raised in the Exclusion List and Elements of a Code of Conduct for Internet/e-Commerce Projects.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: Meteksan is 100% owned, through both direct and indirect ownership stakes, by Bilkent Holding (Holding or the sponsor), a holding company established in 1986 to consolidate a diverse group of companies for the purpose of providing services and financial support (through donations) to Bilkent University (the University), one of Turkey's leading education institutes.  Bilkent Holding is 100% owned by Bilkent University.  Bilkent Holding currently operates in a number of sectors, including construction, furniture and fixtures, printing, pulp and paper, energy, tourism, and information technology.
Cost Nature:
Total project cost over the next two years (2003-2004) is estimated to be approximately $20 million.

The proposed IFC investment consists of a senior secured loan of up to $8.5 million.  The loan will be secured by an irrevocable bank guarantee, for all amounts payable to IFC over the life of the loan.
Investment: 8.50 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan8.50Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The company is located in Ankara, Turkey and operates 19 local support offices throughout the country.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category C project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure. There are minimal environmental or social impacts associated with this project.  Therefore, no further environmental or social analysis is required.If the construction of physical assets becomes necessary during the life of the IFC investment, the sponsor will notify IFC of such plans and obtain IFC''s consent prior to commencing construction.  In addition, the sponsor will develop procedures to appraise these projects and demonstrate compliance with all applicable environmental, occupational health, fire and life safety legislation and standards of the host country, as well as relevant World Bank Group environmental and social policies and guidelines.The sponsor will develop a Corporate Environment and Social Policy Statement demonstrating their commitment to comply with all applicable environmental, occupational health, fire and life safety legislation and standards of the host country in which business is conducted, as well as relevant World Bank Group environmental and social policies, guidelines and industry best practice.  The policy will indicate that the sponsors will not knowingly engage in any of the activities listed in the Exclusion List Annex A or Elements of a Code of Conduct for Internet/e-Commerce Projects.The sponsor will also develop a Code of Conduct to be posted on their web site to address the issues raised in the Exclusion List and Elements of a Code of Conduct for Internet/e-Commerce Projects.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Description: Opet Petrolcülük A.S. (Opet or the company) is a retail distributor of petroleum products in Turkey, owned 50% by the Koç Group of Turkey and 50% by Opets founding shareholders, the Ozturk family.  The project is aimed at strengthening the companys position in the Turkish petroleum products distribution industry and enhancing its competitiveness in advance of further liberalization.  The project is comprised of :-  the construction of a greenfield marine terminal and tank storage facility which will increase the companys oil products storage capacity from 320,000 m3 to 766,000 m3; and,-  expansion of the companys existing retail distribution network, with new stations primarily located in the larger cities of Turkey.  The distribution expansion network will enhance the companys brand recognition in the lucrative Istanbul, Izmir and other larger retail markets. In addition, the project will enable Opet to import larger parcels of products, store in-house, reduce transportation costs and improve the reliability of supply, while simultaneously supporting growth in its fuel distribution business. Opet hopes to take advantage of its strategic location at the mouth of the Black Sea to offer bunkering facilities for Caspian oil products. The intense sea traffic in the region will also give Opet the opportunity to purchase low-cost petroleum products.
Role: Development Impact:The proposed project will have a number of beneficial impacts, including:-  enhancing the long-term viability of a Turkish company which operates in a cyclical industry;  Opet will gain economies of scale, improve its operating efficiencies, and raise standards resulting in potentially lower fuel prices to consumers when the market liberalizes;  -  increasing competition in the automotive LPG and retail petroleum and products sectors;  -  enhancing existing retail distribution offerings and providing cleaner roadside facilities to consumers in the Istanbul and Marmara regions; -  enhancing investor confidence in working with a strong Turkish company;-  putting the company in a position to take advantage of the market liberalization anticipated under the New Petroleum Law; -  allowing oil products to be stored and distributed in compliance with EU quality standards;-  allowing Opet to demonstrate its commitment to sustainable business practices;       -  allowing Opet to continue to be one of the more significant tax paying entities in Turkey.IFC Role:The IFC investment will enable the company to lower its funding cost and secure funding of longer maturities, thus stabilizing its cash flow through periods of cyclicality.  Current market conditions in Turkey do not indicate that alternative sources of long-term finance will be available anytime soon. Under these conditions only larger multinational players such as BP and Shell have access to finance for the upgrading and modernization of their distribution networks.  IFC has a key role to play in the mobilization of long-term capital under the IFC B Loan program and in assisting parallel lenders such as FMO and DEG.  The proposed B Loan aims to provide reasonably priced long-term financing, which is important not only for ensuring profitability in an increasingly competitive domestic distribution market, but also for positioning the company to take advantage of changes in the market expected under the New Petroleum Law.  IFC has provided in depth advice on marketing and technical issues pertaining to the proposed Marmara marine terminal, as well as an important role in ensuring proper environmental compliance.  Finance facilities provided to the project will also help remove the need for petroleum product distributors in the Thrace region to transport supplies over the two Bosphorous bridges by tanker.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. The review of this project consisted of appraising technical, environmental and social information submitted by Opet as well as visits to the proposed terminal site on the Sea of Marmara and the existing Opet terminal in Ismit.  The following potential environment, health, safety and social impacts of the projects were analyzed.-  Site selection and land acquisition;-  Compliance of the marine terminal and storage facilities with IFC, international, and Turkish environmental,      health and safety (EHS) requirements; and      -  Labor and community issues.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe Opet environmental documents will be posted in the following places for local disclosure:-  at the corporate headquarters in Istanbul; and  -  at the site of the proposed terminal.
Sponsor: Opet Shareholder Structure:From its inception in 1992 through November 2002, Opet was owned 100% by the Ozturk family, which had over 20 years trading experience in the Turkish petroleum sector.  In  December 2002, the Koç Group purchased 50% of Opets shares from the Ozturk family for $125 million.  The Ozturk family collectively retained 50% of the outstanding shares.  The Koç Group obtained its shares through Aygaz, its LPG distribution company, as well as through other affiliated companies. The current Opet shareholding structure is as follows:  Öztürk Family Members (50%), Aygaz A.S. (40%) and other Koç Group Companies (10%).                                                       Aygaz & Koç Group:Aygaz is majority-controlled (52.5%) by the Koç Group, Turkeys largest diversified conglomerate with operations in energy and numerous other sectors.  The Koç Group is one of IFCs most important global relationships.  Aygaz is listed on the Istanbul Stock Exchange where 28.5% of its shares are publicly traded.
Cost Nature: The project cost is estimated to be $150 million and Opet has requested IFC to provide a corporate loan consisting of a $25 million A Loan and a $35 million B Loan.
Investment: 25.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan25.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The marine terminal and storage facilities are to be located north of the Marmara Sea in Thrace (in a suburban area) and will consist of a marine terminal, tank farm, truck loading units, pipelines between the marine terminal and tank farm, sanitary waste treatment unit, ballast water treatment facilities, auxiliary systems, fire fighting, steam generation, water treatment unit, motor control center, diesel generator and compressed air system.  The retail stations will be located all over Turkey, with special concentration in the largest cities.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. The review of this project consisted of appraising technical, environmental and social information submitted by Opet as well as visits to the proposed terminal site on the Sea of Marmara and the existing Opet terminal in Ismit.  The following potential environment, health, safety and social impacts of the projects were analyzed.-  Site selection and land acquisition;-  Compliance of the marine terminal and storage facilities with IFC, international, and Turkish environmental,      health and safety (EHS) requirements; and      -  Labor and community issues.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe Opet environmental documents will be posted in the following places for local disclosure:-  at the corporate headquarters in Istanbul; and  -  at the site of the proposed terminal.
Sector: AC - Other Petroleum and Coal Products

Project Description: Nanjing Kumho Tire Company Limited (the company or NKT) is a company based in Nanjing, China that produces tires for passenger cars, trucks and buses.  Total revenues for 2002 were approximately $115 million.  The Company was formed in 1994 as a joint venture between Korea Kumho Tire Co., Ltd. of Korea, local Chinese partners and a consortium of investors.  IFC financed the initial green-field project and is now contemplating the financing of the expansion.The companys current nameplate capacity is 3 million tires per annum, which is insufficient for them to meet demand.  In 2002, the company produced almost 5 million tires, by increasing its working days and shifts, optimizing process flow and substituting bias tire production capacity with radial tire production.  The project is to expand the companys nameplate capacity to 8 million tires per annum, with expectations that it can produce up to 10 million tires on the equipment. The company has a 12% share in the national radial tire market share with strong penetration in the south and east regions of China.  The expansion project will enable to company to meet ongoing demand for tires, and also to produce to a quality standard adequate to meet the requirements of the most advanced OEM customers in China.  NKT will also continue to export a portion of its tires.  The company has had strong financial results in recent years, and intends to finance a portion of the project through internally generated cash flow.
Role: The project contributes to the restructuring of Chinas tire industry, which is a key element of the Chinese governments plan to develop the domestic automotive sector as well as a modern parts and components industry.  NKTs plan to enter the northern market of China will promote competition in that regional market.  The project also benefits from utilizing the technological and marketing expertise of KTC.  NKT currently has 1,558 staff which are projected to increase to 2,081 over the project period.NKT will create jobs.  In addition, the increased economic output will create wealth in NKTs value chains which include domestic Chinese suppliers of raw materials and outsourced components, as well as providers of transport, installation and after sales service.  In particular, attention will be given to strengthening the linkages with the SMEs which form part of NKTs aftermarket distribution network.  The expansion will generate economies of scale and will bring in new technology, enabling the company to meet the quality requirements of Chinas leading automotive OEMs.  Finally, the success of the project will provide a demonstration effect, which will encourage further foreign direct investment into China.IFCs role in the project includes the following:- to structure the investment and provide long-term capital, mobilize co-financing, including long-term loans from local banks;- to support technology transfer, leading to improved efficiency, quality standards and profitability;- to support ongoing environmental performance at the company;- to support and develop the companys linkages with distributor SME companies, increasing benefits in the local economy.  Such a program might include management training, consulting, and MIS development.  In this regard, IFC will leverage its experience in other tire distribution linkage programs developed in the project development facilities.
Environmental Social Issues: The companys environmental performance at its existing operation has been adequate for the last three annual reporting cycles.  The environmental and social issues which may be associated with this project are emissions to air, waste water treatment, energy efficiency, raw material storage including dust control; handling of solid wastes and hazardous materials; fire safety and emergency response and labor and workplace conditions.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityA translation of the ERS will be available at the plant entrance where the workers access the facility.Address: 418 Heyan Road, Nanjing, Jiangsu, China.
Sponsor: Sponsor:  Kumho Tire Co., Inc. (KTC, the Sponsor) was formerly a business segment of Kumho Industrial Co., Ltd. (KIC) and was involved in the manufacture and sale of tires.  Effective July 1, 2003, KIC spun-off its tire business into KTC, in which it retains a 30% shareholding.  The Korean Military Mutual Aid Association, an investment fund for Korean military personnel holds 50%.  The remaining 20% is held by 14 other shareholders that are mostly suppliers or customers of KTC.  KTCs opening balance sheet of July 30, 2003 had total assets equivalent to approximately $1.35 billion, long term liabilities of $679 million and net worth equivalent to $424 million.  KTC has two manufacturing plants in Korea, and accounts for about half of the domestic tire sales in Korea with strong international sales.  The 2002 sales of  KTC (on a pro-forma basis) were $1.23 billion, and 2003 sales are anticipated to be in the same range. Project Company Ownership Structure:  As of July 1, 2003, the company is effectively held by KTC (51%), Nanjing Construction and Building Materials Industrial (Group) Corp., Ltd. and Nanjing Investment Corporation (20% and 5%, respectively), and the following shareholders: International Finance Corporation (8%), Kookmin Bank (6%), Asian Finance and Investment Corporation Ltd. (5%), and DEG (5%).  The official transfer of shareholding from KIC and another Kumho Group company to KTC will be formalized by Ministry of Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation (MOFTEC) in early 2003.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $130 million comprised of $87 million in construction cost,  incremental working capital and refinancing of short-term debt. The total project cost breakdown is as follows:Project Cost:Total Construction Cost: 87 million, 67% of total;Incremental Working Capital: 5 million, 4% of total;Refinancing of ST loan: 38 million, 29% of to total;Total Project Cost: 130 million, 100% of total.The Financial Plan is made up of $28 million in additional equity, internal cash flow, and $61 million in long term debt from IFC, DEG and parallel lenders.  The proposed IFC investment consists of $2.2 million in equity and an A Loan of $30 million for its own account. The Financial plan breakdown is as follows.Financial Plan:Total Equity (Rights Issue): 28 million, 21 % of total;Internal Cash Flow: 41 million, 31% of total;Total Debt: 61 million, 47% of total;Total Financing 130 million, 100% of total.
Investment: 40.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan34.0Equity6.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The project is located on the existing premises of NKT at 418 Heyan Road in Nanjing, China.  There is available land at the existing site for the expansion.  Nanjing is a large city of some 3.4 million people with multiple access routes.  The city is the capital city of Jiangsu Province and is located about 190 miles due west of Shanghai.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The companys environmental performance at its existing operation has been adequate for the last three annual reporting cycles.  The environmental and social issues which may be associated with this project are emissions to air, waste water treatment, energy efficiency, raw material storage including dust control; handling of solid wastes and hazardous materials; fire safety and emergency response and labor and workplace conditions.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityA translation of the ERS will be available at the plant entrance where the workers access the facility.Address: 418 Heyan Road, Nanjing, Jiangsu, China.

Project Description: Banca Comerciala Romana, S.A. (BCR or the bank) was incorporated in 1990 and licensed by the National Bank of Romania to conduct all commercial banking activities.  BCR is the largest bank in Romania, with a market share of more than one third of total banking assets in the country as of year-end 2002.  According to International Accounting Standards (IAS), BCR's  total assets as of December 31, 2002 were approximately $4.7 billion equivalent, total equity was approximately $846 million equivalent, and net profits were approximately $106 million equivalent.  The project consists of a pre-privatization equity investment of up to $111 million for a 12.5% shareholding in the bank.  The pre-privatization equity investment fits within a wider framework to support the Government of Romania (GoR or the Government) to promote banking sector reform.
Role:
Development Impact:

The restructuring and privatization of banks continues to be a costly, though essential, exercise through Eastern and Central Europe.  Efficient intermediation of savings into productive investments is vital to the future growth of the region.  Given the relatively limited alternative vehicles for intermediation, the banking sector has a disproportionately significant role to play.  By supporting the privatization of the largest bank in Romania, IFC's developmental impact is expected to be particularly high.  Enhancing the credibility of the bank privatization process is particularly important in Romania as it is a key pillar in the Government's overall privatization program.

IFC Role-  Lending credibility of the privatization process:

IFC has successfully supported high profile bank privatizations in several of Europe's transition economies.  The project is expected to replicate this success and lend credibility to the BCR transaction within the context of the GoR's privatization program for the financial sector.  The delays in BCR's privatization resulting from the global economic slowdown make this a challenging privatization, one where the signaling effect of multilateral support is particularly significant.  The project is expected to catalyze increased investor interest and improve terms and conditions for BCR's privatization.
 
Strengthening BCR's institutional capacity and enhancing its operational profile:

IFC's involvement with BCR prior to the sale to a privatization investor will enable IFC to play a role in strengthening the Bank's operations by requiring the implementation of an Institution Building Plan (IBP) jointly developed by EBRD and IFC.  The objective of the IBP is to strengthen BCR's corporate governance and operations (including upgrades to its systems and risk management), thereby preparing it for full privatization by the end of 2006.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Financial Intermediary (FI) Type 1 project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure. BCR will be required to establish environmental policies and procedures and require their corporate and SME borrowers to comply with local and national environmental and occupational health & safety requirements.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: BCR is controlled (i.e. 69.88% shareholding) by the Government via the Authority for Privatization and Management of State Ownership (APAPS); the remaining 30.12% is controlled by five financial investment companies (SIFs).  The SIF's (i.e., SIF Oltenia, SIF Banat Crisana, SIF Moldova, SIF Transilvania, SIF Muntenia) were created as tools for assisting the mass privatization process following the breakdown of the communist regime in the early 1990s.
Cost Nature: The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) and IFC will together purchase 25% plus two shares of BCR for a total amount of $222 million.  IFC is planning to purchase 12.5% plus one share of the share capital and voting rights of BCR for $111 million.
Investment: 150.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan75.0Equity75.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: BCR is headquartered in Bucharest and has over 280 branches throughout Romania.  The bank also has subsidiaries in the United Kingdom, Germany, France, Moldova, and representative offices in Moscow and New York.  Also, BCR has equity investments in banks in Italy and Egypt.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Financial Intermediary (FI) Type 1 project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure. Project Description: PT Ecogreen Oleochemicals  (Ecogreen, the company), an Indonesia based company, is implementing a $84 million project involving establishing a new 60,000 tonnes per annum (tpa) capacity fatty acid production plant, incremental working capital and debt refinancing.  The company is one of the leading global producers of natural fatty alcohols, its core product group, as well as co-products and intermediates such as fatty acids, methyl esters and glycerin.   The company produces natural or vegetable oil based fatty alcohol, largely used for the production of detergents, shampoos, conditioners, skin applications and similar consumer products.  They are also used as stabilizers in the production of plastics and lubricants.  The company has 110,000 tpa natural fatty alcohol production capacity at two production plants located in Belawan, Medan (30,000 tpa) and Batam (80,000 tpa) in Indonesia.  Ecogreens FY02 turnover was $86 million, of which about 95% was from exports to Asia-Pacific, North and South America and Europe.  In addition to its production plants, the company has affiliated marketing and distribution companies which have long term lease finished goods storage facilities in Rotterdam, Germany; Houston,Texas; and Newark, New Jersey.The project is part of the companys long-term strategy to improve its international competitiveness through better utilization of assets and strategic management of raw material inventory.  About half of the new fatty acid capacity will be used to support an 8,000 tpa fatty alcohol capacity increase at Belawan, Medan plant through debottlenecking and to supply to an affiliate soap noodle production company.  The surplus will be sold in the merchant market.   The working capital and the debt refinancing are aimed at helping the company structure a flexible working capital facility with a core component to fund the permanent working capital and a stand-by facility to finance raw material purchases at low price points.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The review of this project consisted of appraising technical and environmental/social information submitted by the project sponsor.  The following potential environment, health and safety and social impacts were analyzed.Environmental issues include: development of corporate environmental and health and safety management programs; raw material sourcing; air quality impacts (including odor) and abatement; waste water quality, temperature and treatment if necessary; energy efficiency in general; on-site solid waste management procedures; handling and storage of fuel, oils and hazardous materials; and workplace noise. Health and safety issues include: fire safety and emergency response; pressure vessel integrity; safety training, and housekeeping. Social issues in Ecogreens plants include community relations and community development activities.Further details are provided in the Environmental Review Summary separately available with this document.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe environmental documentation will be made available at the following locations:           PT.Ecogreen Oleochemicals         Jalan Raya Pelabuhan IV, Gabion-Bagan Deli,          Belawan 20414, Indonesia         Phone. (62-778) 711002,         Fax.  (62-778) 711007
Sponsor: The company is owned through a holding company structure whose shareholders are:  -  Messrs. Eddy William Katuari and Fifi Sutanto (representing the Wings group) 47.7%; -  Mr. Jimmy Masrin and PT Lautan Luas Tbk (representing the Lautan Luas group) 33.3% and -  Mr. Robert Budi Hartono (representing the Djarum group) 19%.  The main sponsor of the company is the Wings group, which is one of Indonesias largest producer and marketer of soaps and detergents.  The Wings Group has seven main business activities  -  consumer products; -  packaging; -  chemicals; -  building materials; -  real estate; -  agribusiness and -  financial services.  Of these, the consumer products business is the largest in annual turnover.  IFC has existing relationships with three of the Wings group companies (PT Sayap, PT Wings and PT Gawi).  The other two members of the consortium are the Djarum group, one of the largest Indonesian cigarette manufacturers, and the Lautan Luas group which is Indonesias leading distributor and manufacturer of basic and specialty chemicals.

Project Name: Emerging Markets Small Cap Fund LLC
Company Name: Emerging Markets Global Small Capitalization Fund
Project Description: Emerging Markets Small Cap Fund LLC (the Fund or the company) has been newly formed to seek long-term capital appreciation through investing primarily in emerging markets listed companies with market capitalization of less than $500 million.  The Fund will have a global focus.
Role:
Through its participation in the Fund, IFC will seek to achieve development impact in several ways.  The Fund will respond to an inefficiency that is common to stock markets in developing as well as developed economies:  as a general rule, investors and market researchers tend to pay less attention to smaller companies.  This is particularly the case for companies that are listed but do not form part of the most commonly used market indexes and, therefore, do not automatically get picked up by investors who want their portfolios to track the market.  As a result, market analysts pay less attention to these stocks, which reduces their visibility to investors and consequently limits trading volumes and liquidity.   By demonstrating the value of analyzing and investing in these companies, the Fund will contribute to increasing liquidity in this asset sub-class, which is expected to expand the range of stocks available to investors, attract a broader range of local and foreign investors and encourage greater coverage by market analysts.

IFC will play a catalyst role in attracting other investors to the Fund.  By giving a green light to the project, IFC will serve as an anchor investor, attracting private sector investors that otherwise might not invest in the Fund.   In line with the lessons learned from prior funds, IFC's investment in the Fund will demonstrate our commitment to supporting existing managers with a good track record.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category C project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure. There are minimal environmental or social impacts associated with this project. Therefore, no further environmental or social analysis is required.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: The Fund will be managed by Emerging Markets Management (EMM), which has its offices in Arlington, Virginia. As of June 30, 2003, EMM managed $5.5 billion in separate accounts and commingled funds, primarily for listed equities in emerging markets. The team will be managed by Felicia Morrow.
Cost Nature: The target size of the Fund will be $200 million, although the Fund is likely to be smaller at the initial launch.  The Fund will be a quasi-open-ended fund, with the possibility of monthly subscriptions and redemptions.  The proposed IFC investment is $10 million, but no more than 15% of the Fund.
Investment: 10.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity10.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The Fund will be listed in Ireland.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category C project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure. There are minimal environmental or social impacts associated with this project. Therefore, no further environmental or social analysis is required.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Name: GEF Lolkisale Biodiversity Conservation Support Project
Project Description: As previously disclosed (in Project ID 9579), the project was to establish an exclusive 16-bed lodge on the boundary of the Tarangire national Park in Northern Tanzania. This lodge would form part of a 35,000 acre private wildlife consrvation area that would be established as part of the project (the Lolkisale Conservation Area).  This project has very strong developmental impact because of the following reasons: The local community is involved as a major shareholder, a significant area will be conserved in terms of diversity of flora and fauna, additional income will be generated for the Lolkisale village from royalties which will be directed to community development programs and employment benefits will be generated.The additional component incorporated in this SPI has the purpose of developing and implementing a comprehensive Integrated Conservation Management Plan (ICMP). The ICMP will aim, inter alia, to clarify land tenure policy, strengthen stakeholder relations, mitigate tourism impacts and develop solutions to current overgrazing problems.  The implementation of the ICMP will include hiring and training field staff, community counterparts, establish ranger posts and established community-based conservation processes and programs. In this way the MSP will catalyze global environmental benefit from a project that already aims to generate significant development benefits.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category A project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because it may result in significant adverse environmental and/or social impacts that are sensitive, diverse or unprecedented.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe ERS was disclosed locally at the following locations in Arusha: the Municipal Office, the Community Research Development Services (CORDS); the Tanzania National Parks Authority (TANAPA); and the Partneship Option for Resource Use Innovations (PORI).
Sponsor: The project sponsor is Boundary Hill Lodge Ltd (BHL), a joint venture between the Lolkisale Village Council (LVC) (50%) and the Tarangire Conservation Company Ltd (TCCL) (50%). The LVC is the representative of the Lolkisale village community with a population of about 4000 people of the Maasai tribe.  The community has contributed 100 acres to BHL and has leased a further 35,000 acres for development into a private game reserve. TCCL is wholly owned by East African Safari and Touring Company Ltd (EASTCO), a family-run business in Arusha that runs mobile camping safaris and hires safari vehicles to local travel agencies. The major shareholder is Mr Simon King.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is approximately $1,250,000. The project cost of the lodge operation, which SPI (Project ID 9579) was previously posted on 12/26/2002, comprised $800,000, which included a loan of $200,000 from IFC, as well as a loan of $200,000 from IFC/GEF/SME and a Technical Assistance grant of $ 35,000 from IFC/GEF/SME. These have already been disbursed. This SPI serves as an amendment to that previous SPI, to advise of the current additional component to the project, being the GEF MSP component, comprising $450,000.
Location: The project site is on the eastern boundary of the Tarangire National Park on Boundary Hill, a small basalt outcrop overlooking the park. The core site covers 100 acres and was contributed by the LVC as their equity. The project will however operate in a broader area of 140 square kilometres which has been set aside as the Lolkisale Conservation Area and which borders upon the Tarangire national Park.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category A project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because it may result in significant adverse environmental and/or social impacts that are sensitive, diverse or unprecedented.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe ERS was disclosed locally at the following locations in Arusha: the Municipal Office, the Community Research Development Services (CORDS); the Tanzania National Parks Authority (TANAPA); and the Partneship Option for Resource Use Innovations (PORI).

Project Description: Russian Standard Bank (RSB, Bank or the company) is a medium-sized private Russian bank specialized in consumer finance.  RSB offers its financial products to consumers through partner retail shops, while minor business areas include SME lending and trade finance. RSB started its operations in Moscow and is expanding rapidly to the regions.  As of June 30, 2003 RSB had the net worth of $61 million and total assets of $247 million equivalent and is in the process of increasing its capital by additional $20 million.  Proceeds of the IFC financing would be used to expand RSB's consumer lending and to help prepare the Bank for securitization of some of its consumer loans in 2004.
Role:
Consumer finance is one of the most promising sectors in the Russian banking. However, access to funding remains a serious constraint to consumer lending expansion and RSB continues to have limited access to financing sources.  By providing much-needed funding to RSB, IFC would both promote consumer lending development in Russia and support an existing client.  IFC support would be in large part used for expansion of RSB's activities in the regions, where demand for retail banking services is even greater than in Moscow.

As the Russian economy continues to stabilize, more successful banks and companies increasingly rely on ruble-denominated assets.  Borrowing in dollars exposes these companies to a currency risk.  Therefore, many current and potential IFC clients, including RSB, have expressed interest in ruble financing.  In response to this request, the proposed loan package may include a ruble-denominated component.

Specifically, IFC's financing will: 
-  Provide funds for expansion of consumer lending in Moscow and regions of Russia through a convenient,               flexible structure.
-  Aim to create an innovative ruble-linked financing mechanism for the first time in the Russian market with a technically sophisticated partner.
-  Help RSB expand a pool of loan assets which may be subject to a securitization transaction in 2004.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a FI Type 1 project according to IFCs environmental review procedure.  RSB is required to operate an environmental management system to require and verify that its SME and corporate clients are in compliance with Russian environmental standards and, in connection with the existing IFC financing, it is providing IFC with an annual environmental report.  RSB representatives have already participated in the IFC-organized environmental training.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: RSB was established in 1999 as a new commercial and retail bank with a license to conduct full-scale banking operations. Since its creation, RSB has rapidly increased its retail loan portfolio and has become a market leader.  The Bank is a closed joint-stock company and a part of the Roust group of companies owned and controlled by Roustam Tariko, a successful local entrepreneur. IFC became a shareholder of RSB in February 2003 and holds 10.4% of the Bank's shares.
Cost Nature: The proposed project consists of a three-year revolving $30 million facility and a short-term senior loan of up to $30 million for IFC's account.  In addition, IFC will consider a possibility of arranging a syndicated B Loan for the account of participants.
Investment: 60.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan60.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative

Project Description:
African Bank is a wholly owned subsidiary of African Bank Investment Limited (ABIL, the bank , or the company), an investment holding company listed on the JSE Securities Exchange South Africa. With total assets in excess of ZAR6 billion, African Bank is the largest unsecured credit provider to the previously considered non-bankable  sector in South Africa. The Bank employs more than 860 people and operates through 221 branches and outlets that are grouped in four geographic regions in South Africa.

The project will consist in purchasing two African Bank Limited (African Bank) debt instruments for up to ZAR29 million (~$4 million) maturing on December 2005 and September 2006. This option was given to IFC in the course of another transaction to compensate for the principal impairment suffered by IFC.

Staff also participate  through a share option scheme, which holds options equivalent to  7.4% of issued shares.

Project Description:
Grupo Calidra S.A. de C.V. (Calidra, or the company) is Mexico's leading producer of lime and lime-related products, with 2002 revenue of approximately $80 million equivalent.  The company operates 17 plants across Mexico and one in Honduras.  Its operations comprise the quarrying of limestone, its processing into various grades of quick- or hydrated lime, packaging, and sale to the construction, steel, chemical, mining, agricultural, waste treatment and other industries.


The main components of the project include: 
-   the installation of three new kilns, 
       -   the consolidation and upgrading of lime hydration capacity, 
-   conversion of existing kilns to dual-fuel capability, and 
-   the decommissioning of inefficient kilns and hydrators.  

The project aims to rebalance Calidra's production capacity in favor of regions with limited installed capacity for quality lime, targets faster growing market segments, diversifies its customer base to reduce reliance on the construction sector, and lowers operational risks to Calidra by reducing its dependence on a single fuel type.
Role:
Development Impact:
Calidra is producing a basic industrial input that is important for the construction, steel-making, agricultural and other sectors of the economy, and the project is oriented toward fostering the development of key consuming industries, including glass making, water purification and treatment. The project is aimed at improving Calidra's operational efficiency, better meeting localized demand, promoting new applications for lime-related products and reducing the Company's environmental footprint.  In particular, the project component to install efficient and environmentally friendly capacity in regions which are experiencing higher demand than supply is expected to at least partly substitute production from inefficient plants associated with high emissions and relatively low-quality product.

IFC s Role in the project involves: 
-  support for a second-tier company, 
-  IFC's value-added with respect to governance, increasing management professionalism and reporting in the company's development from a family-owned company, 
-  provision of appropriate tenor and currency debt for a long-term investment program, and 
- substantive, planning (in addition to financial) support of the company's on-going efforts to reduce its environmental footprint.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a Category B project according to IFCs environmental review procedure because a limited number of specific impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized environmental performance standards, guidelines, or design criteria.  Environmental issues associated with the project include: land acquisition, air emissions, water supply, quarry reclamation, local employment and socioeconomic impacts, fuel storage and handling, employee exposure to noise and dust and environmental and health and safety management systems.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThese documents are available at the Head Office of Grupo Calidra in México D.F. (see below) and information is posted at the following locations:

Tablero de Anuncios de la Presidencia Municipal de Torreón, Coahuila

The company's other shareholders are Graymont Ltd. of Canada (40%) and IFC (8%).  IFC's shareholding dates to 1998, when IFC made an equity investment in the Company as part of the financing of the first project it undertook with Calidra.

The proposed IFC investment would consist of a loan of about $20 million equivalent for IFC's own account.  Up to an additional $10 million equivalent may also be raised in parallel from another bank.  The balance of funds will come from internal cash generation and a share capital increase, which was recently completed.

The kiln to be installed near Colima will be on a quarry which is off of an isolated section of an existing highway.

Project Description: The project involves a $3 million credit line to Romanian-American Enterprise Fund (RAEF) for on-lending to three non-governmental organization-led micro loan programs. These sub-borrowers are Credit, Assistance and Business training (CAPA), Cooperative Housing Foundation (CHF) and Opportunity Microcredit Romania, S.A. (OMRO).  RAEF works with these three partners because each serves a different part of Romania, thereby allowing the benefits of micro credit to be spread to the widest number of micro-enterprise  recipients.
Role: According to Romanian government statistics, over 90% of Romanian companies employ fewer than 10 people.  Many of these enterprises are not considered bankable because their businesses are too small and/or they cannot provide suitable collateral for the banks.  While there are some other micro finance groups entering the Romanian market they are small and have limited financial resources.  By funding this proposal, IFC will enable RAEF and its partners to sustain and expand its operations in outlining areas and a wide spread of second tier cities in which the program currently operates.  The benefits to the Romanian economy will be measured in terms of a steady and reliable source of funds that foster business growth and job creation.
Environmental Social Issues: RAEF will be required to establish and maintain an environmental management system to ensure that relevant lending activities of its partners are consistent with IFCs Microfinance Exclusion List and in compliance with applicable Romanian laws.  Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Description: DeltaLease-Far East (DLFE) is a leasing company based in Vladivostok with offices in Yuzhno-Sakhalinsk (Sakhalin Island), Khabarovsk, and Novosibirsk.  The company has been in operation since 2000 and is entirely owned by the U.S. Russia Investment Fund (TUSRIF).  DLFE is involved exclusively in leasing operations with a specific focus on providing financing leases to Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs).  Since its inception and through August 2003 the company has approved over $9.4 million in financial leases on its own account, or a total of $12.0 million in the total value of leased goods.  As of June 2003, DLFE had assets of $6.3 million.The purpose of the project is to provide additional funding to DLFE to enable the company to match the strong demand for leasing products in the SME sector.  The proposed project would be one of IFCs first financial markets investments with a company working specifically in Siberia and the Far East, a considerably more difficult and less advanced market than the European part of Russia.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Financial Intermediary (FI) Type 1 project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  DLFE must establish an environmental management system designed to ensure that all leased assets comply with Russian environmental, health and safety standards.  DLFE must participate in IFC-approved environmental training and provide IFC with annual environmental reports.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: DLFE''s sole shareholder is TUSRIF, a private investment fund established in 1995.  TUSRIF has to date been funded by the US Congress via grants administered by U.S. Agency for International Development, with a total commitment of $440 million.  To date, TUSRIF''s investment activities have focused on two main areas: -  direct equity investments in such industries as telecommunications, consumer goods, and retail networks, and -  financial services, focusing on SME lending, mortgage finance, and leasing.  The Fund has a special mandate to invest $40 million of its resources in the Russian Far East.
Cost Nature: The proposed project consists of a $3.0 million senior loan for IFCs own account.  The proceeds of IFCs loan will be used to expand the volume of DLFEs leasing operations.

Project Description:
The project consists of funding the expansion strategy of TV3 Russia (TV3 or the company), a free-to-air television broadcasting group based in Russia.  The company, which focuses on broadcasting entertainment-related content, is 100% owned by Independent Network Television Holding Limited (INTH), a sole purpose holding company incorporated in Cyprus.  Currently, TV3 broadcasts to a potential audience of over 50 million viewers (30% of the Russian population) through 62 local stations, 8 of which are approximately 100% owned and operated subsidiaries of the company.  Through its expansion, TV3 plans to: 
- increase distribution; 
- improve programming; and 
- enhance its promotional activities.

Sponsor: The company's shareholders are comprised primarily of Western strategic and financial investors, as well as individuals active in the media sector.  Primary shareholders are: Act III Communications (32%), Botts Capital Nominees (19%), and the US-Russia Investment Fund (9 %).
Cost Nature: Total project cost is estimated to be approximately $20.0 million.  The proposed IFC investment is a $7.50 million C Loan  for IFC's own account with warrants.

Project Description: The project, entails establishing a greenfield microfinance institution (MFI), Accion Nigeria, that will specialize in providing financial services to micro and small enterprises, and low-income individuals in Nigeria. In its business operations, Accion Nigeria or the company will focus on credit extension and provision of financial services to private micro and small enterprises, salaried workers, private individuals and the general public.  The purpose of the project is to expand crucial financial services to a sector that rarely has access to services offered by formal financial institutions.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Financial Intermediary (F1) Type 1 category project according to IFCs environmental review procedures. The project sponsor, AIM, will be required to develop an environmental management system that will require that Accion Nigerias lending operations meet Nigerias environmental, health and safety requirements, and be consistent with IFCs Microfinance Exclusion List. IFC will work with AIM to develop an environmental review capacity. Depending upon IFCs assessment, environmental training may be required. AIM will provide IFC with an annual environmental performance report on all its invest companies.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor:
Accion Nigeria's key sponsor is ACCION International. ACCION is a U.S. based private nonprofit organization founded in 1961, has been engaged in microfinance over the past 30 years. ACCION has been a leader in the commercialization of the microfinance industry, dedicated to the integration of microfinance into the formal financial sector. ACCION International is also the sponsor of ACCION Investments in Microfinance (AIM) an investment company with a capitalization of $18 million focusing on Latin America, the Caribbean, and Africa. AIM provides equity and quasi-equity capital to institutions specializing in microfinance and IFC has a $3million equity investment in AIM for a 16.62% shareholding.

Accion Nigeria's proposed shareholders are: AIM (22.5%), IFC (12.6%),  Nigerian commercial banks (64.9%).
Cost Nature: The project cost is $5 million consisting of initial shareholder capital in Accion Nigeria.  IFC's will invest $630,000 in equity for a 12.6% ownership in the MFI. Initial shareholder capital is $5 million.
Investment: 1.89 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity1.89* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The project, a greenfield microfinance institution (MFI), will be located in Lagos, Nigeria. Over time, the MFI will open branches in other major urban centers in the South East and in the North and expand nationally as conditions permit.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Financial Intermediary (F1) Type 1 category project according to IFCs environmental review procedures. Role:
The project is expected to have significant developmental impacts, such as:
-  serving the financing needs of micro and small business clients. It will improve the competitiveness of these businesses and contribute to private-sector led growth in Tajikistan;
-  facilitating greater access to financing for micro and small businesses, which are the main source of employment and income-generation in Tajikistan's economy, the project will have an expected positive impact on employment generation; and
-  creating a viable and sustainable microfinance oriented bank, it is expected to disseminate best practice standards early on in the development of microfinance in Tajikistan with respect to corporate governance, sustainability and outreach.

The IFC Role would be: 
-  Through this small, yet significant investment, IFC will participate in a pioneering effort to  help develop the first private sector commercially oriented microfinance bank in Tajikistan. 
-  The project aims to establish a successful model bank that can be replicated in the country over time; the expected increase in the supply of credit will positively impact currently underserved micro and small businesses. 
-  Working alongside AKFED, IFC will emphasize  FMBT's commercial orientation, use of international best practice, full financial accountability, sound corporate governance, high quality MIS, and strong policies and procedures. IFC's assistance has been given to AKDN to help in the identification and implementation of best practice MIS in its microfinance banks, with a first such programme currently under implementation at the proposed First MicroFinanceBank of Afghanistan.

 IFC will further help AKFED by:
-  helping to secure additional policy and regulatory reforms, which are felt necessary to ensure the development of a vibrant and sound financial system in Tajikistan; 
-  providing equity financing to FMBT;
-  assisting in identifying additional bilateral and institutional shareholders; and 
- helping AKFED to raise donor funding for capacity building, and mobilize additional resources to fund its lending operations, which will be critical during the early years of operation.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Financial Intermediary (FI) Type 1 microfinance project according to IFC''s environmental review procedure. FMFBT will be required to ensure that its operations are consistent with host country requirements and IFC''s Microfinance Exclusion List. In this respect, IFC will require that a senior staff of the Bank be appointed  to oversee the implementation by the Bank of environmental guidelines satisfactory to IFC. In addition, the Bank will be required to submit an annual environmental performance report.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: The main project sponsor is the Aga Khan Fund for Economic Development (AKFED), an international development agency which  promotes economic development in specific regions of the developing world. AKFED helps build economically viable enterprises through long-term equity participation combined with professional management, technical expertise, and support. Its sustainable investments in industry, tourism, and financial services projects play an important catalytic role in mobilizing foreign institutional investors, especially in Asia. AKFED will bring to FMBT its broad expertise in commercial as well as development banking operations. AKFED is currently the lead shareholder in five banks in emerging markets, while AKDN has approximately 40 microfinance banks and programs combined in countries of Central and South Asia, the Middle East, and Africa. AKFED's microfinance projects in Pakistan and Afghanistan, in particular, will provide valuable lessons for FMBT. IFC has worked with AKFED in over 20 projects in Africa as well as Central and South Asia and values it as a strong and committed partner. Most recently, IFC invested alongside AKFED in the First MicroFinanceBank of Pakistan and the Pamir I Power Energy project in Tajikistan. IFC and AKFED have also recently signed a MOU to establish the First Micro- Finance Bank of Afghanistan.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $3.5 million equivalent. IFC is expected to invest up to $0.7 million equivalent for an equity stake of 19%.
Investment: 0.67 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity0.67* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The Bank's headquarters and first branch will be located in Dushanbe, the economic and political capital of Tajikistan. The Bank will first deploy towards the Central and Eastern Region of Tajikistan, which offer a good economic potential, an active portfolio of loans and a strong AKDN presence. The branches will serve as regional hubs for a network of peri-urban and urban branches. Mobile banking services and linkages with village banks will be developed in remote areas.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Financial Intermediary (FI) Type 1 microfinance project according to IFC''s environmental review procedure. In this respect, IFC will require that a senior staff of the Bank be appointed  to oversee the implementation by the Bank of environmental guidelines satisfactory to IFC. In addition, the Bank will be required to submit an annual environmental performance report.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
