Project Description:
The $13.0 million expansion project involves the construction and opening in Kiev of 2 new 10,000sq.m DIY (Do-It-Yourself) stores, in addition to the existing 5,000sq.m store, under the name Nova Liniya (NL or the company).  The new stores, will follow the best practice of modern DIY format, comparable to those of Home Depot, Lowe's, and OBI.  They will offer a wide range of DIY products, more than 30,000, as well as specialized services.  

The project, to be implemented in 2 stages over a 20 month period, will address the growing demand in the construction materials, home care products, and consumer electronics.  The DIY concept has become well established in Ukraine.  Following a slump in the aftermath of the financial crisis in Russia and the subsequent depreciation of the Ukrainian currency, Ukraine's retail sector, and one of its fastest growing segments, DIY retailing, has posted impressive growth, exceeding 16% in 2002.  It is expected that this growth will continue in the forthcoming years and NL, as a first mover, will take full advantage of its established position.
Role:
Development Impact

The project is expected to have a significant developmental impact, as follows:

-   Providing consumers with a wide range of good quality home improvement products at an affordable price.  
-  Upgrading business practices:  The project will have a catalytic effect in developing and improving the quality of  local suppliers and producers.  Since part of the product range is expected to be sourced locally, the company will
have to work closely with local suppliers and producers to improve their quality in order to meet NL's quality standards.  
-  Promoting SME and private sector development:  The project would have a positive effect on the development of the home repair/improvement and construction services industry, which was underdeveloped during the years of state planning.  
-  Demonstration effect:  The project would provide a significant demonstration effect, as its success would encourage other companies pursuing investment opportunities in Ukraine, as the country' s perceived risk begins to diminish. 
-  Increased employment: The project will create new employment, both directly and indirectly.  It will provide direct employment to about 300 employees, mostly women, with a significant multiple of that number expected to be added in the supply stream and in ancillary activities.  In addition, temporary employment will be provided to local labor during the construction phase of the project.




Fit With World Bank Group Strategy and IFC Role
IFC role in the proposed project could be valuable on several grounds: 
-  In view of the perceived macro-economic and political risks of investing in Ukraine, IFC's presence in this transaction will help increase investors' confidence in the country's business environment.  

-  IFC's proposed financing will enable the company to support its medium-term investments by supplying long-term funds on reasonable terms otherwise not available to the company. 

-  IFC will play an important role in determining the project scope, structuring the financial plan, evaluating the environmental issues, thus reducing the project's risk profile.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category B project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  Environmental, occupational health and safety issues associated with this project include: site selection and planning, site environmental and social (including land rights and use) conditions, air emissions, liquid and solid waste treatment and disposal, hazardous materials handling, sale of materials on the IFC exclusion list, power and water supply, life and fire safety, emergency response, general worker health and safety, and environmental management systems.  Opportunities for developing sustainability include promotion of recycling, certified wood products, environmentally friendly home improvement products, and proper handling by consumers of hazardous materials.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe environmental documents for the project will be located in Kiev, at the gates of the project site of the second store, located at the intersection of Lyskivska and Balzaka streets.
Sponsor:
NL was established in February 2000 as a private joint stock company by its present senior management.  In early 2002, an independent investment bank, Dragon Capital, acquired 35% of Nova Liniya's shares.  Currently NL's management owns 50% of NL, Dragon Capital owns 35%, and individual investors own 15%.  
Dragon Capital is the leading equity broker and a major M&A (Merger and Acquisitions) adviser in Ukraine.
Cost Nature:
The total project cost is estimated at about $13 million
IFC is considering an investment of  about $5 million, comprising an A Loan of about $3.5 million and a quasi-equity
investment of about $1.5 million.
Investment: 5.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan5.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: All stores will be located in Kiev, the capital of Ukraine. NL's existing store, with a total area of about 4.700 sq. m. is located in the densely populated and growing Kharkivsky district.  The second store, to be located in the Troyeschyna district, will have a total area of about 10,000 sq. m. The site is unoccupied and is close to residential areas and bus stops.  The third store is expected to be identical in size to the second store.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category B project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  Environmental, occupational health and safety issues associated with this project include: site selection and planning, site environmental and social (including land rights and use) conditions, air emissions, liquid and solid waste treatment and disposal, hazardous materials handling, sale of materials on the IFC exclusion list, power and water supply, life and fire safety, emergency response, general worker health and safety, and environmental management systems.  Opportunities for developing sustainability include promotion of recycling, certified wood products, environmentally friendly home improvement products, and proper handling by consumers of hazardous materials.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe environmental documents for the project will be located in Kiev, at the gates of the project site of the second store, located at the intersection of Lyskivska and Balzaka streets.
Sector: BA - Retail (Including Supermarkets, Grocery Stores, etc.)

Company Name: Euromedic Diagnostics B.V. & International Hemodialysis Centers B.V.
Project Description: The Euromedic group of companies, a leading provider of diagnostic imaging and hemodialysis services in Central, Eastern and Southern Europe and an existing IFC client is undertaking further expansion in the region. An estimated $23 million project is designed to expand the existing network of Euromedics diagnostic and hemodialysis centers in Poland, Hungary, Romania and Bosnia (which was partially financed by the first IFC loan) and to establish similar operations in other countries in the region. Most existing centers are certified to the ISO 9002 quality management system international standard, and new centers are in the process of becoming certified. Each center has (or will have) established policies and procedures related to patient and employee health and safety and waste management.Through the project, Euromedic is extending high quality private healthcare to large and diverse portions of local population thus improving both access to and equity of services. The diagnostic centers are expected to speed the delivery of high quality imaging that will enable faster and more accurate treatment of patients. Euromedic hemodialysis centers have the potential to save the lives of hundreds of patients who would die within weeks of developing end stage renal disease (ESRD) without access to treatment. In addition, by improving the quality of dialysis care, Euromedic will contribute to cost savings due to reduced annual hospitalization and shorter length of annual disability of ESRD patients.
Role: Project Development Impact: As the public healthcare sector is facing growing financial constraints, Euromedic is extending much needed services to large and diverse portions of the local population thus improving both access to and equity of care. Euromedic is well placed to be an important player in the process of improving health services in the region. Its primary target is local patients, irrespective of their income, covered by social insurance or Ministry of Health programs. The diagnostic centers are providing timely and reliable imaging that enables faster and more accurate treatment of patients. The hemodialysis centers are saving lives of hundreds of patients who would die within several weeks of developing End Stage Renal Disease (ESRD), the main clinical indication for chronic hemodialysis, without access to treatment. In addition, by replacing outdated equipment and improving quality of dialysis care, Euromedic is contributing to cost savings due to reduced annual hospitalization and shorter length of annual disability of ESRD patients while enhancing quality of patient lives. IFCs role: IFCs primary role will be to provide long-term financing, which is still difficult to obtain in the countries of Euromedics operations, given the regional nature of the project and the required long maturity of debt. Although some local banks (especially in Poland) have shown interest in the health sector, their financing is generally limited to shorter-term equipment financing or leasing (with maturities rarely exceeding 5 years).
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category B project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  Environmental and social issues associated with this project include:  site selection, acquisition, development and permitting; quality and sustainability of potable water supply; handling and disposal of hazardous and non-hazardous health care waste; liquid effluent management; air emissions; adequacy of disinfection and sterilization programs; occupational health and safety, employee training and implementation of good healthcare facility management practices to prevent nosocomial diseases; life and fire safety in the design, construction and outfitting of new and existing facilities; and systematic management of quality, environmental issues, and occupational health and safety.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe environmental documents will be made available at the following locations:-  Euromedic HQ in Budapest, Hungary; and-  Existing diagnostic and hemodialysis centers
Sponsor: The project sponsor is the Euromedic Group of Companies (Euromedic or the Group), a leading provider of diagnostic imaging services and distribution and tendering services to hospitals in Hungary. Euromedic is owned by:-  HPM Partners, a privately held Dutch investment company; -  GE Health Care Financial Services; -  Dresdner Kleinwort Benson Capital, a private equity arm of Dresdner Bank; and -  Global Environment Fund, an international investment firm.Euromedic Diagnostics B.V. and International Dialysis Centers B.V. (jointly the borrowers) are both 100% owned Dutch subsidiaries of Euromedic International N.V., a holding company of the group.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated to be Euro 20 million ($23 million equivalent). The proposed IFC investment is a Euro 10 million  ($11.4 million equivalent) loan for IFCs own account.
Investment: 12.13 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan12.13Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Euromedic''s headquarters in Budapest, Hungary, at Gerbeaud House, 1. Dorottya Street, 1051 Budapest, Hungary. Phone: (36-1) 267-5314. It currently has diagnostic imaging and dialysis centers in the following countries: existing diagnostic centers: Hungary  8 centers, Poland  7 centers and Romania  2 centers;existing hemodialysis centers: Poland  13 centers and Bosnia  2 centers. As part of the new Project, Euromedic proposes to invest in diagnostic imaging and hemodialysis centers in the following countries: Bosnia, Croatia, Hungary, Poland, Romania, Czech Republic and Slovakia.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category B project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  Environmental and social issues associated with this project include:  site selection, acquisition, development and permitting; quality and sustainability of potable water supply; handling and disposal of hazardous and non-hazardous health care waste; liquid effluent management; air emissions; adequacy of disinfection and sterilization programs; occupational health and safety, employee training and implementation of good healthcare facility management practices to prevent nosocomial diseases; life and fire safety in the design, construction and outfitting of new and existing facilities; and systematic management of quality, environmental issues, and occupational health and safety.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe environmental documents will be made available at the following locations:-  Euromedic HQ in Budapest, Hungary; and-  Existing diagnostic and hemodialysis centers

Company Name: Generale De Banque De Mauritanie Pour L'Investissement Et Le Commerce
Project Description: The project consists of a combined IFC term and subordinated loan of up to $10 million to Generale Banque de Mauritania (GBM, the bank or the company), a well know IFC client, for on-lending to medium and long term project finance transactions in Mauritania and the sub-region.  As of September 30th 2003, GBM, which was formed in 1995, had $113.5 million in assets, a loan book of $86.7 million and $30.8 million in shareholders equity, which makes it the largest bank in terms of net worth and loans in the country with a 25% market share.  The proposed project will be IFC's fourth investment with GBM.
Role:
The expected development impact of this project is high, because it achieves the following objectives in a frontier country:- Contribute to further development of a leading Mauritania bank through supporting its capital base, allowing for increased asset growth and investment in the Bank's infrastructure.   GBM plays a crucial role in terms of improving the public's confidence in the banking sector in general and providing a role model for other banking institutions in the market.- Allow a leading Mauritanian bank to increase the maturity of its liabilities and thereby better manage its asset and liability position. - Introduce a new financial instrument into the Mauritania banking sector. The investment would set a landmark in the Mauritanian  financial system by providing the first subordinated loan intended to count as Tier II capital for a bank, as allowed by the Central Bank of Mauritania.

-By supporting GBM's regional expansion strategy, IFC's role will complement a broader focus by  the World Bank and the IMF to increase the integration of the financial markets in the region.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an FI Type 2 project.  GBM will need to demonstrate that its existing environmental management system is adequate to address the environmental and social issues of the projects to be financed under this new financing.    GBM must require all subprojects to be carried out and operated in compliance with the applicable environmental, health and safety (EH&S) requirements of the country where the subproject is situated. In addition, subprojects whose total cost is less than $500,000 must be consistent with IFC''s Microfinance Exclusion List. Subprojects whose total cost is $500,000 or greater must be carried out in accordance with IFC''s safeguard policies, be consistent with IFC''s Exclusion List, and meet the host country requirements. GBM must obtain IFC clearance prior to making any loan or investment with IFC funds in any Category A subproject, and such a subproject must meet the applicable EH&S guidelines and safeguard policies of the World bank Group.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor:
GBM was established in 1995 as a unique partnership in the Mauritanian Banking Sector between a major European financial group (Belgolaise Fortis Group) and a number of Mauritanian businessmen from various origins, led by Mr. Mohamed Bouamatou, the bank's founder and main shareholder.  GBM's strategy since inception has been to offer to selected corporate customers a wide range of banking services, using state of the art technology and leveraging its relationship with its foreign partner.  

Mohamed Ould Bouamatou the largest shareholder of the bank, controls 31.04% of GBM's shareholdings.  Mr. Bouamatou is a well-respected local entrepreneur with a wide variety of business interests.  Apart from his activities in Mauritania, Mr. Bouamatou is a shareholder in African Financial Holdings, the holding company of the bank of Africa Group.  Belgolaise Bank (Belgolaise) is the second largest shareholder with a 30% stake in the bank.  Belgolaise is 100% owned by Fortis Group, one of the largest European banks.  Belgolaise has developed an extensive network of associated commercial banks in more than 10 countries in Sub-Saharan Africa. Groupe MAOA, the largest industrial group in Mauritania is the third largest investor in the bank with a 23% interest in GBM.  MAOA, which is majority owned by Mohamed Abdullah Ould Abdallah, primarily operates in the agriculture, trade and fishing industries.
Cost Nature:
The proposed IFC investment consists of a : 

-  $5 million term loan to GBM to be used for on-lending to sub-borrowers
-  $5 million subordinated loan -to be counted as Tier II capital
Investment: 10.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan10.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: GBM is headquartered in Nouakchott, Mauritania.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is an FI Type 2 project.  GBM will need to demonstrate that its existing environmental management system is adequate to address the environmental and social issues of the projects to be financed under this new financing.    GBM must require all subprojects to be carried out and operated in compliance with the applicable environmental, health and safety (EH&S) requirements of the country where the subproject is situated. In addition, subprojects whose total cost is less than $500,000 must be consistent with IFC''s Microfinance Exclusion List. Subprojects whose total cost is $500,000 or greater must be carried out in accordance with IFC''s safeguard policies, be consistent with IFC''s Exclusion List, and meet the host country requirements. GBM must obtain IFC clearance prior to making any loan or investment with IFC funds in any Category A subproject, and such a subproject must meet the applicable EH&S guidelines and safeguard policies of the World bank Group.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Description: The proposed project calls for IFC to provide medium term local currency financing to selected Non-Bank Finance Companies (NBFCs) in Pakistan through a partial IFC guarantee.  The NBFCs receiving these funds will use them to on-lend to the Small and Meduim Enterprise (SME) sector in the form of leases or medium term loans.  IFC's local currency guarantee is also expected to lengthen the debt maturities of the selected NBFCs and help reduce maturity mismatches by allowing these companies to partially retire existing short term debt.
Role:
Foreign investment in Pakistan has been negatively impacted by recent tension in the region.  Through the facility, IFC will play a catalytic role in supporting the SME sector and evolution of a few selected NBFCs.   IFC's participation will attract the participation of  major commercial banks to lend on a longer tenor to NBFCs.  It will also create a new source of medium term funding for selected NBFCs.

IFC's role in this project is:
- to encourage Pakistan NBFC's to expand lending to SME's and 
- extend the term funding available to NBFCs to 5-7 years as against the 2-3 year funds that are currently available to them.  Local banks remain risk averse for longer maturity lending, especially for leasing companies which are operating in a highly competitive environment.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an FI Type 1 project. The borrower will be required to develop an environmental management system. The borrowers must require that investments under relevant operations meet host country environmental, health and safety requirements. IFC will assess the borrower''s capacity for environmental review and will provide training as necessary.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Cost Nature: The proposed investment will be structured as a local currency credit line, partially guaranteed by IFC.  The credit line is expected to be between $30-50 million, with a tenor of 5-7 years, including up to a 2 year grace period.  Since no hedging mechanism is available and the revenues of the selected companies are denominated in Pakistani Rupees, a funded US dollar line is not desirable. Hence the proposed structure of an IFC guarantee facility is more appropriate for the clients.  Against IFC's guarantee, one or two commercial banks will extend Pakistan Rupee loans to the NBFCs.  IFC's guarantee fee shall be denominated and paid in either US dollars or local currency.   IFC has initiated discussions with local banks for local currency lending against IFC's guarantee.
Investment: 35.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuarantee35.0Loan0.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The project involves multiple NBFIs located in various cities in Pakistan, including Karachi, Lahore and Islamabad.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is an FI Type 1 project. The borrower will be required to develop an environmental management system. The borrowers must require that investments under relevant operations meet host country environmental, health and safety requirements. IFC will assess the borrower''s capacity for environmental review and will provide training as necessary.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Description:
The project entails an equity investment of the lower of 

-  10% of the total fund capitalization, or 

-  $50 million in the proposed Colony China Opportunity Fund ('the fund').  Included in this investment, IFC would seek a stake of 10% in the General Partner (GP) of the fund. 

The fund is a 7-year closed-end distressed asset investment fund, to be established as a Cayman Islands limited partnership.  An on-shore parallel fund, which will co-invest pari passu with the fund, will be set up as a Chinese limited liability company to facilitate participation by domestic investors, including co-sponsor Shanghai Industrial Investment Co. (SIIC).  The fund will invest in:

-  acquisition of NPL pools from financial institutions, 
-  direct purchase of distressed real estate assets, and, to a lesser extent, 
-  restructuring of distressed operating companies in PRC, Hong Kong, and Macau (Greater China).  

The joint sponsors, Colony Capital Asia Pacific Pte Ltd. (CCAP) and SIIC, will leverage CCAP's global and Asian distressed investment experience with SIIC's domestic business and government relationships to optimize the fund's ability to source, structure and execute distressed investments, aiming to achieve a gross IRR in excess of 25%.  The joint sponsors are seeking to raise total capital, for both the off-shore and on-shore vehicles, of $250-$500 million, and expect to conduct a first closing by the end of first quarter of 2004.  The fund will charge a 2% annual management fee, and will pay the GP a 20% carried interest based on committed capital after achieving a 10% p.a. hurdle rate.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category FI Type 2 project according to IFCs environmental review procedure.  The fund has committed to establishing an environmental management system that will ensure that investments are consistent with applicable host country environmental laws and regulations as well as applicable World Bank Group environmental, health and safety guidelines and policies;  designating appropriate individuals who will have responsibility for the environment and who will attend IFCs environmental management workshops;  submitting to IFC an environmental management plan;  obtaining clearance by IFC for any category A or infrastructure investment by the fund; and submitting to IFC an annual environmental performance report.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor:
CCAP, with a potential shareholding of 45-50% in the GP, is a wholly owned subsidiary of Colony Capital ('Colony').  Colony is led by its founder and CEO, Thomas J. Barrack, Jr. (56), and ten other principals, who on average have worked at Colony for eight years with an average of 22 years of relevant business and investing experience.  Colony is one of a few unaffiliated, privately-held distressed asset fund organizations having the capability to source, execute and realize investment opportunities in the global markets.  

SIIC, a potential shareholder with 45-50% stake in the GP, is incorporated in Hong Kong with executive headquarters in Shanghai.  SIIC has been the 'window' company of the Shanghai Municipal Government since 1981, with the core mandate of attracting global capital to Shanghai.  Its flagship operating entity, Shanghai Industrial Holdings Ltd., is a Hong Kong-listed Hang Seng Index company, 40% owned by the public.  SIIC's total assets of over $4.1 billion (as of December 31, 2002) are invested in real estate, financial services, health care, consumer retailing, infrastructure and logistics, information technology, and the Chongming Development Area.  With a dozen offices across China and nine international offices, SIIC has sought to combine local knowledge with global expertise in various sectors through alliances with international players, including Temasek, Salomon Smith Barney and Goldman Sachs.

CCAP and SIIC are also committed to ensuring an optimal alignment of all investor's interests by investing an aggregate of up to 10% of the fund's total capitalization.  If IFC participates in the GP, 10% of IFC's total commitment would count toward this GP obligation.

CCAP has been in discussion with various Asian and U.S. institutional investors about participating in the fund.  Initial feedback indicates that IFC's involvement in the fund is viewed by those institutions as essential to validate the fund concept and mitigate certain risks.
Cost Nature:
The project entails an equity investment of the lower of :

-  10% of the total fund capitalization, or
-  $50 million in the proposed $500 million fund.
Investment: 50.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity50.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location:
The Fund would be registered as a Cayman Islands limited partnership.  SI Colony China (Colony China), a Cayman Islands entity, will be the GP of the fund.  The GP is currently proposed to be owned 50:50 by CCAP and SIIC.  If IFC takes a stake of 10% in the GP, the shares of CCAP and SIIC would each be reduced to 45%.  CCAP controls the daily management of the GP.  Mr. Tom Barrack will serve as the interim CEO for the Fund until the local operating team is fully in place.

Deals would be sourced through both direct negotiations with domestic banks and asset owners, and auctions by asset management companies (AMCs).  Based on the current pipeline, the GP estimates a portfolio mix of 40% NPL transactions, 40% distressed real estate asset workouts, and 20% corporate restructuring transactions.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category FI Type 2 project according to IFCs environmental review procedure.  The fund has committed to establishing an environmental management system that will ensure that investments are consistent with applicable host country environmental laws and regulations as well as applicable World Bank Group environmental, health and safety guidelines and policies;  designating appropriate individuals who will have responsibility for the environment and who will attend IFCs environmental management workshops;  submitting to IFC an environmental management plan;  obtaining clearance by IFC for any category A or infrastructure investment by the fund; and submitting to IFC an annual environmental performance report.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Description:
The Sokhna Port Development Company (SPDC or the company) operates the Port of North El Sokhna (Sokhna or the Port) under a 25-year concession agreement awarded in mid-1999.  The Port began commercial operations in October, 2002, and is the first fully private port operating in Egypt.  It provides a deep water facility able to handle post-panamax vessels serving the Cairo area as well as the Suez Special Economic Zone (SSEZ), a 9,000 ha industrial development zone being developed adjacent to the Port.  The Port benefits from a strategic location close to the southern entrance of the Suez Canal where it can become a gateway for cargo between Egypt and Asia as well as East Africa.  

The proposed project is to help finance the company's 2001  2004 equipment and civil works investments.  The project will help complete the first two phases of the company's operating plan for the container, bulk, general cargo, and fertilizer terminals at the Port and increase the container terminal's capacity to 250,000 TEUs per year.
Role:
The project's development impact will be substantial as Sohkna develops into the gateway of choice for Egyptian trade to and from Asia and the Middle East.  Asian and Middle Eastern cargo volumes are expected increase in the future, but a lack of adequate port facilities could restrict growth.  The proposed IFC investment will strengthen the Egyptian port sector by providing a well managed and efficient container and general cargo facility.  This, in turn, will give shipping lines and shippers a significant incentive to call on Sokhna to avoid additional costs and delays of navigating through the Suez Canal to call on Mediterranean ports.  Sokhna's improved customs procedures, EDI systems and increased productivity will also incentivize other Egyptian and regional ports to improve their procedures and efficiency.  This should lower the delivered cost of both imported and exported goods and stimulate new export activities, thereby benefiting shippers, shipping lines and consumers alike.  New export activities would also improve Egypt's balance of trade and bring foreign currency to Egypt. 

The project will provide revenues to the Government of Egypt (GOE) in the form of fees paid to the Red Sea Port Authority and additional employment and upgrading of skills for local employees.  Furthermore, the development of Sokhna will encourage further development of the SSEZ as well as warehousing, light/medium manufacturing and regional distribution, thus enhancing economic activity in the region and providing greater employment opportunity for the local population.  As the first privately owned and operated port facility in Egypt, Sokhna will also improve the transfer of know-how from international port experts to the local management and staff.

IFC's funding would support GOE's efforts in attracting private capital to public infrastructure.  IFC's funding would also bring foreign currency lending at a tenor which is essential for this project but not available from local or other foreign sources.  This would provide a strong demonstration effect for future similar projects as a market based limited recourse financing for an Egypt based infrastructure project with local sponsors. The sponsors have asked for IFC's participation to benefit from IFC's accumulated experience in structuring successful financing arrangements and in advising with terminal operations.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a Category B project.  The review of this project consisted of an Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) for the project completed by the Dutch consultants Solid Waste Consultancy B.V., discussions with staff who visited the project site, and a telephone conversation and information exchange with the Sokhnas Security, Safety and Environmental Manager.  The following potential environmental, health, and safety impacts of the project were analyzed: -  environmental, health and safety management -  site selection; -  maintenance dredging; -  stormwater management; -  handling and storage of dangerous cargos and hazardous materials; -  waste management; -  emissions to air; and -  emergency response planning and preparedness. SPDC has presented plans to ensure that its facilities will operate in a manner that complies with applicable laws and regulations and IFCs current guidelines and policies.  A more complete description of environmental mitigation measures is provided in the Environmental Review Summary.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe environmental documentation will be available at the gate of the Sokhna Port and at IFC's office in Cairo starting January 18, 2004.

Port Address:Sokhna Port, Suez, Egypt.

IFC Office in Cairo: International Finance Corporation, World Trade Center Building, Corniche El Nil, Boulac, Cairo, Egypt
Sponsor:
The project sponsors are Orascom Construction Industries (OCI) and Captain Ossama Al Sharif.  Listed on the Cairo Stock Exchange, OCI is Egypt's largest construction and building materials conglomerate with a primary focus on construction and cement.  Captain Al Sharif is a Jordanian national and has been in the shipping business since his graduation from the Alexandria Maritime Academy.  He founded ECHCO in 1997, the first authorized private container handling company in Egypt, and has acted as its Chairman and Managing Director since inception.  

SPDC's ownership structure is as follows: 

ECHCO	               70% 
Captain Al Sharif	  15% 
Coral Holdings	               10%
Mr. Al Tantawy                   5%
Total                                100%

Since ECHCO is a 50/50 joint venture between OCI and Captain Al Sharif, the two parties own, directly and indirectly, a combined 85% of SPDC.  Coral Holdings Investment Ltd. is a UK based investment vehicle.  Mr. Al Tantawy has served as ECHCO's General Manager since 1997.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $97 million. The proposed IFC investment is a $20 million A loan for IFC's own account.
Investment: 20.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan20.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Sohkna is located 150 km south-east of Cairo and 40 km south of the Suez Canal on the Red Sea.  It is connected to the main rail network via a spur off the Cairo to Suez line.  There are also two roads connecting the Port to Cairo.  The first road (Road 24) leads from Cairo eastward to Suez city and then south to Sokhna port along the Red Sea.  The second road (Road 23) route takes a south  east direction from Cairo's ring road until it reaches the coastal Red Sea road a few km north of Sokhna.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati:
This is a Category B project.  The review of this project consisted of an Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) for the project completed by the Dutch consultants Solid Waste Consultancy B.V., discussions with staff who visited the project site, and a telephone conversation and information exchange with the Sokhnas Security, Safety and Environmental Manager.  The following potential environmental, health, and safety impacts of the project were analyzed: -  environmental, health and safety management -  site selection; -  maintenance dredging; -  stormwater management; -  handling and storage of dangerous cargos and hazardous materials; -  waste management; -  emissions to air; and -  emergency response planning and preparedness. SPDC has presented plans to ensure that its facilities will operate in a manner that complies with applicable laws and regulations and IFCs current guidelines and policies.  A more complete description of environmental mitigation measures is provided in the Environmental Review Summary.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe environmental documentation will be available at the gate of the Sokhna Port and at IFC's office in Cairo starting January 18, 2004.

Project Description: Banque Societe Generale Vostok (BSGV or the company) is a wholly-owned Russian subsidiary of the Societe Generale Group. BSGV started operations in 1993, and is a Russian bank licensed, regulated and supervised by the Central Bank of Russia. The project will support BSGV's recently announced major expansion plan within Russia, and specifically the Bank's retail operations, including mortgage finance and its new wholly-owned leasing subsidiary, BSGV-Leasing.  Societe Generale is one of the first major global banking players to enter the Russian market and establish full-service banking operations.  By supporting the Bank's operations, IFC will help bring additional competition and best practices to the market, as well as better access to high standard banking services and products for Russian companies and individuals. In addition, BSGV's commitment to Russia will send a positive signal to other major international financial institutions.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Financial Intermediary (FI) Type 1 project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  BSGV must establish an environmental management system designed to ensure that loans comply with Russian environmental, health and safety standards.  BSGV must participate in IFC-approved environmental training and provide IFC with annual environmental reports.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor:
Societe Generale Group is a leading French-based banking group with operations throughout the world. The Group is active in emerging markets, with a 14 billion loan portfolio in emerging markets (up from 11.7 billion in 2001). Societe Generale had a large banking presence in Russia prior to the Russian revolution, with branches from St. Petersburg to Vladivostok in the Russian Far East. The Banque Russo-Asiatique, as the Russian bank was known, was one of the country's largest banks at the time with a 175-branch nationwide network. This project represents a return of the Bank to retail markets where it has not been present in over eighty years.

Two of the Group's most significant foreign banking operations are in Eastern Europe (Romanian Development Bank and Czech Komercni Banka, both of which were privatized state banks), where the Group's expansion plan entails growing its retail operation. The Group is currently present in 28 countries of Eastern Europe, the Mediterranean basin, Asia, Western Africa and Latin America (Argentina), with 4.8 million customers, 27,000 employees and 1,232 branches in emerging markets, but at present has a limited retail presence in the former Soviet Union.
Cost Nature: The proposed project consists of  a senior loan of up to $75.0 million to BSGV and a loan of up to $20.0 million to BSGV-Leasing for IFC's own account. The proceeds of IFC's loan will be used to support BSGV's mortgage lending operations, and BSGV-Leasing to provide lease financing to Russian corporate clients.
Investment: 75.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan75.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: BSGV is headquartered in Moscow, where it has concentrated on corporate lending since 1993. BSGV has developed an ambitious expansion plan to open a number of retail outlets in Moscow, St. Petersburg, and the Russian regions. BSGV-Leasing will work primarily in the areas where the Bank is active, but will also work in a somewhat broader geographic area.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Financial Intermediary (FI) Type 1 project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  BSGV must establish an environmental management system designed to ensure that loans comply with Russian environmental, health and safety standards.  BSGV must participate in IFC-approved environmental training and provide IFC with annual environmental reports.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Description: The project involves the provision of a guarantee of up to 50% of a $1.5 million equivalent Ruble denominated commercial bank loan to the Russian Women Microfinance Network (RWMN, or the Network) one of the Russia's top microfinance institutions (NGO MFIs).  RWMN has a strong growing network in central European Russia.  The commercial bank loan would be used for expanding the network and for on-lending to RWMN regional partner funds (the Partners), during a period when RWMN is attempting to transform itself from being a non-profit fund into a regulated financial institution.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an  FI Type 1 project.  RWMN must require that investments under relevant operations meet host country environmental, health and safety requirements and be consistent with IFCs microfinance exclusion list.  IFC will assess RWMNs capacity for environmental review.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: RWMN is a member of the Women's World Banking (WWB) network and has received extensive technical assistance and consulting services from WWB.   At this time, RWMN is an NGO and does not have shareholders.
Cost Nature: The project involves the provision of a guarantee of up to 50% of a $1.5 million equivalent Ruble denominated commercial bank loan.
Investment: 1.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan1.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative

It supervises the operations of, and lends to, five regional Partners located in Kaluga, Tver, Vidnoye, Kostroma and Belgorod.  The Partners comprise the 'Network' and they provide microloans to individual entrepreneurs and small businesses mainly involved in production, trade and services.

Project Description: The purpose of the ACC is to provide a financial return for investors while also generating a conservation return in terms of increased preservation of ecologically-significant marine habitats. The ACC has currently achieved a committed capitalization of $12.25 million towards its targeted level of $16.0 million.  It is managed by Next Century Partners, a Manila-based fund management company. The purpose of this project is to conserve significant coastal and marine biodiversity through a unique partnership between a private equity investment holding company (ACC) and two local nongovernmental organizations.  IFC will channel a total of $4.5 million in GEF grant funds for the two local NGOs to carry out conservation activities in the six biodiversity rich areas mentioned above. The conservation activities in the Tranche 1 site of El Nido will be implemented by the El Nido Foundation (ENF).  The conservation activities in the five Tranche 2 sites in the Visayan Sea will be implemented by the World Wildlife Fund-Philippines (WWF-P).   ENF and WWF-P will involve and foster ownership among multiple stakeholders, including governmental agencies, local communities, private sector operators, and other local NGOs. The conservation activities will include: conservation management, marine enforcement, information-education-communication, sustainable livelihoods, biodiversity research and monitoring, and development of institutional and financial sustainability mechanisms.  The ACC portfolio companies  Ten Knots Corporation and Stellar Fisheries  will allocate some of their revenues to sustain these conservation activities after the GEF funds are fully utilized.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category FI Type 1 project, according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because the sub-projects are as yet undefined.  The review of this project consisted of a site visit and review of environmental and social information submitted by the project sponsor, including an independent environmental audit. The primary issue is the establishment of an Environmental Management System (EMS) by the sponsor to track and manage environmental and social issues on a continuous basis.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityBecause this project has been categorized as FI Type 1, it is not necessary to disclose any environmental documents to the local communities.
Sponsor: The project sponsor is the Asian Conservation Company (ACC), which is a private equity investment holding company that purchases majority ownership of companies operating in areas of significant marine biological diversity (biodiversity) in the Philippines. The majority shareholder of  ACC is the Asian Conservation Corporation Limited (ACCL), a Guernsey corporation, whose shareholders include SCS Partners, The Summit Foundation, Shari Sant Plummer, Daniel Lee Plummer, Wolcott Henry, and Mango Global Limited.
Cost Nature: The total costs of this project are $22 million. Of this amount, IFC, in its capacity as GEF Executing Agency, will provide $4.5 million in GEF grant funding.  The ACC will provide $16 million in investment capital.  The remainder will be provided by other donors (e.g., Packard Foundation, Seacology).
Location: This project will be implemented in two tranches.  The first tranche will be implemented in El Nido, Palawan, which is a coastal area containing 19 communities and a marine protected area of significant biological importance.  The second tranche will be implemented in five sites within the Visayan Sea, including Sangay Reserve (Negros Occidental), Asid Gulf (Masbate), North Guimaras Strait (Negros), Estancia and Concepcion (Northern Iloilo), and Bantayan Island (Cebu).  All of these areas in the Visayan Sea contain significant marine biodiversity and fishing communities that will participate in this project.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category FI Type 1 project, according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because the sub-projects are as yet undefined.  The review of this project consisted of a site visit and review of environmental and social information submitted by the project sponsor, including an independent environmental audit. The primary issue is the establishment of an Environmental Management System (EMS) by the sponsor to track and manage environmental and social issues on a continuous basis.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityBecause this project has been categorized as FI Type 1, it is not necessary to disclose any environmental documents to the local communities.

Project Description: Although ITA is a relatively new organization, it contains highly capable and dedicated staff who have been working on biodiversity conservation in Peru for many years.  The staff members have undertaken various conservation projects in conjunction with the Missouri Botanical Garden.  These have included, for example, an orchid conservation initiative and a reforestation project for cock of the rock habitat. ITA staff members have also implemented a conservation project for the spectacled bear and collaborated on a biological research endeavor with the University of Kansas.  This project aims to achieve long-term conservation of the 10,000 hectare Inka Terra Ecological Reserve and its many species of flora & fauna.  The specific objectives include the following: -1  To develop a Forest Conservation and Management Plan that properly zones the reserve based upon a solid understanding of its ecology; -2  To develop partnerships with the four local communities so they can improve their quality of life while helping to preserve the forests; -3  To promote increased support for forest conservation and sustainable development through training programs; and -4  To generate long-term funding for conservation through development of new ecotourism attractions.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project, according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe ERS was disclosed locally at the town hall in Puerto Maldonado.
Sponsor: The project sponsor is the Inka Terra Association (ITA), a not-for-profit, nongovernmental organization that aims to conserve biological diversity in Peru.   ITA was established by, and works in conjunction with, Inka Terra S.A.C., which is a Peruvian hotel owner and operator specializing in facilities oriented towards ecotourism.  Inka Terra S.A.C. is 100% owned by Sr. Jose Koechlin.   Sr. Koechlin is a well-known Peruvian environmentalist and hotelier with long-standing interest in environmentally sustainable tourism.During FY01 IFC approved an $8 million loan to Inka Terra S.A.C.  IFCs investment was intended to refinance the companys high interest debt and to support the companys expansion program. Since then IFCs Environmental Finance Group (CESEF) has assisted ITA to develop a Medium Sized Project proposal for funding from the Global Environment Facility (GEF).
Cost Nature: The total costs of this project are $1,921,000 This does not include IFCs mainstream investment or Inka Terra S.A.s contribution towards its expansion program. Of this amount, IFC, in its capacity as GEF Executing Agency, will provide $725,000 in GEF funding.   With regard to the GEF funding, $362,000 will be provided as a grant and $363,000 will be provided as a loan.  The remainder of the project costs will be covered by ITA and other donors (e.g., Amazon Center for Environmental Education and Research, Missouri Botanical Gardens).
Location: This project will be implemented in conjunction with Inka Terras Reserva Amazónica lodge in southeastern Peru.   Reserva Amazónica has been in operation for over 25 years and was one of the first eco-tourist facilities developed in Peru.  The Reserva Amazónica lodge was formerly known as Cusco Amazónico.    During much of this time, Inka Terra has leased a 10,000 hectare area of tropical rainforest located adjacent to the lodge.  Known as the Inka Terra Ecological Reserve (IER), the company has supported considerable ecological research within this reserve.  The studies carried out to date in the reserve have identified considerable biological diversity, including 136 species of mammals, 366 species of birds, 83 species of reptiles, and 362 species of ants.  Many of the species of flora and fauna in the reserve were discovered there and some have not been found elsewhere in Peru.Despite Inka Terra S.A.s desire to promote forest conservation, the IER has remained largely unmanaged because the company has been largely occupied with running its tourism operations. Although Inka Terra S.A. possesses staff members with considerable conservation experience and expertise, until recently these individuals faced conflicting demands on their time (between commercial and conservation priorities).  In fact, until this project was developed, there had been relatively little diagnosis of the threats to the areas biodiversity.Yet various threats have emerged to the forest.  A transcontinental road has been built on the back (north) of the reserve, going to Brazil.  Since it is still a dirt road it does not have heavy traffic yet, but it has nonetheless facilitated encroachment upon the reserve.  The threat of logging has also been exacerbated by the road. Furthermore, several communities have arisen on the border of the IER.  Finally, mercury pollution from gold mining in the Madre de Dios River is threatening aquatic biodiversity (as well as human health).
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project, according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe ERS was disclosed locally at the town hall in Puerto Maldonado.

Project Description: IFC and the USAID propose to create the Balkans Infrastructure Development Facility (BID Facility), a multi-donor facility that will assist in development of private infrastructure in the Balkans region, enhance private sector participation and investments in infrastructure projects, and facilitate public private partnerships.  The BID Facility would help committed public entities (such as local governments and municipalities etc.) identify, analyze, structure, and develop viable and attractive infrastructure projects suitable for private sector investment and participation mainly in water and sanitation, transport, and energy sectors.  The BID Facility will help prepare infrastructure project proposals which have a reasonable potential to successfully attract private sector participation and financing.  The BID Facility will function as a revolving fund and will support project preparation funding throughout the project development process, from feasibility through transaction structuring, negotiation and financial closure.  At times, IFC may consider BID Facility projects for financing, but IFC would not be obligated to consider or provide such financing. The Facility will be IFC managed and will initially begin operations with an office in Sofia, Bulgaria with a small core team of specialists supported by project specific consultants.  The BID Facility will be governed by a Board of Donor Representatives which will set the overall policies, guidelines and direction of the Facility.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category C project, according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because the facility itself will have no adverse environmental and social impact.  The projects to be undertaken by the Facility will seek to comply with local and World Bank Group environmental and social guidelines.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The project sponsors are IFC, the United States Agency for International Development (USAID), and some European donor countries.  IFC has received strong initial interest and support from the donors with indicative financial commitments totaling about $7 million.  The donor support will be formalized soon after IFC has the Board approval to establish the facility.
Cost Nature: The BID Facility is expected to be capitalized at $10 million.   IFCs proposed contribution of $1.5 million (same as the proposed USAID contribution of $1.5 million) represents 15% of the expected $10 million capitalization.  The Facility is estimated to be operational for an initial life period of 10 years.  The BID Facilitys expenses will be reimbursed upon successful closures of transactions undertaken.  Given this closure-based cost recovery, the Facilitys estimated life could be shorter, if sufficient closures are not reached, or longer, if mutually desired by the project sponsors.
Location: The BID Facility would be established in Sofia, Bulgaria with most of the staff located there, but the Facility would operate regionally in all of the Balkan countries from Sofia covering projects in Albania, Bosnia & Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Croatia, FYR Macedonia, Romania, Serbia and Montenegro.  In addition, as an IFC managed facility, BID Facility will also leverage off of IFCs presence in the region as appropriate.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category C project, according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because the facility itself will have no adverse environmental and social impact.  The projects to be undertaken by the Facility will seek to comply with local and World Bank Group environmental and social guidelines.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community

Project Description: The proposed project consists of equity and debt investments of up to EUR 200 million to support Raiffeisen International Bank Holding AG (Raiffeisen International), a holding company fully-owned by Raiffeisen Zentralbank Österreich AG (RZB).  Raiffeisen International currently holds controlling stakes in 14 banks and several other finance companies in Central, Eastern and South Eastern Europe, namely in Belarus, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Croatia, Czech Republic, Hungary, Kosovo, Poland, Romania, Russia, Serbia and Montenegro, Slovakia, Slovenia and Ukraine.  The purchase of a fifteenth network bank (Savings Bank of Albania) has recently been announced.  Total aggregate assets of the network banks amount to approximately EUR 19 billion as of December 31, 2003, with aggregated equity of close to EUR 1 billion (not including the Savings Bank of Albania).
Role:
Through this investment IFC will support RZB's efforts in the region, which since 1998 are increasingly targeted at the development of small and medium enterprise lending. RZB has a strong commitment to this region and has in many cases been one of the first foreign banks to invest.  Unlike many other foreign banks in the region, RZB has developed a clear focus on local customers.

The countries in which Raiffeisen International operates are still poorly served by their banks. The banking contribution to GDP in the more developed markets of Raiffeisen International (Czech Republic and Slovenia) is at the level of approximately 50%. This is still low relative to developed countries such as Austria or Germany where the comparable figure is over 100%. This shows that there is still significant growth potential and also a development lag.   In addition, other countries in Raiffeisen International's portfolio lag further behind in terms of banking development.  IFC's support of a well-run bank in these countries will have an important developmental impact.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an FI Type 1 project.  Raiffeisen International will be required to develop an environmental management system to ensure that relevant operations meet host country environmental an social requirements.  IFC will assess Raiffeisen Internationals capacity in this regard.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor:
RZB acts as the central bank to Austria's Raiffeisen Banking Group as well as a commercial bank and in some countries as an investment bank. With assets of EUR 46.5 billion it is currently Austria's 3rd largest banking group.  In 1987 RZB started to diversify its activities outside of Austria by creating a subsidiary in Hungary (founding Unicbank together with IFC).  Since then it has grown one of the most complete and locally focused banking networks in the Central, Eastern and South Eastern European region.

RZB continues to play an important role in the economic development of the region, and in particular in the less developed markets, such as Belarus, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Romania, Russia, Serbia and Montenegro, Ukraine and soon in Albania.  RZB has a strong commitment to this region and has in many cases been one of or the first foreign banks to invest.
Cost Nature: The proposed project consists of an equity and/or debt investment totaling up to EUR 200 million to support Raiffeisen International.
Investment: 121.28 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan60.64Equity60.64* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Raiffeisen International is a Vienna based Austrian joint stock company, which holds controlling interests in a number of finance subsidiaries in the countries listed above.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is an FI Type 1 project.  Raiffeisen International will be required to develop an environmental management system to ensure that relevant operations meet host country environmental an social requirements.  IFC will assess Raiffeisen Internationals capacity in this regard.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Company Name: Administradora de Fondos de Pensiones Confia S.A.
Project Description:
The project company is Confia AFP S.A. (Confia or the company), one of the leading pension fund companies in El Salvador, with a 43.5% market share and approximately 449,000 affiliates (as of June 2003). 

In December 2003, Cuscatlan Group entered into a share purchase agreement with Citigroup International, controlling shareholder of Confia, to acquire, subject to regulatory approval, a controlling stake in the company.

Cuscatlan Group, through its holding company Union de Bancos Cuscatlan Internacional (UBCI or the group), is the second largest financial group in Central America. The acquisition of Confia would fit well in Cuscatlan's long term strategy, by helping the group further diversify its revenue stream, reinforce its image as a regional, integrated financial services provider and by creating strong synergies and cross-selling opportunities with the group's retail banking, asset management and insurance activities.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category C project according to IFC''s environmental review procedure.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor:
UBCI, Cuscatlán's holding company provides, through its subsidiaries and affiliated companies in El Salvador, Guatemala, Costa Rica and Panama, corporate banking, credit card, mortgages, factoring, stock brokerage, trade finance and asset management services to its clients across the region.  After Banco del Istmo in Panama, it is the largest financial group in Central America with $3.2 billion in assets and $308 million in equity (as of June 30, 2003).  

UBCI was listed on the Costa Rican stock market through a $7.5 million IPO in July 2002, and in November 2003 UBCI's shares were listed on the LATIBEX program in the Madrid Stock Exchange.  It has a diversified shareholding structure; 78% of UBCI is owned by the Salvadoran vehicle, Corporación UBC S.A. de C.V., which, in turn, is owned by the 2,500 original shareholders of Banco Cuscatlan de El Salvador.
Cost Nature: IFC's proposed investment in Confia AFP will be an equity investment of up to $7.5 million for up to 25% of the share capital of the company.
Investment: 7.50 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity7.50* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Confia is headquartered in San Salvador and has 9 branches across El Salvador.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category C project according to IFC''s environmental review procedure.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Description: The project consists of the construction of a $100-110 million float glass plant in the town of Targovishte in the northwestern part of Bulgaria.  At full capacity, it is expected to produce 200,000 tons of clear float glass annually and employ 200 people.  Approximately 90,000 tons of this production will be exported to the nearby Balkan markets, particularly Greece and Romania, 20,000 tons in the domestic Bulgarian market, and the remainder within Turkey.
Role:
The project will have a strong development impact.  It will bring a modern float glass plant in Bulgaria, allow the transfer of technological know-how related to float glass production, and make a significant contribution towards developing Bulgaria's export base.  It will create direct employment for 200 workers outside the capital, and will foster additional commercial activity.  Approximately 90% of production will be directed to export markets, mainly the Balkans and Turkey, contributing to foreign exchange generation.  The project will benefit from low electricity and labor costs as well as good proximity to local export markets.  Other, non-quantifiable development impacts include the demonstration effect for other foreign investors who are considering Bulgaria for new production facilities and the potential for linkages along the supply chain that could make of Targovishte a glass production center in the region.

IFC is expected to play a critical role in the project by:

- providing long-term, limited recourse financing otherwise not available to the company, 
- mobilizing resources from the international debt markets through its B-loan program and broadening Sisecam's sources of term capital and 
- encouraging Turkish investors to venture abroad.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The review of this project consisted of appraising technical, environmental and social information submitted by the project sponsor as well as site visits to the Targovishte plant site and to a number of Sisecams plants in Turkey.  The following potential environment, health, safety and social impacts of the project were analyzed.- Site selection and related land use;- Compliance of the proposed plant with IFC and Bulgarian environmental, health and safety (EHS) requirements;- Commitment to quality and efficiency; and- Labor and community issues.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe offices of the Regional Governor in Targovishte, Bulgaria at the following address:
7700 Targovishte, BG
2, St. Karadja Str.
Sponsor: The sponsor is Turkiye Sise ve Cam Fabrikalari A.S. (Sisecam or the sponsor), Turkey's leading glass manufacturer and a longtime IFC client.  Technical and management assistance will be provided from Trakya Cam Sanayii A.S. (Trakya Cam), the float glass division of the Sisecam Group. Established in 1977, Trakya Cam started its operations in 1978 and has grown over the past quarter century into one of the leading glass manufacturers in southern Europe with revenues of $220 million over sales of 650,000 tons of float and processed glass.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $100-110 million.  The IFC investment consists of an  A loan of  $22. 5 million, a B loan of $32. 5 million, and either an equity investment or a C loan of $5.0 million.
Investment: 27.50 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan22.50Equity5.0* These investment figures are indicative

Project Description: The proposed project is the construction of a green field glass tableware plant with an annual capacity of 53,000 tons in Targovishte, Bulgaria, at an estimated cost of $60 million.  The project, which is expected to be commissioned in  2005 and employ 500 employees in 8 production lines, is located 123 km from the port of Varna on the Black Sea and 313 km from Sofia.  It will sell 90% of its production in the Balkans, Central, Eastern, and Western Europe and 10% domestically.
Role:
The project will have a strong development impact.  It will bring a state-of-the-art tableware facility to Bulgaria, and create direct employment for approximately 500 workers outside the capital and foster additional commercial activity. Approximately 90% of production will be directed to export markets, mainly Balkans, Central-Eastern and Western Europe countries, contributing to foreign exchange generation.  The large scale of the plant will capture economies of scale in production and low capital cost.  Other non-quantifiable development impacts include the demonstration effect for other foreign investors who are considering Bulgaria for new production facilities and the potential for linkages along the supply chain that could make of Targovishte a glass production center in the region.

IFC is expected to play a critical role in the project by:

-providing long-term, limited recourse financing otherwise not available to the company, 
- mobilizing resources from the international debt markets through its B-loan program and broadening Sisecam's sources of term capital and 
- encouraging Turkish investors to venture abroad.

This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. Established in 1934, over the years Pasabahce has grown to become the third largest player in the tableware industry worldwide.

Project Description: TRG Pakistan Limited (TRG or the company) operates a call center in Lahore, Pakistan, and plans to expand its local operations and invest overseas in order to diversify its operations.  The company was established in 2002, and had consolidated revenues of approximately $280,000 during that year.
Environmental Social Issues: This project is a category C project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedures.  The company uses leased furnished office has no immediate plans to construct or purchase a building.  Therefore, no further environmental or social analysis is required.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

The major sponsors are Zia Chishti (Chairman and CEO, former founder, CEO, and Chairman of Align Technology), Atiq Raza (Board member and CEO of Raza Microelectronics, USA, former Chairman of AMD Microsystems), Peter Riepenhausen (Board member and former Senior EVP, Pepsico), and Asim Abdullah (Board member of Commerce One)

Major Shareholders
TRG is publicly listed on the Karachi Stock Exchange.  The company's major shareholders include United Bank Limited, National Bank of Pakistan, Zia Chishti, and Habib Bank Limited.

Project Description:
The project consists of an IFC senior loan of up to Euro 4 million to Opportunity Bank Montenegro (OBM, bank, or the company) for the purpose of financing an expanding loan portfolio.  Loans will be made to micro and small business clients in line with OBM's strategy to finance the growth of micro and small businesses. OBM's management expects to fund the growth of the loan portfolio partly from externally borrowed funds and partly by mobilizing savings.

Opportunity Bank Montenegro (OBM) was founded in April 2002 to finance the growth of micro and small enterprises in Montenegro and to offer safe savings services to the Montenegrin public.  OBM is a licensed and regulated full service bank that provides loans to both existing businesses and start-ups.  Loan sizes range from EUR 500 to EUR 10,000 for micro-entrepreneurs and generally up to EUR 100,000 (with a present average loan size of EUR 30,000) for small enterprises.

Opportunity Bank Montenegro is the successor to Microcredit Montenegro (MCM), which was founded in 1999 as a non-government, non-profit organization offering loans to small-business entrepreneurs in Montenegro. MCM's primary target clients were entrepreneurs and farmers who lacked the financial means necessary to develop their business. MCM has made a total of more than 10,000 loans to trade, service, manufacturing, and agricultural clients. The existing clients of MCM have mostly become clients of OBM, and MCM has ceased to grant new loans.
Environmental Social Issues: OBM is a category FI type 1 project as classified by IFCs environmental and social review procedures.   Opportunity Bank will be required to implement an environmental managements system to ensure that its lending activities are in compliance with host country environmental and social requirements and with IFC''s Microfinance Exclusion List.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor:
The project sponsor and main shareholder (88%) is Opportunity International USA, a non-profit organization with the aim to fight against poverty. OI is a pioneer in microfinance development and cooperates with 42 implementing partners that deliver Opportunity's loan program in 24 countries. In Eastern Europe, OI has implementing partners in Russia, Croatia, Macedonia, Bulgaria, Romania, Poland, Albania, Serbia and Montenegro. 
Other Shareholders: The rest of the shares (12%) are distributed among 11 other shareholders.
Cost Nature: OBM's portfolio expansion program is expected to require about $20 million in funding from various sources over the next three years.  IFC's senior loan of Euro 4 million (approximately $5.0 million equivalent) will be in two tranches.  Total disbursed loan amount cannot at any time exceed 60% of the Bank's net worth.  Tranche 1 would be for Euro 3 million ($3.8 million equivalent), with tranche 2 becoming effective if and when the bank's net worth can support the extra debt.
Investment: 4.84 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan4.84Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The bank's headquarters are in Podgorice, the capital of the Republic of Montenegro.  In addition, the bank has branches in the towns of Bar (coastal region), Niksic (central region) and Berane (northern region).
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: OBM is a category FI type 1 project as classified by IFCs environmental and social review procedures.   Opportunity Bank will be required to implement an environmental managements system to ensure that its lending activities are in compliance with host country environmental and social requirements and with IFC''s Microfinance Exclusion List.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Company Name: Guangxi Baise Fenglin Fiberboard Corporation Limited
Project Description:
The poject cmpany, Guangxi Fenglin Forestry Development Co. Ltd. (Fenglin or the cmpany), is one of the largest medium-density fiberboard (MDF) manufacturers in China with a production capacity of 140,000 m3 p.a.. Headquartered in Nanning, Guangxi province in China, the Company supplies MDF boards to the country's fast growing furniture and construction industries. 
The purpose of the poject is to expand the production capacity of the cmpany through the addition of a new 150,000 m3 continuous press medium- and high-density fiberboard line (MDF and HDF), a flooring panel line and a decorative panel line  all in Baise, Guangxi province in China. Another component of the project is to establish and develop an additional 200,000 mu fast growing and high yielding plantation forest to build up sufficient raw material supply for the company.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review procedure.  Environmental, social and health and safety issues which may be associated with this project and which will be reviewed during project appraisal include: siting and land acquisition process for the manufacturing sites and plantations; sustainable management and independent certification of plantations and other wood sources, including appropriate selection and use of agrochemicals;  minimization of fossil fuel use by energy efficiency measures, use of waste wood as fuel and cogeneration of heat and power; emissions to air and water; fire protection and emergency response; worker health and safety including exposure to dust, fume and noise, and health, safety and environmental management systems.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe environmental document Environmental Review Summary (ERS) will be available at the company's headquarters. (See the company's address below). In addition, the ERS will be available at the factory gates at Guangxi Baise Fenglin Fiberboard Co., Ltd in the city of Baise.
Sponsor:
The project sponsor is Mr. Liu Yi Chuan, a Hong Kong citizen and entrepreneur who operates a number of successful businesses in China and abroad. Mr. Liu is a 100% owner of Fenglin International BVI, a private company created in 2003, which owns the project company. Mr. Liu has been in the MDF production business since 1995 through his shareholding in Nanning Sanyuan Property Development Company Ltd.

Fenglin International controls two subsidiaries: the project company located in the city of Nanning, China and Guangxi Baise Fenglin Fiberboard Co., Ltd. Located in the city of Baise, China. Fenglin has been producing MDF boards since 1995. At Baise site, the MDF production started in December 2003.
Cost Nature: The estimated total project cost is $61 million.  The proposed IFC investment would be up to $35 million comprising an A-loan of up to $18 million, a B-loan of up to $14 million and equity of up to $3 million.  The remaining project financing amount of $26 million will include equity in the form of internally generated cash and shareholder's subscription.
Investment: 25.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk Management4.0GuaranteeLoan15.0Equity6.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The project site is located in Baise, Guangxi Province, which is approximately 240 km West of Nanning. Baise is a predominantly rural and less developed province in Southern China with vast forest resources.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review procedure.  Environmental, social and health and safety issues which may be associated with this project and which will be reviewed during project appraisal include: siting and land acquisition process for the manufacturing sites and plantations; sustainable management and independent certification of plantations and other wood sources, including appropriate selection and use of agrochemicals;  minimization of fossil fuel use by energy efficiency measures, use of waste wood as fuel and cogeneration of heat and power; emissions to air and water; fire protection and emergency response; worker health and safety including exposure to dust, fume and noise, and health, safety and environmental management systems.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe environmental document Environmental Review Summary (ERS) will be available at the company's headquarters.
