Project Description:
EDYFICAR (or the company) is a microfinance institution that provides basic credit services to low-income populations in Peru. It serves approximately 32,000 clients, of whom approximately 50% are women, 25% live in rural and semi-rural areas, and about 30% live below the country's poverty line. Its main product lines are working capital loans, business improvement loans, and a relatively modest portfolio of housing loans. EDYFICAR, which is constituted as a private stock company, obtained a limited banking licenses in 1998 from the Peruvian Superintendency of Banking and Insurance. It operates 18 branches in various regions of Peru.

The purpose of IFC's financing is to support the continued expansion of EDYFICAR's loan program to low-income microentrepreneurs throughout Peru. In addition to allowing an expansion of EDYFICAR's loan program, IFC's financing will enable the institution to diversify its funding sources and provide a greater range of medium-term loan products, something greatly demanded among the clients served by EDYFICAR.
Role:
IFC's financing to EDYFICAR will have a high impact on economic development and is expected to be significant in terms of its support for productive activities, employment generation and social equity. Given EDYFICAR's average loan size of $890, IFC's financing can be expected to support approximately 3,500 microentrepreneurs. These entrepreneurs in turn support approximately 7,000 employees or family members.

The IFC credit line will allow EDYFICAR to expand its portfolio and develop new lending products. As a result, EDYFICAR's clients will be able to undertake greater investment in business improvement projects for long-term growth and sustainability.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category FI Type 1 project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure.  EDYFICAR will establish an environmental management system that will ensure that activities financed under relevant operations are consistent with applicable environmental, occupational health and safety regulations of Peru; designate appropriate individuals who will have responsibility for the environment and who will attend IFCs environmental management workshops or an approved equivalent;  submit to IFC an environmental management plan;  and submit to IFC an annual environmental performance report.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: The main shareholder of EDYFICAR is CARE Peru, which owns 80.1% of the shares in the institution. The remaining 19.9% is owned by employees and management (10.1%) and Microvest (9.8%), a private investment firm based in the United States.  CARE Peru, which is a local chapter of CARE International, USA, was constituted as a local non-profit organization in 1970 to support the victims of an large earthquake. Since then, its work has evolved into development programs in various areas. All projects focus on making significant and sustainable improvements to the lives of low income populations. Over the years, CARE Peru developed a significant microenterprise loan portfolio, which ultimately enabled it to create EDYFICAR as a legally separated and specialized financial entity.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $3.0 million. The proposed IFC investment is a $3.0 million A loan for IFC's own account.
Investment: 4.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan4.0Equity0.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: EDYFICAR is headquartered in Lima, Peru and serves its clients through 18 branch offices in different regions of Peru. IFC's investment can be used to fund EDYFICAR's loan activities in any of its branches.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category FI Type 1 project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure.  EDYFICAR will establish an environmental management system that will ensure that activities financed under relevant operations are consistent with applicable environmental, occupational health and safety regulations of Peru; designate appropriate individuals who will have responsibility for the environment and who will attend IFCs environmental management workshops or an approved equivalent;  submit to IFC an environmental management plan;  and submit to IFC an annual environmental performance report.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sector: AC - Commercial Banking - Microfinance and Small Business

Project Description: The project consists of expanding the asset base of SugdAgroServe (SAS or the company), an existing client of IFC, to help meet the growing demand for funding by cotton farmers in Tajikistan.  In April 2002, IFC helped establish SAS on a pilot basis to alleviate poverty among cotton farmers.  SAS allows farmers to become shareholders and capitalize on profits by financing crop inputs at affordable prices and selling their cotton in greater quantities and on better terms.  The initial $502,000 was sufficient to provide crop input financing to about 1,200 hectares.  As more farmers want to participate, the contemplated expansion and additional funding would enable SAS to service up to an estimated 3,500 hectares.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a category B project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  As a result of the initial investment in SAS, it is clear that the main environmental issues relate to:-  excess and inefficient water consumption and its impact on reduced river flows, raised groundwater tables, increased salinity, and reduced crop yields; and -  excess and inappropriate tillage by farmers.  The technical assistance program is geared to address these problems by:                  -  introducing laser leveling as a key technology for farmers to reduce water consumption, reduce                           drainage and increase crop yields; and  -  demonstrating minimum tillage techniques.  Labor issues such as worker health and safety as well as  harmful child labor will be discussed with the client.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityPrivate Enterprise Partnership/International Finance Corporation
C/o SugdAgroServe
Building 85 A, Lenina Street
Khujand,  Tajikistan
tel:  992 3422 67211  office
Sponsor: SAS is presently owned by 365 cotton farmers, which belong to some fourteen Dehkan farms in the Nov and adjacent Zafarabad oblasts in Northern Tajikistan.  Participating farmers were selected based on their land holding and financial condition.  SAS is exploring with IFC the opportunity to expand its shareholding and services to an estimated 1,500 additional farmer-owners.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $1.0 million.  The proposed IFC investment is a $500,000 A loan for IFC's own account.  This is IFC's second loan to SAS after approving in April 2002 a $250,000 A loan to help establish the company.  The balance of the proposed financing is capital reserve made available through a second grant fund by the Swiss State Secretariat for Economic Affairs (SECO) and additional share capital paid in by new farmers.

The technical assistance program is geared to address these problems by:                  -  introducing laser leveling as a key technology for farmers to reduce water consumption, reduce                           drainage and increase crop yields; and  -  demonstrating minimum tillage techniques. Project Description: Merlon Petroleum Company (Merlon) has 54% and 50% interests, respectively, in the Qantara and El Mansoura Concessions (including development leases awarded within the area of the concession) through wholly owned subsidiaries, Merlon Petroleum Company of Egypt, Merlon Petroleum Company (Qantara) and Merlon Petroleum Company (El Mansoura) - together 'Merlon Egypt' -.  The remaining interests are held by subsidiaries of Melrose Resources plc (Melrose).  In terms of the joint operating agreement between the partners, Merlon is the operating partner.  The project relates to the ongoing investment program towards exploration and development in these oil and gas concessions.  This comprises the initial exploration and commencement of production, development of the three new gas discoveries in the El Mansoura concession, drilling and completing additional appraisal and exploratory wells and acquiring additional seismic data.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects.  The Operator has committed to the development of an Environmental and Social Management System (ESMS) that will integrate environment, occupational health and safety, and social aspects of the operation in Egypt.  This ESMS will be adopted comprehensively by Merlon Egypt.  The Operator provides training for employees on a yearly basis and relates to health, safety and environment, risk assessment, HAZOP, fire fighting, emergency preparedness and accident investigation.  Land acquisition to date has only involved irrigated agricultural land and to date these activities have required no physical displacement of households.  There is a comprehensive land acquisition and compensation process in place and the Operator has prepared, and committed to the implementation of, a Land Acquisition and Compensation Plan (LACP).Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityMerlon Petroleum CompanyCorner 270 & Palestine StreetNew Maadi, Cairo, EgyptPhone: (20-2) 520-1135Fax: (20-2) 520-1137

Project Description: The Andhra Pradesh Paper Mills limited (APPM, or the company), with sales of about 157,000 MT per annum of paper, is the fourth largest integrated pulp and paper manufacturer in India.  The company was established in 1920 and is listed on the Mumbai and Hyderbad Stock Exchanges.  In October 2000, APPM acquired 71% stake in Coastal Papers Ltd. (CP) with a capacity of 55,000 MT p.a. of printing and writing paper from straw pulp and packaging paper from waste paper and newsprint.  With the proposed project, it will focus on shifting CPs production to printing and writing paper based on pulp transferred from APPM.  The proposed project consists of:-  enhancement of pulp capacity -  improvement of the product mix -  increase in production capacity and efficiency -  improvement of environmental management systems and       -  increase in the existing farm forestry program.  The project also includes the restructuring of part of the companys existing short-term debt and the recent completion of the companys privatization through the purchase of the remaining government shares.
Role: Development Impact:Farm Forestry:  IFCs Industry, Environment and Social Specialists have visited APPMs farm forestry nurseries and plantations.  Since 1989, APPM has distributed quality seedlings to more than 14,000 farmers to cover a total plantation land of more than 27,000 hectares.  The company maintains twelve nurseries and employs 50 to 100 workers per nursery.  The total target seedling production for FY03 is 35 million.  Approximately 70,000 person days of labor are required for this, which will generate about Rs 4.2 million in wages for local laborers.  APPM also provides technical know-how to farmers from low cost planting to post harvest stage, through establishment of demonstration plots, audio, video and printed literature, and personal interactions with the farmers.  With this project, APPMs requirement for wood resources is expected to increase by over 33%, and the company will further increase its farm forestry program.Environment:  IFCs Industry and Environmental Specialists have visited APPMs plants and have identified significant environmental benefits of the Project.  In the Coastal Paper unit of the company, the existing 10,500 MT p.a. rice straw pulping section that is heavily polluting, will be closed down.  This will be replaced by pulp from the new Pulp Mill at APPM.  The Project will also help to achieve better pollution controls in the APPM plant.  The new Pulp Mill will bring down absorbable organohalogens (AOX) in the effluent discharge from present levels of 2kg per MT of pulp to 0.5 kg per MT, and reduce APPMs water consumption and odoriferous emissions to comply with the World Bank guidelines.  This will build on the companys existing green platform and allow it to continue to pursue its commitment to the environment.Employment:  APPM will provide direct employment to about 3,200 people, out of which 480 employees will work in the proposed Pulp Mill.  Additionally, with the increased wood fiber requirements as a result of the Project, APPMs farm forestry operations are expected to support over 25,200 farmers and cover over 50,000 hectares of land by 2007.IFC RoleLong term funding:  IFC will provide long term debt, which is generally not available and without which, it would not be possible to complete the financial plan.  In so doing, IFC will play an important role in stabilizing the companys debt profile, ensuring a proper match of cash from operations with debt service requirements.  APPM believes that IFCs involvement as a lead financier will help attract other local banks for lending long term in the current market scenario.  IFC will also inject additional equity in the company, which will provide needed support to the companys financial plan.Promoting sustainability:  IFCs environmental requirements for forest management will mitigate potential environmental problems and lead to sustainable forestry operations.  IFC is expected to assist the company to comply with the new World Bank Groups Forest Strategy and Policy.  The companys farm forestry operations offer a good example of development at the local farm level.  The closure of a straw pulp process will stop high pollution levels.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category B project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  Environmental and social issues which were reviewed as part of the appraisal of this investment included:  implementation of an Environmental Management System to cover all operations; compliance with air emissions, wastewater effluents and solid waste handling requirements;  worker health and safety; implementation of social programs; and compliance of forest harvesting operations with IFC policy and guidelines.  The review found that all operations will be managed in compliance with the World Bank Group policies and guidelines.  In particular, fiber supply for the plants is provided by an extensive network of small-holders, producing substantial social development benefits for the region.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe Environmental Review Summary will be disclosed in the following locations:For the APPM Facility:District Collectors Office, Kakinada, E.G.DistrictSub Collectors Office, Rajahmundry,E.G. Apart from its interest in APPM, the Bangur Group has an 85% equity interest in Maharaja Shree Umed Mills Ltd. (a company in cotton textiles sector) and a 48% stake in P.K. Tea & Produce Co. Ltd. (P.K. Tea, a small company in the tea sector).
Cost Nature: Total project cost is $139.1 million.  The proposed IFC investment is up to $40 million for IFCs own account including up to $35 million in the form of an A-Loan and up to $5 million in the form of a C-Loan equity investment.

Rajamundary is situated on the trunk route, which connects Chennai and Kolkata. Visakhapatnam, a major port, is 200 kms by rail. The plants are located near farm forests and are well connected by roads to various important centers.  The finished products can be easily transported to important commercial centers of Andhra Pradesh and other states by network of rail and road transport.

Project Description: Ruchi Soya Industries Limited (RSIL or the company) is the premier company of the Ruchi Group.  It is the largest oilseed crusher, importer of edible oils, exporter of oilseed meals and producer of textured soya protein (TSP) in India.  It entered the edible oil business in 1986, with primary focus on the sale of refined edible oil in the Indian market.The project aims to take advantage of the increasingly growing demand of edible oil in India, especially the trend toward the packaged edible oil.  The proposed IFC financing will be used in two main areas:  The first is to finance two new facilities: a port based refinery at Patalganga near Mumbai (Bombay) and a crushing plant and associated refinery at Butibori near Nagpur both in the state of Maharashtra.  The second part is to finance the companys maintenance capex and permanent working capital, and upgrade edible oil plants and refineries that may be acquired.  The Patalganga refinery will rely on imported crude oils and will benefit from a logistical advantage over its competition by being located close to the JNPT/Mumbai ports as well as being close to the major regional market of Mumbai.  The Butibori crushing and refining facility will take advantage of the local production of soybeans.

Project Description: The city of Johannesburg has a $1.7 billion capital expenditure program over the next five years.  A significant portion of these investments are in the area of high priority infrastructure.  To finance a portion of these investments the city is looking at diversifying its funding sources with the help of multilateral support.  The purpose of the project is to provide support to the city in broadening its funding through the provision of a funding facility.
Environmental Social Issues: The city of Johannesburg is committed to adopting and implementing the principles and underlying approaches to sustainable development.  Through extensive stakeholder participation processes, key environmental issues have been identified and include: land degradation, threats to biodiversity, improperly managed pollution and waste.  Policies and management strategies to reduce environmental damage, rehabilitate damaged environments, and encourage sustainable development are being put in place.  Programs are in place to address immediate social challenges, particularly the spread of HIV/AIDS and the decline of the inner city.  The citys social package also includes electricity and water rate rebates for indigent households.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: The city of Johannesburg is an amalgamation of 11 administrations that existed prior to 1994 and is run by an elected council  It is a city of 3.2 million inhabitants, with over 1 million households and 125,000 businesses.  The city employs 25,000 staff in 14 service delivery entities  including water, energy, solid waste and transportation.  The city's consolidated 2003/04 budget is ZAR 12.5 billion or $1.8 billion approximately.  Its economic growth has averaged 2.9% per year since 1994.
Cost Nature: The total money raised through a new financing facility issue is expected to be in the range of ZAR 1.0-2.0 billion ($150-300 million approximately).  IFC's exposure on its own account would be limited to $50 million.
Investment: 50.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuarantee50.0LoanEquity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The city of Johannesburg is located in the Gauteng province of South Africa.  The proceeds of the facility will be used to in part to finance a range of priority investments in the area of infrastructure, spread through out the city.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The city of Johannesburg is committed to adopting and implementing the principles and underlying approaches to sustainable development. Project Description: The project involves up to $43.0 million IFC investment in Baltic-American Enterprise Fund and/or subsidiary thereof, (BalAEF or the company) and comprises: up to $40 million IFC investment in the form of credit enhancement through a combination of :-  purchase/partial guarantees of upper equity, - mezzanine and senior tranches of a cross border Mortgage Backed Securities (MBS) to be issued over the next three years by BalAEF, and,-Euro/US$ swap facilities to support MBS issuances.  Under the project, IFCs exposure will be to an off-shore Special Purpose Vehicle (SPV) which will issue Mortgage Backed Securities (MBS), to be sold to international investors.  The SPV allows to achieve a true sale and bankruptcy remote structure; and under the proposed project, BalAEF will set up a securitization program which entails a series of MBS issuances for about $250 million over a three year period.  The first series of approximately $60 to $80 million MBS is expected to be issued within the coming six months. The securities will be backed by a pool of US dollar and Euro-denominated mortgages generated in Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania (the Baltics). The MBS program will represent the first cross border securitization of a portfolio of residential mortgages in the region and is expected to play a significant catalytic role in the development of this market. In particular, the securitization of mortgages would provide BaLAEF with additional liquidity to originate mortgage loans significantly in excess of what the companys limited access to long term funding base has permitted so far.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category C project, according to IFC''s Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because the facility itself will have no adverse environmental and social impact. The projects to be undertaken by the Facility will seek to comply with local and World Bank Group environmental and social guidelines.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The sponsor of the project is Baltic-American Enterprise Fund (BalAEF, the Sponsor), a privately managed Delaware corporation established in 1994 to contribute to private sector development in the Baltics through loans and investments to SMEs and individuals.  BalAEF, capitalized at US$50 million by the US government through the Agency for International Development (USAID), is governed by an independent Board of Directors comprising of US executives appointed by the US President.  BalAEFs Chair The Honorable Rozanne L. Ridgeway, former US Assistant Secretary of State for Europe and Canada. As a non-bank financial institution, BalAEF focuses on two core businesses :-  mortgage lending and -  SME growth financingThe mortgages to be securitized under the MBS program are generated in Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania (the Baltics). However, the project company or the Special Purpose Vehicle (SPV) that will issue the actual securities will be based in a jurisdiction to be determined.
Cost Nature: BalAEF will set up a securitization program which entails a series of MBS issuances for about $250 million over a three year period. IFCs investment will be up to $43 million.
Investment: 40.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan40.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: BalAEF maintains an office in Annapolis, Maryland and operates an office in the capital city of each of the Baltic States. These offices in Vilnius, Riga and Tallinn are responsible for originating, analyzing and recommending business transactions and for administering BalAEFs portfolio in the country.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category C project, according to IFC''s Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because the facility itself will have no adverse environmental and social impact. The projects to be undertaken by the Facility will seek to comply with local and World Bank Group environmental and social guidelines.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community

Project Description: The project is to extend a term loan of up to $6.0 million to Acleda Bank Limited (Acleda or the company), the leading Cambodian microfinance bank, to support expansion of its lending operations.
Environmental Social Issues: Acleda Bank is a Financial Intermediary (FI) Type 1 project, according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedures. The bank has been required to comply with the relevant environmental laws and regulations of Cambodia, use IFC''s Microfinance Exclusion List as part of its microloan application review procedure, and to disseminate appropriate environmental information to loan applicants. Environmental compliance has been satisfactory to date.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: Established in 1993 as a microfinance NGO, Acleda is currently Cambodia''s fourth largest bank ranked by loan portfolio (December 2003: total assets: $48.2 million; gross loan portfolio $40.6 million).  Acleda''s current shareholding structure is Acleda NGO (44.9%); Acleda Staff Association (6.1%); IFC (12.25%), Triodos Bank (12.25%); DEG (12.25%); and, FMO (12.25%).  Acleda NGO, the project sponsor, is the successor to the former Association of Cambodian Local Economic Development Agencies.  The NGO was established in 1993 with assistance from UNDP and the ILO to promote small and micro enterprise development.  It launched a microcredit program in 1994 which was successfully developed and later transformed into a licensed MFI, Acleda Bank, in October 2000.
Cost Nature: The total project cost and IFCs proposed investment is a loan of $6.0 million, for IFCs own account.
Investment: 6.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan6.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Based in Phnom Penh, Acleda provides microcredit, deposit, account management and other financial services to over 95,000 urban and rural clients through an extensive network of 15 branches and 80 outlets in fourteen provinces.  The banks average loan size (December 2003) was about $400; its customer profile includes urban micro and small enterprises, artisans and other service providers, and rural market traders and small shopkeepers.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: Acleda Bank is a Financial Intermediary (FI) Type 1 project, according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedures. The bank has been required to comply with the relevant environmental laws and regulations of Cambodia, use IFC''s Microfinance Exclusion List as part of its microloan application review procedure, and to disseminate appropriate environmental information to loan applicants. Environmental compliance has been satisfactory to date.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sector: AC - Commercial Banking - Microfinance and Small Business

Project Description: WaterHealth International (WHI, www.waterhealth.com) was founded in 1996 to develop and market distributed (non-centralized) water purification/disinfection systems, based on an innovative Ultra Violet (UV) disinfector (proprietary/patented technology) to provide potable water to small communities, institutions and households, as well as for personal use in the developing world.  As a result of its market development initiatives, WHI has already sold and placed more than 300 systems in pilot locations, with a market value of $1.2 MM, through its affiliate partners in several countries, including Mexico and the Philippines.  In October of 2003 WHI formally entered the distributed water service provider market establishing a joint venture with one of its customers in the Philippines, Bendix Sales Corporation.  They have established a joint venture, WaterHealth Philippines, which operates water store franchise under the brand names Aqua Sure and W. WHI is in the process of negotiating a sale of its community systems water disinfection units to the local municipality governments in the Volta Region of Ghana.  WHI is initial discussions with partners in India and Mexico.In the summer of  2002, Tralance Addys venture management company, Plebys International LLC, led a buy-out and restructuring of WHI.  Plebys International LLC subsequently brought WHI through bankruptcy, restructured the ownership from seventy small shareholders to a core group of nine and converted most of the outstanding debt into equity and reconstituted it with $2 MM dollars through a Preferred Series A Shares funding round.  The role of IFC/EOF is to: -  Identify proven technologies that address local environmental  problems in the developing world; and, -  Provide commercial credits and technical assistance to a company that has a capability to cost effectively deliver products and services to address the demand in the market for clean water.  The demand for small scale distributed decentralized systems market is rapidly growing in the developing world, while very few business models have emerged to serve this demand.  We believe WHI is well positioned to pursue this market based on a commercial model, which addresses an environmental problem that has a direct public health benefit in the developing world.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe ERS has been disclosed in Philippines and Ghana:1.) WHI Philippines 4/F HPL Building, 60 Sen. Gil Puyat Avenue, Makati City, Philippines 1200 The public notice was disclosed in the Philippine Star on February 14, 2004 indicating that the ERS is available to the public at the main entrance of WHI Philippines offices. 2.) WHI Ghana , Darko Farms and Company Ltd,, KIA-Accra, Ghana The public notice was disclosed in the Daily Graphic  local newspaper on February 20th, 2004 date indicating that the ERS is available to the public at: (a)  the main entrance of the Sectratariat of the Volta River Authority (VRA) Resettlement Trust Fund, and; (b)  the Main Entrance and also the Public Notice Board of Darko Farms & Company Ltd, who are Local Partners  of WHI.

As a result of its market development initiatives, WHI has already sold and placed more than 300 systems in pilot locations, with a market value of $1.2 MM, through its affiliate partners in several countries, including Mexico and the Philippines.  In October of 2003 WHI formally entered the distributed water service provider market establishing a joint venture with one of its customers in the Philippines, Bendix Sales Corporation.  They have established a joint venture, WaterHealth Philippines, which operates water store franchise under the brand names Aqua Sure and W. WHI is in the process of negotiating a sale of its community systems water disinfection units to the local municipality governments in the Volta Region of Ghana.  WHI is initial discussions with partners in India and Mexico.In the summer of  2002, Tralance Addys venture management company, Plebys International LLC, led a buy-out and restructuring of WHI.  Plebys International LLC subsequently brought WHI through bankruptcy, restructured the ownership from seventy small shareholders to a core group of nine and converted most of the outstanding debt into equity and reconstituted it with $2 MM dollars through a Preferred Series A Shares funding round.  WHIs shareholders include: - Plebys International, LLC 78.46%; - Elwyn Ewald 7.31%; - Johnson and Johnson 5.18%; - Monsanto Corporation 3.23%; - Eric Lemelson 2.84%; - Richard Cortese 1.4%.  In addition, WHI has formed a joint venture with Bendix Sales Corporation in the Philippines called WaterHealth Philippines, Inc.  WaterHealth Philippines shareholders are WHI 65% and Bendix Sales Corporation 35%.
Cost Nature: Total project cost is estimated at approximately $3.2 MM.  The project includes expanding WHIs business through increasing sales and marketing efforts in two strategic markets -- Philippines and Ghana, and to develop and execute market entry strategies for Mexico and/or India.  The primary focus in the first couple of years is to further develop the technology platform to address two key markets: Residential/SME and Community Systems. IFC, through the Environmental Opportunities Facility (EOF) has been requested to provide $1.2 million. The proposed IFC/EOF investment would be made in the form of equity capital.
Location: WHI International is head quartered in Orange County, CA, USA.  It has a joint venture in the Philippines, WHI Philippines, based out of Manila.  WHI has partnership with a Ghanaian partner based in Accra.  The headquarters and regional/joint venture offices are located in commercial buildings in central, downtown areas, and primarily perform administrative, sales and maintenance functions in support of the company''s products and services.  WHI''s manufacturing is done through an OEM manufacturer, Perrin, located in the state of California, USA.

Project Name: Advent Central and Eastern Europe III L.P.
Company Name: ADVENT CENTRAL AND EASTERN EUROPE III LP
Project Description: This project is a proposed IFC investment of up to 15 million in Advent Central and Eastern Europe III L.P. (ACEEIII), a new regional private equity fund managed by Advent International (Advent).   The purpose of the fund is to achieve significant capital appreciation from a portfolio of expansion-stage and buy-out investments in selected countries in Central and Eastern Europe.  The approach of ACEEIII will be two-fold.  One focus will be on industry restructuring through acquisitions, and particularly buy-outs, in a size range that will enable the fund to invest 20-40 million.  The second focus will be on smaller development and expansion opportunities in the 10-20 million range, particularly in second-wave accession countries, which are less-developed in terms of industry restructuring.  ACEEIII follows the proven track records of two predecessor funds (in which IFC has invested), and will be managed by a team whose members, in majority, have worked together for more than six years.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an FI type 2 project.  Advent will be required to ensure that its environmental management system can address the environmental and social management issues associated with ACEEIIIs investment program.  Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor:
The project sponsor and fund manager for ACEEIII is Advent International, founded in 1984 and one of the oldest private equity firms.  Advent is privately-owned, primarily by the firm's founder and members of the management team, and has a global investment team of over 90 professionals from diverse backgrounds including operations, finance and consulting.  Advent has one of the broadest geographic reaches of any private equity player with 14 offices and 10 affiliates in 25 countries.  Globally, Advent has raised over $6 billion in aggregate and has invested in more than 500 companies in many different industries.  In Central and Eastern Europe, Advent was the first private equity firm to establish a truly regional network, and has helped to establish, sponsor and train a number of local fund managers.   Today, Advent has wholly-owned subsidiaries in Poland, Hungary, Romania, and affiliate relationships in Czech Republic and Slovakia, Croatia and Turkey.    

Other investors in ACEEIII are expected to include multilateral and bilateral development institutions as well as international commercial investors.
Cost Nature:
The target fund size for ACEEIII is 300 million.  

The potential IFC investment of up to 15 million represents up to 5% of the target fund size and up to 15% of the target first closing amount of  100 million.
Investment: 17.59 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity17.59* These investment figures are indicative
Location: ACEEIII will be established as a Delaware, U.S., limited partnership, and its investments will focus primarily on the countries  in Central and Eastern Europe where Advent has a local presence, namely: Poland, Hungary, Czech Republic, Slovakia, Romania, and Turkey.  It may also invest selectively in Slovenia, Croatia, Bulgaria, Serbia, Latvia, Lithuania, and Estonia, and, with specific Advisory Board approval , in Russia.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is an FI type 2 project.  Advent will be required to ensure that its environmental management system can address the environmental and social management issues associated with ACEEIIIs investment program.  Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sector: BB - Private Equity/Venture Cap Fund - Regional

Company Name: Shanxi HongAn Coking Technology Co., Ltd.
Project Description:
The project company will be incorporated in China as a foreign-invested joint venture. It will be owned 75% by Shanxi Antai Group Co. Ltd. (Antai, a company listed on the Shanghai Stock Exchange) and 25% by E.K.S. Investments Co., an investment holding company incorporated in Hong Kong SAR.

The project is to establish a 1 million tons per annum export-oriented merchant metallurgical coke production plant at a total cost of $119 million. Coke, made from coal, is a major reactive material for iron smelting and its demand is linked to downstream steel production. IFC is requested to provide a loan of up to $70 million.
Role:
Development Impact: The project supports the restructuring of the coke production sector in which China has a strong comparative advantage. In line with the Chinese government's efforts towards modernizing the industry and phasing out notoriously polluting beehive coke production units, the sponsor intends to substitute sales of coke from such facilities with production from a modern plant under their control. The high impact of this project comes from the sponsor's strong orientation towards an environmentally friendly and sustainable long-term business model. It will further the development of a competitive local company in the interior Shanxi Province of China through increased industrial activity, job creation, and an increase in the direct and indirect demand for goods and services.

IFC Role:  Although there has been a significant increase in credit growth in China recently, private companies still experience difficulty accessing large loans on a long-term basis for projects in the interior of China. The sponsor has the ambition to develop into a globally competitive coke producer. Despite its solid reputation, it operates in a heavy industry in the poorer interior of China and therefore needs IFC's long-term financing which will enable the project to maintain a sound balance sheet. Given its long-term goal of listing the project company abroad, it seeks partnership with IFC not only for the provision of long-term capital but also for IFC's capacity to share best practices in environmental management and corporate governance.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The review of this project consisted of appraising technical and environmental/social information submitted by the project sponsor, as well as site appraisal. Environmental issues include: air emission control; wastewater management; site acquisition and related social impacts; employment opportunities; sustainable coking coal supply; and performance of other local activities owned by the same sponsor company. Further details are provided in the Environmental Review Summary separately available.  Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityJiexiu City Public Library, Jiexiu City, Shanxi Province, Peoples Republic of China.
Sponsor: The sponsor and major shareholder of the project company is Antai. Antai is one of China's six largest  merchant coke suppliers, the majority of which are SOEs, and a small pig iron producer. It is a founder shareholder (with a 0.6% stake) of Minsheng Bank, China's first private bank in which IFC has made a $23.5 million investment for a 1.22% share.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated to be about $119 million. IFC's investment would consist of a loan of up to $70 million.
Investment: 40.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan40.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The new coke plant will be located in in Jiexiu City, Shanxi Province, China

Project Description: Volga Shipping Company (VSC or the company) is one of Russia's largest river and sea shipping companies involved in the transportation of bulk cargo and passengers. VSC was originally founded in 1843. The proposed project will support the financing of the company's vessel renewal program.
Role: The project will play a significant role in attracting investment to a privately owned shipping company and it will contribute to the development of Russia's strategic North-South (Northern Europe to South Asia) transportation corridor. IFC's assistance is important to support VSC's effort to modernize its fleet. IFC will provide affordable long-term financing which is currently difficult to obtain in Russia. In addition, IFC will function as a catalyst by arranging additional financing through its B Loan program.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. The review of this projected consisted of appraising technical and environmental information submitted by the project sponsor, and site visits by IFC staff. The following potential environment, health and safety impacts of the project were analyzed:- Environmental, health and safety management systems;- Vessel safety and pollution control;- Oil/hazardous cargo spill prevention and control;- Shipbuilding/repair yard pollution control and hazardous materials and waste management;- Environmental contamination; and- Employee health and safety.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityVolga Shipping Company 
15A, Markina sq., Nizhny Novgorod, 
603001, Russia
Sponsor: VSC was privatized in 1994. At present, VSC is majority owned (57%) by a Russian individual, owner of  the Corus Group Holdings Ltd. (BVI) and two other Russians, owners of Anhee Resources Inc. (BVI). Corus Group is a diversified company with its main activities including oil trading and transportation, ownership of a network of gas stations, leasing of rail tank cars and shipping. Anhee Resources is primarily involved in maritime shipping and ship management in Russia and abroad. The remaining shares are held with the Government of Russia (25.5%) and small individual shareholders, including present and former employees of the company.
Cost Nature: The IFC supported project includes the construction of up to 8 new 5,190 dead weight ton ('dwt') dry-cargo river and sea vessels  for about $65 million. The proposed IFC investment involves an A Loan for IFC's own account of up to $27 million and a syndicated B Loan of up to $20 million.
Investment: 27.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan27.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: VSC is headquartered in Nizhny Novgorod, a city of 1.5 million people and a large industrial center located on the crossroads of major north-south and east-west multi-modal transportation routes. The Volga Basin (Volga River plus tributaries) occupies an area of 1,380 square km with a total population of over 40 million people. At present, VSC is an integrated river and short-sea shipping company with a total fleet (operational plus laid-up) of over 300 vessels active in international and domestic trade and passenger transportation.

Project Name: Procesadora Nacional de Alimentos C.A. - PRONACA
Company Name: PROCESADORA NACIONAL DE ALIMENTOS C.A. PRONACA
Project Description: Procesadora Nacional de Alimentos C.A.-PRONACA (Pronaca or the comany) is a fully-integrated poultry and pork processor. IFC will provide financing for Pronaca to construct a new distribution center in Guayaquil and expand storage facilities in its Quito distribution center; upgrade the environmental standards of its farms and slaughterhouses, refinance short-term debt; and acquire a local company in the packaged meats sector.
Role:
Pronaca is the largest private employer in Ecuador. The project will allow Pronaca to increase distribution volume, thus generating significant benefits through linkages. Pronaca's distribution of additional volumes and larger portfolio of products are expected to provide its more than 60 independent wholesale distributors with the opportunity to increase profits. 

Pronaca has led the way in the sector in terms of progress towards compliance with pre-existing Ecuadorian regulatory requirements for wastewater management. Pronaca's current investment to comply with stringent new regulations is expected to have a strong demonstration effect.

IFC will play a role in supporting a locally-owned company by providing long-term finance that is not readily available. IFC is providing technical expertise to assist Pronaca in its continuing efforts to reduce costs and further improve its environmental standards.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The review of this project included a physical visit to selected, representative swine and poultry rearing facilities, principal slaughter and animal processing operations in Santo Domingo and Bucay, and an evaluation of technical and environmental/social information submitted by the project sponsor. Pronaca currently commercializes leading  brands such as Mr. Pollo (poultry), Mr. Chancho (pork), and Fritz (sausages). Pronaca is owned by private local investors. Pronaca owns and operates pork and broiler farms, hatcheries, processing plants, feed mills, and distribution centers across Ecuador. All the company's food processing plants have HACCP quality assurance systems and certifications, which is the international standard for food safety.

Project Description:
The Poteza Fund is a closed-end private equity fund formed to make equity and equity-related investments, through majority or controlling stakes, in companies based in southeastern Europe (the Region).  Bosnia-Herzegovina, Croatia, Serbia, and Slovenia are the primary target countries for investment.  In addition, up to 20% of the fund's capital may be invested in Montenegro, FYR Macedonia, Bulgaria, and Romania.

The objective of the fund is to achieve capital appreciation through active management of a diversified portfolio of companies with high growth potential in the Region.  An average investment size of 5 million is expected.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an FI Type 2 project.  The Fund Manager will be required to undertake an environmental review of each sub-project.  IFC will assess the Fund Managers capability to carry out such reviews.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: Poteza Nalozbe d.o.o. (Poteza), the sponsor of Poteza Adriatic Fund B.V. (Poteza Fund, the Fund or the company), is part of the Poteza Group, an established financial institution in Slovenia.  Between 1992 and 2002, the Poteza Group developed a successful track record investing its own capital in private equity transactions in Slovenia.  In addition to private equity, the Group is active in brokerage services (which was the Group's first business established in 1989), investment banking and asset management.  Poteza has committed 15% of the Fund's total capital commitments.
Cost Nature: The Fund's target size is 75 million.  The proposed IFC investment is up to 11.25 million, for up to 15% of the Fund's total capital commitments.
Investment: 13.68 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity13.68* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The Fund has been formed as a limited liability company (B.V.) in the Netherlands.  The Fund is collectively managed by Poteza Capital Management B.V. and Cielo Azul N.V. (the Fund Manager).  The Fund Manager retains a local advisory team in Ljubljana, Slovenia.  New offices are planned in Belgrade, Serbia & Montenegro and in Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina.

Project Description:
ProCredit Bank in Ukraine (ProCredit, Bank or the company) began operations in March 2001 as Microfinance Bank of Ukraine with the guiding principle of establishing itself as a leader in providing credit and financial services to individual entrepreneurs, micro and small enterprises (MSEs) across Ukraine.  The objective of the investment is to provide ProCredit with the necessary financing to support the rapid growth of its loan portfolio.  

The Bank officially changed its name to ProCredit Bank on October 20, 2003.  The name change is part of an overall marketing strategy by IMI to strengthen its network of microfinance institutions (MFIs) in Eastern Europe under a common corporate identity by linking it to a -strong-universal-bank-image- for the target group.  The transformation has been well received by the Ukrainian media, customers and staff.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an  FI Type 1 project.  ProCredit Bank must maintain an environmental management system to ensure that investments under relevant operations meet host country environmental, health and safety requirements and are consistent with IFCs microfinance exclusion list.  Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Cost Nature: The project involves an IFC credit line of up to $8.5 million to ProCredit Bank.

Location: ProCredit Bank is located in Kiev, Ukraine with fourteen branches and outlets with plans to grow to 25 by end 2004.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is an  FI Type 1 project.  ProCredit Bank must maintain an environmental management system to ensure that investments under relevant operations meet host country environmental, health and safety requirements and are consistent with IFCs microfinance exclusion list. Project Description:
Construtora Norberto Odebrecht (CNO or the company), founded in 1945 in the northeastern state of Bahia, Brazil, is one of the leading Brazilian heavy construction and engineering company in Latin America, and the world leader in hydroelectric dam engineering.  Geographically, CNO undertakes projects in all regions of Brazil as well as in South America, Central America, Portugal, the United States and Angola.  CNO is a subsidiary of Odebrecht S.A. (ODB), one of the ten largest Brazilian private-sector conglomerates in terms of revenues and Brazil's leading service exporter, employing almost 30,000 workers.  Since it was founded in 1945, CNO has expanded its operations into 13 countries in Africa, Europe, and the Americas.

The project consists of a corporate loan of up to $25 million to support the development of CNO's small and medium enterprises (SMEs) suppliers and subcontractors in Brazil, Venezuela, Peru, Ecuador and Dominican Republic and other Latin American countries where the company currently has operations or is expected to win contracts in the near future (the countries). It will help CNO fund its prepayment financing (advances) to SMEs and will also have a strong capacity-building component, leading to a long-term cooperation and partnership between the SMEs and CNO, including the provision of direct or indirect technical assistance to the SMEs to help introduce financial, environmental, health and safety, social and engineering best practices.
Role:
The project is expected to achieve the following objectives in terms of development impact: 

- expand SME financing in the countries where SME's direct access to finance is very limited; and 
- build upon existing supplier linkages to strengthen the SMEs through technology transfer and other best practices such as labor training, and environmental and financial management from CNO.  

The project would enable CNO to leave its (footprint) in each of their job sites where SMEs are present.  

IFC's role in this project includes: 

-  supporting the growth in Brazil's infrastructure by strengthening the industry's key players and SMEs concentrated around those construction and infrastructure projects developed by CNO, who is also IFC's existing client; 
-  reach the SME sector by using CNO as the corporate intermediary allowing it to leverage its extensive experience of working with its suppliers and therefore reducing transaction costs; and 
-  help CNO formalize procedures for screening SMEs and transfer technology and other best practices to its suppliers and subcontractors.
Environmental Social Issues:
CNO will develop an environmental management system to ensure that the SMEs using the facility meet host country environmental requirements and, if applicable World Bank Group safeguard policies.  CNO will also prepare and submit to IFC an annual environmental performance report about the operations of the facility with the financed SMEs. Project Description: Transierra S.A. (Transierra or the company) is a private Bolivian company that constructed and operates the Gasoducto Yacuiba Rio Grande (Gasyrg) pipeline that transports gas extracted from the San Alberto and San Antonio fields for further export to Brazil through the Bolivia-Brazil pipeline (Gasbol).  The project consists of financing the 2002-2004 investment program of Transierra and increasing the capacity of the Gasyrg pipeline by means of a first compressor station.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The review of this project consisted of appraising technical and environmental /social information submitted by the project sponsor.  The following potential environment, health and safety and social impacts of the projects were analyzed.-  The companys capacity to review and manage projects in accordance with World Bank groups environmental and social safeguard policies;-  Liquid and solid waste disposal and management;-  Contamination of the site(s) from past or current operations on or off-site;-  Natural habitats;-  Occupational health and safety including fire protection and emergency response;-  Public consultation and disclosure programs;-  Indigenous peoples development plans;-  Compensation and land use for easements and right-of-way (ROW); and-  Community relations and development programs.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityTransierra S.A.

Sponsor:
Transierra S.A., headquartered in Santa Cruz, Bolivia, is a private company established on November 8, 2000 under Bolivian law in order to increase transportation capacity for the gas extracted from the San Alberto and San Antonio gas fields.  On December 14, 2001, the Superintendency of Hydrocarbons granted the Company a non-exclusive concession for the construction and 40-year operation of a new 432 km feeder pipeline from Yacuiba, province of Tarija, to Rio Grande, province of Santa Cruz de la Sierra.  Transierra now operates the Gasyrg pipeline, which began operating in April of 2003.  The capacity of the pipeline system was increased from initially 11 MMcmd to 17 MMcmd in January 2004 through the completion of construction of a first compressor station in Villamontes. 

Transierra is owned 44.5% by Empresa Petrolera Andina S.A., a 50% owned affiliated company of Repsol YPF S.A., 44.5% by Petrobrás Bolivia S.A., a wholly owned affiliated company of Petróleo Brasileiro S.A., and 11% by Total E & P Bolivie S.A.  Sucursal Bolivia, a Bolivian branch of a company wholly owned by Total S.A.  These shareholders of Transierra are also involved as producers in the joint venture developments of the San Alberto and San Antonio gas fields that supply the gas transported by the Gasyrg pipeline.
Cost Nature: The estimated project cost is $409 million. The proposed IFC investment consists of an A loan for IFC's own account in the amount of $50 million and a syndicated B loan in the amount of $100 million.
Investment: 50.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan50.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The Gasyrg pipeline is 432 kilometer in length, 32 inches in diameter and is buried along its entire length.  It begins in Yacuiba, province of Tarija near the Argentine and Paraguayan border, transporting gas north from the San Antonio and San Alberto gas fields to the Rio Grande, province of Santa Cruz de la Sierra, where it feeds into the Gasbol pipeline to Brazil.  The system is operated remotely from Santa Cruz de la Sierra, the headquarters of Transierra S.A.

The following potential environment, health and safety and social impacts of the projects were analyzed.-  The companys capacity to review and manage projects in accordance with World Bank groups environmental and social safeguard policies;-  Liquid and solid waste disposal and management;-  Contamination of the site(s) from past or current operations on or off-site;-  Natural habitats;-  Occupational health and safety including fire protection and emergency response;-  Public consultation and disclosure programs;-  Indigenous peoples development plans;-  Compensation and land use for easements and right-of-way (ROW); and-  Community relations and development programs.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityTransierra S.A.

Project Description: The aim of the Environmental Business Finance Program (EBFP) is to create a sustainable market for GEF- eligible Small and Medium Enterprise (SME) activities and projects that target the GEF focal areas of climate change, biodiversity, land degradation and persistent organic pollutants.  Through proactive market development, technical assistance and financing support, the EBFP will seek to engage Financial Intermediaries (FIs) to service the GEF-eligible SME market and demonstrate that profitable investment opportunities exist. The EBFP will work with FIs to introduce best practice SME finance tools and training, as well as with SMEs to build local capacity to develop and support viable business plans. The EBFP will proactively develop the GEF-eligible SME market through market assessments, know-how sharing and best practice dissemination, as well as through activities that expand market size and scope, and raise consumer awareness.  In addressing the key obstacles (lack of access to financing, limited capacity and a weak supportive environment), the EBFP aims to create a market for sustainable, mainstream GEF-eligible SMEs. Note:  the EBFP defines GEF eligible as those activities that target one or more of the Global Environment Facility focal areas of biodiversity, climate change, land degradation and POPs.Note: SMEs are defined in accordance with the definition of the World Bank Groups (WBG) SME Department, as follows: micro-enterprises up to 10 employees and total assets or total annual revenues of up to $100,000; small enterprises up to 50 employees and total assets or total revenues of up to $3 million, and medium enterprises up to 300 employees and total assets or total annual revenues of up to $15 million. For the purposes of the EBFP the definition of SME includes micro-enterprises.) The EBFP will be implemented in ten to twelve countries through programs that will be specifically developed for each country. There will be two types of country programs:-  large country programs and -  small country programsThe large country programs are intended for countries where there is a market for a range of types of activities, for instance those covering more than two operational programs (OPs). The small country programs are intended for countries where there is a limited set of activities that can be targeted, for instance those covering just one or two OPs. In addition to country programs, the EBFP will be developing smaller stand-alone interventions which focus on one activity or one intermediary, in up to another ten countries. This particular aspect of the program will focus on non-traditional intermediaries such as the existing clients of the SME Program as well as GEF-eligible medium-sized enterprises or NGOs in countries where there is no specific country program.  Where an activity stands to have a significant impact on a particular sector, or if the enterprise or NGO is working with a particularly innovative approach, the EBFP would consider providing direct financing on the basis of the global environmental benefits to be generated.
Environmental Social Issues: Not applicable.  The EBFP project itself does not have an environment categorization.  However, the individual projects undertaken  through the EBFP will be categorized and subject to appropriate environmental and social requirements.  All projects undertaken by the EBFP must meet IFCs environmental and social standards.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: EBFP is a facility which will engage in country and individual programs.  It does not have a sponsor or major shareholder.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $100 million. The financing plan is detailed as follows:GEF Funding:                                                                                                                                                        $20Expected financing from commercial sources (including IFC):                                                                            $70Co-funding for Technical Assistance (Donor organizations co-funding or complementary projects):               $10
Location: The project has a global scope.  Countries will be selected for an EBFP program based on eligibility criteria.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: Not applicable.  The EBFP project itself does not have an environment categorization.  However, the individual projects undertaken  through the EBFP will be categorized and subject to appropriate environmental and social requirements.  All projects undertaken by the EBFP must meet IFCs environmental and social standards.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community

Project Description:
The project comprises of up to $50.0 million subordinated loan to Banque Internationale Arabe de Tunisie (BIAT or the bank). BIAT is the largest private bank and the third largest bank in Tunisia in terms of asset size ($2.3 billion) and equity ($186 million). BIAT operates as a full-service bank, offering corporate/SME banking services as well as consumer banking through a network of 100 branches and 72 ATM's.  Founded through the merger in April 1976 of the local branch operations of the British Bank of the Middle East and of the French bank Société Marseillaise de Crédit, it is listed on the Tunis and London (through GDRs). BIAT is characterized by a widely diversified ownership. European and Arab banks together hold about 28% of BIAT's shares, Tunisian institutions almost 26%, and private Tunisian investors the remainder. 

BIAT's capitalization-- although adequate by Tunisian standards, with a BIS solvency ratio of 9%, exceeding the minimum Tunisian regulatory requirement of 8%--is on a declining trend.  With loan growth expected to continue at over 10%, in line with BIAT's market-share objectives, there is a critical need for  BIAT to enhance its equity to meet its growing volume of activity.  IFC's loan will partially meet this need.  IFC's proposed subordinated loan is expected to count as Tier II capital and will bolster BIAT's capital base and facilitate its growth particularly in the consumer and SME segments. More importantly, the proposed transaction is expected to serve as an enabling element for Tunisian banks as it will represent the first Tier II capital instrument to be introduced in the sector.
Role:
The project will have the following impacts on development:

-  Impact on Customers: 
the proposed loan will allow BIAT to provide new products and additional loans to existing clients, particularly to SMEs, as well as expand in the more profitable consumer and personal banking area.  Customers will therefore benefit from increased access to financing sources possibility at competitive rates. 

-  Impact on Financial Sector: 
BIAT is considered the most sophisticated Tunisian bank. It is the leading customer-deposit collector through product innovation and sophisticated marketing.  By expanding its presence in the market, BIAT is likely to improve practices and standards in the financial sector. Considering that the proposed IFC loan will be the first tier 2 capital instruments in the sector, the project is expected to introduce a new funding class to the market that can be replicated by other Tunisian banks with capital adequacy constraints. 

Impact on the Economy: The successful implementation of BIAT's development strategy will achieve the following results:

-  promote lending in the economy 
-  develop financial intermediation by increasing the depositor base and 
-  underpin the overall growth in the economy, as higher loan volumes will benefit customers, suppliers and new entrants. 

The three key developmental indicators to be monitored will be:

-  the number of loans originated by BIAT; 
-  the increase of its depositor base and 
-  the diffusion of best practices in the financial sector. 

IFC Role: 

This IFC transaction is expected to 

-  help improve the financial fundamentals of the bank by increasing capital adequacy ratios 
-  support BIAT's in its diversification strategy into the consumer lending market and the growth of its loan book, and 
-  lead the way for other financial institutions to access the subordinated debt market by launching a landmark transaction in Tunisia, representing the first Tier 2 instrument in the banking sector
Environmental Social Issues: This is an FI Type 1 project.  BIAT must establish and maintain an environmental management system to ensure that investments under relevant operations meet host country environmental, health and safety requirements and are consistent with IFCs exclusion list.  IFC will asses BIATs ability to carry out environmental reviews and if need be, will work with the bank to develop the capacity to meet these requirements.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: The sponsor of the project is Banque Internationale Arabe de Tunisie (BIAT). BIAT was  established in early 1976 by a group of investors composed of local institutions and individuals, and Arab and European banks, who acquired the domestic branches of the British Bank of the Middle East and Société Marseillaise de Crédit.  In its early years, BIAT expanded rapidly, and in the 1980s it had become the largest private bank in Tunisia. IFC involvement with BIAT goes back to 1998 when it underwrote the first international equity offering in Tunisian in the form a GDR  in which IFC invested (currently holding 1.13%).   BIAT is considered the most sophisticated Tunisian bank. It is the leading customer-deposit collector through product innovation and sophisticated marketing. Historically the Bank had a strong involvement with domestic corporates and SME's which it is now complementing with new developments in the more profitable consumer/personal banking. This developmental strategy should help the bank broaden its large deposit base, diversify its sources of income, reduce its average risk per customer, and report higher profitability. Overall, BIAT enjoys a strong market franchise among its clients as evidenced by a stable market share of about 11% of loans and 15% of deposits over the past four years.
Cost Nature: IFC's investment will be in the form of subordinated loan (C Loan) for up to $50 million to BIAT.  The loan will be structured to meet the regulatory requirements for a Tier 2 capital as per Central Bank of Tunisia (CBT) guidelines.

IFC will asses BIATs ability to carry out environmental reviews and if need be, will work with the bank to develop the capacity to meet these requirements.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Company Name: COMPANHIA DE GAS DE SAO PAULO
Project Description:
Comgas is the largest natural gas distribution company in Brazil, with a network of 3,250 km of pipelines covering 41 municipalities in the State of Sao Paulo, and reaching over 400,000 residential, commercial and industrial consumers.  Comgas' predecessor companies date to 1872, with its present operations beginning with privatization in April 1999.  Comgas was acquired by a consortium consisting primarily of British Gas and Shell Groups.  The company aims to expand the use of natural gas as a cheaper, more environmentally-friendly option than alternative fuels, such as coal, fuel oil or liquefied petroleum gas (LPG).  

Comgas operates under a 30-year concession to distribute natural gas  covering  177 municipalities in Sao Paulo state.  Metropolitan Region of Sao Paulo.  The concession contract establishes expansion goals for the company, which include achieving 70,000 additional customers and 400 kilometers of new networks within the first 5-year period and a total of 200,000 additional customers within 10 years.  

Comgas is also active in the promotion of natural gas for vehicles (NGVs), which offer savings of up to 70 % over gasoline and emit less pollution.  This commitment includes the operation of nearly 200 NGV filling stations and the conversion of over 100,000 vehicles by the end of 2004.  The company expects to reach 200,000 converted vehicles by 2008.

Comgas obtains its gas supplies from two geographical sources  Bolivia, via the Bolivia-to-Brazil (BTB) transmission pipeline, and offshore Brazil, by the GASAN/GASPAL transmission pipelines from the Santos/Campos Basins.
Role:
IFC funding will allow Comgás to continue to implement projects with a substantial development impact. A strong factor that encourages industries to start up in or relocate to the São Paulo region is the increasing availability of natural gas. It is expected that São Paulo will continue to attract new industries as the Comgás network is expanded to new industrial areas envisaged under the project. The economies of scale generated by operating in close proximity to the significant market represented by São Paulo's 24 million population are also important. This combination of economies of scale and the availability of gas (at the right price) will be a powerful magnet drawing enterprises to the region.  Also, the expansion of the gas distribution network will increase economic activity due to requirement for domestically manufactured goods, as well as lead to an increased requirement for construction jobs.

IFC support will strengthen Comgás as a company that proactively seeks to promote community development programs, including the Comgás Apprentice program, the Corporate Volunteering, and the Environmental Education and Social Programs. The expansion of the company's operations to new areas under the project is expected to result in the expansion of the Comgás social development programs accordingly. The expansion of the Comgás distribution network also carries important safety benefits. The inherent physical characteristics of natural gas give it a higher ignition point, and a higher required concentration for an explosion, than either gasoline or LPG thereby reducing the risk of a catastrophic accident.

The continuous distribution of natural gas through the pipeline by a safety-conscious company such as Comgás, reduces risks associated with accidents in the transport of LPG cylinders, and eliminates the need for storage facilities. Comgás will also widen access of natural gas to more lower income consumers than at present, that will derive benefit from the avoided cost in terms of time and in the handling and change-out of LPG cylinders and the increased convenience of natural gas. Natural gas is the cleanest burning of all the fossil fuels, and environmental benefits include large reductions of nitrogen oxide, carbon monoxide, sulfur dioxide, and total organic emissions compared to emissions from combustion of fuel oil commonly used in São Paulo. Consequently, environmental benefits and a lower contribution to greenhouse gas generation will result from further development of the gas market by Comgás. In time the substitution of diesel in the heavy vehicle transport sector may also provide significant pollution reduction benefits. Other benefits accrue from the cast iron mains replacement where leakage is reduced (natural gas itself being a greenhouse gas).

Comgás is an exceptional candidate for IFC support as a key player in facilitating the expansion and consolidation of the gas distribution system in the state of São Paulo.  The natural gas distribution industry, due to regulatory controls, is typically characterized by relatively long pay-back periods and moderate financial rates of return, which substantially underestimate its very important economic and environmental benefits.  Appropriate long-term financing is essential for such projects.  Since its inception in 1999, Comgás has been able to partly finance its network expansion through a combination of medium and short-term financing of five years or less in maturity.  

IFC's funding would enable Comgás to continue with its expansion plan with a more stable financing structure.   IFC would also be mobilizing substantial international commercial bank financing which would otherwise not be available.  As such, the company lacks access to the more traditional longer-term debt or capital market financing normally available to larger gas distribution companies under more favorable macroeconomic conditions.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Environmental and social review of this project consisted of appraising information submitted by the project sponsor and a report prepared by a technical consultant to IFC.  This review addressed the compliance status of Comgas'' current operations, including right-of-way alignment and land acquisition, and how liabilities such as land contamination and labor obligations associated with pre-privatization operations are managed.  Comgas'' management system for the  environmental, social, and safety aspects of its current and future operations was reviewed, as well as its corporate social responsibility and community development programs.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityComgas administrative office

Sponsor:
In 1872, the (British) São Paulo Gas Company was licensed to distribute piped gas in São Paulo city, mainly for street lighting.  In 1912 the company was acquired by the Canadian Company, Light, which over the next 40 years extended the customer base to include residential, commercial and industrial consumers.  In 1959 the company was nationalized and renamed Companhia Paulista de Serviços de Gás.  In 1968 a joint stock company (Companhia Municipal de Gás (Comgás)) was incorporated and control was assumed by the city authorities.  The company name was changed in 1974 to Companhia de Gas de São Paulo, the shareholding being acquired in 1984 by Companhia Energética de São Paulo  CESP  which managed it until privatization in 1999.

In 1997, 15% of the company was offered for auction and sold to Shell do Brasil, and two years later the company was offered for auction and acquired for R$1.65 billion (equivalent to approximately $1 billion at the time) by a consortium comprising BG and Shell.  

The company's registered share capital is R$244,783,305.18, comprising a total of 11,982,279,687 shares, with around 78% of these being common shares with voting rights and 21% preference shares without voting rights 

Some 14% of the preferred shares are held by Integral Investments BV (the BG (95%) and Shell (5%) investment vehicle in Comgás,) and the remainder are publicly listed. The preferred shares attract priority in liquidation, and convey rights to participate in capital increases and to receive a dividend 10% higher than common shares. Currently, the ownership of the company, in terms of voting rights associated with shareholdings, is the following in percentages:

British Gas				72.74 
Shell					23.72 
Publicly listed				  4.04
