Project Description:
Modern Asia Environmental Holdings Inc. (MAEH), a waste management company based in Southeast Asia, offers modern, environmentally and technologically sound waste management services for the safe disposal and reuse of urban and industrial waste in Indonesia and Thailand. MAEH operates the only site in existence in Indonesia that offers international caliber hazardous waste treatment and disposal services, and is one of the few operators in Thailand that provides non-hazardous industrial waste services to these same standards. MAEH contracts directly with waste generators, who are typically industrial and commercial clients, to collect, transport, recycle, treat and dispose of their wastes. In Indonesia, MAEH also provides on-site remediation services for large industrial clients, particularly in the oil and gas industry.

MAEH intends to expand its industrial waste services business in Thailand and Indonesia and pursue new opportunities in the  Philippines, Malaysia and other countries in the Asia region. The expansion will take place via MAEH equity investments in and company loans to MAEH subsidiaries located in target countries. IFC would support MAEH's growth plans with long-term debt on a corporate basis.
Environmental Social Issues:
MAEH designs, constructs, and operates its facilities and performs related waste management activities to meet best international practice.  As the first company in the rapidly growing East Asia region to provide industrial waste generators with integrated, responsible waste management and recycling services, it offers assurances to its customers, government, and the population at large that wastes are properly handled, treated, and disposed from cradle-to-grave.  MAEH has presented plans to address the environmental and social issues associated with its operations, including: facility siting and licensing; waste collection and transport; waste receiving, storage and materials recovery; chemical stabilization; fuels blending and thermal destruction emissions; landfill disposal and groundwater quality; stormwater runoff and control, wastewater/leachate treatment, and surface water quality; air quality controls, including dust, odor and gas generation; closure and post-closure care; emergency preparedness and response; environmental management systems; employee health and safety; and community development and impacts.  Upon implementation of specific measures, MAEH will comply with applicable host country regulatory requirements, international environmental standards, World Bank environmental and social policies, and IFC Environmental, Health and Safety Guidelines for Waste Management Facilities.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityWaste Management Siam

Sponsor:
MAEH is a private company registered in Mauritius with operating subsidiaries in Thailand and Indonesia. Its shareholders include:

-  Global Environment Emerging Markets Fund II, LP (GEEMF II), a private equity fund, with a 72% equity share. GEEMF II was launched in 1997 with $120 million in funding, including a loan from the Overseas Private Investment Corporation (OPIC).

-  Thai Recovery Fund (TRF), which holds 18.5% of MAEH's equity. TRF is a $50 million equity fund set up by Asian Development Bank, Kreditanstalt für Wiederaufbau (KfW), Japan Bank for International Cooperation (JBIC) and State Street Corporation in 2001 to invest in Thai companies that are undergoing expansion or restructuring.

-  Modern Asia Environmental Company Ltd., represented by Mr. Edward Corcoran, a waste management industry veteran, holds 9.5% of MAEH.
Cost Nature: The total expansion program for the years 2004-2007 is estimated at $34.7 million in 2004 dollars. IFC would provide an A loan of up to $15 million for its own account, including $5 million on a standby basis.  MAEH would finance the balance from internal cash flow and cash resources from a 2003 equity round.
Investment: 15.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan15.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Proceeds of IFC's corporate loan would be invested by MAEH in existing subsidiaries, acquisitions and greenfield investments in the ASEAN region. MAEH's existing operational facilities include the Eastern Seaboard Environmental Complex (ESBEC), which is a non-hazardous industrial waste processing facility in Chonburi Industrial Estate, Thailand, and Prasadha Pamunah Limbah Industri (PPLi), a hazardous waste processing facility south of Jakarta, Indonesia. Both facilities would be upgraded/expanded as part of the project. In addition, MAEH would invest in additional transfer stations in both Thailand and Indonesia to increase volume flows to ESBEC and PPLi and expand the Company's geographic reach. New ventures to be financed as part of the project may include a greenfield solid waste management complex at a site to be determined in the Philippines and a waste-to-steam pilot project inside the Bangpoo Industrial Estate, Thailand. The Bangpoo project is being conducted under the auspices of the Industrial Estates Authority of Thailand with support from NEDO (the National Energy Development Organization of Japan).

Project Description:
Lebedyansky Experimental Cannery (Lebedyansky or the company) is one of the leading Russian juice and nectars manufacturers. Established in 1967, Lebedyansky (located in Lebedyan, Lipetsk region about 360km South of Moscow), produces fruit purees and concentrates from locally grown fruits, natural fruit juices, nectars, fruit drinks, and canned baby food under several well-established brands. Lebedyansky supplies markets in Russia, Ukraine, Kazakhstan and Belarus.

Lebedyansky is undertaking an expansion project to: 

-  modernize and rationalize Lebedyansky's production facilities; 
-  add new capacity in its core juice and nectars business, 
-  introduce new glass and plastic PET packaging, 
-  improve distribution by acquiring a distribution terminal in the Moscow region, and 
-  diversify its product portfolio via acquisitions of new businesses.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityEnvironmental documents are available for public review at the Lebedyansky hotel reception located in Lebedyan, ul. Marksa 50.
Sponsor: Lebedyansky is owned by Nikolay Bortsov (57%) and his son Yury Bortsov (43%). Nikolay Bortsov, 58 years old, has had a life-long career in the food industry, spanning technical and executive positions and was appointed in 1981as General Director of Lebedyansky, a flagship fruit processing company in the Soviet Union. In 2002, he was elected a Deputy to the Lipetsk Region Duma. Yury Bortsov, 33 years old son of Nikolai Bortsov, joined Lebedyansky soon after he graduated from a university in early 1990's.  He holds the titles of both the Deputy General Director and the Chairman of the Board.
Cost Nature: Total project cost is estimated at $87.3 million. The proposed IFC investments is an A loan for IFC's own account of up to $35 million.

Location:
The project is located on the existing site of the Lebedyansky cannery located in the town of Lebedyan, Lipetsk region and its 100% owned subsidiary Progress, also in the Lipetsk region. Production facilities are state of the art, including equipment from Tetrapak. Both sites have own land, adequate rail and road connection as well as utilities. Electricity is supplied from the grid and gas for steam production at own boilers is supplied via pipeline. Both sites use water wells supplying adequate water quality. The company also has four own sales branches covering the whole territory of the Russian Federation: 

-  Moscow area, 
-  the North West (St. Petersburg), 
-  the Urals (Yekaterinburg) and 
-  Siberia (Novosibirsk).

Project Description:
Ege Liman Isletmeleri A.S, (Ege Ports) is a special purpose Turkish company specifically incorporated to operate a cruise ship terminal in Kusadasi (the Kusadasi Port) under a 30-year concession granted by the Government of Turkey (GOT) in July 2003 following a competitive bidding process.  Kusadasi Port is the largest cruise ship terminal in Turkey and is a popular port of call on cruises that originate in Greece, Italy, France, Spain and Turkey.  Ege Ports offers the following basic services to ships calling at the port:  
-  tugging, 
-  pilotage, 
-  sheltering, 
-  clean water supply, 
-  disposal of solid waste, 
-  underwater diving inspection, and 
-  fuel supply.

The proposed project comprises the operation and expansion of the Kusadasi Port, including the financing of the $24.3 million concession payment to the GOT;  construction of a new passenger terminal;  extension of the existing berths and purchase of equipment necessary for carrying out operations of the Kusadasi Port.  The proposed project will bring Kusadasi Port operations into compliance with the International Port and Facility Security (ISPS) Code.
Role:
The development impact of the project would be substantial.  The major revenue earner in Kusadasi is tourism and the main asset in this regard is the Kusadasi Port.  The privatization of Kusadasi Port will ensure, through more efficient operation; enhanced security; and a focused marketing program internationally, long-term economic growth of various local small businesses in Kusadasi which depend on the cruise ship traffic.  In addition, efficient and effective management of the Port will attract additional cruise lines to make Kusadasi their port of choice.  The revenue generated by tourism in the region is essential for the ongoing maintenance and development of the areas' historic sites.  The main tourism destination for passengers from the cruise ships arriving at the Port of Kusadasi is Ephesus and the surrounding area.  Hence, the links between the successful operation of the Port and the development of Kusadasi and the Ephesus area are very strong.  Furthermore, the proposed project would ensure that the port is operated in an environmentally sound manner.

IFC's investment in the proposed project would provide long-term financing necessary for a concession-based project at a reasonable cost.  In this context, IFC will also help catalyze long-term financing from a financial institution(s) through the B loan.  Long-term limited recourse financing is practically nonexistent in Turkey from either domestic or foreign sources.  This was evidenced by the cancellation of the first concession granting process due to the winning bidder's inability to raise financing.  In order for the GOT's privatization program to be successful, private sector companies need to be able to raise long-term financing.  The proposed project is the first major cruise ship port privatization in Turkey and its successful financing would also have a strong demonstration effect on potential investors in other privatizations of other ports in Turkey.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental, social and cultural impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The review of this project consisted of appraising technical, environmental, social and cultural information submitted by the project sponsor, as well as site visits to the Kusadasi Port and to the nearby town of Selcuk where Ephesus is located.  The following potential environment, health and safety, social and cultural impacts of the projects were analyzed.-  Pollution control and waste management;-  Fuel handling and emergency response;-  Employee health and safety;-  EHS management systems; and- Cultural and archeological heritage.Ege Ports has presented plans to address these impacts to ensure that the proposed project will, upon implementation of the specific agreed  measures, comply with the EHS and social requirements and Turkish country laws and regulations and the IFC environment, social and cultural policies and the environmental, health and safety guidelines.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityEnvironmental documents will be made available at the following locations:

-  Ege Ports' office located at the Kusadasi Port, 09400 Kusadasi  Aydin, Turkey.
-  The offices of the Municipality of Kusadasi.
Sponsor:
The description of the project sponsors and their shareholding of Ege Ports is as follows:

Shareholders:
Royal Caribbean Cruises Limited at  27.5%
Akfen Holding A.S at                         25.0%
Avrasya Yatirim Holding A .S            20.0%
Ege Ticaret Limited Sti                      20.0%
Marvel Investments S.A.                     7.5%


-  Royal Caribbean Cruises, Ltd. ('RCCL') 

was established in 1969 under the name Royal Caribbean Cruise Lines by three Norwegian shipping companies.  In 1993, the shares of RCCL were listed on the New York Stock Exchange (symbol RCL), and currently RCCL is the second largest cruise operator in the world.  The Company operates under the Royal Caribbean International and Celebrity Cruises brands with a fleet of 25 modern cruise ships, and a passenger capacity of approximately 53,000.  RCCL has a market share of 25% of the global cruise industry.  In addition to cruise ship operations, RCCL has invested in and operates several cruise ship terminals in the U.S. and Mexico.
 
Akfen Holding A.S. ('Akfen') 

is one of the major construction groups in Turkey.  In addition to its core construction business, Akfen Group has business interests in various industries including tourism, foreign trade, insurance brokerage, and natural gas distribution.  Established in 1976, Akfen Group currently operates through 8 companies and 12 subsidiaries.  Since 2000, Akfen has been a 49% shareholder in TAV, which in October 1997, was awarded a 3 year 9 month (after completion) concession for the expansion and management of the Ataturk International Airport in Istanbul.

-  Avrasya Yatirim Holding A.S. ('Avrasya'), 

founded in 1998, is a holding company, which has interests in several companies in Turkey operating in the finance, information technology and fast food sectors.  

-  Ege Ticaret Limited Sti. 

is a special purpose Turkish company established specifically for the Kusadasi Port investment.  The company is wholly owned by Mr. Erol Goker, a Turkish businessman.

-  Marvel Investments S.A. ('Marvel'), 

a Liberian company with its headquarters in Athens, is an investment company established specifically for the Kusadasi Port investment.  The owner of Marvel, Mr. Erkunt Oner, owns Tura Turizm & Seamer Tours, a travel and shipping agency which he founded in 1966.   Tura Turizm is the tour agent for RCCL in Turkey.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $29.3 million.  The proposed project consists of an A loan of up to $10 million and an equity investment of up to $0.5 million, both for the account of IFC, and a B loan of up to $8 million for the account of participants
Investment: 10.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan10.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location:
The Kusadasi Port is located in the city of Kusadasi which is situated on the west coast of Turkey in the southern Aegean Sea, 90 kms south of Izmir.  Kusadasi is known as one of the most attractive cities in the Aegean region, and is only about 20 kms from the Greco/Roman City of Ephesus, the site of the Temple of Artemis (one of the wonders of the ancient world), the Basilica of Saint John (where Saint John is buried), the Isa Bey Mosque and the Museum of Selçuk.  In the nearby hills lies Merymana, reputed to be the place where the Virgin Mary died and a place of pilgrimage for Christians.  The area has numerous other historical and cultural sites.  

The existing port facilities consist of two parallel piers (the 'old' pier and the 'new' pier) separated by about 93 m and oriented in a North West  South East direction.  The 'old' pier is smaller than the new one and has outside and inside berth lengths of 262 m and 158 m, respectively.  The 'new' pier provides berths of 235 m on the inside and 258 m on the outside.   The piers provide drafts of 9 m near the shore, increasing to 14 m at the ends.  There is a small terminal building which is used for entry and exit of the passengers to the port.  There is also a bus staging area located within the port area with a capacity of 50-60 buses.

Project Description:
Currently as one of the top Mongolian banks by many standards, Agbank's (Agbank, bank or the company) competitive advantage lies in its 377 branches covering almost the entire country, thus enabling it to provide small individual loans to those without access to credit in even the most remote areas.  As of 12/31/2003, it had total assets of approximately $78 million (mostly loans), total liabilities of about $71 million (mostly deposits), and total capital of $7 million.  Successful turnaround of the bank during the past couple of years is evidenced by its strong loan and deposit growth and average return on equity and return on assets of 55% and 4%, respectively.  

The purpose of the project is aimed at supporting the bank's expansion and institutional strengthening of a local private sector commercial bank engaged in microfinance.
Role:
The project has a strong developmental impact, assisting Agbank to expand operations in support of productive micro and small businesses, herders and small agricultural enterprises in rural areas across Mongolia nationwide.  Agbank is the leader among Mongolian microfinance lenders with an average loan size of about $400 equivalent.  IFC's proposed investment will support and help to sustain the strong growth it has demonstrated in recent years.  Its loans, including those classified as consumer loans, are put to productive uses within Mongolia's extended families thereby supporting livelihoods, employment generation in the private sector, and particularly in low income rural communities.  The institution's strong performance, as demonstrated by its portfolio growth and profitability, its methodology and its control mechanisms and its outreach in rather remote and geographically challenging areas will serve as "best practice" examples for other rural finance institutions, state-owned and slated for privatization or otherwise.

IFC's  support, both financial and knowledge sharing, is key to the successful post-privatization development of the bank. IFC expects to also play a strong role in introducing and establishing good corporate governance and will strongly support the continued focus on the provision of small loans and financial services in rural areas.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category FI Type 1 project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure.  Agbank will establish an environmental management system to  ensure that activities financed under relevant operations are consistent with applicable environmental, occupational health and safety regulations of Mongolia and IFC''s Microfinance Exclusion List;  designate appropriate individuals who will have responsibility for the environment and who will attend IFCs environmental management workshops or an approved equivalent;  submit to IFC an environmental management plan;  and submit to IFC annual environmental performance reports.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: The project's main sponsor is HS Securities Co., Ltd. (HS), part of the HIS Group (HIS), a publicly listed conglomerate on the Tokyo Stock Exchange.  HS was established in 1998.  In January 2003, HS successfully placed a bid to purchase 100% of Agbank.  Subsequently, a 40% share in the bank was sold to a diversified Mongolian company, Tavan Bogd Trade, which is owned by three local individuals.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $3.0 million for IFC's own account in the form of a subordinated Tier II loan.
Investment: 3.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan1.80Equity1.20* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The bank is headquartered in Ulaanbaatar and has 377 branches across Mongolia.  Loans can be made throughout the country.

Project Description: The Marlin project (Marlin, the company or the project) is a promising greenfield gold project located in the western Guatemalan highlands approximately 90 air miles northwest of Guatemala City.  The $254 million open pit/underground project is estimated to produce about 217,000 oz per annum over 11 years at about $93/oz cash cost (lowest quartile on the cost curve).  Total open pit and underground reserves in the current mine plan are estimated 13.3 million tonnes at 5.4 g/t gold.  In addition, there is significant exploration potential.  The metallurgy appears simple and conducive to a simple treatment circuit with high recoveries.The project is owned by Montana Exploradora de Guatemala, S.A. (ME), a 100% subsidiary of Glamis Gold Ltd. (Glamis or the sponsor), a mid tier gold producer listed on both the Toronto and New York Stock Exchanges.  ME holds other exploration stage properties in Guatemala in addition to Marlin.
Role: IFC Role:Glamis wants IFCs participation in Marlin first, to mitigate the political risk associated with working in Guatemala. Marlin is one of the first significant mining projects in Guatemala and as such the mining environment in Guatemala is virtually untested.  Second, Glamis is committed to achieving international best practice at Marlin and ensuring that projects benefits outweigh the negative impacts.  IFC can play a strong and positive role in the project by facilitating community partnerships, enhancing projects environment and social management capacity and identifying and developing any potential SME linkages.   Development Impact -  Environmental Protection And Community Development:  ME has aligned with Citizens Development Corps (CDC), a Washington-based NGO, to develop and fund, with IFCs assistance, Fundación Sierra Madre (FSM). The foundations specific mission is to plan and implement sustainable, community-based, development and capacity building programs in the municipalities of San Miguel Ixtahuacán and Sipacapa. IFC will be providing both technical and financial assistance to FSM. Specifically, IFCs Corporate Citizenship Facility (CCF) is coordinating with the FSM in the development of a program to establish community-managed nurseries to supply the mine''s reforestation needs. CCF would supply funding for a consultant to provide TA to the communities in getting the nurseries up and running and possibly provide marketing assistance.  In addition, as part of project supervision, IFC would assist FSM with monitoring and evaluation of its various programs.   This program would lay the groundwork for further IFC involvement including IFC SME assistance. The objective would be to not only create supplier linkages but also opportunities beyond the mine, thereby creating employment in the mine communities that should outlast eventual closure. -  Local Hiring and Skills Transfer: Montana intends to train and hire as many local residents of surrounding communities as practical.  Montanas local hiring target is 80% of the operations workforce.  -  Local Capacity Building and Infrastructure Improvements:  Through FSM, Montana will assist local governments and appropriate non-governmental organizations (NGOs) in the development and improvement of community facilities and services, such as health care, schools, utilities and municipal management.  -  Demonstration Impact:  Marlin will be one of the first mining investments in Guatemala in years. Its commercial success and its community programs should both provide a demonstration impact and help encourage new investment in the sector.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category A project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.  Potential environmental, health and safety issues associated with this project include: associated facilities; longer-term cumulative impacts; natural habitats; international waterways; safety of tailings dam; solid and liquid waste management; hazardous materials management; water resources management; reclamation and closure; management of occupational health and safety issues, as well as emergency preparedness and response. Social issues include: management of impacts on indigenous communities; resettlement, compensation and sustainable economic rehabilitation/development; direct and induced impacts of associated facilities; induced migration to the project area; and management of work camps and residential areas.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe environmental documentation will be made available at the following locations:Montana Exploradora de Guatemala, S.A. 20 Calle 24-60 Zona 10Ofi-Bodegas Pradera #20Guatemala City, GuatemalaMarlin Project OfficeProject SiteSan Miguel IxtahuacanDepartamento San MarcosGuatemalaSan Miguel Ixtahuacan Municipal OfficeSan Miguel IxtahuacanDepartamento San MarcosGuatemalaFundacion Sierra Madre OfficeSan Miguel IxtahuacanDepartamento San MarcosGuatemalaSipacapa Municipal OfficeSipacapaDepartamento San MarcosGuatemala
Sponsor: Glamis Gold Limited, through Montana Exploradora de Guatemala, has a 100% interest in the Marlin project.  Glamis Gold Limited: a description of the sponsor is as follows:Glamis is a Reno based mid-cap sized gold mining company listed on both Toronto and New York Stock Exchanges. Glamis currently produced 230,000 ounces in 2003 at a cash cost of $184/oz from its operations in Honduras and Nevada.  The company has a stated medium term goal of achieving gold production of 500,000 oz/yr at less than US$150/oz.  In addition to Marlin, Glamis holds additional concessions (both through and outside Montana Exploradora) in Guatemala.  As of March 5, 2004 Glamis had a market cap of $2.15 billion at $16.6 per share.
Cost Nature: The project cost for Marlin is estimated at $254 million, including $123 million capital costs and $131 million that Glamis spent to acquire and develop the project to feasibility stage. IFC is providing ME a loan of $45 million, for Marlins development. Glamis will finance the remaining capital costs through shareholders equity and loans.

The Marlin project is accessible by an all-season road, which is connected to a paved highway near Huehuetenango.

Project Description:
Tribanco was created in 1990, it holds a full banking license, and is subject to the supervision of the Central Bank of Brazil. Tribanco provides financing and banking services to customers (small shop owners) of Grupo Martins (as well as some of its suppliers).  Grupo Martins (Gmartins) is the largest wholesaler/ distributor in Latin America. Tribanco, a subsidiary of Gmartins,  provides a wide range of financial services for its clients including receivables discounting, equipment purchase financing, investment alternatives and even credit cards to the clients of the retail shops it supplies. Tribanco's credit portfolio composition is 65% small retail shops, 34% suppliers and 1% logistics services.

This project will provide Tribanco with the funding to develop new products designed to upgrade or expand the sales outlets of micro and small entrepreneurs. There is significant developmental impact, since many of Tribanco's customers are microenterprises located in less privileged or remote regions of the country. IFC's financing will thus support a pioneer microfinance operator in a large, underserved market.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category FI Type 1 project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure. Tribanco will establish an environmental management system that will ensure that activities financed under relevant operations are consistent with applicable environmental, occupational health and safety regulations of Brazil;  designate appropriate individuals who will have responsibility for the environment and who will attend IFCs environmental management workshops or an approved equivalent; submit to IFC an environmental management plan; and submit to IFC an annual environmental performance report.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: Tribanco is wholly owned by Grupo Martins, the largest private Brazilian wholesaler specializing in foods, pharmaceuticals, construction materials, white goods and electronics. GMartins was created in 1953 in Uberlândia (state of Minas Gerais), a privileged location for distribution in Brazil as it is a central crossroads and transport intersection between the South and Southern states with the Center, North and West (Amazon), the Nordeste, as well as the Atlantic coast.  GMartins has a fleet of 1,100 trucks, distributes over 19,000 products and counts on a sales force of 4,900.  Its excellent logistics capability includes 4 hub distribution centers with storage capacity of 123,000 tons and 40 advanced distribution centers.  Its 2003 revenues reached R$2.0bn ($0.72bn).
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $10 million. The proposed IFC Investment is a $10 million A loan for IFC's own account.

Project Description: The project consists of up to $34 million in loans to Banca Transilvania (BT, the company or the bank), a regional bank headquartered in Cluj, Romania.  Through this financing IFC will assist the bank in expanding its mortgage lending operations and reaching its growth objectives by using the best practice underwriting policies and procedures.  The project will also encourage competition among the local banks engaged in mortgage lending and increase clients access to longer term financing, making the home ownership more affordable.   Housing finance is a relatively new, but a fast growing banking sector in Romania, whose potential is limited by the availability of long term bank funding.  Over the last decade, low quality of the existing housing stock, general housing deficit, and low housing affordability translated into a high demand for mortgage products.  With the recent appearance of longer tenor financing, this pent-up demand led to a steep increase in mortgage lending in Romania.  Starting from a low $100 million sector wide mortgage portfolio in the end 2002 it is expected to surpass $1 billion by 2005.    The bank started extended housing loans in 2002 and continued with mortgage loans in 2003.  BT has been an active participant in the mortgage lending, holding about 12% market share and having about half of its mortgage portfolio in the Transilvania region.  The banks objective is to double the size of its mortgage portfolio by the end of 2004 and to this end BT requires more term funds.  With the term of up to 10 years, the IFCs financing package would allow Banca Transilvania to increase the tenors of its mortgage offering for up to 15 years.
Role: The housing finance market in Romania is still in its infancy though the demand for mortgage products is very strong.  An important developmental impact of this project is to provide critically needed long-term funding to support the extension of long term mortgage loans to families that wish to purchase or renovate their homes.  The tenor of IFCs loan would enable BT to provide long-term, and thus, more affordable mortgages.  With increased affordability, more individuals could access funding to purchase new or renovate existing homes.  Furthermore, through linkage effects, the development of the housing industry stimulates the supply of labor and materials for the construction and improvement of homes, a significant contributor to economic growth in Romania.  IFC will play a major role in ensuring that the banks mortgage products are structured using the best practice underwriting and mortgage servicing standards, including the transparency of mortgage information disclosure to the banks borrowers.  Through its long term financing IFC will assist in diversifying the funding base and extending the funding tenor of a dynamic regional bank, which is active in the underrepresented regional housing segment of the Romanian banking sector.  Finally, IFCs participation in the project will help expand the nascent housing finance market in Romania, as well as encourage the competition and the use of best practices among the local players.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category C project according to IFCs environmental review procedure.  The bank will be required to adhere to IFCs exclusion list.  No further environmental review is required.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The project sponsor is Banca Transilvania, a medium-sized and well-capitalized regional Romanian bank.  The bank was established in 1993 by a group of local entrepreneurs.  BT belongs to a financial group, which also includes insurance (life and non life), leasing, brokerage and consumer finance companies.  The bank is listed on the Bucharest Stock Exchange with a market capitalization of about $200 million and among its principal shareholders has EBRD (15%), two local investment funds (5% each), and Mr. Ciorcila, one of the founders (5%).
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $34 million and consists of loans for IFCs own account.
Investment: 24.31 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan24.31Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Banca Transilvania is headquartered in Cluj, Romania and has over 70 branches throughout the entire country.  Its traditional area of geographic focus was Transilvania, a North-Western part of Romania bordering on Hungary and Ukraine.  Over the years the bank has expanded into Eastern and Southern parts of Romania as well.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category C project according to IFCs environmental review procedure.  The bank will be required to adhere to IFCs exclusion list.  No further environmental review is required.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community

Project Description: Established in 1993, Xinao Gas Holdings Limited is a leading Chinese private gas distributor with operations in 39 cities across 10 provinces / municipalities in eastern China.  Its operations cover a total connectable urban population of 18.5 million people.  Xinao is also developing natural gas applications for the transportation sector, including conversions of taxis and buses to CNG and the installation of CNG fueling stations. The project is for Xinao to expand its gas distribution infrastructure to increase gas distribution and utilization in China.
Role:
The project supports China's stated policy to develop the natural gas industry. The project would help Xinao develop gas distribution infrastructure and gas utilization in cities in northern and eastern China, where the growth in gas consumption is expected to be the highest.

Substituting coal energy with natural gas is an effective means of reducing air pollution. Combustion of natural gas results in virtually no atmospheric emissions of sulfur dioxide and particulates, and far lower emissions of other harmful pollutants such as nitrogen oxides (which contributes to urban smog) and carbon dioxide (the main contributor to global warming).

IFC has a strong role in supporting the development of private infrastructure companies whose product results in significant environment and economic benefits by reducing harmful emissions, alleviating air pollution (a major health issue in China) and lowering energy costs. IFC would also be supporting a local Chinese gas distributor which competes with other local and international operators. This will have a strong demonstration effect and lend credibility to other local firms seeking international funding in the Chinese gas distribution market as well as the broader infrastructure market.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The review of this project consisted of appraising information submitted by the project sponsor and a report prepared by a technical consultant to IFC.  The review addressed the compliance status of Xinao''s current operations as well as its management system for the environmental, social, and safety aspects of its current and future operations.  The company''s procedures for land acquisition and how liabilities such as land contamination and labor obligations are managed were reviewed.  Opportunities for social responsibility and community development programs were also assessed.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe environmental documents will be made available at the following locations:

The review of this project consisted of appraising information submitted by the project sponsor and a report prepared by a technical consultant to IFC.  The review addressed the compliance status of Xinao''s current operations as well as its management system for the environmental, social, and safety aspects of its current and future operations.  The company''s procedures for land acquisition and how liabilities such as land contamination and labor obligations are managed were reviewed.  Opportunities for social responsibility and community development programs were also assessed.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe environmental documents will be made available at the following locations:

Project Description:
The proposed project will provide a 3-year bullet loan of up to $22 million to Kotak Mahindra Bank (KMB), a newly formed bank which was previously known as Kotak Mahindra Finance Limited (KMFL). KMFL, locally rated AAA, was one of the country's best non bank financial companies (NBFC). KMB undertakes commercial banking activities as well as direct & indirect holdings in 13 companies, whose main business include:

-  asset financing; 
-  investment banking & brokerage;  
-  wealth management and 
-  life insurance.  

The loan would allow KMB to develop

-  its SME business and 
-  make US dollar funding available for its export clients.  It will also provide funding for the bank in its first years of operation, when it is establishing its track record.
Role:
The development impact of this project will be to:

-  Support the growth of the private sector in the banking industry.  Today, the public sector represent more than 80% of total banking assets.  The inefficiencies of the public sector institutions, and the weak operating standards affect many sectors of the Indian economy, in particular the SMEs which pay the cost of difficult access to credit and the lack of best practice in banking services.  By supporting KMB, this project will contribute to the development of the private sector.

-  Support a new institution with high potential.  Kotak Mahindra Finance Limited was one of the best financial institutions in India, and with the quality of the shareholders and the management, KMB is in a good position to become a leading bank in India.

-  Increase SMEs access to finance and support export-oriented business.  As part of KMB's business plan, these sectors represent a good share of new business opportunities.  Through its loan to KMB, IFC will support these sectors.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category FI Type 1 project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure. KMB will be required to establish an environmental management system to ensure that activities financed under relevant operations comply with applicable environmental, occupational health and safety regulations of India; designate two individuals to have responsibility for environmental affairs, and who will attend IFC''s environmental management workshop or an approved equivalent; and submit to IFC an environmental management plan, and annual environmental performance reports.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: The shareholding of KMB is broken down among Uday Kotak (55.97%), Mrs. Anuradha Mahindra (3.02%) and the public (41.01%).  Uday Kotak is Executive Vice Chairman & MD of KMB.  He was the founder and promoter of KMFL, which he headed for 17 years.
Cost Nature:
Total Project Cost: N/A
Proposed IFC Investment: up to $22 million 3-year bullet senior loan.
Investment: 22.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan22.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: KMB is headquartered in Mumbai, India.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category FI Type 1 project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure. KMB will be required to establish an environmental management system to ensure that activities financed under relevant operations comply with applicable environmental, occupational health and safety regulations of India; designate two individuals to have responsibility for environmental affairs, and who will attend IFC''s environmental management workshop or an approved equivalent; and submit to IFC an environmental management plan, and annual environmental performance reports.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Description: Sibakadembank (SAB or the bank) is a private bank based in Novosibirsk with a branches in seven regions of Western and Eastern Siberia.  The bank focuses on lending to SMEs, entrepreneurs, and individuals and despite its small size and regional location, SAB has established an impressive branch network throughout Siberia.  SAB had the net worth of approximately $16.5 million and total assets of approximately $207.0 million equivalent as of end of 2003.  Proceeds of IFC loan would be used for on-lending to private small and medium-sized enterprises.
Role:
Underdevelopment of the financial sector in Russia, especially in the regions, is one of the major weaknesses of the Russian economy.  In addition to addressing this gap, the project will have a positive impact on regional economic development as:

-  SAB will broaden the range of financial products available to its clients.  The underdeveloped SME sector has been consistently identified as a major barrier to growth in Russia, and this problem is particularly severe in Siberia.
-  SAB's capacity to develop into a leading regional bank with a cross-regional presence will be strengthened.  SAB remains one of the few private independent banking networks in a vast geographic area from Omsk to Irkutsk, a distance of over 2000 km.

IFC's Role: 

-  IFC has provided SAB with significant TA support designed to assist SAB in its efforts to introduce international bank practices in the areas or risk management and organizational development.  
-  IFC would support SAB's continued development as IFC's long-term financing should help the bank to expand its client base, improve structure of its balance sheet, and broaden funding sources.
-  IFC would extend geographic reach of its investment operations in the financial sector to Siberia, the region which is under-served in the area of financial services, and support a bank which may play an important role in consolidation in the banking sector. 
-  Should IFC become SAB's shareholder in the future, it could have an important impact on the bank's corporate governance and its ability to attract other investors.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category FI Type 1 project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure.  The bank will be required to establish an environmental management system for its corporate and SME lending operations to ensure that the activities and enterprises it finances comply with Russian environmental and occupational health and safety requirements.  Designated SAB officers will complete IFCs environmental training course for financial intermediaries and the bank will provide IFC with environmental performance reports on an annual basis.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: Sibakadembank is controlled by three of its senior managers, Messrs. Kim, Bekarev, and Taranov, who together control 80% of the bank's capital.  The bank has maintained its independence from financial and industrial groups and established good reputation throughout its 13 years of operation.
Cost Nature: The project consists of a senior loan for IFC's account of up to $7.0 million and an option to purchase SAB's shares of up to $2.0 million at a later date.
Investment: 7.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan7.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: SAB is headquartered in Novosibirsk and currently has 7 branches and 29 additional offices throughout Siberia.

The bank will be required to establish an environmental management system for its corporate and SME lending operations to ensure that the activities and enterprises it finances comply with Russian environmental and occupational health and safety requirements.  Designated SAB officers will complete IFCs environmental training course for financial intermediaries and the bank will provide IFC with environmental performance reports on an annual basis.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Description: The project companies are OAO Bauxite Timana, an existing company, and ZAO Komi Aluminium a greenfield company, established to operate the planned integrated bauxite/alumina/aluminium project in the Komi Republic of Russia. OAO Bauxite Timana was established to run the Middle Timan Bauxite Mine in the Komi Republic, to which it holds the license. The project entails the expansion of  the mine from the existing 1million tonnes of bauxite per annum to produce up to 6 million tones per annum and to start early works on the construction of an associated alumina refinery. This is the initial phase of the larger integrated project that includes the bauxite mine, an alumina refinery and an aluminium smelter and which will be one of the largest new investment projects in Russia.
Role: This project represents Phase I of one of the largest greenfield projects in Russia to date. The project should have a major development impact on the Komi Republic which to date has had a limited industrial base. The overall size of the integrated project is expected to be in excess of $2 billion. IFC involvement will help secure longer term financing for the project than is currently available and will establish the project on the international financial markets, thereby allowing the SUAL Group to secure further financing for Phase II (refinery construction) and Phase III (smelter construction). IFCs extensive technical experience of the aluminium sector is being used to enhance the technical assessment and design of the mine and refinery.IFC is proposing a large donor funded effort to stimulate local supply chains to the project and improve the climate for SMEs in the Komi Republic. This initiative also envisages the establishment of a financing facility for local SMEs. IFC involvement will also help ensure that best practice is employed in minimizing environmental and social impacts.
Environmental Social Issues: The Phase I project is a category A project as it is considered a key component of the future Integrated Project. There are no major environmental, health and safety risks associated with this expansion project as mining bauxite does not require the use of chemicals or of a process flow generating emissions or effluents. Starting in about 6-8 years the dewatering of certain pits will require caution, and proper mitigation measures and a management plan will be in place by that time. The Phase I project is not anticipated to result in major social and cultural property impacts, as it is an existing site located in a remote and unpopulated area. SUAL Group has agreed to carry out a detailed environmental, social, health and safety assessment of the mines. The due diligence of the mining project was undertaken in two separate phases. The first one, phase 1a, consisted of an environmental and social audit of the current mine (1 to 2.5 mtpa capacity), a detailed review of the SUAL Groups environmental and social management and the initiation of the public consultation and disclosure (PCD) process. Phase 1b includes an Environmental and Social Impact Assessment for the expansion to 6 mtpa, a detailed environmental and social action plan (ESAP), a formal PCD strategy supported by key stakeholders and the necessary environmental documents for initiating permits and early civil works at the refinery site. Strong emphasis was especially put on public consultation, land acquisition, mine decommissioning, water resource management, and local economic development activities (supplier and other SME development, training, etc). As a result of IFC involvement the SUAL Group has hired key environmental and social executives and implemented the first steps of an Environmental Management System (EMS).Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityA dedicated web site is being maintained by the SUAL Group, including all the public documents in downloadable format in both the English and Russian languages.  The web address is: http://www.sual.com/business/komi_aluminium/ecology/.  In addition an e-mail address (info@komial.ru) and a phone number (82147) 67342 are available, where comments and issues can be sent/discussed in either English or Russian. Visitors and information centres are being established in Syktyvkar, Yemva, Chinavoryk, Ukhta, Sosnogorsk, and Pechora in the municipal administrations of the relevant towns and villages. Sponsor: The project sponsor is the SUAL Group, Russias second largest aluminium producer and a major exporter. The Groups parent company is SUAL International Ltd (Bahamas) and its management company is OAO SUAL-Holding (Russia).  The SUAL Group has an integrated aluminium operation, mining bauxite, refining alumina, smelting aluminium and producing semi-finished and some finished aluminium products. SUAL Group owns approximately 80% of OAO Bauxite Timana, with the remainder held by the Government of the Republic of Komi. ZAO Komi Aluminium is owned 100% by the SUAL Group.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $321 million. IFC is proposing an investment of $75 million, comprising an A loan of $45 million for IFCs own account and a syndicated B loan of $30m million.

The SUAL Group has already constructed a railway linking the mine to the national rail network. This investment also entails early works (site clearance, basic infrastructure) on a proposed 1.4 million tonnes per annum greenfield alumina refinery to be located near the towns of Ukhta and Sosnogorsk.

Project Description: The project is a $487 million investment in Jiangxi Chenming a greenfield paper facility in the Changbei economic development zone, Nanchang city, China. The facility will produce 350,000 tpy of light weight coated (LWC) paper and will be built and operated by Shandong Chenming Paper Holdings (Chenming or the sponsor), the largest Chinese-owned paper company, and Shinmoorim Paper MFG Company (Shinmoorim), South Koreas second largest coated paper producer and IFC client.  The project will be implemented over an 18 month period and consist of: -  installation and operation of an LWC paper machine with an annual capacity of 350,000 metric tons per annum (tpy); -  a Bleached Thermo Mechanical Pulp (BTMP) plant with an annual capacity of 187,000 tpy; -  a De-Inked Pulp (DIP) plant with an annual capacity of 136,000 tpy; -  a co-generation power plant with a total capacity of 100 megawatts; and -  ancillary infrastructure, including wastewater treatment and port installations.This purpose of this project is to support Chenmings strategy of becoming a major international paper company within the next five years and it will also facilitate Shinmoorims expansion in China.  In so doing, it will bridge a market gap in the availability of LWC paper in the Asia-Pacific region, which is a limited producer and net importer of coated paper.  Given that market trends indicate an increasing demand for LWC paper, local Chinese production of this light-weight paper will reduce costs for end-users, especially those in advertising and print media.
Role: IFC will play a major role in the supporting the project by-  working closely with Chenming to educate the sponsor about international financing options, corporate governance, and financial risk management.  IFC has helped Chenming identify key risks such as aged receivables and excessive reliance on short-term debt, and will work will the client to optimize its capital structure, -  acting as a honest broker between Chenming and Shinmoorim, its technical partner and the projects other international investor and -  ensuring transparency and strong corporate governance at the level of the project company by taking an equity stake.  IFCs advice will also enhance Chenmings efforts to attain world-class operations, management and governance at the project company.  IFCs role also includes introducing Chenming to international financiers through the B Loan / parallel financing initiative, as well as providing advice related to sustainability practices, particularly with respect to the companys plantation effort and environmental management policies.  In essence, IFC will play a critical role in taking Chenming from the largest Chinese paper company to a leading and ranked player in the worldwide pulp and paper industry.  The development impact of this project will help construct a world-class LWC plant to meet the rapidly growing demand for lightweight coated paper in China.  Chenming has a competitive advantage over imports due to lower transport, co-generation power, and labor costs.  These advantages more than offset the higher fiber in the Chinese market.  In addition, The projects large scale and high quality technical know-how will advantage it over other local suppliers.  In addition, the project will have the following benefits:  -  Regional Development: The project will result in a large-scale investment in Chinas paper sector thereby resulting in increased output, productivity, employment and associated rise in income.  This is especially relevant in rural areas such as Jiangxi, where there are relatively few employment options for the local population.  In addition, the presence of project facility will help develop the local area around the industrial park, creating retail and other business opportunities for the surrounding community.-  Technology Transfer:  The project will receive equipment and technical advice from Metso (Finland) and Andritz (Austria), which will greatly enhance the technical know-how of the company, which will help improve standards across the local paper industry.-  Environment: The project will greatly enhance Chenmings environmental management system and controls beyond local requirements to achieve standardization among the Group companies and international best practices.  All environmental, health, safety and quality activities will be implemented through integrated management systems at all plants to ensure that the environmental conditions are maintained and that the safety and health of the employees is protected, ultimately resulting in cost savings and improved employee morale;-  Corporate Governance:  IFCs guidance vis-à-vis corporate governance, especially as it relates to Chenmings financial risk management policies, will be extremely valuable to the sponsor.  At present, Chenming does not adhere to the stringent financial risk mitigation policies put in place by many of the top P&P producers in the world.  By supporting the project, IFC will be able to guide the sponsor on corporate governance policies that will allow it compete effectively internationally, implement standards prevalent among global P&P companies, and obtain long term financing from international investors.
Environmental Social Issues: This project was defined as an environmental and social Category A project because following project pre-appraisal significant, adverse and sensitive environmental and social impacts were anticipated.  These impacts result from resettlement associated with development of the greenfield site and emissions to air from the boiler plant required to service the 100 MWe power station.  Other issues of concern were environmental management processes, emissions to water and the impact of the project on its immediate environs. Sponsor: Project sponsor: Chenming is the leading Chinese-owned paper and pulp company and is headquartered in Shouguang, Shangdong province, China. The sponsor was established in 1958 as the Shandong Provincial Shouguang County General Paper Mill, and was renamed Shandong Chenming Paper Holdings Limited in 1993 when its shares were offered by the government for a public listing. The sponsor is listed on both the Shanghai (A shares) and Shenzhen (B shares) stock exchanges and its ownership structure is as follows: - international investors (42%), - the Shouguang government (31%), - employees (11%), and - domestic investors (16%). While the Shandong government is the single largest shareholder, Chenming is managed and operated independently by a professional management. Its management and organizational structure is completely separate from that of the government, and the sponsor owns its assets, trademarks and patent rights. In 2003, Chenming had an average of 16,292 full-time employees.At December 31, 2003, Chenming had consolidated total sales of $700 million, EBITDA of $185 million, operating profit of $126 million and net income of $79 million (after deduction of $ 8.7 million of minority interests). Its cash balance was $127 million and operating cash generation amounted to $47 million. In all, despite SARS, the company sustained a sound operational performance with sales increasing by 31%, operating income growing by 38% and net income by 69%. Total assets increased to $1.2 billion at year-end 2003 from $1.0 billion in 2002. The companys equity grew to $485 million from $409 million during the same period. Chenming will hold 75% of the equity ($129 million) of the project company.Shareholders: The project company will be a foreign joint venture owned by the Sponsor, Sappi Limited of South Africa, the worlds largest producer of coated paper, Shinmoorim Paper Manufacturing Company Limited, South Koreas second largest coated paper producer, and IFC.Based in South Africa, Sappi is the worlds largest manufacturer and supplier of coated wood-free paper and dissolving pulp, with a total annual production capacity of 5.1 million tons of paper and 3.5 million tons of pulp.  Sappi brings a high degree of operational experience to the project.  Its market share in the coated wood-free paper market is 24 percent in North America, 20 percent in Europe and 60 percent in Africa.  Currently, Sappi has a market share of 3 to 4 percent in Asia based solely on its exports to the region.  The Project will therefore represent an important step in Sappis strategic objective of expanding its current market share in the Asia region.In fiscal year 2003 (ending September 30, 2003), Sappi had net revenues of $4.3 billion and net income of $149 million.    Sappi owns and manages approximately 535,000 hectares of timberlands in Southern Africa.  It employs 16,000 people mostly in North America, Europe and Southern Africa. Sappis shares are listed on the Johannesburg, London and Frankfurt stock exchanges, and have a secondary listing on the New York Stock Exchange. Shinmoorim is South Korea''s second largest producer of coated paper with total capacity of 470,000 tpy and approximately 30% market share. It has 561 employees and was established in 1978 as an affiliated company (through Moorim Paper and Serim Paper) of the Moorim Group, which itself was established in 1956. The group is controlled directly or indirectly by the Dong Wook Lee Family and associates, who together own approximately 60% of the company. IFC holds an 11% stake, Emerging Markets Partnership (EMP) holds 8% and the public holds the balance. Shinmoorim is listed on the Korea Stock Exchange. Over half (52%) of Shinmoorims sales are local with the remaining 48% exported to over 60 countries. At December 31, 2003, Shinmoorim has net (unaudited) revenues of $339.7 million and net income of $21.3 million. Cash generation and EBITDA were $31.3 and $44.3 million respectively, indicating strong liquidity and a good cash position. Its total assets were $387.3 million and its total debt was $159.6 million. Shinmoorim will hold 12.5% of the project companys equity, representing an investment of $21.5 million.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is $487 million.  The proposed IFC investment consists of -  up to $60 million A Loan for IFCs own account and -  a $21.5 million equity investment for IFCs own account, representing 12.5% of the project companys capital.  In addition, IFC is arranging a B Loan for the account of participants and ECA-backed financing up to $180 million.
Investment: 72.90 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan60.0Equity12.90* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The project consists of a 350,000 ton LWC plant outside Nanchang city in the Nanchang Economy and Technology Development Area, in Jiangxi province.  The project company was registered in Nanchang City on November 4, 2002 and will be located on a 2,000 mu (133 hectare ) site adjacent to the Chang-Jiu Express Highway on the west and the Ganjian River on the east.  It has easy access to several modes of transportation with the Changbei Airport only 6 km north of the site, the Jing-Jiu railway 4 km away and the Nanchang International Container Terminal just south of the plant facility.  The project is well-located in Jiangxi, which is one of the most forested regions in China, with respect to both access to raw materials and product distribution.  It is close to the significant ports in Shanghai and Guangzhou for exports and is also proximate to key local markets, namely Beijing and Shanghai.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This project was defined as an environmental and social Category A project because following project pre-appraisal significant, adverse and sensitive environmental and social impacts were anticipated.  These impacts result from resettlement associated with development of the greenfield site and emissions to air from the boiler plant required to service the 100 MWe power station.  Other issues of concern were environmental management processes, emissions to water and the impact of the project on its immediate environs. Project Description: In 1997, Manila Water Company, Inc. (MWCI) won a competitive tender to operate the Metro Manila East water supply and wastewater service zone under a 25-year concession agreement. It inherited facilities that require significant rehabilitation and to date MWCI has spent approximately $70 million for its own capital expenditures and close to $123 million in projects funded through multilateral bank loans to the conceding authority, Metropolitan Waterworks and Sewerage System (MWSS).  In 2003, IFC provided a loan in support of MWCIs operations.  IFC is now considering extending a second loan to help to support MWCIs expenditure program through 2007. These expenditures will include the following components: -  new raw water sources development; -  service expansion to east and southeast areas of the concession; -  network distribution improvement; -  other pipe extension and improvement projects; -  water supply facilities; -  non-revenue water (NRW) reduction programs; -  sewerage & sanitation services; and -  payment of concession fees to MWSS.IFC is also considering an equity investment in MWCI in preparation for its planned flotation of shares on the Philippines Stock Exchange as early as 2005.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category B project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  Environmental and social issues associated with this project include: raw water resource use and management; potable water treatment technology and finished water quality; wastewater management and water quality impacts; sludge management; hazardous materials management and emergency response; employee health and safety; land acquisition and resettlement; affordability and willingness to pay; community development; and environment management systems.MWC continues to demonstrate that the proposed project substantially complies with applicable Philippine laws and regulations and World Bank requirements.  The company also continues to make progress on implementing the agreed Environmental and Social Action Plan.  Appropriate internal policies and procedures are being followed, and a number of new initiatives that demonstrate environmental and social responsibility are being developed.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityCopies of the environmental documents are available at Manila Water Company Main Office. See address in next section.
Sponsor: Ayala Corporation is the largest shareholder with direct and indirect equity interests totaling 52.7%, including 39.9% direct ownership, 8% through MWC Holdings (a special purpose vehicle) and 4.8% through BPI Capital. Ayala Corporation is one of the oldest business conglomerates in the Philippines with operations in real estate, electronics, utilities, the automotive sector, banking, insurance, telecommunications, transportation, and food. United Utilities (UU) holds an 18.6% equity interest in MWCI through a subsidiary. UU, a listed UK company, provides water, sewer, energy and electricity services to over 28 million people worldwide. Bank of the Philippine Islands Capital Corporation and Mitsubishi Corporation each own a 10.7% equity interest. Employees own 6.8% of the equity through an employee stock ownership program.
Cost Nature: MWCIs capital investment program, including concession fees, for 2004-2007 is estimated at $292 million. The proposed IFC investment comprises a $30 million A loan for IFC''s own account and an equity subscription of up to $15 million.
Investment: 45.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan30.0Equity15.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: MWCIs operations cover Metro Manila East. The East zone comprises Pasig City, Pateros, San Juan, Taguig, Mandaluyong, a small part of old Manila, most of Makati, Marikina, Quezon City, Rodriguez and San Mateo in Rizal and all of the Rizal municipalities.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category B project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  Environmental and social issues associated with this project include: raw water resource use and management; potable water treatment technology and finished water quality; wastewater management and water quality impacts; sludge management; hazardous materials management and emergency response; employee health and safety; land acquisition and resettlement; affordability and willingness to pay; community development; and environment management systems.MWC continues to demonstrate that the proposed project substantially complies with applicable Philippine laws and regulations and World Bank requirements.  The company also continues to make progress on implementing the agreed Environmental and Social Action Plan.  Appropriate internal policies and procedures are being followed, and a number of new initiatives that demonstrate environmental and social responsibility are being developed.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityCopies of the environmental documents are available at Manila Water Company Main Office. Project Name: Sociedad Nacional de Procesamiento de Datos S.A.
Project Description:
Sociedad Nacional de Procesamiento de Datos, S.A. (SONDA or the company) is one of the largest independent IT services providers in Latin America.  Founded in 1974 in Santiago, Chile, SONDA is a one-stop shop for IT services and products.  The company offers hardware and software product sales, systems integration, financial and administrative solutions (such as enterprise resource planning (ERP), payroll solutions, core banking systems), training services, and a variety of outsourcing services.  With over 3,700 employees, SONDA provides IT products and services to eleven Latin American countries.  
  
SONDA's near-term growth strategy consists of consolidating its expansion in the region.  To this effect the company bought an IT services provider in Brazil, in November 2002.  SONDA also acquired a Mexican IT firm Pissa in February 2004.  To consolidate these acquisitions and develop its business throughout the other countries in the region, the company expects an investment program of over $40 million over the next two years.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category C project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  There are minimal environmental and social impacts associated with this project.  If physical assets, for example warehouses, are constructed during the life of the project loan, the company will notify IFC, develop procedures to appraise the construction project(s), and demonstrate compliance with all relevant environment and social policies, guidelines and procedures.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: SONDA has as shareholders Mr. Andres Navarro and its family (through related companies) and Intel Capital (minority participation).
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $60.0 million.  The proposed IFC investment is a $10.0 million in equity.
Investment: 10.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity10.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: SONDA is headquartered in Santiago, Chile, and has branches in eleven countries in Latin America (Chile, Argentina, Uruguay, Brazil, Peru, Ecuador, Colombia, Costa Rica, Mexico, and Venezuela).  The investment can be made throughout Sonda's region of operation.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category C project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  There are minimal environmental and social impacts associated with this project.  If physical assets, for example warehouses, are constructed during the life of the project loan, the company will notify IFC, develop procedures to appraise the construction project(s), and demonstrate compliance with all relevant environment and social policies, guidelines and procedures.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Description: Rain Calcining Limited (RCL or the company) is an export oriented company located in Visakhapatnam, Andhra Pradesh. With a capacity to produce 300,000 metric tons per year (tpy) of Calcined Petroleum Coke (CPC), it generates up to 49.5 MW of power from its power generation facility using the flue gases evolved during the calcination and combustion of green petroleum coke (GPC).   The project entails expanding production capacity to 480,000 tpy and modernizing existing production lines.  The venture is scheduled to reach completion by the mid-2005.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category B project according to IFCs environmental review procedure because specific impacts may result that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The review of this project included an evaluation of technical and environmental information submitted by the sponsor including the business plan, and review of past performance on the preceding investments.
