Project Description:
Industrial development in western China is increasing the region's demand for container, roll on-roll off (Ro-Ro) and bulk shipping over the Yangtze river, one of the largest navigable rivers in the world.  Based in Chongqing, the transportation hub in the south western region of China, Minsheng Shipping Co. Ltd. (Minsheng) is a leading ship operator along the Yangtze river.  Minsheng operates 93 vessels, comprised of tug boats, barges, container liners and Ro-Ro vessels.  In 1993, Minsheng pioneered container liner services in the Yangtze River, and in 2000 the company acquired its first Ro-Ro vessel.  By 2002, Minsheng accounted for 60% of total container volume and about 95% of total Ro-Ro vehicles shipped from Chongqing port.

Containers are the most cost efficient means of transporting goods on the Yangtze river and container volumes are expected to grow rapidly over the next few years.  IFC's investment will support Minsheng's plans to purchase new vessels and optimize its vessel structure, achieve efficiency gains and allow it to meet the growing demand for container and Ro-Ro vessels along the Yangtze river.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The review of this project consisted of appraising technical and environmental and social information submitted by the project sponsor and a consultant to IFC.  The following potential environment, health and safety and social impacts of the projects were analyzed:  conformance with international and PRC standards and requirements for river shipping operations, design standards for new vessels, environmental performance of operation and maintenance of the vessels, dangerous cargo handling practices, shipboard waste handling and disposal, and occupational health, safety and training programs.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityMinsheng Shipping Co.
Minsheng Building, 83 Xinhua Road, Chongqing 400011, China
Sponsor: Minsheng Shipping Co., Ltd., is a subsidiary of Minsheng Industrial (Group) Co., Ltd. (the Group or the company). The Group has more than 30 subsidiaries and branches in major cities and ports in coastal China and alongside the Yangtze River. The shareholders of Minsheng are the Group, Minsheng Int'l Container Transport Co., Ltd and Minsheng Int'l Cargo Agent Co., Ltd. The key shareholders of the Group are Mr. Lu Guoji and Mr. Lu Xiaozhong.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated to be the RMB equivalent of  $36.7 million. The proposed IFC investment is an A loan of up to $22.0 million.
Investment: 20.75 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan15.75Equity5.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Minsheng is located in Chongqing Municipality and it serves the river shipping market along the Yangtze River. The Yangtze river corridor is well established as the principal artery linking the interior of China with the coast. With Shanghai, China's biggest port located at one end of the river and Chongqing, one of the country's biggest and fastest growing cities, located towards the uppermost navigable reaches, water transport along the Yangtze can service large cargo volumes (at low cost and limited pollution) and play an increasing role in the development of the Western economy.  In all, the Yangtze river has more than 2,800 km of navigable channel and well over a dozen ports that are capable of handling containers.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati:
This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The review of this project consisted of appraising technical and environmental and social information submitted by the project sponsor and a consultant to IFC.  The following potential environment, health and safety and social impacts of the projects were analyzed:  conformance with international and PRC standards and requirements for river shipping operations, design standards for new vessels, environmental performance of operation and maintenance of the vessels, dangerous cargo handling practices, shipboard waste handling and disposal, and occupational health, safety and training programs.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityMinsheng Shipping Co.
Minsheng Building, 83 Xinhua Road, Chongqing 400011, China

Project Name: Olam Multi Country Multi Commodity facility
Project Description:
Olam International Limited (Olam or the company) supplies raw and processed agricultural commodities, grown mainly by community and SME producers in emerging countries, to well established regional and international clients.  It is a fully integrated company that engages in the sourcing, primary processing, transport, warehousing and distribution of a broad range of commodities, including cocoa, rice, timber, cashew, cotton, coffee, sugar, sesame, sheanuts, and spices.  

The project is to provide Olam with a $150 million multi-country multi-commodity 2-year committed working capital facility, to help Olam International restructure and increase its working capital lines to provide more flexible financing for its supply chain management activities, and allow them to increase trading volumes from Africa (mainly Cameroon, Ivory Coast, Burkina Faso, Benin, Togo and Nigeria), Asia (mainly Vietnam and Indonesia) and other countries where Olam operates.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category C project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  IFC made an equity investment in Olam last year.  An extensive environmental and social review of Olam''s operations was made at that time and they were determined to be in compliance with IFC requirements.  Further, both Olams business model and its corporate social responsibility model aim to achieve mutually beneficial, stable business relationships between the company and its suppliers.  Although a small proportion of overall company revenue, Olam trades in timber but promotes sustainable forest management practices and its operations are considered fully consistent with the requirements of the November 2002 World Bank Forests Policy.  Through this earlier investment, Olam''s environmental and social performance will be regularly assessed by IFC.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor:
Olam is part of the Kewalram Chanrai Group (KCG), which is held privately by overseas Indian family trusts. From the Chanrai family's beginnings in trading in Nigeria and India in 1860, KCG has grown to become a $1.6 billion (turnover) operation with interests in textile, agro-commodities, software development and distribution, automobile, office automation and property development employing over 12,000 people in over 45 countries. 

Olam is currently owned at 68.8% by KCG and the management team, and 31.2% by financial investors (including IFC for 9.4%).
Cost Nature:
The $150 million facility will be made of three components : 

-  a $50 million 6-month general working capital facility, 
-  a $20 million 60 days pre-shipment facility, and 
-  a $80 million post-shipment / warehouse financing facility.  

The facility will be managed by Standard Chartered Bank (SCB).

IFC is considering to provide a partial guarantee for the facility for up to $50 million.  Other institutional investors or banks will be offered to take risk participations in the facility for up to $50 million.  SCB will retain full risk exposure for the remaining $50 million.
Investment: 30.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuarantee30.0LoanEquity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Based in Singapore, Olam operates in 36 countries, including 22 frontier countries.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category C project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  IFC made an equity investment in Olam last year.  An extensive environmental and social review of Olam''s operations was made at that time and they were determined to be in compliance with IFC requirements.  Further, both Olams business model and its corporate social responsibility model aim to achieve mutually beneficial, stable business relationships between the company and its suppliers.  Although a small proportion of overall company revenue, Olam trades in timber but promotes sustainable forest management practices and its operations are considered fully consistent with the requirements of the November 2002 World Bank Forests Policy.  Through this earlier investment, Olam''s environmental and social performance will be regularly assessed by IFC.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Company Name: PARAMOUNT LIFE AND GENERAL HOLDINGS CORPORATION
Project Description: The project entails an IFC quasi-equity and equity investment of up to $8.5 million in Paramount Life and General Insurance Company (the company or PLGIC), a composite insurance company in the Philippines.  The company provides life and general insurance policies to corporates and individuals in the Philippines.  It was established in May 1950, is headquartered in Manila, and has 27 branches in Metro Manila and outer provinces.  IFC's investment, which will be made in different phases, will help this median-sized, non-captive insurance company to make strategic acquisitions, to stimulate and consolidate the industry.
Environmental Social Issues: Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: PLGIC is privately held by three groups.  The principal shareholder/managing partner is Patrick and Rosanna Go, son and daughter of the founder, Mr. Daniel Go, of the Company.  Mr. and Ms. Go jointly own about 64% shares of the Company.  Mr. and Ms. Go are also principal executives.  PLGIC has been engaged in local insurance business for over half century.
Cost Nature: The company would issue a quasi-equity stock, and new equity shares to IFC in different stages of the IFC investment.  The total IFC investment in the company will be up to $8.5 million.

Project Description:
Amaggi Exportaçao e Importaçao Limitada (Amaggi or the company), an existing IFC client, is one of the leading soybean operators in the Mato Grosso state of Brazil.  Brazil is the world's second largest soybean producer and Mato Grosso accounts for 20% of soybeans produced in Brazil.   Soybean production in Mato Grosso is expected to outpace the other regions and increase by 10% p.a. in the next few years.  To maintain its market share, Amaggi aims to expand its origination activity, particularly to the east of Mato Grosso, where soybean production is growing, replacing other less profitable agribusiness activities. 

The project involves the following components: 
-  the establishment of soybean collection centers; 
-  construction of silos with 250,000 tons storage capacity and 
-  refinancing a portion of short-term debt that is currently used to support Amaggi's permanent working capital needs. 

The company's permanent working capital consists of soybean inventory and pre-financing provided to farmers in the form of inputs and cash.

The project will enable the company to do the following: 
-  lower its financing cost; 
-  sustain its market share; 
-  establish a presence in growth areas in the east of Mato Grosso. 

Amaggi has played an instrumental role in promoting sustainable soybean cultivation practices in the Mato Grosso state. Pursuant to the first IFC investment, Amaggi has developed and successfully implemented an Environmental Management System (EMS) that fully complies with World Bank Group environmental and social guidelines. The EMS specifies procedures to ensure that no child labor is employed, no negative impacts to the natural habitats, indigenous communities are present in Amaggi's own operations as well as the operations of third party farmers who receive pre-financing from Amaggi.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Amaggi has in place an Environmental Management System to ensure that its operations and the operations of the third party farmers that receive financing from Amaggi are compliant with the World Bank Group environment and social guidelines.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe Environmental documents will be located in the following locally affected communities:  Itacoatiara, Porto Velho, Rondonopolis, Sapezal.
Sponsor: Amaggi is 100% owned by the Maggi family via the holding company, Grupo André Maggi Participacoes (the 'Maggi Group').  The Maggi family has been involved in the soybean business since the 1950s. The Maggi Group is involved in cultivation, origination, pre-financing of farmers and transportation of soybeans and power generation in Brazil. Both Amaggi and the Maggi Group is managed by professionals with extensive experience in the soybean industry.
Cost Nature:
Total project cost is estimated at $125 million. The proposed IFC A Loan of $30 million will be used for the following:

-  refinancing the portion of short-term debt used to meet Amaggi's permanent working capital requirements and 
-  construction of the soybean silos and soybean collection facilities.
Investment: 30.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan30.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The company is located in the state of Mato Grosso, Center West Brazil.  Amaggi originates all its soybeans from farmers located in Mato Grosso and Rondonia.  Hermasa, the transportation arm of the group, undertakes transport services and shipment of soybeans and fertilizers. Hermasa has a barge terminal in Porto Velho, Rondonia and a port facility located in Itacoatiara, in the state of Amazonas.  Additionally, Amaggi has two crushing plants, one located in Cuiaba, state of Mato Grosso, and the other in Itacoatiara, in the state of Amazonas.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Amaggi has in place an Environmental Management System to ensure that its operations and the operations of the third party farmers that receive financing from Amaggi are compliant with the World Bank Group environment and social guidelines.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe Environmental documents will be located in the following locally affected communities:  Itacoatiara, Porto Velho, Rondonopolis, Sapezal.

Project Description: The project entails IFC providing Canadia Bank PLC (Canadia, the bank or the company) a credit line of up to $5 million to help finance the growth of the banks residential mortgage portfolio.  The purpose is to augment the level of home ownership within the middle-income segment of the population by supporting the promotion of housing finance products in Cambodia.  The objectives of this project are the following:  -  The bank aims to tap into the increased demand from middle-income homebuyers by providing financing for mid-range priced housing units with longer tenured loans.  Given the growth in population and an emerging young and upwardly mobile middle-income segment, the demand for new housing is strong.  -  The tenor and pricing of IFCs credit line will allow the bank access to long-term funding to better manage its growing long-term mortgage loan exposure.  -  Canadia Bank is Cambodias largest private sector bank, with total assets as of December 2003 amounting to $191.2 million, equity of $22.4 million, and a net income of $3.5 million for FY 2003.  With over 300 employees, Canadia offers a wide range of financial services through its network of eleven branches throughout Cambodia.  Some dates of importance are the following :  1991 - Canadia Bank was established as Canadia Gold & Trust Corporation Limited, a joint venture between overseas Cambodians and the National Bank of Cambodia.1993 -  The name of the bank was changed to Canadia Bank Limited, as it was transformed into a commercial bank registered under the Ministry of Commerce and the National Bank of Cambodia.  1994 -  Canadia was the first Cambodian bank to be granted a foreign exchange license.1998 - The bank was fully privatized.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category C project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  The nature of Canadia''s portfolio (middle-income residential mortgage loans) means that there will be minimal environmental impacts associated with this investment.  Therefore, no further environmental or social analysis is required.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: Canadia is a wholly owned subsidiary of Overseas Cambodian Investment Corporation Ltd. (OCIC), a limited liability company organized under the laws of Cambodia.  The major shareholders of OCIC are Mr. Pung Kheav Se (the Bank''s CEO) and his family members, who together own 87% of the banks shares.  The remaining shares are held by overseas Cambodians and by the employees of the bank.
Cost Nature: The proposed IFC investment is a $5 million A Loan for IFCs own account.
Investment: 5.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan5.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Canadia Bank is headquartered in Phnom Penh and has 11 branches spread across Cambodia.  IFC investment will provide the bank with the required long term funding it needs to support the growth in its mortgage portfolio. To date all housing loans funded by the bank have been in the Phnom Penh area.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category C project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  The nature of Canadia''s portfolio (middle-income residential mortgage loans) means that there will be minimal environmental impacts associated with this investment.  Therefore, no further environmental or social analysis is required.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community

Project Description: The project is to provide a financing package of up to $50 million (the 'Facility') to Banco Agrícola S.A. (Agrícola or the bank, or the company) in El Salvador.  The proceeds are expected to be used to expand the bank's operations in mortgage finance and for on-lending to SMEs, including in the manufacturing, commerce and non-traditional export sectors.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an FI type 1 project.  The bank will be required to develop an environmental management system to ensure that relevant operations (e.g. project finance, corporate lending, leasing, but not including individual mortgage lending) comply with the applicable environmental and social requirements in El Salvador.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor:
Agrícola is El Salvador's largest bank, by equity ($271 million), assets (29% market share) and deposits (29% market share), all as of December 2003.  Founded in 1955 to serve SMEs in El Salvador, Agrícola  has applied successfully a strategy of technological innovation and superior customer service to evolve into one of the largest banks in Central America (incl. Panama).  Having pioneered retail banking in El Salvador, it now offers domestically (together with credit card subsidiary Credibac) a complete range of banking products and services. Internationally, the Agrícola group operates four branches in the USA (primarily handling remittances from the Salvadorian diaspora), a subsidiary in Panama and representative offices in Honduras and Guatemala, and also holds a controlling interest in Banco Calley Dagnall in Nicaragua.  Agrícola is rated BB (Stable) by Standard & Poor's and BB (Negative) by Fitch and has 2,800 employees.

Similar to other major Salvadorian banks, Agrícola is majority-owned (89%) by a holding company - Inversiones Financieras Banco Agrícola ('IFBA') - with the rest of the capital distributed widely among retail investors.  In turn, IFBA is 95%-owned by the ultimate holding company in the Agrícola group, Banagrícola S.A. (Banagrícola) based in Panama.  Banagrícola is 50%-owned by its Board (the directors  a diverse group of Salvadorian businessmen  are the same as for Agrícola), with another 6% held by employees and the rest spread among individual investors.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $50 million.  The proposed IFC investment is an A loan of up to $50 million for IFC's own account.
Investment: 50.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan50.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Agrícola is headquartered in San Salvador, El Salvador and operates the nation's largest distribution network (99 branches and more than 400 kiosks and ATMs).
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is an FI type 1 project.  The bank will be required to develop an environmental management system to ensure that relevant operations (e.g. project finance, corporate lending, leasing, but not including individual mortgage lending) comply with the applicable environmental and social requirements in El Salvador.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Company Name: Hipotecaria Nacional, S.A. de C.V. SOFOM, E.R., Grupo Financiero Bancomer
Project Description:
Hipotecaria Nacional (HipNal or the company) is Mexico's largest housing sofol (specialized mortgage lending institution).  Based in Mexico City, HipNal started operations in 1994.  Its main activity consists of originating and servicing residential mortgages financed by Sociedad Hipotecaria Nacional (SHF), a federal mortgage lending institution and the primary source of funds for sofols, to low-income individuals.  As of December 31, 2003. HipNal's total assets amounted to MXN 27 billion ($2.4 billion), while net worth amounted to MXN 1.6 billion ($150 million).  It is the leader in market share based on total assets among mortgage sofols, holding almost 30% of the market.  Its portfolio is divided as approximately two-thirds in mortgage loans and the balance in construction loans to residential real estate developers.  It has a network of 77 branches around the country and services approximately 82,000 mortgage loans with aggregate amount outstanding of MXN $17.5 billion ($1.6 billion).  

HipNal has grown at a rapid pace since its inception a decade ago, given the high demand for low-income housing in Mexico.  To enable it to continue to grow in step with the market and to diversify its funding source from the SHF, its strategy is to issue MBS, thus freeing up its balance sheet of assets so securitized.  The purpose of IFC's loan is to assist the company to put in place a viable structure to facilitate the planned MBS issue.  IFC's loan will be collateralized by a pool of mortgages that will satisfy IFC-stated criteria, and will be transferred to an independent Trust, in order to facilitate the planned securitization.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category C project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  The nature of HipNal''s portfolio (low- to middle-income residential mortgage loans) means that there will be minimal environmental impacts associated this investment.  Therefore, no further environmental or social analysis is required.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: The project sponsor is Hipotecaria Nacional.  HipNal is owned by 12 individuals, with the largest three shareholders holding 73% of HipNal's shareholding.  Some of the shareholders are also part of the key management group.  The shareholders are members of the local community with diversified business interests, and have long years of experience in the financial sector.
Cost Nature: The proposed IFC investment is a Mexican peso-denominated revolving line of credit, for IFC's own account, of $75 million equivalent, secured by a pool of mortgages that will satisfy IFC-specified criteria.  The mortgages will be held by a trust separate from the borrower.
Investment: 100.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan100.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The location of the project is at the headquarters of Hipotecaria Nacional in Mexico City, Mexico.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category C project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  The nature of HipNal''s portfolio (low- to middle-income residential mortgage loans) means that there will be minimal environmental impacts associated this investment.  Therefore, no further environmental or social analysis is required.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Description:
The project involves IFC providing a senior loan of up to $35 million to Bank NISP (NISP, the bank or the company).  The senior loan would have a maturity of five years.  The IFC loan will help to:  

-  diversify the bank's liability structure; 
-  reduce the bank's maturity mismatches; and 
-  support the bank's core lending activities in the SME sector.  

The IFC loan will also help bank in expanding its other activities (e.g., mortgage lending) which require longer term funding.   

The proposed IFC investment is part of a wide ranging effort by the bank to diversify and improve its capital structure and to expand its operations.  As such, the bank is also contemplating a 40% capital increase during the course of 2004.  Currently, almost all of the bank's activities are funded by short term deposits (about 85% of total liabilities).  By providing longer maturity debt, IFC would help reduce duration and maturity gap, hence reducing the bank's liquidity risk.  While the bank's capital adequacy ratio of 13.78% (as of 31 Dec 2003) is considered adequate, the planned capital increase would facilitate the bank's further growth while maintaining a strong capital adequacy ratio.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an FI Type 1 project.  As part of a previous investment by IFC, NISP established an environmental management system as required by IFC.  For the proposed new investment, NISP''s environmental management system will be reviewed by IFC.  For the duration of IFC''s new investment, NISP will be required to maintain an environmental management system satisfactory by IFC, ensuring that activities financed under relevant operations comply with applicable regulations of Indonesia and IFC''s Microfinance Exclusion List.  Any new NISP environmental officer will be required to participate in an intensive environmental appraisal and management course conducted or approved by IFC; and NISP will continue to be required to submit to IFC annual environmental performance reports.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: The bank, an IFC portfolio company, is the fourth oldest bank in Indonesia, established in 1941 in Bandung, West Java as N.V. Nederlandsch Indische Spaar en Deposito Bank.  The name was later changed to PT Bank Nilai Inti Sari Penyimpan before it became "NISP" in 1981.  The bank was founded by the Surjaudaja family and the family directly owns 33% interest in the bank.  The bank was one of the largest savings banks in Indonesia during the early days of its establishment, but in 1967 it transformed itself into a commercial bank.  The Surjaudaja family is considered to be highly reputable and its business activities are focused solely on its banking business.  IFC has a $13.5 million equity investment in the bank, representing a 15.05% shareholding.  Other than the Surjaudaja and IFC holdings, a variety of shareholders account for the remaining 52% stake.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is the proposed $35 million loan to the bank.

Project Description: China Green Energy (Cayman) Ltd. (China Green, or the company) will be incorporated in the Cayman Islands by Mr. Dou Zhenggang. It will be a holding company which owns, develops and invests in power generation projects in China, with a focus on combined heat and power (CHP) plants, as well as generating facilities that utilize municipal solid waste (MSW) and low quality/waste coal as primary fuel.  Prior to IFCs investment, China Green will own certain interests in several power projects that have been developed by Hangzhou Jinjiang Group (HZJJ), a company owned by Mr. Dou in Hangzhou, China.  It is contemplated that China Green will acquire all of HZJJs interests in power assets and become an independent power development, investment and management company. Upon completion of the acquisition, China Greens portfolio will include the following:  -  Jiaxing Jinjiang Cogeneration Co. Ltd. -- a 50 MW CHP plant (currently being expanded by 12 MW); -  Yuhang Jinjiang Environmental Energy Ltd. -- a 12 MW waste to energy (WTE) plant utilizing MSW as primary fuel; -  Jiande Jinjiang Comprehensive Utilization Ltd.  a 12 MW plant that utilizes bone coal as primary fuel; -  Zhengzhou Xinjin Green Environmental Energy Ltd.  a 24 MW WTE plant (currently being expanded by 12 MW) utilizing MSW as fuel;  -  Henan Dengfeng Xinjin Comprehensive Utilization Ltd.  a 24 MW plant utilizing low grade coal as fuel; and -  Yima Jinjiang Comprehensive Utilization Ltd.  a 270 MW plant currently under construction and will utilize low grade coal as fuel.IFCs investment involves an IFC A loan of up to $20 million to China Green, with detachable warrants that give IFC the right to subscribe up to $10 million of the Companys common equity.   IFCs loan will assist the company in completing the acquisition of HZJJs interests in power generation assets in China.  IFCs investment will also assist the company in improving its corporate governance policies and preparing it for an IPO in an international stock market.
Role: China suffers from severe pollution problems caused by huge numbers of small, inefficient, coal-fired heating boilers that supply steam to residential, commercial, and small industries.  China also suffers from solid waste pollution problems caused by fast paced urbanization on one hand, and the lack of planning, resources and technology to efficiently handle the increasing amount of MSW on the other.  The projects to be owned and developed by China Green are addressing these concerns in efficient ways such as; the company''s use of specialized boiler technology and emissions controls reduces pollution linked to the handling of MSW, current practices for burning of low grade coal, and the stockpiling of waste coal at mines and processing sites. These well-run larger plants enable the shutdown of many of the small boilers.  The success of China Green will demonstrate that environmentally compliant, well-managed power projects can be financially viable in the PRC market, and set a benchmark for other operators.  This project would be the first IFC investment to a leading domestic group in the Chinese power sector, and it will be a concrete example of IFCs support to the government policy reform to encourage more private sector participation in power and other infrastructure areas.  In addition, as an important part of IFCs investment, IFC will take an active role in helping the company improve its corporate governance policies and bring international best practice to the company.  IFCs presence is also important to provide comfort to other international investors and thus help the company access the international capital market.  IFCs involvement will also ensure that existing plants, owned by China Green, are environmentally upgraded to the practical extent, and that new facilities will be constructed to meet World Bank Group guidelines.
Environmental Social Issues: IFC will effectively invest at the corporate level in a power development company, with the investment linked to specific projects.  Key issues are the compliance of projects with Government of China environmental requirements, and the feasibility of projects to comply with applicable World Bank guidelines and policies as well as international best practice for MSW plants.  Issues identified regarding China Green''s existing investments will be addressed through development of an Action Plan for each project.  IFC''s appraisal also assessed China Green''s capacity for environmental and social matters, such as staff qualifications and environmental management systems.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityEnvironmental documentation will be made available at the following location:Hangzhou Jinjiang Group Co. Ltd.Jinjiang building 111 South Hushu Rd.,Hangzhou, Zhejiang, P.R. China 310005

HZJJ is one of the largest private sector companies in Zhejiang province with interests in power, textiles, pulp and paper, and pharmaceutical industries.
Cost Nature: IFCs investment is a corporate loan of up to $20 million to China Green to be used by the company for the acquisition of and investments in the power generating assets in China.  In addition, IFC will obtain detachable warrants free of charge that give IFC the right to subscribe up to $10 million of the companys common equity.

Project Description: The project company, PT. Indorama Synthetics Tbk (Indorama), is a large international competitive export oriented producer of polyester fiber and filament yarns, PET resin, spun yarns and finished fabrics.  The aim of the project is for Indorama to construct, own and operate a 60 MW captive power plant primarily for its internal use.
Role:
The project will secure dependable electricity supply to the project company and ensure that the Indorama continues contributing to Indonesia's export earnings.  Investment climate in Indonesia, although improving, remains largely tenuous, particularly for international investors.  IFC's involvement in the project would demonstrate that it is possible to structure cross-boarder financing transaction in this still difficult business environment.

The proposed IFC investment will provide long-term financing to support major capital expenditures which is not readily available in Indonesia.  IFC's involvement in the project also provides in-house expertise in power generation which is valuable to the project company.

Company Name: TRADE AND DEVELOPMENT BANK OF MONGOLIA LLC
Project Description:
Trade & Development Bank of Mongolia (TDB or the bank) was established in October 1990 by Government resolution under the name of State Bank of Mongolia (International), and started operations on January 1991 with the main purpose of managing the foreign trade and commercial activities of the Government of Mongolia. In October 1993, the bank changed its denomination to TDB. 

In April 1998, the Government of Mongolia sold 24% of its shares to employees while retaining the remaining 76% and, in December 2002, as part of the 2001-2004 privatization strategy, TDB was totally privatized.

IFC is considering an investment of up to the equivalent of $1.5 million representing an up to 10% equity stake. In addition to the equity investment, IFC is also considering a US$ denominated subordinated loan of up to $3.5 million, with a tenor of 7 years.
Role:
-  Development Impact:

Since TDB's privatization in December 2002 both Consortium and ING representatives have commented favorably on the constructive role which IFC and ADB representatives and consultants have played. Given TDB's prominent position in Mongolia's fragile economy, there can be little doubt of the important developmental role that a future IFC investment would fulfill.

-  Catalytic and demonstration effect: 

IFC's investment will demonstrate to the general public that privatization has produced clear and tangible positive results for Mongolia. IFC's support for the current Government of Mongolia privatization policy demonstrates that it is fair and in the country's best interest. 

In time, and with the support of IFC, TDB expects to act as a catalyst for the development of a legal framework for new financial products such as mortgage lending, leasing, factoring and general and life insurance  basic financial service activities which are currently at inception or weak to the point where they impinge upon the country's ability for further development.

-  Financial reforms and FDI attraction: 

Mongolia has seen only limited foreign direct investment to date. IFC's investment in TDB following its successful privatization will raise awareness within the international community as to Mongolia's financial stability. It will create an environment in which foreign investors will feel less exposed and will be a sign to foreign corporations that IFC is sufficiently confident in Mongolia's banking sector and future investors will feel less exposed.

-  Promotion of competitiveness in banking sector: 

This investment is designed to strengthen Mongolia's commercial banking sector. Although TDB's ING-seconded management has been given full authority by the Consortium to manage the bank without intrusion, both the Consortium and the ING management is keen for IFC to play a leading role in terms of the development and implementation of best practices in Mongolia's largest bank which, in turn, will set higher standards for the entire sector as well.

Advancement of best practices and corporate governance: 

IFC will be teamed with financial partners of international standing to promote quality services such as ensuring borrowers' compliance with good corporate governance requirements, hedging currency and metals price risk, ability for co-financing and loan syndication, handling of trade related requirements in the framework of specific projects. Introduction of new financing techniques will be cost effective for borrowers and will result in trade promotion. This proposed investment represents a clear signal that IFC has confidence in TDB's management, strategy, and potential.

IFC Role:

Mongolia's financial sector remains in its nascent stages. The sector requires support from the international financial institutions to develop all its aspects in accordance with international best practices, including retail and corporate lending, mortgage finance, leasing, and insurance.

IFC's investment in TDB will help to ensure the future sustainability of Mongolia's largest and longest standing financial institution and will have a significant developmental impact. As a minority shareholder, IFC would have access to valuable market intelligence and that would prove to be an excellent source of information as to the major issues facing business in Mongolia, including banking regulations, tax and bankruptcy laws. The lessons learned from this investment should result in other investment opportunities that contribute to the sustained growth of Mongolia's financial sector.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an FI Type 1 project. TDB will be required to develop an environmental management system. TDB must require that investments under relevant operations meet host country environmental, health and safety requirements.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor:
TDB shareholding structure is currently the following: Globull Investment & Development Management S.A. ('Globull') with 76.0%, Mongol Postal Bank with 13.9% (2.9% direct and 11.0% indirect participation) and other minority shareholders with 10.1%.

Globull was established by Ernst & Young at the request of the consortium consisting of Gerald UK (a wholly owned subsidiary of GMI) and BCL in Luxemburg in December 2002, with registered head-office in Luxembourg.

GMI, the leading partner in the Consortium, has over 30 years of trading and merchant banking experience in Asia, including a 20-year physical presence in the region, and its interest in TDB stemmed from its historical links to the Mongolian copper and gold trade. On its turn BCL may participate in some of the GMI initiated Mongolian-sourced merchant banking transactions and, at some future time, transfer their asset management expertise to TDB.

Institutional & Government Advisory (IGA), a wholly owned subsidiary of ING, was appointed as manager of TDB and a Management and Technical Assistance Agreement has been signed between all counterparts.
Cost Nature:
The proposed project consists of an IFC investment of up to $5 million in TDB, in Mongolia.

The investment will have two components:
-  an equity participation in the form of a rights issue of up to the equivalent of $1.5 million representing an up to 10% equity stake; and,
-  a US$ denominated subordinated loan of up to $3.5 million, with a tenor of 7 years.
Investment: 5.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan3.50Equity1.50* These investment figures are indicative
Location: TDB is headquartered in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia. The bank has a network of 8 branches (3 in Ulanbaataar and 5 in the most important regional hubs) and 7 settlement centers covering the major population and economic centers.

TDB must require that investments under relevant operations meet host country environmental, health and safety requirements.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Description:
Detroit Belarus Brewing Company LLC, (DBBC or the company) is the special purpose vehicle, which was incorporated in New Jersey, USA for the privatization of OJSC Dednovo Brewery ('Dednovo'), a brewery located in Bobruisk, Mohilev Region, in central Belarus. This will be the first privatization of a brewery involving western investors and among the few privatizations in Belarus. 

In 1990s, Dednovo used to be the second largest brewery in Belarus and the largest employer in the city of Bobruisk.  In September 2002, it ceased regular operations in due to lack of working capital and investment funds to implement the necessary capital improvements. The project will refurbish, modernize and expand Dednovo's facilities to produce a consistent and high quality beer for the Belorussian market. The project will also develop a distribution system and brands for Dednovo's beer.
Role:
The project will be the first brewery privatization involving a western investor and among the few privatizations completed in Belarus.  IFC's participation provides political risk cover and comfort to the sponsor. IFC's involvement as an honest broker will also provide comfort to the government that the transaction is fair to all parties.  The successful and visible privatization of Dednovo will have significant demonstration impacts beyond the immediate sector.  The project is likely to be a catalyst for further FDI in Belarus where such investments have lagged.  In addition to providing long-term financing on terms presently unavailable in Belarus, IFC's presence would be instrumental in attracting additional financing from a co-financier or equipment supplier to complete the Financing Plan.

The project will generate significant benefits to the Belarus economy and create a strong base for economic growth in the beverage industry in Belarus. It will fully rehabilitate the existing productive assets and upgrade and modernize the equipment to international standards.  The project will support more than 300 employees, most of whom were laid off when the plant ceased regular operations in 2002. Additional jobs will also be created as the company develops its transport and distribution network. Through procurement of local goods and services, the project will also establish strong linkages to suppliers and other SMEs.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor:
The project sponsor is DI Belarus Brewing Ltd., a private company incorporated in Cyprus. The sponsor is 100% owned by Detroit Investments Ltd., which is controlled by Eugene Kashper (26%), Edenbury Holdings Limited (51%) and members of the management team (24%) (collectively referred to as the 'Individuals'). Edenbury Holdings Limited is controlled by Arkady Livshits. The Individuals have been in the beer business since 1992 and were successful in turning around three Russian breweries, launching and promoting national brands, and establishing a nationwide distribution network in Russia.  The Individuals' Russian brewery arm, Pivovarni Ivan Taranova (PIT) is a fast-growing beer company which captured 5% of the Russian beer market within the first four years of operations.

DBBC will be owned by DI Belarus (77%), IFC (20%), and Lebortovo Investments Ltd. (3%) ('Lebortovo'). Lebortovo is a Cyprus-based company wholly owned by Sergei Levin, a Belorussian national and the CEO of DBBC.
Cost Nature: Total project cost is estimated at $31.3 million. The proposed IFC investment is an A Loan for IFC's own account of up to $7 million and an equity investment of up to $3 million.
Investment: 10.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan7.0Equity3.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location:
Dednovo is located in on a large site in Bobruisk, Mohilev Region, 100 Km from Minsk in Central Belarus. The production facility was built in the mid 1970s and is in need of refurbishment. Water is supplied from three wells and is of adequate quality. Electricity is supplied from the grid and gas for its boilers is supplied by the local gas company via pipeline. The site is accessible by rail and roads.

With the necessary refurbishments, the brewery has the potential to brew significant quantities of high quality beer.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. Project Description:
Microfinance Bank Romania S.A. (MIRO Bank) is a licensed commercial bank, regulated and supervised by the National Bank of Romania. MIRO Bank, which began operations on July 1, 2002, is a specialized provider of financial services to micro and small businesses as well as low-income individuals in Romania. 

The purpose of the IFC investment is to assist MIRO Bank to achieve outreach on a scale that will ensure the availability of financial services to the vast numbers of the population who are currently marginalized by the formal financial sector, and to facilitate the organization's permanent self-sufficiency and sustainability.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an FI Type 1 project. Project Description: Jointly, Carvajal S.A. and Carvajal Internacional S.A. (or the company), the Colombian and international holding companies of a leading privately-owned Colombian conglomerate founded in 1904, whose core business lines include: -  paper manufacturing and conversion; -  school and office supplies; -  phone directories (yellow pages); -  plastic packaging; and -  book and textbook editing and publishing (the Project Core Businesses). The companys expansion, rationalization and modernization plans in the 2003-2007 period, to help its Project Core Businesses to grow (organically and through acquisitions), to become leaders in their sectors, and to achieve international competitiveness.  In particular, the project includes the following components: -  Paper Manufacturing/Conversion: Modernizing  and rationalizing its existing plants; -  School/Office Supplies: Modernizing its facility in Brazil, and expanding its operations, mainly in Mexico and Brazil; -  Yellow Pages: Rationalizing and growing its operations in Brazil; -  Book and Text Book Publishing/Editing: Growing its operations in Mexico and Spain; and -  Plastic Packaging: Modernizing its Colombian facilities, and expanding its operations there and in Mexico.  In addition, the project will also contemplate environmental and social and health and safety improvements at some of the companys facilities in and outside Colombia.
Role: The project, which will improve the operational performance of each of Carvajals Project Core Businesses, will have several beneficial impacts: -  Employment and growth:  increased output, productivity and associated rise in income in the relevant countries.  This is especially relevant in poor / underprivileged areas south of Cali, which is in the conflict area and which otherwise offers few employment options; -  Regional Focus: Carvajal is embarking on a program that will result in investments in most Latin American countries, including those which have limited access to capital markets (such as Central America), and those in which private sector investments have decreased substantially, such as Brazil; -  High-quality products / services: the focus on reducing operating costs as well as improving employee training and product quality will result in competitively priced, high-quality products for consumers in the region.  In addition, in becoming a more important player in the publishing/editing business, the company is expected to develop into the preferred venue for Spanish-speaking writers or overseas publishing houses wishing to find distribution channels throughout Latin America.  Moreover, increasing the supply of written material in Latin America at more affordable prices is expected to have a positive impact in the populations reading index throughout the region; -  Competitiveness: the investment will make Carvajal more internationally competitive, thereby allowing Colombia and other Latin America countries to increase sales to export markets and improve technical know-how; -  Environment:  the Project will raise the companys environmental and safety standards, often times also resulting in cost savings and improved employee morale, and -  Community development: the success and profitability of Carvajal will help to extend the operations of the Carvajal, Hernando Carvajal B, and Propal Foundations in the communities in Aguablanca and Caloto. IFCs involvement with the company will signal a strong vote of confidence for the Colombian private sector.  Given Colombias loss of its investment grade rating in 1999, recent economic recession, political uncertainty and liquidity constraints in the domestic banking sector, consistent access to long-term investment capital (especially from foreign sources) has decreased even for the blue chip companies.  IFCs investment in the company will provide long-term financing for an independent, professionally-managed Colombian conglomerate and show support for the countrys private enterprises.  In addition, IFCs investment is expected to allow the company to accelerate its investment program, notably with respect to acquisitions.  IFCs involvement and advice is also expected to positively impact the Companys environmental, corporate governance and financial reporting standards with the goal of bringing them in line with international best-practice standards.  The project would also extend support to cross-border market operations in Latin America, including those in poorer Andean and Caribbean countries where Carvajal operates.
Environmental Social Issues: The project is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental impacts may result or which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The following environmental, health, and safety issues were analyzed: -  health, safety and environmental management including energy efficiency and use of raw materials; -  air and water emissions; -  community development and social programs.  Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityEnvironmental documents will be made available at the following locations:On the company website www.carvajal.com.co and At the companys headquarters Carvajal S.A., Calle 29 Norte 6A-40, Cali, Colombia  (copies will also be kept at the security office of Carvajal).
Sponsor: The project sponsors are Carvajal S.A. and Carvajal Internacional S.A., respectively the local and international holding entities of the company.  Both these holdings are privately-held and registered in Colombia, with the former having its principal business in Colombia, and the latter extending throughout the Latin American region, and with some operations in the US and Spain.Carvajal S.A. is 64.2% owned by members of the Carvajal family of Colombia, and 35.8% by the Fundacion Carvajal and the Fundación Hernando Carvajal B, foundations set up by the Carvajal family in 1961 to do philanthropic / charitable work in Cali, Colombia.  Carvajal Internacional S.A. is wholly owned by the Carvajal family.
Cost Nature: To be determined.
Investment: 70.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan50.0Equity20.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The company is headquartered in Cali, Colombia and has operations across 14 sectors in 17 countries throughout Latin America, the United States and Spain, with approximately 36% of its revenue derived from outside Colombia.  The intended project investments are expected to be made across several countries for each of the project Core Businesses as follows: -  Paper Manufacturing and Conversion: investments will be made at the facilities outside Cali, Colombia; -  School and Office Supplies: Capex will be used to modernize/grow the existing facilities in Colombia, Brazil and Mexico, and to expand in Peru, Chile and Brazil; -  Yellow Pages: Modernize/expand operations in Brazil, -  Book and Text Book Editing/Publishing: Expand operations in Spain and Mexico, and -  Plastic Packaging: Expansion in Colombia and potentially building of a new ground-up facility in Mexico.

The following environmental, health, and safety issues were analyzed: -  health, safety and environmental management including energy efficiency and use of raw materials; -  air and water emissions; -  community development and social programs. Project Description:
The project is to provide Victoriabank (VB or the bank), Moldova's 3rd largest commercial bank, with a $5 million loan for IFC's own account.  The loan would have a final maturity of seven years and will be used by the bank for on lending to private Moldovan enterprises, including those operating in the housing sector.

Over the last couple of years the recovery of Moldovan economy has led to the rising demand for housing.  Generally the country is faced with the low quality of the existing housing stock, increased housing deficit, and a low housing affordability.  Recently this situation translated into a lot of construction starts and rising real estate prices due to the increased purchasing power of the population and unmet demand for quality dwelling.  Concurrently, Victoriabank began lending to real estate developers and extending housing  loans to individuals. The bank is planning to continue developing this business line.  However, the local banking sector is still facing difficulties in accessing long term funding.  By extending a seven-year loan to VB, IFC could provide Moldovan companies and individuals with much needed financing of longer tenor.  The proposed project would complement IFC's support to Moldovan SMEs channeled through projects with Moldinconbank, Fincombank and Victoriabank.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an FI type 2 project.  Victoriabank will need to demonstrate that its existing EMS can address the environmental and social issues that may arise from providing loans to housing developers under this line.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor:
Victoriabank was established in 1989 as one of the first private commercial banks in the former Soviet Union.  VB offers traditional commercial banking activities to private companies and retail customers.  The bank was reorganized in 1995, at which time 58,75% of the shareholding was bought by foreign investors.  The current shareholding structure is as follows:

Danube Fund, 23.03%
EBRD, 15.06%
Alpha Bank Romania, 12.50%
LR-Uniune SRL, 9.81%
Intrade Management, 5.61%
Victor Turcanu, 10.45%
Other, mostly Moldovan entities,  23.54%

The largest shareholder, the Danube Fund, is an off shore limited liability fund based in Cyprus.  It is sponsored by Alpha Credit Bank of Greece (21%), EBRD (20%), IFC (11%) and others.  Mr. Turcanu, the bank's president, owns  10.45% of Victoriabank's shares.  Most of VB's top management has been with the Bank since its establishment.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $5 million and consists of an A Loan for IFC's own account.
Investment: 5.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan5.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Victoriabank is headquartered in Chisinau, the capital of Moldova and has  11 branches (including 3 in Chisinau) throughout the entire country and 6 agencies.  Its traditional area of geographic focus is Chisinau, the main economic center of Moldova containing about a quarter of the country's population.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is an FI type 2 project.  Victoriabank will need to demonstrate that its existing EMS can address the environmental and social issues that may arise from providing loans to housing developers under this line.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Description: Tecon Rio Grande S.A. (TRG or the company) was awarded a 25-year lease through a public tender in 1997 to expand and operate the container terminal (the Terminal) in the port of Rio Grande, Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil.  The Terminal was the second Brazilian container facility to be privatized and is currently the second largest container terminal in Brazil, accounting for approximately 12% of the country''s total container movement.  The proposed project is the expansion of the Terminal, and comprises civil works associated with building a third berth of 250 meters and improvements in the container stacking area, together with purchase of additional equipment, including two additional Post-Panamax gantry cranes, three rubber tired gantry cranes and seven trucks.  The expansion will increase the annual capacity of the Terminal from 300,000 container-moves to about 525,000 container-moves, easing capacity constraints and allowing TRG to capture unmet demand for the Terminals services.This project would be the second one to be financed by IFC.  In December 1998, IFC financing (a $31 million loan comprising an A-Loan of $7.5 million, a B-loan of $18 million and a C-Loan of $5.5 million) supported the purchase of four cranes, a 300-meter extension of an existing quay, and repair and upgrading of various facilities.
Role: TRG has had, and will continue to have, a significant development impact with notable private sector development and substantial benefits accruing to its stakeholders.  The project is expected to continue raising the overall efficiency of transportation infrastructure in southern Brazil, reduce transport costs for exporters in the state of Rio Grande do Sul, provide increased employment in the town of Rio Grande, and generate increasing amounts of foreign exchange, tax and other revenues for federal, state and local government including the Port Authority of Rio Grande (SUPRG).  Since 1997, TRG has provided its customers better service and the ability to move more containers through the terminal while simultaneously lowering tariffs; it has also made a substantial contribution to the regional and state economy by generating employment, taxes and royalties and by providing financial support to a number of social projects and activities in the community.  TRG has also devoted significant effort in building and maintaining a productive and amicable relationship with the stevedores union, which views this relationship as best practice.  In the seven years since inception, TRG has increased its own employment by ten-fold and increased its use of non-employee contract labor (stevedores and tallyclerks) by three-fold.  Looking forward, the proposed project will enable TRG to build upon its existing strengths and continue to generate significant development impact for its customers, employees and the community.IFCs investment in the proposed project would provide TRG necessary long-term financing, thereby assisting a local, medium-size company in expanding a highly successful operation that will further enhance transportation infrastructure in the state of Rio Grande do Sul, strengthen the competitiveness of exports from the region, generate significant economic and social benefits for the region and provide additional foreign exchange revenues for Brazil.  IFCs presence would also provide comfort to potential B loan participants/parallel lenders, given that IFC would be making a second loan to TRG.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The review of this project consisted of appraising technical and environmental/social information submitted by the project sponsor.IFC''s original appraisal in 1998 analyzed potential environmental, health and safety issues associated with dredging and land reclamation, protection of coastal resources, control of storm water run-off and protection of water resources, liquid effluents, solid waste management, handling and storage of dangerous cargoes, fire prevention and emergency response, and general employee safety.  The appraisal for the current project confirmed the effectiveness of the company''s ongoing environmental management as evidenced by its compliance status and improvements that have been implemented.  The appraisal also reviewed the potential environmental impacts of expanding the Terminal under the current project and the mitigation proposed, and confirmed that the project will meet Government of Brazil requirements, and World Bank Group policies and guidelines.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityEnvironmental documents will be made available at the following locations:At the companys offices at the terminal  Av. Almirante Maximiano Fonseca, 201-40 Secção da Barra, Rio Grande RS CEP 96204-040, BrazilAt the offices of SUPRG - Superintendência do Porto do Rio Grande, Honorio Bicalho Av., W/N  Mailbox 198  Rio Grande  RS BrazilAt the office of the City of Rio Grande  Largo João Fernandes Moreira , sem nª - Centro  - Rio Grande  - RS BrasilAt the office of the Rio Grande Chamber of Commerce -  Praça Xavier Ferreira 430, Centro  Rio Grande RS Brasil.
Sponsor: The shareholders of TRG are Wilson Sons de Administração e Comércio LTDA (Wilson); Serveng Civilsan S.A. Empresas Associadas de Engenharia  (Serveng); and Concorp TRG Projectos Portuários S.A. (Concorp).  Their shareholding in TRG and a description of their main activities are as follows:Wilson    50.2%Serveng   24.9%Concorp  24.9%-  WilsonWilson is a Brazilian maritime group which has operated in Brazil since 1837.  It is a wholly-owned subsidiary of Ocean Wilson Holdings Limited (OWH), a UK-listed company.  Wilsons operations include port towage services, shipyard and shipping, ship agency, port operations, and logistics.  Port towage services are Wilsons largest operation and its market share for private tugboat services in Brazil is 55%, with a fleet of 60 tugboats in 17 Brazilian ports.  Its shipyard and shipping division has traditionally built and maintained small vessels, including tugboats, both for itself and third parties such as the Brazilian navy; more recently, Wilson has diversified into the manufacturing, maintenance and management of off-shore platform supply vessels.  Wilsons ship agency manages port visits and provides services for vessels visiting port, and is the leading shipping agency in Brazil for general cargo and containers, handling approximately 11% of all Brazilian cargo.  -  ServengServeng is a privately held, mid-size Brazilian engineering and construction company with project experience in transportation (roads, airports, tunnels, ports, bridges), hydroelectric dams, water treatment plants, mining, and commercial real estate.  In the port sector, Serveng has been involved in the construction of piers and quays for passenger terminals, bulk grain and mineral terminals, fishing terminals and general cargo/container terminals.  -  ConcorpConcorp is a special purpose vehicle that is majority-owned by directors of the Fator Group, a privately held Brazilian financial services company.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $25 million.  The project cost is planned to be financed by:  -  equity and cash flow from operations of $8.8 million; -  an A loan from IFC of up to $8.1 million;  -  and either a B loan or a parallel loan of up to $8.1 million.
Investment: 8.10 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan8.10Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The Terminal is located in the port of Rio Grande about seven kilometers south of the city of Rio Grande on the western bank of the Rio Grande River, and about five kilometers north of the entrance of the port.  The port of Rio Grande is Brazils southernmost port located about 200 kilometers north of Brazils border with Uruguay.  The Terminal has a total area of 67 hectares, a total quay length of 600 meters and draft of 12.2 meters (40 feet).

The appraisal for the current project confirmed the effectiveness of the company''s ongoing environmental management as evidenced by its compliance status and improvements that have been implemented. Project Description: Armeconombank (AEB or the bank) is one of the largest, privately controlled banks in Armenia and is the successor of Zhilsotzbank, one of the former state-owned banks.  It is the 4th largest bank in Armenia in terms of assets, with 24 branches across the country and 450 employees.  Today the bank focuses on serving SMEs, retail clients, and financial institutions.  AEB had the net worth of approximately $5.3 million and total assets of approximately $33.4 million equivalent as of the end of 2003.  The proposed $2.0 million senior loan to AEB, to broaden the bank's funding base for on-lending to SMEs and for residential housing projects, would be IFC's first investment in the Armenian commercial banking sector.  IFC will also consider an equity investment of up to $1.0 million to support AEB's capital base.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category FI type 2 project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  AEB will be required to establish an environmental management system satisfactory to IFC, to ensure that lending under this project complies with applicable host country requirements and IFC''s Exclusion Lists, policies, and guidelines.  Any investment by AEB in a Category A project will require the prior approval of IFC.  AEB will designate two key staff who will have responsibility for environmental affairs, and who will attend IFC''s environmental workshop;  and AEB will submit Annual Environmental Performance Reports to IFC.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: The bank is majority-owned by Sukiasyan family (68%) and 1,400 minority shareholders.  The Sukiasyan family controls the SIL Group, an industrial holding composed of over 20 private enterprises engaged in production, trade, construction, services, and banking.  The SIL Group first began its activities in 1989, as one of the first limited liability companies in Armenia and today has about 6,500 employees.
Cost Nature: The project consists of a $2.0 million senior loan to Armeconombank to broaden the bank's funding base for on-lending to SMEs and for financing residential housing projects and an equity investment of up to $1.0 million to support the Bank's capital base.
Investment: 2.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan2.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Armeconombank is headquartered in Yerevan and has 24 branches across Armenia.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category FI type 2 project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  AEB will be required to establish an environmental management system satisfactory to IFC, to ensure that lending under this project complies with applicable host country requirements and IFC''s Exclusion Lists, policies, and guidelines.  Any investment by AEB in a Category A project will require the prior approval of IFC.  AEB will designate two key staff who will have responsibility for environmental affairs, and who will attend IFC''s environmental workshop;  and AEB will submit Annual Environmental Performance Reports to IFC.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Description: The proposed project consists of a long term local currency loan of up to $50 million to Saudi British Bank (the 'SABB' or the Bank'), based in Riyadh Saudi Arabia. SABB is one of Saudi Arabia's leading commercial banks, offering a wide range of financial services, including corporate, personal and investment banking. The proposed project is aimed at providing much needed long term financing to support the growth of SABB's nascent mortgage lending program. SABB started its mortgage lending program three years ago and is now the leading provider of mortgage loans in Saudi Arabia.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an environmental and social Category C project, according to IFCs procedure for Environmental and Social Review.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: SABB was established in 1978 with the takeover of the Saudi operations of the British Bank of the Middle East (BBME).  SABB is now a joint venture bank with 60% owned by Saudi nationals and 40% owned by HSBC.  With  total assets of around $12.3 billion as of end 2003 and market share of 9.4%, SABB is currently the fifth largest bank in Saudi Arabia.  The Bank has signed a Technical Services Agreement (TSA) with HSBC.  The TSA provides SABB with access to the systems, technology and expertise of HSBC group, and enables the Bank to offer its client new products and services still unavailable in Saudi Arabia.
Cost Nature: The total financing targeted under the long term funding mobilization program is estimated at around $100 million. IFC is expected to provide up to $50 million under this proposed project and the remaining $50 million will come from other parallel lenders.  The IFC loan will be in local currency and may be structured as a Sharia compliant instrument.
Investment: 50.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan50.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: SABB's head office is in Riyadh, Kingdom of Saudi Arabia. The Bank currently has 77 branches including a branch in London which provides a full range of banking services.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is an environmental and social Category C project, according to IFCs procedure for Environmental and Social Review.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Name: University of the West Indies-Institute of Business
Company Name: UNIVERSITY OF THE WEST INDIES - INSTITUTE OF BUSINESS
Project Description: The UWI Institute of Business, St. Augustine (IOB or the company), a collaborative venture between the University of West Indies (UWI) and the local private sector, is a private, not-for-profit entity created in 1989 through private endowment funds sourced from local businesses. It provides business education in the form of part-time post graduate programs (predominantly MBAs), training and consulting services as well as research capabilities. The project is to construct and equip a new campus equipped with modern teaching and learning amenities for an estimated cost of  $10 million. The new campus will present IOB with the opportunity to increase its market share of the growing domestic and regional demand for post graduate education, further broaden its strategic linkages with other established international educational institutions and allow the Institute to expand and diversify its offerings.
Role: The project will have a strong development impact in widening access to graduate business education in Trinidad and Tobagothe private returns to which are extremely highand increasing the supply of skilled personnel, for which there is strong demand. A cadre of skilled managers and entrepreneurs is needed to help develop the private sector, particularly the energy sector, which is estimated to grow rapidly over the next decade. IOB will help to reduce the shortfall by enlarging its program and providing practical business education, tailored to local needs. In addition, IOB, will expand its training of public sector personnel, for which it was named a 'Center of Excellence,' by the Commonwealth Secretariat. It will thus help to meet the country's critical demand for training and institution-building required to strengthen public sector management and reform.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a Category B project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure because limited environmental and social impacts associated with the project may be mitigated through adherence to industry best practices, recognized performance standards, guidelines, and design criteria. Environmental, social and occupational health and safety issues associated with this type of project and that will be evaluated during appraisal include: land acquisition, compensation and prior use; site location, planning and permitting; solid waste management; wastewater treatment and disposal; potable water; air emissions from on-site generators and other utilities; heat exchange chemicals used in air conditioning systems; energy use management; managing environmental impacts during construction; student and worker occupational health and safety; and life and fire safety.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityAn Environmental Review Summary report for the project has been prepared by International Finance Corporation as part of its environmental and social due diligence.  The Environmental Review Summary report will be available for public review starting May 04, 2004 on the IFC website and at the following places:

UWI Institute of Business, Cor. Churchill Roosevelt Highway and Pasea Road, Tunapuna Monday to Friday, 8:00am and 4:30pm

UWI Institute of Business Campus Project Site Office, Uriah Butler Highway, Champs FleursMonday to Friday, 8:00am to 4:30 pm

UWI Institute of Business Websitehttp://www.uwi-iob.org
Sponsor:
The project sponsors consist of all parties contributing to the project's financing (and/or collateral) including, among others:

-  Mr. Arthur Lok-Jack  (Director of IOB, Chairman of Associated Brands Group of Companies, Guardian Life Ltd., Guardian General Insurance Ltd., and Director of various other private companies in TT)
-  Republic Bank Ltd.
-  Hydro Agri Trinidad Ltd.
-  Ministry of Science, Technology and Tertiary Education

IOB is a company limited by guarantee with no shareholders (or share capital) but rather Members. It is governed by a Board of Directors that includes some of the leading business people in the country. Its parent, UWI, is an autonomous public institution sponsored by the regional governments. It does not have financial or operational control of the IOB, apart from the oversight provided by its member representatives on the Board, and academic quality control. The seed capital to establish the IOB was sourced from public grants, donations (cash and in kind) from private sector companies and individual benefactors. It has the status of a tax-exempt charitable institution.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $10 million.  The proposed IFC investment is a $5 million A loan for IFC's own account.
Investment: 5.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan5.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The land was recently made available to the Institute by the Government of the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago (GORTT), on a 99-year lease at a token annual lease of TT$10. It is a 3.5 hectare-State Land designated for the purpose of establishing permanent teaching and learning facilities. The site is located on the western side of the Uriah Butler Highway, Mount Hope, in the University belt of the East-West corridor of Trinidad's business sector. It is approximately 20 minutes drive from the city center of the financial capital of the Caribbean, Port of Spain and 10 minutes away from Piarco International Airport, and is within easy reach of transport, housing and amenities.

This is a Category B project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure because limited environmental and social impacts associated with the project may be mitigated through adherence to industry best practices, recognized performance standards, guidelines, and design criteria.
