Project Description:
The green field project supports the mortgage-lending activities of La Hipotecaria ('LH' or the company), the only specialized full-service housing finance company in Panama and El Salvador.  The company controls over 10% of the  residential mortgage market in Panama and a negligible amount in El Salvador where LH began operations in November of 2003.  The company specializes in originating and servicing residential mortgages to individuals mostly in the low to middle income segment of the market.  

In order to free up its balance sheet to continue expanding its lending activities, the company has developed a successful business of originating and securitizing mortgages in Panama. Over the past five years, the company has issued four separate mortgage-backed securities ('MBS'), amounting to over $45 million and holds on balance sheet a mortgage loan portfolio of $29 million as of March 31, 2004.  LH now wants to use the same formula to expand into El Salvador, targeting its lending activities towards the low to middle income segment of the market and eventually selling the mortgages to  investors in El Salvador and Panama via an MBS issue.  

The primary purpose of the IFC facility is to: 

-  support LH's existing mortgage finance operations in Panama, 
-  assist the company expand its operations into El Salvador, and 
-  enable the company put in place a viable structure to facilitate its planned MBS issues in El Salvador.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category C project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  The nature of LH''s portfolio (low to middle income residential mortgages) means that there will be minimal environmental impacts associated this investment.  Therefore, no further environmental or social analysis is required.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: The project sponsor is La Hipotecaria. The company is primarily owned by Gropo ASSA, S.A, a diversified holding company, whose primary asset is ASSA Compañía de Seguros, the largest insurance company in Panama in terms of shareholders equity.  Gropo ASSA which controls 87% of the shareholdings of the company is a publicly held company with over 600 shareholders. The MEK Foundation, a Panamanian Foundation which represents the interests of the family of the CEO of the company, John Rauschkolb controls the remaining 13% of the company.
Cost Nature:
The proposed investment for IFC's own account consists of : 

-  a 3 year $15 million Loan for the company's operations in Panama; and 
-  a 7 year $20 million Loan for its El Salvador Operations.  

This investment is structured such that IFC's combined exposure to the Company will not at no time exceed $20 million during the term of both loans.
Investment: 15.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan15.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The location of the project is in the company's office sites in Panama City , Panama and San Salvador, El Salvador.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category C project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  The nature of LH''s portfolio (low to middle income residential mortgages) means that there will be minimal environmental impacts associated this investment.  Therefore, no further environmental or social analysis is required.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Description: The proposed project consists of a subordinated loan of $50 million to Turkiye Sinai Kalkinma Bankasi (TSKB or the company), Turkey's largest term-lending institution.  Founded in 1950 with assistance from the World Bank, TSKB has played an active role in Turkey's economic development and has provided medium term loans to more than 3,500 projects.  It has also invested in the equity of more than 100 companies. The purpose of this investment is to strengthen TSKB's tier II capital and thereby enable it to expand its balance sheet.  TSKB is the borrower of choice for multi-lateral credit lines and therefore, this project will enable TSKB to enhance availability of medium term funding for capital investment by Turkish private sector companies.
Role:
The developmental impact of this project would include: 

-  providing term funding to Turkish corporates at a time when term funding is scarce, 
-  sending an important signal of support to the Turkish banking system, and 
-  strengthening TSKB's capital structure and expanding its financial intermediary capacity.

IFC's role in this project is to:

-  provide long term capital, not otherwise locally available, to an institution that is central to Turkey's economic development, and 
-  to signal support and confidence in the long term prospects of the Turkish private sector that TSKB will ultimately serve.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category FI type 2 project according to IFC''s Environmental Review Procedures.  The client will be expected to ensure that each sub-project complies with Turkish EHS requirements as well as the IFC Exclusion List; to prepare an Environmental Management Plan (EMP) acceptable to IFC, including an Environmental Policy and Project Review Procedure (for sub-projects); nominate two individuals with responsibility for the EHS due diligence process, including one individual at the senior level for overall corporate responsibility for the process and one as the coordinator to complete the sub-project due diligence; the two nominees to attend IFC''s CEA Workshop as soon as practical; do not support any Category A projects without prior IFC approval; and provide IFC with Annual Environmental Performance Reports (AEPRs) in a form and content acceptable to IFC.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: TSKB has a strong ownership structure.  Principal shareholders are: Isbank (40.52%), Isbank group of companies (14.78%), Vakifbank (8.38%), Akbank (6.45%), Sabanci group (3.21%), Garanti Bank (3.09%), Dis Bank (2.56%) and TSKB Pension Fund (1.70%).  25% of TSKB's shares are publicly held and are traded on the Istanbul stock exchange.
Cost Nature: TSKB plans to augment its capital structure with tier II capital of $50 million.  This increase is expected to be met entirely from the proposed IFC investment of $50 million in TSKB's subordinated debt.

Project Description: The proposed project is to build and operate an 18,000 mt/yr acrylic fiber plant in Alexandria, Egypt.  The project site is adjacent to the operations of Alexandria Carbon Black (ACB or the company), a member of the Aditya Birla Group of India and a longstanding client of IFC.  The facility will be the only acrylic plant in Egypt and ACB will provide utilities (electricity and steam) to the acrylic plant.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The review of this project consisted of appraising technical and environmental/social information submitted by the project sponsor.  The following potential environment, health and safety and social impacts of the projects were analyzed.-  Site suitability for project;-  Land acquisition procedure;-  Performance of the ACB company, which has common owners and is located adjacent to the project;-  Utilization of waste energy;-  Air emissions, liquid discharges and solid waste management; and-  Health and safety standards.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe full Environmental Review Summary  was published in Arabic language in  El Gomhorya newspaper on May 21, 2004.
Sponsor: The project sponsor is the Aditya Birla Group, one of India's largest business conglomerates with worldwide sales of more than $8 billion in 2002.  The Group is a longstanding client of IFC, in Egypt, India and Thailand and Indonesia.  Major group companies include Grasim Industries (fibers, cement, sponge iron, textiles and chemicals); Hindalco (India's largest aluminum company);  Indian Rayon (apparel, yarn, textiles, carbon black) and Indo Gulf Company (fertilizers).  The Birla Group has an existing presence in the acrylic fiber business through Thai Acrylic, which started operations in 1989. The Birla Group's existing  operation in Egypt is Alexandria Carbon Black, which started production in 1994 and after successive expansions is now the largest single site carbon black plant in the world.  The Aditya Birla Group will own 60% of the equity capital of the new company.  Other shareholders are:  SIDPEC a subsidiary of Egyptian Chemicals Holding Co. owned by the Ministry of Petroleum of the Government of Egypt; APICORP, an investment company established by  the governments of the ten member states of the Organization of Arab Petroleum Exporting Countries (OAPEC) and Saudi Egyptian Industrial Investment Company (SEIIC) an investment company owned  the governments of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia and Arab Republic of Egypt. IFC is also proposing to be a shareholder with a 10% equity stake.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $68.9 million.  The proposed IFC investment consists of a loan for IFC's account of $8 million together with a $2.4 million equity investment for a 10% ownership stake.
Investment: 10.40 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan8.0Equity2.40* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The 35 ha project site is located in Ameyra, Alexandria, 25 Km from the main port of Alexandria on the Mediterranean coast.  The project site is in an industrial zone adjacent to the existing operations of Alexandria Carbon Black., to Alexandria Tire Company, a major local tire producer and to a number of petrochemical facilities.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. Project Description: Lojas Americanas (LASA or the company) is one of the most traditional retail chains in Brazil with a broad range of convenience food, apparel and general merchandise items. In activity for 74 years, the company has 121 stores located around 18 states and in the Federal District of the country, with a concentration of 62% of its stores in the Southeast region. The chain employs around 7,800 people and sells more than 80,000 items from 3,000 different companies. In June 1999, the company launched its web-based retail operations (Americanas.com), which currently receives more than 1 million visitors monthly. LASA is also active in providing financial services, through its fully owned subsidiary Facilta Serviços e Propaganda S.A., which has been operating in the market since 1984. In 1998, in partnership with other companies, Lojas Americanas launched the Smart Club, the first multi-loyalty program in Latin America.The proposed project aims to finance the following components:-  Capital investments to support the expansion of stores in all regions of Brazil, focusing in the North, Northeast and Midwest;-  Expansion of Americanas.com, -  Upgrade of management information systems and-  Working capital requirements.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs procedure for environmental and social review of projects. Environmental, occupational health and safety issues associated with this project include: solid waste treatment and disposal, fire prevention, emergency response, and safety training.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityEnvironmental documents related to the project will be placed in the companys internet site: http:/ri.lasa.com.br/.  In addition, after the store locations have been selected and approved by management and prior to store opening, environmental documents related to the project will be available to the local community at the future store site, or in the board of information of the shopping mall where the store will be located, as well as in the local library or community center closest to the future store site of the city where the store will open.  Environmental documentation will be available at the following locations for public consultation starting on May 5, 2004:-  Bahia, Salvador, Shopping Iguatemi Salvador; address: Av. Antonio Carlos Magalhaes s/n;-  Pernambuco, Recife; address: Rua Sete de Setembro, 267;-  Rio de Janeiro, Laranjerais; address: Av. Das Laranjeiras, 49 a 51.
Sponsor: As of December 31, 2003, LASA''s capital consisted of 25,568,119,211 common shares (39%) and 39,990,164,491 preferred non voting shares (61%). Both types of shares are listed in the Bovespa - São Paulo Stock Exchange (72% float). Lojas Americanas is mainly controlled by Jorge Paulo Lemann, Carlos Alberto Sicupira and Marcel Herrmann Telles, the former senior partners of Banco de Investimentos Garantia and current shareholders of AMBEV, who own approximately 52% of the companys voting shares, through the holding company Varbra S.A.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $70 million. Lojas Americanas has requested IFCs assistance to mobilize up to $35 million for the financing of the project. The proposed IFC investment would include an A Loan of up to $35 million for IFCs own account.

Project Description: Fushe Kruje Cement Factory sh.p.k. (FKCF or the company) is an existing cement manufacturing company, which was privatized in 2000.  The factory was originally constructed as a wet-process plant and had  total capacity of about 250,000 tons per year. At privatization the clinker manufacturing plant was not operational and at present, the cement factory operates only as a cement grinding station using imported clinker. The project will construct a modern dry-process, 3,300 tons per day capacity clinker plant, and install additional cement grinding capacity and a captive power plant. Upon completion the project will have a capacity of about 1.32 million tons per year of cement. The project will supply the local market, which currently imports 87% of the total annual cement and clinker consumption of 1.5 million tons.
Role: The project benefits from its location adjacent to low cost local clay and limestone that allow it to produce clinker and cement at a substantial cost advantage to imports. In addition, it benefits from low capital cost and proximity to the market. The project also benefits Albania by avoiding the high natural import costs associated with poor port infrastructure. Other development impacts include the labor surplus received by the 320 workers to be employed by the company, who would otherwise earn a subsistence income, and health and safety training that workers will receive. IFCs role in the project is to help complete the financial plan, which would otherwise not be possible because of the size of the project and the lack of domestic lending capacity and appropriate external funding sources. IFCs presence will give comfort to other financial institutions to participate in the project. The IFC will also ensure the project is implemented in an environmentally sound manner.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFC''s Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. The review of this project consisted of appraising technical and environmental information submitted by the project sponsor as well as visits to the project site. The following potential environment, health and safety and social impacts of the projects were analyzed:-  Site location and suitability for the project;-  Project documentation and local Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) process;-  Sustainability of raw material supply;-  Quarry rehabilitation plans;-  Air emissions and water management;-  Occupational health and safety; and-  Local social impacts.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe ERS will be available for public view at the factory gate office of Fushe Kruje Cement Factory in Fushe Kruje and at Bashkia Fushe Kruje, Fushe Kruje Town, Albania.
Sponsor: The project sponsor is Seament Holding, a private company 99% owned by Mr. Alexander Bouri, which is engaged in cement trading and manufacture, and shipping. Seament Holding is registered in Lebanon and has been in the cement business for over 35 years.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is $130 million. The proposed investment is a $30 million A loan for IFCs own account.
Investment: 30.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan30.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The project is located in Fushe Kruje, 35 km north of Tirana, the capital city, on a site adjacent to limestone and clay quarries.

Project Description: Algerian Cement Company (ACC, or the company) is Algeria's first and only private cement plant, and is an existing IFC client company. The project consists of increasing ACC's capacity from 2.0 million tons per year ('tpy') to 4.0 million tpy, at an estimated cost of $187 million (named Line II).  The project represents the second phase of the original ACC project (Line I), which was completed in February 2004 within budget and in a record time of 22 months.  The project will be a replicate of the original 2.0 million tpy production line which was supplied by F.L. Smidth (FLS), Denmark.  It will be adjacent to Line I at ACC's production site in Msila, central Algeria, 240 km southeast of Algiers, and will share site infrastructure and utilities already developed for Line I. Construction for Line II started in January 2004 and is expected to be completed in 20 months.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The review of this project consisted of appraising technical and environmental/social information submitted by the project sponsor, as well as IFC staff site visits to the plant site, supporting quarries and impacted communities.  The following potential environment, health and safety and social impacts of the projects were analyzed.-  Post construction evaluation of the suitability of the original site selection;-  Established site access;-  Quarry operation and reclamation planning;-  Final technology evaluation for both the existing cement manufacturing facility and the proposed expansion project;-  Water management and green belt planning;-  Social impacts and management of potential influx of people in local area;-  Labor standards and hiring principles;-  Environmental Management System development; and-  Public consultation practice.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityEnvironmental documents will be made available at the following locations:
Municipality (Wilaya) of Hamma Dalaa, and 
at the plant site in Msila.
Sponsor:
The project's sponsor is Orascom Construction Industries (OCI), Egypt's largest private sector construction conglomerate and a listed company. OCI is part of the Orascom Group controlled by the Sawiris family, one of Egypt's leading business families. The Orascom Group is a diversified group consisting of three main holding companies: Orascom Projects and Tourism Development (OPTD), for tourism-related investments; Orascom Technologies (OT), for telecom, cellular services and information technology; and Orascom Construction Industries (OCI).

OCI has three main business lines: 

-  Construction, providing civil and electro-mechanical engineering and construction services for projects in Egypt and the MENA region; 

-  Building Materials, comprising manufacturing of basic and specialized construction related products such as cement, cement bags and packaging, ready mixed concrete, concrete pipes, steel structures, aluminum and glass curtain walling, paints coatings and industrial gases, and 

-  Infrastructure, consisting mainly of the development of an industrial park and the adjacent port facility in the Ain Sokhna area, and a minority shareholding in a natural gas distribution business. OCI currently has investments in 13 companies including: 

    -  its flagship  Egyptian Cement Company (ECC), a joint venture between OCI and Holcim of Switzerland, with an annual capacity of 7 million tons; and 
     -  Algerian Cement Company (ACC).
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $187 million. The proposed IFC investment is a $20 million A Loan for IFC's own account.
Investment: 20.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan20.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location:
The plant site is located near route CW25 (Bourdj Bourerdj  M'sila) about 25 kilometers north of M'sila, 7 kilometers south east of Hamman Dalaa.  Wilaya of M'sila is in central Algeria some 240 kilometers from Algiers. The site is located on arid (rock dominated) land and the surrounding land is extremely marginal and is not used for agriculture or cultivation.  The location was originally chosen based on technical evaluations and the result of a public consultation, including a focus on avoiding sensitive habitats and avoiding land otherwise used by the local population (hereby avoiding any resettlement), while being as near as possible to high quality raw materials.The sponsor has built a new site access road from the CW25 main road to avoid heavy traffic in the nearby settlement (Debil). Private landowners provided right-of-way access for this purpose and were consulted and provided compensation based on a willing-buyer willing-seller basis. There has been no further physical resettlement or economic displacement caused by the initial project or its infrastructure connections and the expansion will be kept within the existing plant area.

The limestone quarry, which is in operation, is located adjacent to the plant, while the clay quarry is located 17 kilometers from the plant site. High quality gypsum is currently bought from domestic commodity suppliers (there are several supply options), but might later be supplied from deposit located 180 kilometers from the plant site.  The project includes progressive quarry reclamation plans for gradual implementation during the lifetime of the quarries. As an example the limestone quarry has till date had 3,000 m2 of overburden removed and stored for later application in connection with reclamation to create a landscape (profile) in harmony with the existing and surrounding landscape.

This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The review of this project consisted of appraising technical and environmental/social information submitted by the project sponsor, as well as IFC staff site visits to the plant site, supporting quarries and impacted communities. Municipality (Wilaya) of Hamma Dalaa, and 
at the plant site in Msila.

Project Description:
PT. Astra Otoparts Tbk. (AOP or the company) is the largest manufacturer and distributor of automotive parts for cars and motorcycles in the increasingly competitive automotive component industry in Indonesia.  AOP has requested a corporate loan from IFC of up to $24 million to fund the $54 million equivalent project which consists of 

-  capital expenditures of $48.3 million in 2004-2006, to increase production and the product range, at the AOP holding company level and at its nearly 100% owned subsidiaries: PT. Federal Superior Chain Manufacturing, PT. Indokarlo Perkasa and PT. Menara Terus Makmur; and 
-  additional working capital requirement of $5.4 million.  

The project aims to 
-  enhance AOP's competencies in product and process engineering; and 
-  strengthening its position in the replacement markets.
Role:
The project will help the company continue to restructure and improve its competitiveness.  AOP began this process in the wake of the removal of duty protection and domestic content requirements on automotive components in 1999.  The company is focusing on high volume products with high margins and market share.  This project will help AOP expand, de-bottleneck and increase its value-added products.  The project will create 551 direct employees through out the project companies. 

IFC has a strong role in the project by providing long term funding that is not easily available in the local market and by creating a 'demonstration' effect to encourage foreign banks to provide long term funds to sound Indonesian companies with proven track records.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The review of this project consisted of appraising technical and environmental /social information submitted by the project sponsor, along with onsite review of selected manufacturing facilities by technical and environmental staff.  Environmental and social issues which were reviewed for this investment included  the coverage and implementation of its environmental and health and safety management system, as well as review of the development impacts and sustainability.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityEnvironmental documentation will be made available at the following locations
-  At Astra International public library and 
at PT Astra Otoparts Tbk  head office.
Sponsor: AOP is controlled by PT. Astra International (Astra) with 87.3% shareholding.  Astra is a long-standing IFC client and one of the largest Indonesian business conglomerates comprising a holding company with operating activities in six business areas: Automotive (its core business which contributes more than 80% of Astra's consolidated revenues), Information Technology, Financial Services, Agribusiness, Heavy Industry and Infrastructure.  Astra's consolidated net revenue, for 2002 and  2003, was $3.3 billion and $3.7 billion respectively, while its net income was $393 million and $516 million respectively.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is $54 million.  The proposed IFC investment is a loan for IFC's account of up to $24 million.

Project Description:
The proposed project is to establish a fund management operation, Business Partners International (BPI or the company), as the basis for expanding the Business Partners SME financing model to other Sub-Saharan African countries.  The project is designed to support IFC's strategy to develop financing vehicles capable of providing funding and technical support to SMEs on commercial terms and in a sustainable manner.  

Although the SME sector is the engine of economic development in most countries, funding SMEs in the developing world has suffered from three main obstacles:  

-  because of the absence or under-development of real property rights or ownership in many developing countries, it is difficult for borrowers to provide collateral against loans and even more difficult for banks to enforce claims over the collateral;  
-  since most SMEs are lifestyle businesses and small in scale, there is limited upside potential for the equity investor; and 
-  the small size of SMEs means that the costs associated with identifying, processing and monitoring an investment are very high relative to the size of the investment, making most SMEs unattractive for investors.

The project will overcome these obstacles by using quasi-equity instruments that do not necessarily require full collateralization and by using efficient processing and monitoring systems that will improve cost efficiencies.  The project is also designed to support IFC's development of the SME Solutions Center (SSC) network across Africa.  BPI fund management companies in Africa will be co-located within the SSCs to maximize synergies in developing deal flow and providing technical assistance services.
It is expected that initially BPI will establish 3 pilot-phase single-country funds in each of Madagascar (8.5 million or equivalent of $10.0 million), Kenya ($15 million) and a third country in Sub-Saharan Africa to be determined ($10 million) to provide local currency financing for SMEs and to manage a technical assistance facility that will provide technical support and advice to investee companies in each country.
Role:
-  Development Impact

The project is expected to have a powerful developmental impact by overcoming the difficulties associated with funding the SME sector discussed above.  This project will address these obstacles and develop a model for investing in SMEs by:

-  structuring and pricing investments as self-liquidating instruments that will not necessarily require collateral;
-  obtaining cashflow rights that maximize the alignment of interests;
-  using low cost and efficient processes to assess, structure and monitor investments; and
-  providing coordinated and highly focused technical assistance that must demonstrate an acceptable financial return and a solid commercial basis.

-  IFC Role

IFC will play an important role in funding the establishment of BPI and also as an anchor investor in each of the three funds.

-  Fit with World Bank Strategy

The project is designed to fit with the World Bank Group's strategy to: 

-  provide financial and technical support to the development of SMEs in Africa; and 
-  mobilize private sector resources to provide services to SMEs.
Environmental Social Issues: IFC will work with Business Partners to establish an Environmental Management System for Business Partners International and each of the fund management teams.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityNot applicable.
Sponsor:
Business Partners Limited (Business Partners) is a specialized investment group, providing debt and equity financing, mentorship and property management services to SMEs in South Africa.  Since its inception in 1981, Business Partners has developed an effective process for evaluating, structuring and monitoring investments in SMEs.  The process minimizes the cost of processing small investments with little upside potential and aligns the interest of investment staff to maximize value from the investments.  The process also provides critical support and mentoring to the investees and, importantly, could be easily adapted to incorporate a formal technical assistance program.

Although banks typically dominate lending to SMEs in South Africa, Business Partners services an important niche by providing quasi-equity and unsecured lending, an expertise that would be critical in financing SMEs elsewhere in Sub-Saharan Africa.

Remgro Ltd, controlled by the Rupert family who founded Business Partners, holds 16% of Business Partners.  Khula Enterprise Finance Ltd, a government owned entity, holds 20%.  The remaining shareholders are mainly large South African mining companies and financial institutions keen to support the development of access to finance for SMEs.
Cost Nature:
The actual project costs are difficult to establish in advance, given the nature of the project as a start-up and as the first of its kind in each country.  The project costs are estimated at up to $55.0 million, including funding available for investments of up to $35.0 million and up to $7.0 million for direct technical assistance to investee SMEs.
	
-  IFC Investment

IFC proposes to invest:

-  up to $2.5 million to purchase services from Business Partners to establish and operate BPI.  IFC will also hold an option to acquire up to 45% of BPI at a later date.  Monies used to purchase services will be in the form of a grant from IFC; and 
-  The lesser of up to 40% of total commitments or $4.0 million equivalent in the Madagascar Fund, up to 40% of total commitments or $5.0 million equivalent in the Kenya Fund, and up to 20% of commitments or US$2 million in a third fund in a country in Sub-Saharan Africa to be determined.
Investment: 0.10 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity0.10* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The three pilot stage funds will be established in Madagascar, Kenya and a third country in Sub-Saharan Africa.  BPI will initially establish offices in Antananarivo and Nairobi, but expects to expand beyond these cities as operations become established.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: IFC will work with Business Partners to establish an Environmental Management System for Business Partners International and each of the fund management teams.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityNot applicable.
Sector: BA - Private Equity/Venture Cap Fund - Country

Project Description: Credit Bank of Moscow (CBM or the Bank) is a medium-sized private Russian bank focused on SMEs, private entrepreneurs, and retail clients and operating in Moscow and the Moscow region.  As of December 31, 2003, the Bank's net worth was $84 million and total assets $380 million.  Proceeds of the IFC financing would be used to expand the SME lending activities of the bank and, as the second phase, to develop its mortgage lending capacity.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Financial Intermediary (FI) Type 2 project according to IFC''s environmental review procedure.  CBM will be required to establish an environmental management system to ensure that SME lending under this project complies with host country environmental and social requirements.  The bank will designate staff who will have responsibility for environmental affairs and will participate in IFCs environmental training.  CBM will also submit annual environmental performance reports to IFC.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: CBM was established in 1992 and acquired by its current shareholders in 1994.  Since then, CBM has developed into one of the  leaders in the Moscow market for SME financing and car lending.  The bank is an open joint-stock company and is controlled by the Rossium Concern, a holding company comprised of manufacturing and trading enterprises.
Cost Nature: The proposed project consists of a five-year credit line of up to $10 million as the first phase and, subject to meeting specific criteria, a $5 million loan for mortgage origination as the second phase.
Investment: 10.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan10.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The bank is located in Moscow and presently, operates through 12 branches.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Financial Intermediary (FI) Type 2 project according to IFC''s environmental review procedure.  CBM will be required to establish an environmental management system to ensure that SME lending under this project complies with host country environmental and social requirements.  The bank will designate staff who will have responsibility for environmental affairs and will participate in IFCs environmental training.  CBM will also submit annual environmental performance reports to IFC.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Description:
This project consists of a senior loan secured by loan assets of up to $30 million to JSC Post-Pension Bank Aval (Aval or the bank), the  largest Ukrainian bank, for on-lending to SMEs. The bank has a country wide branch network with more than 1,300 branches and 16,000 employees, who serve 30,000 corporate and more than 3 million individual clients. The bank offers a wide range of services but sees its comparative advantages in lending to SMEs and retail.  IFC's financing would support this strategy and would increase Aval's ability to offer long term loans to small and medium sized private companies.  

This transaction would form part of IFC's strategy to increase its investment activities in Ukraine, reflecting the country's improved economic climate.  Other potential transactions currently being considered in the financial sector include a follow-on loan to ProCredit Ukraine, and loans to support mortgage financing to Raiffeisen Bank Ukraine and to a start-up, International Mortgage Bank.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an FI type 1 project. AVAL will be required to establish an environmental and social management system (EMS) to ensure that its lending activities comply with applicable environmental and social requirements of Colombia. IFC will assess the bank''s capacity to develop and implement an EMS.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor:
The bank was established in 1992 by Inkobank , the State Pension Funds and Oranta, the national insurer. Today the bank is owned by its management directly and indirectly through three insurance companies that are fully controlled by management.  

-  Ownership

The bank is owned 68% by its management, with another 18% owned by employees who have transferred their voting rights to the president of the bank, Mr Spiegl, a member of parliament.  For tax purposes, management has set up three insurance companies, which each hold 10% of the bank's equity and are fully controlled by management.  Aval is not affiliated with any industrial group.  

-  Management

The members of the management board are all key shareholders and are former leaders of Komsomol,  the youth organization of the communist party.  Over the past several months IFC has had meetings with Mr. Spiegl; the CEO, Mr. Derkach, and, at the working level, the deputy chairman, Mr. Yulenko, who is in charge of corporate business.  Although Aval has a fairly traditional corporate culture, management has promoted a young generation of second level managers who are responsible for the most of the day to day business.  IFC staff were impressed with their professional knowledge and attitude of these staff.
Cost Nature: IFC's investment will be in the form of a senior loan (A Loan) secured by loan assets of up to $30 million to JSC Post-Pension Bank Aval.
Investment: 35.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan35.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The location of this project is in Kiev, Ukraine.  The bank has a country wide branch network with more than 1,300 branches/sub-branches and 16,000 employees, who serve 30,000 corporate and more than 3 million individual clients.  The bank lends to clients throughout the country.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is an FI type 1 project. AVAL will be required to establish an environmental and social management system (EMS) to ensure that its lending activities comply with applicable environmental and social requirements of Colombia. IFC will assess the bank''s capacity to develop and implement an EMS.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Description: The project consists of a line of credit of up to $20 million to Guaranty Trust Bank, Plc (GTB or the bank), the fifth largest commercial bank in Nigeria in terms of total assets and one of the three AAA rated banks in the country. The project's main objective is to address the scarcity of term finance in Nigeria, which has forced Nigerian commercial banks to rely on their capital, or take the maturity risk in order to finance longer-term projects. The lack of term funding results in unsustainable levels of maturity mismatches in the banking system, lost opportunities for financial sector development and lower national economic growth.  Despite a recent improvement in political stability and a commitment to market-oriented economic reform, Nigeria has yet to attract a level of foreign investment in line with the size of its economy. This is creating a critical constraint in the country's development goals, particularly as significant investments are needed to upgrade private sector productive capacity and operations to sustainable levels, and finance the privatization of major industries which the government has planned.  The proposed investment allows IFC to partially address these constraints by making available foreign exchange term resources through an efficient financial institution.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an FI Type 1 project, which requires the beneficiary bank to establish and maintain an environmental management system to ensure that investments under relevant operations meet host country environmental, health and safety requirements, and are consistent with IFCs exclusion list.  GTB has had a good record and is compliant with IFC environmental policies. However, the IFC will re-assess GTBs environmental management system and, if necessary, will work with the bank to strengthen its capacity to meet these requirements.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor:
The sponsor of the project is Guaranty Trust Bank Plc. GTB was founded in the early 1990s by Mr. Fola Adeola, (member of GTB's Board) and Mr. Olutayo Aderinokun (current Managing Director/CEO).  The two sponsors, who both had prior banking experience, felt that the time was right to start a niche bank because of the void created by the departure of most foreign banks from Nigeria.  GTB was incorporated in July 1990, obtained its banking license in August 1990, commenced operations in February 1991 and was listed on the Nigerian Stock Exchange in 1996.   GTB provides a full range of financial services to its customers, mainly mid to top tier corporate and institutional clients, and high net worth individuals. GTB is predominantly a commercial bank with a national branch network covering the major commercial/industrial centers in Nigeria. The operations are supported by a strong technology platform which links the entire branch network via a Wide Area Network with real time capabilities. GTB is also diversifying its activities both in terms of services and geography. Over the last two fiscal years, the Bank acquired an insurance company and opened two subsidiary in Gambia and Sierra Leone.

Despite the difficult economic conditions that have prevailed in the country most of the period, as well as the increased competition, GTB has shown strong and stable growth and profitability from its inception to date.  Over the last five years, GTB's total assets grew from $320 million to $879 million and its equity base from $30 million to $85 million. Its ROAA and ROAE averaged 4.6% and 41% respectively over the same period.  In 2003, GTB joined the group of the AAA rated banks in the country, and became one of the seven settlement banks retained by the Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN), demonstrating its financial strength, national outreach and proven IT/Operations. GTB's success story has been used as a four-part case study at the Harvard Business School.
Cost Nature: IFC's investment will be in the form of a revolving line of credit of up to $20 million to GTB. The loan will be structure to allow the bank to match-fund its clients' needs.
Investment: 20.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan20.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The location of the project is Lagos, Nigeria.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is an FI Type 1 project, which requires the beneficiary bank to establish and maintain an environmental management system to ensure that investments under relevant operations meet host country environmental, health and safety requirements, and are consistent with IFCs exclusion list.  GTB has had a good record and is compliant with IFC environmental policies. However, the IFC will re-assess GTBs environmental management system and, if necessary, will work with the bank to strengthen its capacity to meet these requirements.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Name: PT Prakarsa Alam Segar; PT Karunia Alam Segar
Project Description: PT Karunia Alam Segar (KAS) and PT Prakarsa Alam Segar (PAS'), whose affiliates are existing IFC clients in Indonesia, are expanding into the instant noodle business by establishing plants in Jakarta and Surabaya.  They plan to set up several noodle lines in both Jakarta and Surabaya by the end of 2004, with the Surabaya plant also producing beverages and seasonings.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The review of this project consisted of appraising both plants and reviewing technical and environmental/social information submitted by the project sponsor.  The following potential environment, health and safety and social impacts of the projects were analyzed: existing and planned management systems for quality, environment and health and safety; occupational health and safety; food safety; air emissions from steam and heat generation; sustainability and quality of potable water supply used in food manufacturing; liquid waste management; biological control of pest species; and, solid waste management.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityEnvironmental documents will be made available at the local public post office.
Sponsor: The sponsor of the project is PT Mitrajaya Ekaprana, a local private Indonesian company owned by several individuals.  Mitrajaya Ekaprana owns almost 100% of KAS and PAS.
Cost Nature: Total project cost is estimated at $100 million.  IFC proposes to finance $45 million in the form of an A Loan and a B Loan.
Investment: 16.90 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan16.90Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location:
P.T. Prakarsa Alam Segar (PAS), Bekasi
The Jakarta plant is located on an 11 ha site, formerly a textile factory, in an industrial area of Bekasi, and opened in December 2003.  

P.T. Karunia Alam Segar, Gresik
The KAS plant in Surabaya occupies a portion of a larger industrial site of 75 ha located in north Gresik in a developing industrial area.  The area was formerly occupied by brackishwater fish ponds which are now being filled as the city expands.  The land was purchased from the previous owners on a willing seller-willing buyer basis, and no residents or land users were displaced.  This plant started operation in early 2003.

The review of this project consisted of appraising both plants and reviewing technical and environmental/social information submitted by the project sponsor.  The following potential environment, health and safety and social impacts of the projects were analyzed: existing and planned management systems for quality, environment and health and safety; occupational health and safety; food safety; air emissions from steam and heat generation; sustainability and quality of potable water supply used in food manufacturing; liquid waste management; biological control of pest species; and, solid waste management.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityEnvironmental documents will be made available at the local public post office.

Project Description:
CMS Computers is one of the largest IT service companies serving the domestic Indian market.  The company was founded in 1976 by CEO Ramesh Grover, Varun Prasad and S. Ramadorai, all veterans of IBM.  

The company is playing a major role in providing necessary and fundamental services that are essential to the country's continued growth, particularly in areas such as e-Government, field engineering, print solutions and cash management.  IFC will provide growth capital to fund rapidly expanding operations and extend the company's presence throughout India.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category C project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure. There are minimal environmental and social impacts associated with this project; therefore, no further environment and social review is necessary. Cost Nature: The total project cost is expected to be $47 million over two years.  The proposed IFC investment is up to $22.5 million in a combination of debt and equity.

Project Description: TurboTech Precision Engineering Private Limited (TurboTech or the company) was established in 1989.  TurboTech designs and manufactures micro-turbines, employing aerospace design techniques.  Its products range in size from 50kW to 2.5MW  and can be deployed in combined heat and power or back-up capacity applications.  TurboTechs flagship product, the innovative Energy Conservation (steam) Turbine, is the market leader in providing cogeneration opportunities to small and medium-sized industrial users of saturated steam in India.  The project aims to strengthen TurboTechs manufacturing capabilities to respond to growing demand for its Energy Conservation Turbines, to extend its national marketing and service reach, and to partially finance the beta-testing of its Low Cost Gas Turbine.
Environmental Social Issues: This Category B project may result in a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityEnvironmental documentation will be made available at the following location:At the external gate of the offices of TurboTech Precision Engineering Private Limited at:No.28/29, 2nd Main Road, Rajajinagar Industrial Town, Bangalore, 560 044 India.
Sponsor: The projects sponsor is Krishna Kumar an Indian national, whose family members hold 58% of TurboTechs shares.  Other shareholders include the Industrial Development Bank of India (23%) and Turbocam India Private Limited (10%), a subsidiary of the privately held US engineering company, Turbocam.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at Indian Rupees (INR) 97 million ($2.1 million equivalent). The proposed investment is up to INR 27 million ($ 600,000 equivalent) in equity or quasi-equity.
Location: The company is registered in Bangalore, India, where its manufacturing and design facilities are located. As part of the project, it will open four regional branches, in Kolkata, Mumbai, Hyderabad and Delhi.

Project Description: Aceitera General Deheza (AGD or the company) is one of the major agribusiness groups in Argentina.  Its core business is oilseed crushing, where the company ranks in leading market positions for soybean, sunflower, and groundnut.  The production comprises crude oil, pelletized meals, and refined oil.  In addition to that the Groups portfolio comprises confectionery peanuts, peanut butter and branded products such as mayonnaise, soybean milk, bottled oil, and other value added products.  With a total oilseed volume crushed in 2003-04 of over 4 million tons, AGD is one of the largest crushers in Argentina, exporting over 90% of its production, working with about 6,000 farmers and supplying Argentina and 45 countries in five continents.  The company has an annual turnover of about $1.2 billion and employs around 2,250 people.The project sponsor, Aceitera General Deheza S. A. is an Argentine agribusiness corporation whose principal activity is crushing and oil extraction from soybeans, sunflower-seeds, and peanuts.  AGD ranks among the leading oilseed crushers in Argentina, exporting over 80% of sales, employing over 2,250 people, working with about 6,000 farmers and supplying Argentina and 45 countries in five continents.  The project entails assisting the sponsor with implementation of its 2003-2006 investment program that includes: -  construction of new warehouses; -  crushing capacity increases; and -  high-protein soybean meal production.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The review of this project consisted of appraising technical and environmental social conditions at the following facilities: Terminal (T6), T6 Industrial (T6I), Aceitera Chabas (ACHA), General Deheza Oil Plant, General Deheza Refinery, General Deheza Peanut Plant, General Deheza Bottling Plant, and Santa Eufemia Swine Farm.  The following potential environment, health and safety and social impacts of the projects were analyzed at each site:Health and safety management systems;Ambient and point source air emissions, including workplace air quality;Liquid effluent management, including stormwater drainage and treatment; andSolid waste management.The findings at each site are summarized in the Environmental Review Summary (ERS).Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe ERS will be available to the public in the Intendencia or the Library (Biblioteca) of General Deheza, Province of Córdoba, Argentina.
Sponsor: The project sponsor is AGD; owned by the Urquía family.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated $164 million.  The proposed IFC investment includes, for IFCs own account, an A Loan for up to $50 million and a C Loan for up to $20 million , and a B Loan of up to $50 million.

The following potential environment, health and safety and social impacts of the projects were analyzed at each site:Health and safety management systems;Ambient and point source air emissions, including workplace air quality;Liquid effluent management, including stormwater drainage and treatment; andSolid waste management.The findings at each site are summarized in the Environmental Review Summary (ERS).Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe ERS will be available to the public in the Intendencia or the Library (Biblioteca) of General Deheza, Province of Córdoba, Argentina.

Project Name: GEF Marine Aquarium Market Transformation Initiative (MAMTI)
Project Description: Since its establishment as a private U.S.-based not-for-profit organization in 1998, the Marine Aquarium Counsel (MAC or the company) has spearheaded development of a comprehensive set of performance standards and a third party certification system in order to ensure that the marine ornamentals trade is conducted in a responsible, sustainable manner.  MAC has now partnered with two other nongovernmental organizations  the Conservation and Community Investment Forum and Reef Check  to provide a strategic combination of supply-side and demand-side interventions aimed at accelerating the adoption of MAC standards in the Philippines and Indonesia.The purpose of this project is to convert a substantial portion of the marine aquarium industry into a trade based on marine conservation, sustainable use, and sustainable livelihoods that contribute to poverty alleviation and food security.  The project will achieve this market transformation process by: -  building the capacity of community stakeholders to develop certified ecosystem management, -  ensuring there is scientific assessment and monitoring of coral reefs and marine ornamentals stocks for management, -  establishing no-take zones and reef and stock restoration, -  building the capacity of marine ornamentals collectors to become certified, -  increasing the financial resources and business skills for collectors to participate in a sustainable trade, -  increasing the participation of exporters, importers, and retailers in certification, and -  raising the awareness of, and demand for, certified marine ornamentals among consumers.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category C project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure. As this project is directed at implementing a sustainable and environmentally-sound trading system, there are minimal direct physical environmental or social impacts associated with this project.  Therefore, no further environmental or social analysis is required. The project organization will commit to comply with all applicable environmental, occupational health, fire and life safety legislation and standards of the host country in which business is conducted, as well as relevant World Bank Group environmental and social policies, guidelines and industry best practice.  Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The project sponsor is the Marine Aquarium Council (MAC). MAC is an U.S.-based, not-for-profit, nongovernmental organization that brings marine aquarium animal collectors, exporters, importers and retailers together with aquarium keepers, public aquariums, conservation organizations and government agencies. MAC''s mission is to conserve coral reefs and other marine ecosystems by creating standards and certification for those engaged in the collection and care of ornamental marine life from reef to aquarium. The MAC Board of Directors includes industry representatives and environmental organizations.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is $21,618,000. Of this amount, IFC will provide a $6.62 million grant from the Global Environment Facility. MAC, CCIF and Reef Check will cover $6.92M of the project costs through funds from other donors. Finally, $8.07 million of the project costs is expected to be leveraged from the marine aquarium industry as exporters, importers and retailers make investments to become MAC-certified.
Location: The project will be implemented at 48 coastal sites in the Philippines and 30 coastal sites in Indonesia over a 5 year period.  In the Philippines, the initial sites include the fishing communities of Batasan and Clarin (in the province of Bohol) and Camotes (in the province of Cebu).  In Indonesia, the initial sites include the fishing communities of Tejakula and Gerokgak on the northern coast of Bali.  The remaining project sites will be selected from among the specific places where the marine aquarium trade is occurring in the Philippines and Indonesia.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category C project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure. As this project is directed at implementing a sustainable and environmentally-sound trading system, there are minimal direct physical environmental or social impacts associated with this project.  Therefore, no further environmental or social analysis is required. The project organization will commit to comply with all applicable environmental, occupational health, fire and life safety legislation and standards of the host country in which business is conducted, as well as relevant World Bank Group environmental and social policies, guidelines and industry best practice.  Location of environmental documents In locally affected community

Project Description: ABAMCO Composite Fund (the Fund or the company) is a closed-end investment fund, which will be listed on all three Stock Exchanges of Pakistan including the Karachi Stock Exchange (KSE), the Lahore Stock Exchange (LSE), and the Islamabad Stock Exchange (ISE) by end-June 2004.  The investment objective of the Fund is to invest in large cap publicly listed securities, pre-IPO positions, and local currency debt/money market instruments in Pakistan.  The underlying asset pool will be composed of: -  a minimum 80% of Net Asset Value (NAV) of the Fund in large cap listed or pre-IPO positions with minimum market capitalization of Rs1 billion; and -  a maximum of 20% of NAV in debt/money market instruments.  The Fund will be managed by ABAMCO Ltd. (ABAMCO, or the Fund Manager).  IFC has an existing 4.2% stake in ABAMCO.  The target size of the Fund is $73.5 million equivalent, of which $20 million equivalent has been allocated for over-subscriptions at the time of listing.  The Fund Manager will invest up to $7.2 million equivalent in the Fund.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category C project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure. There are minimal environmental and social impacts associated with this project; therefore, no further environment and social review is necessary. Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: ABAMCO first became acquainted with IFC in 1995, when IFC participated in ABAMCO as a seed investor with an initial 20% stake.  IFC played a pivotal role in establishing ABAMCO, the first asset management company in Pakistan.  ABAMCO, currently the largest asset management company in Pakistan, is a subsidiary of JSCL, which is the largest listed financial services company in Pakistan.  Due to political upheavals during the late 90s, the Pakistani stock markets remained bearish, stalling progress in the development of this nascent industry.  Consequently, ABAMCO did not raise any new funds between 1997 and 2002.  As the economy started recovering in 2001, ABAMCO explored opportunities in new products and considered raising new capital.  During 2002, ABAMCO raised a fixed income fund (UTP Growth Fund) and an Islamic fund (UTP Islamic Fund), and won a bid to manage a pool of privatized funds (ICP Mutual Funds, Lot A) by the Government of Pakistan (GOP).  Currently,  ABAMCOs total assets under management are about $180 million.  In addition to IFC, other shareholders include Jahanghir Siddiqui & Co. Ltd. (54%), AMVESCAP Plc. (6%), Muslim Commercial Bank Ltd. (4%), and Saudi Pak Commercial Bank Ltd. (2%), and individual investors (29%).
Cost Nature: The target size of the Fund is $73.5 million with IFCs proposed investment of $5.0 million.
Investment: 5.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity5.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The Fund is expected to be listed on all three Stock Exchanges of Pakistan including the Karachi Stock Exchange (KSE), the Lahore Stock Exchange (LSE), and the Islamabad Stock Exchange (ISE) by end-June 2004.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category C project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure. There are minimal environmental and social impacts associated with this project; therefore, no further environment and social review is necessary. Location of environmental documents In locally affected community

Company Name: NOVA SOCIEDADE DE SEGUROS DE ANGOLA SA
Project Description:
The project consists of an equity participation of up to $1 million in NOSSA  Nova Sociedade de Seguros de Angola, S.A.R.L. (Nossa or the company), an insurance company to be incorporated in Angola. This equity participation will represent 16.7% of the total share capital of Nossa.

The sponsors of the project, Real Seguros, Real Vida Seguros, the Banco Português de Negócios ('BPN') Group, BPN's holding company Sociedade Lusa de Negócios ('SLN')  in Portugal and Banco Africano de Investimentos in Angola have agreed to an IFC put-option as an exit mechanism related to the IFC equity investment.   The terms of the put option are being negotiated and are taking into consideration that Nossa will have its shares denominated in US$.  The put will have a guaranteed return with an equity upside.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category C project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure. No further environmental review is therefore required.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor:
Real Seguros

The project sponsor and largest shareholder is Real Seguros ('Real'), a Portuguese insurance company held by the Grupo Banco Português de Negócios ('BPN Group') of Portugal.  Real operates out of Oporto in Northern Portugal and was founded in 1988 initially as a non-life insurance company and, in 1989, a life company was added.  The life company is wholly-owned by Real and shares management, infrastructure and administration with its non-life counterpart.  In 1999-2000, BPN Group bought over 95% of the shares of both the life and non-life companies of Real, injected capital and grew both companies aggressively but prudently.  Initially, it expanded the business mainly through its own offices, agents, brokers, intermediaries and corporate accounts, and is now leveraging on bank distribution channels using the 183 branch network of BPN.

Banco Africano de Investimentos

Banco Africano de Investimentos ('BAI') was established as a universal bank in November 1996 and was the first privately owned bank to operate in Angola. The major shareholders of BAI are Sonangol (17.5%) and three international banks: Caixa de Crédito Agrícola Mútuo, Portugal (10.0%), Investec, South Africa (10.0%) and Banco Comercial Português, Portugal (5.0%).As of December 2002, BAI was the largest bank in Angola with total assets of $586.4 million and equity of $59.0 million. Total deposits and credit amounted to $449.6 million and $101.5 respectively. BAI posted a net profit of $14.3 million. BAI has a network of 19 branches, 7 in Luanda and the other 12 spread over 8 provinces, giving this bank one of the best banking networks in the country. The bank is planning to expand its geographical by increasing its branch network to 26 by the end of 2005. BAI employs 259 people. Internationally, BAI opened a subsidiary in Lisbon and is planning to open branches in Cape Verde, Sao Tome and Principe, Brazil and South Africa.
Cost Nature: The project consists of an equity participation of up to $1 million in Nossa, an insurance company to be incorporated in Angola. This equity participation will represent 16.7% of the total share capital of Nossa.
Investment: 1.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity1.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Nossa will be headquartered in Luanda, Angola.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category C project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure. No further environmental review is therefore required.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Description: The project consists of establishing a new hotel company or "the Company using three existing properties fully owned by Occidental in the Dominican Republic (DR), refurbishing the facilities of one hotel to re-brand it to a higher standard and upgrading the fire and life safety systems of another hotel. The Company will start operations with 1,316 rooms.  The proposed project aims to improve the capital and financial structure of the Company to resume its capital investment program in the DR.
Role: Tourism is largely responsible for strong growth in the DR economy in the 1990s accounting for over 554,000 jobs (16.2% of total employment), $2.8 billion in exports (28.3% of total exports), contributing $5.6 billion in economic activity. The government has identified tourism as a key growth sector and given DRs competitive advantages, will drive to make tourism more up-market in the future. The proposed project, in line with this strategy, will allow Occidental to re-capitalize three existing hotels on a more sustainable basis and refurbish/upgrade one, and is thus expected to promote further development of tourism in the DR. IFC has an essential role to play in the project by providing the required long-term project finance, thus ensuring that investors with a proven track record, like Occidental, continue to have access to the international debt and equity markets thus sending a strong positive signal to prospective private investors in the tourism sector in the region.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs procedure for environmental and social review of projects. Environmental and social issues associated with this project include: sustainability and quality of potable water supplies, wastewater management and treated effluent impact on surface waters, solid waste handling and disposal, fire prevention and emergency response.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityEnvironmental documents related to the project will be placed in OHMs internet site: http://www.occidental-hoteles.com. In addition, the environmental documents related to the project will be available to the local communities at the three existing properties, as well as in the local libraries or community centers (closest to the existing property) of the towns where the properties are located.
Sponsor: The parent company is Occidental Hotels Management B.V. (OHM), a company registered in the Netherlands. The three main shareholders in OHM are Mercapital (30%), la Caixa (31%) and Tamar International Sarl (24%), an investment vehicle that in turn is controlled by the founders of the company. Mercapital is a leading Spanish venture capital group dedicated to the industrial and service sectors. la Caixa of Spain is one of the principal saving banks in Europe with interests in several sectors including utilities and telecommunications.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $92 million. OHM has requested IFCs assistance to mobilize up to $70 million for the financing of the project. The proposed IFC investment would include an A Loan of up to $10 million, a B Loan of up to $40 million and a C Loan of up to $20 million.  The A and B loans will be invested directly in a Occidental subsidiary in the Dominican Republic while the C loan will be invested in OHM, the holding company of the Occidental group to help Occidental capitalize its operations in the DR.

Project Description: The proposed project is a jeopardy case and involves the recovery of IFCs arrears in Montenegro, the Republic of Serbia and Montenegro. These loans were made by IFC to enterprises and a bank in Montenegro during the 1980s. The loans stopped being serviced after the break-up of Yugoslavia in the early 1990s. As part of a settlement of these arrears, IFC would subject to satisfactory due diligence: - acquire a stake of at least 10% in Podgoricka Banka a.d., Podgorica (PB or the bank); and- extend a loan of up to EUR 5 million  to PB.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category FI Type 2 project according to IFC''s environmental review procedure. The fund has committed to establishing an environmental management system that will ensure that investments are consistent with applicable host country environmental laws and regulations as well as applicable World Bank Group environmental, health and safety guidelines and policies; designating appropriate individuals who will have responsibility for the environment and who will attend IFC''s environmental management workshops; submitting to IFC an environmental management plan; obtaining clearance by IFC for any category A or infrastructure investment by the fund; and submitting to IFC an annual environmental performance report.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: As of December 31, 2003, PB had total assets of EUR 53 million. The  bank''s equity was EUR 15 million and it is well capitalized. As interest margins in Montenegro are still very high, PB was, in spite of its small size, very profitable and showed an after tax profit of EUR 1.1 million at the end of 2003. PB is majority owned by the Republic of Montenegro, directly (55.43%) and indirectly through state owned companies (26.89%). Private shareholders hold the remaining shares in the bank. PB is slated for privatization and a privatization tender will be announced as soon as feasible, potentially already in the second half of 2004.
Cost Nature: The project will involve an IFC equity investment of EUR 1.5 to 3 million and an A-loan for IFCs account of up to EUR 5 million.

Project Description: Bharat Biotech International Limited (Bharat or the company) is involved in three activities: -  the development and production of vaccines, -  contract development and manufacturing for Western based pharma/biotech companies, and -  the development of its own line of molecules.  The key uses of the project investment are for: -  upgrading and expanding current facilities;-  increasing contract manufacturing;-  increasing marketing and sales to expand revenue both in India and for exports;-  increasing product R&D.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because limited environmental and social impacts can be mitigated by adhering to industry best practices, recognized performance standards, guidelines, and/or design criteria.  Environmental, health and safety issues associated with this project include: solvent recovery system for manufacturing operations; waste minimization programs to reduce water consumed and waste water volumes; waste water treatment compliant with IFC/WBG guidelines limits; use of hazardous material in compliance with IFC guideline requirements; environmental, occupational health and safety programs to ensure consistency with IFC guidelines and international requirements such as ISO 14001 and OHSAS 18000.  General compliance by the company with all applicable IFC/World Bank Group policies and guidelines.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityEnvironmental documentation will be made available within the company headquarters. Dr. Ella holds a doctorate from the University of Wisconsin, Madison and who has over two decades of research experience in biotechnology programs at various universities such as the University of Hawaii and the Medical University of South Carolina. He has over 30 international publications to his credit and has been appointed by the Government of India as a board member of various national programs such as the Indo-USA Joint Vaccine Action Program, the National Task Force on Industrial Biotechnology, the Task Force on Drugs & Pharmaceuticals and the National Health Mission.Bharat Biotech is owned by Dr. Krishna Ella and Associates (mainly management and angel investors) (77.1%) and by IDBI (22.9%).

Project Description:
The project will consist of an A Loan of up to $50 million divided in two tranches of $25 million each (the Facility) to be extended to Banco ABN AMRO Real S.A. (Banco Real or the Bank).  It will support two forms of Sustainability-oriented business activities at the Bank:  

-   Environment-related lending, and 
-  Credit support for family-owned, middle-market companies that improve their Corporate Governance (CG) practices.

In both Environment- and CG-related on-lending supported by the Facility, the Bank has agreed to use IFC's Sustainability Framework as its principal tool in making credit decisions involving sub-projects that will receive funding.  

Banco Real is the first financial institution in the world to agree to use IFC's Sustainability Framework in such a fashion.  Furthermore, in the case of Environment-related sub-projects, in addition to conformity with IFC's Sustainability Framework as well as Banco Real's own (and already benchmark-setting) Environmental and Social Policy, the Bank has agreed to go beyond full compliance with both sets of standards.  

As such, Banco Real will use Facility proceeds to finance only those sub-projects that rate Level 2 or higher in the Environmental component of IFC's Sustainability Framework, thereby increasing the likely contribution of the relevant sub-projects to socially sustainable development.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an FI type 2 project.  The formal compliance requirements are that Banco Real must establish an environmental management system to ensure that subprojects comply with applicable Brazilian and World Bank environmental and social requirements.  Banco Real has already met the requirements to establish an EMS, and will ensure that all projects funded under this credit line meet or exceed applicable requirements through the introduction of cleaner production, energy efficiency, or biodiversity and other environmental investments.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: The sponsor of the project is Banco ABN AMRO Real, a fully owned subsidiary of ABN AMRO Bank NV, in the Netherlands.
Cost Nature: An A loan of up to $50 million with a maturity of up to 10 years.
Investment: 50.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan50.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
