Company Name: PALGAZ DOGALGAZ DAGITIM SANAYI VE TICARET ANONIM SIRKETI
Project Description:
Palgaz Dogal Gaz Dagitim Sanayi ve Ticaret Anonim Sirketi (Palgaz) is an incorporated joint stock company that was created on December 10, 2003 to carry out the natural gas distribution activities in Gebze per its license.  Palgaz is 89% owned by Palmet and an aggregate of 10% by the municipalities of Gebze, Tavsancil, Darica, Sekerpinar, Dilovasi and Caryirova, and with the balance owned by three Palmet employees.

The purpose of the Palgaz project is to develop, construct and operate a natural gas distribution system in the city of Gebze, located outside of Istanbul, Turkey. This will involve the construction of medium and low pressure gas distribution pipelines throughout the city and connecting residential, commercial and industrial consumers in the license areas, primarily in the first three years of the 30-year license. BOTAS, the state-owned oil and gas company, will supply natural gas to the project.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a category B project according to IFCs Environmental Review Procedure because specific impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines, or design criteria.  IFCs Environment and Social Development Department staffs review consisted of appraising technical, environmental, and social information submitted by Palgaz.  The following potential environment, health and safety (EHS), social and community impacts of the project were reviewed:- Compliance of Palgaz and their subcontractors with Turkish EHS requirements and IFC EHS and social requirements;- Commitment of Palgaz to quality and to EHS performance including ISO and OHSAS certification;- Emergency response planning and clean-up of contaminated land associated with past operations; and- Environmental benefits associated with the increased use of natural gas in Gebze. Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityERS will be disclosed in Gebze Municipality, PALGAZ's web site and headquarters in Istanbul at the following location: 
Gebze Belediyesi, Atatürk Caddesi, No:1 Gebze-KOCAELI / TURKEY
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $21.2 million. The proposed IFC investment is a $5.0 million A loan for IFC's own account. A stand-by loan of $5.0 million to Palmet is also being considered for future gas distribution licenses.
Investment: 10.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan10.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The project is located in the municipalities of Gebze, Tavsancil, Darica, Sekerpinar, Dilovasi and Caryirova. This area is located between Istanbul and Izmit in the northwest part of the country, approximately 60 km outside of Istanbul. The climate is generally characterized by warm summers and moderate windters. The Gebze region is one of the most industrialized areas in Turkey, containing fifty of the country's largest 500 enterprises.

Project Description:
Palen Enerji Dogal Gaz Dagitim Endustri ve Ticaret Anonim Sirketi (Palen) is an incorporated joint stock company that was created on October 22, 2003 to carry out the natural gas distribution activities in Erzurum per its license.  Palen is 89% owned by Palmet and an aggregate of 10% by the Erzurum (9.5%) and Ilica (0.5%) municipalities, with the balance owned by three Palmet employees.

The purpose of the project is to develop, construct and operate a natural gas distribution system in the city of Erzurum, located in eastern Turkey. This will involve the construction of medium and low pressure gas distribution pipelines throughout the city and connecting residential, commercial and industrial consumers in the license areas, primarily in the first three years of the 30-year license.  BOTAS, the state-owned oil and gas company, will supply natural gas to the project.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a category B project according to IFCs Environmental Review Procedure because specific impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines, or design criteria. The city consists of an old center city surrounded by newer residential developments. There is very little industry and the city is an important center for trade in livestock and agricultural products.  The climate is characterized by mild summers and very cold winters.

Project Description:
This Photovoltaic Market Transformation Initiative (PVMTI) subproject will involve funding for infrastructure expansion and working capital to enable the company to install solar home systems (SHS) under three parallel schemes; 

-  SPM's in-house fee for service (FFS) scheme, 
-  contracts for 12,000 SHS under Office Nationale de l'Electricite's FFS scheme and,
-  a proposed credit scheme for SHS to be implemented by SPM in collaboration with multiple Moroccan financial institutions.

IFC will provide loan and grant funding to support the project.
This project is financed by the IFC/GEF Photovoltaic Market Transformation Initiative (PVMTI). The Global Environment Facility (GEF) has provided $30 million in concessional funds to IFC to support investments in private sector projects to encourage market development for photovoltaics (PV).  PVMTI aims to address market barriers by making available appropriate financing and stimulating business activity, accelerating PV penetration to achieve reductions in greenhouse gases. By harnessing the innovation and discipline of the private sector in designing and implementing PV projects, IFC is helping to shift the design and financing of PV market activity to a more sustainable and replicable private sector context. 

By investing PVMTI funds in the project, IFC intends to support the demonstration of a successful and replicable business model for the Moroccan, as well as other developing country PV markets.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category C project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure.  No further environmental review is therefore required.  At present, there is no national environmental policy on battery recycling.  However, recently a plant has been established in Casablanca to recycle lead and plastic casings from SHS batteries.  All used batteries generated by the project will be delivered for recycling at this plant.  As part of the project, grant funding will be provided to set up facilities to ensure safe handling and pre-treatment of batteries at the plant.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThis project is a category C project and accordingly does not have any documents in locally affected communities.
Sponsor: SPM is a leading Moroccan PV systems supplier and is headquartered in Rabat.  The company is owned by Swiss Reinsurance Company (38%), Gaia Kapital Beteiligungs GmbH (32%), Dr Abdelhanine Benallou (16%) and Strategic Growth Portfolio (14%).
Cost Nature: Total project cost is estimated at $3,473,000, with proposed IFC/GEF PVMTI loan and grant investment of $1,068,000
Location: The project will be managed out of SPM's headquarters in Rabat and will be implemented through the company's network of Sunlight Service Centres (SSC's) initially in the north western regions of Taza, Sefrou, Taounate and El Khemisset and the central and southern regions of Essaouira, Safi and El Jadida.  With time, the project may see expansion into further regions.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category C project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure.  No further environmental review is therefore required.  At present, there is no national environmental policy on battery recycling.  However, recently a plant has been established in Casablanca to recycle lead and plastic casings from SHS batteries.  All used batteries generated by the project will be delivered for recycling at this plant.  As part of the project, grant funding will be provided to set up facilities to ensure safe handling and pre-treatment of batteries at the plant.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThis project is a category C project and accordingly does not have any documents in locally affected communities.

Project Description:
The project involves the creation of a greenfield bank holding company, PlaNet Bank (PB or the company) that will make equity and quasi-equity investments in either newly created or existing Microfinance Institutions (MFIs) with the aim of creating a network of affiliated microfinance institutions initially focusing on Francophone Africa and then expanding to other regions of the world.

This project will create a new institution, allowing IFC to broaden its grasp of MFIs, while achieving economies of scale in structuring investments that the corporation could not handle on its own because of their smaller size. PB's purpose is to create a group of commercial MFIs able to offer financial services to low-income entrepreneurs in developing countries.

PB will have an initial capitalization of up to 30 million, split as 20 million in equity and 10 million in subordinated debt.  PB intends to create/control a network of 15 banks by year 5 and plans on owning at least an initial 30% stake in new MFIs while gaining a controlling stake through like-minded investors.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an FI type 1 project. PB will be required to ensure that its investee banks have in place an environmental management system for compliance with applicable host country environmental and social requirements and IFC''s microfinance exclusion list.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Cost Nature: The total project cost for PB is estimated at up to 30 million ($36 million), split as 20 million ($24 million) in equity and 10 million ($12 million) in subordinated debt. The proposed IFC investment is up to 4.0 million ($4.8 million) in equity and up to 2.0 million ($2.4 million) in subordinated debt instruments.
Investment: 7.52 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan4.73Equity2.79* These investment figures are indicative

Project Name: Pro Credit Bank SARL Democratic Republic of Congo
Project Description: The project consists of the establishment of Pro Credit Bank SARL (PCB or the bank) which will provide credit and other financial services to private micro and small enterprises and individuals, who currently face serious constraints to accessing these services. PCB will assist in strengthening and deepening the DRC financial markets by demonstrating the commercial viability of lending to micro and small enterprises.
Environmental Social Issues: PCB is a category FI Type 1 project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure.  IMI and project technical partner IPC have developed an environmental management framework to ensure that financial institutions in which IMI invests and IPC manage have appropriate Environmental Management Systems (EMS). IFC''s  Environment Division has approved this environmental framework. Under the framework, IPC and IMI will guide PCBC in the development and implementation of an EMS, requiring activities financed to comply with the applicable environmental, health and safety legislation and standards of DRC and IFCs Microfinance Exclusion List.  Implementation of the EMS may involve an orientation in cleaner production and a focus on clients presenting the greatest environmental risk and opportunities. PCB will provide an annual environmental performance report to IMI/IPC.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The project sponsor is IMI.  The proposed PCB shareholder group includes IFC, DOEN Foundation, IMI, as well as the project technical partner, Internationale Projekt Consult (IPC). - Stichting DOEN based in Amsterdam, was created in 1991 as a philanthropic foundation and socially responsible investor by the Dutch Postcode Lottery. In 1995 DOEN began to support projects to promote small and micro enterprises and strengthen market forces by providing venture capital and issuing subordinated loans. It is now one of the Netherlands leading development cooperation agents in this area. - Internationale Micro Investitionen AG (IMI), a corporation established under the laws of the Federal Republic of Germany, was founded in 1998. Its shareholders include Internationale Projekt Consult (IPC) GmbH, IPC-Invest (IPC employees), the German group KfW/DEG,  DOEN Foundation, FMO and IFC. IMI has an equity of 63 million and is the strategic investor in 18 banks around the world today, which are among the leading providers of micro and small business financial services in their respective countries.- International Projekt Consult GmbH (IPC), a private consulting firm established in 1980 in Germany, whose principal shareholder is Dr. Claus-Peter Zeitinger. IPC is a leading international consulting and financial services company specializing in development and management of microfinance institutions.  Potential Future Shareholder KfW (Germany) has expressed an interest to become a shareholder in the bank, as well as possibly to provide TA funding in an amount to be determined. The shareholding structure will be adjusted to accommodate KfW, which will be accomplished through the sale of IMIs shares to KfW at par value.Capital:The authorized share capital of PCBC will be $3,000,000 and consists of 300,000 shares with a par value of the $10.00 each.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $5.5 million, to include the share capital of $3.0 million and technical assistance grant funds of $2.5 million. IFCs investment would consist of a purchase of up to 15% of the common shares of the company for up to $0.5 million equivalent, at par. In addition, IFC expects to contribute up to $0.5 million in the form of a technical assistance grant.
Investment: 0.47 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity0.47* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The bank will be headquartered in Kinshasa, Democratic Republic of Congo, with branches in other parts of the country being opened in subsequent years as business demand grows. The bank will focus on making credit and other financial services available to individuals and micro and small enterprises on a commercial basis.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: PCB is a category FI Type 1 project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure. Project Description: The project involves the extension of a credit line of up to 5.0 million to Unionbank AD or the company, a private Bulgarian bank.  The facility will help extend the maturity of Unionbank's funding base and will be used as a source of medium term funding for the development of small business finance activities. Bulgaria's SME sector accounts for more than 50% of GDP but remains underserved by the Bulgarian banking sector, which has traditionally focused on large corporate clients. This facility supports Unionbank in addressing this gap in the financial sector.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an FI Type 1 project. As part of a previous investment by IFC, Unionbank committed to establish an environmental management system (EMS) as required by IFC. For the proposed new investment by IFC, Unionbank will be required to confirm that it has established the EMS as required by IFC; that the EMS is functioning as required; and that the EMS will remain in place for the length of the new investment.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: Unionbank is controlled by a limited number of individuals and their families. Mr. Ivan Radev, Mr. Emanuil Manolov, Mr. Emil Ivanov and Mr. Svetoslav Radev control equal shares of 16.3%, or about 65.2% in total, either directly or indirectly through two holding companies  Boras OOD and Union-Group OOD  whose only assets are their shares in Unionbank. None of these individuals serve in the management of the Bank, but rather exercise their shareholder rights through a supervisory board responsible for strategic decisions and internal control.  EBRD holds a 15% stake.  The remaining shares are held by minority shareholders including members of the management team and staff.
Cost Nature: The project involves the extension of a credit line of up to 5.0 million to Unionbank AD.
Investment: 6.46 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan6.46Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Unionbank is headquartered in Sofia and serves its clients through 20 branches located throughout Bulgaria.

For the proposed new investment by IFC, Unionbank will be required to confirm that it has established the EMS as required by IFC; that the EMS is functioning as required; and that the EMS will remain in place for the length of the new investment.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Description: The project consists of the long term financing of TA Orange Company Limited (TA Orange or the company), the third largest provider of GSM mobile telephony services in Thailand. The company launched full commercial services in March 2002, operating a digital GSM 1800 network covering 78 percent of the population on a nationwide scale.  As of June 2004, the Company's total subscriber base amounted to 2.3 million, translating into a 9 percent share of the country's mobile telephony market.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a category B project, subject to appraisal, according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure. Issues to consider with regard to this project include: TA Orange''s environmental and social policies and procedures; environmental management and performance of existing network; site selection, land acquisition procedures and construction impacts of proposed expansion of network (towers, switching center and base stations); development of previously undisturbed land; impacts on environmentally or culturally sensitive areas (national parks, forests and other cultural heritage features); fuels/hazardous materials use; waste management; employee health and safety; training and emergency response.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe environmental documents related to this project will be made publicly available on the premises of the World Bank's Bangkok office as well as at the World Bank Group's InfoShop in Washington, D.C., USA. The address of the Bangkok office is as follows:
International Finance Corporation
c/o The World Bank
17th Floor, Tower A
Diethelm Towers
93/1 Wireless Road
Bangkok 10330, Thailand
Sponsor: After completion of the refinancing, the company will be owned 83 percent by True Corporation (Public) Co., Ltd. (True Corp.), 7 percent by Charoen Pokphand Group Co. Ltd. (CP Group), True Corp.'s largest shareholder, and 10 percent by Orange, S.A., an affiliate of France Telecom, S.A.  True Corp. and CP Group are the two sponsors of the Company whereas Orange, S.A. will remain as a financial investor with limited strategic interests. True Corp., formerly known as TelecomAsia Corp., is a publicly traded fixed line telephony services provider with 2.0 million subscribers in the nation's capital. CP Group, founded in 1921, is a holding company with investments in agribusiness, telecommunications, logistics and retailing. The sponsors are both based in Bangkok, Thailand.  Orange, S.A., majority owned by France Telecom, S.A., is one of the world's largest GSM mobile telephony services operators providing services to 52 million subscribers in 18 countries.
Cost Nature: IFC is considering to participate in the long-term $830 million re-financing replacing a 2-year bridge financing and the financing of the company's 2004  2006 capital expenditure program ($370 million), alongside a group of 13 local banks, two international lenders and one equipment vendor.  IFC is to provide up to $50 million in loans and/or equity on its own account. The bridge financing was provided in 2002 by a group of local banks and equipment vendors and matured in March 2004. The capital expenditure plan for Phase IV of the network build-out for TA Orange is to provide coverage for up to 91 percent of the population by 2006.

Project Description: Aeropuertos Dominicanos Siglo XXI, S.A. (Aerodom or the company) operates six airports in the Dominican Republic under a 30-year build-operate-transfer concession agreement. Aerodom's airports served over 3.8 million passengers in 2003 and accounted for an estimated 51% of all air passenger traffic in the Dominican Republic.  The project is to help Aerodom complete infrastructure investments required under the concession agreement. These infrastructure investments include the renovation and expansion of existing terminal buildings, runways, and aircraft parking areas; the construction of new terminals; the installation of new security, baggage handling and other equipment; and the construction of a new airport in Samaná.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The review of this project consisted of appraising technical environmental, and social information submitted by Aerodom and airport site visits by IFC staff.  IFC also reviewed the results of various environmental and social assessments of the Aerodoms airports conducted since 1999, the EIA for the new La Isabela International Airport prepared by the Dominican Government in 1999, the EIA for the new Samaná International Airport prepared by Aerodom in 2001, and an independent environmental and social review conducted by the Inter-American Development Bank in 2001.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe environmental documents will be made available at Aerodom's offices at the Las Américas International Airport and La Isabela International Airport in Santo Domingo, the Gregorio Luperón International Airport in Puerto Plata; the Arroyo Barril International Airport in Samaná; and the María Montez International Airport in Barahona.
Sponsor:
The project is sponsored by the Hazoury Group.  The Hazoury Group consists of several major Dominican companies controlled by the Hazoury family, including Sinercon S.A., one of the country's largest construction companies, and Cap Cana, the largest tourism development in the Caribbean. The Hazoury family also leads the Universidad Iberoamericana, one of the country's primary private universities. Sinercon would execute the EPC Contract for Aerodom.  A subsidiary of YVR Airport Services Ltd. (YVRAS), a 90%-owned subsidiary of Vancouver International Airport Authority, would serve as the technical partner and manage all of Aerodom's airports under an operations and management agreement.  

The Hazoury Group owns 58.25% of Aerodom through its subsidiaries Operadora de Aeropuertos del Caribe S.A. (50.5%) and Ronal Marketing Inc. (7.75%). Administradora de Aeropuertos del Norte, S.A. (17.0%), Corporación de Inversiones, S.A. (17.0%), and YVRAS. (7.75%) are the other major shareholders in the company.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $265 million. The proposed IFC investment is a $45 million A Loan for IFC's own account. A $15 million B Loan could also be provided if required by the company.
Investment: 45.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan45.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Aerodom's airports are the Las Américas International Airport located 13.7 miles (22 kilometers) to the east of Santo Domingo, the capital city of the Dominican Republic; the Gregorio Luperón International Airport located 11.3 miles (18 kilometers) east of Puerto Plata; the Arroyo Barril International Airport and Samaná International Airport located on either side of the Samaná Peninsula; the La Isabela International Airport in El Higüero near Santo Domingo and the María Montez International Airport located in Barahona.

Project Description: Founded in 1967 in Espírito Santo, Brazil, Aracruz Celulose S.A. (Aracruz or the company) is the world's leading producer of bleached eucalyptus kraft pulp (BEKP), which is used by paper manufacturers to produce a wide range of products, such as tissue, printing and writing papers and specialty papers. Its two pulp plants located in the cities of Barra do Riacho and Guaiba have a combined annual capacity of 2.4 million tons, corresponding to 31% of the global supply. The company also has 247,000 hectares of eucalyptus plantations in the states of Espírito Santo, Bahia, Minas Gerais and Rio Grande do Sul. The proposed corporate loan from IFC will to support a number of corporate-level initiatives that the company is undertaking in an effort to maintain its ability to compete at the highest levels on a global basis.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. The review of this project consisted of appraising technical and environmental/social information submitted by the project sponsor. The following potential environment, health and safety and social impacts of the projects were analyzed:- compliance with IFC''s environmental and health and safety guidelines;- environmental management capacity;- cleaner technologies and eco-efficiency; - sustainable forest management practices and their incorporation in Aracruz''s plantations; and- social programs and relationships and other sustainability aspects.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityEnvironmental documentation will be disclosed at the following locations:

Various other minority investors own the remaining 3.5% of the company's voting shares. Aracruz's preferred shares, which constitute over 50% the company's total outstanding shares, are traded on the Sao Paulo, New York and Madrid stock exchanges.
Cost Nature: The proposed IFC investment is a corporate loan (A Loan) of $50 million for IFC's own account.
Investment: 50.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan50.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location:
Aracruz has corporate offices in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil.  Pulp production is currently distributed between two sites: 

- Barra do Riacho in the state of Espírito Santo, where the company operates a pulp making complex that is fully integrated with company-owned eucalyptus plantations. The site contains three mills with total capacity of 2 million tons a year of pulp. The industrial complex includes three recovery boilers, three continuous digesters, five bleaching and drying lines, and facilities for chemicals recovery, water treatment and electricity generation through biomass.  Environmental control is ensured through modern systems that treat all solid, liquid and gaseous wastes; and 

-  Guaíba in the state of Rio Grande do Sul, where Aracruz operates a high-tech mill with capacity to produce 400,000 tons a year of BEKP. A third unit, Veracel Celulose (Veracel), is being built in the municipality of Eunápolis, in the state of Bahia, in partnership with Stora Enso (a 50% ownership stake each). With startup of operations scheduled for 2005, Veracel will have the capacity to produce 900,000 tons a year of BEKP.

Project Description: Euroventures Management Ltd. (the Fund Manager) is establishing Euroventures Ukraine Fund II LP (EVU II or the Fund) to make direct equity and quasi-equity investments in mid-sized private companies based primarily in Ukraine and in cross-border transactions involving neighboring countries, mainly Russia.  The Fund will make investments averaging $4 million to $6 million in a diversified portfolio of companies operating in the unlisted high growth segments.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an FI Type 2 project.  The Fund Manager will be required to establish an environmental and social management system to ensure that investments made by the Fund comply with applicable host country and World Bank Group environmental, social, and health and safety requirements.  IFC will assess the Fund Managers capacity to establish an EMS.  Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The Fund is being formed and managed by Euroventures Management Ltd., a private company registered in Cyprus and a representative office in Kiev, Ukraine.  The Fund Manager established its first fund in Ukraine, Euroventures Ukraine Fund  (EVU), at the end of 1998 with $30 million.
Cost Nature: The target size of the Fund will be $50 million to $75 million and IFCs proposed investment is $7.5 million in equity or up to a maximum of 19% of the total fund size.

Project Description: Corporación Drokasa S.A. (the Corporación or the company) is a leading Peruvian agricultural and industrial conglomerate with three core activities:  -  the manufacture, marketing and sales of pharmaceutical products; -  the production and export of asparagus and table grapes; -  and the importation and distribution of chemicals, agrochemical, liquors and health and beauty products. The purpose of the project is to finance maintenance capital expenditure as well as to refinance Corporación and its subsidiariess outstanding short-term and long-term debt.  The project will be funded through two components: -  the issuance of a $25 million equivalent bond and a $5.0 million commercial paper program; and -  Corporacións internal cash generation.  The existing debt is the result of a restructuring underwent in 2000 and currently imposes high interest rates and administration costs as well as covenants that inhibit long-term growth.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The review of this project consisted of appraising technical and environmental social conditions at main Corporacións operating companies.  Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe ERS will be disclosed in Corporacións administrative offices in the following locations: -  Lima: Carlos Alaysa y Roel 2180; -  Ica: Km. 312.5 Panamericana Sur. Corporacion Drokasa, Phone: +51-1-470-1111.
Sponsor: The project sponsor is Corporacion Drokasa, an established Peruvian corporation that started out its operations in 1952. It is owned by local and private South American investors.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $50 million. IFC will partially guarantee the $25.0 million bond and the $5.0 million equivalent commercial paper program, raising the credit rating of the issuances.  The level of enhancement is expected to involve an IFC guarantee of 30% of the bond and 15% of commercial paper respective face values.

Project Description: The project involves the establishment of a new private sector company, La Fayette Investissements (or the company), in Luxemburg.  The company will specialize in providing start up capital and other financing for microfinance institutions (MFIs) in frontier, low-income countries, primarily but not exclusively in Africa.
Role:
The project will have a high development impact.  Project outcomes are expected to include the following:

-  Facilitate the long term access of MFIs/microenterprises to sustainable sources of funding.  

The current demand of credit by underserved microenterprises in emerging markets far exceeds the funding provided by donors and commercial lenders.  In order to satisfy the demand and unleash the productive capacity of these microenterprises, MFIs need to tap into funding sources to support their expansion.  The Company will enable new and established MFIs to access long term funding.  

-  Foster the integration of microfinance institutions into the formal financial sector.  

The company will provide the necessary financial instruments required by MFIs to either commence or to expand existing commercially viable operations.

-  Diversify the existing IFC model;

so as to reach countries and regions which present a continuing challenge, e.g. smaller African countries and/or very low income, frontier markets.

The project is in line with the World Bank Group's overall development strategy for the financial sector to reduce poverty by strengthening domestic financial markets, including the support for commercially viable microfinance institutions.  It particularly focuses on leveraging IFC's and donors' scarce resources to raise commercial funding and pave the way for microfinance institutions to provide access to finance on a commercially sustainable basis to target low income micro and small business populations.  The proposed project supports IFC's objectives to support financial institutions that contribute to a thriving microfinance industry.
Environmental Social Issues: The project is a Category FI type 1 project as classified by IFCs environmental and social review procedures.  The company and any subsequent MFI investments will be required to comply with IFCs ESR procedures including the establishment of an environment reporting system acceptable to IFC.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe ERS documents will be available at the company's proposed administrative offices in Luxemburg and at Horus' offices in Paris.
Sponsor:
-  Shareholding:    
The shareholders of the Company are expected to include La Fayette Participations (LFP), a company incorporated as a 'Société par Actions Simplifiée' under the laws of France; Horus a company incorporated under the laws of France;  IFC, and other IFIs who have shown a strong interest in the project.   Other internationally reputable shareholders may join after the initial closing.

-  Sponsor:    
Horus Banque et Finance ('Horus'), a company organized under the laws of France, with its principal place of business in Paris, France, is sponsoring the Company as a way to create a new pool of capital to promote investment in the micro and SME finance sector in developing countries in Africa and Asia.   Horus's mission is to provide technical expertise and know-how in microfinance and retail banking and to implement this expertise in microfinance institutions and microfinance banks. The development of a network of MFIs is consistent with this mission.  Horus intends to be one of the 'Initial Shareholders' and to increase progressively its equity capital in the Company each year, with a view to eventually becoming a controlling shareholder.
Cost Nature:
The Company's initial funding will be up to Euro 15 million, comprising both share capital and subordinated debt.  

IFC's investment will be up to Euro 3 million in any combination of either common equity or subordinated debt, total not to exceed 17.5% of the Company's share capital.
Investment: 2.18 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity2.18* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The company will have its administrative and legal domicile in Luxemburg.  The company aims to achieve its investment objective principally through the creation of microfinance institutions ('MFIs') in which the company has invested equity, in Eligible Countries (WBG Part 2 member countries) that are expected to benefit from changing economic, political, and legal environments and from the continuing commercialization of the microfinance industry.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The project is a Category FI type 1 project as classified by IFCs environmental and social review procedures.  The company and any subsequent MFI investments will be required to comply with IFCs ESR procedures including the establishment of an environment reporting system acceptable to IFC.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe ERS documents will be available at the company's proposed administrative offices in Luxemburg and at Horus' offices in Paris.
Sector: HA - Microfinance and Small Business - Non Commercial Banking

Project Description:
HiSoft Technology International Limited (HiSoft or DMK or the company) is one of the leading enterprise and software development outsourcing companies in the People's Republic of China (China).  The company is one of the few large Chinese software companies that services the Japan market due to its close geographical proximity and the large proportion of Japanese speakers in the city of Dalian.  The company intends to diversify its major markets away from Japan and to increase market share in the US market.

The company was founded in November 1996 and its shareholders include institutional names like China Hualu and Haida Shipping as well as management and the employees.  In August 2004, the company announced a $20million equity financing package with Jafco Asia, Intel Capital and Granite Global.  IFC is looking to contribute up to $4million in this financing.

The funds raised from this round of financing will be deployed to grow the company's market share in Japan as well as build the company's presence in the US market.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category C project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  There are minimal environmental or social impacts associated with this project.  The sponsor will develop a Corporate Environment and Social Policy Statement demonstrating its commitment to comply with all applicable host country/local environmental, occupational health, fire and life safety legislation and standards, as well as relevant World Bank Group environmental and social policies, guidelines, and industry best practice.  The policy will indicate that the sponsor will not knowingly engage in any of the activities listed in IFC''s Exclusion List and will comply with IFC''s ''Elements of a Code of Conduct for Internet/eCommerce Projects.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: The existing shareholders of the Company are two institutional shareholders  China Hualu, Haida Shipping, Jafco Asia, Granite Global Ventures, Intel Capital, management and employees.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $20 million.  IFC's investment will be Series A equity in the form of Redeemable, Convertible Preference shares.  The proposed IFC disbursement is $3million in a first round and a subsequent $1 million in options in a later round.
Investment: 4.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity4.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The company's Head Office is located in Northeast China, in the city of Dalian which is close to the Japanese border.  The company's global operations will continue to be run from this location.  The city of Dalian is a large metropolitan hub, ranked 11th largest in China, with a large population of Japanese speakers.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category C project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  There are minimal environmental or social impacts associated with this project.  The sponsor will develop a Corporate Environment and Social Policy Statement demonstrating its commitment to comply with all applicable host country/local environmental, occupational health, fire and life safety legislation and standards, as well as relevant World Bank Group environmental and social policies, guidelines, and industry best practice.  The policy will indicate that the sponsor will not knowingly engage in any of the activities listed in IFC''s Exclusion List and will comply with IFC''s ''Elements of a Code of Conduct for Internet/eCommerce Projects.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sector: BA - Computer Systems Design and Related Services (System Integration, Custom Computer Programming, IT Services etc.)

Project Description:
MBA Polymers, Inc. (the company or MBA), is a materials recovery/recycling company in Richmond, California, USA.  MBA owns and operates an engineering thermoplastic (ETP) recycling facility in Richmond and plans to construct and operate a 40,000 TPY plant in Guangzhou, China.  The principal source of feedstock for this plant will be collected in and shipped from appliance, electronics, and office equipment recycling facilities in Japan.  The company has requested the Environmental Opportunities Facility (EOF) of IFC to provide an equity investment of $1.2 million in the company.   The proposed investment would support MBA's planned expansion into markets where costs of virgin materials are relatively high and materials 'take-back mechanisms' have been mandated in producer countries.  MBA estimates that its proprietary recovery and refining process, producing high-quality recovered materials, is a minimum of two years ahead of any competing process.
MBA is providing a high-quality, market-driven product which addresses the environmental issue of  ETP disposal.  In those countries where take-back mechanisms have been legislated, ETP is usually burned in municipal waste incinerators or landfilled.  A very small percentage is currently recovered/recycled despite its high value  exceeding that of other recovered waste materials, including aluminum and PET bottles.  Where 1 kilogram of virgin ETP is replaced by recovered material, 2 to 3 kilograms of CO2 is prevented from entering the atmosphere, reducing greenhouse gases.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe ERS has been disclosed in China: The environmental documentation will be made available at the following locations:

-  Posted outside the company's office at the Guangzhou Iron and Steel Science and Technology Building, Baihedong, FangCun District, Guangzhou, China
 
-  The public notice was prominently disclosed in the popular Yang Cheng Evening Newspaper (Yang Cheng is a nickname for Guangzhou) on August 12, 2004 indicating that the ERS is available to the public at the company's office listed above
Sponsor:
MBA Polymers (MBA, www.mbapolymers.com) is a California-based company that has developed a proprietary technology that can recycle High Value Plastics (HVP) materials from durable goods. MBA was founded in 1994 by two former plastics recycling engineers from the Dow Chemical Company, Mike Biddle (CEO) and Trip Allen.  Richard McCombs (President and CFO) joined the company in 1999 to provide senior management leadership to the company.  MBA is poised to transform the plastics industry in a similar way that Nucor did to the steel industry, converting mixed streams of scrap plastic waste into a product comparable to virgin materials, at a fraction of the price.  To date MBA has invested over $ 27 MM in developing the technology, and raw materials sourcing and production capabilities on a commercially viable scale.  The company has been operating a 90,000-sq ft. facility in Richmond, California..  

MBA's Shareholders include Band of Angels, American Industrial Partners, Flextronics, GE Plastics and GE Capital, Asia West and Enspire Capital. MBA recently broke ground on a facility in the Nansha Development Area of Guangzhou, China with its joint venture partner Guangzhou Iron and Steel Enterprises Holdings, Ltd (GISE).  The joint venture is called GISE-MBA New Plastics Technology Co. Ltd. (GMP). The facility will have a 40,000-ton per year production capacity. The joint venture is 55% controlled by MBA and 45% controlled by GISE. The company is in discussions to develop additional joint ventures in China and Europe.
Cost Nature:
Total China facility project cost is estimated at approximately $14.0 MM.  IFC/EOF is anticipating investing up to $1.2 MM, which will be used as part of MBA Polymer's $ 3MM equity contribution and expenditures for the China joint venture as well as to support MBA's capital and working capital expenditures.  EOF's investment enables MBA Polymers to: 
-  Improve the China GISE joint venture's access to term loans from the local commercial banks; and, 
-  Continue discussions for establishing a second joint venture in China; 
-  Reallocate and leverage MBA's scarce capital to support its expansion plan into Europe.

The primary focus of MBA in the first couple of years in China is to bring the first factory to production scale, source materials primarily from Japan and begin construction on a second factory. The proposed IFC/EOF investment would be made in the form of equity capital in MBA Polymers.
Location: The GMP plant is located in an industrial zone in the Nansha Development Area of Guangzhou, China, nearby such factories as GE Plastic's largest plant in China. The location of a second facility is still under discussion, though the current projection is that it would be in Northern China.  In addition, there is the possibility that MBA will allocate some of IFC/EOF's funds to develop a joint venture factory in an IFC eligible country in Southeastern Europe.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati:
This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe ERS has been disclosed in China: The environmental documentation will be made available at the following locations:

Company Name: Proyectos Adamantine, S.A. de C.V. SOFOM ER
Project Description:
GMAC Financiera, S.A. de C.V. is a wholly owned Mexican subsidiary of the US residential mortgage company GMAC Residential Funding Corporation (GMAC RFC), itself a subsidiary of GMAC Financial Services (GMAC FS). The company was setup in 2000 as part of GMAC RFC's international strategy which identified Mexico as one of the growth countries for its mortgage operations. The company provides mortgage and construction warehouse lines of credit to specialized financial intermediaries (Sofols), and is building its presence in the secondary housing finance market through its securitization program. GMAC Financiera has developed an extended business relationship with most of the largest Sofols and has participated in two of the first three MBS issuances in the country. The company is recognized as an important alternative source of funding for Sofols and a key player in the Mexican secondary housing finance market. 
	
GMAC Financiera has enjoyed a rapid growth since its inception. Its loan portfolio has grown from MXN332 million ($36 million) as of December 2001 to MXN5.4 billion ($482 million) as of June 2004.

The project consists of a $150 million line of credit to GMAC Financiera (the company), to finance the origination of eligible mortgage loans, and a Credit Enhancement Facility of $50 million to support the company's mortgage-backed securities (MBS) program. In addition, the IFC would provide a Swap Facility of up to $15 million in loan-equivalent exposure terms, to hedge the market risks associated with the US Dollar loans.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category C project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure. The nature of GMACs portfolio (low- to middle-income residential mortgage loans) means that there will be minimal environmental impacts associated this investment. Therefore, no further environmental or social analysis is required.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: The Sponsor is GMAC Financiera, S.A. de C.V., a wholly owned Mexican subsidiary of the US residential mortgage company GMAC Residential Funding Corporation (GMAC RFC), itself a subsidiary of GMAC Financial Services (GMAC).
Cost Nature:
The total amount of the project is $215 million. 

IFC's proposed investment totals $95 million consisting of:

- a loan of $30 million,
- a swap facility of $15 million; and
- a credit enhancement facility of $50 million.

Company Name: ACIBADEM SAGLIK HIZMETLERI VE TICARET AS
Project Description: The Acibadem Healthcare Group (Acibadem or the company), a leading private provider of healthcare services in Istanbul, Turkey, is undertaking an expansion in Istanbul and Bursa.  The project includes constructing and putting into operation two new hospitalsa 80-bed specialized oncology and neurosurgery hospital in Istanbul (Kozyatagi Hospital) and a 200-bed general hospital in Bursa (Bursa Hospital).  In the longer term, Acibadem is planning further expansion, including construction of a 200-bed general hospital to be located in the Maslak district of Istanbul (Maslak Hospital).
Role:
The expansion of Acibadem will improve access to high quality health care in Istanbul and Bursa and demonstrate best administrative and patient care practices throughout the medical community in Turkey.

The IFC will provide long-term financing tailored to the project with terms which are not otherwise available to private healthcare providers in Turkey.
Environmental Social Issues:
This a category B project according to IFCs environmental and social review because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The review of this project consisted of appraising technical, environmental, health and safety , as well as social/community information submitted by the project sponsor as well as site visits to existing Acibadem healthcare facilities in Istanbul and to the site of the proposed new hospitals in Istanbul and Bursa. Based on this information, IFC concludes that the proposed project will meet the applicable World Bank/IFC environment and social policies and the environmental, health and safety guidelines upon successful implementation of the specific agreed mitigation measures. Mr. Mehmet Ali Aydinlar, Acibadem's President and CEO, holds approximately 40% of the total share capital of Acibadem Saglik and other 25 individual shareholders control the remaining 45%.

Project Description: The Biotechnology Venture Fund (APIDC Biotech, the Fund, or the company) was formed in May 2003 to make equity, equity-related and mezzanine investments in start-up and early stage life sciences businesses in India. APIDC Biotech is the first fund in India to focus exclusively on the life sciences sector and will seek opportunities in areas such as health care, drug discovery, agriculture, dairy, environmental and industrial applications all over the country. APIDC Biotech plans to take significant minority stakes and build a portfolio of 20 to 25 investee companies with average transaction size of around US$1-1.5 million. The Fund has a 10 year term and a 4 year commitment period.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Financial Intermediary (FI) Type 2 project according to IFC''s environmental review procedure. APIDC Biotech will be required to undertake an environmental review of each subproject to ensure compliance with host country requirements, IFC environmental and social safeguard policies, and , if applicable, World Bank Group environmental, health and safety guidelines. IFC will assess APIDC Biotech''s capability to carry out environmental reviews. APIDC Biotech must obtain IFC clearance prior to making any investment with IFC funds in any Category A project.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: The Fund's two main sponsors are Andhra Pradesh Industrial Development Corporation Limited (APIDC) and Dyman Ventureast.  APIDC was established in 1960, by the Government of Andhra Pradesh for planned development of medium and large-scale industries in the state. In 1989, APIDC set up in a wholly-owned subsidiary to manage venture capital funds. In 1995, APIDC privatized its fund management activity and organized a call for tenders for the selection of a manager. Dynam Ventureast Private Ltd was selected. APIDC formed APIDC-Venture Capital Ltd (APIDC-VCL), a joint venture between Ventureast (51%) and APIDC (49%).
Cost Nature: APIDC Biotech's target size is $35 million and the proposed IFC equity investment is up to $4 million for capital contributions as well as management fees and expenses. IFC proposed investment would represent approximately 11.4% of the Fund's size.

Project Description:
The proposed project involves an investment of up to $20.0 million (combination of loan and equity) in Fangxin Limited (a Hong Kong-based holding company, the Holdco) and its wholly owned subsidiaries (operating in mainland China) to support the Holdco and subsidiaries (together referred to as the Group or Fangxin) expansion program, which is estimated at $37.5 million. The Group is engaged in the development, production and sale of cosmetic packaging components and offers a fully integrated supply chain. 

The expansion program comprises of the following components: 

-  improving the current technology, facility and working environment of anodizing process and production; 
-  increasing the capacity of the existing operations; and 
-  the development and manufacture of mascara and pump-based line of products.

Successful implementation of the project will allow the Group to become better integrated into the global cosmetic and toiletry supply chain and increase its market share in this growing sector.
Role:
The project is expected to have a significant development impact as follows:

It will help Fangxin become a larger and more efficient packager of C&T products.  The success of Fangxin will rely on the industry experience, market access and good track record of its founder and the additional capital and operational and  debt restructuring provided by this Project. Fangxin is the top quality producer in China and with the new capital should serve as a benchmark in the industry in China.  The country will gain from the development of this industry as the major C&T companies turn increasingly to lower cost countries for packaging their products.  

IFC's role in the proposed project could be valuable for on the following grounds:

- Transfer of International Best Practices:
Through the technical assistance initiative, IFC is helping the Group evolve from a family-owned business to a leading manufacturer in China with improved financial and strategic management and corporate governance practices, thereby enhancing its access to international financial markets and setting the stage for a future IPO. 

- Provide flexible corporate financing:
As a young company, it has limited access to long-term funding from local banks for the proposed expansion.  IFC will provide the required long term money to Fangxin that will allow it to acquire the scale its operation needs. Moreover, IFC's involvement has helped attract additional financing from DEG and encouraged Fangxin's existing local banks to provide longer tenors to the Group.

- Supporting the development of a competitive local manufacturer:
Fangxin has expressed the desire to work with international experts that provide both financial and strategic advice that will help the Group to grow from an emerging, family-run business to a global player with requisite skills to exploit its competitive advantages.  In addition, IFC also provides the stamp of approval that global players like Maybelline, L'Oreal, Revlon are looking for when making critical outsourcing decisions.

- Corporate Governance:
IFC, through its proposed investment, will help to instill corporate governance that are necessary for Fangxin to evolve from a family business to a professionally managed company with appropriate organizational structure, internal processes and functions. This would also prepare Fangxin for its future IPO.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.  Environmental, social, health and safety issues which may be associated with this type of project, and which were reviewed during appraisal, included: -  site selection and acquisition; -  emissions to air from manufacturing process, boiler and/or generator; -  use, treatment and discharge standards of process and waste water; -  resource consumption and recycling;-  management of waste and hazardous materials; -  environmental and health and safety management systems; -  occupational health issues (e.g. indoor air quality, noise); -  employee safety, emergency response and fire safety, training and benefits. Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe environmental documents for the project will be located in the Government Office mentioned below:

The office is open to the public.

IFC is considering an A Loan of about $15 million to Shanghai Fangxin Metal Technologies Company Limited, a wholly owned foreign entity located in Shanghai, China.  IFC's equity investment of about $5 million will be made at the Holdco.

Project Description:
Established in 1992, Centre-Invest (CI or the Bank) is the largest privately owned bank in the 
Rostov Region and among the largest 150 Russian banks. CI has traditionally serviced large
corporates and SMEs in the Rostov Region. CI has an excellent reputation in its home market which
has enabled the Bank to attract the most important enterprises in the region as clients, as well as the
second largest retail deposit base after Sberbank. More  recently, the Bank  has begun expanding to
neighboring regions in the south of Russia. The purpose of the project is to provide the Bank with
additional funds to onlend to SMEs in the southern Russia for working capital and investment
purposes and to strengthen the Bank's capitalization. This project is IFC's second transaction with 
Center Invest Bank and builds on a partnership begun in 2002, when IFC provided a $2 million
loan for onlending to SMEs.
Environmental Social Issues: The environmental category is FI Type 1.  CI will be required to maintain its environmental management system to ensure that lending under this project complies with host country environmental and social requirements and is consistent with IFCs exclusion list and any applicable WBG environmental health and safety guidelines and safeguard principles.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: CI was founded in 1992 by Rostov-based university economics professors and the largest privatized intuitions in Rostov. Today, CI has 11,644 shareholders, including 36 legal entities and 11,608 individuals. The Bank's Chairman, Professor Vassily Vassilevich Vysokov, and his wife, Dr. Tatiana Vysokova, are the two largest individual shareholders with a combined stake of 18.3%. The two largest corporate shareholders are ZAO Rostovgazoapparat and OAO Rostovenegro, energy sector companies active in the region, with 17.6% and 8.9% stakes, respectively. In late August 2004, EBRD signed agreements to purchase an approximately 25% stake.
Cost Nature: The project consists of a financing package of up to $10 million. The proposed financing includes a senior loan of up to $5 million for on-lending to private SMEs and a subordinated convertible loan of up to $5 million to further strengthen the Bank's capitalization. The loans will be provided in US Dollars or US Dollars linked to the Russian Ruble.
Investment: 10.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan10.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Centre-Invest is the largest private bank headquartered in the Rostov region, an important economic center in southern Russia. The Bank has 7 branches and 20 sub-branches in the Rostov region. The Bank also has branches in Krasnodar and Volgograd and a representative office in Moscow.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The environmental category is FI Type 1.  CI will be required to maintain its environmental management system to ensure that lending under this project complies with host country environmental and social requirements and is consistent with IFCs exclusion list and any applicable WBG environmental health and safety guidelines and safeguard principles.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Description:
Millicom Lao Company Limited (MLL or the company) is a joint venture between Millicom International Cellular S.A. (78%) and the Ministry of Communication, Transport, Post and Construction of the Lao People's Democratic Republic (22%). MLL was awarded a 20-year license in 2002 and launched services in April 2003. The company is the third largest provider of GSM mobile telecommunications services in Laos, with a subscriber base of approximately 30,000. 

The project consists of the expansion and upgrading of company's network to provide MLL increased capacity and national coverage.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category B project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure. Issues associated with this Project include: Millicom Laos environmental and social policies and procedures; environmental management and performance of existing network; site selection, land acquisition procedures and construction impacts of proposed expansion of network (towers, switching center and base stations); development of previously undisturbed land; impacts on environmentally or culturally sensitive areas (national parks, forests and other cultural heritage features); fuels/hazardous materials use; waste management; employee health and safety; training and emergency response.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe Environmental Review Summary was already published in various newspapers in the Lao PDR.
Sponsor: The main shareholder, Millicom International Cellular S.A. (Millicom) is a B+ rated (S&P) global cellular telecom operator with 16 cellular operations and licenses in 15 emerging market countries (Africa, Asia and Latin America). As of March 2004, Millicom's cellular subscriber base worldwide was 5.9 million. Millicom's 2003 revenues totaled $641 million equivalent and EBITDA was $318.2 million equivalent.  The company is listed on NASDAQ and on the Luxembourg Stock Exchange. Millicom has a total market capitalization of $1.6 billion.

Project Description: The project comprises an equity investment of up to New Iraqi Dinar (NID) 50 billion ($35 million equivalent at current exchange rates) in order to acquire an 85% holding in, and provide incremental capital to, Credit Bank of Iraq (CBI), an existing Iraqi commercial bank.  The project will be undertaken jointly by IFC and National Bank of Kuwait (NBK). Their respective holdings in CBI post-completion will be 10% and 75%.  NBK will also assume management control.  The remaining 15% will be retained by CBI's existing shareholders, including several Iraqi industrial groups and a number of individual investors. The purpose of the project is to combine CBI's local knowledge and brand recognition with the international experience and expertise of NBK and IFC in order to build over the medium term an efficient modern bank offering a full range of products and services to domestic and international clients.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an FI type 1 project.  Post-acquisition, CBI will be required to establish an environmental management system to ensure that its relevant operations meet Iraqi and applicable IFC environmental and social requirements.  IFC will assess CBI''s capacity to establish an EMS.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor:
NBK is Kuwait's largest bank, with a 30% market share of both system assets and customer deposits, total assets of $19.8 billion and equity of $1.9 billion, as of end-June 2004. 

Despite operating in a volatile region and in a country primarily dependent on oil production, under strong management and with committed shareholders, it has developed gradually since its establishment in 1952 to become a major regional player with a significant international presence.  

NBK's main businesses are retail, private, corporate and investment banking as well as asset management.  Its key strategic goal is to strengthen its regional and international position by providing a broad range of high-quality client services based on advanced banking technology and professional management.  Historically a universal bank, NBK now focuses on expanding its corporate franchise into the retail area which offers higher growth and profitability potential. It is also seeking to expand within the Arab world, recognizing its dominant position in Kuwait's small banking industry and seeking growth and risk-diversification opportunities in less well-developed markets. 

The NBK group includes NBK Suisse S.A. (based in Geneva), NBK International plc (a wholly-owned subsidiary based in London with a branch in Paris), branches in New York, Singapore and Bahrain, representative offices in Thailand and Vietnam, and a majority stake in National Bank of Kuwait in Lebanon. Most recently, it has acquired banking licenses in Saudi Arabia and Jordan.  Importantly, NBK was one of three international banks (with HSBC and Standard Chartered) selected in January 2004 for the award for the first foreign bank licenses in Iraq.  NBK is also part of the consortium managing the Trade Bank in Iraq.  NBK is currently rated A+ by Fitch, A2 by Moody's and A by Standard & Poor's, all with a stable outlook.

NBK was established by a group of prominent Kuwaiti merchant families who still control some 80% of the bank's shares, with the other 20% publicly traded on the Kuwait Stock Exchange.  No shareholder has a stake of more than 5%.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at approximately NID 50 billion (around $35 million at current exchange rates).  The proposed IFC investment is an equity investment for up to $5 million for its own account.
Investment: 5.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity5.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: CBI is headquartered in Baghdad and operates a network of 12  branches, 9 of which are in the capital.  NBK/IFC's investment plan envisages a significant expansion of the, with ultimately up to 55 outlets nationwide.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is an FI type 1 project.  Post-acquisition, CBI will be required to establish an environmental management system to ensure that its relevant operations meet Iraqi and applicable IFC environmental and social requirements.  IFC will assess CBI''s capacity to establish an EMS.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Company Name: EKIM TURIZM TICARET VE SANAYI ANONIM SIRKETI
Project Description:
Intercity is the largest automobile fleet operational leasing company in Turkey with over 4000 cars and a 14% share of the fleet rental market in the country.  Established in 1992 by Mr. Vural Ak, the company's CEO, Intercity was one of the earliest entrants into the Turkish leasing sector.  Intercity's primary product is medium term vehicle leasing/financing for enterprises operating in Turkey.  The company primarily leases cars, light vans, and trucks which are used for various commercial activities including: supporting sales staff, monitoring and managing inventory and transportation and delivery of goods.  At the end of FY'03, the company reported total assets of over $84 million and total tangible equity of $14 million.

The proposed project consists of a combined IFC investment of:  

-  a term loan for IFC's account of up to $15 million, 
-  a term loan for the account of participating banks of up to $25 million, and

Project Description:
Unicredit Leasing Romania S.A (UCL ). formerly named Demir Romlease S.A. (Romlease or the Company), is a fast-growing joint stock leasing company established in 1994 and based in Bucharest, Romania.  IFC was one of the founding shareholders of the company, the first leasing company in Romania, and has been a mainstay of the company through some lean years, as described in more detail below.  

The investment would support the further growth of UCL's leasing book on a sound financial basis.  Now that the company is on a stable footing, with strong shareholders, and tight credit screening and monitoring policies in place, it is proposed that through this credit line, IFC remains an active supporter of the company.  

The leasing market has been growing relatively fast in Romania.  The total market is currently estimated at about $1 billion.  The company targets middle size and large companies.  With EU accession projected to occur in the next three or four years, the demand for medium term financing (of which leasing is an attractive alternative, especially for smaller companies) is expected to grow, as Romanian companies improve their environmental and quality standards, in order to be more competitive, in a larger EU market. 

IFC's focus has been to build and strengthen financial intermediaries in Eastern Europe.  The leasing sector in Romania is developing and IFC believes that there is a significant opportunity to accelerate its growth.  By granting this loan, IFC will help expand a reputable leasing company in Romania and strengthen the leasing industry.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an FI type 1 project according to IFC''s environment and social review procedure. UCL should demonstrate that the EMS developed under Romlease is adequate for this investment, and that the individuals trained are still managing environmental issues.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: Uni Credito (Italy), UCI is currently the primary shareholder of UCL with 100% ownership.  UCI is one of the largest banking groups in Italy with 68,439 employees , 4,558 branches, and total assets of Euro 238,256 million. UCI's principal shareholders are Cariverona, Cassa di Risparmio di Torino, Cassamarca, Allianz, Max Mara, Luxottica, and the Commercial Union and Société Générale groups. UCI has expanded quite aggressively in the last few years in Southern and Central Europe with presence in Turkey, Croatia, Poland, Slovakia, Czech Republic, and Romania among others.  UCI currently ranks as the third European Bank in Central and Eastern Europe.
Cost Nature: IFC's proposed investment in UCL will be in the form of an A Loan of up to $10 million equivalent.

Project Description: The project entails the establishment of Kongoni River Farm (Kongoni), an 86 hectare farm comprising 20 hectares of roses under steel greenhouses.  The farm, located in the high altitude locale of Timau, on the foothills of Mt. Kenya, will be implemented in two phases of 10-hectares each. The project represents an expansion of the sponsors existing flower operations in response to market demand and the need for geographic diversity of production sites.  Additionally, the higher altitude and climatic conditions at Timau will enable the production of a broad variety of roses including large head, long stem roses which command a market premium.

Project Description: Privredna banka Zagreb (PBZ) is Croatia's second largest commercial bank.  PBZ used to be a state-owned bank and was privatized in 2000 when Gruppo Intesa of Italy acquired a controlling stake of  66.3%.  Subsequently, in the second round of privatization in 2002, Gruppo Intesa increased its stake to 76.3% and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) acquired an equity stake of 20.79%.  PBZ is a full-fledged commercial bank and offers the full range of banking products to corporate and retail customers in Croatia.  The proposed project aims to provide a long term loan facility to PBZ to enable it to enhance long term lending to its customers, particularly to retail mortgage customers and small enterprises.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category FI, type 1 project according to IFC''s environmental and social project review procedure.  As a result of an earlier EBRD investment, PBZ has developed and is implementing an acceptable Environmental Management System (EMS).  The EMS requires PBZ and their clients to comply with Croatian environmental, health and safety requirements.  PBZ has also committed to send two of their environment staff to IFC''s new 5 day Competitive Business Advantage (CBA) Workshop to upgrade their skills.  Finally PBZ will provide Annual Monitoring Reports (AMR) to IFC (in the same format as used to report to EBRD) to ensure their is ongoing compliance to the approved EMS.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: PBZ's main sponsor is Gruppo Intesa of Italy which owns an equity stake of 76.3% in PBZ.  Gruppo Intesa, a private sector corporation, is one of the largest European banks and has a strong multinational presence.  It has total assets of EUR 260 billion and for the year ended December 31, 2003, it reported a Net Income of EUR 1.2 billion.  The bank is a very strong and well-established one.  The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) owns an equity stake of 20.79% in PBZ.
Cost Nature: Total project size and IFC loan amount is expected to be EUR 50 million to EUR 100 million for IFC's own account.

Project Description:
Mazoon Petrogas SAOC (Mazoon or the Company) is engaged in exploration and production of oil and gas.  Mazoon and its 50/50 joint operating partner, Mazoon Petrogas BVI Limited (MPBVI) (an indirect wholly-owned subsidiary of China National Petroleum Corporation), explore and produce crude oil in Block-5 through a joint operating company, Daleel Petroleum LLC (the Operator).  The Operator has proposed a US$331 million Development Plan, which Mazoon and MPBVI will jointly fund.  The Development Plan proposes to further develop Block-5 and to more than double current crude oil production of 12,000 barrels of oil per day (bopd) by way of waterflood.  This proposed project is an expansion of a brown-field investment and consists of financing a small portion of Mazoon's 50% share (US$165.5 million) of the capital expenditures envisioned under the Development Plan.

Block-5 contains the Daleel, Mezoon, Shadi and Bushra fields.  The largest and most explored field is the Daleel field, which extends from the north to the south of Block-5.  This field is further subdivided into five main zones: A, B, C, D and E.  The Development Plan calls for the further development of mainly zones B and C.  

The major Project components of the Development Plan include: (i) further development of the water-supply wells at Masruq (an area twenty-one kilometers from zone B); (ii) water-supply pipeline from Masruq to the B-Block Station (location in zone B housing many of the major Project components); (iii) water-injection equipment; (iv) associated power generation and distribution facilities for the water-supply and water-injection systems; (v) gathering system for new zone B and C production wells; (vi) gas and water separation facilities at B-Block Station; (vii) produced water treatment facility; and (viii) pumping facilities to route separated crude oil from B-Block Station to the main Daleel Gathering Station.  Furthermore, the Development Plan calls for the acquisition and the processing of new 3D seismic and the drilling of over ninety appraisal/producer and fifty-six water-injection wells.

Sponsor:
Mazoon is owned by Mr. Al-Barwani and his family members, who own various companies engaged in trading, oilfield services, exploration and production, and copper and gold mining.  These various companies are expected to be consolidated under a single holding company  for the present they are referred to as the MB Group (the group).  Mazoon and its sister company, Petrogas LLC (Petrogas), are the only two private local companies operating in Oman's exploration and production (E&P) sector.

Mr. Al-Barwani established MB Trading in 1982, which represented a number of international oilfield product and service companies.  Eventually, MB Trading developed its own services capabilities and was renamed MB Petroleum Services LLC (MBPS) in 1986, to reflect the wider scope of services provided by the company.  It is the flagship company of the group, and provides oilfield services to E&P companies operating in the Middle East, Eastern Europe and East Asia.  The company currently has operations in Saudi Arabia, Qatar, Yemen, Syria, China, Hungary and Germany.  Services include: (i) drilling; (ii) workover and well servicing; (iii) well testing and production services; (iv) wireline and completions; (v) cementing and stimulation; (vi) drilling fluids engineering; (vii) mud logging services; and (viii) consultancy services.

The group has two E&P companies, Mazoon and Petrogas.  Petrogas was established in 1999 to acquire the production rights governing Block-7 in central Oman from Elf and produces roughly 2,200 bopd.  The group's second E&P investment was Mazoon, which they established in 2001 to acquire the production rights governing Block-5 in northwest Oman.
