Project Description: The National Housing Mortgage Finance Corporation (NHMFC) has approached IFC seeking support for its May 2004 auction of non-performing housing loans. The sale portfolio, consisting of 55,000 mortgages, has an outstanding principal balance of ~PHP 13.5 billion (about $240 million), equivalent to about 32% of NHMFCs total portfolio of PHP42 billion ($750 million). The winning bidder of the May auction was Deutsche Bank Real Estate Global Opportunities Fund, a $360 million fund managed by Deutsche Bank.  Government agencies have dominated the low to medium-income housing sector in the Philippines, in both funding and origination. Because of resultant inefficiencies, and because of private banks focus on the medium to high end housing sector, there is significant unmet demand for low-income housing loans. The proposed transaction will be the first step in the Governments effort to restructure NHMFC and the housing finance sector itself, an initiative to which the authorities attach great importance.  The purpose of the project/investment is for IFC to provide funding for the following components:-  assisting the purchase of the portfolio; -  the subsequent resolution of the assets; and -  the capitalization of the project-related entities (i.e., the Special Purpose Entity and the Servicer Company).
Role: -  Development ImpactDelinquent mortgage portfolios are a major impediment to the development of the housing finance market in the Philippines, as well as an obstacle to the recovery of the country''s financial system.  The proposed project will support the first-ever auction of a housing portfolio in the Philippines.  This transaction will introduce a replicable mechanism for distressed asset resolution in the Philippines, and provide momentum to the development of the Non Performing Asset (NPA) market.  It will also play an important role in the restructuring of NHMFC, allowing it to transfer its servicing arm to the private sector and enabling it to focus on its mandate of developing the secondary mortgage market.  -  IFC RoleIFC has a critical role to play in countries with underdeveloped markets for distressed asset resolution.  The market for Philippine NPAs is as yet untested, making foreign investors wary.  As such, IFC is playing an honest broker role in this transaction by helping to align interests of the various parties involved.  In addition, IFC''s presence in transaction is a source of comfort for the Philippine Government, and is likely to prove crucial in catalyzing further local and international private capital into the NPA market.  Lastly, IFC will provide medium-term local currency financing at a time when potential participants are finding it difficult to secure such funding from existing Philippine financial institutions.
Environmental Social Issues: The project is classified as a category C within the framework of IFC''s environment and social review procedure.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The project sponsor is Deutsche Bank Real Estate Global Opportunities Fund IB (the Fund), the reinvestment vehicle for an approximately $1.3 billion opportunistic real estate fund managed by Deutsche Bank, AG.  The Funds aim is to invest in a range of opportunistic investments in real estate and real estate-related assets, including joint ventures, loan portfolios, and operating companies.  The Funds geographic focus is on Europe, Asia Pacific and the Americas.  It is expected that upon closing, the portfolio will be transferred to a Special Purpose Entity (SPE).  The SPE is expected to be majority owned by the Fund, with significant participation from NHMFC and a small stake held by IFC.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is approximately $100 million comprising:A loan/guarantee of approximately $58 million, in local currency, to be provided to the SPE pari passu with Asian Development Bank (i.e., about $29 million for IFCs own account).  IFC equity investment for minor stakes in the SPE and the Servicer Company totaling approximately $2 million.  The IFC investment for its own account would total approximately $31 million.
Investment: 33.36 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan30.68Equity2.68* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The project related entities would be domiciled in the Philippines.  The operations of the serivcer would be at the asset level (i.e., covering a number of the Philippine regions and provinces).
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The project is classified as a category C within the framework of IFC''s environment and social review procedure.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community

Project Description: The proposed transaction is  to invest up to $20 million (or Euro equivalent) in form of a senior loan to support the growth of Banca Comerciala 'Ion Tiriac' S.A. (Banca Tiriac, BT or the Bank), the first private bank in Romania founded in 1991, a medium-sized, well-capitalized bank, headquartered in Bucharest, Romania.  IFC's loan is intended to help BT to meet demand for medium term financing from its SME and corporate clients in Romania. With EU accession for Romania projected to happen in 2007, Romanian corporates and SME's will need to upgrade their environmental and quality requirements to meet standards and remain competitive in a larger EU market.  IFC proposed loan is intended to partially meet this demand by providing medium term resources to the Bank to match fund their corporate loans. In addition to the senior loan, IFC will consider a subordinated loan of up to $7.5 million (or Euro equivalent), that will qualify as Tier II capital as per National Bank of Romania guidelines. The subordinated loan is intended to increase the Bank's Capital Adequacy Ratio in line with its projected growth in risk assets and the expansion of branch network. Additional benefits will include in reducing the Bank's maturity mismatch on its balance sheet and increase the amount available for lending under the single obligor limit.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an FI type 1 project according to IFCs environment and social review procedure. Banca Tiriac must implement an environmental and social management system to ensure that relevant lending complies with host country environmental and social requirements.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor:
Founded in 1991, Banca Tiriac was the first privately owned Romanian bank, it provides a full range of banking services to corporate and retail clients in Romania. As at end-2003, Banca Tiriac was the tenth largest bank in Romania by net assets, representing 3.2% of the system. It currently has 58 branches (30 branches, 25 agencies and 3 working points), 200 ATMs and 1,550 POSs (point of sale card readers).

Banca Tiriac is majority owned by Mr. Ion Tiriac, a well reputed businessman and a former Romanian Davis Cup tennis champion.  Mr. Tiriac owns about 73.6% of the Bank directly and indirectly. From sports management, Mr. Tiriac has diversified into business interests in the financial sector (including insurance, in a joint venture with Allianz Insurance, the second largest insurance company in Romania and one of the most successful in the sector), tourism, transportation and real estate. 

EBRD owns 5.4%. of shares in the Bank with the remaining 21% held by around 5,537 legal entities and individuals and private investors.
Cost Nature: The proposed investment consists of up to US$20.0 (or Euro equivalent) in form of a senior loan. IFC is also considering the possibility of  providing a subordinated convertible loan for up to $7.5 million (or Euro equivalent).
Investment: 27.50 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan27.50Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The location of this project is in Bucharest, Romania.

Project Description: Micro Provident Botswana Limited (Letshego) is a leading consumer finance company in Botswana.  It was founded by Micro Provident Limited (MPL), an Isle of Man company, in 1998 as a private entity, after which it converted to a public enterprise in 2002, and listed on the Botswana Stock Exchange in September 2002.  The company provides short to medium-term micro loans to employees of governmental, quasi-governmental and private sector companies in Botswana, with the loans being repaid by payroll deduction.  MPL is interested in disposing of a portion of its interest.  IFC alongside Pan-African Investment Partners and Pan-Commonwealth African Partners (the Funds), two investment funds managed by Zephyr Africa Management Company (Zephyr), are considering acquiring a minority position in Letshego and supporting the Company's growth.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an environmental and social category C project.  No further environmental or social analysis is required.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: The founding shareholder of Letshego is MPL, holding 43.8% of the Company's shares.  The remaining is held by institutional investors and the public.
Cost Nature: IFC is contemplating an investment of up to $5 million equivalent in the shares of the Company, and a credit facility of up to $10 million equivalent to the Company.
Investment: 3.98 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity3.98* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The Company is located in Botswana and its headquarters are in Gaborone.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is an environmental and social category C project.  No further environmental or social analysis is required.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Description: Beijing City Commercial Bank (BCCB) was established in 1996 as a city-level joint-stock commercial bank.  It currently has over 3,600 employees and a network of 116 outlets throughout Beijing.  BCCB is the second largest among the 112 city commercial banks in China in terms of total assets.  This project will strengthen BCCBs capital base, assist the bank to introduce international standards and practice, and to become a competitive regional player in the medium future.  BCCB has been approved to change its name to Bank of Beijing Co., Ltd., effective from January 1, 2005.-
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category FI Type 1 project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  BCCB will be required to establish an environmental management system to ensure that activities financed under relevant operations are consistent with applicable environmental, occupational health and safety regulations of China and IFC''s Exclusion List, designate appropriate individuals who will have responsibility for the environment and who will attend IFC''s environmental management workshops or an approved equivalent, and submit to IFC an environmental management plan and annual environmental performance reports.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: BCCB has a diversified shareholding structure.  The Beijing City State-owned Asset Management Company, on behalf of the Beijing Municipal Government, is currently the largest shareholder with a 20.07% stake.  The second largest shareholder is Beijing International Power Investment Company, with 7.56%.  The remaining shareholders, none of which owns more than 5%, are mostly SMEs and over twenty thousand individuals.  -
Cost Nature: It is proposed that IFC make an equity investment of about 5% of the companys total enlarged share capital.
Investment: 57.87 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity57.87* These investment figures are indicative
Location: BCCB is headquartered in Beijing, China, with a network of 116 branches throughout Beijing.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category FI Type 1 project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  BCCB will be required to establish an environmental management system to ensure that activities financed under relevant operations are consistent with applicable environmental, occupational health and safety regulations of China and IFC''s Exclusion List, designate appropriate individuals who will have responsibility for the environment and who will attend IFC''s environmental management workshops or an approved equivalent, and submit to IFC an environmental management plan and annual environmental performance reports.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community

Project Description:
DCM Shriram Consolidated Limited (DSCL or the company) proposes to invest $74.2 million towards capacity expansion and upgrade of the environmental standards of its plants in the Indian state of Rajasthan.  The project primarily involves expansion of the company's PVC and carbide production capacities, the replacement of the company's chlor-alkali production technology from mercury cells to the environment friendly and efficient membrane cells and supporting capital expenditure to increase captive power generation and expansion of  the company's network of agro-product retail stores.

The Delhi Cloth Mills Co. Ltd. (DCM) was founded in 1889 by late Sir Shriram as a spinning mill in Delhi.  Subsequently, it expanded and diversified into several industries, including sugar, chemicals, engineering and food products.  In 1990, DSCL was carved out as a diversified public limited corporation based in north India with two core businesses:

-  plastics & chemicals, and
-  agro-business.  

DSCL is headquartered in New Delhi and has annual revenues of about $315 million.  The company's production facilities in India are located in Kota (Rajasthan), Bharuch (Gujarat), Ajbapur (Uttar Pradesh), and Rupapur (Uttar Pradesh).
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The review of this project consisted of appraising technical and environmental information submitted by the project sponsor.  The following potential environment, health and safety, and social impacts of the projects were analyzed: Site location (including land ownership and land use), and environmental conditions; Environment, health, and safety (EHS) management; Water source and liquid effluent; Air emissions, workplace monitoring, and ambient air quality; Workplace and ambient noise levels; Hazardous materials handling; Mercury bearing brine sludge landfills; Other solid/hazardous waste handling and disposal; Occupational health and safety; Fire prevention and emergency response plans; Energy consumption and energy efficiency; Community involvement and relationship; EHS situations at other DSCL operation locations.Further details are provided in the Environmental Review Summary available separately with this document.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityEnvironmental documentation will be made available at the following location:

DCM Shriram Consolidated Limited
Shriram Nagar, Kota 324 004 
(Rajasthan) INDIA
Phone: +91-744-248-0991
Fax: +91-744-248-0296
Sponsor: DSCL and its subsidiaries are owned by three Shriram brothers  the sponsors are Messrs. Ajay Shriram, Vikram Shriram and Ajit Shriram who have a 52.7% shareholding in DSCL.  The balance shares are held by the general public (14.1%), banks and financial institutions (22.6%) and other corporates (10.6%).
Investment: 30.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan30.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The project is located at the company's existing facilities at Kota, in the Indian state of Rajasthan.  Kota, an industrial city about 400 km south of Delhi on the main Mumbai-Delhi railway line, is well connected to both cities: four and a half hours by train to Delhi and overnight to Mumbai. The plant site is 3 km from the main Bombay-Delhi line, has its own siding and is linked to the country's large railway network, facilitating dispatch of finished goods such as cement, urea and other products to customers as well as to bring in naphtha and other bulk feedstock.  Though the nearest airport is about 240 km away at Jaipur, Kota is also well connected by road as it is on one of the major north-south national highways, giving the company additional logistical flexibility.

Company Name: Consorcio Energetico Punta Cana Macao, S.A.
Role:
IFC's guarantee and senior loan will be used to help finance CEPM's and CEB's capital expansion plans, which include the wind project, two diesel engines, acquisition of hotel customers in Uvero Alto and the associated transmission lines for these subprojects.  The wind power project will secure a clean source of energy.  This is important for CEPM, as it serves resort areas where clean environments are critical.  The company needs to invest in additional generation capacity in order to supply reliable electricity to its customers in both service areas.  The company is additionally diversifying its generation assets by investing in wind turbines to produce some of its electricity with renewable energy and thus offsetting the use of fuel oil.

IFC will also directly contribute to the development of an Environmental and Social Management System (ESMS), which will be used by the company as a management tool in meeting their social and environmental goals and obligations.  This will be the first wind power investment in Dominican Republic and will additionally be financed by a private company.  This is will be IFC's first investment with Basic Energy, the majority owner of CEPM Energy Ltd.  By supporting CEPM, IFC expects to encourage greater involvement and investment by Basic Energy and ENDESA in renewable energy and the Caribbean.

.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The review of this project consisted of appraising technical and environmental/ social information submitted by the project sponsor and a site visit by IFC staff.IFC''s appraisal focused on the ongoing environmental and social performance of CEPM''s existing investments, as well as its capacity to ensure compliance with applicable host country regulatory requirements and World Bank Group environmental and social policies and guidelines for projects under development.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe environmental documentation will be made available at the following locations:

Edif. Ambar, 5ta. planta, Esquina Av. A. Lincoln y J.F. Kennedy

Carretera Arena Gorda 
Bávaro, prov. La Altagracia

Compañia de Electricidad de Bayahibe
Carretera Dominicus 
Bayahibe, prov. La Altagracia
Sponsor:
CEPM is owned 60% by CEPM Energy Ltd. and 40% by ENDESA of Spain.  Mr. Rolando Bunster, owns 66 2/3% of CEPM Energy Ltd. through his holding company Basic Energy and his partner, Miguel Barletta,  owns the remaining 33 1/3% of CEPM Energy Ltd.

The sponsors of the Project are CEPM, CEPM Energy Ltd., its majority owner, Mr. Luis Roland Gonzales Bunster, and ENDESA of Spain.
Cost Nature: Total project cost is estimated at $42.5 million, of which IFC is expected to fully guarantee up to a $12.5 million loan for the wind project and provide a senior loan of $10 million for a total exposure to IFC of $22.5 million.
Investment: 25.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuarantee15.0Loan10.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Headquartered in Santo Domingo, CEPM owns and operates the power generation and distribution lines serving the Bavaro and Punta Cana area in the eastern part of the country and the power generation and distribution assets serving the Bayahibe area in the southeastern part of the country.  CEPM's assets include 18 power generating units of 56 MW of total installed capacity, two substations and 14 km. of 69 kV lines and about 200 km. of 12.5 kV and lower voltage lines.  CEB's assets include six power generating units of 13 MW of total installed capacity and 25 km. of medium voltage lines and 8 km. of low voltage lines.

Project Description: IFC is considering an equity commitment of up to $5 million to the BioVeda China Fund (the fund or BioChina), an investment vehicle to be established by a select group of institutional investors, to invest in Chinese biotech and life sciences companies.  The Fund will be managed by BioVeda Capital (the manager or BioVeda), a Singapore/US headquartered biotech investment firm which currently manages a $32 million venture fund that has invested in the US and Asia.  The fund is targeting a first closing in early 2005.  BioChina targets to raise up to $25 million to be invested in 3-5 companies to whom the fund would provide both expansion capital and management expertise in order to help to grow their businesses significantly.  Exits are expected to be achieved through a stock exchange listing or a strategic sale.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category FI Type 2 project according to IFCs environmental review procedure.  The fund has committed to establishing an environmental management system that will ensure that investments are consistent with applicable host country environmental laws and regulations as well as applicable World Bank Group environmental, health and safety guidelines and policies;  designating appropriate individuals who will have responsibility for the environment and who will attend IFCs environmental management workshops; submitting to IFC an environmental management plan;  obtaining clearance by IFC for any category A or infrastructure investment by the fund; and submitting to IFC an annual environmental performance report.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: BioVeda Capital provides venture capital financing to companies in the life sciences with leading proprietary technologies, and outstanding scientific and management talent.  BioVeda also plays a role as a business and scientific bridge between companies in the East and West, linking finance and technology between the two markets.  With offices in Singapore and San Francisco, BioVeda has a combination of broad scientific and medical expertise, and financial and investment experience to assist investee companies. The General Partners of Bioveda are Dr. Zhi Yang and Mr. Damien Lim. Dr. Zhi Yang has two decades of experience in biotechnology, having held senior scientific and management positions in a variety of US and Chinese biotech and pharmaceutical companies. He holds an M.A. and a Ph.D. in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology from Harvard University.  Mr. Damien Lim has over 16 years of private equity and investment banking experience. Mr. Lim received a Bachelor of Business Administration from the University of Houston.
Cost Nature: BioChina targets to raise up to $25 million and the proposed IFC equity investment is up to $5 million.  IFCs ultimate investment would represent less than 20% of the funds total capitalization.
Investment: 5.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity5.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The main legal entity for the fund would be a Cayman Islands limited partnership.  The primary geographic focus of the investments would be China.  The investment team would operate primarily out of China.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category FI Type 2 project according to IFCs environmental review procedure.  The fund has committed to establishing an environmental management system that will ensure that investments are consistent with applicable host country environmental laws and regulations as well as applicable World Bank Group environmental, health and safety guidelines and policies;  designating appropriate individuals who will have responsibility for the environment and who will attend IFCs environmental management workshops; submitting to IFC an environmental management plan;  obtaining clearance by IFC for any category A or infrastructure investment by the fund; and submitting to IFC an annual environmental performance report.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sector: BA - Private Equity/Venture Cap Fund - Country

Company Name: Generale De Banque De Mauritanie Pour L'Investissement Et Le Commerce
Project Description: The project consists of an IFC term loan of up to $12 million to Generale Banque de Mauritanie (GBM, the Bank or the company), a well know IFC client, for on-lending to medium and long term project finance transactions in Mauritania and the sub-region.  As of September 30th 2004, GBM, which was formed in 1995, had $151 million in assets, a loan book of $123.5 million and $48 million in shareholders equity, which makes it the largest bank in terms of net worth and loans in the country with a 26% market share.  The proposed project will be IFC's fifth investment with GBM.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an FI Type 2 project.  GBM will need to demonstrate that its existing environmental management system is adequate to address the environmental and social issues of the projects to be financed under this new financing.  GBM must require all subprojects to be carried out and operated in compliance with the applicable environmental, health and safety (EH&S) requirements of the country where the subproject is situated. In addition, subprojects whose total cost is less than $500,000 must be consistent with IFC''s Microfinance Exclusion List. Subprojects whose total cost is $500,000 or greater must be carried out in accordance with IFC''s safeguard policies, be consistent with IFC''s Exclusion List, and meet the host country requirements. GBM must obtain IFC clearance prior to making any loan or investment with IFC funds in any Category A subproject, and such a subproject must meet the applicable EH&S guidelines and safeguard policies of the World bank Group.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor:
GBM was established in 1995 as a unique partnership in the Mauritanian Banking Sector between a major European financial group (Belgolaise Fortis Group) and a number of Mauritanian businessmen from various origins, led by Mr. Mohamed Bouamatou, the Bank's founder and main shareholder.  GBM's strategy since inception has been to offer to selected corporate customers a wide range of banking services, using state of the art technology and leveraging its relationship with its foreign partner.  

Mohamed Ould Bouamatou, the largest shareholder of the Bank, controls 31.04% of GBM's shareholdings.  Mr. Bouamatou is a well-respected local entrepreneur with a wide variety of business interests.  Apart from his activities in Mauritania, Mr. Bouamatou is a shareholder in African Financial Holdings, the holding company of the bank of Africa Group.  Belgolaise Bank (Belgolaise) is the second largest shareholder with a 30% stake in the Bank.  Belgolaise is 100% owned by Fortis Group, one of the largest European banks.  Belgolaise has developed an extensive network of associated commercial banks in more than 10 countries in Sub-Saharan Africa. Groupe MAOA, the largest industrial group in Mauritania is the third largest investor in the bank with a 23% interest in GBM.  MAOA, which is majority owned by Mohamed Abdullah Ould Abdallah, primarily operates in the agriculture, trade and fishing industries.
Cost Nature: The proposed IFC investment consists of an equivalent in Euro of $12 million term loan to GBM to be used for on-lending to sub-borrowers.
Investment: 9.74 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan9.74Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: GBM is headquartered in Nouakchott, Mauritania and has another branch in Nouadhibou.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is an FI Type 2 project.  GBM will need to demonstrate that its existing environmental management system is adequate to address the environmental and social issues of the projects to be financed under this new financing.  GBM must require all subprojects to be carried out and operated in compliance with the applicable environmental, health and safety (EH&S) requirements of the country where the subproject is situated. In addition, subprojects whose total cost is less than $500,000 must be consistent with IFC''s Microfinance Exclusion List. Project Description:
The project consists of the build-out and expansion of the leading mobile operator in Paraguay, Telefonica Celular del Paraguay S.A.'s (Telecel or the company) GSM network, as an overlay to the Company's existing nationwide AMPS and TDMA networks.

Telecel is controlled by Millicom International Cellular S.A. (Millicom or MIC) which holds 96% of Telecel's shares, and Estrella Solitaria S.A. which holds the remaining 4%.  The company began operations in 1992, as a provider of analog (AMPS) cellular services.  In 1997, it was awarded an additional license to provide digital (TDMA) cellular services.  The company's existing operations cover approximately 80% of the total Paraguayan population and 75% of the addressable mobile market.

As of June 2004, the company had approximately 485,000 mobile subscribers, and an estimated market share of 43%.  For the fiscal year ended December 31, 2003, Telecel achieved revenues of $61.0 million equivalent, EBITDA of $24.4 million equivalent, and net income of $4.7 million equivalent.  The company's performance in 2004 is on-track, with revenues of $32.0 million equivalent, EBITDA of $13.4 million equivalent, and net income of $3.5 million equivalent as of June 30, 2004.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category B project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure.  Potential environmental and social issues include corporate environmental and social management systems to ensure compliance of Project facilities with local requirements and World Bank policies and guidelines; environmental management and performance of existing network; site selection, land acquisition procedures and construction impacts of proposed expansion of network (towers, switching center and base stations); development of previously undisturbed land; impacts on environmentally or culturally sensitive areas (national parks, forests and other cultural heritage features); fuels/hazardous materials use; waste management; employee health and safety; and training and emergency response.IFCs Social and Environment Unit have already reviewed the documents that have been provided, and there does not appear to be any significant issues in this regardLocation of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe Environmental Review Summary will be published in newspapers in Paraguay and made available in the company's website.
Sponsor: The main shareholder is Millicom International Cellular S.A. (Millicom), a B+ rated (S&P) global cellular telecom operator with 16 cellular operations and licenses in 15 emerging market countries (Africa, Asia and Latin America).  As of September 2004, Millicom's cellular subscriber base worldwide was 6.85 million.  Millicom's 2003 revenues totaled $641 million equivalent and EBITDA was $318.2 million equivalent.  The company is listed on the NASDAQ and on the Luxembourg Stock Exchanges.  Millicom has a total market capitalization of $2.1 billion.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is expected to be $66.3 million.  The proposed IFC investment is a $15 million A loan for IFC's own account.
Investment: 15.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan15.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The company is headquartered in Asuncion, Paraguay.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category B project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure.  Potential environmental and social issues include corporate environmental and social management systems to ensure compliance of Project facilities with local requirements and World Bank policies and guidelines; environmental management and performance of existing network; site selection, land acquisition procedures and construction impacts of proposed expansion of network (towers, switching center and base stations); development of previously undisturbed land; impacts on environmentally or culturally sensitive areas (national parks, forests and other cultural heritage features); fuels/hazardous materials use; waste management; employee health and safety; and training and emergency response.IFCs Social and Environment Unit have already reviewed the documents that have been provided, and there does not appear to be any significant issues in this regardLocation of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe Environmental Review Summary will be published in newspapers in Paraguay and made available in the company's website.

Project Description:
Peter Hambro Mining Plc (PHM, Hambro or the company), a UK listed gold company, is engaged in gold mining and the acquisition, exploration and development of gold properties in Russia.  Hambro holds a number of licences principally in the Amur Oblast including those covering the Pokrovskiy area, Pioneer, Tokur, Malomir Surround, Voroshilovskoye and additional properties in other regions of Russia.

Hambro has a 97.7% interest in Pokrovskiy Rudnik, which holds the above licenses.  Hambro brought its first mine, Pokrovskiy, into production in 1999.  The project relates to the ongoing investment program towards exploration of these properties including the feasibility studies, detailed engineering and environmental and social impact assessments and other preparatory activities.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a Category B project according to IFC''s Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because it is an equity investment to provide funding for exploration work, feasibility studies and detailed engineering and environmental and social impact assessment (ESIA) documentation. The review of this project consisted of appraising technical and environmental information submitted by the project sponsor as well as a visit to the project site. The following potential environment, health and safety and social impacts of the projects were analyzed:-  Corporate and operations environmental and social management-  Open-pit mining (topsoil stripping, waste rock dumping, surface water diversion, pit dewatering, reclamation);-  Ore processing (heap leach, resin-in pulp processing plant, air and effluent emissions);-  Tailings management (tailings treatment, transport and storage);-  Exploration drilling activities including establishment of access roads, geological/construction camps and vegetation clearing;-  Waste generation (domestic, industrial, hazardous and sanitary);-  Occupational health and safety issues;-  Public consultation and disclosure; and-  Socio-economic issues.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe ERS will be available for public viewing at the following locations:
-  City of Tygda 
-  City of Blagoveschensk 

-  Moscow

Moscow,  103 064

Sponsor: Hambro was formed in 1994 through a partnership between Pavel Maslovsky and Peter Hambro.  Pavel Maslovsky is the largest shareholder with 26.82 % of the shares and Peter Hambro holds 8.84 % of the shares.
Cost Nature: The total cost for the investment program in exploration, feasibility study and project assessment is estimated at $50 million.  The proposed IFC investment is a $15 million equity investment with matching warrants.

Project Description:
Ransa Comercial S. A. (Ransa or the company) is an integrated logistics service company based in Lima, which specializes in handling, storage, and distribution of grains, frozen food, and other general cargoes as well as providing services such as in-bond warehouses, shipping agency, stevedoring services, and trucking.  Ransa is the market leader in the distribution and storage business in Peru.  It is a 100% subsidiary of the Romero Group.  In 1999 IFC approved a $10 million loan (IFC/R99-116) for Ransa's expansion and improvement of operating efficiency; as of December 31, 2004, $6.25 million remains outstanding to IFC.

Ransa's consolidated USD revenue has grown at an average of 15.2% p.a. from 2000 to 2003, storage volume has increased by 7.8% p.a. for the same period.  To accommodate this growth Ransa has been leasing space from Minka, a sister company operating wholesale and retail space in Lima.  Minka has given notice to Ransa that it will terminate the lease in 2004.

As a result of the lease termination, and to accommodate future growth, Ransa has now decided to embark on a capacity expansion project consisting mainly of the following components:

-  the construction of a 13,500-m² warehouse for general merchandise, 
-  the construction of a 15,000-m² warehouse for distribution, and 
-  the acquisition of a 86,600-m² plot.  

In addition the project includes investments in MIS, other capital expenditures, and debt refinancing.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The review of this project consisted of appraising technical and environmental social conditions at main Ransa Comercials operating companies.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe Environmental Review Summary (ERS) will be available to the public at Ransa Comercial S.A., Av. Argentina 2833, Callao, Peru and in Ransa's website www.ransa.net.pe
Sponsor:
-  The Romero Group:

Headed by Mr. Dionisio Romero, the Romero Group (the Group or the Romero Group) is Peru's largest private business group with the following major holdings: Banco de Crédito, the country's largest commercial bank; Alicorp (a large agroindustrial company operating in the following segments: wheat flour, pastas and rice; edible oil, margarine, shortenings and laundry soaps; cookies and crackers; animal feed; and other food products and service); Palmas and Industrias del Espino, Peru's largest palm oil estate (5,000 ha) and crusher; Ransa, the country's largest integrated logistics company; Romero Trading an export/import trading operation (coffee, cotton, mangoes, soybean meal); Industrias de Aceite in Bolivia representing large soybean plantations (7,000 ha), the country's second largest soybean crusher, and Bolivia's largest edible oils operator. The Romero Group also has a few other smaller businesses like auto and truck dealerships.  Total direct employment of the group is about 10,000 people. 

The Romero Group is not an incorporated (holding) company but rather represents the Romero Family interests' consolidation.  Only those Companies in which the Family has a controlling position are included in the Group; hence, the financial sector interests' are excluded from the Romero Group (refer to 'The Romero Family Financial Sector Participation' section below for additional information).  To date the Romero Group is composed of the following companies:
-  Alicorp, 
-  Ransa, 
-  Palmas e Industrias del Espino, 
-  Romero Trading, 
-   Industria Textil Piura, 
-  Universal Textil, 
-  Consorcio Naviero Peruano, 
-  Trabajos Marítimos, and 
-  Terminal Internacional del Sur (the latter three companies are in the shipping sector.)

The Romero Family Financial Sector Participation
Banco de Crédito del Perú (BCP) was the first bank to be established in Peru (founded in 1889) and is now the largest banking institution in the country.  In December 2002, BCP acquired Banco Santander Central Hispano-Perú (BSCH-Perú), whose financials are included in BCP's consolidated financial statements since such date.  BSCH-Perú was merged into BCP on February 28, 2003. 

BCP is 97% owned by Credicorp, a financial holding company incorporated in Bermuda in 1995 and listed on the New York Stock Exchange.  Credicorp is owned by the Romero family (18.7%) and directors and senior officers of the group (3.2%); with the remaining shares held by other investors.  The Romero family controls Creditcorp with 25% of the voting rights.  Credicorp is now the largest financial services holding company in Peru and is closely identified with its principal subsidiary, BCP.  Credicorp is engaged principally in commercial banking (through BCP and Banco Tequendama in Colombia), insurance (through El Pacífico-Peruano Suiza), and investment banking (through Atlantic Security Holding Corporation).
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated $20 million.  The proposed IFC investment is a $10 million A loan for IFC's own account.
Investment: 10.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan10.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Project funding will be directed to investments in Callao, Peru.  The investment will be made at Ransa's 245,000 m² main operating complex located in Callao, close to the Lima's international airport and the Callao sea port.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The review of this project consisted of appraising technical and environmental social conditions at main Ransa Comercials operating companies.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe Environmental Review Summary (ERS) will be available to the public at Ransa Comercial S.A., Av. Argentina 2833, Callao, Peru and in Ransa's website www.ransa.net.pe

Project Description:
PT Ecogreen Oleochemicals Limited (Ecogreen or the company), an IFC portfolio company, was established in 1989 and has grown to become the world's fourth largest and Indonesia's only producer of natural fatty alcohols.  At present, Ecogreen has a production capacity of 122,000 tpa and annual sales of about $105 million.  Ecogreen has two production plants in Indonesia, located at Batam and Medan, and affiliated marketing and distribution companies in Singapore, Germany and the USA.  The company exports 95% of its production, about 50% to Asia-Pacific and about 20% each to the Americas and Europe.  Ecogreen also sells fatty acids, methyl esters and glycerin, which are by-products of the fatty alcohol production process.

Ecogreen plans to implement a $50 million project in which IFC will invest up to $25 million as an A Loan, to add 70,000 tonnes per annum (tpa) to its existing fatty alcohol production facility at Batam, Indonesia using technology from Davy, UK.  The project would allow the company to improve its international competitiveness.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. The review of this project consisted of appraising technical and environmental information submitted by the project sponsor.  The following potential environment, health and safety impacts of the projects were analyzed: Environmental, health and safety management; Raw material sourcing; Air quality impacts (including odor) and abatement; Waste water quality, temperature and treatment; Cleaner production; On-site solid waste management procedures; Handling and storage of fuel and other hazardous materials; Fire safety and emergency response; and Community relations and community development.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityPT.Ecogreen Oleochemicals

Sponsor:
The company is owned through a holding company structure whose shareholders are:  Messrs. Eddy William Katuari and Fifi Sutanto (representing the Wings group) 47.7%; Mr. Jimmy Masrin and PT Lautan Luas Tbk (representing the Lautan Luas group) 33.3% and Mr. Robert Budi Hartono (representing the Djarum group) 19%.  

The main sponsor of the company is the Wings group, which is one of Indonesia's largest producer and marketer of soaps and detergents.  The Wings Group has seven main business activities: consumer products; packaging; chemicals; building materials;   real estate; agribusiness and financial services.  Of these, the consumer products business is the largest in annual turnover.  IFC has existing relationships with three of the Wings group companies (PT Sayap, PT Wings, PT Gawi and PT Prakars).  The other two members of the consortium are the Djarum group, one of the largest Indonesian cigarette manufacturers, and the Lautan Luas group, which is Indonesia's leading distributor and manufacturer of basic and specialty chemicals.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated to be about $50 million including contingencies but excluding incremental working capital.  The proposed IFC investment is an A loan for IFC's own account in an amount of up to $25 million.

Location: The plant will be established at the company's existing facilities in Batam, Indonesia.  Batam is an island off the coast of Singapore connected to it by an hour-long ferry ride. It is also connected by flights to Medan and Jakarta, both about one hour away.  The Batam plant is a stand-alone facility with independent power, steam generation and water supply.   At Batam, the raw material, diesel, LPG and other feedstock are unloaded through an adjacent public jetty through dedicated pipelines.  This jetty is capable of berthing three 12-meter draft vessels simultaneously.  The jetty and related facilities also allow movement of material through isocontainers and dry containers.

Company Name: CSRC China (Ma'anshan) Chemical Industry Co., Ltd.
Project Description:
China Synthetic Rubber Corporation (CSRC or the company) is a carbon black manufacturing company with the capacity to produce 60,000 tons per year (tpy) of carbon black and generate up to 9 MW of power from its co-generation facility, located in Maanshan City, Anhui Province, China. The company has requested IFC financing for the debottlenecking and expansion of the existing plant to increase its production capacity to 125,000 tpy.  

The project will consist of two phases:
- debottlenecking of the existing facility (phase I);
- installing an additional production line and 12 MW of new power co-generation and building a new warehouse (phase II). 

IFC financed the company's original project in 2001 (IFC/R2001-0140), which was to upgrade and modernize the obsolete carbon black plant acquired from a state-owned enterprise, providing $9.0 million in A loan and $2.0 million in equity for a 13.8% shareholding in the company.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category B project according to IFCs procedure for environmental and social review of projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result, which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Further details are provided in the Environmental Review Summary separately available with this document.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityEnvironmental documents, including the ERS and EAP, will be posted at the notice board of the Maanshan City Library.  In addition, the announcement of the public disclosure of ERS will be announced via ads in the local newspapers.
Sponsor: The project sponsor is China Synthetic Rubber Corporation (CSRC), that owns 86.2% of the company indirectly through its wholly owned subsidiary, CSRC Singapore Limited.  Founded in 1973, CSRC is one of the world's leading carbon black producers and technology providers.  CSRC became a listed company in 1986 and its shares are freely traded on the Stock Exchange.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $27.4 million.  IFC's proposed investment is $12 million, consisting of an equity investment of up to $1.0 million and an A loan of up to $11.0 million.
Investment: 12.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan11.0Equity1.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The project is located in the industrial area of Cihu, a major industrial complex in the northwest section of Maanshan city in the Chinese province of Anhui, about 300 km west of Shanghai.  At present, the area of the project site is approximately 137,158 m2 covering the carbon black production lines, power generation facility, feedstock storage, warehouse and administration buildings.  As an expansion program, the project company may purchase the land use rights for an additional three adjacent lands to the current project site totaling 47,533 m2  some of which will cover two new production lines and the remainder reserved for future use.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category B project according to IFCs procedure for environmental and social review of projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result, which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Further details are provided in the Environmental Review Summary separately available with this document.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityEnvironmental documents, including the ERS and EAP, will be posted at the notice board of the Maanshan City Library. Project Description: Embraer - Empresa Brasileira de Aeronáutica S.A. (Embraer, or the company) is one of the worlds leading commercial aircraft manufacturers, and is the largest manufacturer located in a developing country.  Embraer is currently engaged in a strategically important extension of its product line and consolidation of its position as a global player.  The IFC project would help Embraer achieve this goal by providing financing, on commercial terms, for the launch of its program for the new Embraer 170/190 Family of aircraft.  The Family comprises four models that seat between 70 and 118 passengers.  The company has already delivered some of the first model  the Embraer 170 and expects to receive certification of the other models in the coming years.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category B project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure. Sponsor: Privatized in 1994, Embraer is listed on the BOVESPA in São Paulo (tickers EMBR3 and EMBR4) and has American Depository Receipts listed on the New York Stock Exchange (ticker ERJ).  As of October 30, 2004, the  companys main shareholders include PREVI (a pension fund for the employees of Banco do Brasil) 16.24%; SISTEL (a pension fund for the employees of Telebrás) 7.06%, Grupo Bozano (privately-held Brazilian investment group) 10.61%, Dassault Aviation 2.19%, Thales 2.19%, EADS 2.19%, Snecma 1.16%, and the Government of Brazil 0.33%, with a free float of approximately 51.16% ( BOVESPA  14.15% and NYSE  37.02% ).  Embraer reported $2.1 billion in net revenue in 2003, of which about 85% was derived from manufacturing passenger aircraft, consisting primarily of ERJ 145 jet Family that seat between 37 to 50 passengers.  With about 95% of its net revenue derived from exports, Embraer is consistently among the countrys largest exporters.  More information about the company can also be found on its internet site ( http://www.embraer.com).

Project Description: The proposal is to make an investment of up to $15 million in GP Capital Partners III (GPCP III or the Fund).   The Fund has a target size of $200 million and will make control-oriented equity and equity related investments in companies either located in or which have significant business activities in Brazil.  The Fund will be structured as a 10-year Cayman Islands exempted limited partnership with a commitment period of five years.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a FI Type 2 project.  GP Capital III will be required to undertake an environmental review of each subproject. IFC will assess GP Investimentos capability to carry out environmental reviews.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: GP Capital Partners III is sponsored by GP Investimentos and will be managed by a team of 8 investment professionals, including 5 Investment Partners. The Fund will follow a similar strategy as GP Capital I closed in 1994 and GP Capital II closed in 1997.  GP Investimentos was formed in 1993 to manage private equity investments and its activities today also include hedge fund management and real estate finance. The controlling shareholders of GP Investimentos are: Antonio Bonchristiano, Fersen Lamas Lambranho and Marcelo Peano.
Cost Nature: The Fund's target size is $200 million.  IFC's investment would be up to $15 million for capital contributions as well as management fees and expenses, limited to the investment of the largest other single investor and to less than 20% of aggregate commitments in GP Capital Partners III.

Project Description: The project involves the establishment of a new Shariah compliant life insurance (Takaful) company to be named Al-Ahli Life Takaful Company (Al Ahli Takaful or the company) in Saudi Arabia with an IFC equity investment of up to $4.67 million (up to 17.5% shareholding). The company will be sponsored by National Commercial Bank (NCB), the largest commercial bank in Saudi Arabia as well as the Arab world. The technical partner will be the FWU AG Group Germany, a financial services group that is primarily active in the unit linked life insurance and asset management and has been in operation since 1989. FWU has developed an extensive knowledge base and know how of Takaful Industry and has been working with NCB on this project over the last year. NCB being the largest player in the mutual funds market with a customer base of over one million customers, will manage the investment strategy, marketing, sales and distribution, whereas FWU will assist in product development, provide actuarial and IT support.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an environmental and social category C project. No further environmental or social analysis is required.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: Prior to the expected Initial Public Offering (within 3 months of inception), the company is expected to have the following shareholding structure:- The National Commercial Bank (NCB) - 40.0%- FWU - 25.0%- IFC - 17.5%- Other Saudi Corporates - 17.5%- Total - 100.0%The National Commercial Bank (NCB): NCB is the largest Arab commercial bank with total asset of over $31 billion. Net income during 2003 totaled $827 million and Shareholders equity at year-end 2003 totaled $2.8 billion. The bank currently has 252 domestic branches out of which 111 branches exclusively offer Islamic banking services. NCB is the market leader in the mutual funds market in the Kingdom with a total market share of 43.5% at the end of FY 2003. The total assets under NCBs fund management amounts to $6 billion, of which over 75% are Sharia Compliant. The FWU-Group:  FWU is a small, diversified, German financial services group that has been in operation since 1989.  The group is 95% owned by its executive management with its founder Manfred Dirheimer holding a controlling interest. The remaining 5% is held by GE Capital. Its primary activities  are unit linked life insurance and asset management offered through subsidiaries based in Luxemburg.
Cost Nature: The company will have an initial capital of $26.695 million. IFC is expected to have up to 17.5% equity stake in the company (about $4.67 million).

Project Description: Hidroelectrica La Higuera (HLH or the project) is a 50:50 joint venture formed in May 2004 by Pacific Hydro Limited (PHL) and Statkraft Norfund Power Invest AS (SNPI), collectively, the sponsors.HLH will build, own and operate a 155 MW run-of-the-river hydro power plant located in the Tinguiririca Valley east of the city of San Fernando. The project diverts the Tinguiririca River and its major tributary Azufre just upstream of their confluence.  At a gross head of 367 meters and a design flow of 50 m3/s, the installed capacity is 155 MW in two generating units equipped with vertical Francis turbines in a surface powerhouse.  Firm capacity is estimated at 128 MW and average annual energy production at about 840 GWh.  A 38 km long transmission line will be built to connect with Chiles central grid at San Fernando.
Role: The project will contribute to the expansion of cost-effective hydroelectric generation capacity to support electricity demand growth in the Central Interconnected System of Chile (SIC).  As the projects water inflows are primarily determined by snow and glacier melting, La Higueras hydrology is not closely correlated with that of the system.  Hence, it is expected La Higuera will be available to dispatch at full load from November through March during the dry season, when the hydrology in the system is below average and the cost of generation tends to be higher (as increasing costly units are dispatched in merit order).       In addition, the project will generate significant direct and indirect employment in the project area.  It is expected that about 500-600 local jobs will be created directly in connection with the construction of the project.  Also, the project will contribute to reduce greenhouse gas emissions as well as emissions of local pollutants by displacing electricity, particularly during the dry season, that would otherwise have been generated by thermal  plants.IFC, by supporting the project, is therefore playing a key role in ensuring additional power capacity is built in Chile that will help meet the countrys future power demand growth, without being affected by external events such as the recent gas disruption from Argentina to Chile.  In addition, given hydropower projects are generally capital intensive and as a consequence are in need of long-term debt financing, IFC has an important role to play in this transaction in providing 15-year A and C loans and mobilizing a B Loan with up to 13 years in maturity.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an environmental and social review category A project.  The following aspects of the project were analyzed:  public consultation and disclosure, development impact of the project, impact of the project on climate change, water rights and uses (including cumulative and downstream impacts), population/land use, impact of the project on recreation, management of quarries and tunnel spoil disposal, and consistency with IFC's policies on involuntary resettlement, safety of dams, international waterways, natural habitats, and cultural property.  Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityEnvironmental documentation will be made available at the following locations:- Oficinas CONAMA, Región Metropolitana, Teatinos 254, Santiago Centro, Chile  - Oficinas COREMA, VI Región, Rancagua, Hermano Claudio 364, Rancagua. Chile - Oficinas Municipalidad, San Fernando, Carampange 845, San Fernando, Chile - Hostería "Casa Piedra", Puente Negro, Camino Internacional Puente Negro S/N, Chile For more information, please visit:  www.pacifichydro.com.au/Chile/Environment; www.hlh.cl.
Sponsor: PHL was founded in 1992.  Its core business is the development of hydro and wind projects using proven technologies. The companys shareholder structure is comprised of the following major investors: - Industry Funds Services (IFS) as the overall manager of several Australian industry funds with about 31.8% of issued capital;- AEP Investments Inc. (based in Columbus, Ohio) with 15.8%;- Institutional investors with 17.8%; and - Retail investors with 34.6%. PHLs revenues and net income for 2003 were $33.2 million and $21.1 million, respectively.  Total assets and shareholders equity at end of 2003 were $198.2 million and $149.5 million, respectively. SNPI was established in 2002 as a joint venture between Statkraft SF (50%) and Norfund (50%). The objective of SNPI, through participation in or cooperation with other companies, is to plan, design, construct, operate and own energy facilities. SNPIs revenues and net income for 2003 were $3.1 million and a negative $4.6 million, respectively.  Total assets and shareholders equity at end of 2003 were $191.8 million and $140.7 million, respectively.  Statkraft SF is a Norwegian state-owned power company wholly owned by the Ministry of Trade and Industry, and is Norways largest producer of electricity.  Statkrafts revenues and net income for 2003 were $1.7 billion and $421 million, respectively.  Total assets and shareholders equity at end of 2003 were $12.9 billion and $5.1 billion, respectively. Norfund was established by the Norwegian Parliament in 1997. Norfunds revenues and net income for 2003 were $8.9 million and $7 million, respectively. Total assets and shareholders equity at end of 2003 were $260.4 million and $257.5 million, respectively.
Cost Nature: Total project cost is estimated at $212 million, of which IFC is expected to contribute $137 million through a combination of: - an IFC A Loan of up to $35 million;- an IFC B Loan of up to $92 million; and - an IFC C Loan of up to $10 million.
Investment: 45.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan45.0Equity0.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The projects power plant will be located in the Tinguiririca Valley 60 km east of the city of San Fernando in Region VI of Chile and about 150 km south of Santiago. The land is privately owned and is used in the summer for vacation homes and for livestock grazing.  The closest established settlement is Puente Negro (population of 600), about 30 km downstream of the powerhouse.  There are no indigenous people in the area.  The project site is already accessible by road from San Fernando. In addition, a 145 MW upstream project called La Confluencia is under consideration for development by the Sponsors at a later stage.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is an environmental and social review category A project.  The following aspects of the project were analyzed:  public consultation and disclosure, development impact of the project, impact of the project on climate change, water rights and uses (including cumulative and downstream impacts), population/land use, impact of the project on recreation, management of quarries and tunnel spoil disposal, and consistency with IFC''s policies on involuntary resettlement, safety of dams, international waterways, natural habitats, and cultural property. Project Description:
The proposed project is an initiative to provide local currency financing and technical assistance to private K-12 schools in Ghana. It is the first such initiative in the education sector. IFC would provide a partial guarantee of up to 9.5 billion cedis ($1.1 million equivalent) to The Trust Bank (TTB, the Bank, or the company) on loans extended to eligible private schools in the Accra region. These loans will be used to finance construction, purchase of educational materials, and other capital expenditures.  In parallel with the financing facility, a comprehensive technical assistance program is under preparation. The program will be designed to strengthen schools' financial, management, and educational capacities; improve the business environment for private education; and foster the development of an independent provider of educational services to private schools. 

Currently, few local banks are lending to private primary and secondary schools, and those that do, generally lend for less than two years. Thus, even if schools are able to secure bank financing, the tenor of that financing is generally not long enough to support expansion or modernization projects. Such projects thus proceed in a piecemeal fashion, resulting in a great deal of inefficiency and lost potential revenue. Further, expansion by such means cannot keep pace with the huge growth in demand for private schooling. IFC's guarantee would be structured to encourage the Bank to extend maturities to 3-5 years, tenors more appropriate for financing capital investments. 

Despite the impressive growth of private schools in Ghana over the past 15 years, most remain fundamentally weak in their financial and managerial capacities, as well as in their ability to develop more effective educational delivery mechanisms. The majority of schools has minimal financial expertise, weak information systems, if any, and limited opportunities for teacher training and curriculum development. The technical assistance program designed in conjunction with the financing facility is intended to address many of these shortcomings for participating schools, and, in addition, to strengthen the environment for private school operators.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a Category FI Type 1 project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure. The Trust Bank will be required to establish an environmental management system that will ensure that investments are consistent with applicable host country environmental laws and regulations;  designate appropriate individuals who will have responsibility for the environment and attend IFCs environmental management workshops or an approved equivalent; and submit to IFC an environmental management plan and annual environmental performance reports.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityEnvironmental documentation will be made available at the following location:

The Trust Bank, 
Reinsurance House, 
68 Kwame Nkrumah Avenue, 
P.O. Box 1862, 
Accra. Ghana
Sponsor: The Trust Bank Limited was established in November 1, 1996 to take over the assets and liabilities of the liquidated Meridien BIAO Bank. It is currently owned by six institutions: Belgolaise Bank (35%), Social Security & National Insurance Trust (33.09%),  Holding Cofipa (10%), FMO (10%), African Tiger Mutual Fund (6%), and Ghana Reinsurance Company Limited (5.91%). TTB, a licensed commercial bank, provides general financial intermediation with a focus on universal retail banking services. In terms of asset size, it is the eighth largest bank in Ghana. The core of TTB's customers are in the middle-tier market segment, mainly SMEs and corporate bodies engaged in sectors such as agribusiness, commerce, construction, manufacturing and services. TTB is considered one of the most SME friendly banks in Ghana. It is also one of the few banks that lends to schools; its school portfolio is currently the best performing of all its SME sectors.
Cost Nature:
This transaction would be structured as a risk-sharing guarantee with TTB. IFC's guarantee will cover 50% of the principal credit losses that are in excess of a 5% first loss threshold up to a maximum of 9.5 billion cedis (equivalent of $1.1 million) with respect to the credit performance of a pool of loans to schools originated by TTB. The Bank's first-loss position would have to be fully exhausted before IFC would have to pay any guarantee claims under the program. The portfolio is expected to reach a size of 20 billion cedis ($2.2) over the next 18 to 24 months. Individual loan sizes will range from 200 million cedis ($22,500) to 3 billion cedis ($337,100).

Under the proposed structure, with IFC as second loss partial guarantor, IFC would reimburse the Bank for half of the principal credit losses of the underlying loans (but only when credit losses exceed 5%).  IFC's 47.5% share of the second loss guarantee represents our maximum potential liability under this structure.  IFC's partial guarantee would be denominated in local currency.
Investment: 1.08 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuarantee1.08LoanEquity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The Trust Bank is headquartered in Ghana at: Reinsurance House, 68 Kwame Nkrumah Avenue, Adabraka, Accra. It has eleven additional branches located in Accra, Kasoa, Kumasi, and Tema. The participant private schools will be drawn from the Greater Accra Region.

Project Description:
The project will be a greenfield elementary and secondary school built in two phases.  The first phase will construct 19,000 square meters of space which will incorporate academic blocks, laboratories, large rooms for specialty classes, a multi-purpose sports center, administration building and parking area.  The second phase will add an additional 6,000-9,000 square meters of space for an additional academic block, arts center, cafeteria, teacher accommodations, and outdoor sporting areas.   By the completion of the second phase, the facilities will be able to accommodate 1,700 students.

The school is intended to be a flagship of the SABIS group, and as such, will be a showcase for the complete range of educational products and services provided by Intered.  
Some of the key features of the services to be provided are:

- complete curricula aligned with international standards;
- software systems including: an Academic Monitoring systems (AMS) and Computer Based Examinations (CBE) to uniquely monitor and report on student performance;
- text books that support the SABIS instructional program; and 
- patented learning methodologies. 

The company estimates that the initial investment required for setting up the institution would be approximately $26 million, spread over a four-year period. IFC has been requested to provide $8 million of debt.
Environmental Social Issues: Based on the available information, this is a category B project according to IFC''s environment and social review procedure.  Issues to be addressed include fire and life safety provisions for all buildings, water supply and wastewater disposal, solid waste disposal, storage of hazardous materials (if any), provisions for student healthcare, and employee health and safety during construction.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe Environmental documents are located in the INTERED corporate offices: P.O.Box 811;Jounieh, Lebanon.
Sponsor:
The new company is being sponsored by The SABIS Group, which has the experience of running 27 schools in 11 countries with over 25,000 students.  The SABIS Group is owned by two families, the Saad and Bistany families which are descended from the original founders of the Choueifat school.  The families' sole corporate interests are the Sabis school network including  Intered S.A.L.  

The first school in what is now the SABIS School Network was the International School of Choueifat (ISC), located in the village of Choueifat, a suburb of Beirut, Lebanon. In the mid-seventies, Intered started running schools outside of Lebanon.  Currently, Intered S.A.L, based in Beirut, Lebanon manages 17 schools in Africa, the Middle East and Asia while an American affiliate, SABIS USA manages 10 schools in Europe and the USA.  Some of these schools were newly established, but others were operating when Intered began to manage them.  As such, Intered has experience in all aspects of school establishment, including architectural and functional design, construction management, staff training and recruitment, alignment of curricula, development of transitional curricula, academic monitoring, are financial management, The SABIS curriculum is highly structured and designed to pride themselves on achievement of high academic results.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is $25.8 million and IFC participation in an A Loan is of $7.8 million

Project Description: Scancom Limited (Scancom or the company) is the leading provider of GSM mobile telecommunication services in Ghana, with just under one million subscribers or a 65% market share expected end of 2004.  The company launched its operations in 1996. As of December 2, 2004, Scancom is a fully licensed operator (Scancom, like all the other operators in the country, was only authorized operator until then) for a duration of 15 years. The company has also been granted a license to operate its own international gateway.Scancom currently offers coverage in all major cities in Ghana. In addition to its GSM mobile phone services, Scancom has developed alternative wireless GSM products, including community-shared GSM handsets offering substitution for fixed line access. Scancom is also in the process of introducing a broad range of value added services.  The project supports the expansion of Scancoms network in capacity and coverage to sustain the subscriber base growth over the next three years (subscriber numbers are expected to more than double by end of 2007). The project also supports Scancoms improvement of its operating status through the funding of the companys new operating license. The project will allow also the optimization of Scancoms capital structure by increasing its leverage (the company currently has no long-term debt, the only long term liability it has is the one for the repayment of license fee). The project is expected to cost approximately $160 million throughout 2005-2007. Scancom is seeking total external financing of $50 million.
Environmental Social Issues: Since this is Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of projects, a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts  may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityEnvironmental documentation will be made available at the following IFC Office in Accra: IFCNo. 150 Roman RoadRoman RidgeAccra, Ghana
Sponsor: Scancom is owned and is managed  by the Investcom Group (Investcom) which owns 97.65% of the companys shares and manages the company under a management contract. The remaining 2.35% are owned by Zent International, a financial investor in Scancom.  Investcom is a privately-held group providing both fixed and mobile telecommunications services with a focus on markets in Africa and the Middle East.  It has cellular operations in seven countries: Benin, Cyprus, Ghana, Guinea Bissau ,  Liberia, Syria and Yemen. The group is also part of a consortium which has been awarded the second mobile license in Sudan.  Zent International is a subsidiary of the Zubair Group, a diversified business group based in Oman.  The Zubair Group is involved in general trading, manufacturing services, real estate investments, mechanical, electrical and civil engineering activities.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $160.5 million which represents the foillowing components:-  Scancoms new operating license cost ($22.5 million) and -  Capex needs for 2005-2007 ($138 million).  IFC is expected to team up with the OPEC Fund to provide $40 million and $10 million respectively in external funding to the company.  The balance of the project cost is expected to be funded through the companys cash-flow.
Investment: 40.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan40.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Scancoms headquarter is located in Accra, Ghana, and currently operates in 10 regions of the Country.  The company plans to increase its population coverage and enhance quality of its service.  Investments will be made in both greenfield and existing sites.
