Project Description: The Municipality of Guatemala City has a $45 million capital expenditure program to mainly develop the first phase of a Mass Transit System (MTS) within the city. This segregated busway will improve public transport through a combination of: route restructuring; replacement of existing fleet with high-capacity buses; and creation of dedicated lanes, transfer stations and bus stops.  To finance these investments, a local bank has helped the city partially to raise a syndicated loan from national banks. The purpose of the project is to provide part of the funds (and technical assistance) to close the syndicated loan and support the underlying investments.  In the event that there are still funds available after the completion of the first phase of the MTS project, these funds could be used for other infrastructure projects of the Municipality.
Environmental Social Issues: Segregated busways have shown to be among the more environmentally effective approaches to public mass transit in the developing world.  Experience from such projects as TransMilenio, the bus rapid transit system for Bogota, Colombia has demonstrated reduced air emissions, noise, and fatalities from traffic accidents as a result of such busways.  In addition to environmental benefits there will also be fuel efficiency gains.  On the social benefits side, one can also expect users to experience significant savings in travel time.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: The Municipality of Guatemala City has a total population of approximately 2.9 million and more than 250,000 households. Among the main services the City provides to its inhabitants are transportation, water and sanitation and solid waste management. For 2003, the Municipality's budget was approximately $60 million and the consolidated budget, including the water company, the public transportation company and the municipal police, was approximately $133 million.
Cost Nature: The total funding raised through the syndicated loan is expected to be in the range of $45 million. IFC's exposure on its own account would be limited up to $12 million equivalent.
Investment: 6.63 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuarantee6.63LoanEquity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The Municipality of Guatemala City is one of the 17 municipalities located in the Department of Guatemala in Guatemala. The proceeds of the syndicated loan will be used largely to finance the first phase of the MTS.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: Segregated busways have shown to be among the more environmentally effective approaches to public mass transit in the developing world.  Experience from such projects as TransMilenio, the bus rapid transit system for Bogota, Colombia has demonstrated reduced air emissions, noise, and fatalities from traffic accidents as a result of such busways.  In addition to environmental benefits there will also be fuel efficiency gains.  On the social benefits side, one can also expect users to experience significant savings in travel time.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sector: AD - Transit and Ground Passenger Transporation

Project Description:
Established in 1955, Arcelik A.S (Arcelik or the company) is the market leader in Turkey's household appliances sector, with revenues of  approximately $2.4 billion in 2003.  International revenues accounted for approximately 50% of this amount. Its asset size was $1.8 billion at the end of 2003.

The company pursues a two-fold strategy targeted at the following components:

-  maintaining its dominant position in the domestic market and 
-  strengthening its position internationally through brand development, export sales, as well as through acquisitions and greenfield expansions abroad.  

Arcelik has state-of-the-art production facilities, practices advanced production management techniques, maintains cutting-edge research and development (R&D) capabilities and has experience in implementing new technologies and launching innovative products.  In 2002, Arcelik started to develop operational and commercial bases outside Turkey with the acquisition of Romania's only producer of refrigerators and the purchase of five West European brands.  The project supports this strategy through helping the company implement a number of corporate-wide initiatives, including those related to the modernization and capacity increases of existing plants, R&D, information technology, production and the establishment of a green-field washing machine plant in Russia.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental, health and safety, and social/community impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The environmental review consisted of appraising technical, environmental, health and safety, and social/community information submitted by Arcelik.  The following EHS and social/community impacts were analyzed:-  Arceliks commitment to quality and performance including ISO certifications, implementation of the TPM and Six Sigma programs;-  Compliance of the manufacturing plants in Turkey, Romania and Russia with IFC, Turkish, Romanian and Russian environmental, health and safety requirements; and-  Social and community issues.Based on the appraisal of this project and the information currently available, the proposed expansion projects and the new plant in Russia will meet the applicable local (i.e. Turkish or Russian) EHS requirements as well as IFC environment and social policies and the environmental, health and safety guidelines.  IFC will evaluate the projects compliance with the applicable Turkish/Russian and IFC environmental, health and safety, and social/community requirements by reviewing an Environmental Impact Assessment for the Russian project and annual monitoring reports prepared for the project covering ongoing performance of EHS and social/community activities.  Periodic site supervision visits will also be conducted including a visit to the Russian project site once it is selected.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityEnvironmental documentation will be made available at the following locations:

Municipal Office Bulletin Boards located in Tuzla and Eskisehir, the company's website and local newspapers.
Sponsor: The project will be implemented by Arcelik.  Arcelik is 57.3% owned by Koc Group, a leading Turkish industrial conglomerate with investments in consumer durables, automotive, financial services, energy and trade and services.  The Burla Group holds 22.3% of Arcelik, while the remaining 20.4% is publicly traded on the Istanbul Stock Exchange.
Cost Nature: Arcelik would use the IFC financing to fund part of its corporate investment program estimated at 285 million ($379 million).  The IFC financing is a loan package consisting of an 80 million ($106.4 million) for IFC's own account and a loan of up to 80 million ($106.4 million) on the account of participants.
Investment: 106.14 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan106.14Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location:
Arcelik is headquartered in Cayirova, Turkey, approximately 50 kilometers from Istanbul, with 8 other production facilities located in the Istanbul area, Eskisehir, Ankara, Tekirdag (Cerkezkoy), and Bolu in Turkey and Gaesti in Romania.  Manufacturing facilities consist of washing machine, refrigerator, cooking appliance, vacuum cleaner, dishwasher, electrical motors, and compressor plants ranging in areas from 18,000 to 57,000 m2/plant.

The greenfield washing machine plant contemplated by Arcelik's corporate investment program will be built on a site located in an industrial zone in the vicinity of a large city in the European part of Russia.  Currently, the company is in the process of making its choice among several potential sites.

Company Name: Yantai North Andre Juice Co., Ltd.
Project Description:
Yantai North Andre Juice Co., Ltd. (North Andre or the company) is one of China's leading producers and exporters of apple juice concentrate (AJC).  Established in 1996, North Andre has become a major global AJC participant with total processing capacity in excess of 150,000 tons per season.  Its net sales rose about 55% in 2003 to $44.0 million and based on year-to-day figures continue to grow robustly in 2004.  North Andre is listed on the Growth Enterprise Market of the Stock Exchange of Hong Kong.

North Andre has been pursuing an expansion and diversification business strategy within the apple juice and related-products sector.  It upgraded and/or expanded plants in the following provinces:  Shannxi, Shandong (two plants), and Jiangsu.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a Category B project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedures.  Environmental, social, health and safety issues that were reviewed during appraisal included: -  site selection and acquisition; -  management systems for quality, environmental and social affairs; -  occupational health and safety and working conditions; -  social issues and corporate social responsibility; -  control of pests species and technical assistance programs for fruit product out growers; -  air emissions from steam and heat generation; -  sustainability and quality of potable water supply used in food manufacturing; and -  management of liquid, solid and hazardous wastes. This is a Category B project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedures. -  Local newspaper (Yantai Daily);

-  Offices of local government authorities.
Sponsor:
North Andre's main shareholders are Glory Cause (32.2%), Donghua Fruit (16.8%), Donghua BVI (10.4%), Chengdu Uni-President (5.0%), Mr.Yung Ka Hee Titus (2.0%) and Beijing RAJ (0.7%).  The remaining 32.9% shares are held by public shareholders.

Glory Cause and Beijing RAJ are controlled by Creat Group, a limited liability company incorporated in China in 1996 with investments in the hi-tech, electronics, communications, pharmaceutical and agribusiness industries.  Creat Group's largest single shareholder (52%) is Mr. Zheng Yue Wen, who serves as North Andre's Chairman.

Donghua Fruit and Donghua BVI were founded by Mr. Wang An, who is also North Andre's CEO.  Donghua Fruit is a diversified company whose scope of activities includes agribusiness, construction materials, and general merchandise.

Project Description: The Microfinance Downscaling Facility (the facility) is an investment and technical assistance project designed to support commercial banks in Latin America, Africa, Asia, and the Middle East that have a strategic interest in expanding their lending operations to microentrepreneurs (downscaling). The facility, undertaken in collaboration with ACCION International, would establish downscaling units at commercial banks designed to attend the underserved entrepreneurial population. At the conclusion of the program, participating banks are expected to serve at least 100,000 low-income microentrepreneurs with appropriate and sustainable financial services.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Financial Intermediary (FI) Type 1 microfinance project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  Each institution supported by this project will be required to designate appropriate individuals to have responsibility for environmental issues, and to establish an environmental management system to manage environmental opportunities, as well as ensure that activities financed under relevant operations are consistent with applicable local environmental, occupational health and safety regulations and IFC''s Microfinance Exclusion List.  IFC''s Sustainable Financial Markets Facility will contribute to the Technical Assistance Component of this project by providing microfinance-oriented training on environmental, health and safety risks and opportunities, to help microfinance borrowers build better businesses.  Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: ACCION International is U.S. based private non-profit organization founded in 1961. At year-end 2003, its network of 25 affiliates and partner organizations had 1.2 million active borrowers with outstanding loans valued at more than $640 million.  Over the past 25 years, ACCION has been a leader in the commercialization of the microfinance industry, including as the sponsor of BancoSol in Bolivia, the very first microfinance program to transform into a regulated entity in 1991. ACCION''s technical assistance teams have helped build and strengthen some of the most successful microfinance institutions in the world by championing a market-based approach that enables partner institutions to become profitable, permanent parts of the financial systems in the countries where they operate. In particular, as a result of its longstanding involvement in the sector, ACCION has developed cutting-edge expertise in the area of microfinance downscaling.
Cost Nature: The total cost is estimated at approximately $72 million. The proposed IFC investment include $5 million in grant funding for technical assistance services and $15 million in commercial funding to participating banks to support the expansion of their microenterprise loan portfolios. The remainder will be provided by the participating banks themselves.
Investment: 15.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan10.0Equity5.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The facility is global in nature but will focus on Africa. Individual transactions will take place in a variety of countries in Africa, Latin America, Asia and the Middle East.

Each institution supported by this project will be required to designate appropriate individuals to have responsibility for environmental issues, and to establish an environmental management system to manage environmental opportunities, as well as ensure that activities financed under relevant operations are consistent with applicable local environmental, occupational health and safety regulations and IFC''s Microfinance Exclusion List.  IFC''s Sustainable Financial Markets Facility will contribute to the Technical Assistance Component of this project by providing microfinance-oriented training on environmental, health and safety risks and opportunities, to help microfinance borrowers build better businesses.  Location of environmental documents In locally affected community

Project Description:
The project consists of expanding and diversifying the operations of Altyn Ajydar (AA or the company), an existing client of IFC and the leading producer of corrugated carton packaging in the Kyrgyz Republic (KR).  It involves the construction, equipping and placing into operation of a cardboard and fluting paper facility with capacity of 8,250 tons p.a., a plastic packaging facility with capacity of 2,400 tons per annum, and the modernization of the existing corrugated packaging plant reaching capacity of 25 million tons per annum.

The project will allow AA to diversify into plastic packaging, improve operating efficiencies in the cardboard packaging business through economies of scale and achieve additional savings from import substitution of raw material.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a category B project, according to IFC environmental and social review procedures. Key issues include liquid effluents, work place noise levels and work place air quality; solid waste disposal and employee training provided on environmental, health, and safety matters. Sector: AG - Paper Packaging Products (Including Boxes, Cartons, etc.)

Project Description: Nuquls core business is the integrated production, distribution, and marketing of hygienic paper products including tissue paper, baby and adult diapers, feminine pads, table napkins, toilet rolls, and paper toweling. The proposed project is to support the Groups on-going expansion by providing:-  funding for balance sheet restructuring and meeting the 2004-2008 $150+ million core business investment program; and -  technical assistance in corporate governance.
Role: The project will adopt world-class engineering and equipment technology that will lower production cost and maintain the highest quality.  The Project will also allow Nuqul and third party converters to avoid imports of jumbo rolls and the associated higher transport costs.  The Project will create many job opportunities in the Middle East; for example, the Al Sindian expansion will create approximately 100 jobs at average wages that are almost three times the per capita GDP in Egypt.  IFCs role involves the following components:-  IFCs corporate loan would be supporting the financing needs of a Middle East regional player in its strategy to grow its operations in challenging markets.  Moreover, IFCs flexible long-term financing at the corporate level would help the Group in its efforts to consolidate ownership of the core business companies which would require restructuring of intercompany guarantees, and increasing the average maturity of the Groups debt to have a better-matched asset/liability position -  Nuquls management has expressed strong interest in IFCs value-added approach to corporate governance.  IFCs strength in corporate governance is a strong and timely fit with the needs of this family controlled conglomerate looking to go public.
Environmental Social Issues: The Groups existing facilities generally comply with both Jordanian and Egyptian EHS requirements and the requisite laws and regulations as well as the IFC environment and social policies and the environment, health and safety guidelines.  Further agreed mitigation measures have been discussed and agreed with the Group. This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The review of this project consisted of appraising technical, environmental, worker health and safety, labor and community information provided by the project sponsor as well as site visits to the paper mill and associated production facilities in Amman, Jordan and Cairo, Egypt.  The following environmental, worker health and safety, labor and community impacts and issues associated with the project sponsors current activities as well as the potential impacts of the proposed expansion program were analyzed:-  the compliance of the Nuqul Group with Jordanian and Egyptian environmental and worker health and safety (EHS) requirements as well as IFCs EHS requirements;-  the commitment of the Nuqul Group to quality and to international EHS performance including ISO (Quality and Environmental Management) and OHSAS (Occupational Health and Safety) certifications; and-  the commitment of the Nuqul Group to their labor force and the community.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityEnvironmental documentation will be made available at the following locations: - Manufacturing locations in Jordan in both Sahab and Urenibeh areas.- Manufacturing locations in Egypt in Giza area.- Local newspapers in both Jordan and Egypt.
Sponsor: The Nuqul Group (the Group, Nuqul,or the company) is a regional manufacturing conglomerate headquartered in Amman, Jordan.  The Group is headed by Mr. Elia Nuqul and consists of a conglomeration of 27 companies operating in 9 countries and selling in 47 markets. The Group is a longstanding client of IFC. The Group is family owned, with Mr. Elia Nuqul, founder, his eldest son, Ghassan, and younger son, Marwan, having the largest individual shares.
Cost Nature: The proposed project is to support the Groups 2004-2008 $150+ million core business investment program.  IFC financing involves a corporate loan of up to $25 million to finance the project.

Project Description:
PT Austindo Nusantara Jaya Finance (ANJ or the company) is engaged in the business of financing consumer purchases of new and used automobiles.  The company was previously known as PT Elbatama Finance.  In 2003, the name was changed to its current name.

The project consists of an IFC loan of up to $20 million (IFC Loan) equivalent in Indonesian Rupiah (IDR) to ANJ.  The proposed IFC loan would help ANJ to expand its automobile financing/leasing activities, diversify its funding base and better match its asset/liabilities.  

Due to the lack of long term fixed IDR financing in the market, there is heavy reliance on short-term debt to finance longer-term assets leaving leveraged companies (i.e., leasing/financing companies) vulnerable to financial shocks.  The proposed IFC Loan will help ANJ to better match its long-term assets with its liabilities, reducing mismatch risks.  Since the Asian Financial Crisis of 1998, currency mismatches continue to be a key concern; therefore the IDR based loan would significantly reduce foreign exchange risk.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category FI Type 1 project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure.  ANJ will establish an environmental management system to ensure that activities financed under relevant operations are consistent with applicable environmental, occupational health and safety regulations of Indonesia, designate appropriate individuals who will have responsibility for the environment and who will attend IFC''s environmental management workshops or an approved equivalent, and submit to IFC an environmental management plan and annual environmental performance reports.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: The project sponsor is PT Austindo Nusantara Jaya (Austindo), which owns 80% of ANJ.  Austindo is a private Indonesian investment company wholly owned by the Tahija family.  Austindo was established in 1985 to serve as the investment vehicle/holding company for the Tahija family's business activities that range from agribusiness, power generation, and mining to financial services.  Other shareholders of ANJ include PT Nusantara Chase Investment Ltd. (10%) and Capital Risk Management Ltd. (1.6%).
Cost Nature: The proposed IFC investment is a secured senior loan for IFC's own account to ANJ in the amount of up to $20 million equivalent.
Investment: 15.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan15.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative

Project Description:
The proposed Fund is a closed-end special purpose vehicle, structured as a Collateralized Debt Obligation (CDO), which will invest in emerging market debt issues, both in primary and secondary markets.  The Fund is expected to be at least 70% invested at target closing, in a globally diversified portfolio of US Dollar denominated debt issues from approximately 33 countries.  Pacific Investment Management Company LLC (PIMCO, or the Fund Manager) will manage the Fund.
The Fund is structured to offer investment opportunities both to existing emerging markets investors and to credit quality-sensitive institutional investors who can only invest in investment grade instruments.  Against the assets of the Fund, three classes of obligations are expected to be issued in the amount of $300 - 400 million:  
-  Senior Notes,  
-  Second Priority Notes, and 
-  Subordinated Shares (Equity).  
The Senior and Second Priority Notes will be rated by the rating agencies including Moody's and Standard & Poor's.  At inception, all three classes of obligations will have a 12-year maturity.
The assets of the Fund (the Collateral Pool) will consist of a US Dollar denominated portfolio of emerging market corporate bonds and loans, quasi-sovereign bonds and loans, sovereign bonds and loans, and synthetic securities, and include both investment and non-investment grade securities.  The exact composition of the Collateral Pool will be determined after the rating requirements of the rating agencies are met.  

The expected profile of the Collateral Pool is:  
-  up to 52% invested in emerging markets corporate and quasi sovereign bonds and loans; and 
-  up to 48% invested in sovereign bonds and loans.  

In addition, IFC will require the Fund Manager to accumulate a minimum of 10-15% bucket of primary issues consisting of credits which are one-notch below their respective sovereign ratings.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an environmental review category C project.  All potential corporate issues considered for inclusion in the underlying asset pool will require that the issuer''s business does not involve activities on IFC''s exclusion list. Corporate issues from companies with known poor environmental and/or social practices will be excluded.  The Fund Manager will implement a screening procedure to determine the suitability of corporate issues for inclusion in the Collateral Pool.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: PIMCO is one of the world's leading fixed income managers with over $394.7 billion in assets under management (as of March 31, 2004).  Based in Newport Beach, CA, PIMCO was established in 1971 to offer separate account management services primarily for employee benefit plans, endowments and foundations.  PIMCO distinguishes itself as one of the most respected names in fixed income management  due in large part to the success of its innovative total return approach.  The PIMCO Bond Team has received numerous accolades, including being named Morningstar's Fixed Income Manager of the Year twice, in 1998 and 2000.
Cost Nature: The Fund's target size is $300 - 400 million.  The proposed IFC investment is $30 million in subordinated and second priority notes.
Investment: 30.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan15.0Equity15.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Location of the project is not applicable. The project is a global fund which will invest in 33 countries. The Fund Manager will be located in Newport Beach, California.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is an environmental review category C project.  All potential corporate issues considered for inclusion in the underlying asset pool will require that the issuer''s business does not involve activities on IFC''s exclusion list. Corporate issues from companies with known poor environmental and/or social practices will be excluded.  The Fund Manager will implement a screening procedure to determine the suitability of corporate issues for inclusion in the Collateral Pool.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Company Name: Societe Burkinabe De Promotion Hoteliere Sa
Project Description:
The project consists of renovating and expanding Hotel Independance (HI) into a three-star international business hotel with 180 rooms, located in Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso (BF).  In an effort to revamp the hotel, the Government of Burkina Faso (GoB) has leased the property for fifteen years through an open bidding process to Société Malienne de Promotion Hôtelière (SMPH), an existing IFC client.  SMPH created 'Société Burkinabè de Promotion Hôtelière" (SBPH) for the purpose of acquiring and operating HI.  

SMPH sees strong potential in HI because of its size and strategic location, close to the heart of Ouagadougou's business and administrative district. By modernizing, HI would help raise the standard of the hospitality industry in BF.  SMPH seeks IFC's involvement in the project to obtain long-term financing and support for its first investment and expansion outside of Mali.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a category B project.  Key issues associated with this project include: sewage treatment; solid waste disposal; water and power supply; CFCs; fuel storage; fire safety; hygiene and housekeeping; and general employee safety and training.   Under the new management, HI employees are trained through performance-based incentives in an effort to raise efficiency standards in the hospitality sector.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityHotel Independance
01 B.P. 127 Ouagadougou 01
Burkina Faso
Sponsor: SBPH is owned 60% by SMPH and 40% by Burkinabè businessmen.  SMPH is majority owned by Mr. Mossadeck Bally, a Malian businessman with experience in managing hotels.  SMPH is an existing client who over the past few years received IFC financing to renovate the Grand Hotel and build the Hotel Salam in Bamako.

Project Description:
The proposed $150 million project is to establish a Tourism Loan Facility which will provide IFC with a flexible platform from which to support promptly and efficiently tourism companies severely affected by the recent tsunami disaster in South-East Asia.  The Facility will be utilized for financing the following components: 

-  the reconstruction/rehabilitation of tourism properties damaged by the tsunamis; 
-  the increased working capital requirements of tourism companies due to slowdown in demand in the region; 
-  the acquisition, by long-term strategic investors, of hotels and other lodging properties that have suffered damages and face uncertain market prospects as a result of the tsunamis; and 
-  the debt restructuring of tourism companies facing financial difficulties due to damaged property and/or slow-down in demand.  

The Facility will assist established hotel companies in the tourism sector in Thailand, Sri Lanka, Maldives, and Indonesia, who thanks to their distinctive brands, ability to develop attractive properties and well-established relationships with tour operators, will be important in restoring confidence and bringing tourism back to the affected destinations.

It is anticipated that the proposed Facility will enable IFC to support a number of companies (the 'Sub-projects') in the Maldives, Sri Lanka, Thailand and other affected countries, and thus ensure diversification of the portfolio.  Full utilization of the proposed Facility is anticipated within one year.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental impacts may result that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The review of each Sub-project financed by the Facility will consist of an appraisal of technical and environmental information requested from the respective sponsor as well as a site visit as required.  The following potential environmental, social, health and safety impacts of each Sub-project are likely to be considered: site selection and land acquisition for new facilities, protection of cultural property and natural habitats, environmental reviews and permits for new and reconstructed facilities, potable and wastewater treatment, solid waste handling and disposal, use of CFCs in cooling systems, hazardous materials management, occupational health and safety, life and fire safety, and the environmental management capacity of each Sub-project sponsor.  Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe environmental and social documentation for any and all Sub-projects financed by the Facility will be made available at appropriate public information outlets, including local administrative offices, libraries and the project facilities themselves, or in some other culturally appropriate venue, 30 days prior to commitment.  In accordance with IFC's procedures for the disclosure of information, the location of the environmental and social documentation will be announced in the local English-language and vernacular press, or through other culturally appropriate means as required.
Sponsor: Project sponsors and major shareholders have yet to be determined.  It is expected that the proposed Facility will enable IFC to support about 4-5 companies.
Cost Nature: The project is to establish a tourism loan facility of up to $150 million equivalent that will provide IFC with a flexible platform from which to support promptly and efficiently tourism companies affected by the recent tsunami disaster in South-East Asia.  The total project cost is estimated at about $400 million.  The proposed IFC investment would be up to $150 million equivalent.
Investment: 150.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan150.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Tourism companies affected by the tsunami disaster in South-East Asia, especially the Maldives, Sri Lanka, Thailand and Indonesia.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental impacts may result that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe environmental and social documentation for any and all Sub-projects financed by the Facility will be made available at appropriate public information outlets, including local administrative offices, libraries and the project facilities themselves, or in some other culturally appropriate venue, 30 days prior to commitment.  In accordance with IFC's procedures for the disclosure of information, the location of the environmental and social documentation will be announced in the local English-language and vernacular press, or through other culturally appropriate means as required.

Project Description:
The proposed project involves establishing a non-bank finance institution (the company) that will provide factoring and forfaiting (exclusively for trading purpose) services for export-oriented businesses in Egypt.  The initial capitalization of the company is expected to be $5 million and will be expanded to $15 million by the end of its fourth year.  The sponsors of this project include First International Merchant Bank (FIMBank)  as a 40% equity investor, Commercial International Bank Egypt S.A.E. (CIB)  as a 40% equity investor, and IFC holding the remaining 20% of the company's shares.  FIMBank will play the key role as technical partner capitalizing on its international expertise in factoring.  CIB will bring its local market expertise and client base into the new venture by leveraging on its existing market presence.  The company plans to start its operations with international factoring representing between 50-60% of the total business volume, and the rest divided between local factoring and small-ticket forfaiting.  Initially, the company will fund itself through equity, going forward other funding sources will be sourced at the local level.    

The project would create Egypt's first factoring company and is expected to cater to the needs of Egyptian exporters who currently require additional liquidity to fund their growing business needs.  With 38% of Egyptian exports flowing to the United States and Europe (countries with significant factoring activity), Egypt's export-oriented firms would be ideal for export factoring, given the exporters' short-term financing requirements and the relatively lower importer risk. The company would aim to be a one-stop-shop for exporters in Egypt and is expected to have a strong positive impact by enhancing the level of credit being made available to exporters in Egypt.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category C project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure. There will be minimal environmental and social impacts associated with this project. Therefore, no further environmental or social analysis is required.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor:
Commercial International Bank  

CIB was established in 1975 as a joint venture between National Bank of Egypt and the Chase Manhattan Bank. In 1993 CIB was listed in the local exchange and subsequently privatized. CIB's shareholders as of November 2004 are as follows: 

                                                        Shareholding
Individuals (all less than 1%)              25.3%
Foreign Fund Managers                      22.5%
National Bank of Egypt                      18.8%
Bank of New York's GDRs                  17.4%
Private Sector                                    5.6%
Public Sector Companies                     4.0%
Government entities                           3.2%
IFC                                                   3.2%

Total                                               100%

CIB's core market segment has traditionally been large corporations and it is currently the largest private bank in Egypt. The bank has followed a good credit policy, tight cost control procedures, a thorough training program and employs high quality staff. With a strong brand name and market position, the Bank has successfully invested in other JVs ranging from insurance, corporate finance, leasing, asset management and brokerage activities and is now expanding into retail lending. CIB is the highest rated Egyptian bank by the biggest International Rating Agencies: Standard and Poor's (S&P) assigned CIB a rating of BB+/Negative/B, Moody's a rating of Ba2 and Capital Intelligence a rating of BB+/Negative/B. This rating represents the national (sovereign) ceiling for Egypt. 

First International Merchant Bank  

FIMBank was established in 1994 by Kuwaiti Interests for Financial Investments (KIFFI) together with a group of institutional investors. The Bank is registered under the laws of the Republic of Malta and was granted its banking license in November 1994. The license enables FIMBank also to conduct full banking activities in all currencies, except the Maltese Lira. The bank is supervised by the Maltese Financial Services Authority (MFSA).  Fitch Ratings assigned FIMBank a long-term FCY rating of BB with a stable outlook.

As of June 2004 FIMBank's shareholders are as follows:

Other private individual and corporate holdings                                          19.92%

Total                                                                                                       100.00%

FIMBank's core activities include international trade finance, including ship scraping finance, trade finance for banks and trading companies, and commercial lending to trade-related customers.  While FIMBank operates from Malta, it has also promoted its services through a representative office in London and through regional business representatives in New York, Sao Paulo, Istanbul and Moscow.
Cost Nature: The projected growth of the company's operations estimates that the total capital required by the company will be $15 million. IFC's shareholding of 20% will correspond to a total investment amount of $3 million. The disbursement of the equity investment will be staggered over a period of four years  to match the growth in volume of new  business.

Project Name: Siam Industrial Credit Public Co Ltd
Company Name: Siam Industrial Credit Public Co Ltd
Project Description:
Siam Industrial Credit Public Company Limited (SICCO or the company) is a finance company listed on the Stock Exchange of Thailand with a market capitalization of approximately $100 million.  Total assets of  the company were THB36.5 billion ($877.0 million) as of September 30, 2004.  SICCO provides commercial and industrial financing for SMEs, and retail services, such as automobile hire/purchase and retail loans.

In January 2004, the Bank of Thailand (BOT) issued a new Financial Master Plan, a prime objective of which is to achieve further consolidation of  the  financial sector in Thailand.  The plan requires that all commercial banks currently possessing more than one banking license and/or maintaining more than one deposit-taking presence retain only one deposit-taking presence, and divest or merge any additional deposit-taking entities they may have.  As a result, this change will affect the funding strategy of SICCO.  

The purpose of this project is aimed at supporting SICCO diversifying its funding sources and extending the maturities of its liabilities.  The proceeds of this financing will be used primarily to fund the company's growing hire purchase business and SME finance.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an FI Type 1 project.  The company will be required to develop an environmental management system for the company and  require that investments under relevant operations meet host country environmental, health and safety requirements.  IFC will assess the company''s capacity for environmental review and will provide training as necessary.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor:
SCB owns 42% outstanding shares of SICCO.  The remaining shares are held by the public.  Sripravidh Co., Ltd., a holding company owned by the King, is a 1.4% shareholder of SICCO.

Established in 1906 under Thailand Royal Charter, SCB is the oldest bank in the country.  SCB provides a full range of traditional commercial banking services.  It has been listed on the Stock Exchange of Thailand since its inception in 1975.  As of 1Q04 it was the country's fourth largest bank with assets of Bt745 billion and a 12.7% share of the domestic credit market.
Cost Nature: The proposed IFC investment is a local currency, three-year senior unsecured A loan of up to THB 1.4 billion (approximately $35 million) for IFC's own account.

Location: Headquartered in Bangkok, SICCO has 16 lending offices throughout Bangkok and four trading rooms in the provinces.  The Bank of Thailand approved SICCO's request to open eight regional lending branches outside of Bangkok.  Loans can be made throughout the country.

The company will be required to develop an environmental management system for the company and  require that investments under relevant operations meet host country environmental, health and safety requirements. Project Description: The project involves the modification of Animal Waste Management Systems (AWMS) on swine, dairy or other livestock farms to enable the capture and disposal of methane, produced by animal waste.  This capture and disposal of methane will generate a stream of revenues through the creation and sale of Certified Emission Reductions (CERs) or Carbon Credits under the Kyoto Protocol.  The project involves modification of AWMS on sites in Brazil, Mexico and other countries over a several-year period.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific social and environmental impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The review of this Project consisted of appraising technical and environmental/social information submitted by the project sponsor.  Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityInitially, the document will be posted in the local language at the nearest local government office in which the Project is being undertaken.  Thereafter as the company rolls out more sites it will be provided at stakeholder meetings, will be made available to the farmers and can also be viewed on the company website (www.AgCert.com).
Sponsor: The project sponsor and developer is AgCert International Limited and its subsidiaries.AgCert has three (3) key sets of shareholders:  Andlinger Capital III (43.39%), XL TechGroup LLC (43.39%), (XLTG) and the AgCert employees (12.48%).
Cost Nature: The project cost will eventually be a function of the number of sites rolled out and the ability of the company to raise cash from debt or equity sources to finance the construction of the sites.  Under the current business plan, the company plans to construct 1,596 sites at an approximate cost of $120 million.  The total financing needs of the company are expected to be about $150 million over the next 2-3 year period. In addition to the up to $15 million from IFC, $10 million from the existing shareholders, the company is planning to raise a total of $75 million in a combination of equity and debt.

Project Description:
United Riceland Limited (URL or the company) is one of India's leading rice millers and exporters specializing in the premium segment of Basmati rice. URL was established in 1981 at Samana in the state of Haryana, 150 km north of New Delhi by the Thakrar family to export brown Basmati rice to the United Kingdom (U.K.). The company currently sells its products to the European Union (EU), the Middle East and is also active in the domestic market.

IFC entered into a $10 million Loan Agreement with URL in 1996.  The purpose of the loan was to finance the construction of a modern Basmati rice milling facility on a new site located 25km southwest of New Delhi, in Gurgaon.  Since then actual market developments as well as a positive turn in tariffs for Basmati rice has resulted in URL's decision to increase the project's scope.  

The company plans to increase aggregate capacity from 21 tons per hour to an aggregate nominal capacity of 30 tons per hour with a plant design to produce brown and white rice for sales to the EU, the Middle East, other countries and the domestic markets.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a category B project according to IFC''s environmental review procedure because specific impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines, or design criteria. At the time the project was appraised in 1996 and 2001 key social, environmental, and health and safety issues analyzed were air emissions; liquid effluents; solid wastes; ambient noise; fire and explosion risk; use of insecticides; and general employee health and safety.  Additional issues to be assessed during this appraisal include source and volumes of water required for both plants, including efforts to minimize water use; plant hygiene and product quality; use and disposal of hazardous materials; and corporate social responsibility efforts.  Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe ERS will be disclosed in the local library, Civil Lines in Gurgaon. In addition to that with the local Panchayat' (community representative recognized by the Government). 
The advertisement will be published in the 'Dainik Mewat', 753/6, Sadar Bazar, Gurgaon (Tel.: +91-124-2321047), a daily newspaper published in Gurgaon.
Sponsor: The company is privately held and is beneficially owned by Mr. N.R. Thakrar and other members of his family.
Cost Nature: The total project costs are estimated at $51 million. The proposed IFC investment is a $8.5 million A Loan for IFC's own account.

Project Name: CJSC AES Kyivoblenergo & CJSC AES Rivneenergo
Role:
IFC involvement will support the sustainability of the on-going reform and privatization process in Ukraine's electricity sector by supporting capital investments in two of the best performing companies in the sector.

The project's development impacts are expected to include: 

-  a reduction in outages caused by network faults (due to rehabilitation of assets); 
-  a reduction in energy losses to a sustainable level; 
-  improvement in customer services through modernization of billing and collection systems, and through more efficient handling of consumer complaints; and 
-  a demonstration of the economic gains of privatization which may encourage further privatization programs in the region. 

Additionally, IFC's investment in the project will provide the necessary long term financing which is currently unavailable in Ukraine.  Also, since a portion of the financing may be structured as a Hrivnya denominated loan, IFC's financing would also facilitate access to longer term local currency financing for a utility that has local currency revenues. In addition, IFC's involvement would introduce the Companies to IFC's environmental and social policies and help integrate these into their day-to-day operations.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The review of the project consisted of appraising technical and environmental/social information submitted by the Companies and a site visit by IFC environmental and technical staff.  The following potential environment, health and safety and social impacts of the project were analyzed:-  Effectiveness of environment, health and safety program;-  Environmental liabilities from past and current operations;-  Effectiveness of safety tracking and reporting systems;-  Right-of-way management; and-  Risks related to the Chernobyl energy complex.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityEnvironmental documentation will be made available at following locations:

Sponsor:
AES B.V. is the largest shareholder with 89.1% shareholding in KOE and 79.5% shareholding in ROE. The remaining shares are held by employees and financial investors who acquired shares either through a voucher privatization or on the stock exchange.

AES is a power holding company that operates a globally diversified portfolio of electricity generation and distribution businesses.  AES's affiliates operate over 100 individual power assets in 26 countries that span the US, Central and South America, Europe, Asia and Africa. AES is publicly traded on the New York Stock Exchange.

Project Description: Afren plc (Afren or the company) is a newly-established independent exploration and production (E&P) company with an exclusive focus on Africa. It plans to engage initially in the highly-prospective Gulf of Guinea, as a platform for longer-term penetration throughout Africas hydrocarbon provinces. The company is currently raising seed financing to fund its establishment and initial operating costs.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project, according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityEnvironmental documentation will be made available at the following location: Office of Taylor-de-Jongh (Afrens financial adviser) -  4, Millbank  London, SW1P 3JAUnited Kingdom
Sponsor: Afren was founded and registered as a public limited company in the United Kingdom in late 2004 by a group of predominantly African investors and directors.  These include Dr. Rilwanu Lukman (Nigerian), former Secretary General of OPEC, former Minister of Petroleum Resources of Nigeria and former Advisor on Petroleum and Energy to the President of Nigeria who has more than 40 years experience in the oil and gas industry;  Mr. Bert Cooper (Liberian), an entrepreneur with more than 20 years involvement in African natural resources;  Mr. Egbert Imomoh (Nigerian), former Deputy Managing Director of Shell Nigeria and Head of Shells external affairs program for community issues in the Niger delta;  Mr Guy Pas (Belgian) former CFO of the Addax & Oryx Group (Nigerias largest independent oil and gas producer) and chairman of Mano River Resources Ltd (a publicly traded West African mineral resources company based in London); and Mr. Osman Shahenshah, a Managing Director and Head of the London Office of merchant bank Taylor-de-Jongh who has over 15 years experience in financing oil and gas projects in emerging markets, primarily in Africa.
Cost Nature: The total budgeted establishment and operational costs (including contingencies) for Afrens first year of operations amount to $5.7 million. IFC is considering an equity investment in the form of ordinary shares of up to $1,000,000 equivalent.

Company Name: DEVELOPMENT FINANCE COMPANY OF UGANDA LIMITED
Project Description:
The project is to provide a multipurpose term loan to DFCU Ltd. (DFCU or the company) of up to $10 million (Note) with a maturity of up to 10 years including 3 years grace. A part of the project may involve partial guarantee of DFCU's local currency term borrowing from pension funds (or insurance companies) based in the East Africa region. 

The company is a former portfolio client of IFC's and is the forth largest banking group in Uganda. Established as a development finance company, DFCU has evolved into a multi-faced banking group and remains as the only specialized term lending institution in the country servicing mostly small and medium sized enterprises.

The objective of the project is three fold: 

- support DFCU's traditional line of business including term finance and leasing; 
- enable the company to develop the mortgage portfolio of its own thereby assisting the growth of Uganda's mortgage market; and
- foster competition in the local market, reducing costs for private sector in Uganda.

(Note) Given DFCU's interest in participating in IFC's Global Trade Finance Facility, an incremental trade line would be made available to the company.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Financial Intermediary (FI) Type 1/Type 2 project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  For IFC''s previous investment in DFCU, the company participated in an IFC environmental workshop.  For this subsequent investment, DFCU has committed to participate in another IFC environmental workshop.  DFCU will be required to implement and maintain an environmental management system to ensure that relevant operations comply with Ugandan environmental and social standards.  Any investment by DFCU in a Category A project will require the prior approval of IFC, and will be required to comply with applicable World Bank Group environmental, health and safety guidelines and IFC safeguard policies.  Any investment by DFCU made through IFC''s Global Trade Finance Facility will be required to comply with IFC''s exclusion list.  DFCU will be required to submit to IFC annual environmental performance reports.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor:
The company was established by the Government of Uganda (GOU) in 1964 as a development finance company to promote private sector projects in the country. Subsequently, the company has established itself as the prime point of contact for the foreign investors in Uganda. The core of DFCU Group consisted of three finance companies, DFCU Ltd. (term financing arm), DFCU Bank (commercial banking arm) and DFCU Leasing (former Uganda Leasing acquired in 1999). CDC of UK has historically played an active role in DFCU with a majority (60%) control of the company. 
IFC's first investment in DFCU dates back to 1984 when IFC took up a 25% shareholding in the company (Inv. No.723). In 1992, IFC had participated in DFCU's rights issue (Inv. No. 3345). In 2004, IFC and the Government of Uganda have offered a total of 40% stake in the IPO, which turned out to be the most successful IPO in the country's history, raising more than $10 million. Following the IPO, the shareholding structure of the company has changed to: CDC of UK (through Actis Capital LLP) with 60%; National Social Security Fund (NSSF, a national pension fund) with 10%, Norfund of Norway with 10%; and general public 20%. Today DFCU is a profitable institution with an asset base, net worth, and net income of $160 million, $22 million, and $5 million, respectively.
Cost Nature:
The project is to provide a multipurpose term loan to DFCU Ltd. (DFCU or the company) of up to 
$10 million with a maturity of up to 10 years including 3 years grace. 

Given DFCU's interest in participating in IFC's Global Trade Finance facility, an incremental trade line would be made available to the company.
Investment: 10.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan10.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: DFCU Ltd. is headquartered in Kampala, Uganda. Its banking subsidiary, DFCU Bank has branches in Kampala, Masaka, Lira and Arua in Uganda.

Project Description:
Through provision of railway rolling stock, Eurosib-Ivest CJSC and its subsidiaries Eurosib SPb - Transportation Systems CJSC and ERVK CJSC (collectively, Eurosibtrans or the goup), based in Saint Petersburg, offers transportation and logistics services to shippers of coal, steel, fertilizers, paper, lumber and other products within Russia and the former Soviet Union.  With extensive rail transport operations throughout Western Russia, Eurosibtrans' main business is the operation of owned and leased rolling stock for the transportation of bulk goods mainly in the North-Western Region of Russia and the provision of freight forwarding and logistics services.  

The IFC loans of up to $30 million would finance a part of Eurosibtrans' investment program comprising the acquisition of railway freight wagons in 2004 - 2006.

Project Description: The project consists of a line of credit of up to $20 million to Guaranty Trust Bank, Plc (GTB or the bank), the fifth largest commercial bank in Nigeria in terms of total assets and one of the three AAA rated banks in the country. The project's main objective is to address the scarcity of term finance in Nigeria. Despite a recent improvement in political stability and a commitment to market-oriented economic reform, Nigeria has yet to attract a level of foreign investment in line with the size of its economy. This is creating a critical constraint in the country's development goals, particularly as significant investments are needed to upgrade private sector productive capacity and operations to sustainable levels, and finance the privatization of major industries which the government has planned.  The proposed investment allows IFC to partially address these constraints by making available foreign exchange term resources through an efficient financial institution.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an FI Type 1 project, which requires the beneficiary bank to establish and maintain an environmental management system to ensure that investments under relevant operations meet host country environmental, health and safety requirements, and are consistent with IFCs exclusion list.  GTB has had a good record and is compliant with IFC environmental policies. However, the IFC will re-assess GTBs environmental management system and, if necessary, will work with the bank to strengthen its capacity to meet these requirements.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor:
The sponsor of the project is Guaranty Trust Bank Plc. GTB was founded in the early 1990s by Mr. Fola Adeola, (member of GTB's Board) and Mr. Olutayo Aderinokun (current Managing Director/CEO).  The two sponsors, who both had prior banking experience, felt that the time was right to start a niche bank because of the void created by the departure of most foreign banks from Nigeria.  GTB was incorporated in July 1990, obtained its banking license in August 1990, commenced operations in February 1991 and was listed on the Nigerian Stock Exchange in 1996.   GTB provides a full range of financial services to its customers, mainly mid to top tier corporate and institutional clients, and high net worth individuals. GTB is predominantly a commercial bank with a national branch network covering the major commercial/industrial centers in Nigeria. The operations are supported by a strong technology platform which links the entire branch network via a Wide Area Network with real time capabilities. GTB is also diversifying its activities both in terms of services and geography. Over the last two fiscal years, the Bank acquired an insurance company and opened two subsidiary in Gambia and Sierra Leone.

Despite the difficult economic conditions that have prevailed in the country most of the period, as well as the increased competition, GTB has shown strong and stable growth and profitability from its inception to date.  Over the last three years, GTB's total assets grew from $500 million to $1 billion and its equity base from $67 million to $255 million. Its ROAA and ROAE averaged 3.6% and 36% respectively over the same period.  In 2003, GTB joined the group of the AAA rated banks in the country, and became one of the seven settlement banks retained by the Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN), demonstrating its financial strength, national outreach and proven IT/Operations. GTB's success story has been used as a four-part case study at the Harvard Business School.
Cost Nature: IFC's investment will be in the form of a revolving line of credit of up to $20 million to GTB. The loan will be structure to allow the bank to match-fund its clients' needs.
Investment: 20.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan20.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The location of the project is Lagos, Nigeria.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is an FI Type 1 project, which requires the beneficiary bank to establish and maintain an environmental management system to ensure that investments under relevant operations meet host country environmental, health and safety requirements, and are consistent with IFCs exclusion list.  GTB has had a good record and is compliant with IFC environmental policies. However, the IFC will re-assess GTBs environmental management system and, if necessary, will work with the bank to strengthen its capacity to meet these requirements.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Company Name: CONTROLADORA DE SERVICIOS MEDICOS S.A. DE C.V
Project Description:
Centro Medico Puerta de Hierro (or CMPDH, or the project) is a new medical complex in the Zapopan neighborhood of Guadalajara, Mexico, consisting of two main components: 

-  an ambulatory surgery center and 
-  an 80-bed general tertiary care hospital.  

CMPDH is the first health care provider in Guadalajara to specialize in ambulatory surgery.  It aims to meet the growing demand for such services in the area and becoming a reference center for the 6 million inhabitants of the Jalisco state.

Company Name: RAIFFEISEN BANK DD BOSNA I HERCEGOVINA
Project Description: The proposed project consists of a long term loan of up to EUR12 million to Raiffeisen Bank D.D. Bosnia and Herzegovina ('RBBH' or the 'Bank'). RBBH is the largest bank in Bosnia and Herzegovina ('BiH'), with total equity of EUR67 million and total assets of EUR1billion, representing (21% of the market share) as at end-2004. RBBH is considered the leading bank in BiH offering a wide range of financial services, including corporate, personal and investment banking. The Bank's main strategic goal is to consolidate its leading position in the market by establishing long-term, mutual beneficial cooperation with its corporate and retail customers and by providing high quality comprehensive client services based on advanced banking technology and professional management.  The proposed project aims at providing much needed long term financing to support the growth of RBBH's housing lending program. RBBH started its housing lending program in June 1998 and is now the leading provider of mortgage loans in BiH.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an FI Type 2 project to IFCs environmental and social review procedure. As part of a previous investment by IFC and EBRD, RBBH established an environmental management system (EMS) that covers relevant operations. For the proposed new investment by IFC, RBBH will be required to confirm that it will maintain its EMS for the duration of the new investment to ensure that its relevant operations meet BiH and applicable IFC environmental and social requirements. Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: 96.7% of the Bank is currently owned by Raiffeisen Zentralbank Austria ('RZB') through its holding subsidiary Raiffeisen International Bank-Holding ('RI'). RZB was created in 1898 as the central bank to Austria's Raiffeisen banks (rural credit co-operatives), but it also acts as a commercial bank and in some countries as an investment bank. With assets of close to EUR63 billion and 25% of market share in Austrian retail deposits, it is currently Austria's 3rd largest banking group (after Erste Bank and Bank of Austria/ Credit Anstalt). RZB is 87% owned by nine regional Raiffeisen Banks. These regional banks are owned by 586 local Raiffesen Banks, which in turn are owned by 1.7 million co-operative members or clients. Currently, RZB owns and operates 15 Network Banks ('NWBs') in Central and Eastern Europe. RZB is A1 rated by Moody's.
Cost Nature: The proposed IFC investment consists of a long term loan for up to EUR12 million for its own account.
Investment: 16.33 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan16.33Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: RBBH is headquartered in Sarajevo.

Project Description: Bosnalijek d.d. Sarajevo (Bosnalijek or the company), an existing IFC client, is the largest pharmaceutical company in Bosnia and Herzegovina (BiH) is implementing a Euro 18.5 million project to construct a Production-Distribution Center.  The PDC will consist of the two connected entities:- -  a line for production of solid form drugs, which will increase the present capacity from 200 million tablets p.a. to 768 million tablets p.a., and -  a warehouse area of approximately 5,000 sq.m.  Construction of the PDC started during summer 2004 and is expected to be completed by end of 2006.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe press release will be on March 1, 2005 in the Sarajevo daily newspaper Oslobodzanga.The company will also make the disclosure at Bosnalijek city lights located on three tram stations in Sarajevo for 30 days starting from March 1, 2005.
Sponsor: Bosnalijek is a Joint Stock Company with mixed ownership that was established in 1951 in Sarajevo, the capital of Bosnia and Herzegovina.  The BiH Government owns 28.9% shares, Privatization Investment Funds have a cumulative 7.8% shares, IFC has 12.52% shares and the remaining 50.8% is owned by management, employees and other individuals .  Bosnalijek is a generic drug manufacturer.  It has a range of 165 drugs in solid oral forms, ampoules, syrups, solutions, ointments and creams, of which, 90% is produced and sold under Bosnalijek''s brand name.  Today, Bosnalijek is the largest pharmaceutical producer in Bosnia and Herzegovina with sales of around Euro 36.0 million in 2004, market share of 26% and 505 employees.  Its export sales has grown eight times since 1999 and reached 13% of sales revenue in 2004.
Cost Nature: Total project cost is estimated at Euro 18.5 million.  The proposed IFC investment is a Euro 7.5 million senior loan .

Project Description:
Kronostar (the company or the project) is 100% owned by Krono Holding AG since early 2002.  The AOO Sharjadrew combine dates back to early 1900's with a construction of a saw mill in the Sharja, Kostroma region.  Over the years, it has established a particleboard factory, and was privatized in 1992.  AOO Sharjadrew filed for insolvency in 1997.  In 2002, Krono Holding AG purchased AOO Sharjadrew's assets.

The purpose of the investment is to install a new particleboard line at Kronostar.  The project has strong business fundamentals.  It will contribute to the modernization of Russian wood panel industry, which is currently characterized by old and inefficient operations, and it will have a potentially strong impact on the revival and development of the following components:
      -  rural area of the Kostroma Oblast;
-  wood panel industry, and 
      -  furniture industry in the Russian Federation.

The project is supported by the strong expected demand growth for wood panels.  Using modern technology, Kronostar will produce particleboard and will add employment for over 100 direct jobs to the existing operations bringing the total direct employment to over 1000.

The sponsor is a European leader in wood panel board manufacturing with operations in France, Germany, Hungary, Poland, Switzerland, and Ukraine.

The project investment will be made primarily in the Kostroma Oblast's rural area.

Environmental Social Issues:
This is a  Category B project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure.  Because IFC recently reviewed the Groups railway operator activities for IFCs first investment and found it to be compliant with applicable Russian laws and regulations, the second review focused upon the construction and operation of the Taman terminal. For the Taman terminal, IFCs review consists of appraising information submitted by the Group, including feasibility studies and related environmental impact assessment documents prepared for submission to the relevant Russian national and regional authorities.  IFC also conducted field visits to the Taman terminal site.  Environmental and social issues associated with the Taman terminal include: siting and land acquisition, construction impacts, hazardous materials management, emergency preparedness and response, terminal pollution and waste management, navigational safety, community engagement, cultural heritage, employee safety, and environmental systems management.The Group, in coordination with the Krasnodar regional government authorities, presented plans to address these issues to ensure the Taman terminal will comply with applicable Russian laws and regulations and IFC environmental and social requirements. Project Description:
Packages Limited (the Company or Packages) is the leading integrated paper products manufacturer in Pakistan and an IFC client since 1964.  It is widely acknowledged as the market leader in terms of its production of sophisticated and higher quality packaging products.

Packages plans to undertake an investment program during the period 2005-2008. This investment program involves the following:

-  establishing a new pulp and paper plant in Kasur, 
-  relocating the existing pulp and paper production facilities from Lahore to the new plant, 
-  increasing production of higher margin printing and writing paper products and 
-  upgrading and expanding the converting lines and tissues lines at the existing plant.  

With the new and relocated facilities, the company's production capacity will increase from 100,000 metric tons per year to 300,000 metric tons per year.  At the conclusion of the project, all pulp and paper-making facilities at Packages' existing plant in Lahore will cease, with the exception of the manufacture of de-inked pulp and tissue paper.  Other operations at Lahore will, however, continue.

The purpose of the project is to achieve the following:

-  improve the quality of pulp and paper / paper-board production and ensure the supply of quality paperboard at reasonable prices for the company's growing converting operations; 
-  help the company achieve higher production efficiencies through reduced operating costs; and 
-  improve the company's overall environmental performance.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The review of this project consisted of appraising technical and environmental/social information submitted by the project sponsor, and visiting the Lahore mill and the site of the future Kasur mill. Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe Environmental Review Summary (ERS) will be available at the Company's headquarters (see the company's address below) at the factory gates in Lahore.  At the project site in Kasur the ERS will be available for viewing at the factory gates and at Kasur city municipal office at the following addresses:

Tehsil Counsil Kasur
Sponsor:
Packages Limited is the sponsor of the proposed project and is Pakistan's premier integrated pulp and paper mill and packaging materials manufacturer.  It is listed on all three stock exchanges of Pakistan.  It was originally established in 1956 as a joint venture between the Ali Family of Pakistan and Akerlund & Rausing of Sweden.  The original sponsors (i.e. the Ali family) continue to be closely associated with the company.  

The shareholding structure of Packages as of September 30, 2004 was: the Ali family (18.6%); Packages Group of companies (25.4%), StoraEnso, Tetra Laval Holdings and Finance, and Holgar Crafoord family (12.0%); local financial institutions (18%); IFC (0.8%); and the general public (25%).
Cost Nature:
The total cost of the proposed project is estimated at $332 million including: $209 million for fixed assets at Kasur, $33 million for capital expenditures for the converting lines and the tissues lines, $32 million for interest during construction,  $20 million for contingencies, and $38 for additional permanent working capital requirement and other indirect costs. 

The proposed IFC investment consists of:

-  a partial guarantee of local currency loans, 
-  A loan for $5 million and 
-  equity investment of up to $5 million. 

The IFC guarantee amount is $25 million for a guarantee of a local currency loan of up to 13 years.
Investment: 30.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuarantee25.0LoanEquity5.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Packages acquired a flat piece of land of about 42 hectares at Kasur, which is about 70 km from the existing plant in Lahore, for the project.  The project site is in a rural area and the distance for the straw transportation is shorter than the current site in Lahore.  There is a good underground water resource, and about 30,000 m3/day of fresh water consumption will be supplied from four deep well pumps.  A public drainage canal is running next to the plant site.  The site is close to the public grid and the public substation.  The natural gas main supply line is 12 km away from the site.  The site is accessible from the main road network.

Project Description: The project consists of a loan of up to $5 million to Factorline S.A. (Factorline or the company), one of the leading factoring companies in Chile. Factorline was founded in 1993 and it is the fifth factoring company in Chile by volume of overall factoring operations and the largest factoring company in Chile by volume of international factoring.  Through its factoring operations, the company provides key financing to over 1,600 medium and small enterprises in Chile, enabling them to grow their sales, revenues and employment. The purpose of this investment is to enable Factorline to diversify its funding with a longer term and more stable funding source, and to support the growth of Factorlines international factoring operations.
Role: The development impact of IFCs loan to Factorline is expected to be significant in terms of its support for productive small businesses and its stimulus for growth and employment generation. Given the limited interest among traditional Chilean banks in serving small businesses, smaller niche players like Factorline fill an important role in the Chilean market. These niche players often find themselves constrained in their funding, because some of them are not deposit-taking institutions and because potential lenders are avoiding the small business sector. IFC financing will address these issues. The financing will allow Factorline to continue to expand its factoring program while counting on a significant and stable US$ denominated credit line. Apart from providing predictability and diversity in the funding of Factorline, IFCs financing will also facilitate the companys foreign exchange and asset-liability management. Finally, IFC financing will also provide a level of credibility that Factorline can leverage with institutional creditors to obtain better terms in the local capital markets.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category C project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  There will be minimal environmental and social impacts associated with this project.  Therefore, no further environmental or social analysis is required.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: Factorline is controlled by the Saíd Group through Inversiones del Pácifico (30.5%) and Inversiones Santa Virginia Ltda.  (12.6%), and the Massú Group through  Inversiones PHL S.A. (30.5%). Other shareholders in Factorline include Inversiones F.S.A Ltda. (11.1%); Sociedad de Inversiones Belen (10.0%); and E Bertelsen Asesorias S.A (5.27%).
Cost Nature: The IFC investment will be a senior loan of $5 million equivalent for up to 4 years.
