Project Description:
Belgazprombank (the Bank or the company) is the second largest bank in Belarus outside of the state sector and the eighth largest in the country in terms of assets.  Its audited end-2003 equity amounted to $15 million equivalent and assets to $81 million equivalent.  The Bank has 3 branches in the capital city of Minsk and one in each of the 4 regional centers. The Bank's strategy is to strengthen its position in all market segments in which it currently operates, with a particular focus on private SME companies and microenterprises.

Belgazprombank is planning to use IFC funding to expand its lending and leasing portfolio to private SMEs in various sectors of the economy.  The Bank's management and shareholders have expressed a strong interest in developing a relationship with IFC to: 

-  diversify the Bank's funding base and increase its ability to offer longer-term loans to private SMEs; -  increase the Bank's visibility in the financial community, thus opening financing opportunities to work with Western commercial banks; and 
-  strengthen the Bank's reputation in the local banking sector.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an FI type 1 project. The Bank will be required to demonstrate that the environmental capacity developed for EBRD''s SME credit lines is adequate to address the environmental issues associated financing under this credit line, and to make any adjustments that may be required.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: Belgazprombank was established in 1991 as Bank Ekorazvitiye by a group of private shareholders.  It was renamed as Bank Olimp in 1993 and again as Belgazprombank in 1997 after the Russian Gazprombank purchased a majority shareholding.  Currently, Gazprombank and Gazprom, each hold approximately 34% of the Bank, while Beltransgas, the state-owned gas distribution company, is Belgazprombank's third largest shareholder with 23.5%. The remaining shares of Belgazprombank are held by the Belarussian Ministry of Economy (8.6%) and the Bank's employees.
Cost Nature: The proposed IFC's investment consists of a senior loan of up to $5 million to Belgazprombank for IFC's own account.

Company Name: BANCO DE GALICIA Y BUENOS AIRES S.A.U
Project Description:
The proposed project involves a $25 million secured loan to Banco de Galicia y Buenos Aires (the Bank, Banco Galicia or BG), with a tenor of up to 7 years.  The funds would be utilized by the Bank to onlend to export-oriented SMEs and mid-size corporates in Argentina.  Banco Galicia, founded in 1905, is a universal bank providing a wide variety of banking products and services to medium- and small-sized companies, large corporations, and individuals.  BG is the largest private-sector commercial bank in Argentina by total assets and by private-sector loans, commanding 11% and 7% respectively of the market share as of September 30, 2004.  As of that date, BG had total assets of $7.6 billion, shareholders equity of $415 million and deposits of $2.1 billion on a consolidated basis.  The Bank currently serves a total of about 2.7 million customers.

In May 2004, BG successfully restructured debt totaling $1.5 billion to over 240 banks and other creditors.  The restructuring involved the active participation of IFC as Chair of the ad hoc steering committee of Galicia's financial creditors.  The debt restructuring enhanced Tier I capital by $49 million and Tier II capital by $230 million, and extended debt maturities while reducing interest expenses.  

For the last two years, Argentina has steadily regained economic ground after having undergone a deep recession.  In tandem with this recovery, the banking sector is now faced with rapidly increasing credit demand stemming from the sharp growth rates in exports, the creation and expansion of SMEs, and industrial output.  Among private Argentine banks, Banco Galicia has particular expertise in funding SME, corporate and agribusiness borrowers.  As access to medium- and long-term borrowing is very scarce in Argentina, local companies would greatly benefit from longer tenors for much-needed capital expenditures and permanent working capital to support increased export activity.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an environmental and social category FI-1 project. Galicia is required to ensure that borrowers under relevant lending and investment activities are in compliance with the environmental and social requirements of Argentina. Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: Banco Galicia is owned by Grupo Financiero Galicia (the Group or GFG).  The Group was formed in 1999 as a financial services holding company to hold the capital stock of Banco Galicia held by members of the Escasany, Ayerza and Braun families.  The Group owns 93.6% of Banco Galicia.  The families have been majority shareholders of Banco Galicia since 1959, and currently participate on the Board of the Group.  The Bank's management and Board of Directors have extensive experience in the Argentine banking business.  Banco Galicia is one of the few locally-controlled large banks in Argentina.  IFC is a 0.5% shareholder in GFG via preferred shares acquired as part of the Bank's foreign debt restructuring.  GFG common shares are traded on the Buenos Aires Stock Exchange and on NASDAQ through an ADR program.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $25 million.  The proposed investment is a $25 million A loan for IFC's own account.
Investment: 40.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan40.0Equity0.0* These investment figures are indicative

Its branch network covers all of the Argentine provinces, except for Tierra del Fuego, and all the main cities of Argentina.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is an environmental and social category FI-1 project. Galicia is required to ensure that borrowers under relevant lending and investment activities are in compliance with the environmental and social requirements of Argentina. Project Description: Cosan S. A. Indústria e Comércio (Cosan, the company or Group) is the parent company of the largest integrated sugar and ethanol producer and exporter in Brazil, and one of the largest and most efficient producers in the world. Cosan reached this position by acquiring and turning around sugar mills, mostly during the last four years.  Cosan operates 12 mills, 3 sugar refineries and one export terminal at the Port of Santos. All facilities are located in the State of São Paulo, in Brazils Center-South region, with the exception of one small sugar refinery located in the State of Santa Catarina, South region. In FY 2004, ended April 30, Cosan milled 26.1 million mt of cane, sold 2.2 million mt of sugar (of which 82% or 1.8 million mt were exported), and 946 million liters of ethanol (of which 23% or 214 million liters were exported).The proposed project, to be implemented over the FY05 to FY07 period (May 2004 to April 2006), will allow the company: -  to maintain its leading position in the Brazilian sugar industry; -  to respond to growing demand for fuel ethanol, particularly in the domestic market; and -  to respond to increased competition in international markets by improving agricultural yields and cutting costs. More specifically, the project will allow Cosan to increase its installed milling capacity, improve sugar cane agricultural yields and further reduce costs. The project will also support Cosans efforts to improve monitoring and compliance of environmental and social standards.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental impacts may result that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  In view of the fact that this proposed investment is at the corporate level, environmental and social review of this project entailed an evaluation of a cross section of existing operations, which include the Costa Pinto, Rafard, Santa Helena, Univalem, Da Barra, Da Serra, Usati mills and the Port of Santos facility.  Based upon discussions with engineering staff, remaining Cosan operations, which include San Francisco, Diamante, Dois Corregos, Junqueira, Ipaussu, and Gasa mills have similar operational issues and existing approaches to resolving the impacts listed below.  The review analyzed the following potential environmental, health and safety, and social impacts:   -  Company mission and vision in the sector;-  Systematic management of quality, environmental and social affairs; -  Systematic management occupational health and safety; -  Control of air emissions to the environment;-  Management of liquid effluents; -  Management of non-hazardous and hazardous liquid and solid wastes; -  Control of pest species in cane rearing; -  Labor practices in cane rearing operation; and-  Social development programs.The identified environmental, social and health and safety impacts which require ameliorative activities are summarized in a Corrective Action Plan (CAP) that Cosan will implement as part of IFCs Loan Agreement. Upon successful implementation of the agreed mitigation measures, the proposed Project will meet Brazilian laws and regulations as well as the applicable World Bank/IFC environmental, social and health and safety policies and guidelines.   Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe environmental documents will be available in the municipalities of the following locally affected communities: -  Piracicaba; -  Santos; -  Barra Bonita; and -  Araçatuba, in the State of São Paulo, Brazil, as well as Itajaí, in the State of Santa Catarina. In each of these places the documents will be available at the Municipal Administration building (Prefeitura Municipal) where official notices (editais) are available for public review. The documents will also be available in Cosans web site (www.cosan.com.br).
Sponsor: The Group includes five operating companies, of which Cosan is the largest, and two land holding companies. All companies are privately held. Cosan started in 1936 with one sugar mill and in the following 67 years it grew mostly by acquiring and consolidating existing sugar mills. Cosans main shareholders are Indústria Açucareira São Francisco S/A., Irmãos Francheschi Administração e Participação S/A., Usina Costa Pinto S/A Açúcar e Álcool and Nova Celisa S/A.  Mr. Rubens Silveira Mello controls 76% of Cosans voting shares through its ownership in Indústria Açucareira São Francisco S/A;  Irmãos Francheschi Adminstração e Participação S/A; and Nova Celisa S/A..  Mr. Silveira Mello has over 30 years of experience in management of sugar companies and has been with Cosan for over 20 years.
Cost Nature: Total project cost is estimated at $ 344.9 million and comprises the following components: -  acquisition of assets to support the Group''s growth strategy; -  investment in planting, modernization and maintenance of existing operations; and -  additional working capital. The project will be implemented over the FY05 to FY07 period.The proposed IFC investment is a $30 million A Loan for IFCs own account and a $20 million C Loan.
Investment: 70.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan70.0Equity0.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Cosans operations are located in the State of São Paulo, Center-South of Brazil, where all mills and agricultural operations are based, with the exception of a small sugar refinery located in the South. Brazils Center-South region has some of the best cane growing land in the world in terms of soil, topography and climate. As a result, this region has some of the lowest production costs in the world. This natural competitive advantage is compounded by the very large size of cane farms, efficient farming practices, long harvest season and large and efficient mills. Cosans headquarters are located in the city of São Paulo, capital of the State, and the management of industrial and agricultural operations is based in the city of Piracicaba, in the interior of the State.

Based upon discussions with engineering staff, remaining Cosan operations, which include San Francisco, Diamante, Dois Corregos, Junqueira, Ipaussu, and Gasa mills have similar operational issues and existing approaches to resolving the impacts listed below. Project Description: The project involves the construction and operation of a greenfield cement plant with a capacity of 4.4 million tons per annum (p.a.) at Obajana, Kogi State, Nigeria.  The project is located 220 km southwest of Abuja and consists of the following components:-  a cement plant and limestone quarry -  a 135 MW captive power plant, -  a 90 km natural gas pipeline, -  a 351 unit housing complex for staff, -  an earth dam and water reservoir to meet the project''s water requirements, and 500 trucks for cement transportation.  -The project company is Obajana Cement Company Plc (OCP or the company). The project will fill a supply gap in the Nigerian cement market, where over 75% of the annual consumption of 10.6 million tons is imported.  It will use locally available limestone and natural gas to produce cement at a production cost that is expected to be below the current importation cost.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category A project.  For details of the environmental, health, safety and social (EHSS) issues associated with the project, the proposed mitigation measures and the EHSS action plan, please refer to the Project Disclosure Sheet  (accessible via link below).Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe environmental documents are available locally at the following locations:-  Obajana Cement Plc, Obajana Village, Kogi State; or-  Corporate Finance Department, Dangote Group, 1 Alfred Rewane, Falomo, Ikoyi, Lagos
Sponsor: The project is sponsored by Dangote Industries Limited (DIL or the sponsor), a leading Nigerian producer of sugar, salt and wheat flour and an importer and market leader in cement.  DIL is part of a group of businesses controlled by Mr. Aliko Dangote, a Nigerian industrialist.
Cost Nature: The project cost is estimated at $798 million.  The proposed IFC investment is an A Loan of up to $75 million.
Investment: 75.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan75.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The project is located in Obajana, Kogi State, 220 km southwest of Abuja, the Nigerian capital.  The central site (cement and power plant) is located 25 Km from the Kabba road junction which will provide access to the roadway leading to Lokoja (the capital of Kogi State) and beyond. The quarry is in Oyo Village and is connected by a 7.5 km conveyor to the cement plant. The gas pipeline will run from the gas manifold at Ajaokuta Steel Complex and will include sections along the Ajaokuta-Okene road and Oben-Kaduna NNPC pipeline route with the last section running from Lokoja-Kabba junction to Obajana.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category A project.  For details of the environmental, health, safety and social (EHSS) issues associated with the project, the proposed mitigation measures and the EHSS action plan, please refer to the Project Disclosure Sheet  (accessible via link below).Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe environmental documents are available locally at the following locations:-  Obajana Cement Plc, Obajana Village, Kogi State; or-  Corporate Finance Department, Dangote Group, 1 Alfred Rewane, Falomo, Ikoyi, Lagos

Project Name: Tata Iron and Steel Company Limited
Project Description: The Tata Iron & Steel Company Limited (Tata Steel or the company) is a fully integrated steel company headquartered in Mumbai, Maharashtra, India. Tata Steel is a cost-competitive steel manufacturer primarily due to its captive iron ore and coal mines. The company produces hot & cold rolled products and long products at its facility in Jamshedpur (state of Jharkhand), and Mumbai (state of Maharashtra), India. In the year ended March 31, 2004, the company sold 3.96 million tonnes of steel and recorded a net income of $380 million.Tata Steel wants to become a competitive, global player with a significantly larger capacity. The company plans to -  increase its production capacity from its current 5 million tonnes per annum (MTPA) to 7.4 MTPA by 2009 and to 15 MTPA by 2010 through organic growth and acquisitions in India and overseas; -  move up the value chain and improve its product mix; -  further improve its cost competitiveness by improving operational efficiency; and -  maintain its leading position in the Indian market, where further growth is expected.To achieve these goals, the company plans to implement a $2.6 billion investment program. The investment program consists of the following: -  a capacity expansion program in two phases   Phase I includes a 1 MTPA capacity expansion which is under final stage of completion, Phase II includes a 2.4 MTPA capacity expansion and modernization program  - both at its operations in Jamshedpur; and -  the acquisition of the steel-related businesses of NatSteel Limited (NatSteel), a Singaporean company with operations in five emerging countries in Asia, including China.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects.  Please refer to The Environmental Review Summary (ERS).Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe ERS was disclosed in the following newspapers on February 6, 2005:THE AVENUE MAIL" Page 5 "UDITVANI" Page 7These newspapers are distributed in the State of Jharkhand, West Bengal, Orissa and Uttar Pradesh.
Sponsor: The Tata entities (the sponsors) currently have a 26% shareholding in the company. The rest of the shares are held by the general public (29%), private corporate entities (7%), and institutional investors - both domestic and foreign (38%). Tata Steel was established in 1907 by Mr. Jamsetji Tata, the founder of the Tata group, one of the largest and most reputable business groups in India.
Cost Nature: Tata Steel has requested a corporate loan of up to $200 million for part financing of its investment program.
Investment: 100.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan100.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The company has a steel plant in Jamshedpur, Jharkhand, India. It has easy access to major roads and infrastructure.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects.  Please refer to The Environmental Review Summary (ERS).Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe ERS was disclosed in the following newspapers on February 6, 2005:THE AVENUE MAIL" Page 5 "UDITVANI" Page 7These newspapers are distributed in the State of Jharkhand, West Bengal, Orissa and Uttar Pradesh.

Project Description: The investment is an IFC revolving credit facility (the Facility) of $30 million to Grupo Taca for the benefit of Taca International Airlines S.A. (a Central American international airline company headquartered in San Salvador, El Salvador) and other members of Grupo Taca (Taca).  The Facility will be used for pre-delivery payments (PDPs) towards the purchase of Airbus A-320 family aircraft (which include A-319s, A-320s and A-321s).  Taca currently operates 111 daily flights to 35 destinations in 19 countries, servicing its passenger base in North America, Central America and South America, from its hubs at San Salvador (El Salvador), San Jose (Costa Rica) and Lima (Peru), respectively.  The project is part of an ongoing fleet modernization program that Taca began in 2000, resulting in a current average age of 3.3 years for Tacas fleet.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project. The following potential environment, health and safety impacts of the projects were analyzed.-  Flight operations safety and security;-  Maintenance-related hazardous materials, effluents, and waste management;-  Dangerous cargo handling;-  Aircraft noise and emissions control;-  Employee health and safety, including workplace exposure to chemicals; and-  Environmental, health and safety (EHS) management systems.Taca operates in accordance with industry standards and has presented plans to continue to address these impacts to ensure that the proposed project will operate in a manner so as its activities comply with applicable host country laws and regulations and IFC environment and social requirements.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityEnvironmental documentation is available at the following locations:-  Taca International Airlines S.A. -  Edificio Caribe, Segundo Nivel-  San Salvador, El SalvadorIn addition, the above documentation was also available at the following locations prior to consideration of the Project by IFCs Board, from March 15, 2005 to April 21, 2005: -  On the Taca website homepage www.taca.com, under the News section.-  In the local newspaper La Prensa Grafica (www.laprensagrafica.com.sv).In hard copy form, posted in the following Taca offices:-  Paseo General Escalón, Edificio Caribe, 2do. Nivel, Colonia Escalón, San Salvador-  Paseo General Escalón, Edificio Rialto, primer nivel, Colonia Escalón, San Salvador-  Paseo General Escalón, Edificio Montecristo, 1er, 2do. 3er. ó 4to. nivel, Colonia    Escalón, San Salvador-  Paseo General Escalón, Torre Montecristo, 7mo ó 8vo. nivel, Colonia Escalón, San Salvador-  Aeromantenimiento, S.A.,Aeropuerto Internacional El Salvador,San Luis Talpa, Departamento La Paz,El Salvador
Sponsor: Taca International Airlines S.A., the Salvadoran flag carrier, was founded in Honduras in 1931 by New Zealand pilot, Lowell Yerex. In 1961, Mr. Ricardo Kriete, a well-known and respected Central American businessman, acquired a majority interest. The company is controlled by the Kriete family, a leading Central American business family with investments in airlines, financial services, real estate, agribusinesses and telecommunications.
Cost Nature: The IFC revolving credit facility is for $30 million and will remain in existence for approximately five and a half years, (i.e., up to October 2010).   However, the maturity of each aircraft PDP loan is two years as each aircraft PDP loan is fully repaid upon delivery of the aircraft.

It flies to 35 destinations in 19 countries located throughout North, Central and South America from its hubs in San Salvador, San Jose and Lima.  The aircraft to be financed through the IFC facility will be used by Taca throughout its entire network in the Americas.

Project Description: The project is to provide a senior loan of up to $3 million to TBC Leasing or the company, a leasing company established and fully owned by JSC TBC Bank (the Bank), one of Georgia's leading commercial banks and an IFC client since 1998.  Proceeds of the IFC loan would be used to expand the company's leasing operations with small and medium sized companies and entrepreneurs in Georgia. This would be the first IFC loan provided to TBC Leasing and to a Georgian company operating in the leasing sector.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Financial Intermediary (FI) Type 2 project according to IFCs environmental review procedure.  TBC Leasing will be required to maintain an environmental management system satisfactory to IFC, including the appointment of one environmental officer trained in an environmental workshop conducted or approved by IFC, and to submit annual environmental reports to IFC.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: The project's sponsor is TBC Bank, which is the largest bank in Georgia, holding 23% of the country's banking assets and 30.1% of deposits.  Currently TBC Bank focuses on funding SMEs and trade finance projects in addition to doing business with multinational companies, embassies and NGOs.  The founding shareholders are two local Georgian businessmen who retain a 47% direct and indirect shareholding in TBC Bank.  Other major shareholders include Soros Investment Capital (25%), DEG (10%) and IFC (9%).
Cost Nature: The proposed IFC Investment is a senior loan of up to $3 million to expand leasing operations to SMEs.
Investment: 3.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan3.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: TBC Leasing is headquartered in Tbilisi, Georgia
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Financial Intermediary (FI) Type 2 project according to IFCs environmental review procedure.  TBC Leasing will be required to maintain an environmental management system satisfactory to IFC, including the appointment of one environmental officer trained in an environmental workshop conducted or approved by IFC, and to submit annual environmental reports to IFC.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Description: This project is a modification to an existing IFC project in the Dominican Republic  Domicem No. 20490, which was approved by the Board on July 8, 2003.  The original project envisaged partial ownership by Domicem (or the company) of a captive power plant.  During construction of the plant, the company has decided that it would be more efficient to fully own the power plant while having an energy equipment supplier operating and maintaining it.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category C project and no further environmental or social review is necessary.  This is a purely financial change to the original project (No. 20490 approved by the Board on July 8, 2003), which is still in full compliance with the original project description, the local regulations, and the World Bank policies and guidelines.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The project sponsors are Colacem, S.p.A. of Italy (49%), SIMEST of Italy (2%) and a group of local partners in the Dominican Republic with substantial knowledge of the local building materials industry (49%).  Colacem ranks as Italys third-largest cement company and is part of the Financo Holding Group, a private Italian conglomerate owned by the Colaiacovo family of Italy.  Founded in the 1950s as a construction and building materials company, Financo today has interests in cement/hydraulic binders; concrete and aggregates; transport, and diversified industries. SIMEST is a publicly owned Italian company supported by the Ministry of Industry and created to encourage Italian investments abroad.
Cost Nature: The additional investment required for the full ownership of the power plant is $7.5 million, which IFC is proposing to finance fully by A and B Loans.  In addition, the sponsors are funding some enhancements/improvements to the cement plant, which will bring the total cost of the cement plant to $113.5 million.
Investment: 3.75 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan3.75Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The captive power plant will be located at the same site as the Domicem cement plant, which is located 40 km from the capital Santo Domingo, 26 km from the international Port of de Haina and 2 km from the village of Sabana Grande de Palanque.  The site is easily accessible, located 2,000 meters away from the Haina Palanque highway.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category C project and no further environmental or social review is necessary.  This is a purely financial change to the original project (No. 20490 approved by the Board on July 8, 2003), which is still in full compliance with the original project description, the local regulations, and the World Bank policies and guidelines.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community

Company Name: CDH CHINA CAPITAL GROWTH FUND II LP
Project Description: IFC is considering an equity commitment of $18 million in the CDH China Growth Capital Fund II, L.P. (CDH II), an investment vehicle to be established with a target size of $310 million which will make equity and equity-related investments in established Chinese companies that have strong business fundamentals, favorable growth prospects and viable exits via listings or trade sales.  CDH II will be managed by the CDH Team who had worked together since 1995 in the private equity group of China International Capital Corporation (CICC) and raised the first CDH China Fund (CDH I) in 2002, after spinning off from CICC, with a total capital commitment of $102.5 million.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category F1 Type 2 project according to IFCs environmental review procedure.  The Fund Manager has committed to establishing an environmental management system that will ensure that investments are consistent with applicable host country environmental laws and regulations as well as applicable World Bank Group environmental, health and safety guidelines and policies; designating appropriate individuals who will have responsibility for the environmental and who will attend IFCs environmental management workshops; submitting to IFC an environmental management plan; obtaining clearance by IFC for any category A or infrastructure investment by the fund; and submitting to IFC an annual environmental performance report.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor:
The CDH Team consists of 8 investment professionals led by Dr. Wu Shangzhi, President of the fund management company (CDH), and Managing Directors Mr. Jiao Zhen and Mr. Stuart Schonberger, who have an average of eight years of China-specific private equity experience each. 

CDH is jointly owned by the CDH Team, GIC Special Investments Pte. Ltd (GICSI), and Capital Z Investment Partners L.P. (CZIP).  GICSI is the private equity investment arm of the Government of Singapore Investment Corporation.  CZIP is the New York based private equity fund of funds program affiliated to the Zurich Financial Services.  

Other potential investors in CDH II are expected to be mainly institutional investors from the US, Europe and Asia.  Many CDH I investors are expected to continue to participate in CDH II.
Cost Nature: CDH II expects to raise a total amount of $310 million, of which the proposed IFC equity investment of $20 million will represent no more than 10%.
Investment: 18.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity18.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: CDH II would be established as a Cayman Islands exempted limited partnership.  Companies with substantial operations in China are the geographic focus of the investments. The investment team will operate out of China with its headquarters in Beijing.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category F1 Type 2 project according to IFCs environmental review procedure.  The Fund Manager has committed to establishing an environmental management system that will ensure that investments are consistent with applicable host country environmental laws and regulations as well as applicable World Bank Group environmental, health and safety guidelines and policies; designating appropriate individuals who will have responsibility for the environmental and who will attend IFCs environmental management workshops; submitting to IFC an environmental management plan; obtaining clearance by IFC for any category A or infrastructure investment by the fund; and submitting to IFC an annual environmental performance report.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sector: BA - Private Equity/Venture Cap Fund - Country

Project Description:
The project consists of an equity participation of up to $22 million in PT. Wahana Ottomitra Multiartha (WOM), an Indonesian consumer finance company focusing on motorcycle financing. WOM, established in 1982, is the third largest motorcycle finance in Indonesia with Indonesia now being the world's third largest motorcycle market after China and India. IFC's equity participation will represent 20% of the total share capital of WOM. The transaction is subject to Bank Indonesia and other regulatory approvals.

Bank Internasional Indonesia (BII) has signed a conditional sale and purchase agreement (CSPA) to purchase up to 75% of WOM for approximately $82.5 million or about 2.2 times WOM's book value as of December 31, 2004. However, under Bank Indonesia (BI) regulations, a bank can only use up to 10% of capital (Tier I & Tier II) for investment. As a result, BII is expected to take only around  43% of WOM at this time. To address this issue and to bring strong partners to this transaction, BII has asked IFC to purchase 20% of WOM, with DEG taking the remaining 12% (subject to DEG's internal approvals). The sponsor of the project, BII, will have an option to purchase the WOM shares from IFC and DEG over a 5 year period, subject to BII's Legal Lending Limit and BII has agreed to an exit mechanism related to the IFC equity investment in WOM. The terms of the exit mechanism are being negotiated.

The entire project involving BII, IFC and DEG is subject to Bank Indonesia approval. Also the proposed purchase of WOM is subject to approval by BII's shareholder's at BII's Annual General Meeting to be held at the end of March, 2005.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a FI Type 1 project and BII will be required to develop an environmental management system. BII must require that investments under relevant operations meet host country environmental, health and safety requirements. IFC will assess BIIs capacity for environmental review and will provide training as necessary.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: The project sponsor and largest shareholder is BII, which was founded by the Widjaja family in 1959 and became publicly listed in 1989. BII was adversely hit by the Asian Financial Crisis in 1997, and was taken over and recapitalized by the Indonesia Government. Having restructured BII's balance sheet, the Government sold a majority stake to Sorak, a consortium of foreign banks and investors, in late 2003. Sorak Financial Holdings Pte. Ltd holds 56.9% of BII, and this consortium is made up of Asia Financial Holdings Pte Ltd (wholly owned by Temasek Holdings of Singapore), Kookmin Bank of Korea, Barclays Bank and Malaysia's ICB Group Holdings. The Government of Indonesia now holds 5.5% of BII with the public now holding 37.6% of BII.BII is the third largest private bank in Indonesia, and including state owned banks, is the sixth largest overall. As of September30, 2004 , BII had a market capitalization of US$929 million and a capital adequacy ratio of 21.53%.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is $82.5 million, and IFC's equity participation of up to $22 million will comprise 26.6 % of the project cost and 20% of WOM's capital.
Investment: 20.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity20.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: WOM is headquartered in Jakarta, Indonesia, and has branch locations in the major urban areas of the Country.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a FI Type 1 project and BII will be required to develop an environmental management system. BII must require that investments under relevant operations meet host country environmental, health and safety requirements. IFC will assess BIIs capacity for environmental review and will provide training as necessary.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Description: The proposed project comprises a long term local currency loan of about $40 million equivalent to Filinvest Land Incorporated (FLI, or the company) for extending mortgages to the affordable and middle income segments of the population that are unable to access bank financing.  FLI is one of the largest Philippine residential real estate developers, offering a wide range of products from socialized and affordable housing to middle-income and high-end housing to various types of subdivision lots.  FLI's residential real estate activities cover the acquisition of raw land, the horizontal development of such land into residential subdivisions, the sale of subdivision lots, the construction and sale of housing units, and the provision of mortgage financing to its customers.  FLI has an extensive landbank of approximately 2,400 hectares across the Philippines, which it estimates would support its project development activities for the next five to ten years.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category FI Type 2 project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  FLI will participate in IFC''s environmental management workshop and implement an environmental management system to ensure that its real estate development activities are consistent with applicable Philippine environmental and social standards and World Bank Group environmental, health, safety, and social policies and guidelines.  FLI will submit to IFC annual environmental performance reports, and obtain clearance from IFC for any category A sub-project.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor:
FLI is a 58% subsidiary of Filinvest Development Corporation (FDC) and an affiliate of Filinvest Alabang, Inc., an existing IFC client.  FDC is the holding company of the Filinvest group of companies, and was listed on the Philippine Stock Exchange in 1982.  The Filinvest group has engaged in the real estate development business since 1967 and later diversified into non-property businesses.  Its current main sources of revenue are 

-  residential property development, 
-  commercial property development, 

-  banking and financial services, and 

-  information technology.
Cost Nature: The proposed project comprises a seven-year $40 million equivalent local currency senior loan for its own account to FLI to extend housing loans to the affordable and middle income segments of the population.

It is currently expanding the geographic scope of its residential property development activities to areas beyond Metro Manila, such as Calabarzon in Luzon, Cebu and Talisay, Negros Occidental in the Visayas, and Davao in Mindanano and other developing regions of the Philippines.

Project Description:
Universal, the largest tourism company in the Maldives, has requested a loan of up to $25 million to finance the following: 

-  rebuilding of 52 bungalows and a spa at the Full Moon Resort (156 rooms) damaged by the recent tsunami; 
-  refinancing of the loan for the Huvafenfushi resort (42 rooms) that was completed in 2004; and 
-  other corporate purposes.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a category B project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure. The project components will be assessed for compliance with applicable IFC social and environmental performance standards. Issues to be considered in this assessment include: protection of cultural heritage and natural habitats; possession of applicable environmental reviews and permits for new and reconstructed facilities; management of potable water, wastewater treatment, solid waste handling and disposal; hazardous materials management; labor relations, occupational health and safety, life and fire safety, and local environmental management for both construction and operations phases of project implementation. Details of each project component will be reviewed and physical appraisal undertaken as required.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityEnvironmental documentation will be made available at the following locations:

-  Universal headquarters: 
39, Orchid Magu, Male' 20-02, Republic of Maldives; and

-  Ministry of Environment And Construction:  
 Huravee Building, Ameer Ahmed Magu, Male', Republic of Maldives.
Sponsor: Universal Enterprises was founded in 1972 by two brothers from the Maldives, Mohamed Umar Maniku and Ahmed Umar Maniku.  Mr. Mohamed Umar Maniku was one of the hosts for the first organized tour to visit the Maldives.  In 1978, the two brothers incorporated Universal Enterprises Pvt. Ltd., a Maldives based tourism company.  Universal has since grown and evolved and is now the largest single resort operator in the country with ten quality resorts in eight islands and a total of more than 1000 rooms.
Cost Nature: The estimated cost of rebuilding, renovation and refinancing is approximately $65 million.  The proposed IFC investment is a $25 million A Loan for IFC's own account.

Project Description: This SPI has been revised in order to reflect a slight change in the wording related to the process of categorization of any potential future investment in this project to ensure consistency with IFC procedures.The project is to prepare a definitive feasibility study (DFS), including marketing, technical, and environmental and social impact studies, for the re-treatment of processed oxide tailings from the Kolwezi concentrator, located in Katanga province, which began operations in the early 1950s. Owing to the poor recovery rates obtained at the time, valuable amounts of copper and cobalt were discharged in the form of tailings. The tailings reserve consists of 112 million tonnes grading 1.49% copper and 0.32% cobalt. Preliminary technical studies indicate that a leaching and solvent extraction plant costing about US$300 million could produce 30,000  tonnes per annum (tpa) of copper and 5,500 tpa of cobalt, although technical,  marketing, and financing factors, to be considered during the DFS, may dictate a staged development. The project company is Kingamyambo Musonoi Tailings SARL (KMT), a Congolese company which has been created for the purpose of exploiting the tailings.
Role: The DRC is emerging from a prolonged period of instability and conflict. The countrys mining sector offers the best prospect for generating significant economic activity in the near term. For this reason, one of the World Banks priorities after re-engaging in DRC was to assist with updating DRCs mining code and detailed mining regulations. With these now passed into law, a key pre-condition for foreign investment in the mining sector has been met, and it is hoped that the early start up of some major private sector mining projects will send an important signal to both the people of DRC and to foreign investors, that the reform process is on the right track. The tailings at Kolwezi represent one of the most technically viable projects in DRCs mining sector, and their commercial exploitation should be relatively fast, because no mining would be involved. A successful DFS should enable financing and development of the processing plant to proceed relatively quickly, which would have the following development impacts: (i) it would generate significant foreign exchange earnings, and pay royalties, income tax and dividends to the government of DRC; (ii) it would stimulate the revival of regional infrastructure through the transport of goods; (iii) it would provide significant training and employment (estimated at 700 direct jobs for a full scale project); and (iv) it would have a powerful demonstration effect for other investors, and hopefully serve to encourage other mining investments in DRC to proceed. IFCs early engagement in the production of the DFS will enable it to play the following roles: (i) it will work with the Sponsor to maximise the sustainability of the future operation, and to ensure that the environmental and social baseline and impact studies that will be prepared as part of the DFS will be fully compliant with IFCs policies and guidelines; and (ii) IFCs presence in the Project should help attract other investors to complete the financing plan and enable the commercial development of the tailings project.
Environmental Social Issues: This project has been categorized as a Category B project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure as it is an equity investment to provide funding for a feasibility study, detailed engineering and environmental and social assessment (ESIA) documentation. Any future mine development financing would be appraised by IFC as a new project, with a new environmental classification based upon the projects risks and impacts. Based upon review of existing environmental documentation, it is considered likely that IFC support for future mine development financing at the site would be classified as a Category A project according to IFCs Environmental & Social Review Procedure.The Category A ESIA documentation is currently under preparation and will be reviewed and approved by IFC to ensure that, prior to financing and construction, the development stage meets IFC environmental and social standards.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe Environmental Review Summary (ERS) and the initial Environmental Audit completed by SRK during 2003 and the Public Consultation and Disclosure Plan (PCDP) as well as the Public Scoping Report (PSR) are available at the offices of CMD and KMT in Lubumbashi and Kolwezi for consultation by the public, at the following addresses:KMT SARL, Villa Munua, Route de Golf, Golf, Lubumbashi, DRCKMT SARL , 617 Avenue Lumumba, Zone Manika, Kolwezi, DRCThe Sponsors Environmental and Social Policies, Community Development Policy and PCDP can be found on Adastras website: http://www.adastramin.com/
Sponsor: KMT is currently owned 82.5% by Congo Mineral Developments Limited (CMD), 12.5% by Gécamines, the state-owned mining company, and 5% by the government of DRC. CMD is a wholly owned subsidiary of Adastra Minerals Inc. (the Sponsor). The Sponsor is a junior mining company that was formed in 1995, since when it has mainly focused on developing mineral opportunities in Africa. Its head office is in London, England. It is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange and on  the Alternative Investment Market of the London Stock Exchange and is widely held, with a market capitalization at US$114.9 million as of  February 24, 2005. Should IFCs proposed investment be approved, it will acquire an up to 10% stake in KMT from CMD. The Industrial Development Corporation (IDC), a  South African development finance institution, has already elected to exercise its own option to acquire a 10% stake in KMT. IFC may also exercise warrants in the Sponsor which  could result in them owning up to about 0.5% of the Sponsor.
Cost Nature: The estimated total project cost is $50.0 million of which about $32.0 million has already been spent by the Sponsor and CMD. The proposed IFC investment of up to US$6.4 million equity investment to acquire an up to 10% stake in KMT.
Investment: 5.90 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan0.0Equity5.90* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Kolwezi is a well established mining town, with considerable existing infrastructure including a railway, power supply, and small airport.  The tailings reserves are contained in a tailings dam about 2km from Kolwezi town, and over a length of about 11km in the Musonoi river, downstream of the town. Subject to confirmation by the DFS, it is expected that the tailings will be piped as a slurry to a greenfield processing plant, for which a site has provisionally been identified in a rural area 8km north west of Kolwezi town.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This project has been categorized as a Category B project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure as it is an equity investment to provide funding for a feasibility study, detailed engineering and environmental and social assessment (ESIA) documentation. Any future mine development financing would be appraised by IFC as a new project, with a new environmental classification based upon the projects risks and impacts. Based upon review of existing environmental documentation, it is considered likely that IFC support for future mine development financing at the site would be classified as a Category A project according to IFCs Environmental & Social Review Procedure.The Category A ESIA documentation is currently under preparation and will be reviewed and approved by IFC to ensure that, prior to financing and construction, the development stage meets IFC environmental and social standards.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe Environmental Review Summary (ERS) and the initial Environmental Audit completed by SRK during 2003 and the Public Consultation and Disclosure Plan (PCDP) as well as the Public Scoping Report (PSR) are available at the offices of CMD and KMT in Lubumbashi and Kolwezi for consultation by the public, at the following addresses:KMT SARL, Villa Munua, Route de Golf, Golf, Lubumbashi, DRCKMT SARL , 617 Avenue Lumumba, Zone Manika, Kolwezi, DRCThe Sponsors Environmental and Social Policies, Community Development Policy and PCDP can be found on Adastras website: http://www.adastramin.com/

Project Description: The Trinidad Cement Limited Group (the Sponsors, or the Group,), which has cement operations in Trinidad, Jamaica and Barbados, is the leading producer and dominant supplier of cement in the Caricom, the economic grouping of English-speaking Caribbean island nations plus Belize, Guyana and Suriname which together have a population of approximately six million.  Its three main operating subsidiaries are Trinidad Cement Limited (TCL or the company), Caribbean Cement Company Limited (Carib Cement) in Jamaica and Arawak Cement Company Limited in Barbados.  With combined cement production capacity of 2.3 million tons per year, the three plants produce for their domestic markets and also export to the Caricom markets, where the Group commands an 85% market share.Purpose of the project is a $133 million capital expenditure program in Carib Cement between 2005-2009 includes: -  expansion of clinker manufacturing capacity by installing a new modern dry process kiln and upgrading the existing dry process kiln; -  upgrading/expanding the capacity of the existing cement mills; -  quarry mapping and upgrades to mobile fleet; -  expansion of packing capacity; and -  general improvements.The project will help Carib Cement improve the cost base of its cement plant and become a stronger regional player.  Carib Cement will be better able to compete with both importers and competitors in the region.  At present, the markets of Trinidad, Jamaica and Barbados are protected by tariffs on cement imported from outside the Caricom region and have high domestic prices (above $100/ton), reflecting a lack of competition in the local markets and high production costs.  In anticipation of tariff reductions and increased competition from imports, the TCL Group, including Carib Cement is embarking on a strategy that focuses on improving cost competitiveness and upgrading capacity.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The review of this project consisted of site visits to all operations and appraising technical and environmental/social information submitted by the project sponsor. Details of the environmental review can be found in the corresponding Environmental Review Summary.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe documents were published in Jamaica on April 1, 2005  in the following newspapers: Jamaica Observer; and Jamaica Gleaner.
Sponsor: The project sponsor, TCL Group, is incorporated under the laws of Trinidad and Tobago and its principal activity is the manufacture and sale of cement.  It was established as Trinidads first cement company in the early 1950s in response to the invitation by the Government of Trinidad and Tobago to Rugby Portland of the UK.  Until it was effectively privatized in 1990, TCL was wholly owned by Government of Trinidad and Tobago, which began divesting its shareholding in TCL on a phased basis in 1989. To facilitate the establishment of a strategic alliance, a block of shares representing a 20% interest in TCL was sold to Cemex in 1994. Shares were also offered to the general public and, in 1999, GOTT completed its divestment by selling its last remaining shareholding to Trinidad National Insurance Board (9.96%), Trinidad Unit Trust Corporation (4%), TCL Employee Share Ownership Plan - ESOP (6%), and others (0.8%).  At present, the Group is Caricoms only cement manufacturer and it is a vertically integrated operation with involvement in the pre-mixed concrete/aggregates and packaging sectors. TCL is both an operating and holding company with 16 subsidiaries (4 in Trinidad, 4 in Jamaica, 2 in Barbados, 2 in Nevis, 1 in St. Maarten, 1 in Anguilla, 1 in St. Martin and 1 in Guyana) of which 5 are wholly-owned and 11 are majority-owned joint ventures.  Cement accounts for 88% of TCLs total revenues (11% from the concrete and aggregates sector, and 1% from the packaging sector) and geographically, 42% of the Groups revenues are derived from Jamaica, 32% from Trinidad and Tobago, 11% from Barbados and 15% from other regional markets.TCLs shareholding is widely distributed among approximately 6,000 shareholders with Cemex being the single largest shareholder (20%). Other main shareholding groups include institutional investors (52%), Trinidad and Tobago nationals (17%) and employees (7%). TCL is listed on the three regional stock exchanges of Trinidad and Tobago, Barbados and Jamaica.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $133 million.  IFC is considering an A Loan of up to $25 million and a C loan of up to $10 million to TCL.  The remaining $98 million required will be funded with a combination of internally generated cash flow and parallel financing from regional financial institutions.
Investment: 35.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan35.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The project will be implemented in Carib Cement (Jamaica) which is an existing operation.  Carib Cement is located near Manley Airport in Kingston with excellent access to national highways and port facilities. The limestone quarry is located in the mountain above the cement plant, and the gypsum and shale quarries are located nearby in a hilly area.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The review of this project consisted of site visits to all operations and appraising technical and environmental/social information submitted by the project sponsor. Details of the environmental review can be found in the corresponding Environmental Review Summary.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe documents were published in Jamaica on April 1, 2005  in the following newspapers: Jamaica Observer; and Jamaica Gleaner.

Project Description:
Yantai Changyu Group Company Limited (the Group) is a holding company controlling a 53.8% stake in Yantai Changyu Pioneer Wine Company Limited (Changyu or the company), a Shenzhen-listed company involved in the production and distribution of wine, sparkling wine, tonic wine, and brandy.  The Group also has minor operations in a hotel, a tourist company and a general service company.

Established in 1892, Changyu is the oldest and largest wine producer in China, with cumulative output of 80,000 tons per annum of wine products and a domestic market share of 21%.  Changyu has nationwide distribution channels and a wide product range from low-end to high-end wines.  Changyu currently generates more than 75% of its revenue from wine, grape cider, tonic wine and sparkling wine products and less than 25% from brandy products.  The company expects to grow mainly through expanding the core wine operation, in a growing wine market in China.

The Yantai City People's Government State Assets Supervision and Administration Commission (Yantai Government) of Shandong Province currently controls 55% of the Group and intends to sell 43% of its stake to foreign investors.  The shares are planned to be sold in two tranches of 33% and 10% each to two separate investors.  The proceeds from the sale will accrue to the Yantai Government, which has requested IFC to consider taking a stake in the Group.  The proposed IFC investment is to purchase the 10% stake in the group, representing an equity investment of about $20 million.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  Further details are provided in the Environmental Review Summary, separately available with this document.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityEnvironmental documents, including the ERS (Environmental Review Summary) and EAP (Environmental Action Plan), will be posted at the notice of the Yantai City Library.  In addition, the announcement of the public disclosure of ERS will be announced via ads in the local newspaper.
Sponsor:
Changyu (the Company) has the following ownership structure:

-  Changyu Group Co.  (holding) - 53.8% (non-listed 'legal person shares')
-  Public and institutional shareholders of 'A' shares - 12.4% (listed shares)
-  Public and institutional shareholders of 'B' shares - 33.8% (listed shares)

The Group (holding) was historically 100% owned by the Yantai Government, which is privatizing the Group via a two stage process: 

-  an EMBO (Employee and Management Buyout) of 45% of the Group, which was concluded in October 2004; and 
-  Sale of a further 43% stake in the Group to foreign investors, in two separate tranches of 33% and 10% each.  While IFC is considering investing in the 10% stake, IFC has learned that Illva Saronno, an Italian company, was selected for the 33% stake.  

Illva Saronno Group, a diversified group, has interests in three areas: 

-  the production and sales of alcoholic beverages including wines and liquor; 
-  raw materials for ice-creams bakery products, and 
-  optical lenses.  

After the completion of the privatization process, the shareholding structure of the Group will be:

-  Yantai Government - 12%
-  Management and employees - 45%
-  Foreign investors - 43% (including two investors with 33% and 10% each)
Cost Nature: The Yantai Government's asking price for the shares on sale represents a 20% premium over the appraised net asset value (NAV) of RMB 1,215.72 million of the Group.  The corresponding asking price for the proposed 10% shareholding is $ 17.62 million.
Investment: 17.68 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity17.68* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Changyu is headquartered in Yantai city, Shandong province of China.

Further details are provided in the Environmental Review Summary, separately available with this document.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityEnvironmental documents, including the ERS (Environmental Review Summary) and EAP (Environmental Action Plan), will be posted at the notice of the Yantai City Library.  In addition, the announcement of the public disclosure of ERS will be announced via ads in the local newspaper.

Company Name: Changchun TBK SHILI Auto Parts Co., Ltd
Project Description: The project consists of the construction of a new plant in Changchun, Jilin Province, in northeastern China, to produce linings for drum brakes and pads for disk brakes for commercial vehicles. The brake linings and pads to be produced by the plant will be supplied primary to First Automotive Work (FAW) group.  FAW is the largest vehicle manufacturer in China with a production of around 890,000 passenger cars and commercial vehicles in 2004.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure because a limited number of specific environmental impacts may result, which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The review of the Project consisted of appraising technical and environmental information submitted by the project sponsors and a site visits to a TBK site brake linings factory in Dongguang and CSABPCs brake linings factory in Changchun.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe Environment Review Summary (ERS) is disclosed at the following locations:

-  the website of CSABPC (www.shcqzd.com); 
-  at the gates of Sihuan Chassis Parts Plant, 40-19 The First Road of Mengjia, Changchun, China;  and
-  Changchun High-Technology Industries Development Area Investment Promotion Center (4000 Silicon Valley Street, Changchun, China).
Sponsor: The project sponsor is Tokyo Buhin Kogkyo Co., Ltd. (TBK).  TBK, a Japanese corporation listed on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, is the leading manufacturer of brakes for commercial vehicles (CVs) with an approximately 70% market share in Japan.  In addition, TBK is the leading producer of oil and water pumps for CVs representing about 90% and 70% of the Japanese market, respectively.  The Project will be implemented through a joint venture company to be owned 60% by TBK and 40% by Changchun Shili Automobile Brake Parts Co., Ltd (CSABPC). CSABPC is a producer of brake friction materials owned 51% by Sihuan Chassis Parts Plant, and 49% by Zhejiang Shibao Holding Group Co., Ltd, a Chinese private limited liability corporation.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $11 million.  The proposed IFC investment will be $4 million loan for IFC own account.

Project Name: Advent  Latin America Private Equity Fund III L.P.
Company Name: ADVENT LATIN AMERICAN PRIVATE EQUITY FUND III-E LIMITED PARTNERSHIP
Project Description: The Latin American Private Equity Fund III, L.P (LAPEF III, or the Fund) is a closed-end regional private equity fund with a target size of $300 million formed by Advent International (Advent, or the sponsor) to achieve attractive investment returns through a portfolio of diversified investments in Latin American countries. The Fund will acquire primarily control positions in later-stage businesses and add value through active investment management, majority share ownership positions, and board and executive committee participation.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category FI type 2 project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  As a result of IFC''s investment in LAPEF II, Advent implemented an environmental management system (EMS) satisfactory to IFC, including compliance with host country environmental, health and safety standards, IFC''s Exclusion List, and World Bank Group environmental and social policies and guidelines, and the provision of annual environmental performance reports (AEPRs) to IFC.  For IFC''s investment in LAPEF III, Advent will be required to implement an EMS as for LAPEF II, with any appropriate improvements, and provide AEPRs to IFC.  Any new environmental officers will be required to participate in environmental management training conducted or approved by IFC.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor:
Advent, founded in 1984, is one of the world's largest and most experienced global private equity organizations. It operates 14 offices and 10 affiliates in 25 countries and employs over 100 investment professionals. Advent has raised over $6 billion in aggregate and invested in more than 500 companies in 35 countries in many different industries. It manages global, regional and corporate/strategic venture capital funds covering investment opportunities in both developed and emerging markets (including North America, Western Europe, Central and Eastern Europe, Asia and Latin America) and is regarded as a top-tier performer in its industry. 

In Latin America, Advent has been active for 10 years and invested approximately $400 million in 24 companies. It is the only pan-regional private equity firm with a direct presence in each of the markets in which it invests. The firm has wholly-owned offices staffed by local nationals in Mexico City, Sao Paulo, and Buenos Aires.
Cost Nature: The proposed IFC equity investment is of up to $20 million. The fund's target size is $300 million.

Location: The fund will be formed as a Cayman Islands limited partnership. The geographical focus of investments will be the three Latin American countries where Advent has wholly-owned offices: Mexico, Brazil, and Argentina.

As a result of IFC''s investment in LAPEF II, Advent implemented an environmental management system (EMS) satisfactory to IFC, including compliance with host country environmental, health and safety standards, IFC''s Exclusion List, and World Bank Group environmental and social policies and guidelines, and the provision of annual environmental performance reports (AEPRs) to IFC. Project Description: The project consists of an IFC A loan of up to $10 million to Taageer Finance Company (Taageer or the company), to support its growing operations primarily for increased on-lending to Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs) in Oman. The company is the newest entrant in the Omani leasing market and was established in February 2001 as a non banking finance company with the license to offer products such as financing and operating leases, corporate and retail loans, factoring, and consumer loans.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category FI Type 1 project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  Taageer will be required to develop an environmental management system to ensure that investments under relevant operations meet Omani environmental, health and safety standards; and to submit to IFC annual environmental performance reports.  IFC will assess Taageer''s capacity for environmental review, and if necessary, will require Taageer to participate in environmental management training conducted or approved by IFC.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor:
The principal financial investors of the company are The Arab Investment Company (TAIC) and Al Madina Finance & Investment Services Co. (Al Madina) of Oman. Other major shareholders include the Iran Foreign Investment Co. (IFIC),and the pension funds of the Ministry of Defense and the Diwan of Royal Court in Oman. 

The Arab Investment Company (TAIC) is a Pan-Arab joint-stock company established in 1974 and owned by 17 Arab states with a paid-up capital of $450 million. TAIC's prime objective is to invest funds to support the development of economies in the Middle East. TAIC is a 30% equity shareholder in the company.

Al Madina was established in 1998 and is primarily engaged in venture capital, private equity, underwriting and brokerage. It has successfully promoted several greenfield companies in Oman and other countries in the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC).
Cost Nature: The proposed IFC investment is a $10 million A Loan for IFC's own account.

Project Description:
The project consists of a $40 million senior loan to Banco Banex, S.A. (Banex or the Bank), an existing IFC client, to help fund the Bank's expansion in the corporate and mortgage lending activities.  

Banex is one of the largest private banks in Costa Rica, and together with Interfin (another IFC portfolio client) are the two most important private banks in the country. Costa Rica's financial system has been historically dominated by state owned banks. However, during the 1990s some structural reforms were made, allowing private banks to compete with state owned banks. Today, private banks have gained significant presence, with approximately 50% market share of the Costa Rican market.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category FI type 1 project according to IFC''s Environmental and Social Review Procedure.  Banco Banex will be required to designate individuals to have responsibility for environmental issues and who will attend environmental training; submit to IFC an environmental management plan;  establish an environmental management system to ensure that activities financed under relevant operations are consistent with applicable environmental, health and safety standards of Costa Rica;  and submit to IFC annual environmental performance reportsLocation of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor:
Banex was founded in 1981 with the purpose of serving the agricultural and industrial sectors of Costa Rica with potential for exports.  It is a wholly-owned subsidiary of Corporación Banex, a diversified financial services holding company based in Costa Rica.  Today, Banex is a universal bank oriented towards corporate and retail banking. Currently, Banex's loan portfolio is divided between approximately 70% corporate and 30% retail segments. The Bank's expansion will come primarily from the retail side of the business where the Bank's management believes there is stronger growth potential, while maintaining its leadership on the corporate side. Banex is rated AA- (cri) long-term and F1+(cri) short-term by Fitch locally.

Corporacion Banex, the holding company of Banex, has operations in commercial banking, insurance, brokerage services, trust services and pension fund management . The company was authorized as a Financial Group by the Board of Supervision of the Financial System on April 15, 1998.  In June 1999, Banistmo, the largest financial group in Central America and also an existing IFC client, acquired Corporacion Banex through a public tender.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is up to $40 million representing IFC's investment in the form of an A loan for its own account.
Investment: 40.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan40.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Banex is headquartered in San Jose, Costa Rica and has 33 branches across the country.  Investments can be made throughout the country.

Banco Banex will be required to designate individuals to have responsibility for environmental issues and who will attend environmental training; submit to IFC an environmental management plan;  establish an environmental management system to ensure that activities financed under relevant operations are consistent with applicable environmental, health and safety standards of Costa Rica;  and submit to IFC annual environmental performance reportsLocation of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Description:
The project involves an overhaul of the existing activities of NOSA through the following components:

-  improvement of the work flow, 
-  upgrade of the plant safety and environment conditions, 
-  installation of control, measurement and monitoring devices; and 
-  the expansion of the production capacity from about 8,700 to 17,400 tpa. 

The company specializes in the production of laundry soap, using locally produced palm oil as the main raw material. IFC supported the company with a guarantee facility (approved in June 1998, and committed in Feb. 1999) of CFA280 million ($0.4 million) to launch the then greenfield project.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFC''s Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects, because a limited number of specific environmental and/or social impacts may result which, can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe environmental documents will be located in the municipal office of the district of Simbock in Yaounde, as well as on the company's bill board in the company's Office and project site in Yaounde, Cameroon.
Sponsor: The sponsor is Mr. Samuel Noumsi (39), with 99.5% of the company's shares. Close family members (children) hold the remaining balance of the shares. NOSA is a limited partnership company (SARL) with a share capital of CFA200 million ($0.27 million). For over 10 years Mr. Noumsi was primarily involved in palm oil trading under the sole proprietor firm NOSACAM. Mr. Noumsi decided in 1997 to diversify through downstream integration, and to manufacture soap.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at ?uro2.01 million. The proposed IFC investment is an A loan for IFC's own account for the amount of ?uro 800.00.

Project Description:
Brascan Energetica S.A. (BESA), Brazil, is an indirectly-owned subsidiary of Brascan Power Corporation, a leading developer of renewable energy projects in North America. BESA focuses on the development, ownership and operation of small-scale hydro-power generation plants in Brazil, where the Brascan Group already has an established position in the investment banking, real estate and agribusiness sectors. 

BESA was established as an independent power producer in Brazil in 1999, leveraging the strong presence of the Brascan Group in Brazil. The company has projects in several states in Brazil, which it operates and monitors remotely from its operations center at its headquarters in Curitiba in Parana state via satellite links. Presently BESA owns 5 operational projects with installed capacity of 101 MW and one green field in the final phase of construction.

BESA is implementing  Clean Development Mechanism (CDM) projects based on run-of-river hydro generation assets that are displacing fossil fuel based generation in the Brazilian grid. The total installed capacity of the projects is presently 101.4 MW (made up of 5 plants whose capacity range from 15 to 30 MW of capacity). A sixth project (installed capacity of 27 MW) is in its final implementation phase and starts operations at the end of Q1 2005. The CDM projects bundled together will enable BESA to sell Certified Emissions Reductions (CERs) under the CDM of the Kyoto Protocol. IFC via the NetherlandsCarbon Facility is planning to purchase CERs from the project.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a Category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.  Environmental, social, health and safety issues associated with this project include: corporate capacity in environmental and social areas, land acquisition procedures for project facilities, related facilities, implementation of restoration and re-vegetation and community development initiatives, dam and reservoir safety, and projects on international waterways.Based on its review of available information regarding potential environmental impacts and proposed mitigation measures, IFC concludes that the proposed project is being designed to meet Government of Brazil requirements, as well as World Bank policies, and environmental, health and safety guidelines.  No corrective actions are proposed.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityEnvironmental documentation will be made available at the following locations:
