Project Description:
OAO Lukoil is Russia's largest integrated oil company.  In 1998, Lukoil acquired the Petrotel refinery from the Romanian government through a privatization process.  Since then, Lukoil has expanded its downstream operations in Romania to include about 300 retail petrol stations, 60 LPG filling skids and 8 petroleum distribution centers throughout the country.  Through these targeted investments, Lukoil succeeded in creating a fully-integrated business chain starting at the oil well in Russia and going all the way downstream to the pump in Romania.  Apart from the Romanian fuel wholesale and fuel retail market, Lukoil's Romanian operations also cater to the Moldavian market and other export markets through Lukoil's international trading company, Litasco International S.A.  

The project involves the modernization and revamping program of S.C. Petrotel-Lukoil S.A. (Petrotel), its Romanian refinery.  The project is aimed at:

-  providing high quality petroleum products to Romanian consumers that comply with European Euro-3 and Euro-4 standards, 
-  improving refinery operations by increasing the output of higher value petroleum products and reduce emissions and energy consumption; and providing high quality petroleum products to Romanian consumers that comply with European Euro-3 and Euro-4 standards.  

This in turn will strengthen the overall long-term competitive position of Lukoil's entire downstream network.
Role:
The proposed project will have the following development impacts: 

-  As part of Lukoil's operations in Romania, Petrotel forms a crucial element of a professionally run downstream business, which can serve as benchmark for other players.

-  Romania's refining sector is a legacy of the COMECON time with too many refineries at sub-optimal size.  Lukoil's investment in the downstream industry will facilitate rationalization of Romania's refining sector, by helping to remove overcapacity and loss-making players.  By streamlining the industry, the overall economics of the refining sector in Romania will be strengthened, allowing for a market-driven approach.

-  Together with the privatization of Petrom, which was acquired in 2004 by Austria's OMV, the project will reduce the need for the Government of Romania's involvement in the downstream industry.  This by itself is a benefit for the entire economy as western business practices are increasingly adopted.

-  Lukoil's investments in the Romanian economy will also be perceived as a showcase for a successful privatization.  Not only has Lukoil honored its commitment to carry out the modernization program as part of the privatization contract, but it will keep investing in the Romanian economy through the expansion of its gas station network and other activities.

-  In view of Romania's aspired EU accession, Petrotel's modernization program allows Lukoil to supply Euro-3 and Euro-4 fuels (the latest EU fuel Specifications) to Romania, as well as bring new technology to the country's debilitated refining sector, moving Romania's refining industry closer to EU best practices.

-  Due to the modernization program, Petrotel's air emissions have been reduced and meet IFC, EU and Romanian emissions standards, as low NOx burners are installed in boilers and heaters. 

-  As part of the modernization program, $11 million were spent for a wide-ranging environmental improvement program as part of Lukoil's obligation to the Government of Romania to carry out environmental clean-up work.  

-  Lukoil has trained and will continue training its Romanian staff to improve on current working practices, as well as health and safety standards.

-  Petrotel has total direct employment of 1,241 staff.  Moreover, Lukoil has currently 3,819 staff employed at its petrol station network and distribution facilities throughout Romania, which brings the total employment for Lukoil to 5,060.  All of Lukoil's operations will create substantial backward linkages in the country's economy.

The proposed project fits well with the World Bank Group strategy of promoting private sector development in a key sector that has been traditionally important for Romania.  In addition, it is in line with IFC's strategy of supporting the increase of foreign investment flows and investor confidence in the country.

IFC's participation in the project would enable the company to obtain adequate long-term financing at reasonable terms.  In addition to providing direct financing, IFC would serve as a catalyst by mobilizing sources in Europe via a B loan syndication at a time when limited access to long-term financing is available in Romania for these type of projects.  IFC has played a key role in structuring the financial plan, and evaluating environmental issues, thus reducing the project's risk profile.  In view of the perceived macroeconomic and political risks of investing in Romania, IFC's participation together with Lukoil, a regional leader in oil, gas and petrochemicals, will have a significant demonstration effect in supporting foreign direct investment in Romania.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category B project according to IFC''s Environmental Review Procedure.  Key environmental issues associated with this project include environmental and social management capacity, soil contamination, air emissions, liquid effluents, solid waste management, fire/explosion safety and emergency response, storage and transport safety, and logistics and safety handling for product distribution system. Occupational health and safety issues include emergency response training and general occupational health and safety.  Key social issues include public/community relations and community development including the possibility of implementing SME initiatives. Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe ERS document was released for the requisite 30-day period in July/August 2003 at the Petrotel's refinery gate and on Lukoil's website.
Sponsor:
The project sponsor and guarantor is OAO Lukoil, which accounts for roughly 19% of Russia's crude oil production or 86.2 million mt in 2004.   Throughput at Lukoil's refineries amounted to 43.8 million mt in 2004.  Lukoil's shares are publicly traded on the Russian stock exchanges (RTS, MICEX, SPICEX, SSE) and its ADRs and GDRs trade on the US over-the-counter market and exchanges in London, Berlin, Frankfurt, Munich and Stuttgart. Lukoil became the first Russian company to obtain  London Stock Exchange (LSE) listing in 2002.  

In September 2004, the Russian Government sold its remaining 7.59% stake in Lukoil to Houston-based ConocoPhillips, who has since indicated it will increase its stake to up to 20% and become a major equity investor.  

Following an internal reorganization in 2000, the sponsor's international assets were placed with Lukoil Overseas Limited B.V. for upstream operations and Lukoil International GmbH for downstream operation.  Petrotel's shares are owned by Lukoil Europe Holding B.V., a wholly-owned subsidiary of Lukoil International GmbH, (93.67%), the investment company S.I.F. Muntenia (3%), former State Property Fund - A.P.A.P.S. (2.59%) and various individuals (0.75%).
Cost Nature: Lukoil's investments in Romania are in the range of $367 million, out of which $260 million was invested to expand the gas station network, tank farms and other distribution installations, and $107 million for the modernization of the refinery.  At the outset of the project in 2003, Lukoil engaged IFC to provide long term financing.  However, in the interest of expediting the refinery modernization, the sponsor provided its own bridge financing to commence project implementation.  The refinery re-commenced operations in the fall 2004, and IFC's loans will replace the sponsor bridge financing.  IFC's proposed investment will consist of a $35 million A loan and a $47 million B loan.
Investment: 35.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan35.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The Petrotel refinery is located in Ploesti, a city with 300,000 inhabitants in central Romania.  The city is dominated by the Romanian oil industry, there are 4 refineries in the immediate area.  Lukoil has 300 gas stations and 8 storage tank farms across the country.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category B project according to IFC''s Environmental Review Procedure.  Key environmental issues associated with this project include environmental and social management capacity, soil contamination, air emissions, liquid effluents, solid waste management, fire/explosion safety and emergency response, storage and transport safety, and logistics and safety handling for product distribution system. Occupational health and safety issues include emergency response training and general occupational health and safety.  Key social issues include public/community relations and community development including the possibility of implementing SME initiatives. Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe ERS document was released for the requisite 30-day period in July/August 2003 at the Petrotel's refinery gate and on Lukoil's website.

Project Description: The proposed IFC financing is a ten year loan for IFCs account of up to $50 million to Infrastructure Development Finance Company Limited (IDFC, the company).  The loan is intended to help IDFC meets its growing needs for disbursements in infrastructure projects as well as to diversify its borrowing sources.  IDFC was established in 1996 as a specialized financial intermediary to lead private capital to commercially viable infrastructure projects in India.  IDFCs role was to complement existing institutions undertaking infrastructure finance with focus on strengthening market mechanisms where these were evolving or had failed to develop.  In addition to fund-based activities, IDFC also performs a policy advisory role by assisting the Central and State governments in preparing roadmaps for reform initiatives and the development of the regulatory framework.   The companys asset growth has been significant during the past two years, partly reflecting the improvements in the regulatory framework for infrastructure.
Role: The project would have a significant development impact in three areas: -  supporting the development of infrastructure in India through the projects IDFC finances.  The infrastructure projects have a positive contribution to job creation both during the implementation phase and the post implementation phase. -  supporting a specialized institution like IDFC at a time when other local institutions and commercial banks are withdrawing from infrastructure financing due to funding constraints as well as a shift in focus towards retail finance. By providing long term funding to IDFC, IFC will enable IDFC to better leverage its balance sheet, and -  promoting sound lending practices for infrastructure finance.  IFC will help IDFC leverage IFCs vast expertise in the area of emerging markets project finance. IDFC has already adopted IFCs processes and methodologies in environmental and social assessment of sub projects.   IFCs role in the proposed project is in line with its strategy.  At the time of IFCs initial investment in IDFC at its inception, IFC advocated IDFCs commercial orientation.  IFC also played a positive role in strengthening IDFCs environmental assessment capacity.   Specifically, IFCs role in this project is to-  provide long term foreign currency funding to expand IDFCs financing of infrastructure projects in India, and -  diversify IDFCs sources of funding.
Environmental Social Issues: As a general condition of IFCs initial investment, IDFC management established the Environmental Management and Social Development Group (EMSD) within the corporation.  With support from IFC specialists and technical consultants, and its own senior management, EMSD developed into an independent and effective team of specialists charged with assessing the environment and social (E&S) risk associated with sub-projects developed by IDFC investment staff for financing.   IDFCs goal will be to ensure that its environment and social management system is robust enough to address the potential impacts associated with the projects under this line.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: IDFCs ownership is held by the Government of India (35%), Industrial Development Bank of India (5%), by foreign investors (40%) and by domestic institutions and banks (20%).
Cost Nature: The proposed IFC financing is a loan for IFCs account of up to $50 million.
Investment: 50.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan50.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The proposed loan by IFC is expected to be utilized by IDFC to finance investments in commercially viable infrastructure projects in India.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: As a general condition of IFCs initial investment, IDFC management established the Environmental Management and Social Development Group (EMSD) within the corporation.  With support from IFC specialists and technical consultants, and its own senior management, EMSD developed into an independent and effective team of specialists charged with assessing the environment and social (E&S) risk associated with sub-projects developed by IDFC investment staff for financing. Project Description: Kounoune Power or the project company is to develop, construct, operate and maintain a 67.5 MW Heavy Fuel Oil (HFO)-fired diesel power generation plant located at Kounoune, about 23 kilometers east of Dakar, in Senegal.  The project is to be developed as an Independent Power Producer (IPP) selling power under a 15-year Power Purchase Agreement (PPA) to Société Nationale dElectricité du Sénégal (Senelec), Senegals state electric utility, which will be the sole offtaker of the project.  The PPA was executed by and between the project company and Senelec on February 5, 2005, and entered into effect on February 28, 2005.  Senelecs obligations under the PPA are guaranteed by the Government of Senegal (GoS), also executed on February 5, 2005.
Environmental Social Issues: The following environmental and social issues were reviewed and summarized in the Environmental Review Summary:  -  Environmental Assessment and Public Consultation; -  Site Selection and Land Acquisition; -  Buffer Zone Requirement and Possible Relocation of School and Houses; -  Air Emissions and Air Quality Impact; -  Noise; -  Water Supply and Wastewater; -  Solid and Liquid Waste and Incinerator; -  Fuel Storage and Risk Assessment; -  Greenhouse Gas Emissions; -  Health and Safety Management and Emergency Response Plan; -  Future Plan for Expansion of Kounoune Power Plant Complex; -  Associated Facilities (Fuel Pipeline and Transmission Line); -  Environmental and Social Action Plan; and -  Corporate Social Responsibility Initiative. Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityEnvironmental documentation can be found at the following locations:-  Préfecture de RUFISQUE : Rue Adama LO, BP 14, Rufisque-  Sous Préfecture de SANGALKAM : BP 573 Rufisque-  Communauté Rurale de SANGALKAM : BP 573 Rufisque-  Hotel de Ville de RUFISQUE : Boulevard Maurice Gueye, BP 30 , Rufisque-  Service des Eaux et Forêts de RUFISQUE : Rue Adama Lo , Rufisque
Sponsor: The sponsors of the project are the following: -  Matelec S.A.L. (Matelec) of Lebanon, one of the largest companies within the electrical business division of the Doumet group, a diversified industrial and services group operating in the Middle East and North America; and -  MHI Equipment Europe B.V. (MEE), a fully owned subsidiary of Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Ltd. (MHI) of Japan.  Matelec will contribute 20% of the total project costs in the form of equity through a special purpose company, Melec Power Gen, which will be the sole shareholder of the project company.  MEE will contribute 10% of the total project costs as quasi-equity, through a subordinated loan, and will also be the EPC contractor and the operator of the plant.
Cost Nature: The total project costs are estimated at about 61 million.  The proposed IFC investment is a 15.2 million A Loan for IFCs own account.

Project Description:
PNG Microfinance Ltd. (PML or the company) was established in 2004 and is sponsored by PNG Sustainable Development Program Ltd. (PNG SDP or the sponsor).  PML was granted a license by the Bank of Papua New Guinea to operate as a financial institution in December 2004.  PML will provide credit and financial services (including savings) to micro and small businesses in Papua New Guinea (PNG).  With a proposed paid up capital of Kina 15 million (approximately $5 million), PML will operate across PNG and will aim at achieving long-term sustainability on a commercial basis.  

The project comprises of the following components:

-  an IFC equity investment of up to $1.0 million equivalent for shareholding of approximately 19% in the expanded share capital of PML; and 
-  an IFC senior loan of up to $2.0 million to PML with a tenor of up to five years.
Environmental Social Issues: FI Category Type 1.  PML will establish an environmental management system to ensure that investments under relevant operations meet host country environmental, health and safety requirements and are consistent with IFCs microfinance exclusion list.  PML will provide an annual environmental performance report to IFC. Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor:
The main shareholders of PML are proposed to be PNG Sustainable Development Program Ltd. (40%), Bank South Pacific (BSP)  largest commercial bank in PNG (27%), IFC (19%) and technical partners (14%). BASIX, a leading Indian microfinance provider and an IFC investee company, is proposed to be a leading technical partner possibly in cooperation with Developpement International Desjardins (DID) - a Canadian corporation that supplies technical and financial support to microfinance institutions in developing countries.  

PNG SDP was created in October 2001 following agreement between the BHP Billiton and the Papua New Guinean Government, which led to BHP Billiton's withdrawal from OK Tedi Mining Limited (OTML) and transfer of BHP Billiton's 52% ownership interest in OTML to PNG SDP.  PNG SDP's organizational mandate is to ensure the sound use of the funds generated by the OK Tedi mine and to fund sustainable development programs throughout the remaining 10-year economic life of the mine and for up to 40 years following the mine's closure.
Cost Nature:
IFC's investment is proposed to consist of: 

-  an equity investment of Kina 3 million (approximately $1.0 million equivalent); and 
-  a term loan of up to $2.0 million.
Investment: 3.20 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan2.0Equity1.20* These investment figures are indicative
Location: PNG Microfinance Ltd. will operate across Papua New Guinea.  Its headquarters will be in Port Moresby.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: FI Category Type 1.  PML will establish an environmental management system to ensure that investments under relevant operations meet host country environmental, health and safety requirements and are consistent with IFCs microfinance exclusion list.  PML will provide an annual environmental performance report to IFC. Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Description:
The Jinan Shanshui Group (SSG or the company) is the second largest cement manufacturer in China based in Jinan, Shandong.  SSG has a total cement production capacity of 13.4 million tons per year and owns 12 cement facilities, all of which are located in Shandong.  The company was established in 1996, and was until recently, a state-owned enterprise directly owned by the Jinan Municipal Government.  Chuangzin Investment (CX) was established in 2001 as a private investment vehicle for SSG management and staff who owned 94% of CX, with the other 6% was owned by SSG itself.  In October 2004, after SSG received approval to restructure and reorganize, the company began the process of privatization, whereby SSG was taken over by CX (with CX as the surviving entity), and the management and staff became the legal owners of the company.  
The project consists of three main components aimed at assisting SSG:  

-  to merge with Chuangxin Investment (CX), privatize and restructure its cement operating companies;
-  consolidate its cement operations in its home province of Shandong through expansions and new investments; and
-  debt restructuring.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs procedure for environmental and social review of projects. Specific environmental, health & safety and social impacts associated with this project include: be considered during the appraisal include, but is not limited to evaluation of past and potential future land acquisition procedures, sustainable raw material sourcing, quarry rehabilitation plans, emission control, water and wastewater management, transport and infrastructure tie-in, and local social commitments.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThis field will be updated when specific information has been received from the sponsor.
Sponsor: While the exact ownership percentages are yet to be finalized, the likely shareholding structure following the privatization and pre-IPO equity investment is expected to be : Morgan Stanley Private Equity Asia (MSPEA)/CDH  35%; IFC  7%, and Management and Staff  58%. Company Name: S.A. SAN MIGUEL A.G.I.C.I. y F.
Project Description:
San Miguel is an Argentine company that produces fresh lemons on 5,500 ha of agricultural land in the province of Tucumán, in the north of Argentina. From its own production as well as third parties', San Miguel exports over 100,000 tons of fresh lemons, and processes more than twice this amount of fruit to produce frozen lemon juice concentrate, essential oil and dried peel.

The project is to support San Miguel's overall plantation and industrial operations, permanent working capital as well as its sophisticated industrial waste treatment system.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The review of this project consisted of appraising technical and environmental /social information submitted by the project sponsor, a physical inspection of industrial processing facilities, and discussions with the sponsors professional team responsible for management of environmental and social issues.  The following potential environment, health and safety and social impacts of the projects were analyzed.-  Existing and planned management systems for food safety, quality, environmental and social affairs; -  Employment considerations in view of  relocation of selected industrial operations; -  Air emissions from steam and heat generation; -  Sustainability and quality of potable water supply used in fresh fruit processing and food manufacturing; -  Industrial effluent management; -  Uruguayan operations; -  Solid waste management; and -  Occupational health and safety in processing, agriculture and allied facilities.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityIFC prepare an Environmental Review Summary (ERS) for the project as part of its public disclosure obligations regarding its investments and their associated environmental and social impacts. The ERS was translated in Spanish and made available to the public in the city halls of Famaillá and Lules. The availability of the document was first announced in local newspapers on April 8, 2005.

The community will be able to review this document until mid-May 2005. Any questions or enquiries regarding the project may be directed to:

Sr. Daniel Dip, Gerente de Industria, (54) 3863 461427, Ruta Provincial 301, Km 33, Estación Padilla.
Sponsor: San Miguel is listed in the Buenos Aires Stock Exchange, and controlled by a group of individual shareholders. The company also has operations in sweet citrus and lemons in Uruguay, through its subsidiaries.
Cost Nature: IFC is supporting San Miguel with a syndicated corporate loan, financing overall lemon production and processing operations with a particular focus on environmental matters and treatment of the company's industrial waste. IFC is proposing to lend $20 million of long term debt for its own account, and to syndicate a B loan with other lenders.

Location: San Miguel's offices and its main fresh fruit packing facility are located in the suburbs of San Miguel de Tucumán, while its plantations are scattered in the province. San Miguel industrial processing plant is located in Famaillá, about 30km away from the town.

Project Description:
The project company is Absolut Bank (the Bank or the company), a private medium sized bank serving primarily the Moscow region. It is a well-managed and profitable institution experiencing strong asset growth, with good market position and high efficiency of operations. The Bank's three core business areas include corporate finance, retail banking, and financial institutions.

The project consists of a senior loan to be used by the Bank for the expansion of its residential mortgage lending program and, potentially, an equity or quasi-equity investment to enable the Bank to strengthen its capital base and expand its operations.
Environmental Social Issues: For the SME-oriented part of the proposed investment, the environmental category is FI type 2. The Bank will be required to establish an environmental management system to ensure that lending under this project complies with host country environmental and social requirements and is consistent with IFCs exclusion list and any applicable WBG environmental health and safety guidelines and safeguard principles. The Bank will designate staff who will have responsibility for environmental affairs and will participate in IFCs environmental training. Absolut Bank will also submit annual environmental performance reports to IFC.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityn/a
Sponsor: The major shareholders of the Bank are three Moscow entrepreneurs, Messrs. Svetakov, Galin, and Truskov, who collectively hold 76% of the Bank's shares. They are also shareholders of a holding company of the same name, which is active in import of consumer electronics, production of consumer goods, real estate development and other sectors. The remaining 24% of the shares are held by Mr. Kosolapov (Executive Director of Absolut Group) and Mr. Serdtsev, the First Deputy Chairman of the Management Board.
Cost Nature: IFC will provide a senior loan of up to $15 million and potentially, an equity or quasi-equity investment of up to $10 million.

The Bank plans to move to a new head office in Moscow and open another branch in St. Petersburg shortly. By the end of the year 2005 10 branches located in Moscow region will have been opened.

Project Name: Vaalco Gabon Offshore Oilfield Development Facility
Project Description: VAALCO Gabon (Etame), Inc (VAALCO Gabon or the company), an existing IFC client, has successfully completed its first phase of development of the Etame field in offshore Gabon. The Project relates to the next phase of the company's oil development and exploration/appraisal programs in the Etame Block. These currently include the second phase of the Etame field development; new development of the Avouma and South Tchibala field discoveries and potentially the Ebouri field in the same block; conducting 3D seismic surveys and drilling additional exploration wells. The programs will help sustain oil production from the concession as well as maintain exploration investments that can potentially identify additional reserves. VAALCO holds a 28% production interest and is the operator of the Etame Block.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. VAALCO's principal operating assets are focused in Gabon, with nearly 100% of its current production and reserves attributable to fields in the Etame Block. VAALCO also owns small non-operated interests in producing properties in Brazos, Frio and Dimmit counties in Texas. VAALCO Gabon is wholly owned by VAALCO International in which the sponsor, VAALCO Energy, has 90.01% shareholding. The remaining 9.99% shares in VAALCO International are held by Sojitz Corporation, Japan.

Project Description: Alliance Housing Bank (AHB, the Bank, or the company) is licensed by the Central Bank of Oman (the regulatory and apex bank of Oman) as a specialized housing finance bank, focused on commercial mortgage lending to the growing middle-income Omani population. AHB is Oman's only private sector housing finance bank, with the total assets of $260 million and net worth of $76 million as of December 31, 2004. The proposed IFC loan would help AHB to expand its lending operations to mid and low income Omani households.

The second largest shareholder is Pension Fund for the Employees of the Ministry of Defense of Oman (PFE), holding 10% equity stake. None of the other shareholders holds more than 5% stake of the company.

Project Description: RMIT Vietnam is a new entity founded by RMIT to develop its university campus in Vietnam. The first phase of the proposed project, after being developed, will be able to accommodate up to 3,000 students and staff. The project will be the first for-profit, wholly foreign-owned university in the country. The government of Vietnam promulgated, on March 6, 2000, a new decree governing wholly foreign-owned, for-profit, medical, educational, and technical training institutions. RMIT Vietnam is the first company licensed under this decree.The project will alleviate the acute shortage of high-quality colleges and universities in Vietnam. Only one out of six applicants can enter a college or a university in Vietnam at present, which leaves every year one million candidates to either prepare for the next year's exams or look for jobs. In addition, Vietnam has a huge shortage of people with foreign languages, business management, computer and other technical skills. The project, by providing degree programs, and short-term foreign languages and professional training adapted to the market needs, will make significant contribution to the development of human capital in Vietnam. It will also make it possible for thousands of Vietnamese students, who do not have the financial means to study abroad, to receive western-style university education in Vietnam. The project will help enhance the quality of higher education in Vietnam by introducing well-developed academic programs, quality assurance systems, and professional management, at the level of those offered in Australia. The project could provide an example to replicate for the Vietnamese regulatory authorities and public universities. The successful implementation of this venture will demonstrate that the environment for foreign investments in Vietnam is improving.
Role: IFC will provide the long-term financing tailored to the project. Currently, obtaining long-term financing from international capital markets in Vietnam is almost impossible. IFC has assisted RMIT in the project structuring by recommending to phase the campus development. This will help reduce the up-front financing needs, test the market, and improve the chances of success in the early stage. Early in the project's development stage, the Corporation identified key regulatory issues and assisted the sponsor in its dialogue with the Vietnamese governmental authorities. IFC has played the lead role to develop and implement two technical assistance projects funded by AusAid including the preparation of a .resettlement action plan and a feasibility study for the development of a student loan program to support students from low-income families to attend the university.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific social and environmental impacts may result that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.The project was originally categorized as A because the initial 62 ha site would have involved the resettlement of households.  Since the land acquisition changed to an area of 12 ha that did not involve resettlement, the project was re-categorized.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityEnvironmental documentation will be made available at the following locations:
- The MASD new headquarters at 9-11 Tan Phu Street, District 7, Ho Chi Minh City.- The District 7 office at People's Committee of District 7, District 7, Ho Chi Minh City.- The Tan Phong Ward office at Tan Phong Ward People's Committee, Tan Phong Ward, District 7, Ho Chi Minh City.- The RMIT Vietnam office at 21 Pham Ngoc Thach Street, District 3, Ho Chi Minh City.
Sponsor: The project sponsor is RMIT University, a public university based in Melbourne, Australia. With 40,000 students enrolled and a history of over 100 years, it is one of the top universities in the country. Since mid-1990s, RMIT began taking its services outside Australia by offering joint programs in partnership with local universities in Hong Kong, Malaysia, Japan, Thailand, Vietnam and other Asian countries. Following the first few years of successful introduction into Asia, RMIT is stepping up its efforts to position itself as a leading international university in the region by building a new university in Ho Chi Minh city (HCMC), Vietnam  RMIT International University Vietnam (RMIT Vietnam). RMIT Vietnam is the first university wholly owned and operated by RMIT outside Australia.RMIT envisions that the completion of the full campus of RMIT Vietnam could take about 12 years, by the end of which period the total student enrolment could grow up to 13,000. The first phase of the construction is occured from 2003 to 2005. The sponsor has asked IFC and Asian Development Bank (ADB) to help finance the project.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $32.1 million. The proposed IFC investment is a $7.25 million senior A loan. The ADB proposes to provide a $7.25 million senior loan for its account on the same terms and conditions as those of the IFC loan.
Investment: 7.50 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan7.50Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The project will be developed on a 12.4ha area of the initial 62 ha site, about 5 km south of downtown HCMC and along the Ong Lon river. The site is in the South Saigon development area, a 2,900 ha being developed as a new business and residential centre in HCMC. The master development plan includes new roads and bridges linking South Saigon with the existing downtown. Over the past two years, some bridges and roads have already been completed under this development plan. The project does not require resettlement of some households residing on the site and compensation for families who rely on the site for farming incomes.

Project Description: The project is to create a chain of 12 multi-screen cinemas in the Russian Federation under the name Cinema Park ('Cinema Park' or the 'Company').  Cinema Park was established in 2002 and currently operates from its offices in Moscow.
Role:
The project's expected development impact are in the following areas :

-  Affordable Leisure: 
Providing affordable, safe and good quality entertainment and cultural options for the Russian middle class, especially for the young.  In-doors entertainment is particularly important in Russia given its severe weather conditions for most part of the year.

-  Infrastructure: 
Providing infrastructure for a modernizing and fast growing media sector, with spillover effects to other sectors of the economy.  In addition, cinemas help create traffic and extend hours of shopping malls, which is critical to the success of modern retail, a sector IFC is promoting. Clustering leisure facilities like stores, cinemas and restaurants makes efficient use of urban infrastructure including parking lots and access facilities or services
-  Environmental and Social: 
The project will elevate environmental and social standards in the Russian cinema sector.  The company will produce a Master Fire and Life Safety Plan following international standards (German DIN or equivalent), to be designed by international expert consultants acceptable to IFC.  Cinema Park's cinemas will include special facilities for the disabled at international standards, including special hearing aids for the hearing impaired in selected cinemas.

-  Local Content: 
By creating the audiences that creates demand for investors to inject money to the production side of the chain, the Project will indirectly support the production of local films.  The company plans to become an advocate of local film production by supporting the Golden Eagle Award for young local film producers.  

-  Piracy: 
The project will also help counter piracy in media products by increasing the supply of affordable, legitimate products widely within the Russian Federation and supporting an industry whose development will depend on a continued battle against piracy.

- Job Creation:
The project is expected to create over 500 permanent jobs throughout the country.

-  IFC Role: 
Through its investment, IFC will support the development, growth and diversification of a locally-owned and successfully operated company, a role IFC has played in only a select few of its general manufacturing projects to date in Russia.  IFC also has a role to play by providing long-term financing that is otherwise not available in Russia today for projects in the media/entertainment sector.  IFC's participation in the project will also lend credibility to Interros on international markets which, given Interros' considerable contribution to Russian GDP, will have a positive effect on the Russian economy as a whole.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a category B project according to IFC''s Environmental and Social Review Procedure because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. Potential environmental, social and health and safety issues associated with this project include site locations, previous land use and potential land acquisition issues (e.g. economic or physical displacement), fire & life safety and solid waste management. Applicable environmental and social policies and guidelines for this project are General Environmental Guidelines (PPAH, July 1, 1998), Fire & Life Safety Guidelines (December 2002) and General Health and Safety guidelines (IFC, July 1, 1998). Annual environmental monitoring reports (AMRs) will be required which detail project performance against the requirements of these documents, host country regulation and any other requirements incorporated into the investment agreement.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityAn Environmental Review Summary will be available for public consultation beginning April 15, 2005 in the following locations:
Moscow : Cinema Park Theaters: 
- Kaluzhskaya- Ulitsa Profsoyuznaya, 61, 3rd floor, open daily 10 am to 6 pm;
- 'Fifth Avenue'- Ulitsa Marshala Biryuzova, 32, 3rd floor, open daily 10 am to 6 pm.
Central Public Libraries of the following cities : Saint Petersburg, Perm, Ufa, Krasnoyarsk, Ekaterinburg, Tyumen, Novosibirsk, each from 10 am to 6 pm.
Sponsor: The project sponsor is Prof Media, the media arm of the Interros group, one of the biggest Russian private economic groups, with investments, in addition to Prof Media, in mining (Norilsk Nickel), banking (Rosbank), power machines (Silovye Mashiny) and agribusiness (Agros) among others.  The Interros group is controlled by Mr. Vladimir Potanin, a Russian investor and businessman.  Interros currently owns 80% of Cinema Park.  The remaining 20% of Cinema Park is owned by Studio Trite, a Russian company in the film production business in Russia, controlled by Mr. Nikita Mikhailkov, a Russian film producer.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $128 million.  The proposed IFC investment is a $20 million A loan  for IFC's own account.

The company operates two cinemas in Moscow and is planning to open additional cinemas in several cities in the Russian Federation, including Moscow, Saint Petersburg and other regional cities.  Cinema Park will operate mainly in retail space in shopping malls and entertainment centers, as well as in free standing buildings in highly populated urban centers with good access to public transportation.

Project Description:
Jamaica Energy Partners (JEP) is a 74.2 MW barge-mounted power generation plant using medium-speed diesel engines burning heavy fuel oil.  Developed as a fast track project in 1995, it was the first Independent Power Producer commissioned on the island of Jamaica. The project sells its capacity and energy to Jamaica Public Service Company (JPSCo), the national integrated public utility and the grid operator, which was publicly-owned at that time, under a twenty-year (20) PPA contract and a thirty-year (30) electrical license. IFC provided financing for JEP in 1997.  

Jamaica relies almost entirely on imports of fuel oil to power its generation plants.  The high cost of fuel and other factors contribute to the high electricity tariff in Jamaica.  Under a long-term development plan, the Government of Jamaica is seeking to build larger and more efficient plants and secure cheaper sources of fuel for Jamaica.  However, to meet the continuing demand growth on the island, a 50 MW capacity addition was urgently needed by end 2005.

In 2004, JEP and JPSCo signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) to deliver additional capacity.  As per the MOU, JEP will increase its capacity from the currently installed level of 74.2 MW to 123.6 MW by building a 49.5 MW barge-mounted plant based on updated diesel engine technology burning the same heavy fuel oil.  The new barge will be located at a leased site, 200 feet alongshore the existing barge.

JPSCo, 80% owned by Mirant Corporation of the US since 2001, will purchase JEP's aggregate capacity and power under a 20 year Power Purchase Agreement.  Petrojam, the current fuel supplier of the existing capacity, will continue to supply fuel oil under a Fuel Supply Agreement.   

The Project also involves restructuring JEP's existing debt (which has a final maturity in 2007 and 2009) with debt of longer-maturity (15 years). This will reduce JEP's debt service burden, allowing it to offer JPSCo a lower charge for the capacity of the whole expanded plant which will benefit Jamaican consumers also. The IFC's involvement in the financing will not only mobilize financing from commercial lenders in a difficult market but demonstrate as a vote of confidence its support of private participation in the development of the infrastructure to the Jamaican economy thereby boosting investor confidence in the country.
Environmental Social Issues:
An environmental impact assessment (EIA) has been prepared for the project to meet the requirements of the Jamaican environmental agency, NEPA.  The key environmental issue for the project is air quality impacts and cumulative air quality at Old Harbour.  JEP has developed a mitigation plan for SO2 emissions to address this issue.  Other issues analyzed for the project included dredging and site preparation, noise from plant operation, cooling water discharge, discharge of sewage and storm water, spill control, occupational health and safety, and environmental compliance of the existing JEP plant.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityDr. Bird Power Station, Old Harbour Bay , 
JEP Corporate Office, Jamaica Energy Partner, 
RKA Building, 3rd Floor, 
St . Catherine, Jamaica W.I.
10 Grenada Way Kingston 5, 
Jamaica W.I.
Sponsor:
JEP is a Jamaican general partnership whose ultimate equity investors are Latin Power Funds (LPF, formerly known as the Scudder Latin American Power Funds, 62.6%), Caribbean Basin Power Fund (CBPF, 36.4%), and Wartsila (1%). 

LPF consist of two funds specializing in the power sector in the Latin America and Caribbean region:  the $100 million Latin Power Fund I (LPF I), formerly known as 'SLAP I' when launched in 1993) and the $157 million Latin Power Fund II (LPF II), formerly known as 'SLAP II' when launched in 1998). Both funds have been closed and fully invested. LPF's investors include, ABN AMRO Bank, Deutsche Bank AG, Inter-American Investment Corporation, Zurich Financial Services, IFC, etc.  LPF is currently managed by Conduit Capital Partners.   

CBPF was formed in 1999 with capital commitments of $75 million with the mandate to invest in energy companies and projects in the Caribbean and Central America.  The Co-Sponsors of CBPF are the Commonwealth Development Corporation and Dresdner Kleinwort Capital. It is managed by Energy Investors Funds.
Cost Nature: IFC is considering providing an A Loan of up to $20 million, a B Loan of up to $45 million, and a C Loan of up to $8 million.
Investment: 28.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan28.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location:
The town of Old Harbour is located in the southern section of the Parish of St Catherine, about 40 km Southwest of the Country's Capital Kingston. At its southwest gate is Portland Ridge Peninsula. The Bay comprises many islets such as Great Goat Island and Pigeon Island. The minor port of Old Harbour Bay at its head is called Portland Bight.

Located in this peninsula is the Old Harbour Power Station site.  This site is owned by JPSCo that has leased certain sections to JEP. The total generating capacity of this station is in excess of 294MW.  Of this 294MW JPSCo operates 220 MW by way of four (4) oil fired boiler, steam generating units.  JEP owns and operates the Dr Bird facility, which comprises eight Wartsila V12 46 engines burning heavy fuel oil and generating 74.16 MW to the Jamaican Grid. The project will be located at a leased site 200 feet alongshore from its existing barge, thereby augmenting JEP capacity to 123 MW.

Other issues analyzed for the project included dredging and site preparation, noise from plant operation, cooling water discharge, discharge of sewage and storm water, spill control, occupational health and safety, and environmental compliance of the existing JEP plant.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityDr. Bird Power Station, Old Harbour Bay ,

Project Description: Stora Enso Oyj (Stora Enso or the sponsor), the worlds largest paper and board producer in produced tonnes and number three sawn timber producer, has approached IFC for a loan facility to finance the development of its timber plantation and related investments in China.  China is the second largest and fastest growing paper market in the world, yet it is critically short of timber/fiber.  China accounts for over 1/3 of the total increase in global paper capacity for the period 2001-2006, however the countrys short supply of fiber has led it to import unsustainably harvested fiber from neighbors such as Russia or the Pacific Rim.  Stora Ensos current projects in China include expanding its plantation in the Guangxi province of Southern China, which began operating in 2002 as well as a paper mill in Suzhou, which was acquired by Stora Enso in 1998.  Stora Enso plans to further develop both operations, with an immediate financing need to help development of their plantation.  These investment projects, combined with Stora Ensos other possible investment projects in China comprise an estimated $125 million investment program over the next five years.  Stora Enso has thus requested IFC for a flexible debt facility for to help it with its investment program financing needs.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure. Sponsor: Stora Enso is a publicly listed (Helsinki, Stockholm and New York), Finland-based global forest products company.  It specializes in integrated paper, packaging and forest products, producing publication and fine papers, packaging boards and wood products, areas in which the Group is a global market leader.  The Group has approximately 45,000 employees in more than 40 countries in five continents.  It has about 16 million tonnes annual production capacity in various paper and packaging board grades and more than 7 million m3 in sawn timber.  It maintains a leading global market share in most of its paper grades, namely coated (magazine) paper, graphic and specialty papers where it enjoys market leadership in Europe and North America, and also has a leading position in Europe in newsprint, office paper, consumer packaging board and forest products. On the forestry side, it has leading competence of sustainable forestry operations, including long experience of developing fast growing plantations in Southern Europe, Latin America and Asia.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is $125 million.  The proposed investment is a $50 million A loan for IFCs own account and up to a $25 million B loan from syndicate lenders.

The plantations are located in rural locations which have primarily been used for forestry and/or agricultural plantations.Stora Ensos paper mill is located on an industrial site in an industrial region of the city of Suzhou, some 160 kilometers west of Shanghai.

Project Description:
The project entails a $75 million credit line (Credit Line) to be provided to Banco ABN AMRO Real S.A. (Banco Real or the Bank).

Proceeds from the Credit Line will be used by Banco Real for:

-  origination of eligible (i.e., predominantly SME) domestic trade receivables from Brazilian corporates, which would be securitized in an appropriate, bankruptcy-remote ABS (i.e., Fundos de Investimento em Direitos Creditórios or FIDC) format, and eventually placed with local investors, and

-  on-lending activities to support two forms of sustainability-oriented business activities at the Bank, (environment-related lending and credit support for family-owned, middle market companies that improve their corporate governance practices).  The lending in (ii) above will be identical to the purpose of the $51 million IFC Sustainability Credit Line (SCL) currently outstanding to Banco Real.

The project is intended to:

-  Broaden the availability to local companies of funding sourced in the domestic capital markets using recently established FIDC structures, and thereby allow these companies to provide incremental credit (at more favorable terms) to their SME  as well as other end-consumer  clients.

-  Encourage further Sustainability-targeted (in particular, Environment- and Corporate Governance-related) reforms in Brazilian companies, like those already being engendered by the SCL outstanding to Banco Real.
Environmental Social Issues: Banco Real has established an environmental and social management system to assess the capacity and environmental compliance status of their clients for project finance, corporate lending, and SME lending.  In addition, Banco Real is familiar with IFC''s sustainability framework and how to apply it to prospective clients under this funding.   Clients funded under this loan will already have complied with applicable environmental and social requirements, and be aiming to take their projects beyond compliance status.  Banco Real will provide to IFC annual reports of the environmental and social performance of the projects funded under this loan.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: The sponsor, Banco ABN AMRO Real is a wholly-owned subsidiary of ABN AMRO Bank N.V. in the Netherlands.
Cost Nature: The proposed IFC investment is a $75 million loan for IFC's own account.

Project Description: The project comprises the construction of a greenfield bleached eucalyptus kraft pulp (BEKP) mill with annual capacity of one million tons in Fray Bentos (Uruguay) by Europes second largest pulp producer, OY Metsa Botnia AB (Botnia, or the sponsor) from Finland.  Uruguay is one of very few locations in the world where already existing plantations can supply the raw material for a new pulp mill of this scale.  Wood for the mill will be procured from existing plantations owned by the sponsors and from third parties within Uruguay and Argentina.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an Environmental and Social Review Category A project.  The following environmental, social, health and safety impacts of the project were analysed: the quality and impact of air emissions and effluents, including cumulative and downstream impacts; the source and sustainability of raw material supplies; social impacts; public disclosure and consultation; and compliance with IFC policies on involuntary resettlement, international waterways, forestry, natural habitats, and cultural property.   Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityEvironmental documentation wil be made available at the following locations:Biblioteca Municipal; Terminal de Omnibus, Fray Bentos and Oficina de Turismo, 18 de Julio frente a Plaza Constitutucion, Fray Bentos
Sponsor: The company: Botnia S.A. (or the project company) is 100% owned by entities controlled by the sponsor (with an option for the local partner to purchase up to 9% of the shareholding).  The local partner, the Otegui Group, has been in the agribusiness sector since the beginning of the last century and employs approximately 600 people.  Grupo Otegui started its forest products activities at the end of 1980s and currently owns eucalyptus plantations (FSC certified since 2001) and sawmills.  The sponsor:  Botnia is Europes second largest pulp producer and owns five pulp mills in Finland with total production capacity of 2.7 million tons per annum.  Approximately 80% of Botnias pulp is sold to its shareholders and the rest is sold as market pulp, mainly to Europe.  Botnias audited turnover as of end of 2004 amounted to $1.5 billion and net profit to $142 million equivalent (compared to $69 million as of end of 2003).  Botnia is owned by three Finnish companies: M-Real Corporation (39%), UPM-Kymmene (47%) and Metsaliitto Cooperative (14%).  M-Real is Europe''s third largest paper merchant and a leading supplier of paper, paperboard and packaging solutions.  UPM is the worlds leading magazine paper, silicon paper and label producer and Europes leading envelope paper, industrial wrapping products and plywood producer.  Metsaliitto Cooperative, the parent company of Metsaliitto Group, is an organization of Finnish forest owners with approximately 131,000 members.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is expected to be approximately $1.2 billion.  The proposed IFC investment consists of an A loan for IFCs own account of up to $100 million and a syndicated B loan for the account of participants of up to $100 million.
Investment: 70.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan70.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The pulp mill will be built in Fray Bentos, the capital of the Rio Negro Department. The city is located some 200 miles North-West from Montevideo and has an estimated population of 23,000.  Fray Bentos is an important trade conduit as it is located on the Uruguay River and next to an international bridge that connects Uruguay to Argentina.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is an Environmental and Social Review Category A project. Project Name: Hipotecaria Su Casita, S.A. de C.V. - SOFOL - Warehousing Line
Company Name: Hipotecaria Su Casita, S.A. de C.V., SOFOM, E.N.R.
Project Description:
Hipotecaria Su Casita, S.A. de C.V. (HSC or Su Casita) is Mexico's second largest Sofol (specialized mortgage lending institution) by market share.  Its main function is to extend mortgage loans to low-income individuals under the auspices of SHF (Sociedad Hipotecaria Federal) financing programs, and to provide construction financing to developers of low-income housing.  It controls approximately 18% of the mortgage market served by Sofoles, based on total loan portfolio.  It has 107 offices in Mexico.  Su Casita was established in 1994.  As of December 2004, it had total assets of $1.85 billion equivalent and shareholders' equity of $127 million equivalent.  It is rated A3.mx (national scale issuer rating), and Ba3 (global scale local currency issuer rating) by Moody's, and A-.mx by Standard and Poor's.  

HSC has grown at a rapid pace since its inception a decade ago, given the high demand for low-income housing in Mexico.  To enable it to continue to grow in step with the market and to diversify its funding source from the SHF, its strategy is to maintain its ongoing securitization program, thus enabling it to free up its balance sheet of assets so securitized.  The purpose of IFC's loan is to support HSC in this securitization program.  IFC's loan will be collateralized by a pool of mortgages that will satisfy IFC-stated criteria and be held in a Security Trust.  This loan will thus readily enable Su Casita to support its securitization from a pool of high-quality assets that will already be in the Trust.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category C project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  The nature of HSC''s portfolio (low- to middle-income residential mortgage loans) means that there will be minimal environmental impacts associated this investment.  Therefore, no further environmental or social analysis is required.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: The project sponsor is Hipotecaria Su Casita.  HSC is wholly owned by Grupo Su Casita.  Grupo Su Casita, in turn, is majority owned by Caja Madrid of Spain with a 25% stake, Pulte Mortgage Corporation (the second-largest U.S. homebuilder), Mexican homebuilders (including Corporacion GEO, one of Mexico's largest homebuilders), individual shareholders, and IFC.
Cost Nature: The proposed IFC investment is a Mexican peso-denominated revolving line of credit, for IFC's own account, of $50 million equivalent, secured by a pool of mortgages that will satisfy IFC-specified criteria.  The mortgages will be held by a trust separate from the borrower.
Investment: 49.85 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan49.85Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The location of the project is at the headquarters of Hipotecaria Su Casita in Mexico City, Mexico.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category C project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  The nature of HSC''s portfolio (low- to middle-income residential mortgage loans) means that there will be minimal environmental impacts associated this investment.  Therefore, no further environmental or social analysis is required.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Description:
The proposed transaction consists of an IFC investment of up to $30 million in the form of a 5 year senior secured loan to Ural-Siberian Bank (UralSib, the Bank, or the company), a leading regional bank in the Russian Federation.  The project is aimed at helping the Bank to expand its lending to medium-sized private Russian companies.  

UralSib was founded in 1993 as an entity wholly-owned by the Republic of Bashkortostan (RoB), a mineral-rich autonomous region located in the east of the European part of Russia.  Until 2000, when a 14% stake of the Bank was sold to external parties, the Bank had been 100% owned by the RoB.  In late 2003, 72.5% of the Bank was acquired by companies related to the Nikoil Financial Corporation (Nikoil FC), a major Russian financial group that owns and controls two commercial banks, IBG-Nikoil Bank (Nikoil) and Avtobank-Nikoil (Avtobank) as well as several other banking financial companies such as factoring, leasing, insurance and asset management.  The acquisition of the Bank was part of an expansion process initiated by Nikoil FC to bring together one of the most complete financial groups in Russia. The new merged group will be among top 5 banking institutions in Russia.
.
Role:
This project is expected to have a significant development impact in developing the financial sector and the private sector in Russia.  As one of the first post-crisis IFC loans to a Russian bank with a large regional network, it will help increase geographical diversification and outreach by making credits available to SMEs throughout Russia.   Moreover, the IFC loan will provide additional resources for the banking sector, thereby allowing it to play a more effective role in the development of the private sector through financial intermediation.

By providing this loan, IFC would:

Help a major Russian bank with a strong presence in the regions to expand its funding base and extend its maturity profile, thus enabling it to provide longer-term funds to its SME clients.  
Support UralSib's growth and therefore, improve financial intermediation and foster competition among new and existing players.
Improving operational standards at UralSib FC, thereby setting a positive example for other Russian banks.
Send a positive signal to international financial community about IFC's commitment to Russia and to the development of the private sector in the country.
Further demonstrate IFC's efforts to help Russian banks to realize growth opportunities through partnership, transparency, and good corporate governance.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category FI Type 1 project according to IFCs environmental and social procedure.  The Bank will be required to establish an environmental management system for its corporate lending operations to ensure that the activities and enterprises it finances comply with Russian environmental and occupational health and safety requirements.  UralSib must appoint staff responsible for environmental issues that should attend IFCs environmental training course for financial intermediaries and submit environmental performance reports to IFC on an annual basis.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Cost Nature: The proposed project is to provide the Bank with an A loan for up to a $30.
Investment: 30.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan30.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The location of the project is in Moscow, Russia

Project Description:
The proposed IFC investment consists of a loan of up to $45 million to National Commercial Bank Jamaica (NCBJ, the Bank, or the company), 

NCBJ is the second-largest private commercial bank in Jamaica with total assets of $2.9 billion, total group equity of $266 million and a network of over 50 branches as of year end 2004. 

The purpose of the project is fourfold:

- support the growth of the Bank's lending operations
- alleviate the lack of mid-term and long-term financing for private sector companies
- provide NCBJ with an additional source of funding
- ensure there is sufficient equity in the company to facilitate its future regional expansion plans

Given NCBJs interest in IFC's Global Trade Finance Facility, an incremental trade line may be made available to the company as well as Technical Assistance opportunities.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an FI Type 1 project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.  The Bank will be required to:-  establish an environmental management system to ensure that activities financed under relevant operations are consistent with applicable environmental, occupational health and safety regulations of Jamaica,  -  designate appropriate individuals who will have responsibility for the environment and who will attend IFCs environmental management workshops or an approved equivalent, and -  submit to IFC an environmental management plan and annual performance reports.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityNA
Sponsor:
NCBJ was established in 1837 by the Colonial Bank of London, and was bought by Barclays Bank in 1925.  The Jamaican Government acquired all the Bank's shares in 1977, when it took on its identity as NCBJ.  NCBJ was listed on the Jamaican Stock Exchange in 1986.  Following the merger between NCBJ and Mutual Security Bank Jamaica Ltd. in 1996, the NCB Group (today NCBJ) has become a dominant force in the Jamaican financial sector. 

AIC acquired NCBJ in March 2002 from the Government of Jamaica as part of rescue package of the financial sector in Jamaica.  AIC owns just over 75% of the ordinary shares of NCBJ, held directly through the wholly-owned AIC (Barbados) Ltd. AIC has grown rapidly to become the 11th largest mutual fund company in Canada, with more than US$12 billion assets under management for more than 1 million clients.  AIC was acquired by Michael Lee-Chin in 1987, who coined the corporate motto; 'Buy. Hold.  Prosper.'.  Mr. Lee-Chin is credited for growing AIC from a niche fund firm with $1 million in assets under management in 1987, to the conglomerate it is today.  AIC has expanded through acquisitions and making alliances with strong reputable financial groups in Canada.
Cost Nature: The project it to provide up to $45 million from IFC own account to National Commercial Bank of Jamaica (NCBJ or the company) to support the expansion plans of NCB, its working capital needs, as well as the growth of the Bank's lending operations.
Investment: 30.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan30.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative

Project Description: Distrigaz Sud (DGS) is the dominant gas distribution and supply company in southern Romania.  In 2004, the Government of Romania (GOR) signed a privatization agreement for the sale of a 51 percent interest in DGS to Gaz de France (GdF), the leading supplier and distributor of natural gas in France and one of the largest gas utilities in Europe.  The privatization closing is expected to occur soon.  IFC's investment in Distrigaz Sud will support the company's 2005-2012 investment program aimed at upgrading and expanding the company's distribution network.

Project Description: The proposed transaction is to invest up to $7 million in form of senior and/or convertible loan to support the development of first specialized housing finance company in Ukraine, International Mortgage Bank (IMB, the Bank or the company).  IMB, established on January 2005, will offer variety of products ranging from housing purchase loans to housing improvement loans.  Local banks in Ukraine currently lack expertise in housing finance sector and this new specialized bank with its standardized underwriting guidelines will act as a role model in development of housing finance sector in Ukraine.
Role:
Project Development Impact:

The development impact of this project should be positive in many respects.

-  This project will provide a world class model for mortgage origination and servicing that can be used as an objective standard for the rest of the market to follow.

-  This project will stimulate a higher level of competition in the primary market which can only benefit the market as a whole.  Consumers will have more choices, lower prices and better customer service.  The lenders will bring their craft to a higher level of performance and productivity.  Finally, long term investors will realize a higher level of confidence and more readily seek mortgage products in securitized form, benefiting the development of the capital markets.

-  This project and its positive effects on other primary market participants will stimulate new home building, causing existing construction firms to offer affordable products perhaps of improved quality, while stimulating new entrants into the construction sector.  The flow-through effects of this on employment in both the professional trades and in the unskilled labour forces should be quite significant.

The increased level of homeownership engendered by all the forces described above and the increased expenditures stemming from new homeowners on improvements to their new homes will act as a catalyst in development of downstream industries and the economy of Ukraine at large.

IFC's Role

The primary mortgage market of Ukraine needs to be bolstered.  The mortgage market needs to be competitive and consumers need to have choices.  Both consumers and participating institutions will benefit from new competition.  This competition will be an antidote for the relatively low level of transparency currently found in many banking firms in Ukraine today.  IFC's most obvious role is to foster this competition.  In addition, bringing this new primary market originator and mortgage loan servicer will introduce a world class model for other participants to emulate.  IFC by virtue of its world wide experience and staff expertise is best positioned to champion and help sponsor the introduction of a world-class competitor to this emerging mortgage market.  

The proposed investment fits well within IFC's strategy and the overall Bank Group strategy for Ukraine as this will be the first attempt to establish a specialized housing finance institution in the country, with the intentions of providing alternative source of funding to purchase residential real estate and further deepening Ukraine's financial sector.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an environmental and social review category C project.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor:
The Western NIS Enterprise Fund is a not-for-profit corporation formed to promote the development of the private sector and the policies and practices conducive to such development of the Western NIS region, which consists of Ukraine, Belarus and Moldova. The United States Congress has authorized appropriations of $150 million of which, $141.7 million has been committed by the United States Agency as of September 2003.

The Fund's primary purpose is promoting the development of the private sector and the policies and practices conducive to such development of the Western NIS region, which consists of Ukraine, Belarus and Moldova. As of September 30, 2004, The Fund had total outstanding investment commitments of $53.5 million (approximately UAH 278 million) in small and medium-sized Ukrainian and Moldavian companies in variety of sectors ranging from transportation to food processing.  Under financial services portfolio, WNISEF has these following investments: Equity and debt investment of total $9 million in ProCredit Bank, equity and debt investment of total $1 million in ProCredit Bank Moldova, equity investment of $7 million in International Mortgage Bank, and equity investment of $1.6 million in Moldova Agroindbank.
Cost Nature: The proposed IFC investment consists of up to $7 million in form of senior loan.
Investment: 7.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan7.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The location of this project is Kyiv, Ukraine.

Project Description: Anhui Conch Cement (Conch or the company) is the largest cement manufacturer in China, and depending on the metric used, about the seventh largest cement manufacturer in the world.  Conch operates 11 clinker plants with a total capacity of 36.5 million tons and 23 cement grinding mills with a total capacity of 41.5 million tons.  During 2004, the company produced a total of about 32 million tons of each of cement and clinker.  IFC's proposed investment would support the company's capital expenditure program for 2005.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The review of this project consisted of appraising technical and environmental/social information submitted by the project sponsor and site visits by IFCs environmental and social specialists.  The following potential environment, health and safety and social impacts of the projects were analyzed.-  Corporate management systems for environmental performance;-  Land acquisition, compensation and resettlement;-  Quarry operations and rehabilitation;-  Environmental performance of existing clinker kilns and cement plants;-  Environmental performance of future expansions;-  Emission reduction activities for greenhouse gas (CO2); and-  Health and safety standards.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityAnhui Conch's headquarter:

Project Description: Dabur Pharma Limited (DPL or the company) is a leading Indian pharmaceuticals company.  The company is the market leader in oncology formulations and active pharmaceuticals ingredients (API or bulk drugs) in India and exports to over 30 markets across the world.  The project is to undertake a plan to leverage its manufacturing expertise and its research and development efforts over the last few years and to grow significantly by expanding its international market reach and commercializing new products.

This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. Its main focus has been the manufacture and marketing of personal care and healthcare products based on traditional Indian herbs and medicines.  After DPL's de-merger from DIL and its subsequent listing on the stock exchange on September 30, 2004, the shareholders of DPL were the same as of DIL. In December 2004/ January 2005, the sponsors sold approximately 2% of their shareholding in DPL, consequent to which the Burman family controls approximately 76% of DPL . Project Description: The project is to establish a new microfinance bank in Pakistan, Tameer Microfinance Bank (Tameer Bank or the Bank), with the involvement of Cooperative Housing Foundation (CHF), a U.S based NGO, and local sponsors. The target market would be urban self employed small businesses with combined aggregate annual household incomes of Rs 18,000 ($300 equivalent) and above. Tameer Bank is seeking a license to operate from the State Bank of Pakistan on a nationwide level. Initially, the bank would focus on the urban markets.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Financial Intermediary (FI) Type 1 microfinance project according to IFC''s environmental review procedure. Tameer Bank will be required to ensure that its operations are consistent with host country requirements and IFCs Micro finance Exclusion List. IFC will assess the Banks capability to carry out environmental reviews.  In addition, the Bank will be required to submit an annual environmental performance report.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor:
The main sponsors of the project will be Emerging Markets Consulting (Pvt) Limited (EMCPL), an investment and management services company. The initial capital of the bank will be set at $10 million and IFC expects to participate in 10% of the equity and to provide a partial local currency guarantee or loan of $3.7 million equivalent as the bank grows. EMCPL will take a 60% stake in Tameer Bank. Two local shareholders, who are businessmen, propose to subscribe to 30% of the equity.

EMPCL is to be owned 25% by CHF (Cooperative Housing Foundation), a U.S based NGO,and the remainder will be owned by a number of Pakistani shareholders, most of whom are experienced bankers. CHF has worked in nearly 100 countries worldwide. It is a pioneer in the small business finance arena and, for the past twenty years, through CHF International, it has been providing a range of array of financial services to economically disadvantaged groups..
Cost Nature: IFC's equity participation will be up to 10% of the bank's capital. The partial local currency guarantee or loan would be for up to $3.7 million.
Investment: 5.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan3.70Equity1.30* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The Bank is planning on beginning operations in Karachi and Lahore, although the business plan expects an extensive network of nationwide branches over a five year period. The Bank will be headquartered in Karachi.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Financial Intermediary (FI) Type 1 microfinance project according to IFC''s environmental review procedure. Tameer Bank will be required to ensure that its operations are consistent with host country requirements and IFCs Micro finance Exclusion List. IFC will assess the Banks capability to carry out environmental reviews.  In addition, the Bank will be required to submit an annual environmental performance report.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
