Project Description:
Eco-Power Ltd was incorporated in 1998, with the sole purpose of implementing and operating mini-hydro power projects. Since then it has commissioned 17.3 MW of installed capacity which it owns. 

Eco Power is implementing CDM projects based on run-of-river hydro generation assets that are displacing fossil fuel based generation in the Sri Lankan grid (mostly diesel and fuel oil). The total installed capacity of the projects is presently 12.6 MW (made up of 4 plants whose capacity range from 2.4-4.8 MW). The three remaining projects (3 to 9.9 MW) are in different phases of development and will enter operations between January 2006 and June 2007, at which time final installed capacity will be 31 MW. These projects when bundled together will enable Eco Power to sell up to an estimated 115,000 tonnes/year of Certified Emissions Reductions (CERs) under the Clean Development Mechanism (CDM) of the Kyoto Protocol
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The review of this project consisted of appraising the companys operational units at Hulu Ganga  I, Alupola & Hapugastenne and proposed/under construction sites at Magal Ganga, Hulu Ganga  II .The following potential environment, health and safety and social aspect of the project (s) were analyzed: environmental, social, and health and safety management systems; permitting requirements; source and volumes of water required including efforts to minimize water use; source of power and energy, including fuel storage if applicable; air emissions from existing and new sources and corrective actions needed to ensure compliance with local and World Bank Group emissions limits; ambient air quality and noise impacts on nearby receptors; recycling and treatment of process effluent and waste water; hazardous materials management; occupational health and safety programs and performance; fire and life safety and emergency response; minimization, recycling and disposal of solid and hazardous wastes; biodiversity conservation; involuntary resettlement and R&R;  corporate social responsibility efforts, including HIV/AIDS awareness; and timely reporting on environmental and social performance to IFC.Based on its review of available information regarding potential environmental impacts and proposed mitigation measures, IFC concludes that the proposed project will meet the applicable World Bank/IFC environment and social policies and the environmental, health and safety guidelines upon successful implementation of the agreed mitigation measures.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityDocuments will be located at Eco Power's head office and locally at the following addresses:

Maliboda Estate,

Hulu Ganga Town
Divisional Secretariat, 
Meegahakiula via Badulla.
Sponsor:
Eco Power is a Sri Lankan owned company which has no foreign technical collaborators and which has developed its own in house technical capabilities for designing, constructing and operating small hydro power plants.  It was until very recently controlled by Metropolitan Resource Holdings Limited (MRH), a publicly quoted Sri Lankan company which was part of the well know Sri Lankan Metropolitan Group controlled by the Ambani family of Sri Lanka. MRH's investments were in the plantation sector through Bogawantalawa Plantations Limited and in the small hydro power sector through Eco Power. In a restructuring of MRH that took place recently the plantation interests of MRH were separated from the small hydro power interests and the Eco Power share holding of MRH was transferred to a separate company, Eco Power Holdings Limited (EPH), with the shareholders in MRH receiving the same percentage of shares in EPH as they held in MRH.

At present 90% of Eco Power's shares are owned by EPH while the balance 10% is owned by company management.  EPH is a Sri Lankan company which is 40% foreign owned and 60% locally owned.  The largest individual shareholder is a Sri Lankan national with a 22.9% stake. Other large shareholders in EPH include Sri Lankan companies Ocema Investment Company (Pvt) Ltd. with 17.6% and Metrocorp (Pvt) Ltd. with 14.8%.
Cost Nature: The value of INCaF's contract or emissions reductions purchase agreement to purchase CERs is expected to be in the range of  USD 3.5  4.5 million, payable in installments on annual delivery of CERs (generated through to the end of 2012) to the CDM registry account of the Netherlands.

Project Description:
Paul Maitland International Inc. (PMI or the company) is a BVI registered company with three manufacturing facilities in Vietnam and is one of the largest furniture manufacturers in Southeast Asia with 9,000 employees worldwide, 8,900 of which are based in Vietnam.  The company manufactures high quality European style furniture under the trade names of Theodore Alexander and Atelier De La Madeleine.  

The purpose of the project is to help PMI fund additional working capital which is largely driven by the introduction of a new product line and to help the company maintain its competitive advantage which stems from its superior product design capabilities, well-established customer network, high quality production, and ability to serve customers by providing full furniture packages.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review procedure. Environmental, social and health and safety issues which may be associated with this project and which will be reviewed during project appraisal include: environmental and occupational health and safety management, wood sourcing from sustainably managed forests, air and water emissions, solid waste management and disposal, hazardous materials management, fire protection and emergency response and workplace conditions including occupational health and safety.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe environmental document Environmental Review Summary (ERS) will be available at the Company's headquarters in Ho Chi Minh City.
Sponsor:
PMI is a private company closely held by Maitland-Smith family and friends. The founder, Mr. Paul Maitland-Smith has been in the high-end furniture production business for over 50 years, most of which has been in Asia. 

The major shareholders of the company are Mr. Paul Maitland-Smith (31%), Sherrill Furniture company (a US-based company) with 25% shareholding and Mr. David Pemberton (17%).  28 other individuals own the rest of the shares, none of whose holding exceeds 7%.
Cost Nature: The total transaction is estimated at $22 million project, which involves predominantly the expansion of permanent working capital and the refinancing of short-term debt. A small component (9% of project cost) of the funding would be directed towards the installation of an Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) and MIS system, the establishment of warehouses and the development of an acacia plantation. IFC's proposed investment is $8 million in the form of an A Loan.
Investment: 8.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan8.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location:
PMI has three sites in Vietnam including 2 manufacturing facilities, and a plant with a saw-mill, dry kiln facility and a foundry.  The company also has approximately 600 hectares of acacia plantation.  

The IFC investment will be directed towards activities at the two manufacturing facilities in Ho Chi Minh City  
-  Theodore Alexander HCM Ltd. (TAHL), a 334,000 sq. feet, 4-storey manufacturing facility constructed in the principal export processing zone and 
-  Saigon Fine Furniture (SFF) is a 430,000 sq. feet manufacturing facility situated in Linh Trung Export Processing Zone (EPZ) II.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review procedure. Environmental, social and health and safety issues which may be associated with this project and which will be reviewed during project appraisal include: environmental and occupational health and safety management, wood sourcing from sustainably managed forests, air and water emissions, solid waste management and disposal, hazardous materials management, fire protection and emergency response and workplace conditions including occupational health and safety.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe environmental document Environmental Review Summary (ERS) will be available at the Company's headquarters in Ho Chi Minh City.

Project Description:
First International Merchant Bank (FIMBank or the bank), based in Malta, is a provider of trade related financial services to clients in emerging markets.   FIMBank was established in 1994 and has grown its trade finance operations steadily since inception.  FIMBank plans to continue its global expansion by establish factoring/ forfaiting joint ventures in five select markets  Argentina, Brazil, UAE, China and Russia  over the next 2-3 years (the project).  FIMBank has requested IFC to consider: 
- a subordinated long term convertible loan in an amount up to ten million United States Dollars to be utilized by the bank to expand its operations by establishing joint-venture factoring and forfaiting companies in IFC member countries; and
- a participation by the bank in IFC's global trade facility for an amount up to $5 million.   

Malta is currently a member of IBRD and the IMF but not IFC.   In February 2005, the Government of Malta formally notified IFC of its intention to apply for membership.  The World Bank Corporate Secretariat in charge of membership has responded to the Maltese authorities with all the supporting documents necessary for IFC membership.  IFC will seek Board approval for the project after Malta has become a shareholder of the Corporation.
Environmental Social Issues: Based on the available information, this is a Category C project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  FIMBank will be required to appoint a staff member responsible for environmental issues who will participate in IFC''s environmental training workshop.  FIMBank will be required to review potential commitments to ensure that the underlying business does not involve any activity on IFC''s Exclusion List.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor:
Sponsors:
FIMBank was established by Kuwaiti Interests for Financial Investments (KIFFI) together with a group of institutional investors.  FIMBank is registered under the laws of the Republic of Malta and was granted its banking license in November 1994.  The license enables FIMBank also to conduct full banking activities in all currencies, except the Maltese Lira.  The bank is supervised by the Maltese Financial Services Authority (MFSA).   As of November 2004, Fitch Ratings assigned FIMBank a long-term FCY rating of BB with a stable outlook.   As of December 2004, FIMBank's shareholders are as follows:

Project Description: The project aims to provide a loan to Investments and Mortgages Bank (Kenya) Limited (I&M or the bank) of up to $5 million to support the banks growing SME client base and export-oriented segment in Kenya. The proposed loan will have a six year maturity, with a one-year grace period.  IFC will also consider providing I&M with equity of up to $2 million to shore up the banks core capital.The proceeds from the loan will enable I&M to better meet increasing demand from its SME client base.  I&M has also effectively targeted medium-sized corporate customers in the export segment. The bank has successfully grown this market niche, but is now faced with growth constraints due to a lack of suitably tenured, hard currency financing. The project would further foster competition in the local credit market, thus reducing costs for the private sector.  IFC financing will underscore the banks regional expansion strategy.  I&M has requested to participate in IFCs Global Trade Finance Program as an L/C issuer.  The trade facility will enable I&M to increase its limits with confirming banks based on an IFC guarantee. IFCs proposed exposure to I&M under the trade facility would be up to $5 million, with the final exposure to be maintained within policy determined levels.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an FI Type 1 project. I&M will be required to develop an environmental management system.  The bank must require that investments under relevant operations meet host country environmental, health and safety requirements.  IFC will assess the banks capacity for environmental review and will provide training as necessary.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: I&M was established as a non-bank financial institution in 1980, and received a commercial banking license in 1996.  The principal shareholders are the SBR Shah family and related parties, which control 83% of the Bank.  Other shareholders include City Trust, a listed investment company on the Nairobi Stock Exchange, and former shareholders of Biashara Bank, which was acquired by I&M in 2003.
Cost Nature: The project is to provide a senior term loan to I&M Bank of up to $5.0 million with a maturity of up to six years including a one year grace period.  IFC will also consider providing equity of up to $2 million. I&M has requested to participate in IFCs Global Trade Finance Program as an L/C issuer.  IFC will consider providing a trade line under this program of up to $5 million, with the final exposure to be maintained within policy determined levels.
Investment: 5.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan5.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: I&M is headquartered in Nairobi, Kenya. The bank has eight branches, six located in Nairobi, and two others located in Mombasa and Kisumu.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is an FI Type 1 project. I&M will be required to develop an environmental management system.  The bank must require that investments under relevant operations meet host country environmental, health and safety requirements.  IFC will assess the banks capacity for environmental review and will provide training as necessary.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community

Project Description:
The proposed project is the creation of an investment company named Solidus (the company) which will make quasi-equity type investments in microfinance institutions in the Latin America and the Caribbean region (LAC).  The IFC investment will be an equity investment of up to $3 million. Other co-investors are expected to be financial institutions like IDB, Norfund, Finnfund, KfW and Desjardins.  The management company will be Cyrano Management, a fund management company experienced in debt investments in microfinance institutions (MFIs) in LAC and other regions.  Cyrano Management will also be a shareholder of the company with a small equity stake. 

The purpose of the project is to fill in a gap for quasi-equity type funding which is expected not only to grow the capital base of the MFIs but also to diversify and improve their overall capital structure.  Through this investment IFC would encourage financing to commercial MFIs, thus supporting the development and growth of microfinance sector in LAC.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an environmental and social category FI Type 1 microfinance project. Solidus will be required to establish and maintain an environmental management system to ensure that relevant lending activities of its borrowers are consistent with IFCs Microfinance Exclusion List and in compliance with the applicable local laws.  Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: The shareholders of Solidus at the first closing are expected to IDB, IFC, Norfund, Finnfund, KfW, Desjardins, Cordaid and Cyrano Management.
Cost Nature: The proposed IFC investment is equity of $3 million of a total initial project size of $15.3 million.

Company Name: KHAI VY CORPORATION AND DUYEN HAI CORPORATION
Project Description:
Khai Vy Corporation (Khai Vy) and Duyen Hai Corporation (Duyen Hai)  known collectively as KVC or the group  together produce and export outdoor and indoor furniture to the Asian, European and North American markets and employ 6,200 workers in four operating sites across Vietnam.  Total export market for the group is split 70% to European market, 25% to U.S. market and 5% to Asia.  The group has its main factory in Ho Chi Minh City and three others are located in Binh Dinh Province.  

By investing in this project, IFC will be providing longer-term financing to help a low cost Vietnamese company maintain its competitive edge while upgrading its operations, and improving environmental, social and corporate governance practices.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review procedure. Environmental, social and health and safety issues which may be associated with this project and which will be reviewed during project appraisal include: environmental and occupational health and safety management, employment conditions, wood sourcing from sustainable managed forests, air and water emissions, solid waste management and disposal, hazardous materials management, fire protection and emergency response and workplace conditions including occupational health and safety.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe environmental document Environmental Review Summary (ERS) will be available at the company's headquarters in Ho Chi Minh City. (See the company's address below).
Sponsor: Mr. Doan Van Trang, the Chairman, founded the group in 1995.  Prior to establishing Khai Vy, Mr. Trang worked in the local wood sector for nearly 17 years.  Mr. Trang and his wife have majority ownership of the group with 90% of Khai Vy (Mr. Trang's brother-in-law owns the remaining 10%) and 100% of Duyen Hai.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $11.5 million project, which involves predominantly the expansion of permanent working capital. A small component (12% of project cost) of the funding would be directed towards additional capital expenditure.  IFC's proposed investment is $6 million in the form of an A Loan.
Investment: 6.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan6.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: KVC has four operating sites across Vietnam.  The main site, Khai Vy Factory, is based in Ho Chi Minh City and the remaining three - Duyen Hai 1 Wood Processing Factory, Duyen Hai 2 Wood Processing Factory and Duyen Hai 3 Wood Processing Factory are located in Binh Dinh Province. The Binh Dinh Province is a predominantly rural and less developed province in Central Vietnam with vast forest resources.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review procedure. Environmental, social and health and safety issues which may be associated with this project and which will be reviewed during project appraisal include: environmental and occupational health and safety management, employment conditions, wood sourcing from sustainable managed forests, air and water emissions, solid waste management and disposal, hazardous materials management, fire protection and emergency response and workplace conditions including occupational health and safety.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe environmental document Environmental Review Summary (ERS) will be available at the company's headquarters in Ho Chi Minh City. (See the company's address below).

Project Description:
Ramenka (or the company), a Russian limited liability company, was founded in 1997.  Operating under the name Ramstore, Ramenka conducts two major types of business operations: 

-  retail sales of food and non-food products and 
-  lease of retail space in the company-owned hypermarket stores to other businesses.

Ramenka started its business in Moscow with one hypermarket, which opened in 1997.  Now, the company operates a total of 6 hypermarkets and 32 supermarkets with a net retail area of 92,000 sqm and a net leasable area of 61,000 sqm.

To respond to the booming market demand for quality retail outlets and rental space in Russia, Ramenka is planning to build two additional supermarkets with attached shopping malls located in the Moscow Region (Orekhovo-Zuyevo and Reutov) and three additional hypermarkets with attached malls in Moscow, St.Petersburg and Togliatti.  The total retail area and rental area of the project stores will be 19,435 sqm and 55,700 sqm, respectively.
Environmental Social Issues: Main environmental, health and safety issues of the project are:  site selection and site environmental conditions; land acquisition, rights and use, air emissions; liquid and solid waste treatment and disposal including sewage collection; use of appropriate refrigerants; power and water supply; fire protection and life safety; emergency response; general worker health and safety; and environmental, health and safety management.  As this is the fourth investment with Ramenka, IFC staff has engaged in a constructive dialogue with the company on overall environmental management since 2000.  The company has presented plans to address and mitigate impacts, and it is anticipated that the proposed project will comply with applicable Russian Federation laws and regulations and World Bank Group/IFC requirements.Lease rights are acquired through a willing seller/willing buyer relationship.  Space for some existing supermarket stores is leased in shopping centers owned by third parties.  At all sites the local utility company will provide potable water.  Electricity will be drawn from the grid.  At all sites employee- and customer-generated sanitary sewage discharged to the municipal sewage system with permission from the authorities.  Most of the waste generated by the stores will be packaging-related material and will be recycled.  Operational environmental issues are relatively well managed.  Ramstore design and lay out of their retail outlets to conform to Russian fire safety standards, which are compatible with international standards.  Each store has either a sprinkler system with full coverage of the sales area or clearly marked fire hydrant including detailed fire and emergency instructions.  A dedicated staff member is in charge of all licenses, safety approvals and permitting documentation.  In order to properly manage environmental the sponsor has developed an Environmental Management System (EMS) with full implementation taking place in the second quarter of 2005.  During the appraisal IFC provided advice on how to best implement the EMS, which has just received ISO 14001 certification.  An independent review of the life and fire safety systems and emergency plans for all the stores will take place as a condition of disbursement.  In addition IFC has recommended Ramenka to prepare a comprehensive Security, Life and Fire Safety Manual.In addition, IFC has recommended to Ramenka to review its corporate environmental, health and safety structure to reflect key issues that need to be addressed as well as the additional demand linked with the companys growth.  Better integration of EHS issues at the corporate management level as well as in store operations is needed.  Finally Ramenka has developed positive relationships with local communities and is supporting municipal activities on life safety prevention and public health improvement.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityAnnouncements in the local press (Moscow oblast, Moscow city, St Petersburg and Togliatti) will inform all stakeholders about the disclosure of the ERS at Ramstore shops. The ERS will be posted in Russian and English in all Ramstores sites.  Originals of all environmental and safety documents are being kept mostly in stores, and rarely in central office depending on the type of the documents.
Sponsor:
Ramenka is 50% owned by Migros Turk Ticaret Anonim Sirketi (Migros), the largest and the oldest supermarket chain in Turkey with international operations in Azerbaijan, Bulgaria, Kazakhstan and Russia.  48.94% of Migros' shares are traded at the Istanbul Stock Exchange.  The remaining shares are controlled by the Koc Group, one of Turkey's leading industrial conglomerates.

The remaining 50% of the company are owned by Enka Insaat ve Sanayi Anonim Sirketi (Enka) through its European subsidiaries:

-  Enka Holding Investment S.A. (38.3%); and 
-  EnTrade GmbH (11.7%).  

Enka is a Turkey-based international conglomerate active in construction, power, management of real estate properties and retail.  Enka is active in Algeria, Azerbaijan, Croatia, Germany, Kazakhstan, Lybia, the Netherlands, Russia and Turkey.  13.1% of Enka's shares are traded at the Istanbul stock exchange.  The remaining shares are held privately.
Cost Nature: The estimated project cost is $119 million.  IFC is considering an A loan of $40 million to the company.  The financial plan also includes subordinated loans and cash generation.
Investment: 40.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan40.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative

The project consists of 2 supermarket/malls located in Moscow oblasts and 3 hypermarket/malls in Moscow, St. Petersburg and Togliatti.

Udelny Park in St. Petersburg is going to be located on a 2.0 ha land plot.  Orehokhovo-Zuyevo in Moscow oblast is located on the eastern side of the city of Moscow with a land plot of 2.0 ha. Reutov in Moscow oblast is also located on the eastern side of the city of Moscow with a land plot of 1.5 ha. Butova is located in the southern part of Moscow with a land plot of 2.9 ha. Togliatti located in Samara oblast, Southern Russia has the biggest land plot in the project with 5.2 ha.

Project Description:
TEB is a medium size bank having 93 branches and employing over 2,200 people. The Bank is a conservatively run, high quality bank with total assets of $2.67 billion equivalent and shareholders' equity of $295 million equivalent as of end December 2004. In February 2005 BNPP and Colakoglu family agreed to have 50% ownership in TEB Mali that is 84% owner of TEB. Following the strategic investor coming in, TEB's strategy will be focused on expanding its retail operations and increasing its SME lending operations.

TEB is an existing client and this is IFC's fourth project with the Bank. IFC's investment aims to support Tier 2 capital of the Bank through a subordinated loan of up to $50 million.
Environmental Social Issues: IFC will coordinate with the company to:-  review the existing IFC approved Environmental Management System (EMS) and agree on areas for improvement based on past experiences;-  review the need for additional training and capacity building for company staff, particularly credit officers, in the area of Environmental Risk Management to ensure the efficient implementation of the EMS;-  ensure implementation of the EMS results in all subprojects complying with Turkish environmental, health and safety requirements as well as appropriate IFC requirements;-  ensure the company provides required annual environmental performance reports to IFC on compliance with the EMS.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor:
The project sponsor is TEB Mali, the financial holding company, that owns 84% of TEB, that used to be owned privately by members of Colakoglu family and is now owned equally by the Colakoglu Group and BNP Paribas (50% stake each) since February 2005.

The Colakoglu Group has operations in production of steel, production of containers, trading, shipping, power generation and banking.  Like TEB itself, the Colakoglu Group has a reputation of conservative management and is known for treading cautiously into new business areas and for having low leverage.  

16% of the Bank's shares are publicly traded in Istanbul Stock Exchange since February 2000.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $50 million. The proposed IFC investment is up to $50 million C loan to be qualified as Tier 2 capital of TEB.
Investment: 50.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan50.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: TEB is headquartered in Istanbul, Turkey with 92 branches and an off shore branch in Bahrain. Throughout its relatively wide branch network investments can be made within a wide geographical area.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: IFC will coordinate with the company to:-  review the existing IFC approved Environmental Management System (EMS) and agree on areas for improvement based on past experiences;-  review the need for additional training and capacity building for company staff, particularly credit officers, in the area of Environmental Risk Management to ensure the efficient implementation of the EMS;-  ensure implementation of the EMS results in all subprojects complying with Turkish environmental, health and safety requirements as well as appropriate IFC requirements;-  ensure the company provides required annual environmental performance reports to IFC on compliance with the EMS.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Name: Financiera Educativa de Mexico S.A. de C.V.
Company Name: FINANCIERA EDUCATIVA DE MEXICO, S.A. DE C.V.
Project Description: The project is to support the establishment of Financiera Educativa de Mexico S.A. de C.V. (FINEM or the company), a new specialized non-bank financial institution that will be established as a sociedad financiera de objeto limitado (SOFOL) and focus on financing the Mexican education sector. FINEMs core business will be to provide peso denominated term loans to eligible Mexican privately-owned schools and higher education institutions, to help fund their expansion and infrastructure modernization programs. In addition, FINEM will provide advisory services or technical assistance in a wide range of managerial or technical disciplines, to help qualifying clients reinforce the quality of their management and become more viable and competitive firms. FINEM will initially target upper-secondary and higher education institutions and gradually extend its services across all segments of the education market.The project aims to address the currently large gap between demand and supply of long-term financing for private education institutions in Mexico, and to contribute to improving the quality of infrastructure, education and management in the private education sector through investments and technical assistance.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category FI Type 2 project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  The company will be required to establish an environmental and social management system to ensure that investments comply with applicable host country environmental laws and regulations as well as applicable World Bank Group environmental, health and safety policies and guidelines;  designate appropriate individuals to have responsibility for environmental and social issues;  submit to IFC an environmental management plan;  obtain clearance from IFC for any category A investment by the company; and submit to IFC annual environmental performance reports.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The project sponsor is Consorcio Pro-Desarollo S.A. de C.V.., a private Mexican company that has established business interests in the real estate, construction, agribusiness, biotechnology and security areas.  Consorcio Pro-Desarollo S.A. de C.V..will also be FINEMs majority shareholder, owing 81% of its share capital. The remaining 19% will be held by IFC.
Cost Nature: The project corresponds to the initial phase of establishment of FINEM, and covers the first two years of operation, by the end of which the companys portfolio is expected to reach $20 million equivalent. During this period, the company intends to finance high schools and universities that will primarily be located in the Mexico City metropolitan area. The second phase, which is beyond the scope of the project, will scale up the Companys portfolio and expand its activities into other cities of Mexico.The proposed IFC investment consists of: -  an equity investment for up to $680,000, which would represent approximately 19% of the companys aggregate share capital, and -  a Mexican peso denominated loan facility of up to the equivalent of $15 million.  The IFC loan will finance the first two years of operations of the company.
Investment: 15.77 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan15.08Equity0.69* These investment figures are indicative
Location: FINEM is headquartered in Mexico City and does not plan to operate branches or local representation offices outside Mexico City at this stage.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category FI Type 2 project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  The company will be required to establish an environmental and social management system to ensure that investments comply with applicable host country environmental laws and regulations as well as applicable World Bank Group environmental, health and safety policies and guidelines;  designate appropriate individuals to have responsibility for environmental and social issues;  submit to IFC an environmental management plan;  obtain clearance from IFC for any category A investment by the company; and submit to IFC annual environmental performance reports.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community

Project Description: Text Updated as of May 28, 2005: IFC, in 2005, committed multiple investments totaling $15 million in the Ramky Group (Group) which consisted of investments in Ramky Enviro Engineers Limited (REEL), a company handling the Groups waste management business, to part-finance the establishment of a number of waste management facilities and also investments in Ramky Infrastructure Limited (RIL), the engineering, procurement and construction (EPC) arm of the Group for various infrastructure sectors. Subsequently, the committed investment in REEL was cancelled and IFC proceeded with only a part of the committed investment in RIL ($3 million), though the nature of this investment in RIL has also been significantly modified.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The review of this project consisted of appraising technical and environmental/social information submitted by RIL, field visits by IFC staff, and an IFC-sponsored independent technical and environmental performance review of RILs existing and proposed operations.  The following potential environment, health and safety and social impacts of the projects were analyzed and remain relevant in the context of remaining investment.-  Environmental management systems;-  Siting, environmental assessment, and licensing;-  Emergency preparedness and response;-  Employee health and safety; and-  Community engagement and impacts.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The founder and sponsor of the Group is Mr. Ayodhya Rami Reddy (ARR or the sponsor).  ARR is also the Chairman of the Company and has been on the Board since its incorporation. He holds a Bachelors degree in civil engineering from Karnataka University and a Masters degree in civil engineering from Osmania University. He has 23 years of experience in the field of environmental services, civil works, bio-medical waste and hazardous waste management. He has worked for various water, waste water and engineering projects, notably with Gannon Dunkerly & Co., Reliance Industries Ltd. during the years 1984 to 1988 and has also worked for various projects on Turnkey EPC basis till 1995. The sponsor has an 84% stake in RIL.
Cost Nature: IFC has invested $3 million in the common equity of RIL.

The review of this project consisted of appraising technical and environmental/social information submitted by RIL, field visits by IFC staff, and an IFC-sponsored independent technical and environmental performance review of RILs existing and proposed operations.  The following potential environment, health and safety and social impacts of the projects were analyzed and remain relevant in the context of remaining investment.-  Environmental management systems;-  Siting, environmental assessment, and licensing;-  Emergency preparedness and response;-  Employee health and safety; and-  Community engagement and impacts.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community

Project Description: The project involves the extension of a convertible loan of up to US$1.2 million to Micro Credit Agency Bai Tushum Financial Fund (Bai Tushum), one of Kyrgyzstan's leading licensed micro lending institutions.  The purpose of the investment is to support the establishment of a regulated deposit taking microfinance company.  IFC would seek an option to convert part of the loan into equity equivalent to 15% of the equity of the new regulated deposit taking institution to be established by Bai Tushum. At December 31, 2004, Bai Tushum had total assets of US$4.8 million equivalent, including a loan portfolio of US$3.3 million equivalent.  Total equity was US$3.6 million equivalent at December 31, 2004.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an FI Type 1 project.  Bai Tushum must require that investments under relevant operations meet host country environmental, health and safety requirements and be consistent with IFCs microfinance exclusion list.  IFC will assess Bai Tushums capacity for environmental review.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: The main sponsor is Bai Tushum, which is dedicated to the social and economic development of both rural and urban sectors of the Kyrgyz Republic through providing sustainable financial services to micro and small private entrepreneurs.

Company Name: Kyrgyz Investment and Credit Bank CJSC
Project Description: The project consists of a credit line facility of up to $2.5 million to Kyrgyz Investment and Credit Bank (KICB, the bank or the company), an IFC existing portfolio commercial bank specialized in small- and medium-sized (SME) enterprise finance. KICB is looking to raise debt financing to meet loan demands from eligible clients in the Kyrgyz Republic. The facility would broaden the Bank's funding base, and support the growth of the Bank and the financing of SMEs. As of end 2004, KICB had total assets of $21.1 million, shareholders' equity of $6.9 million, and net income of $423 thousands.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category FI Type 1 project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure. KICB follows EBRDs guidelines in appraising subprojects for environmental risks and in reviewing portfolio subprojects; and, all KICB staff involved in evaluating credit proposals have attended environmental risk management workshop in 2003 under an EBRD-sponsored technical assistance program.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: The project sponsor is KICB. Established in August 2001, KICB is a licensed commercial bank, based in Bishkek, Kyrgyzstan. The Bank is a full-service, deposit-taking institution regulated by the National Bank of Kyrgyz Republic, NBKR, and licensed to operate nationally. KICB's founders and shareholders include: the Aga Khan Fund for Economic Development ('AKFED') (30.0%); IFC (20.0%); DEG (20.0%); EBRD (20.0%); and the Kyrgyz State Property Committee (SPC) (10.0%). Additionally, because it provided concessional loans to the Kyrgyz government for the purchase of shares in the Bank and for a credit line facility to the Bank, KfW is a co-founder but not a shareholder.
Cost Nature: IFC's proposed investment is a long-term loan of $2.5 million.
Investment: 2.50 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan2.50Equity* These investment figures are indicative

Project Description:
The project is to help Manzanillo International Terminal - Panama S.A. (MIT or the company) finance its capital expenditure program through 2008.  MIT operates the Manzanillo container terminal adjacent to the Colon Free Trade Zone on the Atlantic side of the Panama Canal under a concession agreement. The expansion program will more than double the company's capacity and allow it to service projected container traffic through 2017.  

MIT is a major success story for privatization in the port sector.  Prior to MIT's entry as a container terminal in 1995, the former US seaplane base was utilized as a storage facility for handling about 61,000 cars for distribution in Panama and Latin America. MIT's investment and management transformed the facility into a key transshipment hub for shipping lines servicing the Asia-East Coast North America and Asia-East Coast South America shipping routes. MIT's efficient operation allows shipping lines to concentrate their calls at Manzanillo and use smaller, less expensive feeder vessels to transport cargo from Manzanillo to their final destinations. The resulting hub-and-spoke system provides greater market coverage and lower transportation costs, critical components to increasing trading activity.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category B project. Key issues to be reviewed during appraisal include: maintenance dredging and dredge spoil disposal; stormwater management; oil/hazardous materials storage and handling; liquid, solid and hazardous waste disposal (including waste oils and other maintenance wastes); ship support operations (such as sewage and bilge waste effluent disposal, and fueling services); handling and storage of dangerous cargoes; emergency response planning and preparedness; employee health and safety (including training); and EHS organization and management. This is IFCs third project with MIT and MIT has been very responsive to environmental and social issues.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe environmental documentation will be made available at the Manzanillo International Terminal, Calle Curtin, Coco Solo Norte, Colon
Sponsor: MIT is majority-owned by Carrix, Inc., the parent company of SSA Marine, Rail Management Services (RMS), and Tideworks Technology. SSA Marine is the world's largest privately held container terminal operator and cargo handling company with 11 container terminals and about 60 non-container port operations worldwide. RMS operates 45 rail terminals across the United States and Tideworks Technology provides software for marine terminals.
Cost Nature: IFC is expected to provide an A loan of up to $50 million for its own account.
Investment: 50.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan50.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The Manzanillo International Terminal is located at the Atlantic entrance of the Panama Canal next to the Colon Free Trade Zone.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category B project. Key issues to be reviewed during appraisal include: maintenance dredging and dredge spoil disposal; stormwater management; oil/hazardous materials storage and handling; liquid, solid and hazardous waste disposal (including waste oils and other maintenance wastes); ship support operations (such as sewage and bilge waste effluent disposal, and fueling services); handling and storage of dangerous cargoes; emergency response planning and preparedness; employee health and safety (including training); and EHS organization and management. This is IFCs third project with MIT and MIT has been very responsive to environmental and social issues.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe environmental documentation will be made available at the Manzanillo International Terminal, Calle Curtin, Coco Solo Norte, Colon

Project Description:
The proposed investment would enable HVB Bank Serbia and Montenegro (HVB, the bank or the company) to address its long-term funding needs including the areas of mortgages and SMEs.  Current term loans in the Serbian market have typical tenures of three to four years.  The Bank therefore has approached IFC for funding with longer tenor to be able to expand its long-term lending.  

HVB Bank Serbia and Montenegro a.d. was established in 2001.  The Bank is a member of the HVB Group through Bank Austria Creditanstalt (BA-CA).  BA-CA owns 99% of the shareholding of the Bank.  It is being geared by BA-CA to become a universal bank offering a variety of products. As of December 2004, it had total assets of EUR202 million, shareholders' equity of EUR21 million, and total liabilities of EUR181 million of which deposits totaled EUR133 million.  For the year 2004 its ROAE and ROAA were 23% and 2.5% respectively.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category FI type 1 project according to IFC''s Environmental and Social Review Procedure.  HVB will be required to designate individuals to have responsibility for environmental issues and who will attend environmental training; submit to IFC an environmental management plan; establish an environmental management system to ensure that activities financed under relevant operations are consistent with applicable environmental, health and safety standards of Serbia and IFC''s microfinance exclusion list;  and submit to IFC annual environmental performance reports.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: The Sponsor, Bank Austria Creditanstalt, is a member of HVB Group, Germany.  HVB is the second-largest banking group in Germany, with the majority of its shares publicly traded. It is rated A- by S&P.  HVB offers a full range of banking services to retail and corporate customers and has a network of some 2,100 branches of which around 950 are located in Germany and 400 in Austria.  As of December 2004, HVB's total assets were EUR467 billion and shareholders' equity was EUR11.5 billion.
Cost Nature: The proposed IFC investment is a senior loan of up to EUR30 million for IFC's own account.
Investment: 38.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan38.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Belgrade, Serbia and Montenegro

HVB will be required to designate individuals to have responsibility for environmental issues and who will attend environmental training; submit to IFC an environmental management plan; establish an environmental management system to ensure that activities financed under relevant operations are consistent with applicable environmental, health and safety standards of Serbia and IFC''s microfinance exclusion list;  and submit to IFC annual environmental performance reports.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Description:
The project entails financing of up to $1.3 million from:

- the Environmental Business Finance Program (EBFP), a GEF funded, IFC managed program; and, 
- other IFC sources, to Environmental Quality International (EQI) for the implementation of a comprehensive sustainable development program in the Siwa Oasis region.  

Financing will be in the form of loans and technical assistance grants.

The project will primarily address the objectives of the Global Environment Facility (GEF) Operational Policies #1 (Arid and Semi-Arid Zone Ecosystems), through four specific initiatives including:  sustainable agriculture, eco-tourism, women's artisanship and renewable energy.  The project will directly promote entrepreneurialism and job creation through sustainable measures among Siwa's indigenous population while helping to maintain the delicate environmental balance of one of Egypt's most pristine locations.  Without immediate intervention, Siwa's unique ecosystem is in danger of becoming extinct as the population takes on more current and less environmentally friendly methods of living.

Founded in 1981, EQI is a Partnership Company, incorporated in Egypt.  It has approximately 200 employees and specializes in Environment and Natural Resources, Policy and Governance, and Enterprise Development and Microfinance.  EQI has major projects implemented across the Middle East and North Africa; and affiliate companies in both the United States and United Kingdom.
Environmental Social Issues: The social and environmental issues which will be monitored in association with each of the four components of this project are: - Shali Lodge Extension:  changes in land use, air emissions, water use, wastewater disposal, energy use, noise, aesthetics, and utilities; - Workshops for Native Artisanship: changes in land use, air emissions, water use, environmental health, safety of employees, aesthetics, and energy use; - Sustainable Agriculture: changes in land use, air emissions, environmental health; safety of farmers (including exposure to pesticides), and water use; - Biogas Energy Generation:  changes in land use, air emissions, liquid effluent disposal, and environmental health and safety.  Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityEQI carried out an environmental and social impact assessment (ESIA) of the issues outlined above.  The ESIA will be available at the Shali Lodge, Siwa, Egypt and by contacting EQI at the address below.
Sponsor: EQI is an Egyptian family owned company.  Its primary shareholders are: Mounir Neamatalla (50%) (President), Laila Neamatalla (25%), and Mona Nimatallah (25%).
Location: The project will take place in the Siwa Oasis region of Egypt.  Siwa represents one of the last pristine desert environments in the world. The indigenous people of Siwa possess a rich indigenous knowledge that has supported the community in a sustainable lifestyle for centuries.  Siwa's unique ecosystem is located in a depression below sea level surrounded by desert.  The oasis occupies a surface of approximately 1125 km2 and is situated in a remote location 800 km from Cairo, 300 km southwest of the Mediterranean port city of Mersa Matruh, and 70 km east of the Libyan border.  Made up of the town of Siwa, several scattered villages, 20,000 inhabitants and some 230 natural freshwater springs, the oasis supports a rich cultural and biological diversity.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: The social and environmental issues which will be monitored in association with each of the four components of this project are: - Shali Lodge Extension:  changes in land use, air emissions, water use, wastewater disposal, energy use, noise, aesthetics, and utilities; - Workshops for Native Artisanship: changes in land use, air emissions, water use, environmental health, safety of employees, aesthetics, and energy use; - Sustainable Agriculture: changes in land use, air emissions, environmental health; safety of farmers (including exposure to pesticides), and water use; - Biogas Energy Generation:  changes in land use, air emissions, liquid effluent disposal, and environmental health and safety.  Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityEQI carried out an environmental and social impact assessment (ESIA) of the issues outlined above.  The ESIA will be available at the Shali Lodge, Siwa, Egypt and by contacting EQI at the address below.

Project Description: The project involves the extension of a senior credit line of up to $3 million to Microfinance Bank of Azerbaijan (MFBA or the Bank). IFCs current exposure to MFBA is a $1.75 million equity investment, representing 25.55% of the share capital. The proposed loan is part of a larger credit envelope of up to $9 million in which two additional shareholders in MFBA, Kreditanstalt Fur Wiederaufbau (KfW) and the Black Sea Trade and Development Bank (BSTDB), will participate. The purpose of the credit line is to support MFBAs rapid loan portfolio growth, which is critical to the further development and sustained profitability of the Bank.MFBA started operations in October 2002 as a specialized provider of credit and financial services to individual entrepreneurs, and small and micro enterprises (SMEs) across Azerbaijan. The Bank started operations in Baku with a headquarters office, and has since opened four branch offices in Baku (Airport market, Xalqlar Dostlugu and 20th January area) and Sumgait. The Bank is expected to open a fifth branch office in Ganja in May 2005.To date, MFBA has served 4,500 micro and small enterprise clients with 10,500 credit lines totaling over $23 million. Loan portfolio has increased by 73 percent in 2004 to $7.2 million as of December 31, 2004 and $8.8 million by the end of March 2005. The Bank projects its loan portfolio to increase to $15.1 million by the end of 2005. MFBA requires additional funds to expand its growing loan portfolio.MFBA requires additional funds to expand its growing loan portfolio, which is expected to double to $15 million by the end of 2005. Because MFBA is only now able to accept deposits and the inter-bank market in Azerbaijan remains underdeveloped, MFBA must rely primarily on IFI financing until it can build up its deposit base. In February 2005, the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) finished disbursing a $5 million credit line which is expected to be fully utilized by end May 2005. The other shareholders, KfW and BSTDB, are planning on providing an additional $3 million each also in the first half of 2005.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category FI type 1 project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure. As a result of an earlier IFC investment in MFBA, the Bank implemented an environmental management system (EMS) satisfactory to IFC, including environmental training of staff, compliance with Azeri environmental, health and safety standards and IFC''s Microfinance Exclusion List, and the provision of annual environmental performance reports (AEPRs) to IFC. For the duration of IFC''s new investment, MFBA will be required to maintain its EMS and continue to provide AEPRs, and any new environmental officers will be required to participate in environmental management training conducted or approved by IFC.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The shareholders of MFBA are: IFC (25.55%), BSTDB (25.55%), KfW (24.96%), EBRD (18.25%), and LFS Financial Systems GmbH (5.69%).LFS Financial Services (LFS) is the projects technical partner in addition to being a shareholder. This is the first project in which IFC has invested with LFS, which came highly recommended by MFBAs co-investors, EBRD and KfW. Its track record encompasses managing SME credit lines in Azerbaijan (KfW German-Azerbaijan Fund), loan programs in Bosnia (EU housing refurbishment loans) and Uzbekistan (EBRD-Japan Small Business Fund), and a micro bank in Mozambique (GTZ Sociedade de Credito). LFS is engaged as the professional manager under a Management Services Contract financed by an EBRD Technical Assistance Program.
Cost Nature: Total project cost is estimated at $9 million. The proposed IFC Investment would be a $3 million A loan for IFCs own account.
Investment: 3.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan3.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The Bank started operations in Baku, Azerbaijan with a headquarters office and has since opened four branch offices in Baku (Airport market, Xalqlar Dostlugu and 20th January area) and Sumgait. The Bank is expected to open a fifth branch office in Ganja in May 2005.

Project Description: The project is a subordinated IFC loan of up to $30 million to Banco Industrial S.A. (BI, the company or the leading Guatemalan bank). The proposed investment in BI's Tier-II regulatory capital would enable BI to play a leading role in the ongoing consolidation of the domestic banking sector by strengthening BI's capital base. BI's strong market position enables it to take advantage of expansion opportunities arising from Guatemala's financial sector reform which is strongly supported by the World Bank Group.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an FI Type 1 project. BI will be required to maintain an environmental and social management system (EMS) to ensure that its lending activities comply with the applicable environmental and social requirements of Guatemala.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: The project sponsor is BI, with consolidated total assets of $2.54 billion and equity of $189 million as of December 31, 2004. It represents 20% of the banking system's total assets and has a 20% market share in terms of deposits. BI is owned by approximately 1,400 Guatemalan shareholders, with none of them holding more than a 5% stake. BI started operations in 1968. During the first 25 years of operations it focused on servicing large domestic and multinational corporations operating in Guatemala. BI has expanded toward small and medium size companies and individual clients in the course of the past 10 years. It has also launched a successful program for processing remittances mainly from Guatemalans in the United States to their relatives back in Guatemala.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $30 million. The proposed IFC investment is a C loan of up to $30 million for IFC's own account.
Investment: 30.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan30.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: BI is headquartered in Guatemala City and has a network of more than 1,175 branches, offices and ATMs nationwide which would benefit from the investment.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is an FI Type 1 project. BI will be required to maintain an environmental and social management system (EMS) to ensure that its lending activities comply with the applicable environmental and social requirements of Guatemala.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Description: The Municipality of Buffalo City (MBC) has a capital expenditure program over the next three years of $151 million. A significant portion of these investments are in the area of high priority infrastructure. The purpose of the project is to provide support to the city in financing its capital investment plans and optimizing its borrowing structure through the provision of a partial credit guarantee.
Environmental Social Issues: MBC is committed to adopting and implementing the principles and underlying approaches to sustainable development. Objectives and strategies to reduce environmental damage, rehabilitate damaged environments, and encourage sustainable development are reviewed on an annual basis. Priority environmental issues for the city are solid waste management and water, soil and air pollution. Programs are in place to address immediate social challenges, particularly the spread of HIV/AIDS and the widespread poverty. The citys social package also includes electricity and water rate rebates for indigent households.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: MBC is the result of the amalgamation of the two former municipalities of East London and King William's Town and also other areas, which previously were not included in either municipality. MBC has 880,000 inhabitants and employs 4,000 employees. The municipality's consolidated 2003/04 budget was ZAR 1.2 billion or about $197 million and its surplus for the year was ZAR 18 million or approximately $3 million.
Cost Nature: The total money obtained through the partial credit guarantee is expected to be in the range of ZAR 92-276 million ($15.0-45.3 million approximately). IFC's exposure on its own account would be up to ZAR 120 million ($19.7 million approximately).
Investment: 15.77 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuarantee15.77LoanEquity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The Municipality of Buffalo City is located in the Eastern Cape Province, the second largest province in land area and the third largest in population in South Africa  approximately 880,000 people. It includes the areas of East London, King William's Town and Bhisho.  It is in the Amatole district.

Project Description: Vicentin is one of Argentinas leading oilseed processors and exporters.  IFC will provide financing for Vicentin to expand port storage capacity at San Lorenzo (Santa Fe province); upgrade management information systems; establish new origination and commercial offices; and extend the maturities of some debt.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The review of this project consisted of appraising technical and environmental and social conditions at the following facilities: oilseed crushing plants and port; edible oils refinery plant; cotton ginning facilities in General Pinedo and Villa Angela; cotton spinning facility in Reconquista, herbicides and pesticides formulation plant and two Friar facilities (slaughterhouse and sausages plant) in Reconquista.The following potential environment, health and safety and social impacts of the projects were analyzed:-  Ambient and point source air emissions, including workplace air quality;-  Liquid effluent management, including storm water drainage and treatment;-  Solid waste management; -  Occupational health and safety and food safety; -  Biological and chemical control of pests;-  Complaint mechanism for stakeholders;-  Training of workers and contract workers;-  Labor regulations in Argentina;-  Existing and planned management systems for quality, environmental and social affairs; and-  Acquisition of land (potential issues with resettlement or squatters) for the planned port facility expansion or other infrastructure development. The company has agreed to address these impacts to ensure that the project will, upon implementation of the specific measures, comply with the environmental and social requirements of the Argentinean laws and regulations and the World Bank/IFC environment and social policies and guidelines. The information about how these potential impacts will be addressed by the company is summarized in the Environmental Review Summary (ERS) disclosed in the World Bank InfoShop.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe ERS will be available to the public at the following locations:-  Municipality of San Lorenzo:Urquiza 517  -  2200 San Lorenzo, Santa Fe-  Municipality of Avellaneda:Calle 13 Nº 492 - 3561 Avellaneda, Santa Fe
Sponsor: The project sponsor is Vicentin, a private local company founded in 1929.  The companys core business is oilseed crushing and exporting of its byproducts, oil and meals.  Vicentins operations also include cotton ginning and spinning; formulation of pesticides and herbicides; and meat processing through its subsidiary Friar S.A. (Friar).
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $120 million.  The proposed investment includes an A Loan of up to $20 million and a C Loan of up $15 million, for IFCs own account, and a B Loan of up to $50 million.

Pinedo (Chaco) and Villa Angela (Chaco); -  herbicides and pesticides formulation plant in Reconquista (Santa Fe); and -  spinning plant in Reconquista (Vicentin has also a 50% interest in a spinning facility in Brazil).  Friar has facilities in Reconquista, Santa Fe City, Desvío Arijón (Santa Fe) and Carcaraña (Santa Fe).

Project Description: The proposed project is an equity / quasi-equity investment of up to $60 million in Aval Bank (Aval or the Bank) in Ukraine.  Aval is an existing client of IFC.  IFC committed a $15 million senior loan and $20 million subordinated loan (tier 2 capital) in December 2004, both of which were disbursed in February 2005 (IFC project ID number 22762).   With total assets in excess of $2.2 billion, Aval is the largest bank in Ukraine.  The Bank has more than 1,400 branches and sub-branches, 12,000 corporate clients and 500,000 individual clients.  It is one of the few leading banks without the support of an industrial oligarch, as it is controlled and majority owned by its management.  Its leading position in the market makes it strategically important for the development of the Ukrainian banking sector. IFCs investment may be a convertible loan, to be converted into Aval common shares upon its acquisition by the strategic investor.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category FI type 1 project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  For IFC''s previous investment in Aval, the Bank was required to establish an environmental management system (EMS) to ensure that activities financed under relevant operations are consistent with applicable environmental, occupational health and safety regulations of the Ukraine, designate appropriate individuals to have responsibility for the environment and to attend IFC''s environmental management training, and submit to IFC annual environmental performance reports (AEPRs).  For IFC''s new investment in Aval, the Bank will be required to maintain an EMS satisfactory to IFC for the duration of the new investment.  This will include submission by Aval of AEPRs to IFC, and environmental training for any new environmental officer designated by Aval.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: Aval was established in 1992 by Inkobank, the State Pension Fund, Oranta (the national insurer), and a few members of the current management board of the Bank, primarily the current President, Chairman and First Deputy Chairman of the Management Board.  The institutional shareholders did not have the intention of staying in the Bank.  Nonetheless, they supported Aval with the initial deposits from the pension system, the branch network of Inkobank, and other funds from Oranta as well as client base with Ukrotelecom, Post, and Customs.  Currently Aval is majority owned by its management.
Cost Nature: The proposed IFC investment is an equity/quasi-equity investment of up to $60 million.

Project Description: Wadi Holdings Company (SAE) (Wadi or the company) and its ten subsidiaries comprise a group of Egyptian companies which, at present, has two core business activities.  The first of these consists of poultry and, in particular, the production of broiler day old parents, commercial broilers, layer chicks, hatching eggs and poultry feed.  The second core activity is the planting, cultivating, harvesting and processing of olives and other vegetables and fruits.  Having started operations in 1984, Wadi is now implementing a four-year expansion and diversification investment program, which will lead Wadi from a mid-tier company to one of Egypts and the regions premier agribusiness groups.  The investment program in implementation includes: -  a modern 60 MT per hour feed mill (completed in October 2004), -  a grandparent hatchery and breeder sites, -  olive groves, vegetable farms and processing facilities, -  contract farming with independent out-growers to raise broiler chickens, and -  a joint-venture with local and foreign partners to manufacture glass containers to be used by Wadi and other glass packaging companies in Egypt and abroad.
Role: IFCs investment will support the further development of a successful private sector company in Egypts poultry and food sector.  Drawing on its operational, technical and managerial capabilities, Wadi is expanding and diversifying its poultry and food activities and entering the complementary container glass industry.  It will develop a broiler chicken production system based on contracts with outgrowers, which will be one of the first in Egypt for poultry. The investment program will create about 1,000 jobs in Egypt over the next four year period.  The new glass company will employ modern glass technology provided by Hwa Hsia.Mobilizing its global agribusiness and industrial experience, IFC specialists and consultants will provide financial, technical, environmental and best management practices resources to Wadi.  IFCs loan will help Wadi achieve a more balanced debt structure.  Its loan will include a long grace period to help the new agribusiness investments to become well established prior to the beginning of principal repayment.  IFC will support agribusiness and food processing which are critical sectors in Egypt.  These sectors benefit from Egypts comparative agricultural advantages, a growing economy, and proximity to export markets.  IFC will provide financing and technical services which will facilitate Wadis transition to an international enterprise.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result that can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  Review of this project consisted of appraising technical and environmental /social information submitted by the project sponsor and a physical review of all existing operations and sites proposed for expansion in Egypt.  The following potential environment, health and safety and social impacts of the Project were analyzed.-  Management systems for quality, food safety and environmental affairs;-  Sustainability of farming practices and activities;-  Sustainability and quality of potable water for farming, animal rearing and food processing;-  Discharges to the environment (air emissions and wastewater);-  Solid waste management; -  Proposed glass manufacturing operation;-  Occupational health and safety; and-  Future poultry and agricultural expansions in North Africa and in the Middle East region.   Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityEnvironmental Review Summary and Environmental Action Plan for the investment are available for review at the following location:  Sadat City Investors Association28 Aby Zer Elghafary1st Residential DistrictSadat CityMenoufiaEgypt
Sponsor: The project sponsors are owner-operators who have been involved in the Middle Eastern poultry industry for over 46 years and in the Egyptian poultry industry for the past 20 years.  The main project sponsors are:  Messrs. Musa S. Freiji, Tony S. Freiji, Ramzi P. Nasrallah and Khalil P. Nasrallah.  The investment program includes the establishment of a new glass packaging company, Wadi Glass Container (SAE), which is a joint-venture and whose shareholders are Wadi (70%), Hwa Hsia Glass Company of Taiwan, China (12%), Mr. J.J. Jow, chairman of Jochlenlee Molds & Machine Manufacturing, Inc. of Singapore (3%), and Mr. Samih Sawiris of Cairo (15%).

Company Name: Beijing DQY Agriculture Technology Co., Ltd.
Project Description: Beijing Deqingyuan Agriculture Technology Co. Ltd (Deqingyuan or the company) is a company based in Beijing, China, that produces high quality eggs.  It currently houses 500,000 layers and produces and sells 200,000 eggs per day.  Its eggs received the no harmful ingredients certificate, the organic food product certificate, and the safe agricultural food product certificate from the government.  It is the only egg product that was granted as a national priority new product by the Ministry of Technology, Ministry of Commerce, Ministry of Quality Inspection, and Ministry of Environment Protection. The quality of the Deqingyuan eggs is well recognized by the market.  The eggs sell at a price that is substantially higher than that of the non-brand, regular eggs and the sales grow rapidly.  Deqingyuans strategy is to quickly increase its production capacity and market share.  It plans to expand the capacity of the layer sheds to house an additional 800,000 birds, which will add production capacity by 500,000 eggs per day.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The review of this project consisted of appraising technical and environmental information submitted by the project sponsor.  The following potential environment, health and safety  impacts of the projects were analyzed: -  Siting and design of plant, -  Air emissions, and solid and liquid waste management,-  Feed supply and sources, -  Occupational health and safety (including fire and life safety issues), -  Company environmental management capacity.  Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe ERS is disclosed at the companys administrative office:Agronomy Building, Room 518Chinese Academy of Agricultural ScienceZhong Guang Cun South StreetHaidian District, Beijing 100081, China
Sponsor: The shareholders of the company (collectively, the Sponsors) and their shareholding percentages are: Beijing Deqingyuan Technology, 51.76%, Tianjin Baodi Agricultural Technology, 10.50%, Shanghai Yibei Management Consulting, 7.63%, and six individuals, together 30.11%.  Mr. Zhong Kaimin is the major shareholder and one of the key founders of the company.  Mr. Zhong holds an engineering master degree and an MBA.  Between 1984 and 2001, Mr. Zhong worked for the government in Beijing.  He became aware of the health, safety and environmental issues of the egg industry and saw the potential for producing high quality eggs.  Mr. Zhong left the government in 2002 and devoted himself to building the company into a leading high quality egg producer in China.
Cost Nature: Total project cost is $12.6 million.  The proposed IFC investment is an equity of $2.76 million for IFCs own account.
Investment: 2.82 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity2.82* These investment figures are indicative

The site comprises barren land that is owned by local government and the company (1.5 ha is owned by the company the remainder will be leased by the company on a long term basis from local government).  The site is served by municipal electricity and water supply and has access to local transport infrastructure. Development of the site has not required any resettlement.

Project Description: The project consists of a line of credit of up to $30 million to Diamond Bank Limited (DBL or the Bank), one of the largest new generation banks in Nigeria. The project's main objective is to address the scarcity of term finance in Nigeria, which has forced Nigerian commercial banks to rely on their capital, or take the maturity risk in order to finance longer-term projects. The proposed investment allows IFC to address part of these constraints by making available foreign exchange term resources through an efficient financial institution.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an FI Type 2 project. Diamond Bank will be required to undertake an environmental review of each subproject.  DBL has had a good record and is fully compliant with the IFC environmental policies. However, the IFC will re-assess DBLs environmental management system during appraisal.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: The project sponsor is Diamond Bank Limited, one of the largest new generation banks in Nigeria. Diamond Bank offers a full range of products and services in retail, commercial, corporate and investment banking, including advisory, investment, debt, equity, lending and transactional services supported by a network of over 51 branches. The operations are supported by a strong technology infrastructure.  As of April 30, 2005, Diamond Bank had total assets over $951 million and total shareholders' funds in excess of $157 million.
Cost Nature: IFC's investment will be in the form of a loan of up to $30 million to Diamond Bank Limited.

DBL has had a good record and is fully compliant with the IFC environmental policies. Project Description:
VeriSilicon is an IC (integrated circuit) design foundry providing semiconductor chip design services and intellectual property (IP) products to fabless IC companies and Original Equipment Manufacturers worldwide, primarily in Greater China and the US.  The company was founded in 2001 to serve as a bridge between China-based wafer foundries and global IC system design houses.

The purpose of the project is to provide the company capital: 

- for research and development of new IP products,
- expansion of sales and marketing efforts; and
- to support the expansion of the company's turn-key business.

There are minimal environmental or social impacts associated with this project.  Therefore, no further environmental or social analysis is required.  During appraisal, the team reviewed building safety conditions and social aspects.  Construction on the first, state-of-the-art office building of the new technology campus was completed in January 2005.   It meets safety standards in terms of emergency exits and evacuation channels.  It houses 1,500 employees in an area of 160,000 square feet and has many well-lit open spaces and common areas.  KPIT plans to build two more office buildings which together will house 2,500 employees in an area of 250,000 square feet.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Cummins Inc. is the world's largest manufacturer of diesel engines and related power systems for the automotive industry.  Headquartered in the United States, Cummins Inc. is publicly traded on the New York Stock Exchange.  The company serves customers in over 160 countries, reporting sales of US$8.4 billion in 2004.  Cummins Inc. has three Directors on KPIT's twelve member Board.

Lehman Brothers is a New York investment bank founded in 1850, and has $71 billion in total capital.  The company is publicly traded on the New York Stock Exchange.  Lehman Brothers owns an 8% equity stake in KPIT.

Management owns 28% of KPIT Cummins Inc. owns 14%; Indian institutions own 8%; and Foreign Financial Institutions own 23%, including Lehman Brothers' 8% stake.  The remaining shares are held mainly by retail investors on the Mumbai Stock Exchange.  The two sponsors, S B (Ravi) Pandit and Kishor Patil together own about 19% of shares outstanding.
