Project Description:
The project involves an IFC equity investment of up to $2.0 million-equivalent in Rio Bravo Securitizadora S.A. (RBSec or the company).  RBSec is one of the leading real estate securitization companies in Brazil.  Its principal business activities include: 
-  the origination of residential and commercial real estate receivables, 
-  their subsequent securitization in CRI format (Certificados de Recebiveis Imobiliários, which are effectively the Brazilian equivalent of mortgage-backed securities) and placement with investors, and 
-  acting as a master servicer for CRI transactions.

RBSec will utilize the IFC investment to strengthen its capital base, in order to raise more debt funding so as to further expand its residential real estate receivable origination and securitization activities.
Role:
-  Extension of financial services to a large number of previously underserved groups.

 By providing alternative  and therefore increased  sources of residential real estate financing in addition to those that already exist, the project will help to address Brazil's current housing deficit and make the purchase of homes more affordable for middle-income families.

-  Significant contribution towards improving the legal and regulatory environment for housing finance in Brazil.  

IFC's involvement in this project will allow the Corporation to play an active role in helping to remedy any remaining legal and regulatory deficiencies in the Brazilian primary and secondary mortgage sectors, as well as the country's growing securitization markets.  In addition to necessary review of relevant legal and regulatory underpinnings for these markets, IFC's participation in this project is expected to result in further standardization of eligibility, underwriting and servicing criteria for mortgage loans, all of which are important preconditions for the development and viability of a large and liquid MBS market.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an environmental category C project.  RBSec will be required to establish an appropriate screening procedure to ensure that properties associated with securitized real estate receivables are not environmentally impaired.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: RBSec's current shareholders are various investment funds and vehicles associated with the Rio Bravo Group (who hold 82% of the company's shareholders' equity), as well as other high net-worth individual investors.
Cost Nature: IFC's proposed investment in the company is up to $2.0 million-equivalent, and will not exceed 20% of the company's shareholders' equity.
Investment: 1.49 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity1.49* These investment figures are indicative
Location: RBSec is headquartered in São Paulo.

Project Name: Pan American Energy LLC - Argentine Branch
Company Name: PAN AMERICAN ENERGY, S.L., ARGENTINE BRANCH
Project Description:
Pan American Energy LLC (PAE or the company) is engaged mainly in the exploration, development and production of oil and gas.  The company holds interests in thirteen oil and gas production blocks in Argentina and ten active oil and gas production and development blocks in Bolivia, through its indirect Bolivian subsidiary Empresa Petrolera Chaco S.A. (Chaco).  In addition, PAE holds interests in 15 exploration blocks, eight in Argentina and seven in Bolivia.  

PAE was the second largest oil and gas producer in Argentina during 2004, accounting for approximately 15% of the country's total oil production and approximately 12% of its total gas production.  The company's blocks in Argentina are located in the four major hydrocarbon basins - Golfo San Jorge, Austral, Neuquen and Northwest.  The most significant blocks in terms of average net daily production, as of 2004, were Cerro Dragon in the Golfo San Jorge Basin, Cuenca Austral in the Austral Basin, and Acambuco in the Northwest Basin.  

IFC has been requested to provide financing of up to $250 million for Pan American Energy LLC, Argentine Branch (the 'Branch'), PAE's Argentine branch, to help finance its 2005 capital expenditure program for the continued development and production of three key blocks  Cerro Dragon, Piedra Clavada and Koluel Kaike, all located in the Golfo San Jorge Basin. The Project contemplates:

-  drilling for oil and gas, optimization of water-flooding projects and installation of facilities in the Cerro Dragon field; and 
-  drilling and water flooding projects in the Koluel Kaike and Piedra Clavada blocks.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The review of this project consisted of appraising the projects technical and environmental /social information, in addition to appraising other operations in the company.  The following corporate systems and potential environment, health, safety, social impacts were analyzed:-  Establishing a corporate Integrated Environmental, Health, Safety and Social Management System;-  The companys capacity to manage multiple projects and implement the integrated management system;-  Potential impacts on protected areas;-  Air emissions including Greenhouse Gases;-  Water supply and disposal;-  Liquid and solid waste;-  Public and worker safety;-  Archaeology;-  Social development programs;-  Community relations and public consultation;-  Potential future interactions with indigenous people;-  Potential related land use/rental or compensation issues; and-  Emergency Response Plans including oil spill response plans.The company has presented plans to address these impacts to ensure that the project will, upon implementation of the specific agreed measures, comply with the environmental and social requirements - the Argentinean laws and regulations and the World Bank/IFC environment and social policies and the environmental, health and safety guidelines.  The information about how these potential impacts will be addressed by the company is summarized in the Environmental Review Summary (ERS) disclosed in the World Bank InfoShop. Sponsor: PAE was formed in Delaware on September 29, 1997 to effect the strategic alliance between Amoco Corporation (Amoco) and Bridas Corporation (Bridas) for specific oil and gas activities in the Southern Cone of South America.  Upon the formation of the alliance, each of Bridas and Amoco contributed to PAE their respective Argentine oil and gas operations.  BP plc (following Amoco's merger with and into BP in 1999) currently owns 60% of the equity interest of PAE, and Bridas owns the remaining 40%.  PAE conducts its operations primarily through the Branch, which holds approximately two-thirds of its assets and is the obligor on substantially all of the financial debt of the PAE consolidated group of companies.

Both the Piedra Clavada and Koluel Kaike blocks are located in the province of Santa Cruz.  The Branch's headquarters are located in Buenos Aires.

Company Name: BACS BANCO DE CREDITO Y SECURITIZACION S.A.
Project Description: The proposed project consists of a new Warehousing Credit Line (WCL) of up to $25 million for BACS Banco de Credito y Securitizacion, S.A. (BACS or the Bank), to fund the origination and securitization of mortgages and mortgage-backed securities (MBS).  In conjunction with this project, IFC would also modify the FIDEX project (#20942), to re-orient the use of proceeds in a similar structure to that of the WCL.  The Fidex project was originally intended for securitization of trade receivables, but the client has requested the modification due to changing market dynamics.Following the higher than expected 76% acceptance of the sovereign debt restructuring offer in February 2005, and in an environment of continued improvements in the Argentine economy, the mortgage market is beginning to re-emerge. The contemplated project would support BACS original business plan, which was curtailed by the Argentine crisis. The warehousing line would help BACS rebuild its business in line with the purpose that it was originally set up for, at a time when there is growing demand for mortgage products.BACS was created in May 2000, with Banco Hipotecario, S.A. ("BH") as the main sponsor.  BACS was Argentina''s first secondary mortgage market securitization company.  As of December 31, 2004, BACS had $58.7 million in assets, $23.2 million in liabilities, and a relatively strong capital position (with a ratio of equity to total assets of 60%). As a result of the Argentine financial crisis, the bank registered losses in 2002 and 2003 totaling $12.7 million.  However, the bank returned to profitability in 2004, with net income of $2.8 million.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an environmental category C project. No further environmental or social analysis is requiredLocation of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The principal sponsor of BACS is Banco Hipotecario (BH), a privately managed and controlled but majority Government-owned mortgage bank, which has a 70% shareholding in BACS.  In addition to IFC, which has a 20% stake-holding, BACS other shareholders are IRSA (Inversiones y Representaciones S.A.), an Argentine real estate development and management company with 5.1%, and Quantum Industrial Partners, a Soros Management Fund, with 4.9%  BH completed the restructuring of its debt on 12/29/03, which became effective on 1/14/04. Since that time, the bank has quickly returned to profitability and in 2004 it was the most profitable private bank in Argentina as well as the best capitalized.
Cost Nature: The proposed new IFC investment is $25 million.  The new project combined with the re-orientation of the Fidex project would total $50 million, to be available in two separate tranches.
Investment: 25.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan25.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: BACS is based in Buenos Aires, Argentina, and its operations fund originations and securitizations of assets throughout Argentina.

Company Name: MODERN KARTON SANAYI VE TICARET ANONIM SIRKETI
Project Description: Modern Karton Sanayi ve Ticaret A.S. (Modern Karton), the main operating company of the Eren Groups paper and packaging business, was established in 1974.  It manufactures test liner and fluting paper using wastepaper at its factory located in Corlu, located 100 km west of Istanbul.  With a 300,000 metric tons per annum capacity, Modern Karton is Turkeys largest plant in the corrugated cardboard sector. The project consists of a $365 million expansion program of Eren Holdings paper and packaging businesses in Corlu.  The project includes: -  a capacity increase of 300,000 metric tons per annum to the paper mill (i.e. installation of a new paper making machine); -  an investment in their packaging and paper recycling businesses; and -  an expansion of the associated cogeneration plant (for steam and power) and wastewater treatment plant.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social/community impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The review of this project consisted of appraising technical and environment, health and safety, and social/community information submitted by the project sponsor.  Plant visits have been made by IFCs Environmental Specialist as a result of this new project and as part of IFCs supervision of earlier investments.  The following potential environment, health and safety (EHS), and social/community impacts of the projects were analyzed:-  Compliance of the expansion project and associated facilities as well as the existing facilities with Turkish and IFC environment, health and safety (EHS) requirements;-  Eren Holdings continued commitment to quality and to performance to international standards including ISO and OHSAS certifications; and-  Social and community issues.  Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe environmental documents translated in Turkish will be available at the gate of Modern Karton at the following address: Kirikgoz Mevkii Ulas Corlu, Turkey.
Sponsor: The Eren Group is a diversified industrial group with operations in the paper, energy, cement, textiles and retail sectors. It is owned by the Eren family through Eren Holding, which owns and manages portfolio investments in various Eren Group companies.  Eren Holdings consolidated revenues during 2004 were $470 million on total assets $543 million.  Modern Karton, the flagship company of the Group, is currently the leader in the Turkish corrugated paper industry.  Eren Holding has controlling shareholding of Modern Karton (93%).

Company Name: Beijing ChinaSoft International Information Technology Co., Ltd.
Project Description:
Chinasoft International Limited (Chinasoft or the company) is a Chinese IT services firm providing solutions and software to the domestic market, with a particular focus on government and state-linked customers.  The company's clients include the State Bureau of Auditing, the General Administration of Quality Supervision, Inspection & Quarantine, the State Tobacco Control Bureau and the six largest Economic Technology Development Areas ('ETDAs') in China.  Chinasoft is headquartered in Beijing with branch offices and delivery centers in six cities.  

The company was established in April 2000, when 20 key management staff left China National Software & Technology Service Corporation ('CS&S') to start the company.  CS&S is a 42% state-owned enterprise ('SOE') that is regarded as one of the country's best established software companies and is listed on the Shanghai stock exchange.  Chinasoft was publicly listed on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange's Growth Enterprise Market ('HK GEM') in June 2003.  For the year ended December 31, 2004, Chinasoft generated revenues of $35.5 million, EBITDA (Earnings Before Interest, Taxes, Depreciation, and Amortization) of $5.5 million and net income of $4.3 million.
Environmental Social Issues: Based on available information, this is a category C project according to IFC''s environment and social review procedure.  During appraisal, the project team should assess Chinasoft''s office buildings to determine whether improvements in fire and life safety and employee health and safety provisions are required.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor:
Chinasoft is a publicly listed company trading on the HK GEM.  Management owns 18%; CS&S 8%; Far East Technology International 25%; overseas individual investors 21%; and the public about 27% of the company.  

Far East Technology International is an investment company with businesses in the industrial sector, information technology sector, and property development and investment sector.  The company has been trading on the HKSE since 1973.

CS&S was established by the Chinese Ministry of Information Industry and is a well established national software developer that specializes in computer software development, system integration and information services. Having established a firm foothold in the China market, CS&S has been one of the largest system integrators in China for many years, making contributions to the information and software industry.  CS&S is listed on the Shanghai Stock Exchange.
Cost Nature: The company is considering an expansion program costing around $20 million.  IFC is evaluating ways of working with the company on its expansion program.

Project Name: Emerging Europe Convergence Fund II, L.P.
Company Name: EMERGING EUROPE CONVERGENCE FUND II, L.P.
Project Description:
The Emerging Europe Convergence Fund II, L.P. (EECF II, or the Fund), is a 10-year closed-end regional private equity fund formed by Mid Europa Partners LLP (MEP), with the objective to achieve superior returns through a portfolio of investments primarily in mature, cash-flow generative companies in sectors with high barriers to entry based in the markets of the new European Union members and the EU accession candidate countries (Emerging Europe, or the Region).  

The Fund is targeting total capital commitments of 500 million, and expects to have a first closing in late June/early July, 2005.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an FI type 2 project.  EECF II will be required to ensure that its environmental management system can address the environmental and social management issues associated with funds investment program.  Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor:
The Fund will be managed through a limited liability partnership, Mid Europa Partners LLP ('MEP'), which is controlled by its three Partners: Thierry Baudon, Craig Butcher and Colin Hewett. 

MEP is a successor to EMP Europe Ltd, which was formed in 1999 by EMP Global (an independent private equity fund advisor, responsible for the investment of six private equity funds totalling US $5.7 billion in commitments in Africa, Asia, Latin America, Europe and the Middle East) for the purpose of advising the AIG Emerging Europe Infrastructure Fund ('EEIF'), a $550 million private equity fund focused on infrastructure projects in Central and Eastern Europe, in which IFC is an investor. 

Although MEP will now be operating independently of EMP Global, the two organizations will retain a close relationship. Under the management of Thierry Baudon, EMP Europe was built to its current size of 11 investment professionals and successfully operates out of three offices in Budapest, London and Warsaw. The majority of the core team has been working together since EEIF's inception in 1999. This team of professionals' shares over 50 years of combined private equity investment experience, 100 years of transaction experience, and 80 years of experience in the region including managerial and industrial expertise in relevant sectors.
Cost Nature: The total size of the EECF fund is expected to be 500 million.  IFC would be investing up to 20 million in the Fund.
Investment: 25.84 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity25.84* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The region in which EECF II is planning to invest includes both countries that recently joined the EU (Czech Republic, Estonia, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, Slovakia, and Slovenia) and accession candidate countries (Bulgaria, Croatia, Romania). Also EECF is contemplating investing up to 20% of its capital in other countries (such as Russia and Ukraine).
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is an FI type 2 project.  EECF II will be required to ensure that its environmental management system can address the environmental and social management issues associated with funds investment program. Company Name: ASSAN DEMIR VE SAC SANAYI ANONIM SIRKETI
Project Description:
Assan Demir ve Sac Sanayii A.S. (Assan or the company), established in 1977 and part of the family-owned Kibar Group, is the largest aluminum sheet, coil, and foil manufacturer in Turkey, and also ranks amongst the top Turkish steel galvanizing companies.  

The project comprises of:

-  restructuring of the company's balance sheet; and 
-  implementing a debottlenecking and modernization program, primarily at its aluminum plant. 

As part of the project the sponsors have also committed to improve the corporate governance of Assan.  

The project will significantly improve Assan's balance sheet, enable it to focus on its operations, and consolidate and further grow on its market position.
Environmental Social Issues:

Company Name: COMPANIA DE NAVIGATIE FLUVIALA ROMANA NAVROM SA
Project Description: Transport Trade Services S.A. (TTS or the company), its shipping subsidiary CNFR Navrom Galati S.A. (Navrom), its other subsidiaries and affiliates (the Group) are leading providers of freight forwarding, river shipping and integrated logistics services in Romania.   TTS was founded in 1997 and its core operations entail the provision of shipping and handling (river, rail and sea) services to top tier Romanian and multinational clients.  The Group is currently undertaking a $25 million capital investment program consisting of: -  upgrading of engines and propulsion systems for twelve pushers; -  building a grain storage and handling terminal in Constanta; and -  refinancing the purchase of a 25 ton second hand floating crane.  The project will improve TTS logistics infrastructure and asset quality, strengthen its product offering and enhance the modular nature of its services.  The investment program will also improve the Groups efficiency, enhance reliability, allow it to service more clients and reduce operating costs.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category B project.  In conducting the due diligence, the following potential environmental and health and safety impacts were analyzed: -  environmental, health and safety management systems; -  vessel safety and pollution control; -  oil / hazardous cargo spill prevention and control; -  maintenance / repair yard pollution control and hazardous materials and waste management; and   -  employee health and safety.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityEnvironmental documentation will be made available at the following locations:- Navrom Galati headquarters, 34 Portului Str., Galati, Galati county- MAST office in Constanta, 1, Ion Creanga, Agigea, Constanta county- TTS Bucuresti office, 34 Str. Vaselor, Sect. 2  Bucharest
Sponsor: The Group is a Romanian owned and operated integrated logistics and transport provider.  Of the two main companies, TTS is privately held and Navrom is publicly listed on RASDAQ, the Romanian electronic exchange.  TTS has 15 individual shareholder, 12 of whom are part of the companys management.  Its five primarily shareholders, Mr. Mircea Mihaelescu (45.5%), Mrs. Lucia Barbalescu (10%), Mr. Ion. Stanciu (10%), Mr. Viorel Stefan (10%), Mr. Peter Hungerbuhler (10%), together own 85% of the Company.  Mr. Mihailescu is also the founder and CEO of TTS.  Navrom is 53.7% owned by TTS, 6.13% by Transfer International Services, 9.86% by SIF Transilvani, 5.11% Transorient, 0.14% by Constantin Hartan, the CEO and 25.05% by public shareholders.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is $24.7 million and consists of :-  $15.6 million for the pusher upgrade; -  $5.8 million for the grain terminal; and -  $3.3 million for the crane re-financing.  IFCs proposed investment consists of:-  an A Loan of $2.6 million equivalent in Euros to TTS S.A. to fund the construction of the grain terminal and refinance the crane; and -  an A Loan of $15.6 million equivalent in Euros to Navrom to finance the pusher upgrade.
Investment: 16.95 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan16.95Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The crane and grain handling terminal will both be located at TTS facilities at the Constanta port, located on the Black Sea, which is Romanias largest port.  The pushers will be used on the Danube River, both within Romania and in neighboring European countries. TTS is headquartered in the capital, Bucharest.

Company Name: IHDC DODSON LINDBLOM HYDRO POWER PVT LTD
Project Description:
IFC will lend to and invest equity in Dodson-Lindblom HydroPower Private Limited (DLHPPL) and Ascent Hydro Projects Limited (Ascent) on a joint and several bases.  These two companies will merge into one company, Indian Hydropower Development Corporation (IHDC), within the next few years. DLHPPL and Ascent are Indian companies, established in 1997 and 1994 respectively, that are 100% owned subsidiaries of Dodson-Lindblom International (DLI), a wholly-owned subsidiary of DLZ Corporation of the U.S. (DLZ or the Sponsor).

The project comprises a package of six small and mini hydroelectric generation facilities located in three states in India including: 

-  the construction of three greenfield mini-hydroelectric generation facilities in the state of Himachal Pradesh (Sechi, Melan and Panwi), 
-  the acquisition, rehabilitation and refurbishment of an existing 34 MW facility in Maharashtra (BH II), 
-  an existing 12 MW operational facility in Maharashtra (BH I), and 
-  the completion of a 2.2 MW mini-hydropower plant in Madhya Pradesh state (Birsingphur) currently under construction.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a Category B project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure.The review of this project consisted of appraising technical, environmental and social information submitted by the project Sponsor; and visits to the two existing facilities in Maharashtra (Bhandardara I and II), to the Birsinghpur plant (currently under construction) in MP, and to the three greenfield sites (Melan, Panwi and Sechi) in HP. The following potential environment, health and safety and social aspect of the project (s) were analyzed:-  corporate environmental, social, and health and safety management systems;-  national and local government permitting requirements;-  dam safety (relevant to Bhandardara only);-  potential impacts on downstream users; -  land acquisition, compensation and physical and/or economic resettlement;-  community consultation and disclosure;-  site access during construction and operation;-  community health and safety during both construction and operation; -  provision of housing, hygiene facilities, water, and power (including fuel storage) during construction and operation;-  hazardous materials management; -  fire and life safety and emergency response; -  minimization, recycling and disposal of solid and hazardous wastes during construction and operation;-  biodiversity conservation;-  corporate social responsibility efforts, including HIV/AIDS awareness; and -  timely reporting on environmental and social performance to IFC.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityEnvironmental documentation will be made available at the following locations:

Sponsor:
The project sponsor is DLZ Corporation of Columbus, Ohio, USA.  DLZ, founded in 1951, is a privately-held well-respected full service architectural, engineering and environmental consulting firm with annual revenues of approximately $80 million.  DLZ provides water resources, wastewater, architectural, facilities, transportation and environmental engineering analysis, design and project management functions to clients in the US and more than 20 countries around the world.  Its largest clients include the US Army Corps of Engineers, US Department of Agriculture, various state and municipal departments of natural resources, transportation, water and environmental quality, and a wide array of private companies including Bethlehem Steel.    

In 1979, DLZ was purchased by Mr. Vikram Rajadhyaksha, who currently owns 59% of the company.  The remaining shareholders are: employees (30%), Mr. P.V. Rajadhyaksha, brother of Vikram (10%), and Janet, wife of Vikram, and Dr. Kasturi Rajadhyaksha, mother of Vikram (1%).

DLI, a wholly-owned subsidiary of DLZ, was formed in 1984 to expand the business into the international market.  DLI is the direct 100% owner of DLHPPL and Ascent.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $49 million.  The proposed IFC investment includes an up to $14 million A Loan and an up to $4 million equity investment.
Investment: 17.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan17.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location:
The BH I project is located on Lake Arthur Hill Reservoir in the Upper Pravara River Basin in Maharashtra state. The nearest town, Ghoti, is 36 km away from the project site.  BH I was constructed in 1986 by the Government of Maharashtra Irrigation Department, and rehabilitated by the Sponsor upon acquisition in 1996.   

The BH II project is located 10 km downstream of BH I on the Pravara River in Maharashtra state.  BH II was constructed in 1999 and operated until today by the Government of Maharashtra Irrigation Department.  Upon acquisition later this year, the Sponsor will rehabilitate and refurbish the project site.

Birsingphur project is located in the Umaria District, about 180 km northeast of the city of Jabalpur in the eastern part of the State of Madhya Pradesh.  The project is located within the fence of the Sanjay Gandhi Thermal Power Station, an 840 MW coal-fired power plant owned and operated by the Madhya Pradesh State Electricity Board.  The sponsor is finalizing construction of the Birsingphur plant and anticipates commercial operations in August 2005.

The three greenfield mini-hydro plants will be located in the state of Himachal Pradesh.  All are located in the mid-range Himalaya mountains at elevations of around 2,000 meters.  The climate is of the tropical monsoon nature, with a maximum summer temperature of around 30 degrees celsius and a minimum winter temperature below freezing.  The exact location of each project is:

-  Sechi: located on Sechi khad (stream), a tributary of the Sutlej river, near the village of Samej in the district of Shimla,
-  Melan:  located on Melan khad, also a tributary of the Sutlej river, in the Kinnaur district, and
-  Panwi: located on the Panwi khad, also a tributary of the Sutlej river, very close to the Melan khad, in the Kinnaur district.  

Access roads to the Sechi and Panwi sites are via a state road and a bridge from a national highway, respectively.  Access to Melan is currently very limited; however, a bridge is being constructed by the Himachal Pradesh government which will provide adequate access to the project site.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati:

Project Description:
This project  Open Joint-Stock Company Eskhata Bank (Eskhata Bank or the Bank)  is part of IFC's Central Asia Micro and Small Enterprise Facility (the Facility), comprising of individual credit lines to selected partner banks for on-lending to micro and small enterprises (MSEs) through specialized micro and small business finance windows created at the partner banks' level for this purpose.  Within the framework of the facility, IFC will, in close collaboration with EBRD, make available up to $45 million for lending (in the form of credit lines) to selected local banks for onlending to micro and small enterprises (MSEs) in Kazakhstan, The Kyrgyz Republic, Uzbekistan, and Tajikistan.

Eskhata Bank, a Tajik commercial bank with approximately 4% of the banking system's total assets in Tajikistan, has been selected as a partner bank for the Facility.  It was registered as a commercial bank on November 16, 1993 following the issue of a General License for banking operations by the National Bank of Tajikistan.  Eskhata Bank has obtained licenses for conducting all types of banking operations, including foreign currency dealings.  The main objective for the establishment of the Bank was to provide private companies and individuals (mostly in the cotton and agribusiness sectors) with access to credit and with a range of diversified banking services.

The objective of this project is to expand the frontier of finance by extending downward the range of market segments served by Eskhata Bank. Thus, the IFC credit line will increase the availability of sustained credit to creditworthy MSEs, while at the same time building up the lending capacity and skill base of Eskhata Bank.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Financial Intermediary (FI) Type 1 project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure. The Bank will be required to develop and implement an Environmental Management System (EMS) to screen loan applications for compliance with host country environment, health and safety requirements and consistency with a Microfinance Exclusion List developed jointly by EBRD and IFC.  Further, Eskhata Bank must identify two individuals with responsibilities for environmental matters and provide the appropriate training.  The Bank will also be required to provide an Annual Report on its EMS.  Eskhata Bank will commit to meet the above requirements.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

- Nasirov Family: 36%

- Mr. Abdulloyev: 8%
- Mrs. Abdulleyova: 7%
- Others (less than 5% shareholding): 37%
Cost Nature: The project involves an IFC investment of up to $1.0 million in the form of a credit line to Eskhata Bank.

Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Financial Intermediary (FI) Type 1 project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure. Project Description: The IFC Private Enterprise Partnership (PEP) is the technical assistance (TA) facility for the former Soviet Union, specifically covering the countries of Armenia, Azerbaijan Belarus, Georgia, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyz Republic, Moldova, Mongolia, Russia, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, Ukraine and Uzbekistan. The creation of PEP was initially approved by the Board in May 2000 for a three year period (IFC/R2000-75 dated May 8, 2000) and extended in September 2002 (IFC/R2002-0191) for a further 3 years (FY04-FY06). This project represents an extension of the program for an additional five years (FY07-FY11), commencing July 1, 2006.
Environmental Social Issues: Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityn/a
Sponsor: PEP is funded by IFC and its donor partners. PEPs current donor partners include the Governments of Austria, Bavaria, Canada, Denmark, the European Union, Finland, Iceland, Japan, the Netherlands, Norway, Saxony, Sweden, Switzerland and the United States.
Cost Nature: PEP requests $6.07 million dollars per year in FY07 dollars, to be adjusted for inflation each subsequent year. This amount includes: $5.1 million per year, which represents a continuation of IFC core funding at the same level in real terms as from the start of the PEP in FY01 and $0.97 million per year for exporting its expertise on proven TA products such as Corporate Governance and Leasing to the rest of the organization as well as for further TA product innovation specifically in new emerging areas such as Energy Efficiency.  For its current funding cycle (FY04-FY06) PEP has already raised $25.4 million from donors to complement the IFC core contribution and is currently in negotiations with donor partners about raising additional funds in the coming fiscal year.  Consistent with fundraising projections for the previous phase of PEPs lifecycle, PEP expects to raise $28-35 million in new contributions from existing and new donors for the first three years of its next phase (FY07-FY09).
Location: PEP is based in Moscow, Russia and has country offices in the capital cities of Ukraine, Belarus, Uzbekistan, Kyrgyz Republic, Tajikistan, Georgia and Azerbaijan. Field offices in regional cities operate in Russia, Ukraine, Kazakhstan and Tajikistan.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityn/a

Project Description: Ethos Private Equity Fund V (Ethos V or the Fund) is a private equity fund which will make equity and equity-related investments primarily for control positions in market-leading growth businesses located in South Africa as well as in other African countries.  The Fund has a target committed equity capital of up to $500 million.  The Fund will be the fifth fund raised and managed by Ethos Private Equity Limited (Ethos) which is based in Johannesburg and has a core group of 16 professionals that have worked together since 1985.  IFC intends to invest up to $25 million in Ethos V and will also consider an investment of up to $5 million in Sphere Private Equity Fund I (Sphere I) which is a related fund set up as a joint venture with Ethos V to share deals and the expertise of senior Ethos partners.  Sphere I is a Rand-denominated private equity fund with target capital commitments of Rand 600 million (~$100 million) which will be managed by Sphere Holdings (Sphere). Ethos V and Sphere I are fundraising simultaneously for capital commitments in the ratio of 5:1 respectively.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an F1 Type 2 project.  The Fund Manager will be required to demonstrate that their existing EMS is adequate to address the environmental and social issues for investments under the new fund.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The sponsor of Ethos V is Ethos Private Equity Limited (the Fund Manager or Ethos) based in Johannesburg, South Africa.  The Fund Manager has been operating since 1984 and has managed four previous funds with aggregate capital commitments of Rand 2.48 billion ($487 million) which was invested in 85 investments.Sphere I will be managed by Sphere Private Equity (the Sphere Team), composed of a group of four young black professionals with investment banking and private equity experience who have a 24% shareholding in Ethos (under a Black Economic Empowerment shareholding restructuring).  The Sphere Team has previously concluded one investment.
Cost Nature: Ethos V has a target equity commitment of $500 million and may include an additional debt feature of $150 million in guaranteed debt from the Overseas Private Investment Corporation (OPIC).  Sphere I has target capital commitments of Rand 600 million (about $100 million).  IFC expects to invest up to $25 million in Ethos V, and up to $5 million in Sphere.
Investment: 30.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity30.0* These investment figures are indicative

Project Description:
Apollo Hospitals Enterprise Limited (Apollo or the company) is the holding company of the largest private integrated healthcare group in India, with 16 owned and 24 managed hospitals (bed capacity of over 5,000), a network of 206 retail pharmacies and a healthcare management consulting practice.  Through a number of joint ventures and associated companies, its business lines include also clinical and diagnostic services, medical business process outsourcing and insurance services.

Apollo is in the process of raising funds for the implementation of the company's strategy, designed to strengthen its position of a market leader by taking advantage of existing growth and consolidation opportunities in its domestic market, as well as build on its established brand name by expanding to new markets.
Environmental Social Issues:

The review of this project consisted primarily of discussions with Apollo management on its systems for managing environmental, social, health and safety issues; a limited appraisal of technical, environmental, social and occupational safety and health information made available for review by the Company at its Indraprastha Apollo Hospital in Delhi; and a site visit to the Indraprastha Apollo Hospital in Delhi. Project Description:
The project is to purchase approximately 21.7% of TBC Bank's shares (the 'Bank') from Messrs Badri Japaridze and Mamuka Khazaradaze, the founding shareholders of the Bank (the 'Georgian Shareholders'), for up to US$8.5 million.  IFC will retain 3.1% of the Bank's shares for its long term holdings and will grant the Georgian Shareholders an option to repurchase the remainder of the shares over a 4 year time period.  The project will increase IFC's direct shareholding in the Bank and will enable the Georgian Shareholders to purchase additional shares from a financial investor which has chosen to exit the Bank.

The purpose of the project is to consolidate the shareholding structure of the Bank, thus positioning the institution for growth through a possible future alliance with potential strategic investors.  The opportunity for consolidation has arisen as a result of the recent exit of a financial investor from the Bank's shareholding.  IFC's share purchase and will enable the Bank to give serious consideration to building alliances with strong strategic players.  This strategy, when fully implemented, would provide the Bank with (a) expertise and know-how in offering the Georgian public new banking products, and (b) access to capital to support the Bank's growth.  
 
TBC Bank, is the largest bank in Georgia, holding 25% of the country's banking assets and 34% of deposits. TBC Bank was established on December 17, 1992 and provides a wide range of retail and corporate banking services.  In recent years, TBC Bank has emerged as a leader in the Georgian banking sector and has been key in restoring the public's confidence in the banking sector.  Banks are the primary financial intermediaries in Georgia and play a significant and increasing role in financing economic growth.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category FI Type 2 project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  Under IFC''s previous investments in TBC, the Bank has established an environmental management system (EMS) to ensure that investments are consistent with applicable Georgian and IFC/World Bank environmental requirements and exclusion list, and has been submitting annual environmental performance reports to IFC''s satisfaction.  For the duration of this new investment, TBC will be required to maintain its EMS and continue to provide annual environmental reports.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: "The project's sponsors and founding shareholders are several local Georgian businessmen, the more prominent of whom include Mr. Mamuka Khazaradze and Mr. Badri Japaridze.  Messrs Khazaradze and Japaridze currently directly or indirectly own or control a 71% stake in the Bank. After the proposed transaction, Messrs. Khazaradze and Japaridze will own or control just over a 50% stake. Other major shareholders of TBC Bank include DEG (10%) and IFC (9%)".
Cost Nature: The total project cost will be approximately $8.5 million in the form of an equity investment.
Investment: 8.75 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity8.75* These investment figures are indicative
Location: TBC Bank is headquartered in Tbilisi, Georgia with 11 branches all but six of which are located in this city.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category FI Type 2 project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  Under IFC''s previous investments in TBC, the Bank has established an environmental management system (EMS) to ensure that investments are consistent with applicable Georgian and IFC/World Bank environmental requirements and exclusion list, and has been submitting annual environmental performance reports to IFC''s satisfaction.  For the duration of this new investment, TBC will be required to maintain its EMS and continue to provide annual environmental reports.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Description:
The project consists of the acquisition and refurbishment of five hotels and lodges in Kenya that previously comprised Lonrho Hotels Kenya B.V. These are the following:

-  Norfolk Hotel, Nairobi (167 rooms)
-  Mount Kenya Safari Club (114 rooms)
-  Mara Safari Club (50 room tents)
-  Ark Safari Lodge, Aberdare (60 rooms)
-  Aberdare Country Club (48 rooms)

Acquisition has been recently finalized for $33.4 million and refurbishment cost is estimated at $29.6 million, for a total project cost of $63.0 million.

Kenya is rich in tourism assets and after suffering in the last few years mainly due to security concerns, signs of recovery are apparent.  In addition to capitalizing on the upswing in demand in Kenya, the sponsors believe the project will create significant value by:

-  enhancing performance through stronger management; 
-  positioning the hotels to effectively compete at the top end of the market; 
-  leveraging off KHI and Fairmont's international exposure; and 
-  benefiting from KHI's economies of scale in the Africa region.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The review of this project consisted of appraising technical and environmental/social information submitted by the project sponsor.  The following potential environment, health and safety, and social impacts of the projects were analyzed.-  waste disposal and treatment;-  water and power supply;-  energy efficiency;-  guest and staff safety;-  fire safety; and-  staff training.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityIFC requires that this document is made available through the World Bank InfoShop and to the locally affected community no less than 30 days prior to project consideration by the IFC Board of Directors. The  ERS will be translated into Swahili and made available locally through the five properties, and the respective local municipal offices of Nairobi, Nanyuki, Ol Choro Oirowua and Nyeri; availability of the document at these locations will be advertised in a national newspaper and notices of it's availability should be posted at the local municipal offices.  In addition oral presentations of the ERS in Maa will be made at Ol Choro Oirowua
Sponsor:
The project is sponsored by Kingdom Hotel Investment Group ('KHI'), Fairmont Hotels, Inc. ('Fairmont'), and International Financial Advisors Hotels and Resorts ('IFA Hotels and Resorts') (together, known as the 'Sponsors').
KHI, chaired by Prince Alwaleed bin Talal of Saudi Arabia, is a private equity group engaged in the hospitality and leisure business mostly in the Middle East and Africa.  Fairmont is one of North America's leading operator of luxury hotels and resorts with a distinctive collection.  IFA Hotels and Resorts is a Kuwaiti-based tourism and real estate development company active in the Middle East, Europe and Africa. 
The project's five hotel properties were acquired by a joint venture formed by KHI, IFA and Fairmont. The following summarizes the shareholders of the joint venture and their corresponding equity interest.

KHI - 55%
IFA Hotels and Resorts - 30%
Fairmont - 15%
Cost Nature:
The total project cost is estimated at $63.0 million.  It includes a purchase price for the hotel properties of approximately $33 million and a refurbishment of the hotels at a cost of $25.6 million. Working capital needs and interest during construction have also been included as part of the project cost. 

The proposed financial plan includes equity of $33.4 million and cash generation of $4.6 million.  Debt financing includes an IFC A Loan of $15 million, an IFC C Loan of US$5 million and a Fairmont loan of $5 million.
Investment: 20.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan20.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location:
The following is a summary description of each hotel property:

-  The Norfolk (167 rooms)
The Norfolk Hotel has been one of Nairobi's most storied gathering places since it opened in 1904 hosting notables like American President Theodore Roosevelt, Lord Baden-Powell and Baroness Karen Von Blixen-Finecke, better known as Out of Africa author Isak Dinesen. Today, this 167-room hotel 30-minutes from Jomo Kenyatta International Airport continues to provide a sophisticated respite from the bustling nearby business district and an ideal safari departure point, complete with four impressive dining venues, an outdoor heated swimming pool, a full-scale health club, a ballroom and four function rooms.

Mount Kenya Safari Club (114 rooms)
Located 190 kilometers (118 miles) north of Nairobi, the 115-room Mount Kenya Safari Club showcases magnificent views of neighboring Mount Kenya and a long-held reputation for secluded elegance including a variety of cottages, suites and villas. Spread over 100 acres of landscaped grounds, the property features a nine-hole golf course, heated swimming pool, horseback riding, bird walks, organized trips to game reserves, fishing as well as access to an animal orphanage. Seven restaurant and bar offerings range from casual poolside cocktails to formal dinners accompanied by music and traditional Chukka dancers. Originally the retreat of movie star and Club founder, William Holden, illustrious members have included Winston Churchill, Bing Crosby and John Wayne..

Mara Safari Club (50 room tents)
The Mara Safari Club is located at the foot of the Aitong Hills, northwest of the Masai Mara Game Reserve, Kenya's most popular game reserve, on the Ol Choro Oirowua Group Ranch. This expansive lodge with dining room, lounge and pool bar is surrounded by lush gardens clustered around indigenous trees. The 50 tented accommodations include deluxe beds, en suite baths and other features of a top hotel. Guests can choose from a wide range of activities, including game drives, walking safaris, bird walks, fishing and balloon safaris over the Mara plains. A naturalist, traditional dancing and talks on Masai culture enrich this luxurious adventure.

The Aberdare Country Club (48 rooms)
Described as "Scotland with lions," the unique 1,300-acre setting of the Aberdare Country Club encompasses moorland, thick forests and clear mountain streams. An easy three-hour transfer from Nairobi, this 1930s country hotel was originally built on the slope of Mweiga Hill as the private farm and residence of wealthy English landowners. The hotel's 48 accommodations are in luxurious cottages with spectacular views of the Aberdare Mountains to the west, Mount Kenya to the east and the plains below. Beyond a main lodge dining room with two lounges and a well-equipped conference center, the Club offers a nine-hole golf course, swimming pool, two tennis courts, riding stables, trout fishing and a wildlife sanctuary that abounds with zebra, giraffe, gazelles and even the elusive leopard.

The Ark (60 rooms)
Built in 1969 to complement the Aberdare Club, The Ark is a tree-lodge set in the heart of Aberdare National Park and uniquely shaped to resemble Noah's Ark. True to its ship-like structure, it overlooks the floodlit Yasabara waterhole and contains 60 "cabins," accommodations with en suite bathrooms. In addition to a main dining room, lounge and bar, this one-of-a- kind safari lodge also features three decks of balconies and a lounge with 24-hour tea and coffee service, providing ideal vantage points for viewing game. A ground-level "bunker" takes you close to the animals for photography and cabins are fitted with buzzers to announce the arrival of the one of the "Big 5" at the forest waterhole.

Project Description: The project involves the establishment of a facility for IFC to provide up to MXN300 million of credit enhancement for the senior tranches of residential mortgage-backed securities (RMBS) to be issued in Mexico.The project would help Mexican private-sector housing sofoles (specialized mortgage finance companies, requiring an aggregate of up to MXN11.7 billion per annum of new long-term financing in order to meet the current demand for new housing) tap domestic institutional investors (controlling at least MXN986 billion of funds but lacking highly-rated securities to purchase for the long term). The need for the sofoles to access alternative sources of long-term funding arises largely from the phased cessation of lending by the government housing development bank to sofoles. Commercial banks which may consider entering the market with RMBS would also benefit from the project.IFCs credit exposure would be to special-purpose vehicles (to be incorporated in future) by which Mexican local-currency residential mortgage loans would be securitized. The securities would be backed by future cash flows from the loan repayments. The loans would be secured by first-ranking mortgages over the owner-occupied properties.
Environmental Social Issues: This project is a category C project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedures. There are minimal environmental or social impacts associated with this project. Therefore, no further environmental or social analysis is required. Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The project sponsors (sofoles or banks to be determined at each RMBS issuance under the project) would be the prospective issuers of individual RMBS in future after the credit enhancement facility is approved by IFC. The major sponsor shareholders would be identified upon the determination of the sponsor at each future RMBS issuance.
Cost Nature: It is estimated that credit enhancement involving an ultimate MXN300 million credit exposure for IFC would help mobilize approximately MXN3.6 billion in additional long-term funding for housing finance institutions through five or more securitizations.
Investment: 30.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuarantee30.0LoanEquity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The project is located in Mexico and would support residential mortgage loan origination all over the country by sofoles and commercial banks. Most of the prospective sponsor financial institutions would probably be headquartered in Mexico City.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This project is a category C project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedures. There are minimal environmental or social impacts associated with this project. Therefore, no further environmental or social analysis is required. Location of environmental documents In locally affected community

Project Description: IFC proposes to provide a loan facility for IFC's own account of up to 5.0 million to FORUS Bank (the bank), of which 3.0 million would be the A' Tranche amd 2.0 million will be in the form of a stand-by tranche that would become available after the bank is fully capitalized.  The loan will be used to support the bank's microfinance lending operations during its formative years of operations.  The loan is expected to be Ruble-linked, to avoid any currency mismatch on the bank's balance sheet.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category FI Type 1 project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  FORUS will be required to designate individuals to have responsibility for the environment and who will attend IFC''s environmental management workshop or an approved equivalent, establish an environmental management system to ensure that activities financed under relevant operations are consistent with applicable Russian environmental, occupational health and safety regulations and IFC''s Microfinance Exclusion List, and submit to IFC an environmental management plan and annual environmental performance reports.     Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: Following receipt of its banking license in June 2005, the bank is expected to be fully capitalized at $12.0 million equivalent, over the next 18 months.  Equity is expected to come from FORA Fund (the fund), a non-profit, non-governmental entity based in Nizhny Novgorod, Russia. The fund has been operating in its current form since 2000, when existing regional organizations that had been working in Russia since 1994 were merged. The fund's operations were originally financed by grants from the governments of the UK, USA, and the UNHCR, as well as from private donors.  The fund is owned by several Opportunity International (OI) network members located in Australia, UK, Germany, USA and Russia. Founded in 1979, OI is an international coalition of microfinance institutions and supporting organizations, with roots in Christian charity.  OI is dedicated to providing opportunities to poor entrepreneurs to transform their lives through small and micro loans.  In 2002, OI was incorporated in Switzerland as a Verein, a not-for-profit, cooperative entity that was selected as the most flexible legal structure. Today, OI has one of the largest global microfinance networks with operations in 27 countries serving over 500,000 clients.  The aggregate equity capital of OI's network is over $90 million equivalent.
Cost Nature: IFC proposes to provide a loan facility for IFC's own account of up to 5.0 million to FORUS Bank.

Project Description: The proposed project is the second phase of the redevelopment and expansion of Sangster International Airport (SIA) under a 30-year build, operate and transfer concession granted by the government of Jamaica (GOJ) to the project company, MBJ Airports Limited (MBJA). As the principal gateway for tourists visiting Jamaicas major resorts, SIA is of particular importance to the countrys tourism infrastructure. The GOJ has made its expansion and modernization a high priority. The project consists of the construction of a new landside terminal facility and the renovation of the existing landside terminal to provide additional arrival, baggage claim and customs facilities, departure lounges, retail concessions and food courts. By the end of the project, SIAs annual handling capacity will have been boosted to 7 million passengers per year, eliminating capacity constraints at SIA for the foreseeable future.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project.  The review of this repeat investment consisted of appraising updated technical and environmental information submitted by MBJ, review of the most recent annual monitoring report submitted to IFC, as well as site visits by IFC staff.  Environmental and social issues associated with this project are essentially the same as those identified for the original investment, and include:·	Subsurface contamination monitoring;·	Stormwater drainage, including impacts on marine ecosystems;·	Solid waste management;·	Liquid effluents and sewage discharge;·	Fuel/Hazardous materials storage and handling, including emergency response;·	Bird hazards to aircraft;·	Aircraft noise;·	Employee health and safety;·	EHS management systems; and·	Community development.IFCs ongoing monitoring of MBJs environmental and social performance, and the appraisal carried out for Phase 2, confirms that the Company is meeting the requirements of the original Loan Agreement, including the Environmental Action Plan, and continues to demonstrate that the activities associated with the final phase of the airport expansion will comply with requirements of the Jamaican National Environmental Protection Agency (NEPA) and applicable World Bank Group policies and guidelines.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityEnvironmental documentation will be made available at the following locations:Administration Office of the Airports Authority of Jamaica at Sangster International Airport and Post Office in Montego Bay.
Sponsor: The Shareholders of MBJA are the following: -  AGUNSA (35% stake), a leading Chilean company in ship agency and integral cargo services which operates in several countries in Latin America. It also controls the concession for Arturo Merino Benítez International Airport in Santiago; -  Grupo Dragados (35% stake), a diversified Spanish construction, engineering and services conglomerate which was purchased in 2003 by Actividades de Construccion y Servicios S.A., Spains biggest construction company. Dragados builds and manages large-scale infrastructure and infrastructure concession projects; -  YVRAS (15% shareholding), which manages 20 airports in seven countries and provides consulting services worldwide. YVRAS is majority-owned (55%) by the Vancouver International Airport Authority, which operates Canadas second busiest airport; and, -  Ashtrom (15% stake) Israel''s leading private development and manufacturing concern which is involved in a wide range of residential and commercial construction and related activities and is one of the leading construction companies in Jamaica. Ashtrom is the EPC contractor for the proposed project.
Cost Nature: The project is the second, and final, phase of a $150 million, multi-year development program at Sangster International Airport (SIA). The cost of Phase 2 is $69.9 million. IFCs proposed phase 2 investment is a $21 million A loan for IFC''s own account and a $21 million B loan for the account of participants.

Project Description: Sibacadembank (SAB or the bank) is a private bank based in Novosibirsk with an extensive branch network in Western and Eastern Siberia.  The bank focuses on lending to SMEs, entrepreneurs and individuals.  SAB had the net worth of approximately $42 million and total assets of approximately $373 million equivalent as of the end of 2004.  The project is intended to support SAB's rapid expansion of its SME and retail lending business and implementation of its strategy of becoming the largest universal bank in the Siberian Federal District ('SFD').  This is a follow-on transaction with SAB.  In 2004, IFC approved a senior loan of $7 million in two tranches for SME lending and an option of $2 million to purchase shares in SAB.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category FI Type 1 project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure.  The bank has already established an environmental management system for its corporate and SME lending operations to ensure that the activities and enterprises it finances comply with Russian environmental and occupational health and safety requirements. Designated SAB officers have already completed IFCs environmental training course for financial intermediaries and the bank will continue to provide IFC with environmental performance reports on an annual basis for the duration of this follow-on investment.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: SAB is currently owned by EBRD (25% plus one share), Igor Kim (33.6%), Andrey Bekarev (16.8%), Alexander Taranov (16.8%), and other shareholders (7.8%).  After registration of the results of the new share issue, the top six shareholders will be EBRD (28.44%), Igor Kim (24.37%), Andrey Bekarev (12.34%), Alexander Taranov (12.19%), DEG (10.31%) and Clariden (6.87%).
Cost Nature: The proposed project consists of a senior unsecured loan of up to US$10 million.  If requested by the Bank, the senior loan may be structured as a Ruble denominated loan to help SAB mitigate its foreign exchange risk, while meeting its SME customers' needs.

Location: SAB is headquartered in Novosibirsk and currently has 8 branches and 123 offices throughout Siberia.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category FI Type 1 project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure.  The bank has already established an environmental management system for its corporate and SME lending operations to ensure that the activities and enterprises it finances comply with Russian environmental and occupational health and safety requirements. Designated SAB officers have already completed IFCs environmental training course for financial intermediaries and the bank will continue to provide IFC with environmental performance reports on an annual basis for the duration of this follow-on investment.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Description:
Guangzhou Development Industry (Holdings) Co., Ltd. (GDIH or the company) has three main business lines: electric power generation, energy logistics and infrastructure.  It is the largest electric power producer in the City of Guangzhou, the largest load center of South China Grid.  GDIH is a publicly listed company on the Shanghai Stock Exchange, and its stock is a component of the Shanghai Stock Exchange 50 Index.  
The Project is to lend an RMB-denominated loan to GDIH in an amount of $50 million equivalent to support the company's on-going capital expenditure program.  As part of IFC's involvement, GDIH has agreed to implement a detailed Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP) which will help GDIH in meeting the applicable World Bank/IFC environmental and social policies and environmental, health and safety guidelines.
Environmental Social Issues:
GDIHs three main business sectors are electric power, energy logistics and infrastructure.  GDIH is the largest electric power generating company in Guangzhou City.  In order to continue to provide reliable supply of electricity, the company is expanding its power generation business by developing a new LNG-fired combined cycle power plant project and investing in several large-scale coal-fired power plant projects.  Some of their power plants and power projects under development are within the Pearl River Delta region where improvement of ambient air quality has been a challenging task by Provincial and Municipal environmental regulators.  GDIH is also promoting energy logistics (coal loading / unloading dock, coal storage yard, oil loading / unloading jetty, oil storage capacity) in Pearl River Delta.  GDHIs infrastructure business includes investment in highway network in the Pearl River Delta and development of natural gas distribution network in Guangzhou Nansha Development Zone.The appraisal by IFC included:- GDIHs environmental and social management system- Environmental and social performance of GDIHs existing and new investments (both directly owned and through investment as a minor shareholder) in the electric power, energy logistics and infrastructure- Environmental benefit of FGD installment- Air quality issue of the Pearl River Delta region- Greenhouse gas emissions and energy efficiency related to GDIHs electric power business.- Health and safety risks associated with coal mines- Environmental and Social Action Plan (ESAP) by GDIHIn order to address issues for risk minimization and opportunities for enhancement of sustainable business operations, GDIH and IFC are working to agree on ESAP, which will be disclosed once finalized. Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityEnvironmental documentation will be made available at the followinglocation:

Financial Department, 
29th Floor, Development Center, No. 3, Linjiang Road, 
Guangzhou, 510623, China
Sponsor: The controlling shareholder of GDIH is Guangzhou Development Group Co., Ltd. (GDGC), a state-owned company under the leadership of the Guangzhou Municipal Government.
Cost Nature: GDIH is planning an investment program in an amount of approximately $440 million equivalent in different industries, including power generation, shipping, fuel oil logistics, natural gas distribution, etc.  The proposed IFC investment involves a 10-year RMB-denominated loan to GDIH in an amount of $50 million equivalent, in support of GDIH's on-going capital expenditure program.

In addition, GDIH has an investment as a minority shareholder in a mine-mouth coal-fired power plant under construction in Pannan, Guizhou Province.

Company Name: Open joint-stock company "Urals Commercial Bank For Foreign Trade" ("Uralvneshtorgbank")
Project Description: The project is to provide a $15 million financing package to Uralvneshtorgbank (UVTB or the bank), a medium-sized regional bank based in Yekaterinburg, Russia. UVTB specializes in lending to Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs) and individuals.  The proposed IFC financing would support UVTB's strategy and assist in its expansion.  The bank is one of the market leaders in Yekaterinburg (a large industrial city in the Urals), the greater Yekaterinburg area and neighboring regions, which it considers its home market.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category FI Type 1 project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure. UVTB is required to establish an environmental management system (EMS) to the satisfaction of IFC. The EMS should ensure that the SME enterprises it finances comply with Russian environmental and occupational health and safety requirements, and that the micro-finance investments are incompliance with the microfinance exclusion list. Designated UVTB officers will need to complete IFCs environmental training course for financial intermediaries and the bank will need to provide IFC with environmental performance reports on an annual basis.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: UVTB's two main shareholders are Messrs. Igor Kim, a Novosibirsk-based Russian banker with approximately 46%, and his business partners, Yury Koropachinsky and Oleg Kirillov who own together approximately 46% of the bank's share capital as beneficiary shareholders. The remaining approximately 8% belong to small corporate shareholders, among them Vneshtorgbank with a 0.001% stake, the bank's management and employees with a 0.26% stake, and individuals.
Cost Nature: The project is to provide a $15 million financing package, which may include equity, quasi-equity and loan financing.

Location: The head office of UVTB is based in Yekaterinburg, a large industrial city in the Urals. The bank has approximately 12 branches across important regional centers in Russia and a number of supporting offices.

UVTB is required to establish an environmental management system (EMS) to the satisfaction of IFC. Project Description: The proposed project consists of the construction and operation of a grain river port terminal at Timbues (Timbues Port), located about 340 km from Buenos Aires on the lower Parana River in Santa Fe province.  The project will be constructed and operated by Noble Argentina S.A. (Noble Argentina or the company).  Established in 2001, Noble Argentina is a commodity trader that offers a range of highly diversified agricultural commodity products, as well as logistics and technical services.  The project includes:-  the acquisition of 201 hectares of land with 1,800 m of waterfront; -  the construction of a truck parking area and facilities for sampling, conditioning and storage; and -  the purchase of equipment.  Timbues Port will have a storage capacity of 120,000 tons and will be able to accommodate a throughput of about 2.5 million tons of grain per year, consisting mainly of exports of wheat, corn and soybeans.  Construction began at the end of February 2005 and the project is expected to be completed by July 2006.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category B project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure.  Potential environmental issues associated with the project that were reviewed during appraisal include: -  environmental, health and safety performance of the existing Delta Dock grain terminal operated by Noble Argentina; -  Timbues site land acquisition and related social impacts; -  dust emissions from grain handling and storage; -  effluent and stormwater discharges; -  hazardous materials/pesticide handling and storage; -  emergency preparedness and response (including fire and explosion prevention); -  employee health and safety (including workplace air quality and noise); and -  environmental, health and safety management systems.IFCs Environmental and Social Department staffs review of this project considered: -  information collected during the appraisal visit of the Delta Dock grain terminal; -  the appraisal visit of the Timbues port site; and -  the Environmental Impact Assessment of the Timbues Port and other relevant documentation provided by the company.  Based on this review, Noble Argentina demonstrates that its operations at Delta Dock comply, and the Timbues Port project will comply, with applicable Argentine laws and regulations, and World Bank/IFC requirements.  Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityEnvironmental documentation will be made available at the following location:Timbues Port.  Brigadier E. López S/N.  Zona Industrial.  CP  (2204).  Timbúes.  Santa Fe.  Argentina.
Sponsor: The project sponsor is the Noble Group.  Founded in 1987 and headquartered in Hong Kong, the Noble Group is a major commodity trading group.  Noble Argentina is 99% owned by Stelmont Group Limited, which is wholly-owned by Noble Group Limited, the holding company of the Noble Group.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $51.2 million.  The proposed IFC investment comprises an A Loan of $18 million, for IFCs own account, and a syndicated B Loan of $18 million, for the account of participant banks.
Investment: 18.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan18.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The Timbues Port project will be a new grain river port located on the lower Parana River in Santa Fe province, about 35 km north of Rosario or 340 km from Buenos Aires.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category B project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure.  Potential environmental issues associated with the project that were reviewed during appraisal include: -  environmental, health and safety performance of the existing Delta Dock grain terminal operated by Noble Argentina; -  Timbues site land acquisition and related social impacts; -  dust emissions from grain handling and storage; -  effluent and stormwater discharges; -  hazardous materials/pesticide handling and storage; -  emergency preparedness and response (including fire and explosion prevention); -  employee health and safety (including workplace air quality and noise); and -  environmental, health and safety management systems.IFCs Environmental and Social Department staffs review of this project considered: -  information collected during the appraisal visit of the Delta Dock grain terminal; -  the appraisal visit of the Timbues port site; and -  the Environmental Impact Assessment of the Timbues Port and other relevant documentation provided by the company.  Based on this review, Noble Argentina demonstrates that its operations at Delta Dock comply, and the Timbues Port project will comply, with applicable Argentine laws and regulations, and World Bank/IFC requirements.
