Project Description: Wataniya Telecom, the second cellular operator in Kuwait, currently serving 3.2 million subscribers in the MENA region, was awarded the second nationwide GSM license in the Maldives through its local subsidiary Wataniya Maldives Private Limited (WTM or the company) in November 2004 for a license fee of $1 million.  The license award was the result of an open, competitive auction with other bidders including Telekom Malaysia, Syriatel Mobile Telecom and the Bharat Consortium.  The project consists of the financing of network roll-out and related start-up losses as well as a fiber optic submarine cable, for a total estimated project cost of $70 million equivalent.  IFC has been asked to provide a senior loan of $17.5 million, to be complemented by a similar $7 million loan from the OPEC Fund and a revolving facility of $5 million from the Bank of Maldives.
Environmental Social Issues: This project is a category C project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedures. There are minimal environmental or social impacts associated with this project. Therefore, no further environmental or social analysis is required. Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: Wataniya Telecom (or the Group) was established in 1999 as the second cellular operator in Kuwait and has since expanded into the MENA region.  To focus on its international expansion strategy, it bundled its operations outside Kuwait by setting up Wataniya International FZ LLC (Wataniya International or the sponsor) in mid 2004.  Wataniya International, based in Dubai, offers strategic support to the Groups operations in Algeria, Iraq, Maldives, Saudi Arabia and Tunisia and is pursuing further growth opportunities.  By acquiring the license in the Maldives, the Group has made its first acquisition outside of the MENA region.  With its existing operations, the sponsor has substantial experience in building and successfully operating GSM networks as a second and third market entrant.  The sponsor is wholly owned by Wataniya Telecom, which has been listed on the Kuwait Stock Exchange since 1999 and had a market capitalization of $2.9 billion equivalent by end of March 2005.  At present, 45% of the Groups shares are publicly held, while KIPCO (Kuwait Projects Company Holding, the largest non-government company in Kuwait with over $10 billion equivalent under management or control) owns 31%, and the Kuwait Investment Authority the remaining 24%.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $70 million.  The proposed IFC investment is a US $17.5 m senior loan.
Investment: 20.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan20.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Wataniya Maldives Private Limiteds headquarter is located on Hulhumale.  By building a nationwide greenfield cellular network, the company is providing mobile phone services to all inhabited islands in the Maldives.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This project is a category C project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedures. There are minimal environmental or social impacts associated with this project. Therefore, no further environmental or social analysis is required. Location of environmental documents In locally affected community

Project Description: The project companies are Newmont Ghana Gold Limited (NGGL) and Rank Mining Company (Rank Mining), both wholly owned Ghanaian subsidiaries of Newmont Gold Corporation (Newmont).  The project involves the development of two mining leases: the Ahafo lease owned by NGGL and the Rank mining lease owned by Rank Mining.  Newmont gained control of the two leases (via NGGL and Rank Mining) after its merger with Normandy in 2002.  The project involves the construction of a greenfield open cast gold mine and associated facilities (the mill facility, a tailings storage facility, a water storage facility, construction camp and access roadways) to mine, process and extract gold.  It will have an estimated mine life of 20 years producing approximately 500,000 oz. of gold per annum at an estimated cash cost of $225/oz.  The projects reserves currently stand at 11.7 million ounces (157 million tonnes grading 2.31 g/tonne) with a further 15.4 million ounces of resources (217 million tones grading 2.22 g/tonne).  It is expected to start producing gold in mid 2006.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category A project according to IFC's Environmental and Social Review Procedure.  The key environmental and social issue which is associated with this project, and which has been reviewed in detail during project appraisal, is ensuring broad community support (particularly relating to resettlement and livelihood restoration).  The sensitivity of the project is the reason three separate appraisal missions have been undertaken.  These missions provided adequate assurance that Newmont are planning and designing their approach within WBG Policies & Guidelines.The project extends over a strike length of about 16km although the known ore deposits extend to about 70 km, trending in a SW-NE direction.  Initially, a processing plant and four southern pits will be developed, and an ESIA has been completed covering these deposits.  Later, NGGL may develop ore deposits further north along the strike, which may include up to ten new pits.  Should NGGL decide to proceed to develop the north deposits, a full ESIA in accordance with IFC Policies and Guidelines would be prepared and disclosed.The southern deposits and the reserves further north are bisected by a narrow strip of gazetted forest reserve.  Newmont is implementing a bio-diversity management plan to ensure that its operations do not cause any significant degradation or conversion of critical natural habitats. Other significant issues with this mining development will include those common to all large gold mining operations, including handling of cyanide and other hazardous materials, and tailings facility management. NGGL is committed to implement a socially responsible business model and to improve the economic situation of local communities through the mining operation.  Consultation with local groups have been taking place since early 2003.  NGGL staff work hard to ensure that good relations are maintained with local communities.  NGGL has a capable local team of competent staff working together with partners including local NGOs, international development NGOs (OICI), and Ghanaian communication professionals (StratCom).The development of the project involves 3,111 hectares of total mine area and is expected to result in the physical or economic displacement of 1,701 households.The resettlement planning efforts have been a collaborative process with project-affected persons.  Resettlement principles, policies, procedures, and compensation rates have been determined through multi-stakeholder involvement in a Resettlement Negotiation Committee (RNC), which includes representatives of villages, traditional authorities, local government, and non-governmental organizations, and NGGL.  This has resulted in a Resettlement Action Plan that will be disclosed publicly.In order to achieve livelihood restoration, resettlement and community development programs include programs geared toward job training and creation as well as an ongoing search for both ways to enhance agricultural productivity on underutilized land and identification of replacement land through traditional systems in coordination with traditional leaders.  These efforts are complemented by community development initiatives including provision of water, sanitation, upgrading of the local clinics and training centers, and small and medium enterprise (SME) activities that can enhance the sustainability of positive economic impacts of the project. NGGL has also launched an HIV/AIDS program for workers and their families and a program on malaria prevention.  IFCs SME program is developing linkage programs that can further maximize the local development impact.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityHard copies of the project documents will be available at the following locations:- At NGGL Kenyase Office;- At NGGL Office, Accra;- At the Land Valuation Board office (Resettlement Action Plan);- At the Brong-Ahafo Regional Coordinating Council Office;- Offices of the Traditional Authorities at: Kenyase 1 and 2; Ntotoroso; Gyedu; and (iv) Wamahinso;- At the Asutifi District Assembly;- At the Town and Country Planning National Office, Regional Office, and District Office;- At the Brong Ahafo Regional Coordinating Council Office;- Newmont Mining Corporation Web Site: http://www.newmont.com/en/operations/projectpipeline/ghana/index.asp.
Sponsor: The Sponsor is Newmont Mining Gold Corporation (Newmont), a company listed on the New York Stock Exchange and with parallel listings in Canada and Australia.  It has a market capitalization of about $17.5 billion with producing operations in the US, Canada, Mexico, Bolivia, Peru, Uzbekistan, Indonesia, Australia, and New Zealand.  In 2004, Newmont produced about 7 million ounces of gold from these countries, representing 9% of global mine supply, at an average cash cost of $231/oz.  It earned revenue and net income of $4,524 million and $434 million respectively, and cash flow from operations was $1,557 million.  At the end of 2004, Newmonts gold reserves stood at 92.4 million ounces, it had $1.6 billion in long-term debt (Rated BBB+ by Standard and Poors), and over $2.1 billion in cash and marketable securities.  Newmonts current exploration efforts are focused on Peru, Ghana, Nevada and Australia.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $470 million. The proposed IFC investment is a $75 million A loan for IFCs own account and a $50 million syndicated B loan.
Investment: 75.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan75.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative

It is approximately 42 km from the nearby Sunyani town (Sunyani is a major regional center  with a modern hospital, schools, banks and a post office) and close to the twin towns of Kenyase (Kenyase 1 and Kenyase 2).  The dominant activity in the area is primarily subsistence farming.

Company Name: PUBLIC JOINT STOCK COMPANY NBD BANK
Project Description: The project is a follow-on 5-year senior, secured loan of up to $5 million to NBD Bank (NBD or the bank) for on-lending to local SMEs in Russia. The SME sector remains underserved in Russia, as most larger banks shy away from the smaller clients in pursuit of large corporates.  NBD remains among the few regional banks with technical capacity and experience to effectively and efficiently serve this segment.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category FI Type 1 project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure.  The Bank will need to demonstrate that it has maintained an environmental management system that is adequate to identify and address any environmental and social issues associated with its projects, and has adequate staff and resources in place for the same.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: NBD was established in 1992 under the initiative of the local government of Nizhny Novgorod, Russia.  Despite its small size, NBD became one of the leading banks active in the SME segment in the region.  NBD continues its focus on SMEs, entrepreneurs, individuals and aims to remain a leading regional, independent institution, providing services to smaller enterprises and limited non-lending specialized services to larger companies.  According to the Bank, in Nizhny Novgorod region NBD has about 30% market share in the SME sector and a 60%-70% share in the sub-segment of sole proprietorship companies, catering to the needs of about 5,000 SME clients through its 13 branches in the region.The main shareholders and their percentage of voting stock they hold are: Nizegorod Promstroiproect (36.9%), EBRD (25.0%), Region (21.66%). The bank is independent from large financial industrial groups which dominate large parts of the Russian economy.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $5 million.  The proposed IFC investment is $5 million A loan for IFCs own account.
Investment: 5.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan5.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The bank is located in Nizhny Novgorod, Russian Federation, and has 13 branches throughout the Nizhny Novgorod region.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category FI Type 1 project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure.  The Bank will need to demonstrate that it has maintained an environmental management system that is adequate to identify and address any environmental and social issues associated with its projects, and has adequate staff and resources in place for the same.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community

Project Description: Suzano Petroquimica S.A. (Suzano or the company) is one of the largest petrochemical companies in Brazil that, through its controlled company Polibrasil Resinas S.A. (Polibrasil), and its joint controlled companies, Politeno Industria e Comercio S.A. (Politeno) and Petroflex Industria e Comercio S.A. (Petroflex), produces, markets and distributes petrochemical products. The company was incorporated in 2001 as a result of a corporate reorganization that culminated in a spin-off of all petrochemical assets then held by Companhia Suzano de Papel e Celulose (a former IFC client).  These companies produce three main products: polypropylene (PP), in the case of Polibrasil, polyethylene (PE), and synthetic elastomers, which are sold in both the domestic and the international markets. The company also has a controlling block of a new company, Rio Polimeros S.A. (Rio Polimeros), which is building the first petrochemical complex in Brazil that will use natural gas fractions as raw material and has integrated ethylene and polyethylene production units.  The project under consideration includes the buyout of Basell''s 50% stake in Polibrasil with the aim to hold 100% ownership of the company, the announced corporate restructuring, the debottlenecking of Polibrasils operations and debt refinancing. The acquisition was announced on June 20, 2005 and was completed on September 1st 2005.  By taking full control of Polibrasil, Suzano will become an operating company, positioned as one of Latin Americas largest thermoplastic resins producers and the largest PP producer.  This acquisition enables Suzano to become a major integrated petrochemicals player, instead of an investor and holding company, positioning itself as a consolidating agent in the Brazilian petrochemical sector in the Southeast region.  Suzano will also implement a corporate restructuring aimed at simplifying its group structure and turn itself into an operational company as disclosed to the market on its press release of September 1st, 2005.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project. Environmental, social and health and safety issues associated with this project to be confirmed during appraisal include: corporate environmental, health and safety management programs, energy efficiency, HAZOP upgrades; solid/hazardous waste management, on-site hazardous material management, emergency preparedness and response, liquid effluents management, air emissions control, occupational health and safety including workplace noise, community relationships, community development programs, supply chain (suppliers) non-commercial interactions.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe environmental documentation will be disclosed for a period of 30 days at the following locations and municipalities (prefeituras):- Prefeitura Municipal de Camaçari    Secretaria de Planejamento e Meio Ambiente    Rua Francisco Drummond, s/n    Working hours: Monday to Friday, from 08:00 to 14:00- Prefeitura Municipal de Dias DÁvila  Secretaria de Desenvolvimento Econômico   Rua Raul Seixas, 418 Centro   Working hours: from Monday to Friday, from 08:00 to 14:00- Prefeitura Municipal de Duque de Caxias  Secretaria de Desenvolvimento Econômico de Duque de Caxias   Alameda Dona Esmeralda, 206 Jd. Sponsor: The company is a publicly held corporation.  The Feffer family holds, directly and indirectly, all the outstanding common shares and approximately 9,32% of the preferred shares through Suzano Holding S.A., some other parties related to the Feffer family hold approximately 45,62% of the preferred shares, and the remaining 45,07% is free float.Leon Feffer founded Suzano group in 1924.  The Feffer family are long-time entrepreneurs in the pulp and paper market, and they initiated activities in the petrochemical sector in 1974.  The members of the Feffer family who are currently on the Board of Directors are: David Feffer (48), President of the Board, his brother Daniel Feffer (45), Vice-President of the Board, and Jorge Feffer (44 - another brother), member of the Board. The three brothers are sons of Max Feffer, who was the son of Leon Feffer.
Cost Nature: Total project cost is approximately $452 million.  The proposed IFC Investment is a corporate loan of $60 million for its own account and $140 million as a B loan.

Location: The industrial complex of Polibrasil is formed by three facilities producing polypropylene resins with a combined annual production capacity of 625.0 thousand tons, located in the municipalities of Duque de Caxias, State of Rio de Janeiro, Mauá, State of São Paulo, and Camaçari, State of Bahia.  Inaugurated in 1992, the Duque de Caxias facility has a production capacity of 200.0 thousand tons per year, and produces homopolymers and random copolymers using Lipp technology.  The new polypropylene industrial facility located in Mauá has world-size production scale of 300.0 thousand tons per year, using the latest generation Spheripol technology licensed by Basell Polyolefins and is located in Brazil''s main consumer market.  The Camaçari industrial facility in Bahia was inaugurated in 1978.  This facility has an installed capacity of 125.0 thousand tons per year, and produces homopolymers and heterophasic copolymers.

Project Description: Arcor S.A.I.C. (Arcor or the company) is one of the leading producers and distributors of candies, chocolates and cookies in South America.  The project entails providing a corporate loan to Arcor to lengthen the maturities of its debt and to finance its capital expenditures program.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. Arcor and its subsidiaries are vertically integrated with industrial operations in the dairy, maize, sugar, and packaging industries, among others.

Project Description: Socketworks Limited (Socketworks or the company) is a privately held Nigerian limited liability corporation.  It was established in June 2002.  It has been supported by the IFC since this time by way of capacity-building and advisory support services through the African Project Development Facility (APDF).  Socketworks is a software and outsourcing company that aims to provide packaged ICT solutions to its clients.  In the education market, it has developed software (trademarked CollegePortal) that has been endorsed by the Nigerian Universities Commission as the most suitable management software for Nigerias universities.  Socketworks packaged solution for universities is helping universities automate their processes (eg: student admissions and registration, course selection, course management, exam management, facility management) that are currently done manually and is providing internet access that would not otherwise be available.  These services are making an enormous difference to universities in Nigeria that otherwise have no ICT systems.  Socketworks is currently focused on the Nigerian markets, but has ambitions to expand to other countries in Africa.
Environmental Social Issues: This project is a category C project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedures. There are minimal environmental or social impacts associated with this project. Therefore, no further environmental or social analysis is required. Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The project sponsors are: President and CEO of Socketworks, Aloy Chife and Executive Director Roland Ewubare.  Aloy has served as Director (Business Systems and Processes) for Apple Computers in Silicon Valley, as IT Director for Enron Corporation in Houston, Texas, and as a Project Executive with IBM Global Services.  He holds a PhD in economics from London School of Economics.  Roland was previously executive director of Schlumberger Nigeria.  Prior to that, he held various senior roles as counsel in Schlumberger, primarily in the United States.  Roland holds a Master of Laws degree from Harvard.Socketworks has a nine person Board.  Aloy Chife and Roland Ewubare, sit on that Board.  Six of the other seven Board members comprise senior executives or former executives of large multinational or Nigerian corporations.  The one remaining Board seat is held by Zenith Bank.Ownership of Socketworks is as follows: Aloy Chife (CEO) 46%; Fola Adeola (Board memner) 10%; Pius Onobhayedo 7%; Roland Ewubare (Executive Director) 13%; Tunde Sotunde (Board member) 1%; Zenith Bank 10%; and Socketworks employee stock option plan 13%.
Cost Nature: The project to be financed involves the implementation of 11 new contracts to provide fitout, hardware, and software to university campuses in Nigeria.  (Socketworks have already implemented 10 similar contracts.)  Each of these implementations requires an investment of, on average, $500k (of which approximately 60% is for capital expenditure).  Thus, the project requires an investment of approximately $5.5m.The proposed IFC investment is a $2.5 million C for IFCs own account.  The C loan will be a partially convertible loan.
Investment: 2.50 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan2.50Equity0.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Universities to have IT installations by Socketworks as a part of this project include: Imo State University, Owerri; Abubakar Tafewa University, Bauchi; University of Ilorin; University of Abuja; Federal University of Technology, Yola; Ahmadu Bello University, Zaria; Ebonyi State University, Abakaliki; Rivers Redeemers University; and Yaba College of Technology.  All of these universities are in Nigeria.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This project is a category C project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedures. There are minimal environmental or social impacts associated with this project. Therefore, no further environmental or social analysis is required. Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sector: AB - Colleges, Universities, and Professional Schools

Project Description: Carnex a.d. (Carnex or the company) is the leading meat producer in Serbia & Montenegro (SaM) and was founded in 1958 as an integrated meat operation, which developed over 250 products with a strong market share in former Yugoslavia and exported products to Great Britain, USA, the former Soviet Union, Germany, Spain, Australia, Bulgaria and Jordan.  With the disintegration of Yugoslavia during the nineties, Carnex lost parts of its operations and a large part of its market. The project is for Carnex to increase: -  meat production from 18,000 tpa to 25,000 tpa within existing plants; -  Feed production capacity from 36,000 tpa to 72,000 tpa; -  swine production capacity from 70,000 pigs p.a. to 140,000 pigs p.a.; -  grain drying and storage from 50,000 tpa to 70,000 tpa; and -  irrigation equipment to improve crop production.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The review of this project consisted of appraising technical, environmental, health and safety, and social/community information submitted by the project sponsor as well as site visits to Carnex operations in and around Vrbas.  The following potential environment, health and safety, and social/community impacts of the projects were analyzed.-  Compliance with international quality standards including Hazard Analysis and Critical-  Control Point (HACCP) certification;-  Improvement in worker health and safety (OHS) management and performance;-  Compliance with Serbian, EU and IFC environmental requirements;-  Employment issues including retrenchment; and -  Social and community issues and involvement. Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe Environmental Review Summary (ERS) was posted on September 13, 2005 in Vrbas Municipality Building and on the Carnexs website (www.carnex.co.yu).Links to website:English version  http://www.carnex.co.yu/pdf_files/IFCProjectEn.pdfSerbian version - http://www.carnex.co.yu/pdf_files/MFKProjektSr.pdf
Sponsor: The project Sponsor is Midland Resources Holdings (Midland).  Midland acquired 51.3% of Carnex a.d. by buying stock from individual shareholders in a public auction at the Belgrade stock exchange in August 2003.  The other major shareholders of the company are the Share Fund (31.1%) and PIO Fund (9.76%).  Several small shareholders own the remaining 7.8%. Midland, a Guernsey based company, is a privately owned trading and investment holding company, with interests in a broad range of industries including steel, shipping, construction and real estate, energy distribution and agriculture.  The Group operates in Eastern Europe, CIS, Turkey, China and the Far East.
Cost Nature: Total project cost is estimated to be Euro 25 million.  The proposed IFC investment is Euro 16 million A Loan for IFCs own account.
Location: Carnexs operations are located in and around Vrbas, near Novisad in Serbia.  In addition to the processing plant in Vrbas, Carnex has a feedmill, pig farms, cropping farms and silos.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The review of this project consisted of appraising technical, environmental, health and safety, and social/community information submitted by the project sponsor as well as site visits to Carnex operations in and around Vrbas.  The following potential environment, health and safety, and social/community impacts of the projects were analyzed.-  Compliance with international quality standards including Hazard Analysis and Critical-  Control Point (HACCP) certification;-  Improvement in worker health and safety (OHS) management and performance;-  Compliance with Serbian, EU and IFC environmental requirements;-  Employment issues including retrenchment; and -  Social and community issues and involvement. Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe Environmental Review Summary (ERS) was posted on September 13, 2005 in Vrbas Municipality Building and on the Carnexs website (www.carnex.co.yu).Links to website:English version  http://www.carnex.co.yu/pdf_files/IFCProjectEn.pdfSerbian version - http://www.carnex.co.yu/pdf_files/MFKProjektSr.pdf

Project Description: The project consists of a senior loan of up to EUR75 million to Banca Comerciala Romana SA (BCR or the bank). The Loan will be used to support the Banks long-term funding activities and prudently manage its balance sheet by enabling it to address maturity mismatches between long-term currency assets and short-term currency liabilities, and release the necessary funding to support the growth and expansion of Romanian private sector entities.The proposed loan is being processed in parallel with BCRs on-going privatization which is expected to be completed by the end of FY 2005.BCR was incorporated in 1990 as a spin-off of the National Bank of Romania, which carried out the majority of banking activities in Romania during the former communist regime. Five newly-established state-owned banks were created according to customer profile, similar to other bank restructurings in former communist regime countries. The clients transferred to BCR comprised mainly the countrys largest state-owned industrial companies. Over the last decade, however, the Banks customer base has moved away from the state-owned corporate sector to private enterprises and individuals.BCR is the largest bank in Romania in terms of assets (US$9.2 billion as of June 30, 2005) and customer base (5 million clients). It operates as a full-fledged commercial bank, with a focus on expanding its business with small and medium-sized enterprises. As at the end of March 2005, the Banks market share accounted for 26% of banking assets.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an FI Type 1 project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure. Under previous investments by IFC, the Bank has implemented an Environmental Management System (EMS), which mandates compliance by corporate and SME borrowers with Romanian environmental, health and safety standards. The EMS was elaborated taking into consideration IFC''s social and environmental standards and the relevant IFC exclusion list. A technical assistance program to enhance BCR''s capacity to manage environmental and social issues is being funded by IFC''s Sustainable Financial Markets Facility. The bank has been submitting Annual Environmental Performance Reports (AEPRs). BCR will be required to maintain its EMS and continue providing AEPRs for the duration of this new investment.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The bank is 36.88%-owned by the Government via the Assets Recovery Agency (AVAS). Five financial investment companies (SIFs), previously called Private Ownership Funds, were created as tools for assisting the mass privatization process following the breakdown of the former communist regime. They control another 30.12%. The SIFs are organized on a regional basis, each fund receiving the state enterprises located in its area as well as some specific industries (financial institutions were evenly distributed among the five funds). Individuals were given privatization vouchers which they exchanged for shares in the SIFs, which are listed on the Bucharest Stock Exchange.
Cost Nature: The proposed IFC investment is a EUR 75 million A loan for IFCs account.
Investment: 89.94 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan89.94Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: BCR is headquartered in Bucharest, Romania. The bank has a comprehensive nationwide branch network of 339 outlets, employing more than 12,000 individuals.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is an FI Type 1 project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure. Under previous investments by IFC, the Bank has implemented an Environmental Management System (EMS), which mandates compliance by corporate and SME borrowers with Romanian environmental, health and safety standards. The EMS was elaborated taking into consideration IFC''s social and environmental standards and the relevant IFC exclusion list. A technical assistance program to enhance BCR''s capacity to manage environmental and social issues is being funded by IFC''s Sustainable Financial Markets Facility. The bank has been submitting Annual Environmental Performance Reports (AEPRs). BCR will be required to maintain its EMS and continue providing AEPRs for the duration of this new investment.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community

Project Description: Banco Davivienda S.A. (Davivienda or the bank) is a longstanding IFC client and the fourth largest financial institution in Colombia, with approximately $3 billion of assets and $390 million of equity as of August 2005. Originally specialized in mortgage lending, Davivienda has since diversified its product offering to become a full service commercial bank in Colombia. Having consistently delivered strong financial results, Davivienda has currently a local long-term credit rating of AAA by Fitch Ratings. The Bank is seeking to raise subordinated and medium-term senior debt to strengthen its balance sheet, diversify funding sources, maintain its strong liquidity position and improve the Banks capitalization levels. The project consists of a financing package of up to $120 million to support the expansion and consolidation of the Banks operations in Colombia. The project will help Davivienda continue to expand its retail business while maintaining a strong presence in the mortgage industry.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category FI Type 1 project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  Davivienda will be required to designate individuals to have responsibility for the environment and who will attend IFC''s environmental management workshop or an approved equivalent, establish an environmental management system to ensure that activities financed under relevant operations (e.g., corporate, construction, and SME lending) are consistent with applicable Colombian environmental, occupational health and safety regulations and the relevant IFC Exclusion List, and submit to IFC an environmental management plan and annual environmental performance reports.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The project sponsor is Davivienda, which is majority owned (66.25%) by Grupo Bolivar. Founded in 1938, Grupo Bolívar is the fifth largest economic conglomerate in Colombia and focuses on the financial sector.  The Group is a strong player in the insurance industry, with the second largest insurance company in Colombia, including life and general insurance. Grupo Bolívars companies include strong players such as Davivienda itself, Seguros Bolívar, Leasing Bolívar, Constructora Bolívar and a host of smaller entities such as a mutual fund, trust company, stock broker and beach resort.  Furthermore, Davivienda recently acquired a controlling stake in Banco Superior (Bansuperior), a successful commercial bank in Colombia with a strong position on retail banking, especially on the credit card business.
Cost Nature: The project consists of a financing package of up to $120 million equivalent to Davivienda. The Facility will comprise of:-  a Colombian peso subordinated loan of up to $60 million equivalent with a final maturity of up to ten years and a conversion option to be negotiated, and -  a senior loan comprised of an IFC A loan of up to $20 million and a parallel loan of up to $40 million for the account of participant banks, both with a final maturity of up to five years.
Investment: 50.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan35.0Equity15.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Davivienda, headquartered in Bogotá, provides a wide coverage of products and services in Colombia. Davivienda services its more than 2 million customers through a nation-wide network of 216 branches and 3,933 employees, operating in 45 towns and cities. Additionally, Bansuperior has 56 branches nationwide and 1900 employees.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category FI Type 1 project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  Davivienda will be required to designate individuals to have responsibility for the environment and who will attend IFC''s environmental management workshop or an approved equivalent, establish an environmental management system to ensure that activities financed under relevant operations (e.g., corporate, construction, and SME lending) are consistent with applicable Colombian environmental, occupational health and safety regulations and the relevant IFC Exclusion List, and submit to IFC an environmental management plan and annual environmental performance reports.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community

Project Description: The project is to establish a credit facility of up to $30 million for use by companies developed by InfraCo. InfraCo is a privately managed, donor funded infrastructure project developer which aims to identify viable infrastructure projects in the energy, water, transport and agribusiness sectors in frontier countries.  Once potential projects have been identified, InfraCo will carry out the necessary project development - due diligence, feasibility studies and negotiations on significant project agreements - to the point where the project is ready for financing or construction.  The development rights will then be sold through a transparent process to private sector developers/financiers.  Sales may take the form of either a one time development fee or ongoing royalty payments (or carried equity interest) from the company that buys the prepared project.  It is expected that by doing this, InfraCo should facilitate the realization of projects which would otherwise not be developed.  InfraCo will target projects in Africa and in frontier countries in South Asia and South-East Asia.  Countries targeted will depend on the sector but will include, for instance, Gambia, Senegal, Mozambique, Namibia, Bangladesh, Cambodia and Indonesia.InfraCo aims to develop and sell about two projects a year with a typical size of $25 to $50 million each.  They may be sold at different stages: as developed concepts, as developed and funded projects or, in the case of rehabilitations and expansions, as operating projects. Projects will be chosen on the basis of development value as well as commercial viability.  The credit facility would form part of a wider non-exclusive cooperation agreement between IFC and InfraCo.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category C project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure. InfraCos operational requirements for environmental and social performance of their projects are consistent with the intent of IFCs environmental and social policies and procedures. Projects that will seek to use the proposed credit facility will be subject to IFCs investment approval.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: InfraCo is owned by the Private Investment Development Group (PIDG) who were responsible for its creation.  The PIDG is a non-profit donor group comprising the UK, Sweden, Netherlands, Switzerland, and the World Bank Group that was established in 2002. PIDG aims to address the major financial constraints limiting private sector investment in the infrastructure of developing countries. It has already launched a number of innovative initiatives including: the Emerging Africa Infrastructure Fund, which makes long term loans to private sector infrastructure developments in Sub-Saharan Africa; Guarantco Ltd. which aims to mitigate the risks of local currency lending; and Devco Ltd. which supports the work of IFCs Advisory Services Department on privatization transactions.  Initial funding has already been secured from the UKs Department for International Development to launch InfraCo and support its initial operations.  PDIG is now looking for partners to extend this program.
Cost Nature: IFC would establish a credit facility of up to $30 million. This facility would be available for loans to individual project companies created by InfraCo, and not to InfraCo itself. The funds under any loan would be disbursed only after InfraCo has concluded the sale of the project company to a long-term investor, and would be subject to IFC being satisfied with the technical and financial capabilities and reputation of the purchaser. Loan sizes under the facility would be restricted to the range of $2 million - $8 million. For each prospective loan, InfraCo would prepare an information memorandum for consideration by IFC. IFC would release a Summary of Project Information and an Environmental Review Summary prior to each investment under the facility.
Investment: 30.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan30.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: InfraCo is headquartered in London but is pursuing projects exclusively in Africa and frontier countries of South Asia and East Asia.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category C project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure. InfraCos operational requirements for environmental and social performance of their projects are consistent with the intent of IFCs environmental and social policies and procedures. Projects that will seek to use the proposed credit facility will be subject to IFCs investment approval.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sector: FA - Power Projects through FI (Non RE)

Project Description:
Indecomm Corporation (Indecomm or the company) is an outsourcing company located in Bangalore, India that uses proprietary document management technology to provide high quality document and transaction processing services to the financial services industry.  The company was founded in July 2003 from an earlier company called TRRS Imaging.

The purpose of the project is to provide Indecomm with capital to expand business activities and facilities in India.
Environmental Social Issues: Indecomm is a category C project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedures.  The company has only leased space and has no immediate plans to construct or purchase a building.  There are minimal environmental or social impacts associated with this project.  Therefore, no further environmental or social analysis is required.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: The sponsors of the project are Mr. Naresh Ponnapa, CEO of Indecomm; Mr. CV Prakash, President of Strategic Initiatives and principal founder of TRRS Imaging; and Westbridge Capital Partners (Westbridge), an Indian venture capital fund with $340 million under management focused primarily on outsourced services and information technology companies.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $6.5 million. IFC is considering providing equity financing for part of the project cost for a shareholding representing between 5 - 10% of the ownership.

Therefore, no further environmental or social analysis is required.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Description: TAM provides scheduled air transportation in both the Brazilian domestic market and the international market through its operating subsidiaries TAM Linhas Aéreas and TAM Mercosur. According to data provided by the Brazilian Department of Civil Aviation (DAC), the company is the leading airline in the domestic market, with a 44.3% market share as of August 31, 2005, as measured in revenue passenger kilometers. TAM offers frequent and direct flights to and from all major domestic Brazilian airports at competitive prices, serving the largest number of destinations in Brazil of all Brazilian airlines, and operate scheduled passenger and cargo air transport routes to 44 cities, in addition to a further 29 domestic destinations that the company serves through regional alliances with other airlines.  The company also directly serves ten international destinations and provides connections to other destinations through commercial agreements with American Airlines, Air France and certain other airlines. In 2004, the company carried approximately 12 million passengers on domestic flights and 1 million passengers on international flights, averaging 435 take-offs per day.The project is a $50 million loan comprising: -  a $25 million revolving facility for pre-delivery purchase (PDP) financing of Airbus 320 family aircraft it intends to obtain between 2005 and 2010, and -  a $25 million corporate loan for ongoing operational requirements.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project. Project Description: The project consists of further funding the expansion strategy of TV3 Russia (TV3 or the company), a free-to-air television broadcasting group in Russia, and an existing client of IFC.  The company, which focuses on broadcasting entertainment-related content, is 100% owned by Independent Network Television Holding Limited (INTH), a sole purpose holding company incorporated in Cyprus whose shareholders are comprised primarily of Western strategic and financial investors.  TV3 broadcasts to a potential audience of 51 million viewers (35% of the Russian population) through a group of 35 affiliate stations, 13 of which are 100% subsidiaries of the company.  Through its expansion, TV3 plans to: - increase distribution; - improve programming; and - upgrade the equipment of its affiliates.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an environmental and social category C project.  The company will  ensure that all operations comply with applicable environmental, health and safety laws of the Russian Federation.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community

An investment of up to $20 million in JS Private Equity I (or the Fund), which has a target size of $100 million.  The fund management team will be led by Mr. Ali Siddiqui, with close supervision from Mr. Jahangir Siddiqui, a well-reputed asset manager with thirty years of asset management experience and well known to the IFC.

Project Description:
Bank Danamon (the Bank or the company) was established in 1956 and is one of the leading SME, micro and consumer lending banks in Indonesia.  Following the Indonesian crisis in 1997, the Bank came under the Indonesian Bank Restructuring Agency (IBRA).  Subsequently, IBRA auctioned 51% of the Danamon shares in mid 2003 which were purchased by Asia Financial (Indonesia) Pte Ltd (AFI).  AFI is a consortium of Asia Financial Holdings (AFH) (85%) and Deutsche Bank (15%). AFH is wholly owned by Temasek Holdings.  AFI has since raised its stake in the Bank to 70% as the Government of Indonesia has recently sold its entire shareholding in the Bank.  The remaining 30% shares are held by the public.   

The project involves IFC providing a medium-term senior loan of up to $140 million equivalent in Indonesian Rupiah (IDR) to PT Bank Danamon Indonesia Tbk. (Danamon or the Bank).  The IFC Loan would help Danamon to:  

-  finance its growing loan portfolio in SMEs, consumer finance and microfinance; 
-  diversify funding base; and 
-  reduce its asset liability maturity mismatches.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category FI Type 1 project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  Bank Danamon will be required to designate individuals to have responsibility for the environment and who will attend IFC''s environmental management workshop or an approved equivalent, establish an environmental management system to ensure that activities financed under relevant operations are consistent with applicable Indonesian environmental, occupational health and safety regulations and IFC''s Microfinance Exclusion List.  Bank Danamon will need to submit annual environmental performance reports to IFC.     Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: Asia Financial (Indonesia) Pte Ltd (AFI) 85% owned by Asia Financial Holdings (AFH) and 15% owned by Deutsche Bank.  AFH is wholly owned by Temasek Holdings. As noted above, AFI has a 70% ownership in the Bank.
Cost Nature: The proposed loan is for an amount of up to $140 million equivalent in local currency.
Investment: 150.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan150.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The Bank, headquartered in Jakarta, operates out of over 1,109 branches and 799 ATMs located throughout the country.

Bank Danamon will need to submit annual environmental performance reports to IFC.     Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Project Description: Karsten Farms (Pty) Limited (Karsten or the company) is the parent company of the largest table grape exporter in South Africa.  In addition to grapes, Karsten produces dates, apples, melons and citrus on a total of 1,527 hectares.   The project entails providing a corporate loan to Karsten to support its on going investment program, which consists of replanting ageing vines and orchards, establishing berries and cherries production, establishing grape farming activities in Egypt; building a complementary logistics and marketing operation in the United Kingdom; and refinancing $1.7 million of medium term debt.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  Review of this project consisted of appraising technical and environmental and social information submitted by the project sponsor and an onsite visit to selected company operations.  The following potential environmental, health and safety and social impacts of the projects were analyzed: Farming practices and certification schemes, including environmental and quality control systems; Water extraction and sustainability; International waterways policy; Pesticide use; Use of CFC /Refrigerants and other hazardous material; Waste management; Workers welfare and labor policies; HIV/AIDS policy; Black economic empowerment actions; Social and community development policies; Karsten Group expansion in Egypt; and Land acquisition in Egypt.  The Sponsors plans to address these potential impacts is summarized in the Environmental Review Summary and Karsten Farms Environmental Action Plan (EAP).Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe ERS is located at the gates of the project sites and on the Upington town council bulletin board.
Sponsor: The project sponsor is Mr. Petrus Karsten Sr., who established Karsten as a 13ha raisin farm 30 years ago. The Shareholding structure now comprises: Karsten Family Trust (51.4%); Industrial Development Corporation (36.6%); Yarona Farms Limited and Yarona Company Property Trust, two entities formed by the employees of Karsten (11.3%).  The remaining shares are owned by Land Merit Trust, investment vehicle of South Africa's state owned Land Bank and BAASA (a Black Empowerment Group).
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $15 million.  The proposed IFC investment is a $ 7.5 million A loan for IFC's own account.
Investment: 7.50 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan7.50Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location:
The project will be implemented in 3 geographical locations:

South Africa:	Karsten will expand farming operations located in the Northern Cape and Western Cape Provinces. 
Egypt:  	Karsten will enter into contracts to manage and provide packhouse and cold storage facilities in the Cairo Alexandria region.  Karsten will also establish a Greenfield grape farm in Aswan.  
United Kingdom: Karsten will set up complementary marketing company close to London

Project Description: 7L Capital Partners Emerging Europe L.P. (7L Capital or the Fund) is a closed-end regional private equity fund with a target size of 100 million formed by 7L Capital Partners (EE) Ltd (7LCP or the Fund Manager), which will make equity and equity-related investments in companies located principally in the region of Emerging Europe (the Region), including Bulgaria, Greece, Romania, Turkey and the Former Yugoslavia.  The Fund's primary objective is to achieve superior long-term capital appreciation through majority or control stakes in a portfolio of commercial and industrial companies.  Target industries will include branded goods and services, communications, technology and applications.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an FI type project.  The Fund Manager will be required to establish an environmental management system to ensure that its investee companies are in compliance with host country environmental and social requirements, and any applicable environmental, health and safety requirements of IFC.  IFC will assess 7LCP''s capacity to conduct environmental and social reviews.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: 7LCP is an independent private equity firm.  Working together from 1995 to 2002, the principals of 7LCP have been involved in originating and managing direct investments in over 50 companies, making investment commitments of over 240 million in aggregate through two predecessor funds, the Commercial Capital Group ('CCG'), the private equity arm of the Commercial Bank of Greece ('CBG'), and Baring Communications Equity Emerging Europe ('BCEEE').  The key CCG principals left CCG in 2002-2003 to establish 7LCP jointly with a key principal of BCEEE.  CCG operated from Russia to Cyprus and from Central Europe to Turkey while BCEEE was the first private equity fund in that region focused solely on the communication sector.
Cost Nature: It is proposed that IFC invest up to 20 million, up to 20% of total commitments to the Fund.

Project Description: This proposal comprises two independent Projects with Russian Standard Bank, (RSB, or the Bank), Russias leading retail bank and an existing client of IFC:Loan Facility:  The first project comprises A and B loans totaling $100 million to RSB. Mezzanine investment in securitization:  The second project comprises an investment of about $30 million in credit enhancement to support a proposed securitization of consumer loans by RSB.Both of the above transactions build on IFCs existing successful investments in RSB, both equity and debt, and represent an effort by IFC to play a mobilization role to source funding for RSB, while limiting direct IFC funding to the Bank. The Bank:  RSB is a large-sized rapidly growing private Russian bank and one of the leading consumer finance banks in Russia, with a unique point-of-sale (POS) consumer finance business model. RSB sells its financial products and services, comprising POS loans, credit card loans, and car loans to consumers through partner retail shops. RSB started its operations in Moscow in 1999 and has since expanded into various regions of Russia. RSB now operates through its network of 21 branches in Moscow and other regions in Russia, 13 regional centers, 158 representative offices in other major Russian cities representing 93% of Russias population and over 21,500 POS. RSBs strategic objective is to broaden its distribution network by extending its business to all of the major Russian regions and to provide a wider group of customers with a full range of consumer finance products.
Environmental Social Issues: Both projects are Category C projects according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure. Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: RSB is part of the Roust Group of companies owned and controlled by Roustam Tariko, a successful local entrepreneur. RSB is a closed joint-stock company directly owned by Russian Standard Company (dealing in international branded goods) and by Roust Inc. (dealing in Russian branded goods), both of which are held nearly 100% by Mr. Tariko through a holding company. Mr. Tariko first established himself as an importer and distributor of luxury consumer goods from Italy. Besides the beverage and banking businesses, Mr. Tariko has launched an insurance business in partnership with Cardiff, an insurance arm of BNP Paribas Group. IFC is a 6.42% shareholder in RSB.
Cost Nature: The total cost of the A/B loan project is estimated $100 million and IFC would provide the A Loan of about $40 million and mobilize about $60 million as B Loan. The total cost of the securitization project is about $300 million and IFC will provide credit enhancement of about $30 million.
Investment: 65.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan65.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: RSB is headquartered in Moscow, Russia and operates through offices across many Russian cities. IFCs investment will used by RSB for on-lending to consumers in the Russian market.

Project Name: Capital Alliance Private Equity II, L.P.
Company Name: CAPITAL ALLIANCE PRIVATE EQUITY II LIMITED
Project Description:
Capital Alliance Private Equity II, Limited ('CAPE II') is a 10-year closed-end regional private equity fund formed by African Capital Alliance, Ltd.  The Fund will make privately negotiated equity and equity-linked investments in businesses located in West Africa, principally in Nigeria.  The Fund aims to take advantage of trends in the local market by partnering with strong management teams or international investors.

The Fund is targeting total capital commitments of $100 million.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an FI type 2 project according to IFCs environment and social review procedure.  African Capital Alliance developed a satisfactory environmental and social management system under the first fund.  The Investment Advisor will need to demonstrate that the EMS is robust enough to address the environmental and social impacts arising from investments under the new fund.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: African Capital Alliance was founded in 1997 by six partners to promote private sector investments in Africa through the mobilization of capital and know-how to take advantage of attractive investment opportunities.  Two of the founding partners (Tom Barry and Okechukwu Enelamah) had previously worked together in private equity, whilst four of the founding partners (Richard Kramer, Mohammed Hayatu-Deen, Chief Ernest Shonekan and Pascal Dozie) had worked together in the Nigerian Economic Summit Group, a Nigerian economic think-tank that is dedicated to achieving sustainable economic development in the national interest through responsible private sector initiative.  African Capital Alliance has since grown to eight partners and a team of over twenty professionals operating out of Lagos, Nigeria.  African Capital Alliance launched the first private equity fund in West Africa through Capital Alliance Private Equity ('CAPE I'), a $35 million fund launched in 1998 in which IFC is an investor.

Project Description:
The project is to provide a $20 million senior loan of up to 6 year maturity to EFG-Hermes Holding SAE (EFG, or the company). 

 EFG-Hermes is the leading investment bank in Egypt and has an excellent track record. Over the last few years EFG has emerged as a major player in the areas of investment banking, securities brokerage, asset management and private equity in Egypt.

The purpose of the IFC loan is: 
-  to finance EFG's plans for further regional expansion; and 
-  to provide medium term liquidity needed to finance its growing investment banking business. 

By providing the proposed loan to EFG, IFC will expand the company's operation in the region and help bring additional competition in the respective markets. Ultimately, IFC's investment would contribute to the development of regional capital markets. IFC will promote further best practices in internal control policies and procedures. 

The proposed project would be IFC's second investment in the company. In February of 2001, IFC Board approved a $30 million, 5-year term loan to EFG, of which $3.1 million is currently outstanding.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category C project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure. There will be minimal environmental and social impacts associated with this project. Therefore, no further environmental or social analysis is required.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor:
EFG was formed as the result of a merger between Egyptian Financial Group and the Hermes Group in 1996. In early 2000, Citibank acquired a minority stake in the company and continues to play an active role through its 4% stake in EFG. In 2001, EFG joined forces with CIIC, a leading private investor in Egypt and maintained its position as the largest player in the Egyptian investment banking industry. EFG's shares are listed on the Cairo and London Stock Exchanges and are among the most actively traded stocks in Cairo.  As of July 2005, EFG's shareholders included the following: EFG Employee Trust (ESOP) 16%; Foreign Institutions 15%; Gulf retail investors 12%; Local Institutions 10%, and Treasury shares 5%. Public ownership amounted to 41%. 
EFG comprises of four business lines including investment banking, securities brokerage, asset management and private equity. Its total revenue and net income amounted to $32 million and $8.5 million, respectively, in 2004. Its' ROAE and ROAA were 9.1% and 4.8%, respectively. As of June 30, 2005, total revenue grew to reach $42 million and net profit $15.8 million. EFG employs more than 350 people.
EFG is seeking to consolidate its leading position in Egypt and capitalize on synergies in the Middle East region by becoming a regional financial institution. A regional expansion is central to its growth plans, since it will further enhance its distribution capability in the Gulf region and reduce its dependence on Egypt.
Cost Nature: EFG's expansion plan is estimated at $40 million to be financed through $40 million of loans to be provided by multilateral organizations including IFC and internal cash generation.  The proposed IFC investment is a $20 million senior loan to EFG.
Investment: 20.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan20.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: EFG is headquartered in Cairo, Egypt. It also has a brokerage operation in Dubai since December 2004 and in Abu Dhabi since February 2005.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category C project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure. There will be minimal environmental and social impacts associated with this project. Therefore, no further environmental or social analysis is required.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Strategic investors include the Cleveland Clinic and Elaj Medical Company (KSA), a network of specialized medical centers with locations in London, Cairo, KSA and GCCs.  Other new investors include Dr. Fahed Khater, the chairman of CarePlus, an Egyptian medical insurance company, a Greek investor, Mr. Contominas.  SEDCO, a Saudi strategic investor for DAF's expansion of outpatient clinics in KSA and the Gulf is undertaking its due diligence and may subscribe for additional shares (in addition to the private palacement).  This will further dilute the public sector.

The location is excellent being in the heart of a very large residential area with a two main road frontage.  The new facility currently only occupies around one third of it.

Project Description:
Launch Tech Company Limited ('Launch Tech' or the 'Company') is a Chinese firm that designs and manufactures tools and equipment used in the automotive aftermarket sector.   Its product line includes automotive diagnostic equipment, lifts, wheel aligners and balancers, tire changers and other products such as emission testing equipment and hand tools.  The Company was founded in 1992 by Messrs. LIU Xin and LIU Jun and is today the leading manufacturer of automotive diagnostic equipment in China.  Launch Tech was listed on the Hong Kong GEM board in October 2002.

The project consists of Launch Tech's capital investment program to (i) consolidate its various Shenzhen-based production and facilities into a single new complex; (ii) expand the operations of its lift equipment manufacturing facility in Shanghai; and (iii) purchase new manufacturing equipment, (the 'Project').  By implementing the Project, the Company aims to: (i) integrate Launch Tech's manufacturing, administrative and R&D facilities into one location in Shenzhen; (ii) increase the Company's manufacturing and R&D capacity; and (iii) reduce costs.  Bringing together the existing facilities will allow Launch Tech to maintain its competitive advantage, better cater to market demand, provide additional R&D and manufacturing capacity and execute on its growth strategy.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a category B project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedures. The project is to consolidate the company''s diagnostic equipment production in a new industrial park in Shenzhen and expand its existing lift production activities in Shanghai. The appraisal of this project will include, but not be limited to: an assessment of existing operations compliance with both local regulations and World Bank guidelines and policies, an assessment of the procedures used for acquiring the industrial park facilities and the suitability of these facilities, occupational health and safety control, air emission and waste water management, recycling or disposal of waste materials, and a review of the proposed expansion in Shanghai. The latter will include an assessment of potential need for extra land take and potential effects on the size of the work force.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityLaunch Tech Company Limited
Xinyang Building, Bagua No. 4 Road, Futian District, Shenzhen, P.R. China

Project Description: OJSC Pivoindustria Primoriva (PIP or the company) is the only brewery located in the Russian Far East capital city of Vladivostok. Its nearest competitors are located 750 Kilometers away in Khabarovsk. The project, which will be implemented in two phases, involves a $58 million investment program for the following:-  acquisition of PIP by the Sponsors; -  upgrading of PIPs facilities and expand its current production capacity to 1.5 million Hectoliters (HL) p.afrom the present 720,000 HLby 2008; -  settlement of $14 million in old debt; and -  provision of the necessary working capital. The project also includes plans to improve product quality, revive existing brands and develop new brands for PIP.The project will enable PIP to become the leading brewer in Vladivostok city and the surrounding Primorye krai markets, serving a population of 2.2 million people.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityEnvironmental documentation will be made available at the following location:Gorky State Library Nekrasov Street, 59, Vladivostok
Sponsor: The project sponsor is Endovart Holdings Inc., a company equally owned by Mr. Igor Kim and the Alfa Group. Mr. Igor Kim, a Russian national, will be the project manager of PIP. From 1999-2003 Mr. Kim was the CEO of Ivan Taranov Breweries (ITB), a Russian group involved in the production and distribution of beer and beverages. During his tenor at ITB, Mr. Kim was responsible for developing distribution networks and brands and ultimately for the success of ITB. Mr. Kim was also responsible for overseeing the refurbishment of ITBs breweries located throughout the Russian Federation. Founded in 1989 as Alfa-Eco, the Alfa Group is one of Russias largest privately owned financial industrial conglomerates, with interests in oil and gas, commercial and investment banking, asset management, insurance, retail trade, telecommunications, and technology. The Group focuses on value-oriented, longer-term opportunities, primarily in Russia and the CIS. The role of Alfa in PIP will be primarily that of a financial investor.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $58 million. The proposed IFC investment consists of an A Loan of up to $14.5 million equivalent for IFCs own account and an equity investment of up to $5.31 million.
Investment: 19.99 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan14.68Equity5.31* These investment figures are indicative

The civil structures and brewery were built in 1982. Investments for basic upgrades and maintenance were made by the previous management but substantial investments are requiredas per the Financial Planto bring the brewery up to international standards. The site houses:-  malt house and silos;-  office headquarters;-  boiler house;-  brewery;-  warehouses for storage; and-  a railway terminal.

Project Description: The Asian Lion Fund (Asian Lion or the Fund) is a mining fund which will target equity and equity-related investments in listed and unlisted mining companies engaged in advanced exploration to pre-feasibility work on base and precious metal deposits in the South Eastern Asia region. (Lion or the Fund Manager), which is based in Melbourne Australia.

Company Name: IHDC DODSON LINDBLOM HYDRO POWER PVT LTD
Project Description:
INCaF is contracting with Dodson-Lindblom HydroPower Private Limited (DLHPPL) and Ascent Hydro Projects Limited (Ascent) on a joint and several basis to purchase Certified Emission Reductions (CERs) generated by the two companies' small hydro projects in India.  DLHPPL and Ascent are Indian companies, established in 1997 and 1994 respectively, that are 100% owned subsidiaries of Dodson-Lindblom International (DLI or the Sponsor), a wholly-owned subsidiary of DLZ Corporation of the U.S.  IFC is also lending to these companies, on a joint and several basis (Note that a Summary of Project Information for IFC's investment project with DLI Small Hydros, known by the name IHDC, was already released on June 16, 2005 by IFC). As of June 20, 2006, the project name changed from DLI small Hydros to IHDC Small Hydros. The reason for this change was because the first sponsor, DLI, formed a new company, IHDC, as a special purpose vehicle to own the projects and facilitate the investment of additional investors.

In 2002, IFC and the Netherlands established the IFC-Netherlands Carbon Facility (INCaF) and an associated Trust to enable IFC to purchase, for the benefit of the Netherlands, certified emission reductions (CERs) under the framework of the Clean Development Mechanism (CDM) of the Kyoto Protocol.  INCaF will purchase CERs from DLHPPL and Ascent generated between 2001 and 2012.  INCaF's purchase will be approximately 90% of the total amount of CERs expected to be generated by the Project during the period from 2001 to 2012.

The Project comprises a package of six small- and mini-hydroelectric generation plants located in three states in India including: 
-  the construction of three greenfield mini-hydroelectric generation facilities in the state of Himachal Pradesh (Sechi, Melan and Panwi);
-  the acquisition, rehabilitation and refurbishment of an existing 34 MW facility in Maharashtra (BH II); 
-  an existing 12 MW operational facility in Maharashtra (BH I); and, 
-  the completion of a 2.2 MW mini-hydropower plant in Madhya Pradesh state (Birsingphur) currently under construction.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a Category C project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedures because this transaction does not cause any impact beyond the existing proposal for an IFC investment in this company.  IFCs investment in this project was already classified as Category B and an Environmental Review Summary was released by IFC on its website and by the Sponsor locally in India in June 2005. The recommendations of the ERS and any CAP agreed prior to commitment with IFC under the investment project would be applicable in the case of this carbon finance deal as well.The review of this Project consisted of appraising technical, environmental and social information submitted by the project Sponsor; and visits to the two existing facilities in Maharashtra (Bhandardara I and II), to the Birsinghpur plant (currently under construction) in Madhya Pradesh, and to the three greenfield sites (Melan, Panwi and Sechi) in Himachal Pradesh. The following potential environment, health and safety and social aspect of the project (s) were analyzed:-  corporate environmental, social, and health and safety management systems;-  national and local government permitting requirements;-  dam safety (relevant to Bhandardara only);-  potential impacts on downstream users; -  land acquisition, compensation and physical and/or economic resettlement;-  community consultation and disclosure;-  site access during construction and operation;-  community health and safety during both construction and operation; -  provision of housing, hygiene facilities, water, and power (including fuel storage) during construction and operation;-  hazardous materials management; -  fire and life safety and emergency response; -  minimization, recycling and disposal of solid and hazardous wastes during construction and operation;-  biodiversity conservation;-  corporate social responsibility efforts, including HIV/AIDS awareness; and, -  timely reporting on environmental and social performance to IFC.Location of environmental documents in locally affected communityThe Environmental Review Summary (ERS) for IFC's investment in this Project was released in June 2005 and was categorized as Category B for that purpose. The recommendations of the ERS or any possible CAP agreed prior to commitment with IFC under the investment project would be applicable in this transaction as well.  The ERS was made available at the following locations:

Sponsor:
The Project Sponsor is DLI of Columbus, Ohio, USA, a wholly-owned subsidiary of DLZ Corporation.  DLZ, founded in 1951, is a privately-held well-respected full service architectural, engineering and environmental consulting firm with annual revenues of approximately $80 million.  DLZ provides water resources, wastewater, architectural, facilities, transportation and environmental engineering analysis, design and project management functions to clients in the US and more than 20 countries around the world.  Its largest clients include the US Army Corps of Engineers, US Department of Agriculture, various state and municipal departments of natural resources, transportation, water and environmental quality, and a wide array of private companies including Bethlehem Steel.    

In 1979, DLZ was purchased by Mr. Vikram Rajadhyaksha, who currently owns 67% of the company.  The remaining shareholders are: employees (25%), Mr. P.V. Rajadhyaksha, brother of Vikram (7%), and Janet, wife of Vikram, and Dr. Kasturi Rajadhyaksha, mother of Vikram (1%).

DLI was formed in 1984 to expand the business into the international market.  DLI is the 100% owner of DLHPPL and Ascent.
Cost Nature: The total value of the contract between INCaF and the two project companies, DLHPPL and Ascent, will likely fall in the range of $4.2 million to $5.0 million depending on the final negotiated price and final contracted quantity of CERs.  The total project cost is estimated at $45 million (the proposed IFC investment is an A Loan up to $16 million).
Location:
The BH I project is located on Lake Arthur Hill Reservoir in the Upper Pravara River Basin in Maharashtra state. The nearest town, Ghoti, is 36 km away from the project site.  BH I was constructed in 1986 by the Government of Maharashtra Irrigation Department, and rehabilitated by the Sponsor upon acquisition in 1996.   

The BH II project is located 10 km downstream of BH I on the Pravara River in Maharashtra state.  BH II was constructed in 1999 and operated until today by the Government of Maharashtra Irrigation Department.  Upon acquisition of BH II, the Sponsor will rehabilitate and refurbish the project site.

Birsingphur project is located in the Umaria District, about 180 km northeast of the city of Jabalpur in the eastern part of the State of Madhya Pradesh.  The project is located within the fence of the Sanjay Gandhi Thermal Power Station, an 840 MW coal-fired power plant owned and operated by the Madhya Pradesh State Electricity Board.  The sponsor is finalizing construction of the Birsingphur plant and will start commercial operations shortly.

The three greenfield mini-hydro plants will be located in the state of Himachal Pradesh.  All are located in the mid-range Himalaya mountains at elevations of around 2,000 meters.  The climate is of the tropical monsoon nature, with a maximum summer temperature of around 30 degrees celsius and a minimum winter temperature below freezing.  The exact location of each project is:
-  Sechi: located on Sechi khad (stream), a tributary of the Sutlej river, near the village of Samej in the district of Shimla;
-  Melan: located on Melan khad, also a tributary of the Sutlej river, in the Kinnaur district; and,
- Panwi: located on the Panwi khad, also a tributary of the Sutlej river, very close to the Melan khad, in the Kinnaur district.  

Access roads to the Sechi and Panwi sites are via a state road and a bridge from a national highway, respectively.  Access to Melan is currently very limited; however, a bridge is being constructed by the Himachal Pradesh government which will provide adequate access to the project site.

This is a Category C project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedures because this transaction does not cause any impact beyond the existing proposal for an IFC investment in this company.  IFCs investment in this project was already classified as Category B and an Environmental Review Summary was released by IFC on its website and by the Sponsor locally in India in June 2005. The recommendations of the ERS and any CAP agreed prior to commitment with IFC under the investment project would be applicable in the case of this carbon finance deal as well.The review of this Project consisted of appraising technical, environmental and social information submitted by the project Sponsor; and visits to the two existing facilities in Maharashtra (Bhandardara I and II), to the Birsinghpur plant (currently under construction) in Madhya Pradesh, and to the three greenfield sites (Melan, Panwi and Sechi) in Himachal Pradesh.
