Project Description: The proposed project is a $30 million IFC investment in Kingdom Installment Company (KIC or the company) to support the companys future housing finance program. IFCs investment would be in the form of a credit enhancement of the mezzanine tranche of the mortgage backed securities (MBS) to be issued by KIC. The project will allow the company to grow its housing finance operations and establish a market based housing finance program. IFC will also consider taking a small equity/quasi equity position in KIC. The rationale for the equity investment would to help KIC develop its business further along industry best practice lines and to eventually become a housing finance bank once the law establishing housing finance banks in Saudi Arabia has been enacted. Saudi Arabia currently does not have specialized body for regulating housing finance lenders and regulatory oversight is limited. Through its investment, IFC will help the company in its preparation and transition to becoming a non-bank housing finance institution IFCs equity investment will be considered following due diligence and only if there is a robust role for IFC, and a potential for an upside can be established as well as appropriate exit mechanisms can be identified or negotiated with the sponsors.  IFC will play a catalytic role in introducing the company to a potential technical partner (HDFC etc) in helping them convert into a housing finance bank.   Under the proposed securitization, KIC will issue MBS backed by a pool of Shariah-compliant housing finance contracts originated in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia (KSA). The issue will represent the first Shariah-compliant MBS issued in Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) countries. The MBS would allow the KIC to diversify its funding sources by tapping the regional capital markets and enhance its liquidity needed to originate additional housing finance contracts especially as the company launches a new growth phase of its housing finance operations. The project will also introduce a high quality new shariah compliant asset class to the regional markets. KIC has engaged Unicorn Investment Bank (UIB) out of Bahrain as arranger/placement agent, Lovells (London), who has an extended legal practice in Islamic financing and securitization, as the lead counsel and White and Case (Saudi Arabia) as local counsel for the MBS. Also, KIC has mandated Ernst and Young (Saudi Arabia) to provide advice on the tax and other accounting implications of the transactions.  Finally Bearing Point (US) has been contracted to complete the cash-flow model for the MBS.  The transaction is expected to be rated by Capital Intelligence Limited out of Cyprus..
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category C project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure. There will be minimal environmental and social impacts associated with this project. Therefore, no further environmental or social analysis is required.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: Sponsors:The sponsor of the project is KIC, the largest private finance company to support housing finance in Saudi Arabia.  KIC was established as a strategic unit of Al Arkan Real Estate Development Company which is the largest developer of housing units in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia. Established in 2000, it commenced operations in Riyadh, as a limited liability company, in response to the rapid growth in the housing finance market and the significant change in the balance of supply and demand for real estate finance services.  KIC was the first to offer 20 year mortgage loans in the Saudi Arabian market with a focus on the middle income segment of the market.KICs main activity is to provide housing finance to individuals seeking to purchase a home or a developed land parcel.  KIC achieves this by purchasing real estate within KSA from property developers and reselling to consumers on a Shariah-compliant installment basis. In addition to housing finance, KIC also engages in wholesale trading of automobiles, office fixtures and fittings, and electronic devices.Ownership and Management: KICs shareholding structure is the following:Al Arkan Construction Limited Co.	34.8%Yousef Bin Abdullah Al Shelash	14.7%Majed A. Rehman A. Aziz Al Gassim	12.4%Khalid Bin Abdullah Al Shelash	10.4%Tariq Bin Mohammad Ali Al Jarallah	10.0%Hathloul Bin Saleh Al Hathloul	8.9%Majed Roumi Soliman Al Roumi	5.0%Abdul Aziz Al Shelash	3.4%Abdul Karim Bin Hamad Al Babtain	0.4%                                              100.0%Sheikh Yousef Al Shelash is the founding member of the company who conceptualized and initiated the real estate business operations.  All shareholders have a sound business experience mostly in the real estate area. Local authorities have also confirmed to IFC regional staff that the shareholders are respectable individuals, always having had honored their responsibilities.
Cost Nature: Up to $5 million in equity in KIC and up to $25 million in the form of partial credit guarantee or purchase of the mezzanine tranche to support the placement of one or more of MBS issuances by KIC for an amount of up to $200 million

Project Name: European Microfinance Fund for Southeast Europe
Company Name: The European Fund For Southeast Europe S.A., SA
Project Description: The proposed project involves the creation of a Euro 500 million collective debt investment vehicle, named The European Microfinance Fund for Southeast Europe (EFSE, or the company), which will make investments in microfinance institutions in the Southeast Europe region. EFSE aims to attract investments from multilateral, bilateral, as well as private institutional investors, via multiple closings. The promoter of this project is KfW. The purpose of the project is to provide development finance in the Southeast Europe region through the local financial institutions, focusing on the credit needs of micro and small businesses and private households. The company presents a unique opportunity to create a public-private partnership which leverages private capital and supports the economic growth and job creation in the region. In parallel with the creation of the company, a Development Facility will be established to provide technical assistance to the investee institutions assisting them in their development and growth. The management company will be Oppenheim Pramerica, a prime asset management firm, in consortium with microfinance specialist advisor, Bankakademie.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an FI type 1 project. EFSE will commit to appointing a person to be responsible for the environment function within the company and participate in IFC training program. EFSE will commit to ensuring that each of its investee companies has the capacity and commitment to comply with applicable host country standards and IFCs Microfinance Exclusion List. EFSE will be required to submit an annual environmental performance report to IFC.  Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The shareholders of EFSE at the first closing are expected to be: -  KfW - the promoter, -  European Union: the German, Swiss and Austrian Governments -  multilateral/bilateral institutions including IFC, FMO, EIB and EBRD; and -  private institutional investors.
Cost Nature: The proposed IFC investment comprises a Euro 30 million quasi-equity (mezzanine) type funding of a total project size of Euro 500 million.
Investment: 36.90 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan0.0Equity36.90* These investment figures are indicative
Location: EFSE will be incorporated in Luxembourg, as an investment company and is expected to make investments in qualified financial institutions (i.e. Commercial Banks and NGOs) in Southeastern European countries/entities, including but not limited to Bosnia & Herzegovina, Serbia, Montenegro, Kosovo.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is an FI type 1 project. EFSE will commit to appointing a person to be responsible for the environment function within the company and participate in IFC training program. Project Description: The project consists of a line of credit of up to $20 million to Diamond Bank Plc ('Diamond Bank' or the 'Bank'), one of the largest new generation banks in Nigeria. The project's main objective is to address the scarcity of term finance in Nigeria, which has forced Nigerian commercial banks to rely on their capital, or take the maturity risk in order to finance longer-term projects. The credit line will also be used to support small to medium enterprises, a critical sector in the Nigerian economy. The proposed investment allows IFC to address part of these constraints by making available foreign exchange term resources through an efficient financial institution.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an FI Type 2 project. Diamond Bank Plc will be required to undertake an environmental review of each subproject.  Diamond Bank has had a good record and is fully compliant with the IFC environmental policies. However, the IFC will re-assess Diamond Banks environmental management system during appraisal.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: The project sponsor is Diamond Bank, which offers a full range of products and services in retail, commercial, corporate and investment banking, including advisory, investment, debt, equity, lending and transactional services supported by a network of over 76 branches. The operations are supported by a strong technology infrastructure.  On October 27, 2005, the Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN) gave its final approval to the merger of Lion Bank Plc with Diamond Bank Plc. The approval resulted in a larger capitalized Diamond Bank Plc with total Shareholders Funds of NGN28.6 billion (US$220 million), which surpasses the NGN25 billion (about US$192 million) minimum capitalization required by CBN by December 31, 2005.
Cost Nature: The proposed IFC investment will be in the form of a loan of up to $20 million to Diamond Bank Plc for IFC's own account.

Company Name: VEOLIA WATER MIDDLE EAST NORTH AFRICA
Project Description: Veolia AMI is a French holding company with water, wastewater and electricity operations exclusively in Africa, the Middle East and India (AMI). The largest operations are in Gabon and Morocco although Veolia AMI also has operations in other countries. Veolia AMI aims to broaden its portfolio of operations, and provide a range of services in the water sector to the Africa and Middle East regions and India, dealing with either the entire water system of a country or parts of it, including distribution services (either at the municipal or at the national level), operation and maintenance of water treatment plants (including desalination plants) and water reuse plants; and industrial outsourcing. When appropriate, Veolia AMI may also provide electricity services in conjunction with water services. To further expand its portfolio of investments in the target regions, Veolia AMI will significantly increase its capital. Its parent company, Compagnie Generale des Eaux (CGE) is planning to inject a significant amount of equity in Veolia AMI, which will allow further expanding its portfolio of investments in the target regions. Veolia AMI has invited both IFC and another international financial institution (IFI) to provide equity, by capital increase. IFCs investment would be 25 million.In addition to equity, Veolia AMI has asked IFC to assist one of its subsidiaries to raise debt financing and obtain credit enhancement with suppliers. In June 1997, Veolia AMI was awarded the concession for the production, transmission and distribution of electricity and water services in Gabon for a twenty year period, through a competitive tender. The concessionaire, SEEG (Société dEau et dElectricité du Gabon) is 51% owned and controlled by Veolia AMI. From the time of its privatization until present SEEG financed all of its investments with equity and cash flow from operations only. It is now negotiating a debt package with local banks. It hopes to secure the debt on a non-recourse basis but would need guarantees to extend the maturity from seven to ten years. It is therefore considering obtaining from IFC a partial credit guarantee to increase the tenor or the debt from seven years to ten years.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category B project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure.  Environmental and social issues associated with this project include: -  Environmental management systems; -  Potable water production and distribution; -  Wastewater management and public health; -  Electricity generation and distribution;-  Fuels/Hazardous materials management and emergency response; -  Employee health and safety; and -  Low-income access to water and sanitation services.  Veolia AMI has presented plans to address these issues and to demonstrate that the proposed project will, upon implementation of the specific measures detailed below: -  be consistent with Veolia Environnements corporate environmental protection and social responsibility commitments; and -  comply with applicable host country laws and regulations and World Bank requirements.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityAt headquarters : Veolia Water AMI - 52 rue dAnjou, 75384 Paris Cedex 08 FranceIn Morocco: CMSE19 av. Ibn Sina Rabat Agdal MoroccoIn Gabon: SEEG BP 2187 Libreville GabonIn Niger: SEEN BP 12209Boulevard Zarmaganda Niamey NigerIndia: Veolia Water India Pvt-Ltd B-1, Marble Arch, 9  Prithviraj Road  New Delhi 110 011  India
Sponsor: Veolia AMI is an indirect subsidiary of the Veolia Environnement (VE) group, a world leader in environmental services with a 150-year history of public service in developed markets and emerging countries alike. VE has a market capitalization of 19 billion and is listed on the Paris and New York stock exchanges.Veolia AMIs only shareholder is Compagnie Generale des Eaux (CGE), a wholly owned subsidiary of VEs water. CGE is the worlds largest water services company, with 2004 revenues of 8 billion, 81% of which was earned in operations and the balance in construction. Of this turnover, 53% was earned in France, 26% in other European countries, 9% in AMI countries, 7% in the Americas and 5% in Asia. CGE is one of a handful of majors actively cultivating business in the water sector in Africa and the Middle East. Veolia AMI owns 51% of SEEG. The remaining 49% of the registered capital was sold to local investors on January 1st, 1998. Local corporations own 26%, employees 4% and other local individuals 19%.
Cost Nature: IFC has been invited to make an equity investment of up to 25 million in Veolia AMI. IFC has also been requested to extend a partial credit guarantee (PCG) to SEEG on a loan of up to 35 million that will be provided by a syndication of local banks. The loan will allow funding part of SEEGs investments planned for 2005-2010. Those investments include adding generation capacity in the form of thermal plants, improving water and electricity transmission and distribution networks, and adding water treatment capacity. The requested PCG would allow extending the maturity of the loan from seven years to ten years.

It has four regional networks, around the regions of Libreville, Port-Gentil, Franceville, and the central region.

Project Description: MRS Logistica S.A. (MRS or the company) operates a 1,674 km freight rail network connecting Brazils three largest industrial regions -- São Paulo, Minas Gerais, and Rio de Janeiro -- under a 30-year concession granted by the Brazilian federal government in 1996.  The companys rail network consists of four primary lines and a branch line that link Brazils principal iron ore mines and steel plants, its largest consumer markets, and its principal sea ports.  MRS currently operates a rolling stock fleet comprised of 143 owned and 319 leased locomotives; and 1,890 owned, 1,858 customer-owned, and 9,638 leased rail cars.MRS is implementing a five-year investment program that includes permanent way expansion, track reconfigurations, signaling improvements, and additional rolling stock acquisitions and upgrades, intended to increase the capacity of the companys network while also improving its efficiency, productivity, and safety.  The expansion is expected to increase the companys freight handling capacity from around 100 million tons p.a. at present to up to 160-180 million tons by 2009.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category B project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  Environmental and social issues associated with this investment include:-  Rehabilitation of previously contaminated/degraded areas;-  Hazardous materials management;-  Air emissions;-  Operational safety and accident prevention;-  Maintenance-related effluents, emissions, and waste management;-  Employee health and safety;-  Irregular occupation of right-of-way;-  Community engagement and development;-  Cultural properties;-  Indigenous peoples; and-  Environmental management systems.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe Environmental Review Summary (ERS) is available on the companys web-site at www.mrs.com.br and at its principal offices between 9 a.m. and 12 p.m. at the following locations:Av. Brasil 2001, 3° Andar  Juiz de Fora, MGAv. Raimundo Pereira de Magalhães, 902  São Paulo, SPPraia de Botafogo, 228 / 1201-E  Rio de Janeiro, RJPlease contact the company to make advanced arrangements to review the ERS.
Sponsor: The principal shareholders of MRS include Brazils leading iron ore mining and steel products companies as follows:-  Companhia Siderúrgica Nacional (CSN)  32% total equity stake  Brazils largest steel producer with 5.5 million tons of crude steel produced in 2004.-  Mineração Brasileiras Reunidas S.A. (MBR)  32% total equity stake  Brazils second largest iron ore producer and one of the top five iron ore exporters in the world.  MBR is controlled by the Caemi Group which, in turn, is directly and indirectly held by CVRD.  -  Companhia Vale do Rio Doce (CVRD)  10% total equity stake  CVRD is the worlds largest iron ore exporter, the second largest producer of manganese and ferro alloys, and one of Brazils primary transportation and logistics providers.-  Usinas Siderúrgicas de Minas Gerais S.A. (Usiminas)  10% total equity stake  Usiminas is Brazils second largest steel producer with 4.7 million tons produced in 2004.  Usiminas also controls Companhia Siderúrgica Paulista (COSIPA), which produced 4.2 million tons of crude steel in 2004.-  Gerdau S.A.  1% total equity stake  Gerdau is the largest producer of long-rolled steel in the Americas with mills in Brazil, Argentina, Uruguay, Canada, and the United States.
Cost Nature: MRSs five-year capital investment program is estimated at approximately R$2 billion (equivalent to approximately $890 million at current exchange rates).  MRS intends to finance its expansion program with a combination of internal cash generation and new debt, including proposed financing from International Finance Corporation (IFC).  IFC is considering a $100 million corporate loan package to support the companys capital investment program comprised of an IFC A Loan of $50 million for the Corporations own account and a syndicated IFC B Loan of $50 million for the account of participant banks.
Investment: 50.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan50.0Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: MRS is headquartered in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, with its principal operational offices located in Juiz de Fora in the State of Minas Gerais.  The company operates four primary rail lines and a branch line that link the States of São Paulo, Minas Gerais, and Rio de Janeiro as follows:Steel Line  370 km of single track rail running south from the mining quadrangle near Belo Horizonte in the State of Minas Gerais to Saudade in the State of Rio de Janeiro.  The Steel Line is used nearly exclusively for the transport of iron ore.  In Saudade, the Steel line intersects with the Rio to São Paulo Line and continues to Barra do Piraí, where it interconnects with a series of branch lines that continue to Brisamar and the Atlantic ports of Rio de Janeiro, Guaiba Island terminal and Sepetiba.  Iron ore is transported on the Steel Line to MBRs Guaiba Island terminal and to CVRDs iron ore terminal at the port of Sepetiba for export, and to CSNs steel mill near Volta Redonda in the State of Rio de Janeiro for domestic consumption.  This branch line is also used to transport imported coke and coal from the port of Sepetiba to CSNs steel production facilities.Central Line  566 km of single track rail running south from Belo Horizonte in the State of Minas Gerais to Barra do Piraí in the State of Rio de Janeiro through Juiz de Fora.  The Central Line is predominantly used for the north-south transport of cement and bauxite and for the south-north transport of empty iron ore trains returning to the mines in the State of Minas Gerais.  The configuration of the Central Line and Steel Line essentially double-track the Companys rail connection between the States of Minas Gerais and Rio de Janeiro.Rio to São Paulo Line  single track line running from Barra do Piraí in the State of Rio de Janeiro to São Paulo.  The Rio to São Paulo Line includes interconnection points with the Central Line and the Steel Line, making it the most congested segment of track operated by MRS.  The Rio to São Paulo Line is principally used for transport of finished steel products, iron ore to supply the COSIPA steel mill in Cubatão, cement and bauxite transported south on the Central Line and then west to São Paulo, and container traffic between the States of Minas Gerais, Rio de Janeiro and São Paulo.  Santos to Jundiaí Line  single track rail running south from Jundiaí in the State of São Paulo through the city of São Paulo to the port of Santos.  The line is used principally for the transport of soy, containers and other products to the port of Santos.  The iron ore destined for COSIPA is also transported on this line to Cubatão, near the port of Santos.MRS is currently facing bottlenecks and constraints in efficiently handling the freight volumes being demanded and, as such, the Companys management has identified a series of capital investments to address various bottlenecks and position the company to handle the projected future freight handling volumes anticipated to serve the demand of its customers.  The key components of the companys five-year investment plan include:- Permanent way expansion including:-  the construction of additional sidings on the Steel Line to optimize train movements on a 195 km stretch on which pusher locomotives are used to climb a 1% grade and then need to return against oncoming trains; -  the expansion of two rail yards and the rehabilitation of two sidings on the Central Line to shorten the distance between sidings on a stretch traveled by both southbound (loaded) and northbound (empty) trains; -  expansion of a key siding at the interconnection point of the Steel and Central Lines in the State of Minas Gerais near the rail spur to the Açominas (Gerdau) steel mill; -  the lengthening of five existing sidings in the São Paulo area; -  the addition and lengthening of two sidings on the Rio to São Paulo line; -  the lengthening of existing sidings to extend the 45 km double-tracked section in Rio de Janeiro between CSNs steel mill, Barra do Piraí and Brisamar; and -  the expansion and addition of cross-overs in the marshalling yard for general cargo near Barra do Piraí at the beginning of the Rio to São Paulo line;-  Acquisition of locomotives: the purchase of 49 GE locomotives  29 refurbished locomotives already acquired in 2005 and 20 new locomotives ordered for delivery in 2006; -  Acquisition of rail cars: proposed purchase of approximately 2,480 new cars between 2005 and 2009;-  Locomotive maintenance: various upgrades to improve cabin layout and comfort, install locotrol distributed power systems, and perform preventive major maintenance on the companys fleet of existing locomotives;-  Rail car maintenance: preventative maintenance on the companys existing rail cars including an increase of the axle rating to increase the carrying capacity of the company''s iron ore gondola fleet;-  Permanent way maintenance: preventative and corrective maintenance to the rail network and superstructures including rail grinding, tamping, replacement of rails, ties and ballast; -  Rail maintenance equipment: Acquisition of an additional rail grinder, two high-productivity tamping machines, new shoulder cleaning equipment, the upgrade of track maintenance vehicles and the acquisition and maintenance of other new vehicles and equipment;-  Existing signaling and telecommunications system: installation of additional hot box/hot wheel detectors, friction management systems, derailment detectors, and additional field signals on the São Paulo to Rio line;-  Safety initiatives: investments to protect existing rights-of-way with fences, construction of pedestrian and vehicular overpass bridges, and upgrading of level crossings and marshalling yards in metropolitan regions;-  New signaling system: upgrade of the central control and dispatch center in Juiz de Fora, installation of cab signals, onboard computers and digital voice/data radios on the existing locomotive fleet for real-time mobile communications; and-  Conveyor belt: the installation of a cable conveyor belt to transport iron ore on a portion of the 18 km, 10% grade stretch on the Santos to Jundiaí Line between Paranapiacaba (summit) and the COSIPA steel mill in Cubatão near the port of Santos.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category B project according to IFCs environmental and social review procedure because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  Environmental and social issues associated with this investment include:-  Rehabilitation of previously contaminated/degraded areas;-  Hazardous materials management;-  Air emissions;-  Operational safety and accident prevention;-  Maintenance-related effluents, emissions, and waste management;-  Employee health and safety;-  Irregular occupation of right-of-way;-  Community engagement and development;-  Cultural properties;-  Indigenous peoples; and-  Environmental management systems.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe Environmental Review Summary (ERS) is available on the companys web-site at www.mrs.com.br and at its principal offices between 9 a.m. and 12 p.m. at the following locations:Av. Project Description: Brait IV, L.P. (Brait IV or the Fund) is a private equity fund formed by Brait SA (Brait) and managed by Brait Capital Partners Limited (the Manager) with a target size of approximately $525 million which will make privately negotiated equity and equity-related investments primarily in entities (whether private or publicly traded) having primary business activities principally in South Africa.  The Funds primary objective is to achieve superior long-term capital appreciation through control investments (majority or significant minority) in a portfolio of commercial and industrial companies.  Target industries will include, but not be limited to, consumer products and services, healthcare, manufacturing, media and communications, and resources.  It is expected that Brait will continue to seek out Black Economic Empowerment (BEE) related opportunities which meet the investment and return criteria of Brait IV.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an FI type project.  Brait will be required to demonstrate that their Environmental Management System (EMS) is adequate to address the environmental and social issues for investments under the new Fund.  IFC will assess the adequacy of the Fund''s EMS.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: Brait SA (Brait) is a South African financial services company listed on the Luxembourg Stock Exchange.  Besides its core private equity operations with a team of 14 investment professionals, Brait also provides fund management and corporate finance services.  Since inception in 1991, the Brait private equity team has made 47 investments through 3 predecessor funds, of which 37 are fully realized.
Cost Nature: It is proposed that IFC invest up to $25 million, up to 20% of total commitments to the Fund.

Project Description: The project consists of: -  a partially convertible senior loan of up to $50 million to support the long-term lending activities of newly merged, United Bank of Africa (UBA), now the largest commercial bank in Nigeria in terms of total assets and; -  an IFC partial guarantee (PCG) amounting to approximately $25 million to support a local currency denominated bond offering for UBA to support its residential mortgage lending program.  The New UBA was formed as a result of an effective takeover of UBA by Standard Trust Bank (STB), the fifth largest bank in terms of assets in Nigeria. The merger which was announced in January, 2005 was approved by the regulators in July, 2005 .The merged entity now controls approximately $3 billion in assets (14% of the banking sector) and $360 million in shareholders equity.  The bank also has over 400 branches spread through out Nigeria.UBA intends to use the proceeds from IFCs term loan to: -  leverage its large equity base and -  to provide scarce funding to its corporate and SME clients for their capital expenditures. The $25 million PCG is expected to support up to Naira (N) 13 billion (approximately $100 million equivalent) issuance with a maturity of up to 10 years. The Naira proceeds of the issue are expected to be used mainly for the provision of mortgage loans to be originated by UBA.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an FI Type 1 project.  UBA will be required to develop an environmental management system to ensure that relevant operations meet host country environmental and social requirements.  Through the life of the investment, IFC will continue to evaluate UBAs capacity in this regard.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The new UBAs ownership structure is well diversified, with no single dominant shareholder.  It has over 140,000 shareholders and is one of the most actively traded shares on the Nigerian exchange.  Direct holdings by executive and senior management as well as the holding of an approved employee share ownership plan account for approximately 6% of the issued share capital. Foreign institutional investors consisting of Stanbic Nominees of Nigeria (5%) Deutsche Bank, (2%) and Banca Nazionale (1%) control approximately 9% of UBAs shares. The rest of the shareholder is widely held.
Cost Nature: IFCs investment in the proposed UBA project will consist of $50 million partially convertible loan and $25 million partial bond guarantee of a long-term Naira denominated bond to support UBAs mortgage residential lending activities.

Project Description:
Enercon India Ltd (EIL) is a joint-venture between Enercon Gmbh from Germany (56% share) and the Mehra family of Mumbai (44%). EIL's commercial operations started in 1995. The company is involved in the manufacturing, installation and services (O&M) of wind turbines in India. While the core business of EIL is to provide turn-key solutions for potential investors in wind power in India, the company also takes principal positions in some of the projects. EIL has wind projects in 8 high potential states in India. Enercon Gmbh is a technology leader in the industry and operates across 27 countries and manufactures from 5 of them (Germany, India, Brazil, Turkey and Sweden). As of April 2005, Enercon Gmbh has an installed capacity of 7.4 GW of wind power around the globe.

EIL is implementing CDM projects based on wind farms that are displacing fuel based generation in the regional grids in India (Karnataka and Rajasthan). The total installed capacity of the projects is presently 75 MW. The EIL project comprises many sub-projects (individual wind farms owned by several entities) of smaller capacities. These plants share common facilities within 2 wind parks managed by EIL. 

EIL owns 50% of the installed capacity in the Karnataka site (8.4 MW out of 16.8 MW) and 41% of the installed capacity in the Rajasthan site (24 MW out of 58.2 MW). EIL is aggregating all projects into a 'bundle' and plans to sell CERs from the bundle of wind projects to INCaF.
Environmental Social Issues:
This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The review of this project consisted of appraising technical and environmental/social information submitted by the project sponsor.  The following potential environment, health and safety and social impacts of the projects were analyzed. The review of this project consisted of appraising environmental and social information submitted by the project sponsor and site visits to EILs wind farm installations in Jaisalmer and turbine manufacturing facility at Daman.  The following potential environment, health and safety and social aspect of the project (s) were analyzed:site selection process used for existing and proposed new wind farms;environmental, social, and health and safety management systems;national and local permitting requirements;source and volumes of water required including efforts to minimize water use; source of power and energy, including fuel storage if applicable; air emissions and compliance with local and World Bank Group (WBG) emissions limits; ambient air quality and noise impacts on nearby receptors; recycling and treatment of process effluent and waste water; hazardous materials management; occupational health and safety programs and performance; fire and life safety and emergency response; minimization, recycling and disposal of solid and hazardous wastes;biodiversity conservation; involuntary resettlement and potential economic displacement;corporate social responsibility efforts, including HIV/AIDS awareness; andtimely reporting on environmental and social performance to IFC. Cost Nature: The value of INCaF's contract or emissions reductions purchase agreement to purchase CERs is expected to be in the range of  $ 7-8 million, payable in installments on annual delivery of CERs (generated through to the end of 2012) to the CDM registry account of the Netherlands.
Location:
Karnataka windfarm: The Jogimatti Wind Zone is situated in Chitradurga District in the State of Karnataka, India. Chitradurga is approximately 200 Km from Bangalore City, adjacent to the Bangalore  Mumbai highway. The JK Wind Zone, where the 16.8 MW windpark is located, has an annual mean wind speed (at 25 m height) of 31 Km/Hr and an annual mean wind power density of 582 W/m2.

Rajasthan windfarm:  The Jaisalmer Wind Zone is situated in Jaisalmer District, and includes 58.2 MW of the bundled 75 MW.  The recorded annual wind speed of Jaisalmer wind zone at 25 m is 17.8 Km/Hr with an annual mean wind power density of 159 W/m2.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati:
This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The review of this project consisted of appraising technical and environmental/social information submitted by the project sponsor.  The following potential environment, health and safety and social impacts of the projects were analyzed. The review of this project consisted of appraising environmental and social information submitted by the project sponsor and site visits to EILs wind farm installations in Jaisalmer and turbine manufacturing facility at Daman.  The following potential environment, health and safety and social aspect of the project (s) were analyzed:site selection process used for existing and proposed new wind farms;environmental, social, and health and safety management systems;national and local permitting requirements;source and volumes of water required including efforts to minimize water use; source of power and energy, including fuel storage if applicable; air emissions and compliance with local and World Bank Group (WBG) emissions limits; ambient air quality and noise impacts on nearby receptors; recycling and treatment of process effluent and waste water; hazardous materials management; occupational health and safety programs and performance; fire and life safety and emergency response; minimization, recycling and disposal of solid and hazardous wastes;biodiversity conservation; involuntary resettlement and potential economic displacement;corporate social responsibility efforts, including HIV/AIDS awareness; andtimely reporting on environmental and social performance to IFC. Project Description: The proposed transaction consists of a financing package of up to EUR 15 million to Nova Banka a.d., Bijeljina (Nova Banka or the Bank or company), a commercial bank in Bosnia and Herzegovina (BiH), operating predominantly in the less developed Republic of Srpska (RS). Alongside this financing, Nova Banka has requested IFC to consider supporting a technical assistance program involving training and consulting in specific areas to enable better service delivery to the Bank's retail and corporate clients. Profitable and well-positioned, Nova Banka plans to accelerate its growth with the requested funds and technical assistance through on-lending to private small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and to the consumer retail housing sector. The Bank is facing growing needs from both companies and consumers for long-term financing. As the economy of BiH is still in the early stage of transition, the country has much need for the development of its SMEs and its medium-low income households. Consequently, the project is expected to have a high developmental impact on BiH.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an environmental and social FI type 1 project. Nova Banka will be required to establish an environmental management system which is acceptable to IFC in order to ensure that its operations in lending to clients are in compliance with host country environmental and social requirements.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor: The project sponsor is Poteza Adriatic Fund B.V. (Poteza, or the Fund), an IFC existing portfolio private equity fund formed by Poteza Nalozbe d.o.o from Slovenia.  The Fund makes equity and equity-related investments in companies based in Southeastern Europe through majority or significant minority stakes. Its primary target countries for investment are Bosnia and Herzegovina, Croatia, Serbia, and Slovenia.  In June 2005, Poteza and a co-investor, Prva Pokojninska Druzba d.d., a pension insurance company based in Slovenia, acquired 50% + 1 share ownership of the Bank.  Poteza and its co-investor own 44.1% and 5.9% respectively of the Bank's share ownership. Other shareholders include local individuals and corporations such as Slobodan Radanovic (5.7%), Invest Nova d.o.o. (3.7%), and Goran Avlijas (3.4%).
Cost Nature: The proposed IFC financing package is for a total amount of EUR 15 million.
Investment: 18.15 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan12.30Equity5.86* These investment figures are indicative
Location: Nova Banka is a licensed commercial bank headquartered in Bijeljina, Bosnia and Herzegovina, with 11 branches and 58 outlets mainly in RS.

Project Description: Brunswick Rail Leasing (BRL Russia or the company) is a Russian registered company formed in 2003 to provide railcar operating leases in Russia and neighboring broad gauge countries.  BRLs business model is based on acquiring railcars and leasing them to large industrial or transport companies on a long-term operating lease basis.  The first stage of BRLs operating plan consists of purchasing approximately 10,000 railcars for a total cost of $500 million to serve clients with whom BRL has signed lease agreements or is in contract negotiations (the Project).  At the end of September 2005, BRL had purchased 3,060 railcars through the capital provided by its shareholders and is now seeking debt financing to fund the remainder of the project.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B Project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The review of this project consisted of appraising technical and environmental information submitted by the company.  The following potential environment, health and safety impacts of the projects were analyzed: -  hazardous materials management; -  emergency preparedness and response; -  maintenance-related effluent and waste management; and -  employee health and safety.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityEnvironmental documentation will be made available at the following location :Entrance foyerBashnya na PaveletzskayaPaveletzskaya Plashod 2/2Moscow 115054, Russia
Sponsor: BRL Russia is a wholly owned subsidiary of Brunswick Rail Leasing Bermuda (BRL Bermuda).  BRL Bermuda is owned 51.72% by Brunswick Leasing Limited (BLL), 19.16% by Sumitomo Corporation, and 29.12% by independent financial investors.  BLL is a subsidiary of Brunswick Investment Holdings Limited (BIHL), a holding company which has been active in Russias financial services sector since 1994.  BIHL is, through its subsidiary Brunswick Capital Limited (BCL), the former 50% owner of Brunswick UBS, a leading Russian investment bank.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is $500 million.  The project will be financed with between $130 million $160 million of equity and $350 million of debt.  IFC is expected to provide up to $45 million of financing for its own account, comprising approximately $35 million in the form of an IFC A Loan and the remainder in preferred equity in BRL Bermuda.

Project Description: Tout Transit Transport Cameroun (3T Cameroun) is a private limited partnership company operating in the business of road transportation and handling.  The company was incorporated in 1991 and current share capital is CFAF 250 million ($0.47 million).  The purpose of the project is to support the expansion of 3T Cameroun.  Part of the expansion plan has already been completed in September 2004 and includes the commissioning of the office building, and the acquisition of a forklift, five lorry-tractors and five trailers. The remaining part of the expansion plan involves the acquisition of the seven lorry-tractors and seven trailers, a spare engine and working capital. Total project cost for the entire expansion plan is estimated at Euro 2.14 million, Euro1.07 million (50%) of which is solicited from IFC in the form of a medium term loan.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project.  Key issues associated with this project include: site selection and land acquisition; power and water supply; fuel storage; waste management (including sewage, liquid, and solid waste); workshop management and housekeeping; truck maintenance standards; driver training and safety; general worker health and safety; and building fire safety.  The sponsor must also clearly define the type of goods to be carried and measures to ensure only authorized goods are transported.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe environmental documents will be located at the front desk in the company''s office in Douala, Cameroon.
Sponsor: The main shareholder is Mr. André Fotso (75.52%), a Cameroonian entrepreneur, while the other shareholders are also Cameroonian nationals not related to the sponsor, some of them sharing interest in FME Gaz, an industrial gas production and distribution business, majority owned by Mr. Fotso and also financed by IFC. Mr. FOTSO is presently chairman of Ecobank, one of the biggest banks in Cameroon, and also Vice President of GICAM, the largest and most influential business association in Cameroon.  He holds an MBA equivalent from the University of Lyon in France.
Cost Nature: Total project cost is estimated at Euro 2.14 million.  The proposed IFC Investment would be a Euro 1.07 million A loan for IFCs own account over a 7-year term.
Investment: 1.30 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoan1.30Equity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The company is located within the industrial zone adjacent to the port area of Douala. Douala is the economic capital of and the largest city in Cameroon.  The companys site is 4 kilometers away from the main port terminal where it performs handling, pick-ups and drop-offs services. Most clients are within a 5-to-10 kilometers range from the companys site.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a Category B project.  Key issues associated with this project include: site selection and land acquisition; power and water supply; fuel storage; waste management (including sewage, liquid, and solid waste); workshop management and housekeeping; truck maintenance standards; driver training and safety; general worker health and safety; and building fire safety.  The sponsor must also clearly define the type of goods to be carried and measures to ensure only authorized goods are transported.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe environmental documents will be located at the front desk in the company''s office in Douala, Cameroon.

Project Description: Turk Demir Dokum Fabrikalari A.S. (TDD or the Company) is a leading producer of heating appliances in Turkey with revenues of $379 million in 2004. International revenues accounted for approximately 40% of this amount. Its asset size was $283 million at the end of 2004. Founded in 1954, TDD is listed on the Istanbul Stock Exchange.  TDDs manufacturing facilities are located mainly in Inegol and Bozuyuk in Central Anatolia, Turkey.  The proposed project consists of: -  the expansion of TDDs panel radiator plant and combination boiler plants at Bozuyuk; -  the modernization and investments in new product development, including solar-energy powered water heating systems; and -  working capital, project contingencies and some debt refinancing for an estimated total cost of EUR55 million ($66 million).
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFCs Procedure for Environmental and Social Review of Projects because a limited number of specific environmental, worker health and safety (EHS), and social/community impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria.  The review of this project consisted of appraising technical, environmental, health and safety, social and community information submitted by the project sponsor as well as site visits to the Inegol and Bozuyuk plants   The following potential environment, health and safety (EHS) and social/community impacts of the projects were analyzed.-  The compliance of TDDs Bozuyuk plant with Turkish and IFC EHS requirements;-  The commitment of TDD to quality and efficiency and to EHS performance including international certifications;-  Labor, community and social issues. Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe companys website, the gates of the Bozuyuk and Inegol plants, Bozuyuk municipality house, local news papers.
Sponsor: The project will be implemented by TDD.Koc Group companies own 73.9% of TDDs shares, Taylan Holding owns 5.7%, and the remaining 20.4% is publicly owned. Founded in 1926, the Koc Group is one of Turkey''s leading diversified conglomerates with activities in the automotive, household appliances and electronics, financial services, food, retailing, energy, hospitality and information technology sectors.  The Group has a long history of cooperating with international firms as evidenced through joint ventures, as well as production and licensing agreements with companies like GE, Siemens, Whirlpool, LG Electronics, Fiat, and Ford.  At end-2004, the Koç Group comprised of 106 companies employing about 60,000 staff.  Koç Holding and 14 Koç Group company shares are traded on the Istanbul Stock Exchange.
Cost Nature: The project cost is estimated at approximately EUR55 million (US$66 million). The IFC financing is an A loan of EUR25 million for its own account.

The review of this project consisted of appraising technical, environmental, health and safety, social and community information submitted by the project sponsor as well as site visits to the Inegol and Bozuyuk plants   The following potential environment, health and safety (EHS) and social/community impacts of the projects were analyzed.-  The compliance of TDDs Bozuyuk plant with Turkish and IFC EHS requirements;-  The commitment of TDD to quality and efficiency and to EHS performance including international certifications;-  Labor, community and social issues. Project Description: LLC Savservice Center (Savservice Center or the company) is a Ukrainian company involved in the distribution, warehousing and logistics of fast-moving consumer goods.  Savservice Center carries out its activities under the trade names of Savservice, Komora-S through a network of 18 fully-owned subsidiaries, including 16 distribution companies present in 13 regions throughout Ukraine.To support its operations, the company owns and operates warehousing and logistics facility in Kyiv, maintains a fleet of leased and owned vans and employs approximately 2,400 people.  In addition, the company rents warehouse space from third parties both in Kyiv and throughout Ukraine.To respond to the booming demand for high-quality modern distribution, warehousing and logistics services in Ukraine, Savservice Center is implementing a capital investment program (the Project), which contemplates the construction of a new warehouse and customs terminal at the companys existing warehousing and logistics facility, the acquisition and renovation of a warehousing center near Kyiv, investments in vehicles and a management information system.
Environmental Social Issues: The review of this project consisted of appraising technical, environmental and social information submitted by the company and visiting the Kalynivka and Esma sites.  The following potential environment, health and safety and social impacts of the projects were analyzed.-  Environmental management procedures.-  Land acquisition and planning procedures;-  Emissions to air and water;-  Solid and hazardous materials management;-  Occupational health and safety, including fire protection and emergency response;The company has presented plans to address these impacts to ensure that the proposed project will upon implementation of the specific agreed measures, comply with the environmental and social requirements -  the host country laws and regulations and the World Bank/IFC environment and social policies and the environmental, health and safety guidelines.  The information about how these potential impacts will be addressed by the sponsor/project is summarized in the Environmental Review Summary (ERS).Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityEnvironmental documentation will be made available at the following location:Krasnova 27 street in Kiev.
Sponsor: The sponsor of the project is CJSC Asnova Holding (Asnova or the Sponsor), which fully owns the company.  Asnova was founded in 1992 and is currently owned by a group of 9 Ukrainian businessmen.  In addition to Savservice Center, Asnova is the owner of DC, a leading home care and personal care retail chain in Ukraine, as well as a number of other businesses most of which are involved in retail and/or distribution activities.
Cost Nature: The estimated cost of the project is approximately $18.5 million.  IFC is considering a $6 million A loan and a $2 million C loan to the company.

The Kalynivka site is located in an industrial zone in the vicinity of Kyiv at 5, Industrialna Street, Kalynivka, Kyiv Region.In addition to operations in Kyiv, the company has subsidiary distribution companies in Bila Tserkva, Dnipropetrovsk, Cherkasy, Chernigiv, Chernivtzi, Khmelnytzky, Lutzk, Lviv, Ivano-Frankivsk, Rivne, Ternopil, Uzhgorod and Zhytomyr.

Project Description: The proposed project consists of term financing to be provided by IFC to five ORIX Group Non Bank Financial Institutions (NBFIs) operating in the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) region all of whom are either current or previous IFC portfolio clients and have been established with the assistance of  IFC. These companies are ORIX Leasing Pakistan Limited (OLP), ORIX Investment Bank Pakistan Limited (OIBPL), Oman ORIX Leasing Company (OOLC), ORIX Leasing Egypt (OLE) and Saudi ORIX Leasing Company (SOLC). The proceeds of the financing will be on-lent by the borrowers predominantly to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in their respective markets in the form of leases or medium term loans.  The proposed aggregate amount of the program is expected to be  US$50 million, with a tenor of up to 8 years, including a grace period of up to 2 years.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an FI Type 1 project. The borrower will be required to develop an environmental management system. The borrowers must require that investments under relevant operations meet host country environmental, health and safety requirements. IFC will assess the borrower''s capacity for environmental review and will provide training as necessary.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community
Sponsor:
The major shareholders of the ORIX NBFI's in the MENA region are:

ORIX Corporation, Japan:
ORIX Corporation is an integrated financial services group based in Tokyo, Japan, providing innovative value-added products and services to both corporate and retail customers. It is listed on Tokyo and New York Stock Exchanges. With operations in 24 countries and regions worldwide, ORIX's activities include corporate financial services, such as leases and loans, as well as automobile operations, rental operations, real estate-related finance, real estate, life insurance and investment banking. By pursuing new profit earning opportunities through specialized leasing capabilities and broadening operational scope, ORIX has achieved sustained growth in earnings over the years. The Group reported per-tax profit of US$ 1.4 billion for the year ended March 31, 2005 and its asset base exceeded US$ 56.5 billion on that date.

ORIX Leasing Pakistan (OLP):  
OLP is the largest leasing operation in Pakistan. OLP has also been the regional hub for expansion of ORIX Corporation in MENA and Central Asia.  With PRs19 billion (US$ 317 million) in total assets, OLP is the largest and most diversified leasing company in Pakistan with assets spread over broad spectrum of industries, products, sizes and a diversified portfolio of over 3000 clients. The Company has also been consistently reporting strong profitability. For the quarter ended on 9/30/05, the company posted net profit of Prs.70 million (US$ 1.2 million), 11% higher than the net profit of PRs.63 million (US$ 1.0 million) earned in the corresponding period of 2004. 

ORIX Corporation, Japan holds 49.9% of OLP, whereas OLP and ORIX Corporation together have the following holdings in each of the proposed Company:

ORIX Investment Bank Pakistan Limited                         45.07%
ORIX Leasing Egypt                                                         46.00%
Oman ORIX Leasing                                                         20.25%
Saudi ORIX Leasing Company                                         30.00%

Project Description: The proposed project is to invest in a start-up pension administration company (AFORE) being set-up by Banco del Ahorro Nacional y Servicios Financieros (BANSEFI), a development finance institution in Mexico and the Mexican Savings and Loan Sector.  The AFOREs initial capitalization is estimated at up to MXN160 million ($15 million equivalent).  IFCs participation is expected to be up to 18% of total equity, or up to $3 million equivalent approximately.  Other international and domestic investors have also been invited to participate in the equity.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category C project according to IFC''s Environmental and Social Review Procedure, as minimal environmental and social impacts are expected in this project. The AFORE will be asked to screen its investments against Mexican environmental and social standards and IFC''s exclusion list.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The project sponsor is BANSEFI.  BANSEFI was set up in 2001 to deepen the Mexican financial system by spreading accessibility of basic financial services through facilitating the offering of products to segments of the population that are typically not served or are underserved by conventional financial intermediaries.  BANSEFI operates on the pillar of promoting savings among the poorer segments of the Mexican population, and serves as a supporting bank to savings and loans institutions that serve this sector, by assisting them in a variety of ways, including IT and technical advisory support.  It is responsible for coordinating the transformation of Mexicos savings and credit sector, targeted towards the social segment, into a formalized sector.  BANSEFI is currently wholly-owned by the Ministry of Treasury and Finance of Mexico; however, democratization of the institution is envisioned to ultimately disperse the ownership of BANSEFI.
Cost Nature: The AFOREs initial capitalization is estimated at up to MXN160 million ($15 million equivalent).   IFCs participation is expected to be up to 18% of total equity, or up to approximately $3 million equivalent.
Investment: 3.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity3.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: BANSEFI is headquartered in Mexico City.  It has a network of over 540 branches and serves approximately 3.2 million accounts.   More than half its branches are in areas that are minimally served or not served by the formal financial sector.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category C project according to IFC''s Environmental and Social Review Procedure, as minimal environmental and social impacts are expected in this project. Project Description:
Subject to due diligence, negotiations, and regulatory approval, IFC is considering an investment package of up to $50 million in Federal Bank's (the Bank). The investment package consists of the following:

-  a long-term loan to support SME lending operations, and 
-  a potential equity investment in the Bank. 

The Bank has been in existence for 74 years. It is currently the 6th largest private sector bank in India, and the largest scheduled commercial bank in the state of Kerala. The Bank is actively involved in the SME lending in Kerala.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an FI Type 1 project according to IFCs Environmental and Social Review Procedure.  The Bank will be required to:-  establish an environmental management system to ensure that activities financed under relevant operations are consistent with applicable environmental, occupational health and safety regulations of India,  -  designate appropriate individuals who will have responsibility for the environment and who will attend IFCs environmental management workshops or an approved equivalent, and - submit to IFC an environmental management plan and annual performance reports.Location of environmental documents in locally affected community

Company Name: FONDATION ARRAWAJ DE LA FINANCE INCLUSIVE
Project Description: The project involves IFC providing Foundation for Local Development and Partnership (FONDEP or the company) with a comprehensive developmental financing and technical assistance package that will complement the companys strong growth potential and expansion plans in the coming years.FONDEP is a microfinance institution operating in Morocco.  It began its microfinance activities in 1997, targeting rural and semi-urban regions in Morocco by providing solidarity group lending.  Since its inception in 1996, FONDEP has built a loan portfolio of MAD 41 million as at end of August 2005 divided among more than 25,000 borrowers.The project has two components:  -  a Partial Credit Guarantee Facility (the Guarantee) to enable the company to source much-  needed local currency financing from local banks, and -  and a technical assistance package (TA) to develop the companys internal controls and risk management system, and strengthen its human resources function.  Moreover, the TA is aimed at enabling the company to reinforce its operations and management structure to pre-empt its eventual transformation into a non-bank financial institution.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an FI type 1 microfinance project.  FONDEP will be required to apply IFC''s microfinance exclusion list and develop appropriate procedures to ensure that its borrowers are in compliance with any applicable host country environmental requirements.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: FONDEP was established in 1996 as a nonprofit nongovernmental organization (NGO) dedicated to the provision of credit facilities to micro-entrepreneurs in urban and semi-urban areas in Morocco.  The company aims at integrating disadvantaged individuals, particularly women and unemployed youth, into the economic and productive sectors in the country, by extending micro-credit facilities to finance revenue-generating micro-projects and businesses.  FONDEPs mission aims at enhancing the livelihoods of individuals and economic groups who have no formal access to credit services.FONDEP is also engaged in social services such as literacy and micro-entrepreneurial training campaigns, aimed at sensitizing disadvantaged economic groups to the fundamentals of enterprise and business creation.As FONDEP is organized as an NGO, it relies primarily on donor funding and long-term debt to finance its lending activities.
Cost Nature: The Guarantee Facility is intended to cover up to 50% of up to MAD 60 million worth of credit lines extended by local commercial banks over the course of two years.  The Guarantee Facility will partially cover the principal and interest payments and is expected to have a tenor of up to ten years.The Guarantee is intended to help FONDEP build its credit history among the local creditor institutions.
Investment: 3.34 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuarantee3.34LoanEquity* These investment figures are indicative
Location: FONDEPs head office is based in Rabat, Morocco.  The company has 41 branch offices located across the country.
Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is an FI type 1 microfinance project.  FONDEP will be required to apply IFC''s microfinance exclusion list and develop appropriate procedures to ensure that its borrowers are in compliance with any applicable host country environmental requirements.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community

Project Description: The project is the construction of a greenfield ceramic tile plant, CJSC Zeus Ceramica (Zeus or the Company), with a total annual production capacity of 4.3 million square meters of porcelain (ceramic granite) tiles in Slavyansk, Donetsk region in Ukraine.  The Project is being implemented in two phases.  The first phase (Phase I), the construction and installation of the companys first line with an annual production capacity of 2.0 million square meters, was completed in March 2005.  The second phase (Phase II), the installation of another line with a capacity of 2.3 million square meters, is expected to be completed in the first quarter of 2007.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category B project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure. Environmental and social issues which may be associated with this type of project, and which will be assessed during project appraisal, include: site selection and land acquisition process including any associated resettlement or economic displacement, sustainable raw material supply, fuel selection and air emission control, wastewater treatment, handling of solid wastes and hazardous materials (including glazes and pigments), energy efficiency, development of environmental and health & safety management programs, and employment creation.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityThe environmental documents are available at the companys administrative office at the following address: 7 Goncharnaya St., Slavyansk, Donetsk Region, Ukraine.
Sponsor: The company is a joint venture between CJSC Yuzhno-Oktiabrskie Gliny Yug (YUG) (26%) and Emilceramica S.p.A. (EC) (74%) (collectively, the Sponsors).  YUG is a Ukrainian supplier of clay and kaolin, key raw materials in the production of ceramic tiles. It was started in the early 1990s as a result of the privatization of several entities, including clay and kaolin quarries.  EC:  Founded in 1961 by an Italian family in Modena, the center of the Italian ceramic industry, EC is the main entity of the industrial group Speranza S.p.A. (Speranza or the Group). The Group comprises companies involved in the manufacturing of ceramic tiles (flooring and wall tiles and special pieces), in subcontracting for the ceramics industry and in the quarrying and processing of raw materials. EC, together with its subsidiaries, is the 7th largest tile producer in Italy.
Cost Nature: The total project cost is estimated at $44 million. The company has requested an IFC loan of up to $8 million.

Project Description: PSL Limited is Indias largest manufacturer of high-grade large diameter (18-120 inches) Helical Submerged Arc Welded (HSAW) pipes for oil, gas and water transmission as well as structural and piling applications for the onshore and offshore sectors.  PSL supplies its pipes, which are certified to meet American Petroleum Institute (API) standards, to all the leading Indian oil and gas companies and state government agencies involved in the management of water and sanitation services in India.  PSL also exports large diameter pipes to neighboring countries. To better address the needs of the rapidly growing market for SAW pipes and to improve its cost competitiveness, PSL is embarking on a $ 119.4 million investment program (the Project) which is detailed under the section entitled, Total Project Cost and Proposed IFC Investment below.The purpose of the project is to: -  meet the needs for the rapidly growing market for HSAW pipes, -  improve cost competitiveness, -  increase productivity and -  enhance product quality.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a Category B project according to IFC''s environmental and social review procedure because a limited number of specific environmental and social impacts may result which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to generally recognized performance standards, guidelines or design criteria. The environmental and social issues associated with this project which were assessed during the appraisal were corporate environmental, social, and occupational health and safety management systems; compliance with local and national environmental and occupational health and safety laws; land acquisition for the new production facilities and physical or economic resettlement if applicable; source of  power, including fuel storage if applicable; air emissions from existing and new sources; ambient air quality and noise impacts on nearby receptors; handling and storage of hazardous materials; minimization, recycling and disposal of solid and hazardous wastes; fire and life safety and emergency response;  and employee relations and retrenchment.Location of environmental documents In locally affected communityEnvironmental documentation will be made available at the following location:PSL Towers615, Makwana Road Marol, Andheri (E) Mumbai  400 059
Sponsor: Mr. Ashok Punj is the Managing Director and the main Sponsor of the Company. He has a Bachelors degree and a Masters degree in engineering from the Illinois Institute of Technology located in Chicago, Illinois. Mr. Punj has over 20 years experience in setting up industrial enterprises in diverse fields and managing them successfully.On 30th Sept 2005, the promoters (Mr. Punj and his family) and affiliated companies held 71% of the Companys equity and the balance of 29% was held by non promoters, including mutual funds, bank, FIIS, NRIs, the general public, etc.
Cost Nature: Details of the project cost are given on the attachment found below:IFC is exploring possible cooperation with the company to finance part of the project.

Location: The project is proposed to be located at the companys facilities at the following locations:-  Anjar, in the state of Gujarat, is an industrial/port city about 850 km north of Mumbai on the main Western railway line.  The plant site is 22 km from the main Gandhidham Railway station and is linked to the countrys large railway network.  Anjar is also well connected by road, as it is on one of the major north-south national highways, giving the company additional logistical flexibility.-  Mehsana, in the Indian state of Gujarat, 35 km from Ahemdabad an industrial cum port city about 550 km north of Mumbai on the Western railway line. The plant site is 20 km from the Railway station. It is well connected by train to both Delhi and Chennai. The plant site is 7 km from the main railway line and is linked to the countrys large railway network. It is well connected by road, as it is on one of the major east-south National Highways, giving the company additional logistical flexibility. -  Panipat, in the Indian State of Punjab, is about 100 km north of Delhi railway line, is well connected to Delhi by road and railways. -  Daman, is a union territory about 200 km north west of Mumbai on the main Western railway line, is well connected by 3 hours by train to Vapi (industrial city of Indian state of Gujarat). The plant site is 2-3 km from the main Railway station at Vapi, The nearest airport is about 150 km away at Diu, Daman.-  Pipavav, Distt. The plant site is 10 km from the main Rajula Railway station and is linked to the countrys large railway network. The nearest airport is about 150 km away at Diu, Pipava.

Project Description: The project involves an IFC investment of up to $2 million for shareholding of up to 19% in Lok Investments or the company, a limited liability company established under the laws of Mauritius, whose investment objective will be to provide social impact capital in the form of equity and debt to qualifying micro finance institutions (MFIs) in India. The company will be the first India-focused microfinance venture tied to an advisory service provider managed by local professionals, with a significant on-the-ground presence, capable of making long-term equity investments in, and delivering effective non-financial  technical assistance to MFIs in India.  The decision to establish the company in Mauritius was driven by the need to make the investment structure as cost effective as possible and also allow the project sponsors to take advantage of the tax treaty established between India and Mauritius. The proposed investment aims to increase the penetration rates of micro credit in India by enhancing the volume of loans made by financial institutions to micro borrowers. The project has three underlying objectives:-  to act as a catalyst for directing private capital to MFIs in India; -  to fund and provide long term management and technical support to these MFIs; and -  -  to act as a platform for disseminating knowledge and supporting initiatives aimed at empowering the rural poor, especially women.
Environmental Social Issues: This is an FI type 1 project. The company will commit to appoint a management person to act as its environmental advisor and to designate staff who will participate in an environmental capacity-building exercise. The company will further need to ensure that each of its investee institutions will maintain an environmental management system to assess that relevant operations comply with applicable host country standards and IFCs Microfinance Exclusion List, and to submit to IFC annual environmental performance reports providing a summary of annual environmental performance reports from its investee institutions.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: The main sponsor for this project is Lok Foundation, Inc., a New York based, not-for-profit corporation. The Foundation is to be a receptacle for mobilizing capital from social investors, both institutional and individual, that are willing to participate as Members and entrust the Foundation with the task of directing/managing technical assistance to MFIs in India.  These funds will be deployed through Lok Advisory service (LAS), a New Delhi based Services Company intended to facilitate the investment activities of the company.  The companys investment activities will be supported by LAS management team which will be overseen by the Lok Foundations directors, Rajiv B. Lall, Vijay Advani and Donald Peck, each of whom will also serve as executive officers to the Foundation.   Rajiv B. Lall will act as the Chairman of the Foundation.  Vijay Advani will act as the President of the Foundation and together with Rajiv B. Lall will be responsible for raising funds from social investors who may want to participate as donors to the Foundation.  Donald Peck will act as the Treasurer of the Foundation, will act as advisor to LAS and manage its investment and portfolio activities.  The investment decisions of the company will be made by a three person Investment Committee and the Board of the company. Potential shareholders for this investment include: IFC and other development focused banks and organizations.
Cost Nature: IFC will invest up to $2 million for a shareholding of up to 19%.  The company will aim to liquidate its investment holding over a period of 10 years to allow for further use of funds. The initial capital is expected to be at least $12 million with IFCs disbursements staggered to match the growth of the company.
Investment: 2.0 million (USD)Product LineIFC Investment (million USD)Risk ManagementGuaranteeLoanEquity2.0* These investment figures are indicative
Location: The company will be based in Mauritius but all investments will be made in MFIs based in India.

The company will commit to appoint a management person to act as its environmental advisor and to designate staff who will participate in an environmental capacity-building exercise. The company will further need to ensure that each of its investee institutions will maintain an environmental management system to assess that relevant operations comply with applicable host country standards and IFCs Microfinance Exclusion List, and to submit to IFC annual environmental performance reports providing a summary of annual environmental performance reports from its investee institutions.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community

Project Description: The project consists of a senior loan of up to $10 million for on-lending to small- and medium-sized companies, an equity investment of up to $20 million, and a trade finance facility of up to $5 million to LOCKO-Bank (LOCKO-Bank or the Bank), a medium-sized Moscow based bank specializing in lending to SMEs. IFC financing would support the Banks strategy, recognize its commitment to improving corporate governance standards, and increase its ability to offer longer-term loans to SME clients.
Environmental Social Issues: This is a category FI Type 1 project. The project would need to ensure that its investments are in compliance with the Environmental, Health Safety and Social requirements of the Russian Federation and establish and implement an Environmental Management System to the satisfaction of IFC to achieve this. The project is required to appoint an Environmental Manager and Environmental Coordinator, and to provide IFC an annual environmental performance report (AEPR) as per a format provided by IFC.Location of environmental documents In locally affected community
Sponsor: LOCKO-Bank is beneficially owned by 10 individuals, each owning a less than 20% stake. The largest stakes are maintained by Messrs Stanislav Boguslavsky, Andrey Kulikov, Vladimir Davydik, Victor Davydik and Leonid Zayonts. Mr. Boguslavsky chairs the Banks Board of Directors and Mr. Victor Davydik heads the Executive Board.
Cost Nature: The project is to provide a $10 million senior loan to the Bank for on-lending to small and medium enterprises of Moscow and the Moscow region, and in other regional centers of Russia, an equity investment of up to $20 million, and a trade finance facility of up to $5 million.

Environmental Social Categorization Rati: This is a category FI Type 1 project.
